Ketubot



Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A virgin is married on Wednesday and a widow on Thursday.</b> The reason for the former is <b>that twice a week courts convene in the towns, on Monday and Thursday,</b> so <b>that if</b> the husband <b>had a claim concerning</b> the bride’s <b>virginity</b> when consummating the marriage on Wednesday night, <b>he would go early</b> the next day <b>to court</b> and make his claim.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Due to what</b> reason <b>did they say that a virgin is married on Wednesday?</b> It is <b>because we learned</b> in a mishna elsewhere (57a): <b>If the time</b> that the groom designated for the wedding <b>arrived,</b> and the wedding was postponed, <b>and they were not married,</b> the brides are entitled to <b>eat from his</b> food <b>and,</b> if he is a priest, <b>eat <i>teruma</i>.</b>
<b>One might think</b> that if the designated <b>time arrived on Sunday,</b> and the wedding was postponed, <b>he would provide her sustenance</b> beginning on Sunday. <b>Therefore, we learned: A virgin is married on Wednesday.</b> Until Wednesday, the designated time is not considered to have arrived, even if the original date was earlier in the week.
After citing the statements above, <b>Rav Yosef said</b> in astonishment: <b>Lord of Abraham,</b> Shmuel <b>makes</b> that which <b>is taught dependent on</b> that which <b>is not taught,</b> using the latter to explain the former. The Gemara asks: <b>Which is taught and which is not taught?</b> Both <b>this</b> mishna <b>is taught</b> and <b>that</b> mishna <b>is taught.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> Shmuel <b>makes</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>is taught</b> in the mishna here, <b>whose reason is explicit, dependent on</b> a <i>halakha</i> that <b>is taught</b> in the later mishna, <b>whose reason is not explicit.</b> Citation of the later mishna contributed nothing to the understanding of the mishna here.
<b>Rather, if it was stated, this</b> is how <b>it was stated: Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Due to what</b> reason <b>did</b> the Sages in the mishna <b>say</b> that <b>a virgin is married on Wednesday?</b> It is so <b>that if</b> the husband <b>had a claim concerning</b> the bride’s <b>virginity, he would go early</b> the next day <b>to court</b> and make his claim. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if that is the reason, <b>let her marry on Sunday, as</b> then too, <b>if</b> the husband <b>had a claim concerning</b> the bride’s <b>virginity, he would go early</b> the next day <b>to court</b> and make his claim. The Gemara answers: The <b>Sages were assiduous in seeing to the well-being of Jewish women</b> and instituted that the wedding take place on Wednesday, <b>so that</b> the groom <b>would exert</b> himself <b>in</b> arranging <b>the</b> wedding <b>feast for three days: Sunday, Monday, and Tuesday, and on Wednesday, he marries her.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>And now that we learned</b> that the reason for the ruling in the mishna that a woman is married on Wednesday is that the Sages <b>were assiduous</b> in this matter, then with regard to <b>that</b> <i>halakha</i>, <b>which we learned</b> in the later mishna: <b>If the time arrived and they were not married,</b> the brides are entitled to <b>eat from his</b> food <b>and eat <i>teruma</i>,</b> one may conclude: <b>If</b> the <b>time arrived on Sunday, since</b> he is <b>unable to marry</b> her because he is busy preparing the wedding feast, <b>he is not obligated to provide her sustenance</b> until Wednesday.
<b>Therefore,</b> according to the same line of reasoning, if the husband <b>fell ill, or if</b> the bride <b>fell ill, or</b> in a case <b>where she began to menstruate [<i>peirsa nidda</i>]</b> and the wedding had to be postponed, he similarly need <b>not provide her sustenance</b> from the designated time, as he did not initiate the delay.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who raised it as a dilemma: If</b> the groom <b>fell ill, what is</b> the ruling with regard to his obligation to provide her sustenance? <b>There,</b> in the case where the designated time arrived on Sunday, <b>what is the reason</b> that he is exempt? It is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he was forced</b> to postpone the wedding by circumstances beyond his control. <b>And here too, isn’t he forced</b> by circumstances beyond his control, and he should therefore be exempt? <b>Or, perhaps</b> there is a distinction between the cases. <b>There, he was forced by an ordinance that was instituted by the Sages</b> that a virgin marries on Wednesday, and they exempted him from providing for her until then. <b>However, here,</b> that is <b>not</b> the case. Therefore, despite the existence of circumstances beyond his control, he is not exempt from providing her sustenance due to his illness.
<b>And if you say that if he fell ill, he provides her sustenance</b> at the time designated for the wedding, then <b>if she fell ill, what is</b> the ruling? <b>Can he say to her: I am standing here</b> prepared to wed you, and if you are not prepared, it is not my fault? <b>Or perhaps she can say to him that his field was inundated,</b> i.e., her illness is tantamount to a natural disaster that befell him, and he must nevertheless provide for her.
<b>And if you say that</b> if she fell ill <b>she</b> can <b>say to him that his field was inundated,</b> if <b>she became a menstruating woman</b> and the wedding was postponed, <b>what is</b> the ruling? Is this too considered an unavoidable circumstance, like illness, and he must provide for her, or was this predictable?
If she began menstruating <b>at the time of her set period [<i>vista</i>], do not raise the dilemma,</b>

Daf 2b

<b>as</b> it is clear that <b>she cannot say to him</b> that <b>his field was inundated.</b> Here, the circumstances were avoidable, and postponement of the wedding is attributable to her. <b>When you</b> should <b>raise a dilemma</b> is in a case where menstruation began <b>not at the time of her set period. What</b> is the ruling there? <b>Since it is not the time of her set period,</b> it is comparable to the case of her illness, and <b>she can say to him that his field was inundated. Or, perhaps since there are some women whose set period changes,</b> it is avoidable, and its legal status <b>is like</b> menstruation at <b>the time of her set period,</b> and postponement of the wedding is attributable to her.
<b>Rav Aḥai resolved</b> these dilemmas through a careful reading of the mishna: <b>If the time arrived and they were not married,</b> the brides are entitled to <b>eat from his</b> food <b>and eat <i>teruma</i>. It doesn’t teach: And</b> the grooms <b>didn’t marry,</b> in the active form. <b>Rather,</b> it teaches: <b>And</b> the brides <b>were not married,</b> in the passive form.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> described in the phrase: They were not married? <b>If the</b> brides <b>postpone</b> the marriage, <b>why do they eat from his</b> food <b>and eat <i>teruma</i>? Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where they were compelled</b> by circumstances beyond their control <b>in that manner,</b> e.g., the bride falling ill or beginning to menstruate, <b>and it teaches:</b> The brides <b>eat from his</b> food <b>and eat <i>teruma</i>,</b> and his bad fortune is responsible for his situation.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Actually, I will say to you: In any</b> case <b>of unavoidable circumstances,</b> whether they affect him or they affect her, <b>she doesn’t eat</b> from his food, <b>and</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> grooms <b>postpone the wedding. And by right,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have taught: They didn’t marry,</b> which would have established that grooms caused the postponement. <b>And since</b> the <i>tanna</i> taught <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna cited above <b>in</b> terms of a bride: The Sages give a virgin twelve months, <b>it taught the latter clause in</b> terms of a bride. Therefore, no inference may be drawn from the formulation of the latter clause. Only if the groom postpones the wedding is he obligated to provide sustenance for the women when the time designated for the wedding arrives.
<b>Rava said: And</b> although delays caused by circumstances beyond his control exempt the groom from providing support to his betrothed at the time originally designated for the wedding, with regard <b>to bills of divorce that is not so. Apparently, Rava maintains that unavoidable circumstances</b> have <b>no</b> legal standing with regard <b>to bills of divorce.</b> If one stipulated that the bill of divorce will take effect only with the fulfillment of a condition, even if that condition was fulfilled due to circumstances beyond his control, the bill of divorce takes effect.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where does Rava</b> learn <b>this</b> principle? <b>If we say it is from that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 76b) with regard to one who said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce, if I do not return from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months, and he died within</b> those <b>twelve months,</b> the document <b>is not a bill of divorce.</b> Therefore, if she has no children from her deceased husband, the <i>halakhot</i> of levirate marriage would apply to her. The Gemara infers: If <b>he died,</b> that <b>is when it is not a bill of divorce,</b> since a divorce cannot take effect posthumously. By inference, in cases involving other circumstances beyond his control, e.g., if <b>he fell ill,</b> and therefore did not return, <b>it is a bill of divorce</b> and it takes effect. Apparently, if the reason for his failure to arrive is a circumstance beyond his control, the divorce takes effect.
The Gemara refutes that proof. <b>And perhaps, actually I will say to you</b> that in the case where <b>he falls ill it is also not a bill of divorce,</b> and the mishna cited the case of death merely as an example of circumstances beyond his control. <b>And</b> the reason <b>that</b> example <b>itself</b> was chosen is <b>to teach us that there is no bill of divorce posthumously.</b> Even if the divorce is not conditional, and the husband simply states that it will take effect after he dies, it is not a valid bill of divorce.
The Gemara asks: Does it come to teach that <b>there is no bill of divorce posthumously? Wasn’t it</b> already <b>taught in the first clause</b> of the mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 72a) that if one on his deathbed said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce if I die,</b> or: <b>This is your bill of divorce</b> if I die <b>from this illness,</b> or: <b>This is your bill of divorce after I die, he said nothing.</b> The bill of divorce does not take effect after his death.
The Gemara answers: <b>Perhaps</b> it was necessary for the first clause to mention specifically the case of death, <b>to exclude that which our Rabbis</b> said and not to exclude the case of one who fell ill, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And our Rabbis permitted her to remarry,</b> in a case where he died within the twelve months that he stipulated. <b>And we said: Who are our Rabbis</b> mentioned here? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> It is <b>the court that permitted</b> the <b>oil</b> of gentiles for consumption. In this regard, <b>they hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, who said: The time</b> written <b>in a document proves</b> when <b>it</b> takes effect. The fact that a certain date is written in the bill of divorce indicates that one’s intention was that the divorce take effect from the day that it was written and delivered, not after his death. In any event, there is proof neither for nor against Rava’s opinion from this <i>baraita</i>.
<b>And rather,</b> proof may be cited from the <b>latter clause</b> of the mishna. If a man says to his wife: This is your bill of divorce <b>from now if I do not return from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months, and he died within</b> those <b>twelve months, this</b> document <b>is a bill of divorce.</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> in a case where <b>he dies,</b> and <b>the same is true</b> if <b>he fell ill.</b> If the divorce takes effect when his failure to return is attributable to death, the ultimate circumstance beyond his control, all the more so should it take effect if it is attributable to a less extreme circumstance.
The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>Perhaps</b> the divorce takes effect <b>specifically</b> in the case where <b>he died,</b> because <b>he is not amenable</b> to have his wife <b>happen before</b> her <b><i>yavam</i>,</b> his brother, if he had no children. However, if other circumstances beyond his control caused the condition to be fulfilled, where levirate marriage is not a consideration, his intention is that the bill of divorce will not take effect.
<b>Rather,</b> proof may be cited <b>from this</b> case, <b>where a certain</b> man <b>who said to</b> the agents with whom he entrusted the bill of divorce: <b>If I do not return from now until after thirty days</b> have passed, <b>let this be a bill of divorce. He came at the end of thirty days,</b> before the deadline passed, <b>but was prevented</b> from crossing the river <b>by the ferry</b> that was located on the other side of the river, so he did not come within the designated time. <b>He said to the</b> people across the river: <b>See that I have come, see that I have come. Shmuel said:</b> This <b>is not considered</b> to be <b>a return.</b> Apparently, even if the condition was fulfilled due to circumstances beyond his control, the condition is considered fulfilled.
The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>And perhaps unavoidable circumstances that are common</b> and could be anticipated, e.g., the ferry is located at the other side of the river, <b>are different, since he should have stipulated</b> that exception when establishing the condition, <b>and he did not stipulate</b> it, <b>he brought the failure</b> to arrive <b>upon himself.</b> Although he regrets it now, at the time his intent was that even if the condition were fulfilled due to that circumstance, the divorce would take effect. In contrast, however, if the condition is fulfilled due to an uncommon circumstance that could not have been anticipated, the divorce would not take effect.
<b>Rather, Rava is stating</b> a <i>halakha</i> based on <b>his own reasoning.</b> Circumstances beyond one’s control are not a factor in determining whether or not a condition is fulfilled, and this is <b>due to virtuous women and due to licentious women.</b> The Gemara articulates: There is concern <b>due to virtuous women</b>, <b>as, if you said: Let it not be a bill of divorce,</b> if the reason that the condition was not fulfilled was due to circumstances beyond his control,

Daf 3a

then <b>sometimes, where he was not</b> detained <b>unavoidably</b> but he fulfilled the condition willingly to effect the divorce, <b>and</b> the wife <b>thinks</b> that he was detained <b>unavoidably, she will sit deserted,</b> forever unable to remarry. <b>And</b> the concern <b>due to licentious women</b> is, <b>as, if you said: Let it not be a bill of divorce,</b> then <b>sometimes, when he was</b> detained <b>unavoidably and she thinks</b> that he was <b>not</b> detained <b>unavoidably,</b> she goes <b>and remarries. And</b> the result will be <b>that the bill of divorce is void, and her children</b> from the second marriage will be <b><i>mamzerim</i>,</b> products of an adulterous relationship.
The Gemara questions the following premise: By Torah law, a condition that is unfulfilled due to circumstances beyond one’s control is considered fulfilled, and it is merely by rabbinic ordinance that it is deemed unfulfilled: <b>And is there a matter where by Torah</b> law <b>it is not a bill of divorce, but due to virtuous women and due to licentious women we permit a married woman to others?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> it is within the authority of the Sages to institute an ordinance freeing the woman from the marriage, as <b>anyone who betroths</b> a woman, <b>betroths</b> her contingent <b>upon the agreement of the Sages,</b> and in certain cases, such as those mentioned above, <b>the Sages invalidated his betrothal</b> retroactively.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> That <b>works out well</b> if <b>he betrothed</b> her <b>with money,</b> as in that case, the courts could declare the money ownerless, and one cannot betroth a woman with money that is not his. However, if <b>he betrothed</b> her <b>with intercourse, what can be said?</b> Rav Ashi answered: <b>The Sages rendered his intercourse licentious intercourse.</b>
<b>Some say,</b> to the contrary, that <b>Rava said:</b> Just as with regard to postponement of a wedding due to circumstances beyond his control, the groom is not obligated to provide sustenance for his betrothed, <b>the same is true with regard to the matter of bills of divorce.</b> The Gemara concludes that <b>apparently Rava maintains: Unavoidable circumstances</b> have legal standing <b>with regard to bills of divorce.</b>
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 76b): With regard to one who said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce if I do not return from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months, and he died within</b> those <b>twelve months,</b> the document <b>is not a bill of divorce.</b> The Gemara infers: If <b>he died,</b> that <b>is when it is not a bill of divorce,</b> since a divorce cannot take effect posthumously. However, in cases involving other circumstances beyond his control, e.g., if <b>he fell ill</b> and therefore did not return, <b>it is a bill of divorce</b> and it does take effect.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually, I will say to you</b> that in the case where <b>one falls ill it is also not a bill of divorce,</b> and death is merely an example of circumstances beyond one’s control. <b>And</b> the fact that the mishna cited <b>that</b> example <b>itself teaches us that there is no bill of divorce posthumously.</b>
The Gemara asks: Does it come to teach that <b>there is no bill of divorce posthumously? Wasn’t it already taught in the first clause</b> of that mishna? The Gemara answers: <b>Perhaps</b> it was necessary for the first clause to mention specifically the case of death, <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of our Rabbis.</b>
<b>Come and hear</b> an additional proof from the latter clause of that mishna: If one said: This is your bill of divorce <b>from now if I have not returned from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months, and he died within</b> those <b>twelve months,</b> then <b>this</b> document <b>is a bill of divorce. What, is it not that the same is true</b> if his failure to return is due to the fact that <b>he fell ill?</b> The Gemara rejects that proof. The divorce takes effect <b>specifically</b> in the case where <b>he died,</b> and he wrote the bill of divorce because <b>he was not amenable</b> to have his wife <b>happen before</b> her <b><i>yavam</i>,</b> his brother, for levirate marriage if he had no children. However, in cases where that is not a consideration, if other circumstances beyond his control caused the condition to be fulfilled, his intention is that the bill of divorce will not take effect.
<b>Come and hear</b> an additional proof <b>from</b> the case of <b>a certain</b> man <b>who said to</b> the agents with whom he entrusted the bill of divorce: <b>If I do not return from now until thirty days</b> have passed, <b>let this be a bill of divorce. He came at the end of thirty days,</b> before the deadline passed, <b>but was prevented</b> from crossing the river <b>by the ferry</b> that was located on the other side of the river, so he did not come within the designated time. <b>He said to the</b> people across the river: <b>See that I have come, see that I have come. Shmuel said:</b> It <b>is not considered</b> to be <b>a return.</b> Apparently, even if the condition was fulfilled due to circumstances beyond his control, the condition is considered fulfilled.
The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>Perhaps unavoidable circumstances that are common</b> and could be anticipated, e.g., the ferry being located at the other side of the river, <b>are different, since he should have stipulated</b> that exception when giving his wife the bill of divorce. <b>And</b> since he did not <b>stipulate</b> it, <b>he brought the failure upon himself.</b>
§ <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The Sages <b>teach</b> that this <i>halakha</i> that a virgin is married on Wednesday is in effect <b>only from</b> the institution of <b>the ordinance of Ezra that courts are in regular session only on Monday and Thursday. However, prior to</b> the institution of <b>the ordinance of Ezra, when courts</b> were in <b>regular</b> session <b>every day, a woman was married on any day</b> of the week.
The Gemara asks: <b>Prior to</b> the institution of <b>the ordinance of Ezra? What was</b> in the past <b>was</b> in the past. There are no halakhic ramifications to that statement. The Gemara answers: <b>This is what</b> Rav Shmuel bar Yitzḥak <b>is saying: If there are courts</b> in <b>regular</b> daily session <b>today, as</b> they were <b>prior to</b> the institution of <b>the ordinance of Ezra, a woman is married on any day</b> of the week.
The Gemara asks: <b>Don’t we require</b> the additional reason that a virgin is married on Wednesday because the Sages <b>were assiduous</b> in seeing to the well-being of Jewish women and made certain that the groom would have several days to prepare for the wedding feast prior to the wedding? The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case <b>where he</b> already <b>exerted himself</b> and prepared everything before Shabbat, so the feast will be prepared even if the wedding is Sunday or Monday.

Daf 3b

The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: The Sages <b>were assiduous?</b> It is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Due to what</b> reason <b>did</b> the Sages in the mishna <b>say</b> that <b>a virgin is married on Wednesday?</b> It is so <b>that if</b> the husband <b>had a claim concerning</b> the bride’s <b>virginity, he would go early</b> the next day <b>to court</b> and make his claim. The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>But</b> if that is the reason, <b>let her marry on Sunday, as</b> then too, <b>if</b> the husband <b>had a claim concerning</b> the bride’s <b>virginity, he would go early</b> the next day <b>to court</b> and make his claim. The Gemara answers: The Sages <b>were assiduous in seeing to the well-being of Jewish women</b> and preferred Wednesday, <b>so that</b> the husband <b>would exert</b> himself <b>in</b> arranging <b>the</b> wedding <b>feast for three days, Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, and on Wednesday, he marries her.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And from</b> the time of <b>danger and onward, the people adopted the custom to marry on Tuesday</b> as well, <b>and the Sages did not reprimand them. And on Monday one may not marry</b> even in time of danger. <b>However, if it is due to the coercion,</b> it is <b>permitted.</b> The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>One isolates the groom from the</b> virgin <b>bride,</b> so that he will not engage in intercourse with her for the <b>first</b> time <b>on Shabbat evening, because</b> by rupturing the hymen <b>he inflicts a wound,</b> which is a labor prohibited on Shabbat.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>What is</b> the <b>danger</b> mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>? <b>If we say</b> it is referring to a situation where the government <b>said that a virgin who is married on Wednesday will be executed,</b> would the response be merely <b>that they adopted the custom</b> to marry on Tuesday? <b>Let them</b> totally <b>abolish</b> the ordinance to marry on Wednesday in the face of life-threatening danger.
<b>Rabba said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a period where the government <b>said that a virgin who is married on Wednesday will</b> submit to <b>intercourse with the prefect [<i>hegmon</i>] first.</b> The Gemara questions the formulation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Is that</b> characterized as <b>danger? It is coercion.</b> The Gemara answers: There is also danger involved, <b>as there are virtuous women who give their lives</b> rather than allow themselves to be violated, <b>and they will come to</b> mortal <b>danger.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if so, <b>let</b> the Sages <b>instruct</b> these women <b>that</b> in cases of <b>coercion</b> it is <b>permitted</b> to submit to violation rather than sacrifice their lives, and they will not be forbidden to their husbands. The Gemara answers: The Sages cannot issue an instruction of that sort, because <b>there are licentious women</b> who would exploit the situation to engage in intercourse willingly, rendering them forbidden to their husbands. <b>And</b> furthermore, <b>there are also</b> women married to <b>priests,</b> who are rendered forbidden to their husbands even if they are raped.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> the Sages completely <b>abolish</b> the ordinance to marry on Wednesday and establish marriage on a different day. The Gemara answers: <b>A decree of religious persecution [<i>shemada</i>] is likely to be abrogated, and we do not abolish a rabbinic ordinance in the face of a decree of religious persecution.</b> Rather, a lenient ruling is issued instructing them not to follow the ordinance, as long as the decree of persecution is in effect. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> what is accomplished by moving the marriage to Tuesday? The prefect <b>will come on Tuesday too,</b> to violate them. The Gemara answers: The date of the marriage is not fixed, and <b>for</b> a situation of <b>uncertainty</b> the prefect will not <b>uproot himself</b> to violate the bride.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And on Monday one may not marry</b> even in time of danger. <b>However, if it is due to the coercion, it is permitted.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <b>coercion</b> mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>? <b>If we say it is referring to that which we mentioned</b> with regard to the decree of <i>prima nocta</i> it is difficult, as <b>there</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>calls it danger, and here he calls it coercion. Furthermore, there</b> it says that they <b>adopted the custom</b> to marry on Tuesday; <b>here</b> it states that it is <b>permitted.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> Coercion refers to a case <b>where they said: A general</b> and his army <b>are coming to the city</b> on Wednesday, and the concern is that the troops will appropriate the supplies for the feast. <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> it is a situation <b>where</b> the general <b>comes and passes</b> through, <b>let</b> them <b>postpone</b> the wedding until the following week. <b>Rather, it is necessary</b> to teach the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the general only in a case <b>where he comes and establishes</b> himself there. The Gemara asks: <b>In any case, let one marry on Tuesday.</b> Why does the <i>baraita</i> permit marrying on Monday? The Gemara answers: It was necessary to move the wedding to Monday because <b>his entourage [<i>asperava</i>] arrives on Tuesday.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>Due to the coercion?</b> It is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If one’s bread was baked, and his animal slaughtered, and his wine diluted,</b> and all preparations for the wedding feast were complete, <b>and the father of the groom or the mother of the bride died</b> before the wedding, then before burying the deceased, which would trigger the onset of mourning, <b>one moves the corpse into a room, and the bride and groom</b> are ushered <b>to the wedding canopy</b> and they are married.

Daf 4a

<b>And</b> the groom then <b>engages in intercourse</b> with the bride to fulfill the <b>mitzva, and</b> then he <b>withdraws</b> from his wife, and the corpse is buried. <b>And</b> the groom then <b>observes the seven days of</b> the wedding <b>feast,</b> which are a personal festival for him, when the obligation of mourning rites does not take effect, <b>and thereafter he observes the seven days of mourning. And throughout those days</b> of rejoicing and mourning, the groom <b>sleeps among the men, and</b> the bride <b>sleeps among the women,</b> and they are not permitted to enter into seclusion. <b>And</b> in the event of mourning, <b>one does not withhold jewels from the bride</b> for the <b>entire thirty-day</b> period after the wedding, so that she not be undesirable to her husband.
<b>And</b> the wedding takes place and is followed by seven days of feasting and seven days of mourning, <b>specifically</b> if it is <b>the father of</b> the <b>groom or the mother of</b> the <b>bride</b> who died, <b>as</b> in that case <b>there is no</b> other <b>person who</b> would <b>exert</b> themselves <b>for them.</b> They are the ones responsible for the wedding preparations, and therefore the preparations that were completed must be utilized. <b>However,</b> if <b>the opposite</b> takes place, i.e., the mother of the groom or the father of the bride dies, <b>no,</b> the practice is different. The corpse is buried immediately, the seven-day mourning period is observed, and only afterward is the couple married.
<b>Rafram bar Pappa said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that they are married immediately <b>only if one</b> already <b>placed water on the meat.</b> In that case, it will be impossible to sell it to others, and if it is not cooked immediately it will spoil and a significant loss will be incurred, potentially resulting in cancellation of the wedding feast. <b>However, if he did not place water on the meat, it</b> can be <b>sold.</b> No significant loss will be incurred, so the mourning period need not be postponed.
<b>Rava said: And in a city,</b> where there are typically many buyers, <b>even if he placed water on the meat it</b> can be <b>sold,</b> and the mourning period need not be postponed. <b>Rav Pappa said: And in a village, even if he did not place water on the meat, it cannot</b> be <b>sold,</b> because no buyers can be found to purchase a quantity of meat that great. Based on the statements of Rava and Rav Pappa, whether or not water was placed on the meat is irrelevant both in a large city and in a village. The Gemara asks: <b>Where do you find</b> a case where the statement <b>of Rav Ḥisda</b> applies? <b>Rav Ashi says:</b> It can be found in a place <b>like</b> his city of <b>Mata Meḥasya, which is removed from</b> the category of <b>a city,</b> as it is too small, <b>and removed from</b> the category of <b>a village,</b> as it is too large.
The following <i>baraita</i> was <b>taught in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda: If one’s bread was baked, and his animal slaughtered, and his wine diluted, and he placed water on the meat, and the father of the groom or the mother of the bride died, one moves the corpse into a room, and the bride and groom</b> are ushered <b>to the wedding canopy,</b> and they are married. The groom then <b>engages in intercourse</b> with the bride to fulfill the <b>mitzva,</b> and he then <b>withdraws</b> from his wife, and the corpse is buried. <b>And</b> the groom then <b>observes the seven days of</b> the wedding <b>feast, and thereafter observes the seven days of mourning. And throughout those days</b> of feast and mourning, the groom <b>sleeps among the men, and his wife sleeps among the women,</b> and they are not permitted to be alone together.
<b>And likewise,</b> a groom <b>whose wife began to menstruate</b> at the time of the wedding, <b>he sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women,</b> until she becomes ritually pure. <b>However,</b> the Sages <b>do not withhold jewels from the bride</b> while she is in mourning for the <b>entire thirty-day</b> period after the wedding. <b>In any event, the</b> groom <b>may not engage in intercourse</b> with his virgin bride, <b>neither on Shabbat evening,</b> as he will thereby inflict a wound, <b>nor</b> at the <b>conclusion of Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara proceeds to analyze the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said: He sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women.</b> This <b>supports</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan, as Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Although they stated that there is no mourning</b> observed <b>on a Festival, yet one observes matters of privacy,</b> i.e., mourning practices not apparent to onlookers. Therefore, the groom and the bride may not engage in relations during the seven days of rejoicing, as the legal status of those days is like that of a Festival for them.
<b>Rav Yosef, son of Rava, taught in the name of Rava: They taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> that if the bride began menstruating, the bride and groom may not be alone together, <b>only if he did not engage in intercourse</b> with her. <b>However, if he engaged in intercourse</b> with her, and afterward she begins menstruating, <b>his wife sleeps with him,</b> and there is no concern that this will lead to their engaging in forbidden relations.
The Gemara asks: <b>But here,</b> with regard to mourning, <b>we are dealing</b> with a case <b>where he</b> already <b>engaged in intercourse</b> that was permitted prior to the funeral, <b>and</b> yet the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches: He sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When he states</b> the ruling that if they already engaged in intercourse she sleeps with him, it was <b>concerning</b> only a case where <b>his wife began menstruating,</b> and it is not a case of mourning.
The Gemara asks: But <b>doesn’t it state: And likewise,</b> indicating that the legal status of the mourner and the legal status of the groom whose wife is menstruating are the same?

Daf 4b

<b>This is what</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying: And likewise,</b> with regard to a groom <b>whose wife began to menstruate, and he had not</b> yet <b>engaged in intercourse</b> with her, <b>he sleeps among the men, and his wife sleeps among the women.</b> However, in the case of a mourner, even if they already engaged in sexual relations, he sleeps among the men and she sleeps among the women.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that</b> the prohibition against relations during <b>mourning is more lenient in his</b> opinion <b>than</b> the prohibition against relations with <b>a menstruating woman?</b> That is apparently the case, as after engaging in the initial intercourse, he may enter into seclusion with his menstruating wife but not with his wife when either of them is in mourning.
The Gemara continues: <b>But didn’t Rav Yitzḥak bar Ḥanina say</b> that <b>Rav Huna said: All tasks that a woman</b> typically <b>performs for her husband, a menstruating woman performs for her husband, except for pouring</b> his drink into the <b>cup; arranging</b> his <b>bed; and washing his face, hands, and feet,</b> as these actions are particularly intimate. <b>Whereas with regard to mourning, it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Although they said that a man may not compel his</b> mourning <b>wife, to paint</b> her eyes <b>blue or to rouge [<i>pokeset</i>]</b> her face, <b>in truth they said that she may pour</b> his drink into <b>the cup; arrange his bed; and wash his face, hands, and feet.</b> Apparently, the concern lest they come to engage in relations while in mourning is less pressing than the concern while she is menstruating.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where the Sages required them to sleep apart, it is <b>in</b> a case of the husband’s <b>mourning; there,</b> where the Sages allowed her to pour his drink and perform other intimate activities, it is <b>in</b> a case of the wife’s <b>mourning.</b> The prohibition against relations when one is mourning is not perceived to be as severe as the prohibition against relations with a menstruating woman. However, when his wife is mourning, even were he unable to restrain himself, his wife would not be complicit. Therefore, the Sages did not restrict their interaction.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in that <i>baraita</i>: <b>The father of the groom and the mother of the bride?</b> This indicates that it makes no difference which of them was in mourning. <b>When</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> that there is no distinction between which of them was in mourning, it was <b>concerning the rest</b> of the mourning practices cited there, not with regard to prohibiting their seclusion.
The Gemara asks: <b>And do</b> the Sages <b>distinguish between his mourning and her mourning? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one whose father-in-law or mother-in-law died, he may not compel his wife to paint</b> her eyes <b>blue or to rouge</b> her face. <b>Rather, he overturns his bed,</b> as was the practice among mourners, <b>and observes</b> the <b>mourning</b> period <b>with her. And likewise, if</b> a wife’s <b>father-in-law or mother-in-law dies, she is not allowed to paint</b> her eyes <b>blue or to rouge</b> her face. <b>Rather, she overturns her bed and observes</b> the <b>mourning</b> period <b>with him.</b> There is no mention in the context of his mourning that he must not be alone with his wife.
The Gemara emends the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Teach with regard to his mourning: He sleeps among the men and his wife sleeps among the women.</b> The Gemara asks: But <b>doesn’t</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach: And likewise?</b> This indicates that there is no difference between the two cases. The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> that there is no distinction between which of them is mourning, it is with regard to <b>painting and rouge.</b> The Gemara asks: But <b>doesn’t</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach: With him? What,</b> does <b>it not</b> mean <b>with him</b> together <b>in bed,</b> and there is no concern that it will lead to sexual relations? <b>No,</b> it means <b>with him at home, and</b> it is <b>as that which Rav said to Ḥiyya, his son,</b> when his wife’s father died: <b>Before her, observe mourning</b> practices; <b>not before her, do not observe mourning</b> practices. Understood in this context, the term: With him, means in his presence.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that the question was based on a mistaken premise: <b>Can you compare the mourning here with mourning in general? Mourning in general is stringent, and one will not come to take it lightly.</b> However, with regard to <b>mourning here,</b> immediately following the wedding, <b>since the Sages were lenient, one will come to take it lightly.</b>
<b>What leniency</b> did the Sages enact in this case? <b>If we say</b> it is that <b>which</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches:</b> The groom <b>engages in</b> the initial <b>intercourse</b> with the bride to fulfill the <b>mitzva</b> and then he <b>withdraws</b> from his wife, then <b>there,</b> where the corpse is placed into a room in the house, it is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that mourning has not yet taken effect upon him.</b> Consequently, there is no leniency with regard to mourning practices. <b>If</b> it is according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> mourning does not take effect <b>until the</b> corpse <b>emerges from the entrance of the house</b> for burial. <b>If</b> it is according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> mourning does not take effect <b>until the covering of the grave is sealed.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the leniency is that <b>which</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches:</b> And the groom then <b>observes the seven days of feast</b> following the wedding, <b>and thereafter he observes the seven days of mourning.</b> Since the Sages were lenient and allowed him to observe the wedding feast, despite the fact that he is a mourner, they prohibited his being alone with his wife so he would be less likely to practice additional leniencies in his mourning.
§ <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>In any event, the</b> groom <b>may not engage in intercourse</b> with his virgin bride, <b>neither on Shabbat evening, nor</b> at the <b>conclusion of Shabbat. Granted, on Shabbat evening</b> he may not engage in intercourse <b>due to the</b> prohibition against inflicting <b>a wound</b> on Shabbat. <b>However, at the conclusion of Shabbat, why</b> may he <b>not</b> engage in intercourse with his virgin bride?
<b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b>

Daf 5a

It is <b>due to calculations</b> performed on Shabbat to prepare for the wedding. He would thereby engage in weekday matters on Shabbat.
<b>Abaye said to him: And are calculations for a mitzva prohibited</b> on Shabbat? <b>But wasn’t it Rav Ḥisda and Rav Hamnuna who both said:</b> With regard to <b>calculations for a mitzva,</b> it is <b>permitted to reckon them on Shabbat? And Rabbi Elazar said: One may allocate charity to the poor on Shabbat. And Rabbi Ya’akov said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One goes to synagogues and study halls to supervise matters</b> affecting the <b>multitudes on Shabbat. And Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One supervises matters of saving a life on Shabbat.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One goes to theaters [<i>tartiyyaot</i>] and circuses [<i>karkiyyaot</i>] to supervise matters</b> affecting the <b>multitudes on Shabbat,</b> because the fate of the Jewish people or of individual Jews is often decided there and one’s presence could prevent calamity. <b>And</b> the Sage <b>of the school of Menashya taught:</b> One <b>makes matches [<i>meshadkhin</i>]</b> among the families concerned <b>for a young girl to be betrothed on Shabbat, and</b> similarly one may make arrangements <b>for a young boy to teach him Torah and to teach him a craft.</b> Apparently, calculations for a mitzva may be reckoned on Shabbat, including calculations for a wedding. Therefore, this cannot be the reason for the prohibition against marrying at the conclusion of Shabbat.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Zeira said: It is a decree lest one slaughter a young fowl on</b> Shabbat, due to his preoccupation with the preparations for that night’s wedding feast. <b>Abaye said to him: If</b> that is <b>so, Yom Kippur that occurs on Monday should be postponed</b> when fixing the calendar, due to <b>a decree lest one slaughter a young fowl</b> on Shabbat for the meal on Yom Kippur eve, which is a mitzva. The Gemara distinguishes between the cases. <b>There,</b> with regard to Yom Kippur eve, when one is preparing a meal <b>for himself, he is not preoccupied,</b> and he will not overlook the fact that it is Shabbat. <b>Here,</b> in the case of a wedding, one is preparing a meal <b>for others</b> and is <b>preoccupied. Alternatively, there,</b> on Yom Kippur eve, <b>he has an interval</b> of time during which he can slaughter the bird, as the mitzva is to eat the meal on Yom Kippur eve the next day. <b>Here, he does not have an interval</b> of time, because the wedding and the feast take place at night at the conclusion of Shabbat.
The Gemara says: <b>Now that we have come to this</b> understanding of the prohibition against marrying at the conclusion of Shabbat, the prohibition not to engage in sexual intercourse on <b>Shabbat evening, too,</b> is not due to the intercourse. Rather, it is <b>a decree lest one slaughter a young fowl</b> for the wedding feast.
§ The Gemara <b>raises a dilemma: Is a virgin married on Wednesday and</b> does she <b>engage in intercourse on</b> that <b>Wednesday, and we are not concerned</b> lest <b>his resolve</b> to take his bride to court upon discovering that she was not a virgin <b>cool</b> overnight? Rather, he will certainly go to court the next morning. <b>Or perhaps, a virgin is married on Wednesday but engages in intercourse on Thursday, as we are concerned that his resolve will cool.</b>
<b>Come and hear</b> proof, <b>as bar Kappara taught: A virgin is married on Wednesday and engages in intercourse on Thursday, since the blessing to the fish:</b> Be fruitful and multiply, <b>was stated</b> on the fifth day of Creation. <b>A widow is married on Thursday and engages in intercourse on Friday, since the blessing</b> of procreation <b>was stated to man</b> on the sixth day of Creation. It may be inferred that <b>the reason is due to the blessing, but with regard to</b> the possibility lest <b>his resolve cool, we are not concerned.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, a widow should also engage in intercourse on Thursday, since the blessing to the fish was stated then.</b> The Gemara answers: Since there is the option to postpone engaging in relations to the day on which <b>the blessing of man</b> was stated, doing so <b>is preferable for him.</b>
<b>Alternatively,</b> that day was established as the day for a widow to engage in sexual relations <b>due to</b> the fact that the Sages <b>were assiduous</b> in seeing to the well-being of Jewish women, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Why did</b> the Sages <b>say that a widow is married on Thursday and engages in intercourse on Friday?</b> It is <b>because if you say that she should engage in intercourse on Thursday, on the next day</b> the groom will <b>go to</b> ply <b>his craft early</b> and leave his wife alone. When a man marries a widow, there is no observance of the seven days of rejoicing, whose legal status is like that of a Festival, during which he does not go to work. Therefore, <b>the Sages were assiduous in seeing to the well-being of Jewish women</b> and ensured <b>that</b> the groom <b>rejoice with her</b> for <b>three days: Thursday,</b> the day of the wedding; <b>and Shabbat eve,</b> the day when they engage in sexual relations; <b>and Shabbat.</b>
<b>What</b> practical difference <b>is there between</b> the two reasons given to engage in relations on Friday, i.e., the <b>blessing</b> of procreation for man <b>and</b> the fact that the Sages <b>were assiduous?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> in the case of <b>an idle person,</b> who has no job, in which case the reason of blessing applies and the reason that the Sages were assiduous does not, as no matter what he will not go to work early. <b>Alternatively,</b> there is a practical difference in the case of <b>a Festival that occurs on Shabbat eve.</b> There too, the reason of blessing applies but the Sages’ assiduousness does not apply, as one does not work on a Festival.
§ The Gemara cites additional aggadic statements of bar Kappara. <b>Bar Kappara taught: The handiwork of the righteous is greater than the creation of heaven and earth, as with regard to the creation of heaven and earth it is written: “My hand also has laid the foundation of the earth, and My right hand has spanned the heavens”</b> (Isaiah 48:13). There, hand is written in the singular. <b>Whereas with regard to the handiwork of the righteous it is written: “The place which You have made for Yourself to dwell in, Lord, the Sanctuary, Lord, which your hands have established” (Exodus 15:17).</b> The reference is to the Temple, which is the handiwork of man, and hand is written in the plural.
<b>A certain Babylonian, and his name is Rabbi Ḥiyya, responded</b> with a challenge. It is written with regard to creation of the earth: <b>“And His hands formed the dry land”</b> (Psalms 95:5). The Gemara answers: <b>“His hand”</b> is the way it <b>is written.</b> Although the word is vocalized in the plural, it is written in the singular, without the letter <i>yod</i>. <b>But isn’t it written: “Formed,”</b> in the plural? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: The plural is referring to <b>His fingers, as it is written: “When I see Your heavens, the work of Your fingers, the moon and stars, which You have established”</b> (Psalms 8:4).
<b>The Gemara raises an objection: “The heavens declare the glory of God, and the firmament proclaims the work of His hands”</b> (Psalms 19:2). The heavens were created by His hands. The Gemara answers that <b>this</b> is what the verse <b>is saying: Who attests to the handiwork of the righteous,</b> that they are performing the will of God? It is <b>the heavens. And what is</b> the avenue through which the heavens do so? It is by means of <b>rain</b> that falls due to the prayers of the righteous.
<b>Bar Kappara taught: What is</b> the meaning of that which <b>is written: And you shall have a peg among your weapons [<i>azenekha</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:14)? <b>Do not read</b> it as: <b>Your weapons [<i>azenekha</i>]. Rather,</b> read it: <b>On your ear [<i>oznekha</i>],</b> meaning <b>that if a person hears an inappropriate matter,</b>

Daf 5b

<b>he should place his finger,</b> which is shaped like a peg, <b>into his ears. And that is what Rabbi Elazar said: Why are the fingers of a person similar to pegs?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that Rabbi Elazar said that fingers are like pegs? <b>If we say</b> that it is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that they are discrete</b> from each other, <b>each and every</b> finger <b>was designated for its</b> own discrete, sacred <b>matter, as the Master said: This</b> small finger is for measuring <b>a span,</b> the distance between the little finger to the tip of the thumb used in measuring the breastplate of the High Priest; <b>this</b> next finger is used for taking <b>a fistful</b> of the meal-offering; <b>this</b> middle finger is used for measuring <b>a cubit,</b> the distance from the elbow to the tip of the middle finger; <b>this</b> one next to the thumb is the <b>finger</b> used to sprinkle the blood of offerings on the altar; <b>this</b> is the <b>thumb,</b> on which the blood and oil is placed in the purification ritual of a leper.
<b>Rather,</b> the question is: <b>What is the reason that they are pointed like pegs?</b> It is so <b>that if a person hears an inappropriate matter, he will place his fingers in his ears.</b> Similarly, a Sage <b>of the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Why is the entire ear hard and the earlobe soft?</b> It is so <b>that if a person hears an inappropriate matter, he will bend his earlobe into</b> his ear to seal it. <b>The Sages taught: A person should not allow his ears to hear idle matters. Because</b> of the fact <b>that</b> ears are very sensitive and <b>are</b> the <b>first of the limbs burned,</b> one should make certain not to expose them to anything problematic.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised</b> before the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to engaging in intercourse</b> with one’s virgin bride <b>for the first time on Shabbat?</b> The dilemma is with regard to the nature of the blood that emerges as a result of the piercing of the hymen. Is it that the <b>blood is pooled,</b> and it is released once the hymen is pierced, so that no prohibition is violated? <b>Or,</b> is the blood flowing through vessels <b>attached</b> to the body, and it emerges as a result of a wound, so that he does violate a prohibition?
<b>And if you say</b> that <b>it is pooled</b> and the intercourse does not cause a wound, there is an additional dilemma: <b>Does</b> the husband <b>require the blood</b> to flow, and that is his objective in performing the act, in which case it is <b>permitted? Or, perhaps he requires the opening</b> caused by the rupture of the hymen, <b>and</b> creating that opening is <b>prohibited</b> on Shabbat.
<b>And if you say</b> that <b>he requires the blood, and the opening comes</b> about <b>incidentally</b> as an unintended consequence, <b>is the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said: An unintentional act,</b> i.e., a permitted action from which a forbidden labor inadvertently ensued, <b>is permitted? Or, is the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who said: An unintentional act is forbidden?</b>
<b>And even if you say that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> in this regard, is this <b>a destructive</b> action <b>vis-à-vis the opening,</b> and is it consequently permitted on Shabbat because only constructive actions are forbidden? <b>Or, perhaps</b> it is <b>a constructive</b> action <b>vis-à-vis the opening.</b>
<b>Some say</b> that the series of dilemmas is as follows: <b>And if you say</b> that <b>the blood is</b> flowing through vessels <b>attached</b> to the body and emerges as a result of a wound, <b>does</b> the husband <b>require the blood,</b> and engaging in intercourse is consequently <b>prohibited,</b> as his intent is to cause the wound? <b>Or, perhaps he requires</b> the act of intercourse solely <b>for his own pleasure, and</b> it is <b>permitted.</b>
<b>And if you say that he requires</b> the act of intercourse solely <b>for his own pleasure, and the blood comes incidentally,</b> as it was not his intent to draw blood, <b>is the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> with regard to an unintentional act, <b>or</b> is it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon?</b>
<b>And if you say</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> and unintentional acts are forbidden, is one <b>destructive in</b> causing the <b>wound</b> or <b>constructive in</b> causing the <b>wound?</b>
<b>And if you say</b> that he is <b>destructive in</b> causing the <b>wound, in</b> cases involving <b>destructive</b> acts <b>is the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who rules that one who performs any destructive act on Shabbat is exempt, even if he did so intentionally?

Daf 6a

<b>Or, is the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who ruled that one who is destructive in causing a wound on Shabbat is liable if he did so intentionally?
With regard to the <i>halakha</i> of engaging in intercourse with one’s virgin bride on Shabbat, <b>it was stated</b> that <b>in the school of Rav they say: Rav permitted</b> doing so <b>and Shmuel prohibited</b> doing so. <b>In Neharde’a,</b> where Shmuel lived, <b>they say: Rav prohibited</b> doing so <b>and Shmuel permitted</b> doing so. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: And your mnemonic</b> is: <b>These are lenient</b> with regard <b>to themselves, and those are lenient</b> with regard <b>to themselves.</b> Each attributes the lenient ruling to the local halakhic authority, whose ruling is binding in that locale.
The Gemara asks: <b>And did Rav permit</b> engaging in intercourse in those circumstances? <b>But didn’t Rav Shimi bar Ḥizkiyya say in the name of Rav:</b> In the case of <b>this</b> cloth <b>stopper of a barrel [<i>nazyata</i>],</b> it is <b>prohibited to</b> insert <b>it tightly</b> in the spout of the barrel <b>on a Festival,</b> because in the process liquid will be squeezed from the cloth, and squeezing liquids is prohibited on Shabbat and Festivals. Apparently, Rav prohibits even unintentional actions.
The Gemara answers: <b>In the case</b> of the barrel, <b>even Rabbi Shimon concedes, as</b> it is <b>Abaye and Rava who both say: Rabbi Shimon concedes in</b> the case of: <b>Cut off its head and will it not die,</b> i.e., a case that involves inevitable consequences like the decapitation of an animal, that the action is forbidden. Here, the liquid will inevitably be squeezed from the cloth.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi say</b> that <b>Rav said</b> with regard to unintentional acts: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and Rav Ḥanan bar Ami said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. And Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin taught</b> these rulings directly, <b>without</b> citing additional <b>men</b> who transmitted them. <b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> How then did Rav permit intercourse with one’s virgin bride on Shabbat?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually, Rav holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> According <b>to that version that said</b> that <b>the blood is pooled, he is destructive vis-à-vis the opening.</b> According <b>to that version that said</b> that blood is flowing through blood vessels <b>attached</b> to the body, <b>he is destructive in</b> causing the <b>wound,</b> and Rabbi Yehuda concedes that it is permitted.
<b>Rav Ḥisda raised an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Nidda</i> 64b). With regard to <b>a young girl whose time to see</b> the flow of menstrual blood <b>has not arrived,</b> as she has not yet reached puberty, <b>and she married, Beit Shammai say: One gives her four nights</b> during which she may engage in intercourse, as any blood is attributed to the ruptured hymen. <b>Beit Hillel say:</b> There is no limit. Rather, any blood she sees is attributed to the ruptured hymen <b>until the wound heals.</b>
If, however, <b>her time to see</b> the flow of menstrual blood <b>has arrived,</b> as she has reached the age of puberty, even if she has not yet menstruated, <b>and she married, Beit Shammai say: One gives her the first night,</b> during which the blood is attributed to the wound. Thereafter, the blood is presumed to be menstrual blood, and she is forbidden to her husband. <b>Beit Hillel say: One gives her</b> from Wednesday, the day designated for marriage of a virgin, <b>until the conclusion of Shabbat, four nights.</b> During that period, any blood is attributed to the wound, and she is permitted to her husband.

Daf 6b

<b>What, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where if he did not</b> yet <b>engage in</b> full-fledged <b>intercourse,</b> i.e., rupturing the hymen, with his bride, <b>he may engage in</b> full-fledged <b>intercourse</b> with her <b>even on Shabbat?</b> Apparently, it is permitted to engage in intercourse with a virgin on Shabbat. <b>Rava said: No,</b> it is referring to any other day <b>except for Shabbat. Abaye said to him: But isn’t it taught: Until the conclusion of Shabbat, four nights?</b> Four nights from Wednesday until the conclusion of Shabbat includes Shabbat. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> It is referring to a case <b>where he engaged in</b> full-fledged <b>intercourse</b> with his bride before Shabbat. Therefore, there is no concern lest he cause a wound on Shabbat.
However, <b>if</b> it is referring to a case where <b>he</b> already <b>engaged in intercourse, what is</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaching us</b> when he says that it is permitted to have intercourse with her even on Shabbat? <b>He teaches us that</b> although it might cause bleeding, <b>it is permitted to engage in intercourse on Shabbat, in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Shmuel, as Shmuel said:</b> It is <b>permitted to enter into a narrow opening</b> in a wall <b>on Shabbat, although</b> doing so <b>causes pebbles to fall</b> from the wall. Here too, although it might cause a wound and bleeding, intercourse is permitted on Shabbat.
<b>Rav Yosef raised an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Berakhot</i> 16a): <b>A groom is exempt from the</b> mitzva <b>of reciting <i>Shema</i> on the first night</b> of his marriage to a virgin on Wednesday night, <b>until Saturday night, if he has not taken action</b> and consummated the marriage. <b>What, is it not</b> that he is exempt due to the fact <b>that he is preoccupied because he wishes to engage in intercourse</b> with her and is concerned that he will fail to do so properly? Apparently, if he did not yet consummate the marriage, he is exempt from reciting <i>Shema</i> even on Shabbat, indicating that it is permitted to engage in intercourse on Shabbat. <b>Abaye said to him: No.</b> It can be explained <b>that he</b> is exempt from reciting <i>Shema</i> because he <b>is preoccupied</b> due to the fact <b>that</b> he did <b>not</b> yet <b>engage in intercourse</b> with her. No proof may be cited with regard to engaging in intercourse on Shabbat.
<b>Rava said to</b> Abaye: <b>And</b> is one <b>exempt due to preoccupation? If that is so,</b> would <b>one whose ship sunk at sea also</b> be exempt? The Gemara reinforces its question: <b>And if you would say:</b> In fact, <b>that is so, didn’t Rabbi Abba bar Zavda say</b> that <b>Rav said: A mourner is obligated in all the mitzvot in the Torah except for</b> the mitzva to don <b>phylacteries, as</b> the term <b>splendor is stated with regard to</b> phylacteries: “Make no mourning for the dead; bind your splendor upon yourself” (Ezekiel 24:17). Splendor is antithetical to mourning. If a mourner, who is clearly pained and preoccupied, is obligated to recite <i>Shema</i>, then certainly all others who are preoccupied due to events that transpired in the past should be obligated. If the groom is exempt, it must be due to his preoccupation with a mitzva that remains incumbent upon him to perform in the future.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> This matter of intercourse with a virgin on Shabbat <b>is</b> subject to a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as one</b> <i>tanna</i> <b>taught: If he did not take action on the first</b> night <b>he is exempt</b> from reciting <i>Shema</i> <b>even on the second.</b> If he failed to consummate the marriage on the <b>second</b> night <b>he is exempt even on the third</b> night, which is Shabbat evening.
<b>And another</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught:</b> On the <b>first and second</b> nights <b>he is exempt;</b> on the <b>third he is obligated</b> to recite <i>Shema</i>. He is obligated on the third night, even if he did not yet consummate the marriage, because the third night is Shabbat, when intercourse with his virgin wife is forbidden. The different rulings in the two <i>baraitot</i> indicate that there is a tannaitic dispute with regard to intercourse with a virgin on Shabbat.
<b>And</b> how does <b>Abaye</b> respond to this proof? He says that <b>there too,</b> it can be explained that it <b>is with regard to preoccupation</b> that the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree.</b> Everyone agrees that it is prohibited to engage in intercourse with a virgin on Shabbat. The dispute is whether or not one’s preoccupation with the fact that he has not yet performed the mitzva of consummating the marriage in the past is considered preoccupation with a mitzva, which would exempt him from reciting <i>Shema</i>?
<b>And</b> the dispute between <b>these <i>tanna’im</i></b> in the <i>baraitot</i> cited is <b>parallel</b> to the dispute between <b>these <i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who marries a virgin, he may not engage in intercourse</b> with her for the <b>first</b> time on <b>Shabbat, and the Rabbis permit</b> doing so.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who are</b> the <b>Rabbis</b> that permit doing so? <b>Rabba said: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said: An unintentional act is permitted</b> on Shabbat. Since one’s intention is to perform a permitted action, i.e., the consummation of the marriage, and there is no intent to perform a forbidden action, any forbidden action that may ensue is not a source of concern.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rabba: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Shimon concede</b> that <b>in</b> the case of: <b>Cut off its head and will it not die,</b> i.e., inevitable consequences, one is not exempted by lack of intent. Since rupture of the hymen and the subsequent bleeding is inevitable, Rabbi Shimon would concede that intercourse with a virgin is forbidden. Rabba <b>said to him: Unlike these Babylonians, who are not experts in diverting</b> during intercourse and are unable to engage in intercourse without rupturing the hymen, <b>there are</b> those who are <b>experts in diverting.</b> Therefore, rupture of the hymen is not an inevitable consequence.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> and the groom is expert in diverting, <b>why</b> is there <b>preoccupation</b> that renders him exempt from reciting <i>Shema</i>? The Gemara answers: The exemption due to preoccupation is limited to <b>one who is not expert.</b> The Gemara asks: If so, the Sages <b>should say</b> explicitly: One who is <b>expert is permitted</b> to have intercourse with a virgin on Shabbat, and one <b>who is not expert is prohibited</b> from doing so. The Gemara answers: The <b>majority</b> of men <b>are experts</b> in this matter. Therefore, rupture of the hymen is not an inevitable consequence, and intercourse is permitted on Shabbat.
<b>Rava bar Rav Ḥanan said to Abaye: If that is so,</b> and most people are able to engage in intercourse with a virgin without rupturing the hymen, <b>why are groomsmen</b> stationed to ensure that no deceit is employed by the groom with regard to the bride’s virginity? And <b>why</b> is <b>a sheet</b> necessary to determine whether there was blood? The absence of blood proves nothing if intercourse is possible without blood. Abaye <b>said to him: There,</b> the groomsmen and the sheet are necessary <b>lest</b> the groom <b>see</b> blood <b>and</b> seek to <b>destroy</b> it intentionally. Certainly, if he seeks to engage in intercourse and keep the hymen intact he can do so. However, if he engages in full-fledged intercourse and the hymen is ruptured, the Sages sought to ensure that the facts are clear.
<b>Rav Ami raised an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Eduyyot</i> 2:5): With regard to <b>one who drains an abscess on Shabbat, if</b> his intent is <b>to create</b> a permanent <b>opening</b> so that the abscess will dry, <b>he is liable</b> to receive punishment for performing an action similar to the prohibited labor of building on Shabbat. <b>However, if</b> he created the opening <b>to remove pus,</b>

Daf 7a

<b>he is exempt.</b> In this case, exempt means permitted <i>ab initio</i>. Ostensibly, intercourse with a virgin is comparable to creating an opening in an abscess. Why then, would intercourse with a virgin be forbidden on Shabbat? The Gemara rejects the proof: <b>There,</b> the pus in the abscess <b>is pooled</b> in one place <b>and</b> completely <b>removed</b> from the vessels in the flesh. In creating the opening, he creates nothing enduring. <b>Here,</b> however, in the case of the ruptured hymen, even according to the opinion that the blood <b>is pooled, it is not</b> completely <b>removed</b> from the blood vessels in the flesh. Through intercourse, the blood is removed from its place, which constitutes an aspect of a prohibited labor.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Ami permitted</b> one <b>to engage in intercourse</b> with his virgin wife for the <b>first</b> time <b>on Shabbat. The Sages said to him: But her marriage contract is not</b> yet <b>written.</b> Engaging in conjugal relations with one’s wife without a marriage contract is considered an act of promiscuity. <b>He said to them: Have her seize</b> a portion of her husband’s <b>movable property</b> equivalent to the value of her marriage contract, and that will serve as a deposit until he writes the marriage contract. He may then engage in sexual relations with her.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Zevid permitted</b> one <b>to engage in intercourse</b> with his virgin wife for the <b>first</b> time <b>on Shabbat. There are</b> those <b>who say: Rav Zevid himself engaged in intercourse</b> with his virgin wife for the <b>first</b> time <b>on Shabbat.</b>
It was further related: <b>Rav Yehuda permitted</b> one <b>to engage in intercourse</b> with his virgin wife for the <b>first</b> time <b>on a Festival. Rav Pappi said in the name of Rava: Do not</b> infer and <b>say:</b> It is <b>on a Festival that</b> it is <b>permitted,</b> but <b>on Shabbat</b> it is <b>prohibited,</b> similar to actions involving food preparation, which are permitted on Festivals and prohibited on Shabbat, <b>as the same is true that even on Shabbat it is permitted. And</b> the reason Rav Yehuda issued his ruling with regard to a Festival is due to the fact that <b>the incident that took place, took place in this way.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said in the name of Rava:</b> According to Rav Yehuda, <b>on a Festival</b> it is <b>permitted, on Shabbat</b> it is <b>prohibited. Rav Pappi said to Rav Pappa: What is your thinking?</b> Is it: <b>Since</b> causing <b>a wound was permitted</b> on a Festival when performed <b>for</b> the <b>purpose</b> of food preparation, it <b>was also permitted</b> when <b>not</b> performed <b>for</b> the <b>purpose</b> of food preparation? <b>If that is so,</b> it would be <b>permitted to prepare incense [<i>mugmar</i>] on a Festival</b> due to the following reason: <b>Since kindling</b> a fire <b>was permitted</b> on a Festival when performed <b>for</b> the <b>purpose</b> of food preparation, it <b>was also permitted</b> when <b>not</b> performed <b>for</b> the <b>purpose</b> of food preparation.
Rav Pappa <b>said to him:</b> It is <b>about your</b> assertion that <b>the verse states</b> with regard to a Festival: <b>“Save that which every person must eat,</b> that alone may be done by you” (Exodus 12:16), indicating <b>a matter that is equal for every person.</b> Incense is burned only by those who are particularly delicate. It is not equally utilized by everyone, and therefore it is not permitted. Intercourse, on the other hand, is universally practiced.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: If that is so, if a deer happened to</b> come into <b>his</b> possession <b>on a Festival, since</b> it is <b>not</b> a food that is <b>equal for every person,</b> would the ruling <b>also</b> be <b>that</b> it is <b>prohibited to slaughter it?</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to him: I said a matter that</b> is <b>a need for every person,</b> and <b>deer</b> meat <b>is a matter that</b> although difficult to acquire, is <b>a need for every person.</b> Incense, even when available, is not universally utilized.
<b>Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi said: Rabbi Yoḥanan issued a ruling in</b> the city of <b>Tzaidan: It is prohibited to engage in intercourse</b> with one’s virgin wife for the <b>first</b> time <b>on Shabbat.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And is there a ruling issued to prohibit</b> an action? Typically, that language is utilized in reference to a firmly established ruling. A stringent ruling can be issued even based on uncertainty. In contrast, a lenient ruling can be issued only if the matter is clearly established by means of tradition or the reasoning of the Sage issuing the ruling.
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> that language is used with regard to a stringent ruling, as <b>didn’t we learn</b> the following in a mishna (<i>Nazir</i> 19b): When Queen Helene’s son went to war, she took a vow to be a nazirite for seven years, and she fulfilled that vow for the duration of her stay in the Diaspora? When she immigrated to Eretz Yisrael, <b>Beit Hillel issued a ruling that she shall be a nazirite for seven additional years.</b> Apparently, rulings are issued to prohibit an action as well.
<b>And alternatively,</b> this is <b>similar</b> to <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If a majority of the spinal cord</b> of an animal <b>is severed,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>; <b>this is the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Ya’akov says: Even</b> if the spinal cord is <b>perforated</b> but otherwise intact, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>issued a ruling in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ya’akov.</b> Here too, the term: Issue a ruling, is employed with regard to a stringent ruling. <b>Rav Huna said:</b> Despite the fact that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi ruled in accordance with his opinion, <b>the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ya’akov,</b> but rather it is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi. This is one version of this discussion.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak taught this</b> alternative version of the ruling of Rabbi Yoḥanan. <b>Rav Abbahu said: Rabbi Yishmael ben Ya’akov, who is from Tyre, asked Rabbi Yoḥanan in Tzaidan, and I heard</b> the exchange: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to engaging in intercourse</b> with one’s virgin wife for the <b>first</b> time <b>on Shabbat? And he said to</b> him: It is <b>prohibited.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is</b> that it is <b>permitted to engage in intercourse</b> with one’s virgin wife for the <b>first</b> time <b>on Shabbat,</b> and one need not be concerned lest he cause a wound, create an opening, or initiate bleeding.
§ <b>Rabbi Ḥelbo said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba bar Rav Zavda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Both a virgin and a widow</b> who marry <b>require</b> that the <b>benediction</b> of the grooms be recited. The Gemara asks: <b>Did Rav Huna say that? But didn’t Rav Huna say: A widow does not require</b> that <b>a benediction</b> be recited? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where Rav Huna said that a widow requires a benediction, it is <b>with regard to a bachelor who married a widow. There,</b> where Rav Huna said she does not require a benediction, it is <b>with regard to a widower who married a widow.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And does a widower who married a widow not</b> require a benediction to be recited? <b>But didn’t Rav Naḥman say: Huna bar Natan said to me</b> that it was <b>taught: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the benediction of the grooms</b> is recited <b>in</b> a quorum of <b>ten</b> men? It <b>is as it is stated</b> with regard to Boaz, who married Ruth: <b>“And he took ten men of the Elders of the city and said: Sit you here, and they sat”</b> (Ruth 4:2). <b>And</b> when <b>Boaz</b> married Ruth, <b>he was a widower marrying a widow.</b> As that is the primary source for the obligation to recite the benediction, apparently the benediction is recited even in that case.
The Gemara answers: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>Does not require a benediction, that Rav Huna stated?</b> It means that <b>she does not require a benediction all seven</b> days of the wedding celebration, <b>but</b> everyone agrees that for <b>one day, she requires</b> that <b>a benediction</b> be recited.
The Gemara asks: <b>However, that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, that <b>the Sages were assiduous in seeing to the well-being of Jewish women,</b> ensuring <b>that</b> the groom <b>will rejoice with her three days,</b> and that is why they established that a widow is married on Thursday, <b>with regard to what</b> circumstance is the <i>baraita</i> speaking? <b>If</b> it is <b>with regard to a bachelor</b> who marries a widow, <b>didn’t you say</b> he celebrates <b>seven</b> days; why then did the Sages see to a mere three-day celebration? <b>If</b> it is <b>with regard to a widower</b> who marries a widow, <b>didn’t you say</b> he celebrates for <b>one</b> day? Why then did the Sages see to a three-day celebration?
The Gemara answers that this can be resolved in several manners. <b>If you wish, say: In</b> the case of <b>a widower</b> marrying a widow, there is <b>one day for benediction and three days for celebration.</b> The wedding is scheduled on Thursday to facilitate a three-day celebration. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>In</b> the case of <b>a bachelor</b> marrying a widow, there are <b>seven days for benediction and</b> there are <b>three days for celebration,</b> during which he must refrain from going to work.

Daf 7b

<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One recites a benediction for a virgin</b> who marries for <b>seven</b> days <b>and for a widow</b> who marries for <b>one</b> day. <b>What, is it not even</b> in the case of <b>a widow who is married to a bachelor,</b> that one recites the benediction for one day? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is only in the case of a widow who is married <b>to a widower</b> that the benediction is recited for one day. The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> one may then infer that in the case of a widow who is married <b>to a bachelor, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? The blessing is recited <b>seven</b> days? <b>If so, let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> the <i>baraita</i>: <b>One recites a benediction for a virgin</b> who marries for <b>seven</b> days, <b>and for a widow</b> who marries <b>a bachelor seven</b> days, <b>and for a widow</b> marrying a widower for <b>one day.</b> Why was the middle case omitted?
Although the <i>tanna</i> could have included that case in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>he taught categorical matters.</b> He preferred to avoid entering into detail, <b>as there is no virgin</b> for <b>whom</b> the benediction is recited <b>fewer than seven</b> days, <b>and there is no widow</b> for <b>whom</b> the benediction is recited for <b>less than one day.</b> However, there are circumstances where even for a widow the benediction is recited for more than one day.
§ Apropos the source for the benediction of the grooms, the Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rav Naḥman said: Huna bar Natan said to me</b> that it was <b>taught: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the benediction of the grooms</b> is recited <b>in</b> a quorum of <b>ten</b> men? It is <b>as it is stated: “And he took ten men of the Elders of the city and said: Sit you here,</b> and they sat” (Ruth 4:2). <b>And Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that the source is <b>from here: “In assemblies [<i>mak’helot</i>], bless God, the Lord, from the source of Israel”</b> (Psalms 68:27). This verse indicates that a congregation [<i>kahal</i>], which contains at least ten men, blesses God when reciting a benediction related to the source of Israel, i.e., conjugal relations, which will lead to the birth of Jewish children.
<b>And what does Rav Naḥman derive from this verse</b> from <b>which Rabbi Abbahu</b> derived that <i>halakha</i>? <b>He requires</b> the verse <b>to</b> derive <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Meir would say: From where</b> is it derived <b>that even fetuses in their mother’s womb recited</b> the <b>song at the</b> Red <b>Sea?</b> It is <b>as it is stated</b> in the chapter of Psalms that describes the exodus from Egypt: <b>“In assemblies, bless God, the Lord, from the source of Israel.”</b> Even those fetuses that were still in the source, i.e., the womb, joined the assemblies in blessing God. <b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Abbahu says: <b>If that</b> is the meaning, <b>let the verse say: From the belly of Israel. What is</b> the meaning of the term <b>“source”?</b> Clearly, it is referring <b>to matters</b> related to <b>the source</b> of Israel, i.e., the benediction of the grooms, which must be recited in a congregation, a quorum of ten.
<b>And what does Rabbi Abbahu derive from this verse</b> from <b>which Rav Naḥman</b> derived his <i>halakha</i>? <b>He requires</b> the verse stating that Boaz assembled ten men in order <b>to teach</b> that the Torah prohibition with regard to marrying members of the nations of Ammon and Moab is limited to a male <b>Ammonite and not a female Ammonite,</b> and to a male <b>Moabite and not a female Moabite, as, if it would enter your mind</b> that Boaz gathered the men only <b>to</b> recite <b>a benediction,</b> would it <b>not</b> have been <b>sufficient</b> if they <b>were not Elders?</b> From the fact that he convened a quorum of Elders, apparently it was to engage in halakhic discourse and to issue a halakhic ruling.
