One should not corrupt a <i>baraita</i> due to a difficulty that arose in understanding it. <b>Rather, Rava said</b> that <b>this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Anyone who did not practice the custom of the Galilee in the Galilee, but</b> instead observed <b>the custom of Judea in the Galilee, cannot make a claim concerning virginity</b> against the bride. <b>Rav Ashi said: Actually,</b> this principle could be applied <b>concerning the latter clause, and teach: Anyone who was not examined.</b> When it said in the <i>baraita</i>: Anyone who did not conduct himself in accordance with this custom, it is referring to the custom of being examined.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> For <b>both a widow</b> who is <b>an Israelite woman and a widow</b> who is the daughter <b>of priests, her marriage contract is one hundred dinars. A court of priests would collect</b> a marriage contract of <b>four hundred dinars for a virgin</b> daughter of a priest, twice the sum of the standard marriage contract for a virgin, <b>and the Sages did not reprimand them.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> A Sage <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> for <b>a widow</b> who is the daughter <b>of priests, her marriage contract is two hundred</b> dinars. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: For <b>both a widow</b> who is <b>an Israelite woman and a widow</b> who is the daughter <b>of priests, their marriage contract is one hundred dinars?</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: There were two ordinances</b> instituted: <b>Initially, the</b> court of priests <b>instituted for a virgin</b> daughter of a priest a marriage contract of <b>four hundred dinars, and for a widow,</b> a marriage contract of <b>one hundred dinars.</b>

Daf 12b

<b>Once</b> the members of the court <b>saw that</b> the priests <b>were demeaning</b> the widows, <b>they instituted for them</b> a marriage contract of <b>two hundred</b> dinars, so that they would treat them with greater esteem. <b>Once they saw that</b> the grooms <b>were distancing</b> themselves <b>from them, as they said: Instead of marrying a widow</b> who is the daughter of <b>priests</b> and paying a marriage contract of two hundred, <b>let us go marry a virgin Israelite woman</b> for the same price. Since men would no longer marry widows from priestly families, <b>they restored</b> matters <b>to their</b> original <b>status.</b> This indicates that the mishna and the <i>baraita</i> are addressing different time periods and different ordinances.
§ It is stated in the mishna that <b>a court of priests</b> would collect a marriage contract of four hundred dinars for a virgin daughter of a priest. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Not only with regard to a court of priests did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that they could collect a greater sum for the marriage contract of their daughters, <b>but even families of distinguished lineage in Israel. If they wanted to act as the priests do, they may act</b> in that manner.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who sought to act as the priests do,</b> as in cases <b>where an Israelite woman</b> is married <b>to a priest, or the daughter of a priest</b> is married <b>to an Israelite, may act</b> in that manner. The Gemara infers: This allowance is specifically in cases where <b>an Israelite woman</b> is married <b>to a priest, or the daughter of a priest</b> is married <b>to an Israelite, where there is an aspect of priesthood</b> involved. <b>However,</b> apparently, in a case where <b>the daughter of an Israelite</b> is married <b>to an Israelite, no,</b> it is not allowed.
The Gemara rejects that inference. The <i>baraita</i> <b>is stated</b> employing the style of: <b>It is not necessary. It is not necessary</b> to state a case where <b>the daughter of an Israelite</b> is married <b>to an Israelite, as</b> in that case the groom <b>cannot say to her:</b> By marrying you, <b>I am raising your</b> social status, and it is clear that women from distinguished families would demand a marriage contract with a greater sum. <b>However,</b> in a case where <b>an Israelite woman</b> is married <b>to a priest, where he can say to her: I am raising your</b> social status, as you are marrying into the priesthood, you might think to <b>say no,</b> the woman cannot demand a marriage contract with a greater sum. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that even in the case of a woman from a distinguished family of Israelites marrying a priest, she may demand a marriage contract with a greater sum.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There is a case of one <b>who marries a woman and did not find her hymen</b> intact, and <b>she says: After you betrothed me I was raped, and his,</b> i.e., her husband’s, <b>field was inundated,</b> meaning that it is his misfortune that she is not a virgin, as she was raped after betrothal. <b>And he says: No; rather,</b> you were raped <b>before I betrothed you, and my transaction was a mistaken transaction. Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Eliezer say: She is deemed credible. Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It is <b>not</b> based on the statement emerging <b>from her mouth</b> that <b>we conduct our lives; rather, this</b> woman assumes <b>the presumptive status of one who engaged in intercourse when she was not yet betrothed and she misled him, until she brings proof</b> supporting <b>her statement.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was stated:</b> With regard to one who approaches another and says: <b>I have one hundred dinars in your possession, and the other says: I don’t know, Rav Yehuda and Rav Huna say:</b> The respondent is <b>obligated</b> to pay, because he did not deny the claim, <b>and Rav Naḥman and Rabbi Yoḥanan say:</b> He is <b>exempt</b> from payment. The Gemara elaborates. <b>Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda say</b> that the respondent is <b>obligated</b> to pay based on the principle: When there is a <b>certain</b> claim, e.g., that of the claimant, <b>and an uncertain</b> claim, e.g., that of the respondent, the <b>certain</b> claim <b>prevails. Rav Naḥman and Rabbi Yoḥanan say:</b> The respondent is <b>exempt</b> based on the principle: <b>Establish the money in the possession of its owner,</b> and the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. Since the claimant does not support his claim with proof, the money remains in the possession of the respondent.
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: This</b> ruling <b>of Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda is</b> essentially the statement <b>of Shmuel, as we learned</b> in a mishna (13a): In the case of an unmarried woman <b>who was pregnant, and</b> the Sages <b>said to her: What is the nature of this fetus,</b> i.e., who is the father. And she says: It is <b>from a man</b> called <b>so-and-so and he is a priest</b> and is certainly of valid lineage. <b>Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Eliezer say: She is deemed credible,</b> and the fetus is deemed to be of valid lineage. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel.</b>
<b>And Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda said to Rav Yehuda: Big-toothed one [<i>shinnana</i>], you said to us in the name of Shmuel</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel even in the first</b> dispute, the dispute cited in the mishna, which is the first in a series of disputes with regard to conflicting claims. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>even the first?</b> What is unique about that dispute relative to the others? The Gemara answers: The novel element in the first dispute is that the claim of the bride is accepted <b>despite the fact that</b> although <b>there is</b> room <b>to say: Establish the money in the possession of its owner,</b> and since the money is in the possession of the husband and the woman is the claimant, <b>Rabban Gamliel said</b> that the <b>certain</b> claim of the bride <b>prevails</b> over the uncertain claim of the groom, who can only speculate about when she was raped.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that it is <b>Rav Yehuda and Rav Huna who say</b> their ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel,</b> who says that a certain claim prevails over an uncertain one even to collect money from the possession of the respondent. <b>And</b> it is <b>Rav Naḥman and Rabbi Yoḥanan who say</b> their ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> that one does not collect money based merely on a claim.
The Gemara rejects that suggestion. <b>Rav Naḥman</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> That <b>which I said, is even in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel. Rabban Gamliel says his ruling only there,</b> with regard to claims of a groom and a bride, <b>where there is a <i>miggo</i>,</b> a halakhic argument that the ability to make a more advantageous claim grants credibility to the claim one actually makes, that bolsters the bride’s claim. She could have claimed that she wasn’t raped at all, but rather that her hymen was ruptured by wood. That is a more advantageous claim because she is not disgraced in the eyes of the groom. Therefore, her claim that she was raped is accorded credibility. <b>However here,</b> where one claims that another owes him money, <b>what <i>miggo</i> is there</b> bolstering his claim and according it credibility?
<b>Alternatively,</b> Rav Naḥman could have said to you: <b>Rabban Gamliel says his ruling only there, where we say: Establish her</b> legal status according to her <b>presumptive status</b> as a virgin, and the husband’s claim seeks to undermine that presumptive status. <b>However here, what presumptive status does this</b> claimant <b>have</b> supporting the claim that another owes him money? Therefore, even Rabban Gamliel would concede that his certain claim does not prevail.
The Gemara notes: <b>Indeed,</b> it is <b>also reasonable</b> to explain <b>as we are teaching, that it is Rav Naḥman who said</b> his ruling <b>in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel.</b>

Daf 13a

<b>Because if</b> that were not <b>so,</b> it is <b>difficult,</b> as there would be a contradiction between one <b><i>halakha</i></b> and another <b><i>halakha</i>. Since,</b> on the one hand, <b>we maintain</b> a principle in halakhic ruling that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman in civil law; and,</b> on the other hand, <b>in that</b> case involving the claims of the bride and the groom <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel. Rather,</b> can we <b>not conclude from</b> this apparent contradiction that the matter must be understood <b>as we are teaching,</b> that the opinion of Rav Naḥman can be reconciled with the opinion of Rabban Gamliel? The Gemara affirms: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is the case.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case where <b>she says: I</b> am one whose hymen was <b>ruptured by wood,</b> i.e., she admits that her hymen is not intact but claims that it was not ruptured through intercourse, <b>and</b> the groom <b>says: No; rather, you are</b> one who was <b>trampled by a man,</b> and your hymen was ruptured through intercourse, <b>Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Eliezer say: She is deemed credible</b> and her claim is accepted because she certainly knows what actually happened. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It is <b>not</b> based on the statement emerging <b>from her mouth</b> that <b>we conduct our lives; rather, she</b> retains <b>the presumptive status of</b> one who <b>was trampled by a man, until she brings proof</b> supporting <b>her statement</b> that her hymen was ruptured by wood.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What are their</b> respective financial <b>claims? Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The bride claims that since her hymen was ruptured by wood, her legal status is that of a virgin and she is entitled to a marriage contract of <b>two hundred</b> dinars; <b>and</b> the groom claims that she engaged in intercourse and is entitled to a marriage contract of <b>one hundred dinars. Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The bride claims that although her hymen is not intact she did not completely deceive him, as she never engaged in intercourse, and therefore she is entitled to a marriage contract of <b>one hundred dinars; and</b> the groom claims that she engaged in intercourse, rendering the betrothal a mistaken transaction, and therefore she is entitled to <b>nothing at all.</b>
The Gemara elaborates. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The dispute between the bride and groom is whether the marriage contract <b>is two hundred</b> dinars <b>or one hundred dinars,</b> because the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said: Whether</b> the husband <b>was aware that her</b> hymen was ruptured by wood <b>or whether he was not aware of her</b> condition, she receives payment of her marriage contract of <b>two hundred</b> dinars and it is not a mistaken transaction. <b>And Rabbi Elazar says: The dispute</b> between the bride and groom is whether the marriage contract <b>is one hundred dinars or</b> whether she is entitled to <b>nothing at all,</b> because the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who said: Whether</b> the husband <b>was aware that her</b> hymen was ruptured by wood or <b>whether he was not aware of her</b> condition, she receives payment of her marriage contract of <b>one hundred dinars.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, Rabbi Elazar did not state</b> his explanation of the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan because he</b> preferred to <b>establish</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> according to which the <i>halakha</i> is ruled, and not the opinion of Rabbi Meir. <b>However, what is the reason that Rabbi Yoḥanan did not state</b> his explanation of the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rabbi Elazar?</b>
The Gemara answers: The reason that Rabbi Yoḥanan explained the mishna in that manner is that <b>he holds:</b> If the groom <b>married</b> a woman <b>with the presumptive status of a virgin, and she is found to be a non-virgin, she</b> receives payment of her <b>marriage contract of one hundred</b> dinars. Therefore, <b>here,</b> according to the explanation of Rabbi Elazar, who explains the mishna according to the opinion of the Rabbis, <b>he is saying</b> that she engaged in intercourse and is entitled to a marriage contract of <b>one hundred dinars; and she is saying</b> that her hymen was ruptured by wood and she is entitled to a marriage contract of <b>one hundred dinars. What</b> difference <b>is there between his claim and her claim?</b> Therefore, Rabbi Yoḥanan explains the mishna in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, who holds that the dispute between the bride and the groom is whether she is entitled to a marriage contract of two hundred dinars or a marriage contract of one hundred dinars.
Again we question: <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Elazar,</b> who explains that the dispute between the bride and the groom is with regard to whether she is entitled to a marriage contract of one hundred dinars because her hymen was ruptured by wood, or whether she is entitled to nothing because she engaged in intercourse, <b>that is</b> why the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches two</b> similar disputes, in this mishna and in the previous one. <b>One</b> dispute, in this mishna, comes <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rami bar Ḥama,</b> who said: If he was not aware that her hymen was ruptured by wood, everyone agrees that she receives no marriage contract at all, as the marriage was a mistaken transaction. From this mishna it is clear that according to her claim that her hymen was ruptured by wood, she is entitled to one hundred dinars.
<b>And one</b> dispute, in the previous mishna, is brought in order <b>to exclude</b> that <b>which Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin</b> said that <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> If the groom married a woman with the presumptive status of a virgin and she is found to be a non-virgin, she receives payment of her marriage contract of one hundred dinars. In the previous mishna he claims: Before I betrothed you, you were raped and my transaction was a mistaken transaction, indicating that she is entitled to nothing. <b>However,</b> according <b>to Rabbi Yoḥanan, why do I</b> need the <i>tanna</i> to teach <b>two</b> similar disputes? In his opinion, the previous mishna could not have been taught to exclude that which Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin said that Rav Sheshet said. It has already been established that Rabbi Yoḥanan agrees with the opinion that if she is found to be a non-virgin, she receives payment of her marriage contract of one hundred dinars.
The Gemara answers: The two similar disputes were necessary. <b>One</b> is <b>to convey to you the far-reaching nature</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabban Gamliel</b> and the extent of the credibility that he accords to her claim; <b>and one</b> is <b>to convey to you the far-reaching nature</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua</b> and the extent to which he does not accord credibility to her claim. The Gemara elaborates: <b>The first</b> mishna, where she admits she was raped but claims that it was after betrothal, <b>conveys to you the far-reaching nature</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua: That even though there is</b> room <b>to say</b> that her claim is bolstered by a <b><i>miggo</i>, she is not deemed credible. The second</b> mishna, where she claims that her hymen was ruptured by wood and he claims that she engaged in intercourse, <b>conveys to you the far-reaching nature</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabban Gamliel: That even though there is no</b> room <b>to say</b> that her claim is bolstered by a <b><i>miggo</i>,</b> in his opinion <b>she is deemed credible.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If people <b>saw</b> a woman <b>speaking to one</b> man, but they did not recognize him, <b>and they said to her: What is the nature [<i>tivo</i>] of this man?</b> And she said to them: <b>He is a man</b> called <b>so-and-so and he is a priest; Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Eliezer say: She is deemed credible, and Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It is <b>not</b> based on the statement emerging <b>from her mouth</b> that <b>we conduct our lives. Rather, she</b> assumes <b>the presumptive status of</b> one who <b>engaged in intercourse with a Gibeonite or with a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> men of flawed lineage who disqualify her from marrying a priest, <b>until she brings proof</b> supporting <b>her statement.</b>
Similarly, <b>if</b> a single woman <b>was pregnant, and</b> people <b>said to her: What is the nature of this fetus?</b> And she says to them: <b>It is from a man</b> called <b>so-and-so and he is a priest; Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Eliezer say: She is deemed credible, and Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It is <b>not</b> based on the statement emerging <b>from her mouth</b> that <b>we conduct our lives. Rather, she</b> assumes <b>the presumptive status of</b> one who <b>conceived from a Gibeonite or a <i>mamzer</i>, until she brings proof</b> supporting <b>her statement.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>speaking</b> mentioned in the mishna? <b>Ze’eiri said:</b> It means that <b>she secluded herself</b> with a man and it is unknown whether she engaged in intercourse. <b>Rav Asi said:</b> It means that <b>she engaged in intercourse. Granted, according to Ze’eiri, that is</b> why the mishna <b>teaches</b> the case employing the term <b>speaking,</b> as it is certain only that they were in seclusion. Perhaps all they did was speak. <b>However, according to Rav Asi, what is</b> the reason the mishna employed the term <b>speaking</b> if the reference is to intercourse? The Gemara answers: The mishna employed <b>a euphemism, as it is written</b> with regard to licentious women: <b>“She eats and wipes her mouth and says: I have done no wickedness”</b> (Proverbs 30:20). The verse euphemistically ascribes the act of intercourse to the mouth instead of to the appropriate body part.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to Ze’eiri,</b> who said that speaking means that she secluded herself with him, <b>that is</b> the reason <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches two</b> cases in the mishna: A woman <b>speaking</b> to a man <b>and</b> a woman who is <b>pregnant. However, according to Rav Asi,</b> if speaking means that she engaged in intercourse, <b>why do I</b> need <b>two</b> cases addressing the same issue?
The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> teaches <b>one</b> case, the case of speaking to a man, <b>to deem her fit</b> to marry a priest, because although she engaged in intercourse, Rabbi Eliezer and Rabban Gamliel rule that she is deemed credible and is not considered to have engaged in intercourse with a man of flawed lineage. <b>And</b> the <i>tanna</i> teaches <b>one</b> case, the case of the single woman who is pregnant, in order <b>to deem her daughter</b> born from that pregnancy <b>fit</b> to marry a priest, as Rabbi Eliezer and Rabban Gamliel rule the mother is deemed credible.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says:</b> With regard <b>to the statement of the one who deems her fit</b> to marry a priest, <b>he deems her daughter fit</b> to do so as well. <b>However, according to the one who says:</b> With regard <b>to the statement of the one who deems her fit</b> to marry a priest, <b>he</b> nevertheless <b>deems her daughter unfit, what is there to say?</b> Why did the mishna cite two cases addressing the same issue? The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Asi holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said:</b> With regard <b>to the statement of the one who deems her fit</b> to marry a priest, <b>he deems her daughter fit</b> to do so as well.
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye:</b> According <b>to Ze’eiri, who said: What is</b> the meaning of the term <b>speaking?</b> It means that <b>she secluded herself, and Rabbi Yehoshua said</b> that she is <b>not deemed credible</b> to say that she engaged in intercourse with a man of proper lineage, but the assumption is that she engaged in intercourse with a man of flawed lineage. <b>Didn’t Rav say: One flogs</b> a man and a woman <b>for</b> entering into <b>seclusion,</b> for violating rabbinic law, <b>but one does not render</b> a woman <b>forbidden</b> to her husband <b>for</b> entering into <b>seclusion?</b> Only if it is established as a certainty that she engaged in intercourse with a man other than her husband, is she forbidden to her husband.
<b>Let us say that</b> this statement of Rav is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> as Rabbi Yehoshua rules that she assumes the presumptive status of one who engaged in intercourse with a Gibeonite or with a <i>mamzer</i>, and she is forbidden to marry a priest even for entering into seclusion. The Gemara rejects that conclusion. <b>Even</b> if you <b>say</b> that Rav’s statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> the Sages <b>established a higher standard with regard to</b> matters of <b>lineage.</b> Although she is not forbidden to her husband for entering into seclusion, she is deemed unfit to marry a priest.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection: If</b> people <b>saw that</b> a woman <b>entered with one</b> man <b>into seclusion,</b>

Daf 13b

<b>or into a ruin,</b> which is typically located outside the city, and if a man and woman meet there it is presumably in order to engage in sexual relations, <b>and</b> people <b>said to her: What is the nature of this man</b> with whom you secluded? She said to them: <b>He is a priest, and he is the son of my father’s brother,</b> a respectable person of impeccable lineage. <b>Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Eliezer say: She is deemed credible. Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It is <b>not</b> based on the statement emerging <b>from her mouth</b> that <b>we conduct our lives; rather, she</b> assumes <b>the presumptive status of</b> one who <b>engaged in intercourse with a Gibeonite or with a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> men of flawed lineage who disqualify her from marrying a priest, <b>until she brings proof</b> supporting <b>her statement.</b>
<b>Granted, according to Ze’eiri,</b> who said that speaking means that she secluded herself, <b>that is</b> the reason <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches two</b> cases where there is merely concern: The case of: <b>Into seclusion,</b> where there is lesser concern that she engaged in intercourse, <b>and</b> the case of: <b>Into a ruin,</b> where there is greater concern. <b>However, according to Rav Asi, who said</b> that speaking means that <b>she had intercourse,</b> and only in that case is she not deemed credible according to Rabbi Yehoshua, <b>why do I</b> need <b>two</b> cases? The Gemara answers: According to Rav Asi, the <i>tanna</i> <b>is teaching one</b> case: If people saw a woman enter with one man <b>into the seclusion of a ruin,</b> where the likelihood is that that they entered to engage in relations.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> the mishna <b>teaching</b> two different cases: <b>Into seclusion or into a ruin?</b> The Gemara suggests a different explanation. According to Rav Asi, two cases are necessary, <b>one</b> with regard <b>to a ruin in the city and one</b> with regard <b>to a ruin in the field,</b> distant from the city. <b>And</b> both cases <b>are necessary, because if</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only the case of <b>a ruin in the city,</b> one might have concluded that <b>in that</b> case <b>Rabban Gamliel deems her fit</b> to marry a priest <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that the majority</b> of the people <b>in its proximity are honorable</b> and of impeccable lineage. <b>However,</b> with regard <b>to a ruin in the field, where the majority</b> of the people <b>in its proximity are unfit</b> and of flawed lineage, as people from all over the world pass the ruin in the field and the majority of the people in the world are of flawed lineage, <b>say</b> that Rabban Gamliel <b>concedes to Rabbi Yehoshua</b> and deems her unfit to marry a priest.
<b>And if</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only <b>that</b> case of a ruin in the field, one might have concluded that <b>in that</b> case <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said</b> she is not deemed credible, because the majority of the people there are of flawed lineage. <b>However here,</b> in the case of a ruin in the city, where the majority of the people are of impeccable lineage, <b>say</b> that Rabbi Yehoshua <b>concedes to Rabban Gamliel</b> that she is deemed credible. Therefore, both cases were <b>necessary.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>This,</b> i.e., that she engaged in intercourse with a man of impeccable lineage, <b>is testimony that a woman is fit</b> to testify. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua says: She is not deemed credible. Rabbi Yehoshua said to</b> the Sages: <b>Do you not agree in the case of a woman who was taken captive, and she has witnesses</b> testifying <b>that she was taken captive, and she says: I am pure,</b> i.e., I was not violated by my captors, <b>that she is not deemed credible?</b> The assumption in that case is that most captive women are violated by their captors.
The Sages <b>said to him: But</b> there is a difference between the cases. <b>And what difference is there between this</b> case of a captive, where the woman is not accorded credibility, <b>and that</b> case of a woman who secluded herself with a man? <b>For this</b> captive, <b>there are witnesses</b> that she was taken captive, and due to the prevalent immorality in that situation, she loses the presumptive status of virtue and is considered to have certainly engaged in intercourse. <b>But for this</b> woman who secluded herself with a man, <b>she does not have witnesses</b> that she engaged in intercourse. Since she could have claimed that she did not engage in intercourse and instead admitted that she engaged in intercourse and claimed that it was with a man of impeccable lineage, she should be accorded credibility.
Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them: Even for that</b> woman, the one who secluded herself, <b>there are witnesses, because her belly is between her teeth,</b> i.e., her pregnancy is conspicuous and therefore she does not have the option of claiming that she did not engage in intercourse. The Sages <b>said to him:</b> There remains a difference between the cases, as <b>most gentiles are steeped in sexual immorality.</b> Therefore, presumably, they engaged in intercourse with the captive woman. However, in the case of the woman in seclusion there is no presumption that she engaged in intercourse specifically with a man with flawed lineage. Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them: There is no steward for</b> restraining <b>sexual immorality,</b> and therefore, everyone is suspect in that regard. Therefore, this woman, since she engaged in intercourse, lost her presumptive status of virtue, and there is no basis to trust her that it was with a person of impeccable lineage.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>In what</b> case <b>are these</b> divergent <b>statements</b> of Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said?</b> It is <b>in the case of the testimony of a woman with regard to herself,</b> to render her fit to marry a priest. <b>However,</b> in the case of <b>testimony of a woman with regard to</b> the fact that the father of <b>her daughter</b> is a man of unflawed lineage, <b>everyone agrees</b> that her testimony is not deemed credible, and the legal status of <b>the child</b> is that of <b>a <i>shetuki</i>,</b> the identity of whose father is unknown and to whom all the stringencies that apply to a <i>mamzer</i> apply, due the uncertainty of his lineage.
The Gemara seeks to understand the exchange between Rabbi Yehoshua and the Sages. <b>What did he say to them and what did they reply to him?</b> It appears that they were not discussing the same case. <b>This is what</b> the Sages <b>are saying to him: You answered us concerning the pregnant woman,</b> asserting that there is testimony in the case of the pregnant woman comparable to the testimony in the case of the captive. However, <b>what will you answer us concerning the</b> woman who was seen <b>speaking</b> to a man? In that case, there is no testimony that she had intercourse. Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them:</b> The case of <b>speaking is the same as</b> the case of the <b>captive,</b> as there is reason to believe that she engaged in intercourse. The Sages <b>said to him:</b> The case of <b>a captive is different, as most gentiles are steeped in sexual immorality,</b> and presumably they engaged in intercourse with the captive woman. Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them:</b> In <b>this</b> case <b>too, since she secluded herself</b> with a man, based on the principle: <b>There is no steward for</b> restraining <b>sexual immorality,</b> presumably she engaged in intercourse with him.
With regard to the dispute over the meaning of the term: Speaking, the Gemara says: <b>In any event,</b> from this discussion it is clear that the <i>tanna</i> <b>is teaching two</b> different cases, one case of <b>speaking,</b> where there is uncertainty whether she engaged in intercourse, <b>and</b> one case where she is <b>pregnant,</b> and there is no uncertainty in that regard. The Gemara suggests: This is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rav Asi,</b> who explained that speaking in the mishna means that she engaged in intercourse. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, this is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of his opinion.
The Gemara asks with regard to the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>derive</b> this distinction between a captive woman and a woman who secluded herself with a man from the fact <b>that there,</b> in the case of the captive, <b>the majority</b> of the men <b>in her proximity are unfit</b> and of flawed lineage, <b>but here,</b> where she was secluded, <b>the majority of the men in her proximity are honorable</b> and of impeccable lineage. Since she is unmarried, most men are not unfit for her. The Gemara notes: The fact that the <i>tanna</i> did not derive the distinction from that source <b>supports</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said:</b> According <b>to the statement of</b> Rabban Gamliel, <b>the one who deems her fit</b> to marry a priest, <b>he deems her fit even in</b> a case <b>where the majority of the men</b> in her proximity <b>are unfit.</b> According <b>to the statement of</b> Rabbi Yehoshua, <b>the one who deems her unfit</b> to marry a priest, <b>he deems her unfit even in</b> a case where <b>the majority</b> of the men in her proximity <b>are fit.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> According <b>to the statement of the one who deems her fit</b> to marry a priest and accepts her claim that she engaged in intercourse with a man of unflawed lineage, <b>he deems her daughter fit</b> as well. According <b>to the statement of the one who deems her unfit, he deems her daughter unfit</b> as well. <b>But Rabbi Elazar says:</b> According <b>to the statement of the one who deems her fit, he deems her daughter unfit.</b>
<b>Rabba said: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Elazar,</b> who distinguishes between the effectiveness of the woman’s claim in determining her own status and its effectiveness in determining the status of her daughter? The reason is that <b>granted,</b> her claim is effective with regard to her status because <b>she has the presumptive status of fitness.</b> Therefore, until proven otherwise, she retains that status. <b>Her daughter,</b> the identity of whose father is unknown, <b>does not have the presumptive status of fitness.</b> Therefore, a full-fledged proof is required to establish her fitness.
<b>Rabbi Elazar raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what</b> case <b>are these</b> disputing <b>statements</b> of Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said?</b> It is <b>in the case of a woman’s testimony with regard to herself. However,</b> in the case of <b>testimony of a woman with regard to her daughter, everyone agrees</b> that her testimony is not credible, and the legal status of <b>the child is</b> that of <b>a <i>shetuki</i>. What, is it not</b> that contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan, the <i>baraita</i> means that the child is <b>a <i>shetuki</i> and unfit</b> until proof can be brought that the lineage of the father is unflawed? The Gemara rejects that objection: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that the child is <b>a <i>shetuki</i>,</b> as her lineage is unclear, but she is nevertheless <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And is there</b> a case of <b>a <i>shetuki</i></b> who is nevertheless <b>fit?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, as</b> in the statement <b>of Shmuel. As Shmuel said:</b> If <b>ten priests</b> were <b>standing and one of them left and engaged in intercourse, the child is a <i>shetuki</i>,</b> literally one who is silenced, because the identity of the father is unclear. In that case it is clear that the child is fit, because it is known that the father is a priest of flawless lineage.
The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> sense <b>is</b> this child <b>a <i>shetuki</i>? If we say</b> that it means <b>that one silences him from</b> a claim to <b>his father’s assets</b> and he does not inherit his estate, that is <b>obvious. Do we know who his father is?</b> It could be any one of the ten. <b>Rather,</b> it means <b>that one silences him from</b> a claim to <b>the status of priesthood.</b> Although there is no doubt that his father is a priest, the son is not a priest, <b>as it is written: “And it shall be for him and for his offspring after him an everlasting covenant of priesthood”</b> (Numbers 25:13). From this it is derived: In the case of a priest <b>whose offspring are attributed to him,</b> his offspring are priests; to the <b>exclusion of this</b> priest, <b>whose offspring are not attributed to him,</b> and whose offspring are not priests. This child, therefore, is a <i>shetuki</i> only in the sense that he may not perform the Temple service as a priest. However, he is permitted to marry a Jewish woman.
Apropos paternity, the Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain betrothed man and his betrothed,</b> who was pregnant, <b>who came before Rav Yosef. She said</b> that she conceived <b>from</b> relations with <b>him, and he said:</b>

Daf 14a

<b>Yes,</b> she conceived <b>from</b> relations with <b>me. Rav Yosef said:</b> The ruling here is clear, as <b>with regard to what</b> suspicion need we <b>be concerned? First, he concedes</b> that he is the father. <b>And furthermore, didn’t Rav Yehuda say</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel,</b> and even if he didn’t admit that the child was his, the woman’s claim is accorded credibility?
<b>Abaye said to him: And in this</b> case, based on the fact that you cited two reasons to deem the child fit, is that to say <b>when he does not admit</b> that he is the father <b>Rabban Gamliel deems</b> the child <b>fit? But didn’t Shmuel say to Rav Yehuda: Big-toothed</b> one, <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel,</b> i.e., that she is accorded credibility, <b>but you should not perform an action</b> based on this ruling <b>unless the majority of the men in her proximity are honorable</b> and of impeccable lineage, corroborating her claim. <b>And here,</b> since she is betrothed, <b>the majority of the men in her proximity are unfit,</b> as a child fathered by any man other than her betrothed is a <i>mamzer</i>. Shmuel should not have ruled that the <i>halakha</i> was in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Gamliel.
Rav Yosef said to Abaye: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>itself should pose a difficulty for you,</b> as on the one hand Shmuel rules that it is the <b><i>halakha</i> and</b> on the other hand he adds: <b>But you should not perform an action</b> based on this ruling. <b>Rather, what have you to say</b> to explain this contradiction? <b>This</b> statement that one relies on the woman’s claim only if a majority of men in her proximity are of unflawed lineage is <b><i>ab initio</i>. That</b> statement that one may rely on the woman’s claim regardless of the status of the men in her proximity is <b>after the fact. And this</b> case of the betrothed woman, <b>too, is like</b> a case <b>after the fact,</b> as failure to rely on her claim will render her child a <i>mamzer</i>. Therefore, in this case, Shmuel would rule that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Gamliel.
§ <b>Abaye raised a contradiction before Rava</b> from a mishna (<i>Eduyyot</i> 8:3): <b>Did Rabbi Yehoshua say that</b> the woman <b>is not deemed credible</b> and her claim is not accepted? <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction: Rabbi Yehoshua and Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira testified concerning the widow</b> whose late husband was a member <b>of a</b> priestly <b>family of questionable lineage [<i>issa</i>], that she is fit to</b> marry into the <b>priesthood.</b> Since the matter is uncertain, the woman retains her presumptive status of fitness and her late husband is presumed to be of unflawed lineage.
Rava <b>said to him: How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of the widow, one could say: A <b>woman</b> who <b>marries investigates</b> the lineage of her prospective husband before the wedding <b>and</b> only then <b>marries.</b> Therefore, one may rely on her presumptive status of fitness and deem her fit to marry a priest. <b>Here,</b> can it be said that <b>a woman</b> who <b>engages in licentious intercourse investigates</b> the lineage of her partner and only then <b>engages in licentious intercourse?</b>
<b>Rava said</b> with regard to the contradiction that was raised: Is the contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua and</b> another statement <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua difficult,</b> and the contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabban Gamliel and</b> another statement <b>of Rabban Gamliel not difficult? But isn’t it taught in the latter clause</b> of that mishna with regard to the widow whose late husband was from a priestly family of questionable lineage that <b>Rabban Gamliel said to them: We accept your testimony</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i>, <b>but what</b> can <b>we do, as Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai decreed not to convene a court for this</b> purpose of ruling the woman fit, <b>because the priests obey you</b> when your ruling calls <b>to distance</b> a woman of questionable lineage from marrying them, <b>but not</b> when your ruling calls <b>to bring her near</b> and deem her fit to marry them. Apparently, Rabban Gamliel did not accept the lenient ruling in the case of the widow, contrary to his statement here that she is accorded credibility.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabban Gamliel and</b> another statement <b>of Rabban Gamliel is not difficult. There,</b> in the case of the woman who engaged in intercourse with an unidentified man, her claim that the lineage of the man is unflawed is <b>a certain</b> claim. <b>Here,</b> in the case of the widow, her claim that his lineage is unflawed is <b>an uncertain</b> claim, because there is objective uncertainty with regard to his lineage.
The contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua and</b> another statement <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua is</b> similarly <b>not difficult. There,</b> in the case of the woman who engaged in intercourse with an unidentified man, there is only <b>one uncertainty:</b> Is the lineage of the man with whom she engaged in intercourse flawed or unflawed? In the case of one uncertainty, the ruling is stringent. <b>Here,</b> in the case of the widow, there are <b>two uncertainties</b> with regard to the objective situation. It is established that there is uncertainty with regard to one of the members of the family whether or not he is a <i>ḥalal</i>. The first uncertainty is whether her late husband is the member of that family with regard to whom the uncertainty exists. Even if it is established that her late husband is indeed the one with regard to whom the uncertainty exists, there remains an uncertainty whether he is in fact a <i>ḥalal</i>.
<b>Therefore,</b> according <b>to Rabban Gamliel, a certain</b> claim is so <b>powerful for him that even in</b> a case where there is <b>one uncertainty, he also deems her fit</b> to marry a priest. <b>And an uncertain</b> claim is so <b>insignificant for him that even in</b> a case where there is <b>a compound uncertainty, he also deems her unfit</b> to marry a priest. According <b>to Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> a case where there is <b>one uncertainty</b> is so <b>powerful for him that even in</b> a case where she makes <b>a certain</b> claim, <b>he also deems her unfit. And</b> the case of <b>a compound uncertainty is</b> so <b>insignificant for him that even if she makes an uncertain</b> claim, <b>he also deems her fit.</b>
§ Apropos the widow, <b>the Rabbis taught: Who is the widow</b> whose late husband was a member <b>of a</b> priestly <b>family of questionable lineage</b> and is fit to marry a priest? It is one who married into <b>any</b> family <b>that does not have</b> the status of being unfit, <b>neither due to</b> uncertain <b><i>mamzer</i> status, nor due to</b> uncertain <b>Gibeonite status, nor due to</b> uncertain status as <b>slaves of kings,</b> who would force Jewish women, even daughters of priests, to marry them. <b>Rabbi Meir said:</b>

Daf 14b

<b>I heard</b> that with regard to the widow of <b>any</b> family <b>that has none of these</b> uncertainties associated with it, <b>one</b> allows <b>her to marry</b> members of <b>the priesthood.</b> The only uncertainty where this ruling applies is in the case of uncertain <i>ḥalal</i> status.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Meir, and likewise Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya would say in accordance with his statement: Who is the widow</b> whose late husband was a member <b>of a</b> priestly <b>family of questionable lineage?</b> It is a widow who marries into <b>any</b> family in <b>which</b> a person with regard to whom there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether or not he is a <b><i>ḥalal</i> was assimilated</b> among its members. Therefore, she is referred to as a widow of dough [<i>issa</i>]. Just as dough is the result of a mixture of several ingredients, this family too has a person with regard to whom there is uncertainty whether he is a <i>ḥalal</i> mixed within it.
The reason for the distinction between uncertain <i>ḥalal</i> status and uncertain <i>mamzer</i> status is that <b>Jews identify the <i>mamzerim</i> that are among them,</b> and there is no concern lest they assimilate into families of unflawed lineage. <b>But they do not identify the <i>ḥalalin</i> among them.</b> Therefore, there is concern lest a <i>ḥalal</i> assimilate into the family.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Who is the widow</b> whose late husband was a member <b>of a</b> priestly <b>family of questionable lineage?</b> It is one who married into <b>any</b> family <b>that does not have</b> the status of being unfit, <b>neither due to</b> uncertain <b><i>mamzer</i> status, nor due to</b> uncertain <b>Gibeonite status, nor due to</b> uncertain status as <b>slaves of kings.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>However,</b> if it is due to uncertain <b><i>ḥalal</i></b> status, her marriage to a priest is deemed <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>these</b> flaws in lineage, uncertain <i>mamzer</i> status and Gibeonite status, which render her unfit to marry a priest <b>by Torah</b> law? <b>A <i>ḥalal</i></b> also renders her unfit <b>by Torah</b> law. <b>And furthermore,</b> the <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Meir said: I heard</b> that with regard to the widow of <b>any</b> family <b>that has none of these</b> uncertainties associated with it, <b>one marries her to</b> members of <b>the priesthood. That is</b> identical to the opinion of the <b>first <i>tanna</i>.</b> If there is uncertainty with regard to one in the late husband’s family that he is a <i>mamzer</i> or a Gibeonite, she is unfit to marry a priest; if the uncertainty is with regard to <i>ḥalal</i> status, she is fit to marry a priest. What novel element does Rabbi Meir introduce?
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And furthermore, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Meir, and likewise, Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya would say in accordance with his statement: Who is the widow</b> whose late husband was a member <b>of a</b> priestly <b>family of questionable lineage?</b> It is a widow who marries into <b>any</b> family in <b>which</b> a person with regard to whom there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether or not he is a <b><i>ḥalal</i> was assimilated.</b> Because <b>Jews identify the <i>mamzerim</i> that are among them</b> there is no concern that they will assimilate into families of unflawed lineage, <b>but</b> Jews <b>do not identify the <i>ḥalalin</i> among them.</b> Due to the concern that a <i>ḥalal</i> assimilated into the family, the widow is unfit to marry a priest. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t you say</b> in <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> that if there is uncertainty whether or not a <b><i>ḥalal</i></b> was assimilated among its members, her marriage to a priest is deemed <b>fit?</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The case of one who when called <b><i>mamzer</i> screams</b> and protests that he is being slandered, <b>and</b> when called <b><i>ḥalal</i> is silent, is</b> the subject of the dispute <b>between</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> in the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The first <i>tanna</i> holds: Anyone who</b> when others <b>call him unfit and he is silent, is unfit,</b> as his silence confirms the allegation. <b>And this is what the first <i>tanna</i> is saying: Who is the widow</b> whose late husband was a member <b>of a</b> priestly <b>family of questionable lineage,</b> who is fit to marry a priest? It is one who married into <b>any</b> family <b>that has neither</b> unfitness due to <b>silence</b> in response to allegations of <b><i>mamzer</i> status, nor silence</b> in response to allegations of <b>Gibeonite status, nor silence</b> in response to allegations that they are <b>slaves of kings, nor silence</b> in response to allegations of <b><i>ḥalal</i></b> status. Only a woman who was married into a family that protested in response to all these allegations is fit to marry a priest.
<b>And Rabbi Meir is saying to him:</b> Specifically, each of <b>those</b> silent in response to allegations of <i>mamzer</i> or Gibeonite status or allegations that they are slaves of kings are rendered unfit <b>because these</b> allegations <b>render him unfit</b> to marry <b>into the congregation</b> of Israel. <b>However,</b> despite <b>silence</b> in response to allegations of <b><i>ḥalal</i></b> status, her marriage to a priest is deemed <b>fit. And</b> the fact <b>that he is silent is due to his indifference,</b> as even were he deemed a <i>ḥalal</i> the only restriction would be with regard to marriage to priests.
<b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar is saying to the first <i>tanna</i></b> who quoted <b>Rabbi Meir</b> as saying: I heard, etc. <b>If you heard that Rabbi Meir deems</b> her marriage to a priest <b>fit, in</b> a case of <b>silence</b> in response to allegations, it is <b>not</b> in a case <b>where they called him <i>ḥalal</i> and he is silent; rather,</b> it is in a case <b>where they call him <i>mamzer</i> and he is silent.</b> In that case, the reason <b>he is silent</b> is <b>that he holds:</b> The fact that one is <b>a <i>mamzer</i></b> generates <b>publicity,</b> and since he is not reputed to be a <i>mamzer</i>, he is indifferent to the allegation. <b>However,</b> in a case where he is called <b><i>mamzer</i> and he screams</b> in protest, or where he is called <b><i>ḥalal</i> and he is silent, he is unfit. And</b> the fact <b>that he is silent</b> and does not protest <b>is</b> because <b>he holds:</b> It is <b>sufficient for him that they do not expel him from the congregation</b> of Israel.
The Gemara notes: <b>It is taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> Despite the fact that with <b>silence</b> in response to allegations of <b><i>mamzer</i></b> one is <b>fit; silence</b> in response to allegations of <b><i>ḥalal</i></b> renders one <b>unfit. It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: Despite the fact that with <b>silence</b> in response to allegations of <b><i>ḥalal</i></b> one is <b>fit; silence</b> in response to allegations of <b><i>mamzer</i></b> renders one <b>unfit.</b>
The Gemara explains: The contradiction between the <i>baraitot</i> is <b>not difficult. This</b> second <i>baraita</i> is the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who holds that silence in response to allegations of <i>ḥalal</i> does not render one unfit. And <b>this</b> first <i>baraita</i> is the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who holds that silence in response to allegations of <i>mamzer</i> is motivated by indifference and does not render him unfit; however, silence in response to allegations of <i>ḥalal</i> is an indication that the allegations are true and he is unfit.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Yosei said:</b> There was <b>an incident involving a young girl who descended to fill</b> her jug with <b>water from the spring, and she was raped,</b> and the identity of the rapist was unknown. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said: If the majority of the people of the city marry</b> their daughters <b>to</b> members of the <b>priesthood, this young girl may be married to</b> a member of the priesthood.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman: In accordance with whose</b> opinion is it <b>that Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri stated</b> his opinion? <b>If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel, even in</b> a case where <b>the majority</b> of the people <b>are</b> of <b>flawed lineage as well, he deems</b> her <b>fit</b> to marry into the priesthood. <b>If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, even in</b> a case where <b>the majority</b> of the people <b>are</b> of <b>unflawed lineage, he deems</b> her <b>unfit</b> to marry into the priesthood. Rav Naḥman <b>said to</b> Rava that <b>this</b> is what <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b>

Daf 15a

The <b>incident</b> transpired <b>among the wagons [<i>keronot</i>]</b> in the marketplace <b>of Tzippori</b> on the market day, and this <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Ami, as Rabbi Ami said: And this is</b> the ruling only in a case <b>where there was a contingent of men of unflawed lineage passing there.</b> Due to the fact that both the lineage of the majority of the people of the city where the girl was raped and the lineage of the majority of the passersby is unflawed, the rape is attributed to a man of unflawed lineage. <b>And</b> this ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yannai, as Rabbi Yannai said: If she engaged in intercourse in the wagons, she is fit to</b> marry a member of the <b>priesthood.</b>
The Gemara asks: Does it <b>enter your mind</b> to say that the woman was raped <b>in the wagons,</b> in the crowded area of the marketplace where business is conducted? <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yannai is saying that if <b>she</b> was forced to <b>engage in intercourse at the time of the wagons,</b> i.e., when the convoys pass, <b>she is fit to</b> marry a member of the <b>priesthood. However,</b> if <b>one</b> individual, whose lineage is unknown, <b>left Tzippori and engaged in intercourse</b> with a woman, <b>the child is a <i>shetuki</i></b> and deemed unfit to marry into the priesthood even though the majority of the inhabitants of city are of unflawed lineage.
The Gemara notes: That is <b>similar</b> to <b>this</b> statement <b>that when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>Ze’eiri said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said, and some say</b> directly that <b>Ze’eiri said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: One follows the</b> flawed lineage of the <b>majority of</b> the people in <b>the city and one does not follow</b> the unflawed lineage of <b>the majority of the</b> traveling <b>contingent,</b> and the woman who engaged in intercourse with a member of the itinerant contingent is deemed unfit to marry into the priesthood.
The Gemara asks: <b>On the contrary [<i>kelapei layya</i>],</b> the opposite is logical. <b>These</b> members of the contingent <b>are moving,</b> and in that case the principle is that one follows the majority. <b>And these</b> people of the city <b>are fixed and standing</b> in one place, and in that case the principle is that even if the lineage of the majority is unflawed, the uncertainty is treated as if it were equally balanced.
<b>Rather,</b> this is what Rabbi Yannai is saying: <b>One follows the</b> lineage of the <b>majority of the city, and that is</b> specifically in a case <b>where there is a majority</b> of men of unflawed lineage in the passing <b>contingent</b> together <b>with</b> the city’s unflawed majority. In that case, from both perspectives the intercourse can be attributed to a man of unflawed lineage. <b>However, neither does one follow the</b> unflawed lineage of the <b>majority of the city alone, nor</b> does he <b>follow the</b> unflawed lineage of the <b>majority of the contingent alone. What is the reason</b> that one does not follow the lineage of the majority of the moving contingent? It is because the Sages issued <b>a decree</b> not to follow <b>the majority of the contingent due to the majority of the city,</b> where one does not follow the majority.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> aren’t there cases where one follows <b>the majority of the city as well,</b> as, <b>if</b> one of the residents of the city <b>goes</b> out of the city <b>to her</b> and rapes her, the principle is: The legal status of <b>any</b> item <b>that is separated</b> from the group is that of one <b>separated from the majority?</b> Therefore, there is no reason to issue a decree. The Gemara answers: The decree is <b>necessary only</b> due to a case <b>where she went</b> into the city <b>to them,</b> in which case the rapist <b>is</b> an indistinguishable member of a <b>fixed</b> set, <b>and Rabbi Zeira said:</b> The legal status of uncertainty with regard to <b>any</b> item <b>fixed</b> in its place is that of an uncertainty that is <b>equally balanced,</b> and one does not follow the majority.
The Gemara questions the statement of Rabbi Ami: <b>And do we require two majorities</b> to overcome the minority? <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>nine stores</b> in a city, <b>all of which sell</b> kosher <b>meat</b> from <b>a slaughtered</b> animal, <b>and one</b> other store that <b>sells meat</b> from unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses, and</b> a person <b>bought</b> meat <b>from one of</b> the stores <b>and he does not know from which</b> store <b>he bought</b> the meat, in this case of <b>uncertainty,</b> the meat <b>is prohibited.</b> The legal status of uncertainty with regard to any item fixed in its place is that of an uncertainty that is equally balanced, and one does not follow the majority. This <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And in</b> the case of meat <b>found</b> in the street, outside the stores, <b>follow the majority</b> of stores that sell kosher meat. In other words, the meat is kosher.
<b>And if you would say</b> that one follows the majority only in a case <b>where the gates of the city are unlocked, where</b> the meat could have <b>come</b> to the city <b>from the majority</b> of kosher meat <b>outside</b> the city and only by combining that majority with the majority of kosher meat stores inside the city, creating two majorities, is the meat ruled kosher; <b>but didn’t Rabbi Zeira say: Even if the city gates are locked,</b> one follows the majority and the meat is kosher even without a double majority? The Gemara answers: The Sages require two majorities only in cases such as establishing the identity of the child’s father, because they <b>established a higher standard with regard to</b> matters of <b>lineage.</b> However, in other cases, e.g., concerning kosher meat, a single majority is sufficient.
§ In terms of the matter <b>itself, Rabbi Zeira said:</b> The legal status of uncertainty with regard to <b>any</b> item <b>fixed</b> in its place is that of an uncertainty that is <b>equally balanced, both</b> when it leads to <b>leniency,</b> e.g., in a case where, were one to follow the majority, the ruling would be stringent, and when it leads to <b>stringency,</b> e.g., in a case where, were one to follow the majority, the ruling would be lenient.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where does Rabbi Zeira</b> learn that the legal status of uncertainty with regard to any item fixed in its place is that of an uncertainty that is equally balanced, both when it leads to leniency and when it leads to stringency? <b>If we say</b> that it is derived <b>from</b> the case of <b>nine stores</b> in a city, <b>all of which sell</b> kosher <b>meat</b> from <b>a slaughtered</b> animal, <b>and one</b> other store that sells <b>meat</b> from unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses, and</b> a person <b>bought</b> meat <b>from one of</b> the stores <b>and he does not know from which</b> store <b>he bought</b> the meat, in this case of <b>uncertainty</b> the meat <b>is prohibited. And in the</b> case of meat <b>found</b> in the street, outside the stores, <b>follow the majority</b> of stores that sell kosher meat, and therefore the meat would be kosher. <b>There,</b> in the first case, ruling it an equally balanced uncertainty is <b>a stringency,</b> as there is a majority of kosher stores.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Zeira learns that <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> a different <i>baraita</i>. If there were <b>nine frogs,</b> which is a creeping animal that does not impart ritual impurity while alive or when dead, <b>and one</b> ritually impure <b>creeping animal,</b> whose carcass imparts ritual impurity, <b>among them, and</b> a person <b>touched one of the</b> ten creatures, <b>and he does not know which of them he touched,</b> in this case of <b>uncertainty</b> the person is <b>ritually impure. There too,</b> ruling it an equally balanced uncertainty is <b>a stringency,</b> as the majority of the creeping animals do not impart impurity.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Zeira learns that <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the continuation of that <i>baraita</i>. If there are <b>nine creeping animals,</b> whose carcasses impart ritual impurity, <b>and one frog among them, and</b> a person <b>touched one of them, and he does not know which of them he touched,</b> if it was <b>in the private domain,</b> in this case of <b>uncertainty</b> the person is <b>ritually impure,</b> as all cases of uncertainty with regard to ritual impurity are ruled impure in the private domain. This is derived from the case of <i>sota</i>. However, <b>in the public domain,</b> in that case of <b>uncertainty</b> the person is <b>ritually pure.</b> Although contact with a creeping animal from the majority would render him ritually impure, since the uncertainty is with regard to a fixed group, its legal status is that of an equally balanced uncertainty, and in the public domain he is ritually pure. Rabbi Zeira learns that <i>halakha</i> from this case of leniency.
After citing a tannaitic source for Rabbi Zeira’s opinion, the Gemara asks: <b>And from where in the Torah do we</b> derive that the legal status of any item fixed in its place is like that of an uncertainty that is equally balanced, both when it leads to leniency and when it leads to stringency? It is derived from <b>the verse</b> that <b>states</b> with regard to a murderer: <b>“And lie in wait for him, and rise up against him”</b> (Deuteronomy 19:11), indicating that one is liable <b>only</b> in a case <b>where he intends to</b> kill <b>him.</b> One who intended to kill one person and inadvertently killed another is exempt from punishment. <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that one is liable in that case, interpret that verse? The Sages <b>of the school of Rabbi Yannai say:</b> It <b>excludes</b> the case <b>of</b> one who <b>throws a stone into a crowd</b> and did not intend to kill a specific person.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of the case where he threw the stone and is exempt? <b>If we say that there are nine gentiles</b> in the crowd <b>and one Jew among them,</b> even without the verse, <b>let him derive</b> the exemption from the fact <b>that they are a majority of gentiles. Alternatively,</b> even if we say that <b>half</b> of the ten people are considered gentiles <b>and half</b> are considered Jews, let him derive the exemption from the principle: In a case of <b>uncertainty</b> concerning a <b>life-threatening</b> situation, the <i>halakha</i> <b>is lenient.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the verse is <b>necessary</b> only in a case where <b>there are nine Jews and one gentile among them.</b> Were the ruling to follow the majority the one who threw the stone would be liable. But in that case, <b>because the gentile is fixed</b> among them, <b>and</b> the legal status of <b>any</b> item <b>fixed</b> in its place is <b>like</b> that of an uncertainty that is <b>equally balanced,</b> he is exempt, based on the principle: In a case of uncertainty concerning a life-threatening situation, the <i>halakha</i> is lenient. Apparently, even in cases of Torah law in which the result would be a leniency, i.e., exemption from the death penalty for murder, the legal status of any item fixed in its place is like that of an uncertainty that is equally balanced.
§ With regard to the matter of following the majority in cases of lineage, it <b>was stated</b> that there is an amoraic dispute: <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi</b> said that <b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> in the mishna, and it is permitted for the young girl who was raped to marry a priest. <b>And Rav Ḥanan bar Rava</b> said that <b>Rav said:</b> That <b>was a provisional edict</b> issued in exigent circumstances. However, typically, with regard to matters of lineage two majorities are required.
<b>Rav Yirmeya raised an objection</b> to the ruling of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi, who apparently ruled that even in cases where there is one majority the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei: <b>And in matters of lineage, do we not require two majorities,</b> a majority of the city’s inhabitants and a majority of the passing contingent? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Makhshirin</i> 2:7):

Daf 15b

If there is a city in which both Jews and gentiles reside, and <b>one found</b> an unidentified, <b>abandoned baby in</b> the city, <b>if</b> there is a <b>majority of gentiles</b> in the city the baby is deemed <b>a gentile; if</b> there is a <b>majority of Jews</b> in the city the baby is deemed <b>a Jew.</b> If <b>half</b> the population is gentile and <b>half</b> Jewish, the baby is deemed <b>a Jew.</b>
<b>And Rav said</b> with regard to this mishna: The Sages <b>taught</b> that if there is a majority of Jews in the city the baby is deemed a Jew <b>only</b> with regard <b>to sustaining him; however,</b> with regard <b>to lineage,</b> e.g., marrying him to a Jewish woman, <b>no,</b> he is not deemed a Jew based on the majority and would require conversion. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> It was taught that he is deemed a Jew in order <b>to create an opening</b> in <b>a heap</b> of debris <b>on his</b> behalf on Shabbat, i.e., desecrating Shabbat in order to save his life. Apparently, contrary to the ruling of Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi, Rav holds that a single majority is insufficient to deem him Jewish in matters of lineage.
The Gemara answers: Rav Yirmeya <b>overlooked that which Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> with regard to the mishna: The <b>incident</b> of the rape of the young girl transpired <b>among the wagons</b> in the marketplace <b>of Tzippori,</b> and there were two majorities; the majority of the inhabitants of the city and the majority of the passing contingent. Therefore, when Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi ruled that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, i.e., that the young girl may marry a priest, it was in a case of two majorities.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if the case in the mishna is one of two majorities, according <b>to Rav Ḥanan bar Rava who said</b> in the name of Rav: <b>That was a provisional edict</b> issued in exigent circumstances, meaning that two majorities were required in that case but typically one majority is sufficient, it is <b>difficult.</b> Didn’t Rav say that in matters of lineage one majority is insufficient? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> is not difficult. <b>The one who teaches this,</b> that the ruling in our mishna was a provisional edict, <b>does not teach that</b> statement that Rav Yehuda said that Rav said that the incident took place among the wagons in the marketplace of Tzippori. Rather, he holds that there was a single majority and nevertheless, due to exigent circumstances, the girl was permitted to marry into the priesthood, although generally two majorities are required in cases of lineage.
§ Apropos the case of the abandoned baby, the Gemara analyzes the matter <b>itself:</b> If there is a city in which both Jews and gentiles reside, and <b>one found</b> an unidentified, <b>abandoned baby in</b> the city, <b>if</b> there is a <b>majority of gentiles</b> in the city the baby is deemed <b>a gentile. If</b> there is a <b>majority of Jews</b> in the city the baby is deemed <b>a Jew.</b> If <b>half</b> the population is gentile and <b>half</b> Jewish, the baby is deemed <b>a Jew. Rav said:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that the baby is deemed a Jew <b>only</b> with regard <b>to sustaining him; however,</b> with regard <b>to lineage, no. And Shmuel said:</b> It was taught that he is deemed a Jew in order <b>to create an opening</b> in <b>a heap</b> of debris <b>on his</b> behalf on Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>And did Shmuel say that? But didn’t Rav Yosef say</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: One does not follow the majority in matters</b> involving <b>saving a life?</b> Even if there is the slightest concern that the life of a Jew may be in danger, one takes all steps necessary to save him, even on Shabbat. <b>Rather, when the statement of Shmuel was stated</b> with regard to saving a life <b>it was stated concerning the first clause</b> of the mishna: <b>If</b> there is a <b>majority of gentiles</b> in the city the baby is deemed <b>a gentile. Shmuel said: And</b> with regard <b>to creating an opening</b> in <b>a heap</b> of debris <b>on his</b> behalf <b>[<i>lefake’aḥ alav et hagal</i>]</b> on Shabbat, <b>that is not so.</b> Even if there is a gentile majority in the city, one does not follow the majority in cases involving the saving of a life.
The mishna continues: <b>If</b> there is a <b>majority of gentiles</b> the baby is deemed <b>a gentile.</b> The Gemara asks: With regard <b>to what <i>halakha</i></b> was this stated? <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It was stated in order <b>to feed</b> the baby <b>animal carcasses,</b> i.e., non-kosher food.
And it is taught in the mishna: <b>If</b> there is a <b>majority of Jews</b> the baby is deemed <b>a Jew.</b> The Gemara asks: With regard <b>to what <i>halakha</i></b> was this stated? <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It was stated in order <b>to return lost property to him,</b> as one is required to return lost property to a Jew.
And it is taught in the mishna: If <b>half</b> the population is gentile and <b>half</b> Jewish, the baby is deemed <b>a Jew.</b> The Gemara asks: With regard <b>to what <i>halakha</i></b> was this stated? <b>Reish Lakish said:</b> It was stated with regard <b>to damages.</b> In terms of payment of damages, the courts judge him as a Jew. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If we say that our ox,</b> one belonging to a Jew, <b>gored his ox,</b> one belonging to a person of uncertain status, and he claims that he should be compensated for the damages as a Jew, <b>let the</b> owner of the ox that gored <b>say to him: Bring proof that you are a Jew, and take</b> payment. Due to the uncertainty surrounding his status, he is unable to produce any proof.
Rather, this <i>halakha</i> is <b>necessary only</b> in a case <b>where his ox gored our ox,</b> one belonging to a Jew. In that case, there is no question that <b>he pays half</b> the damage, which is the payment when an innocuous ox belonging to a Jew gores an ox belonging to a Jew. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the other half,</b> which the owner of the gored ox is claiming, asserting that this person of uncertain status is a gentile and therefore liable to pay full damages, the owner of the ox that gored can <b>say to</b> the claimants: <b>Bring proof that I am not a Jew and I will give you</b> payment of the other half of the damages. It is with regard to that case that Reish Lakish ruled that in a case of uncertainty, the baby has the presumptive status of a Jew, and it is incumbent upon the claimant to prove otherwise.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a woman who was widowed or divorced,</b> and is now claiming payment of her marriage contract that is not before the court, and <b>she says: You married me</b> as <b>a virgin,</b> who is entitled to two hundred dinars, <b>and he says: No; rather, I married you</b> as <b>a widow,</b> who is entitled to one hundred dinars, then, <b>if there are witnesses that she went out</b> of her father’s house to her wedding <b>with a <i>hinnuma</i> or</b> with <b>her hair uncovered,</b> in a manner typical of virgins, payment of <b>her marriage contract is two hundred</b> dinars. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says: Even</b> testimony that there was <b>distribution of roasted grain,</b> which was customary at weddings of virgins, constitutes <b>proof</b> that she is a virgin.
Several disputes between Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Yehoshua were cited previously with regard to the credibility accorded to the respective claims of parties to a dispute. Based on one of those disputes, the <i>tanna</i> adds: <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua concedes in</b> a case where <b>one says to another: This field,</b> which is currently in my possession, <b>belonged to your father and I purchased it from him, that he is deemed credible,</b> and his entire claim is accepted. The court accepts not only his admission that it once belonged to the other’s father, but also his statement that he purchased it.

Daf 16a

This is so, <b>as the mouth that prohibited,</b> i.e., claimed that the field had belonged to the other’s father, <b>is the mouth that permitted,</b> i.e., claimed that he purchased the field. Even if he had not admitted that it had belonged to the other’s father, the field would have remained in his possession. Therefore, his claim is accepted. <b>However, if there are witnesses that the field belonged to his father, and</b> the one who has the field in his possession <b>says: I purchased it from him, he is not deemed credible</b> and his claim is rejected.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that the bride’s claim is accepted <b>is</b> specifically due to the fact <b>that there are witnesses</b> that she went out of her father’s house to the wedding with a <i>hinnuma</i>. <b>However, if there are no witnesses,</b> the <b>husband is deemed credible. Let us say that</b> the <b>unattributed</b> ruling that <b>we learned</b> in the mishna <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel, as, if</b> the ruling was according to <b>Rabban Gamliel, didn’t he say</b> that <b>she is deemed credible?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Even</b> if <b>you will say</b> that the ruling in the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel, Rabban Gamliel stated</b> his opinion <b>only there, in</b> a case where the claim of the bride is <b>certain and</b> the claim of the groom is <b>uncertain,</b> as the groom does not know what actually happened. <b>However, here, in</b> a case where the claim of the bride is <b>certain and</b> the claim of the groom is also <b>certain,</b> as he is certain that he married her as a widow, Rabban Gamliel <b>did not say</b> that her claim is deemed credible.
The Gemara asks: <b>And he who asked</b> the question, <b>why did he ask it?</b> The cases are clearly different, as <b>this is</b> a case of <b>a certain</b> claim <b>and a certain</b> claim. The Gemara answers: <b>Since most women are married</b> as <b>virgins,</b> one might have thought that the legal status in this case <b>is like</b> that of a <b>case of a certain</b> claim <b>and an uncertain</b> claim, as her claim is supported by a majority of cases.
<b>And it also stands to reason</b> that the first clause of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Gamliel, who concedes that without witnesses the woman’s claim is not deemed credible, despite the fact that the case is comparable to one of a certain claim and an uncertain claim, <b>as</b> the mishna <b>teaches: And Rabbi Yehoshua concedes. Granted, if you say that Rabban Gamliel is speaking in</b> the first clause of the mishna and <b>he concedes</b> that even though it is similar to a case of certain and uncertain, her claim is not accepted, it works out <b>well.</b> Rabban Gamliel concedes to Rabbi Yehoshua in the first clause of the mishna and the mishna cites a case where Rabbi Yehoshua concedes to Rabban Gamliel. <b>However, if you say that Rabban Gamliel is not speaking in</b> the first clause of the mishna and <b>he</b> does not <b>concede, to whom does Rabbi Yehoshua concede</b> in the latter clause?
The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>Do you think that</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua is</b> in reference <b>to</b> a mishna in <b>this chapter?</b> Actually, <b>it is</b> in reference <b>to</b> the principle of <b><i>miggo</i>, and it is</b> in reference <b>to the first chapter.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua is saying that although he does not accept the claim supported by a <i>miggo</i> in the first chapter, here he accepts the claim supported by the principle: The mouth that prohibited is the mouth that permitted, which is based on the same reasoning as <i>miggo</i>, i.e., the fact that he could have made a more advantageous claim lends credibility to the less advantageous claim. In this case, he could have remained silent and the field would have remained in his possession. If challenged, he could have claimed that the field was his. Therefore, his less advantageous claim, that the field was not originally his but he purchased it from the father of the claimant, is accepted.
The Gemara elaborates: In reference <b>to which</b> case in the first chapter did Rabbi Yehoshua make his statement? <b>If you say</b> that it is in reference <b>to this</b> case (13a): <b>If</b> a single woman <b>was pregnant, and</b> people <b>said to her: What is the nature of that fetus, and she says to them: It is from a man</b> called <b>so-and-so and he is a priest, Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Eliezer say: She is deemed credible, and Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It is <b>not</b> based on the statement emerging <b>from her mouth</b> that <b>we conduct our lives. There, what <i>miggo</i> is there</b> lending credibility to her claim? In that case, <b>her belly is between her teeth,</b> i.e., her pregnancy is conspicuous, and consequently she does not have the option of making the more advantageous claim that she did not engage in intercourse.
<b>Rather,</b> it is in reference <b>to this</b> case (13a): <b>If</b> people <b>saw</b> a woman <b>speaking to one</b> man, <b>and they said to her: What is the nature of this man?</b> And she said to them: <b>He is a man</b> called <b>so-and-so and he is a priest, Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Eliezer say: She is deemed credible, and Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It is <b>not</b> based on the statement emerging <b>from her mouth</b> that <b>we conduct our lives.</b> Again this is challenged: <b>There, what <i>miggo</i> is there? This</b> works out <b>well according to Ze’eiri, who said: What</b> is the meaning of <b>speaking</b> mentioned in the mishna? It means that <b>she secluded herself</b> with a man. In this case there is <b>a <i>miggo</i>. Since, if she wished</b> to lie, <b>she could have said: I did not engage in intercourse</b> at all, <b>and</b> instead <b>she said: I engaged in intercourse</b> with a man of unflawed lineage. Therefore, <b>she is deemed credible</b> according to Rabban Gamliel. <b>However, according to Rav Asi, who said: What is</b> the meaning of <b>speaking?</b> It means that <b>she engaged in intercourse, what <i>miggo</i> is there?</b> There was no better claim available to her.
<b>Rather,</b> it is in reference <b>to this</b> case (13a), where <b>she says: I</b> am one whose hymen <b>was ruptured by wood, and</b> the groom <b>says: No; rather, you are</b> one who <b>was trampled by a man.
