Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Eliezer say: She is deemed credible,</b> and <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It is <b>not</b> on the basis of the statement emerging <b>from her mouth</b> that <b>we conduct our lives. There, what <i>miggo</i> is there?</b>
<b>Granted, according to Rabbi Elazar, who said</b> that the bride claims that she is entitled to a marriage contract of <b>one hundred dinars, and</b> the groom claims that she is entitled to <b>nothing at all,</b> as in that case, there is a <b><i>miggo</i>. Since, if she wished</b> to lie, <b>she could have said: I</b> am one whose hymen <b>was ruptured by wood under your</b> authority after betrothal, <b>and she would have</b> been entitled to <b>two hundred</b> dinars, as she was a virgin at betrothal. <b>And</b> therefore, when <b>she says</b> that her hymen was already ruptured <b>initially,</b> prior to betrothal, <b>when she is</b> entitled to <b>only one hundred dinars, she is deemed credible. However, according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said:</b> The bride claims that she is entitled to a marriage contract of <b>two hundred</b> dinars; <b>and</b> the groom claims that that she is entitled to a marriage contract of <b>one hundred dinars, what <i>miggo</i> is there?</b> Her claim is the most advantageous claim available to her.
<b>Rather,</b> it is in reference <b>to this</b> case (12b): One <b>who marries a woman and did not find her hymen</b> intact, and <b>she says: After you betrothed me, I was raped and his field was inundated,</b> i.e., it is attributable to your own misfortune. <b>And he says: No; rather,</b> you were raped <b>before I betrothed you,</b> and my transaction was a mistaken transaction.
<b>Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Eliezer say: She is deemed credible,</b> and <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It is <b>not</b> based on the statement emerging <b>from her mouth</b> that <b>we conduct our lives, as,</b> in that case there is <b>a <i>miggo</i>. Since, if she wished</b> to lie, <b>she could have said: I</b> am one whose hymen <b>was ruptured by wood under your</b> jurisdiction after betrothal, which is a more advantageous claim, <b>because she does not</b> thereby <b>disqualify herself from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood. But she said: I was raped</b> after betrothal, which is a less advantageous claim, <b>because she disqualified herself from the priesthood. Therefore, Rabban Gamliel says that she is deemed credible. And Rabbi Yehoshua says to Rabban Gamliel: With regard to this <i>miggo</i></b> in the mishna <b>here, I concede to you</b> that the <i>miggo</i> is effective. <b>With regard to that <i>miggo</i> there</b> in the first chapter, <b>I disagree with you.</b>
The Gemara asks: But <b>after all, this is</b> a case of <b><i>miggo</i> and that is</b> a case of <b><i>miggo</i>.</b> In <b>what</b> way, in the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua, <b>is this <i>miggo</i> different from that <i>miggo</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Here,</b> in the case of contested ownership of the field, <b>there is no slaughtered ox before you,</b> i.e., there is no reason to question his claim of ownership, as the field is in his possession. However, <b>there,</b> in the case of the woman who was found not to be a virgin, <b>there is a slaughtered ox before you,</b> i.e., there is reason to question her virginity, and it is only in response to that question that she makes her claim. Therefore, although it is supported by a <i>miggo</i>, Rabbi Yehoshua does not accept her claim.
§ The Gemara resumes discussion of the inference that it drew at the outset with regard to witnesses that the bride was a virgin. <b>And since</b> the Gemara established earlier that the woman’s claim is supported by the fact <b>that most women are married</b> as <b>virgins, if witnesses did not come, what of it?</b> That majority should be sufficient to establish that she married as a virgin. <b>Ravina said:</b> It is <b>because there is</b> room <b>to say</b> that although <b>most women are married</b> as <b>virgins and a minority</b> of women marry as <b>widows</b> or non-virgins, there is an additional presumption: The marriage of <b>anyone who is married</b> as <b>a virgin generates publicity,</b>

Daf 16b

<b>and</b> with regard to <b>this</b> woman, <b>because her</b> marriage <b>did not generate publicity, the</b> effect of the <b>majority is undermined.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> in fact, the marriage of <b>anyone who is married</b> as <b>a virgin generates publicity,</b> and the marriage of this woman did not generate publicity, <b>when witnesses come, what of it? These are false witnesses,</b> as their testimony runs counter to the presumption governing all marriages. <b>Rather, Ravina said</b> that it is not a universal presumption, but a majority. The marriage of <b>most</b> women <b>who are married</b> as <b>virgins generates publicity, but</b> for <b>this</b> woman, <b>since her</b> marriage <b>did not generate publicity, the</b> effect of the <b>majority is undermined.</b> Therefore, the testimony that she went out of her father’s house to her wedding with a <i>hinnuma</i> overrides the lack of publicity.
§ It was stated in the mishna: <b>If there are witnesses that she went out</b> of her father’s house to her wedding <b>with a <i>hinnuma</i>,</b> or with her hair uncovered, in a manner typical of virgins, payment of her marriage contract is two hundred dinars. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> since she collects payment without producing her marriage contract, <b>let us be concerned</b> that <b>she might produce witnesses in this court and collect</b> payment, <b>and then produce</b> her <b>marriage contract in that</b> other <b>court and collect with it</b> payment a second time. <b>Rabbi Abbahu said: This indicates</b> that <b>one writes a receipt</b> indicating that the woman received payment. Were the woman to attempt to collect payment of her marriage contract a second time, her husband would produce the receipt. <b>Rav Pappa said: We are dealing</b> in the mishna <b>with a place where one does not write a marriage contract.</b> It is only in a case where there is no concern lest she produce her marriage contract that she collects payment based on the testimony of witnesses.
<b>And there are</b> some <b>who teach</b> the dispute between Rabbi Abbahu and Rav Pappa with regard <b>to the <i>baraita</i></b> that says: In a case where a woman <b>lost her marriage contract</b> or <b>concealed her marriage contract</b> and she claims that she is unable to find it; or <b>her marriage contract was burned,</b> and there is no proof with regard to the sum to which she is entitled; or practices performed exclusively at the weddings of virgins were performed at her wedding, e.g., people <b>danced before her,</b> or <b>played before her,</b> or <b>passed before her a cup of</b> good <b>tidings or a cloth of virginity; if she has witnesses with regard to any one of these</b> practices, <b>her marriage contract is two hundred</b> dinars.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> since she collects payment without producing her marriage contract, <b>let us be concerned</b> that <b>she might produce witnesses in this court and collect</b> payment, <b>and then produce</b> her <b>marriage contract in that</b> other <b>court and collect</b> payment <b>with it</b> a second time. <b>Rabbi Abbahu said: This indicates</b> that <b>one writes a receipt</b> indicating that the woman received payment. Were the woman to attempt to collect payment of her marriage contract a second time, her husband would produce the receipt. <b>Rav Pappa said: We are dealing</b> in the mishna <b>with a place where one does not write a marriage contract.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> how could Rav Pappa say that the <i>baraita</i> is dealing with a place where one does not write a marriage contract? <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in that <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>lost her marriage contract?</b> The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> her husband <b>wrote her</b> a marriage contract contrary to the local custom. The Gemara asks: If he wrote her a marriage contract, the concern remains that <b>ultimately she</b> will <b>produce</b> the marriage contract <b>and collect</b> payment <b>with it</b> a second time. The Gemara answers: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>lost?</b> The woman <b>lost</b> her marriage contract <b>in the fire.</b> In that case, there is no longer any concern.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, that is</b> the case of: Her marriage contract <b>was burned,</b> listed separately in the <i>baraita</i>. <b>And furthermore, what is there to say</b> with regard to the case of <b>concealed,</b> where the concern that she will collect payment twice remains? <b>And furthermore,</b> if burned comes to explain the meaning of lost, <b>why do I</b> need the <i>baraita</i> to list the case of <b>lost</b> at all? It would have been sufficient for the <i>baraita</i> to mention the case of a burned marriage contract. <b>Rather,</b> the meaning of the <i>baraita</i> is: The legal status of <b>any</b> case where the woman claims that <b>she lost</b> her marriage contract <b>is like</b> that of a case <b>where she concealed</b> it <b>before us, and we give her</b> payment of her marriage contract <b>only when the witnesses say that her marriage contract was burned.</b> Otherwise, even if witnesses testify that the practices characteristic of the wedding of a virgin were performed at her wedding, she does not collect payment of her marriage contract.
The Gemara notes: <b>The one who teaches this</b> dispute between Rabbi Abbahu and Rav Pappa with regard <b>to the <i>baraita</i>, all the more so</b> would he teach it with regard <b>to the mishna.</b> Applying Rav Pappa’s opinion to the mishna does not necessitate the emendation and reinterpretation necessitated by its application to the <i>baraita</i>. <b>However, the one who teaches this</b> dispute with regard <b>to the mishna</b> would <b>not</b> teach it then with regard <b>to the <i>baraita</i>, in accordance with the difficulty</b> raised there, as the plain meaning of the <i>baraita</i> is that it is a place where one writes a marriage contract.
With regard to that same passage in the mishna: <b>If there are witnesses</b> that she went out of her father’s house to her wedding with a <i>hinnuma</i>, or with her hair uncovered, in a manner typical of virgins, payment of her marriage contract is two hundred dinars, the Gemara asks: <b>But let us be concerned lest she</b> first <b>produce witnesses</b> that she went out with <b>a <i>hinnuma</i>, in this court, and collect</b> payment, <b>and then produce witnesses</b> that she went out with <b>a <i>hinnuma</i>, in that court, and collect</b> payment a second time. The Gemara answers: <b>In a place where it is not possible</b> to guarantee that she will not collect her marriage contract more than once in any other way, <b>certainly we write a receipt,</b> even according to the opinion that as a rule, one does not write a receipt.
§ It is taught in that <i>baraita</i>: Or <b>passed before her a cup of</b> good <b>tidings.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is a cup of good tidings? Rav Adda bar Ahava says: A cup of <i>teruma</i> wine is passed before</b> the virgin bride, <b>meaning</b> that <b>this</b> woman <b>would have been eligible to eat <i>teruma</i></b> had she married a priest. <b>Rav Pappa</b> strongly <b>objects to</b> this: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>a widow does not eat <i>teruma</i></b> if she marries a priest? Clearly she does. Therefore, what is the proof from <i>teruma</i> that she is a virgin? <b>Rather, Rav Pappa says:</b> The cup of <i>teruma</i> is passed before her to indicate that <b>this bride is first,</b> as she has not yet engaged in intercourse, <b>like <i>teruma</i></b> that <b>is</b> the <b>first</b> gift separated from the produce.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The custom is that <b>one passes a barrel of wine before her. Rav Adda bar Ahava said: One passes a sealed</b> barrel of wine <b>before a virgin, and one passes an open</b> barrel of wine <b>before a non-virgin.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> is that necessary? <b>Let us pass</b> the sealed barrel <b>before the virgin, and before the non-virgin let us not pass</b> a barrel <b>at all.</b> Why is it necessary to publicize the fact that she is a non-virgin? The Gemara explains: It is necessary, as, <b>at times</b> there could be a case where a non-virgin unilaterally <b>seized two hundred</b> dinars as payment for her marriage contract <b>and said: I was a virgin, and</b> the fact <b>that they did not pass</b> a sealed barrel <b>before me was due to circumstances beyond their control.</b> In order to prevent deceit of that kind, an open barrel is passed before the non-virgin, so that people will remember that she is not a virgin.
§ <b>The Sages taught: How does one dance before the bride,</b> i.e., what does one recite while dancing at her wedding? <b>Beit Shammai say:</b>

Daf 17a

One recites praise of <b>the bride as she is,</b> emphasizing her good qualities. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> One recites: <b>A fair and attractive bride. Beit Shammai said to Beit Hillel:</b> In a case <b>where</b> the bride <b>was lame or blind,</b> does <b>one say</b> with regard <b>to her: A fair and attractive bride? But the Torah states: “Keep you from a false matter”</b> (Exodus 23:7). <b>Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai:</b> According <b>to your statement,</b> with regard to <b>one who acquired an inferior acquisition from the market,</b> should another <b>praise it</b> and enhance its value <b>in his eyes or condemn it</b> and diminish its value <b>in his eyes? You must say</b> that <b>he should praise it</b> and enhance its value <b>in his eyes</b> and refrain from causing him anguish. <b>From here the Sages said: A person’s disposition should always be empathetic with mankind,</b> and treat everyone courteously. In this case too, once the groom has married his bride, one praises her as being fair and attractive.
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said: This is what they sing before brides in the West,</b> in Eretz Yisrael: <b>No eye shadow, and no rouge, and no braiding</b> of the hair, <b>and</b> yet she is comparable to <b>a graceful ibex.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>When the Sages ordained Rabbi Zeira, this</b> is what <b>they</b> metaphorically <b>sang</b> with regard <b>to him</b> in his praise: <b>No eye shadow, and no rouge, and no braiding</b> of the hair, <b>and</b> yet she is comparable to <b>a graceful ibex.</b>
On a related note, the Gemara relates: <b>When the Sages ordained Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi, this</b> is what <b>they sang to them: Anyone from</b> people of <b>this</b> kind <b>and anyone from</b> people of <b>that</b> kind, <b>ordain</b> them <b>for us. Do not ordain for us</b> others, <b>neither from</b> those who <b>corrupt [<i>sarmisin</i>]</b> <i>halakhot</i>, <b>nor from</b> those who are <b>worthless [<i>sarmitin</i>]. And some say: Not from</b> those who provide only <b>one-fifth [<i>ḥamisin</i>]</b> of the reason for a <i>halakha</i>, <b>and not from</b> those whose knowledge is <b>incomplete [<i>turmisin</i>].</b>
The Gemara relates another instance of singing the praise of the Sages: <b>When Rabbi Abbahu would come from the academy to the house of the emperor, the maidservants of the emperor’s house would go out to greet him, and this</b> is what <b>they sang to him: Master of his people and leader of his nation, candle of illumination, blessed is your arrival in peace.</b>
With regard to the mitzva of bringing joy to the bride and groom, the Gemara relates: The Sages <b>said about Rabbi Yehuda bar Elai that he would take a myrtle branch and dance before the bride, and say: A fair and attractive bride. Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak would</b> base his <b>dance on three</b> myrtle branches that he would juggle. <b>Rabbi Zeira said: The old man is humiliating us,</b> as through his conduct he is demeaning the Torah and the Torah scholars. It is further related: <b>When</b> Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak <b>died, a pillar of fire demarcated between him</b> and <b>everyone</b> else, <b>and we learn</b> through tradition <b>that a pillar of fire demarcates only for either one</b> person <b>in a generation or for two</b> people <b>in a generation.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said: His branch [<i>shotitei</i>] was effective for the old man,</b> as it is due to this mitzva that he fulfilled so enthusiastically that he was privileged to receive this great reward. <b>And some say</b> that Rabbi Zeira said: <b>His nonsense [<i>shetutei</i>]</b> was effective <b>for the old man. And some say</b> that he said: <b>His method [<i>shittatei</i>]</b> was effective <b>for the old man.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa would place</b> the bride <b>on his shoulders</b> and dance. <b>The Sages said to him: What</b> is the ruling? Is it permitted for <b>us to do so as well? He said to them: If</b> brides are <b>comparable for you to a beam, fine, but if not, no,</b> you may not.
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said:</b> It <b>is permitted to look at the face of a bride</b> throughout <b>all seven</b> days of the wedding celebration, <b>in order to endear her to her husband,</b> whose appreciation of her beauty will be thereby enhanced. The Gemara notes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with his</b> opinion, as it is prohibited to look at any married woman, even a bride.
§ <b>The Sages taught: One reroutes</b> the funeral procession for burial of <b>a corpse</b> to yield <b>before</b> the wedding procession of <b>a bride. And both this,</b> the funeral procession, <b>and that,</b> the wedding procession, yield <b>before a king of Israel. They said about King Agrippa [<i>Agrippas</i>] that</b> although he was not required to do so, <b>he rerouted</b> his entourage <b>before</b> the wedding procession of <b>a bride, and the Sages praised him</b> for doing so.
The Gemara asks: The Sages <b>praised him;</b> is that to say <b>by inference that he did well</b> in yielding? <b>But didn’t Rav Ashi say: Even</b> according <b>to the one who said</b> with regard to <b>a <i>Nasi</i> who relinquishes</b> the <b>honor</b> due <b>him</b> that <b>his honor is relinquished,</b> i.e., he may do so, with regard to <b>a king who relinquishes</b> the <b>honor</b> due <b>him, his honor is not relinquished. As the Master said</b> that the meaning of the verse <b>“You shall place a king over you”</b> (Deuteronomy 17:15) is <b>that his awe shall be upon you.</b> The Torah established that the subjects’ awe is an essential component of kingship and it is not the prerogative of the king to waive it. The Gemara answers: <b>It was</b> at <b>a crossroads</b> that he encountered the wedding procession, and the fact that he yielded to the bride was not obvious to onlookers. Therefore, the honor due the king was not compromised.
<b>The Sages taught: One suspends the study of Torah to</b> attend <b>the removal of a corpse</b> for burial <b>and to</b> attend <b>the entry of a bride into</b> the wedding canopy. The Sages <b>said about Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Elai, that he would suspend the study of Torah to</b> attend <b>the removal of a corpse</b> for burial <b>and to</b> attend <b>the entry of a bride into</b> the wedding canopy. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case <b>where</b> there are <b>not</b> enough people <b>with him,</b> i.e., accompanying the corpse, to satisfy <b>all his needs,</b> i.e., to appropriately honor him. <b>However, if</b> there are enough people <b>with him</b> to satisfy <b>all his needs, one does not suspend</b> Torah study.
The Gemara asks: <b>And how many</b> people constitute <b>all his needs? Rav Shmuel bar Eini said in the name of Rav: Twelve thousand men and six thousand</b> additional men each sounding <b>a shofar</b> to herald the approaching funeral procession. <b>And some say: Thirteen thousand men and, among them, six thousand</b> men sounding <b>a shofar. Ulla said:</b> All his needs means a crowd large enough <b>so that the men</b> in the funeral possession <b>form a partition</b> stretching <b>from the gate of the city [<i>abbula</i>] until the cemetery. Rav Sheshet, and some say Rabbi Yoḥanan, said: The</b> number of people required for <b>taking</b> of the Torah from the Jewish people with the death of a Torah scholar <b>is equivalent to</b> the number present at <b>its giving</b> to the Jewish people. <b>Just as its giving</b> took place <b>with six hundred thousand</b> men present at Sinai, <b>so too,</b> the <b>taking</b> of the Torah at the funeral of a Torah scholar <b>is with six hundred thousand</b> men. The Gemara notes: <b>This applies only to one who read</b> the Bible <b>and studied</b> mishna, i.e., one who is a student of Torah, and consequently worthy of that honor.

Daf 17b

<b>However, for one who taught</b> others, there is <b>no measure for</b> the number of people attending the funeral.
The mishna continues: <b>And if there are witnesses that she went out</b> of her father’s house to her wedding <b>with a <i>hinnuma</i></b> her marriage contract is two hundred dinars. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> a <b><i>hinnuma</i>? Surḥav bar Pappa said in the name of Ze’eiri:</b> It is <b>a canopy of myrtle</b> over the bride’s head. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It is <b>a veil [<i>kerita</i>]</b> covering the bride’s face <b>under which the bride dozes [<i>menamna</i>].</b>
The mishna continues: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says: Even</b> testimony that there was distribution of roasted grain constitutes <b>proof</b> that she is a virgin. It was <b>taught</b> with regard to the mishna: <b>In Judea,</b> that is <b>proof;</b> however, <b>what are</b> the customs at the weddings of virgins <b>in Babylonia? Rav said: Smearing</b> fragrant <b>oil on the heads of the Sages</b> was customary. <b>Rav Pappa,</b> who was unfamiliar with that practice, <b>said to Abaye: Is the Master saying oil for shampooing</b> the hair? Calling him an orphan because he was ignorant of the custom, <b>he said to him: Orphan, didn’t your mother perform for you smearing of oil on the heads of the Sages at the time of the performance</b> of your wedding ceremony? <b>As</b> this was the case <b>when one of the Sages who arranged for his son</b> to marry into <b>the family of Rabba bar Ulla</b> attended the wedding, <b>and some say that</b> it was <b>Rabba bar Ulla</b> who <b>arranged for his son</b> to marry into <b>the family of one of the Sages; and he smeared oil on the heads of the Sages at the time of the performance</b> of the wedding ceremony.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> custom at the wedding of <b>a widow? Rav Yosef taught: A widow does not have roasted grain [<i>kisanei</i>]</b> distributed at her wedding.
The mishna continues: <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua concedes in</b> a case where <b>one says to another:</b> This field belonged to your father, and I purchased it from him, that he is deemed credible. The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> the mishna <b>teach: Rabbi Yehoshua concedes in</b> a case where <b>one says to another: This field belonged to you, and I purchased it from you.</b>
The Gemara answers: Although Rabbi Yehoshua concedes that his claim is accepted even in that latter case, he addressed the case where the field originally belonged to the father <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>wanted to teach</b> in <b>the latter clause that if there are witnesses that it was</b> the father’s field, <b>and he says: I purchased it from him, he is not deemed credible.</b> That is the <i>halakha</i> only with regard to a field that belonged to the father, and not to the claimant himself. Were it referring to a field that he purchased from the claimant, <b>what are the circumstances?</b>
<b>If</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the one in possession of the field <b>consumed</b> its produce for the three <b>years</b> necessary to establish <b>presumptive ownership, why is his</b> claim that he purchased the field <b>not deemed credible?</b> After three years of unchallenged possession, the purchaser’s claim is sufficient to establish ownership without documentation. <b>And if he did not consume</b> its produce for the three <b>years</b> necessary to establish <b>presumptive ownership,</b> it is <b>obvious that his</b> claim <b>is not deemed credible.</b> Since the distinction between a case where witnesses are present and a case where there are no witnesses present does not apply when the field in question was the property of the claimant, the <i>tanna</i> cited a case where the field belonged to the father.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> the same difficulty may be raised <b>with regard to</b> a field belonging to the claimant’s <b>father as well: If</b> the one in possession of the field <b>consumed</b> its produce for the three <b>years</b> necessary to establish <b>presumptive ownership, why is his</b> claim that he purchased the field <b>not deemed credible? And if he did not consume</b> its produce for the three <b>years</b> necessary to establish <b>presumptive ownership,</b> it is <b>obvious that his</b> claim <b>is not deemed credible.</b> The latter clause is no more applicable to the father’s field than it is to the claimant’s field. Why did the <i>tanna</i> prefer to cite a case where the field belonged to the claimant’s father?
The Gemara answers: <b>Granted, with regard to</b> the case where the field belonged to <b>his father,</b> a circumstance can <b>be found</b> where there is uncertainty with regard to the presumptive ownership of the field, <b>where</b> the one in possession of the field <b>consumed</b> its produce for <b>two</b> of the three years necessary to establish presumptive ownership <b>during the lifetime of the father</b> and <b>one</b> year <b>during the lifetime of the son</b> after the death of his father. <b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna, as Rav Huna said: One cannot establish presumptive ownership of the property of a minor, even</b> after <b>he reached majority.</b> This is because the minor is unaware of the property owned by his father; the fact that he did not challenge the claim of the one in possession of the field proves nothing. Therefore, only two of the three years necessary to establish presumptive ownership have passed.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> since the mishna can be explained only in the case delineated by Rav Huna, <b>did Rav Huna come to teach us a mishna?</b> There is no need for an <i>amora</i> to teach matters that appear in a mishna, as the content of <i>mishnayot</i> is known by all. The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that <b>Rav Huna is stating the inference from the mishna,</b> as the circumstances are not written explicitly in the mishna. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that he is teaching us</b> that even if during the year after the father died his son was no longer a minor, one may not establish presumptive ownership of the property of a minor, <b>even</b> after <b>he reached majority.</b> From the mishna, one could learn only a case where during the third year the son was still a minor.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>in</b> a case where the one in possession of the field says that he purchased the field from the claimant <b>himself. And let him establish</b> the mishna in a case <b>where</b> the one in possession of the field <b>consumed</b> its produce <b>in the presence</b> of the claimant, who was the original owner of the field, for <b>two</b> of the three years necessary to establish presumptive ownership, <b>and</b> consumed its produce not <b>in his presence</b> for <b>one</b> year. <b>And</b> that scenario is in a case <b>where</b> the claimant <b>fled</b> and therefore, the fact that he did not challenge the claim of the one in possession of the field proves nothing.
The Gemara asks: That scenario is referring to one who <b>fled due to what</b> reason? <b>If</b> it is <b>that he fled due to</b> the fact that his <b>life</b> was in jeopardy, it is <b>obvious that</b> the one claiming presumptive ownership <b>is not deemed credible, since</b> the owner of the field <b>is unable to protest,</b> as he fears for his life. <b>And if he fled due to money</b> that he owes, and that is why he does not return to protest the possessor’s occupation of the field, <b>he ought to protest</b> from afar, <b>as we maintain that a protest</b> lodged <b>not in the presence of</b> the one using the field <b>is a</b> legitimate <b>protest.</b> He could have lodged in a court in his place of exile his protest against the illegal occupation of his field.
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 38a): There are <b>three</b> independent <b>lands</b> in Eretz Yisrael with regard to establishing <b>presumptive ownership: Judea, Transjordan, and the Galilee.</b> If the original owner of the field <b>was in Judea</b> and another <b>occupied</b> his field <b>in the Galilee,</b> or if he was <b>in the Galilee</b> and another <b>occupied</b> his field <b>in Judea,</b> that does <b>not</b> establish <b>presumptive ownership, until</b> the one occupying the field <b>will be with</b> the original owner <b>in the same country.</b>
<b>And we discussed</b> that mishna: <b>What does</b> this <i>tanna</i> <b>hold? If he holds that a protest</b> lodged <b>not in the presence of</b> the one using the field <b>is</b> a legitimate <b>protest,</b> then <b>even in</b> the case where one is in <b>Judea and</b> one is in the <b>Galilee</b> the protest should <b>also</b> be legitimate. <b>And if he holds that a protest</b> lodged <b>not in the presence of</b> the one using the field <b>is not</b> a legitimate <b>protest,</b> then <b>even</b> in the case where one is in <b>Judea and</b> the other one is in <b>Judea</b> as well, the protest should <b>also not</b> be legitimate.
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Memel said: Actually</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>holds that a protest</b> lodged <b>not in the presence of</b> the one using the field <b>is</b> a legitimate <b>protest, and</b> the Sages <b>taught this mishna with regard to a crisis period,</b> when travel is perilous and information cannot be transmitted from Judea to the Galilee. Therefore, although no protest was received from the original owner, the occupier does not establish presumptive ownership of the field, because the lack of protest can be attributed to the perilous situation.
The Gemara asked: <b>And</b> if it is due only to the exigent circumstances that the protest is ineffective, <b>what is different</b> about <b>Judea and</b> the <b>Galilee that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>cited</b> specifically these two lands? Ostensibly, even within one of the three lands, if travel and communications are restricted, the same <i>halakha</i> would apply.

Daf 18a

The Gemara answers: The reason that the <i>tanna</i> cited specifically a case where each is located in a different land is <b>that</b> the <b>standard</b> situation with regard to travel between <b>Judea and</b> the <b>Galilee is tantamount to a crisis period,</b> as war was commonplace, and there was a strip of Samaritan territory between Judea and the Galilee.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> in the mishna: <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua concedes in</b> a case where <b>one says to another: I borrowed one hundred</b> dinars <b>from you and repaid</b> the loan <b>to you, that he is deemed credible.</b> The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> chose not to teach that case of the mouth that prohibited is the mouth that permitted <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>wanted to teach</b> in <b>the latter clause: If there are witnesses that he borrowed</b> money <b>from</b> another, <b>and he says: I repaid</b> the loan, <b>he is not deemed credible.</b> However, the <i>tanna</i> would not be able to distinguish between a case where witnesses testify and a case where there are no witnesses, <b>as don’t we hold</b> that in the case of <b>one who lends</b> money to <b>another in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses,</b> the borrower <b>need not repay</b> the loan <b>in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses?</b> Therefore, even if witnesses testify that he took the loan, his claim that he repaid the loan is accepted.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> in the mishna: <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua concedes in</b> a case where <b>one says to another: Your father has one hundred dinars in my possession</b> in the form of a loan, <b>but I provided him</b> with repayment of <b>half</b> that amount, that <b>his</b> claim is <b>deemed credible.</b>
The Gemara answers: There is a tannaitic dispute with regard to that case and the case that the Gemara suggested does not correspond to either opinion. <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion would the mishna be taught? <b>If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis, didn’t they say</b> that in that case <b>he is</b> the equivalent of <b>one returning a lost article?</b> Since the son is unaware that the borrower owes his father money, and the borrower takes the initiative and admits that he owes part of the sum that he borrowed, it is as if he returned a lost article, and clearly his claim is accepted and no oath is required. <b>And if</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, didn’t he say</b> that in that case the borrower is <b>required</b> to take <b>an oath,</b> and only then is his claim accepted?
This dispute is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> There are <b>times when</b> although no one claimed that another owes him money, <b>a person takes an oath on</b> the basis of <b>his own claim. How</b> so? If one says to another: <b>Your father has one hundred dinars in my possession, but I provided him</b> with repayment of <b>half</b> that amount, <b>he</b> is required to <b>take an oath</b> that he repaid half, <b>and that is</b> the case of one <b>who takes an oath on</b> the basis of <b>his own claim. And the Rabbis say:</b> In that case <b>he is merely</b> the <b>equivalent of one returning a lost article, and is exempt</b> from taking an oath.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov not of</b> the opinion that <b>one who returns a lost article is exempt from taking an oath</b> that he did not take part of the sum? He returns what he admitted taking without an oath. <b>Rav says:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where a minor makes a claim</b> against <b>him.</b> The lender’s minor son claims that the borrower did not repay any part of the loan to his father. The borrower’s claim comes in response to that claim. Therefore, his admission is not at all comparable to returning a lost article. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t the Master say: One does not take an oath on</b> the basis of <b>the claim of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor?</b> Due to their lack of cognition, they are not deemed halakhically competent to require another to take an oath based on their claim.
The Gemara answers: In Rav’s statement, <b>what</b> is the meaning of <b>minor?</b> It means one who reached <b>majority,</b> and is therefore halakhically competent. <b>And why does</b> Rav <b>call him a minor?</b> It is due to the fact <b>that with regard to his father’s matters, he is</b> the equivalent of <b>a minor,</b> as he is uncertain about the particulars of his father’s dealings. <b>If so,</b> i.e., that the son making the claim has already reached majority, the language of the <i>baraita</i> is imprecise. Why does the <i>tanna</i> refer to this case as one taking an oath on the basis of <b>his own claim?</b> This is not his own claim; it <b>is the claim of others.</b> The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> employed that language for the following reason: It <b>is the claim of others, but</b> he is taking an oath on the basis of <b>his own</b> partial <b>admission.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>All claims</b> where an oath is required <b>are</b> cases of <b>a claim of others and his own admission.</b> However, in the <i>baraita</i>, Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov introduces his opinion with the phrase: There are times, indicating that the case to which he is referring, that of one taking an oath on the basis of his own claim, is not the standard case of taking an oath.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara suggests an alternative explanation of the tannaitic dispute. <b>Here,</b> Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov and the Rabbis <b>disagree with regard to</b> the statement of <b>Rabba, as Rabba said: Why did the Torah say that</b> one who <b>makes a partial admission</b> in response to <b>the claim</b> is required to <b>take an oath?</b> It is because there is a <b>presumption</b> that <b>a person</b> would <b>not be</b> so <b>insolent in the presence of his creditor</b> as to deny his debt. Presumably, <b>this</b> borrower who made a partial admission <b>would have liked to deny the entire</b> loan, <b>and</b> the fact <b>that he did not deny</b> the entire loan <b>is due to</b> the fact <b>that a person</b> would <b>not be</b> so <b>insolent</b> in the presence of his creditor.

Daf 18b

<b>And,</b> as a result, <b>he would have liked to admit to him that</b> he owes him the <b>entire</b> loan. <b>And</b> the reason <b>that he did not admit to him</b> that he owes him the entire loan is <b>so that he may</b> temporarily <b>avoid</b> paying <b>him. And he rationalizes</b> doing so, saying to himself: I am avoiding him only <b>until</b> the time <b>that I have money, and</b> then <b>I will repay him.</b> Due to the concern that the partial admission is motivated by that rationalization and the claim of the lender is true, <b>the Merciful One says: Impose an oath upon him so that he will admit that</b> he owes him the <b>entire</b> loan.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov maintains:</b> It is <b>no different with regard to</b> the creditor himself, and it is <b>no different with regard to his son.</b> The debtor would <b>not be</b> so <b>insolent</b> as to deny the debt. <b>And therefore, he is not</b> considered as <b>one returning a lost article</b> on his own initiative. Rather, he is considered as one who partially admits his debt in response to a claim, and is therefore required to take an oath. <b>However, the Rabbis maintain: In</b> the presence of the creditor one would <b>not be insolent, but in</b> the presence of <b>his son,</b> who did not lend him the money, <b>he</b> would be <b>insolent</b> and deny the claim entirely. Since he had the option of completely denying the loan and opted to admit to part of the claim, <b>he is</b> considered as <b>one returning a lost article</b> and his claim is accepted without an oath.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>the witnesses who said</b> in their testimony to ratify their signatures in a document: We signed the document and <b>this is our handwriting; however, we were compelled</b> to sign, or <b>we were minors</b> when we signed, or <b>we were disqualified witnesses,</b> e.g., we are relatives of one of the parties, <b>they are deemed credible.</b> Since the document is ratified on the basis of their testimony, it is likewise invalidated on the basis of their testimony. <b>However, if there are</b> other <b>witnesses</b> who testify <b>that it is their handwriting, or if their handwriting emerges</b> on a document <b>from another place,</b> enabling confirmation of their signatures by comparing the two documents, then the witnesses who signed the document <b>are not deemed credible.</b> The document is not invalidated based on their testimony, because ratification of the document is not dependent on their testimony, as their signatures can be authenticated independently.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the latter clause in the mishna, in which it is stated that if there is independent corroboration of the signatures of the witnesses the document is not invalidated based on their testimony, <b>Rami bar Ḥama says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where they said: We were compelled</b> to sign the document <b>due to a monetary</b> threat. Their testimony incriminates them, as they testified falsely for money, and the principle is: The testimony of one who incriminates himself is not accepted. <b>However, if</b> the witnesses <b>said: We were compelled</b> to sign the document <b>due to</b> a threat to our <b>lives, they are deemed credible,</b> as that testimony is not self-incriminating, since in that case it is permitted to testify falsely.
<b>Rava said to</b> Rami bar Ḥama: <b>Is it within their power</b> to retract their testimony? There is a principle: <b>Once a</b> witness <b>stated</b> his testimony in court, <b>he cannot again state</b> testimony that contradicts his previous testimony. <b>And if you say</b> that this principle applies specifically to <b>oral testimony, but</b> with regard to <b>testimony in a document, no,</b> the principle does not apply and one may retract that testimony, <b>didn’t Reish Lakish say:</b> The legal status of <b>witnesses who are signatories on the document becomes like those whose testimony was</b> cross-<b>examined in court.</b> Therefore, just as one may not retract oral testimony, neither may he retract written testimony.
Rather, <b>when</b> the statement of Rami bar Ḥama <b>is stated, it is stated with regard to the first clause</b> of the mishna, that if there is no independent corroboration of their signatures <b>they are deemed credible. Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the witnesses <b>said: We were compelled</b> to sign the document <b>due to</b> a threat to our <b>lives,</b> as in that case they do not incriminate themselves. <b>However, if</b> the witnesses <b>said: We were compelled</b> to sign the document <b>due to a monetary</b> threat, <b>they are not deemed credible. What is the reason</b> that they are not deemed credible? It is based on the principle: <b>One does not render himself wicked,</b> and self-incriminating testimony is not accepted.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> Witnesses who testify to invalidate their signatures on a document <b>are not deemed credible to invalidate</b> the document; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: They are deemed credible.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to the Rabbis,</b> their opinion corresponds to <b>their reasoning</b> stated previously: <b>The mouth that prohibited</b> it, i.e., ratified the document, <b>is the mouth that permitted</b> it, i.e., invalidated the promissory note. <b>However,</b> according <b>to Rabbi Meir, what is the reason</b> that their testimony to invalidate the document is not accepted? <b>Granted,</b> their testimony that they were <b>disqualified witnesses</b> is not accepted, as <b>the lender himself initially ascertains</b> that the witnesses are fit to testify <b>and</b> only then <b>signs</b> them on the document. <b>Similarly,</b> according to Rabbi Meir, their testimony that they were <b>minors</b> is <b>also</b> not accepted, <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, as Reish Lakish said:</b>

Daf 19a

There is <b>a presumption that witnesses sign on the document only if</b> the transaction <b>was made when</b> both parties to the transaction are <b>adults.</b> A corollary of that presumption is that each party would sign only adult witnesses to the document. <b>However,</b> if their testimony was that they were <b>compelled</b> to sign the document, <b>what is the reason</b> that Rabbi Meir rules that their testimony is not accepted?
<b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir maintains: Witnesses that</b> others <b>said to them: Sign</b> a document containing <b>a falsehood and</b> you will <b>not be killed, should</b> allow themselves to <b>be killed and they should not sign</b> a document containing <b>a falsehood.</b> Therefore, even when they testify that they were compelled to sign the document due to a threat to their lives, they are incriminating themselves.
<b>Rava said to him: Now, if</b> the witnesses <b>came before us to consult</b> with the Sages, <b>we say to them: Go sign</b> the document <b>and you should not be killed, as the Master said: You have no matter that stands before saving a life, other</b> than <b>idol worship, forbidden sexual relations, and murder. Now that they signed,</b> do <b>we say to them: Why did you sign?</b> Only in those three cases, when faced with a choice between violating the prohibition and being killed, must one be killed rather than violate the prohibition. Signing a false document does not fall into that category. Why then, according to Rabbi Meir, is their testimony that they were compelled to sign the document not accepted?
<b>Rather, the reason</b> for the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir is in accordance with</b> the statement that <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said, as Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In the case of a borrower who <b>admits with regard to a document that he wrote it,</b> the lender <b>need not ratify</b> the document in court. Once the borrower admits that he wrote the document, he cannot then claim that it is forged or that the debt was repaid. Similarly, once the witnesses testify that they signed the document, it is a credible document that they cannot then invalidate (<i>Tosafot</i>).
§ With regard to <b>the matter itself, Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In the case of a borrower who <b>admits with regard to a document that he wrote it,</b> the lender <b>need not ratify</b> the document in court. <b>Rav Naḥman said to</b> Rav Huna: <b>Why do you</b> need <b>to conceal</b> the reason for your opinion like a <b>thief? If you hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, say: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b> Do not state your opinion in a manner that obscures its connection to a tannaitic dispute.
Rav Huna <b>said to him: And what does the Master hold</b> in a case where the borrower admits that he wrote the document? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: When</b> lenders <b>come before us for judgment, we say to them: Go and ratify your documents and descend</b> and stand before us <b>for judgment.</b> If a lender relies solely on the confession of the borrower, the borrower could claim that although he wrote the document, he then repaid the loan. However, if the document was ratified by the court based on the testimony of the witnesses who signed it, the borrower’s claim that he repaid the loan is not accepted.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who says</b> with regard to a document: <b>This is a document of trust, is not deemed credible.</b> If one claims that the document is a valid document but that no loan actually took place, and instead the borrower trusted the lender and gave him the document in order to borrow money in the future, or as security, he is not deemed credible.
The Gemara asks: In the case to <b>which</b> Rav’s statement is referring, <b>who is saying</b> that the document was a document of trust? <b>If you say</b> that it is the <b>borrower who is saying</b> so, it is <b>obvious</b> that he is not deemed credible. <b>Is it within</b> the <b>power</b> of the borrower to establish that the document is not genuine? <b>But rather,</b> say it is the <b>lender who is saying</b> that it is a document of trust. In that case, not only is he deemed credible, but <b>let a blessing come upon him</b> for admitting that a debt may not be collected with this document. <b>Rather,</b> say it is the <b>witnesses who are saying</b> that it is a document of trust. If so, the question arises: <b>If</b> it is a case <b>where their handwriting emerges from another place,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that they are not deemed credible, as the document is ratified. <b>And if</b> it is a case <b>where their handwriting does not emerge from another place,</b> and the witnesses themselves testify that it is their signatures on the document, but that it was a document of trust, <b>why are they not deemed credible?</b> This is a clear case of: The mouth that prohibited is the mouth that permitted.
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the names of the <i>amora’im</i> who seek to explain Rav’s statement and resolve the problem: <b><i>Beit</i>,</b> the second letter in the name of Rava; <b><i>alef</i>,</b> the first letter in Abaye; and <b><i>shin</i>,</b> the second letter in the name of Rav Ashi. <b>Rava said: Actually,</b> it is <b>the borrower who is saying it, and</b> it can be explained <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rav Huna, as Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In the case of a borrower who <b>admits with regard to a document that he wrote it,</b> the lender <b>need not ratify</b> the document in court. In this case, the borrower admits that he wrote the document and had witnesses sign the document. Rav Yehuda teaches the novel <i>halakha</i> that although the borrower later contends that it was a document of trust, once he admits that he wrote the document, that contention is not accepted.
<b>Abaye said: Actually,</b> it is <b>the lender who said</b> it, <b>and</b> it is in a case <b>where he causes loss to others</b> by invalidating the document and relinquishing his debt. If the lender owes money to others and lacks funds to repay his debt, then his invalidation of the document creates a situation where his creditor is unable to collect the debt. This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says: From where</b> is it derived that in a case where <b>a creditor</b> seeks to collect a debt <b>of one hundred dinars from another, and the other</b> person seeks to collect a debt <b>from another, from where</b> is it derived <b>that one takes</b> money <b>from this</b> second debtor <b>and gives it to the</b> first creditor without the money passing through the debtor of the first, who is the creditor of the third? It is derived as <b>the verse states: “And he shall give to the one to whom he is guilty”</b> (Numbers 5:7). One pays the person to whom the money is owed, even if he did not borrow the money directly from him. When the debtor of the first who is the creditor of the third invalidates the document, he causes a loss to his own creditor.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Actually,</b> it is <b>the witnesses who are saying</b> it, <b>and</b> it is a case <b>where their handwriting does not emerge from another place. And</b> with regard to <b>that which you are saying: Why are they not deemed credible,</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Kahana, as Rav Kahana said: It is prohibited for a person to keep a document of trust in his house, as it is stated:</b> “And <b>let not injustice dwell in your tents”</b> (Job 11:14). This false document is likely to engender injustice when the lender seeks to collect payment with it.

Daf 19b

<b>And Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, says: Conclude from the statement of Rav Kahana</b> that <b>witnesses who said: Our statement was</b> a statement of <b>trust,</b> and the document we signed was a document of trust, <b>are not deemed credible. What is the reason? Since</b> that document <b>is an injustice, they</b> would <b>not sign</b> a document of <b>injustice.</b> Their contention that they signed the document would incriminate them and is therefore not accepted.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: It is prohibited for a person to keep a repaid document within his house, due to</b> the fact <b>that the verse states:</b> “And <b>let not injustice dwell in your tents”</b> (Job 11:14). Even if he does not use the document to collect payment, the concern is that it might fall into the hands of one who will use it illegally to collect payment. <b>In the West,</b> in Eretz Yisrael, <b>they say in the name of Rav:</b> With regard to the first half of the verse: <b>“If iniquity be in your hand, put it far away”</b> (Job 11:14), <b>this</b> is referring to <b>a document of trust and a document of security [<i>passim</i>].</b> With regard to the second half of the verse: <b>“And let not injustice dwell in your tents,” this</b> is referring to <b>a repaid document.</b>
They note: With regard to <b>the one who said</b> that <b>a repaid document</b> is the injustice referred to in the verse, <b>all the more so a document of trust</b> is an injustice and may not be kept, as a document of trust is fundamentally false. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the one who said</b> that a <b>document of trust</b> is the injustice referred to in the verse, <b>however,</b> with regard to <b>a repaid document,</b> perhaps it is permitted to keep it, <b>as, at times</b> people <b>keep it</b> and do not return it to the borrower. This is because in those cases it serves as security <b>for the coins of the scribe,</b> whose fee has not yet been paid by the borrower, who is legally responsible to pay the scribe for writing the document.
On a similar note <b>it is stated,</b> with regard to keeping items with potential to lead to transgression: With regard to a Torah <b>scroll that is not proofread</b> and therefore contains errors, <b>Rabbi Ami says: It is permitted to keep it</b> without emending the mistakes for <b>up to thirty days,</b> and <b>from that time onward it is prohibited to keep it, as it is stated:</b> “And <b>let not injustice dwell in your tents”</b> (Job 11:14).
§ <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>witnesses who say: Our statement was</b> a statement of <b>trust</b> and we signed a document of trust, <b>are not deemed credible.</b> Similarly, witnesses who said: <b>Our statement was</b> a statement accompanied by <b>a declaration</b> by the person who is rendered a debtor by this document that he was coerced into the agreement, thereby invalidating the document, <b>are not deemed credible. Mar bar Rav Ashi said</b> that witnesses who said: <b>Our statement was</b> a statement of <b>trust, are not deemed credible,</b> but witnesses who said: <b>Our statement was</b> a statement accompanied by <b>a declaration, are deemed credible. What is the reason</b> for the difference between the cases? <b>This</b> document, which was accompanied by a declaration, <b>may be written,</b> as it is written under duress. <b>And this</b> document of trust <b>may not be written,</b> as it is fundamentally unjust.
<b>Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman:</b> In a case where the witnesses say: <b>Our statement was a conditional</b> statement, i.e., they verify their signatures, but add that the transaction was contingent upon fulfillment of an unwritten condition, <b>what is</b> the ruling? Perhaps it is similar to the cases of a statement accompanied by a <b>declaration and</b> a statement of <b>trust.</b> In those latter cases, <b>this is the reason</b> that their statement is rejected, <b>as</b> in doing so <b>they undermine the document, and</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>too, he undermines the document. Or perhaps a condition is a different matter,</b> as it does not necessarily undermine the document. Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: When</b> people <b>come before us for judgment</b> in this latter case, <b>we say to them: Go and fulfill your conditions, and</b> then <b>descend</b> before us <b>for judgment.</b>
The Gemara asks: What is the ruling in a case where one <b>witness says:</b> There is a <b>condition</b> attached to the transaction <b>and</b> one <b>witness says: There is no condition? Rav Pappa says: Both are testifying that it is a valid document, and that</b> witness <b>who says:</b> There was a <b>condition</b> attached, <b>is</b> only <b>one</b> witness whose testimony challenges that validity. <b>And the statement of one</b> witness <b>has no</b> validity <b>in a place</b> where there are <b>two</b> witnesses.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua,</b> strongly <b>objects to this: If</b> it is <b>so</b> that testifying that there is a condition is considered to undermine the document, then <b>even</b> if <b>both</b> of the witnesses testify that there was a condition, their testimony should <b>also</b> not be accepted. Once they testified that the document is valid, they cannot give additional testimony that contradicts their original testimony. <b>Rather, we say: These</b> two witnesses <b>are coming to undermine their testimony</b> that the document is valid. These are not two separate testimonies, one that the document is valid and one with regard to the condition. Rather, the second testimony revokes the first. Similarly, <b>this</b> single witness <b>is coming to undermine his testimony as well.</b> Therefore, there is only one witness testifying that the document is valid. The Gemara concludes: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua,</b> and the testimony of even one witness who says that there was a condition attached to the transaction is accepted.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> If <b>two</b> witnesses were <b>signatories on a document and they died, and two</b> strangers <b>from the marketplace came and said: We know that this is their handwriting, but they were coerced</b> into signing the document, <b>or</b> if they said that <b>they were minors</b> when they signed the document, or if they said that <b>they were disqualified witnesses</b> when they signed the document, <b>these</b> strangers <b>are deemed credible,</b> as the mouth that prohibited and ratified the document is the mouth that permitted and undermined the document. <b>However, if there are</b> other <b>witnesses</b> who testify <b>that it is their handwriting, or if their handwriting emerges from another place, from a document that one challenged and</b> that <b>was deemed valid in court, these</b> witnesses from the marketplace are <b>not deemed credible</b> and their testimony does not undermine the validity of the document.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if the testimony of these witnesses is not accepted, is that to say <b>that we collect</b> debts with that document <b>as</b> one would collect debts <b>with a valid document? And why</b> would that be the case? <b>Aren’t</b> the <b>two</b> signatories whose signatures were ratified <b>and</b> the <b>two</b> witnesses from the marketplace whose testimony invalidates the document contradictory witnesses? Therefore, the document cannot be used to collect payment.
<b>Rav Sheshet said: That is to say</b> that <b>contradiction</b> of their testimony <b>is the first</b> stage in <b>rendering</b> them <b>false, conspiring witnesses,</b> in the sense that certain restrictions that apply to the latter apply to the former as well.

Daf 20a

<b>And just as</b> witnesses <b>render</b> other <b>witnesses false, conspiring</b> witnesses <b>only in their presence,</b> because with their testimony they render them liable to be punished, <b>so too,</b> witnesses <b>contradict</b> the testimony of other witnesses <b>only in their presence.</b> Since the signatories to the document are dead, their testimony cannot be contradicted.
<b>Rav Naḥman said to</b> Rav Sheshet: <b>If</b> the first pair of witnesses <b>was before us and</b> the second pair would <b>contradict</b> their testimony, <b>that is contradiction, and we would not consider their</b> testimony and would not collect money with the document, <b>as it is contradicted testimony. Now that they are not</b> before us, and in a case <b>where if they were before us perhaps they would have admitted to</b> the second witnesses that the testimony of the second witnesses is correct, <b>are they deemed credible,</b> and the document that they signed valid?
<b>Rather, Rav Naḥman said</b> in the case where the testimony of the first witnesses is contradicted not in their presence, the ruling is: <b>Establish two</b> witnesses <b>against</b> the <b>two</b> witnesses who contradict their testimony, thereby neutralizing both testimonies, <b>and establish the money in the possession of its owner, just as it was</b> in the case <b>of the property of bar Shatya. As</b> when <b>bar Shatya,</b> a man who suffered from periodic bouts of insanity, <b>sold</b> his <b>property, two</b> witnesses <b>came</b> and <b>said: He sold</b> it <b>when he was insane; and two</b> other witnesses <b>came</b> and <b>said: He sold</b> it <b>when he was sane.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> in that case: <b>Establish two</b> witnesses <b>against</b> the <b>two</b> witnesses who contradict the testimony of the first pair, <b>and establish the money in the possession of bar Shatya.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>We say</b> that the property remains in the possession of bar Shatya <b>only when he has</b> possession of the property based on <b>the possession of his fathers. However, if he does not have</b> possession of the property based on <b>the possession of his fathers,</b> but he acquired the property himself, <b>we say: He purchased</b> his properties <b>when he was insane, and he sold them when he was insane.</b> He does not have presumptive ownership of them. Therefore, the property remains in the possession of the person to whom bar Shatya sold it.
<b>Rabbi Abbahu</b> disagrees with the opinion of Rav Sheshet and <b>says:</b> Witnesses <b>render</b> other <b>witnesses false, conspiring</b> witnesses <b>only in their presence, but</b> witnesses <b>contradict</b> the testimony of other witnesses <b>not in their presence. And</b> with regard to <b>rendering</b> other <b>witnesses false, conspiring</b> witnesses <b>not in their presence, although it is not</b> effective in <b>rendering them false, conspiring</b> witnesses in the sense that they are punished for their false testimony, <b>in any case, it is a contradiction</b> of their testimony.
§ <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i> cited previously: <b>If there are</b> other <b>witnesses</b> who testify <b>that it is their handwriting, or if their handwriting emerges from another place, from a document that one challenged and</b> that <b>was deemed valid in court,</b> these witnesses are <b>not deemed credible.</b> The Gemara infers: From a document <b>that one challenged, yes,</b> the signatures are authenticated and the testimony of the other witnesses is not accepted; however, <b>if one did not challenge</b> the document, <b>no,</b> the document cannot be used to authenticate their signatures. This <b>supports</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Asi, as Rabbi Asi said: One ratifies a document</b> by authenticating the witnesses’ signatures <b>only from a document that</b> someone <b>challenged and</b> that <b>was deemed valid in court.</b>
The Sages <b>of Neharde’a say: One ratifies a document</b> by authenticating the witnesses’ signatures <b>only from two marriage contracts or from</b> the bills of sale for <b>two fields</b> that those witnesses signed. <b>And</b> those bills of sale are effective <b>only</b> in a case <b>where their owner ate their</b> produce for <b>three years,</b> the requisite period to establish presumptive ownership of the field, <b>and in peace,</b> undisturbed by protest. In that case we can rely on the signatures, and the documents are considered valid.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said:</b> Authentication of signatures by comparison to other documents can be accomplished specifically <b>when</b> the documents <b>emerge from the possession of another. However,</b> when the documents emerge <b>from the possession of</b> the litigant <b>himself, no,</b> they may not be used to authenticate the signatures. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> in a case where the documents emerge <b>from the possession of</b> the litigant <b>himself that</b> they may <b>not</b> be used to authenticate the signatures? It is that <b>perhaps</b> while the documents were in his possession he learned how to copy the signatures and <b>forged</b> them. If so, <b>also</b> in a case where the documents emerge <b>from the possession of another, perhaps he went and saw</b> the signatures, and <b>came</b> back <b>and forged</b> them. The Gemara answers: In that case, <b>he would not be able</b> to <b>accurately</b> reproduce the signatures <b>to that extent</b> based on memory alone.
§ <b>The Sages taught: A person may write his testimony in a document and testify on its</b> basis <b>even after several years</b> have passed. <b>Rav Huna said: And</b> that <b>is</b> the <i>halakha</i> only <b>if he remembers</b> the testimony <b>on his own</b> and he uses the document merely to refresh his memory with regard to certain details. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> One may rely on that written testimony <b>even if he does not remember</b> the testimony <b>by himself</b> at all. <b>Rabba said: Conclude from</b> this statement of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> With regard to <b>these two witnesses who know testimony</b> in a certain case, <b>and one of them forgot</b> the testimony, <b>one</b> witness <b>may remind his fellow</b> witness of the testimony, as according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, even if the witness remembers the testimony only by means of an external stimulus, the testimony is valid.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If the litigant <b>himself</b> reminds the witness of the testimony, <b>what is</b> the ruling? <b>Rav Ḥaviva said: Even</b> if the litigant <b>himself</b> reminds the witness, he may testify. <b>Mar, son of Rav Ashi, said:</b> If the litigant <b>himself</b> reminds the witness, he <b>may not</b> testify. <b>And</b> the Gemara concludes that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is</b> that if the litigant <b>himself</b> reminds the witness of the testimony, the witness <b>may not</b> testify, due to the concern that the litigant influenced the nature of his testimony.

Daf 20b

<b>And if</b> the witness <b>is a Torah scholar,</b> then <b>even</b> if the litigant <b>himself</b> jogged the witness’s memory, the witness may testify. A Torah scholar would not testify if he did not actually remember the testimony himself, <b>as</b> in <b>that</b> case <b>involving Rav Ashi, who knew testimony</b> relating <b>to Rav Kahana.</b> Rav Kahana <b>said to</b> Rav Ashi: <b>Does the Master remember this testimony?</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to him: No.</b> Rav Kahana said to him: <b>Didn’t</b> the incident transpire in <b>such and such</b> a manner? Rav Ashi <b>said to him: I don’t know. Ultimately, Rav Ashi remembered</b> the testimony and <b>testified for</b> Rav Kahana. <b>He saw that Rav Kahana was hesitant [<i>meḥassem</i>]</b> with regard to accepting his testimony, concerned that he had influenced the content of Rav Ashi’s testimony. Rav Ashi <b>said to him: Do you think</b> that <b>I am relying on you? I made an effort, and I remembered</b> the incident.
§ Apropos recalling testimony, the Gemara adds that <b>we learned there</b> in a mishna (<i>Oholot</i> 16:2): <b>Mounds of dirt that are near either to a city or a path, whether</b> these mounds <b>are new or whether</b> they are <b>old, are ritually impure</b> due to the concern that a corpse is buried there. With regard to <b>the</b> mounds <b>that are distant</b> from the city: If they are <b>new</b> they are <b>ritually pure,</b> as, were there a corpse buried there, someone would remember, and if they are <b>old</b> they are <b>impure.</b> The mishna elaborates: <b>What is</b> a mound that is <b>near?</b> It is one at a distance of up to <b>fifty cubits. And what is</b> a mound that is <b>old?</b> It is one that was there for more than <b>sixty years;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> A mound that is <b>near</b> is one that there is <b>no</b> mound <b>closer than it. Old</b> is referring to a mound <b>that no one remembers.</b> According to Rabbi Yehuda, the parameters are not quantifiable.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is a city and what is a path</b> in this context? <b>If you say city means an actual city and a path is an actual path</b> and the mishna is referring to any city or path, the question arises: <b>Do we presume</b> the existence of <b>ritual impurity</b> in Eretz Yisrael? <b>But didn’t Reish Lakish say</b> in explaining how the Sages, based on meager proof, deemed an area in Eretz Yisrael ritually pure where uncertainty arose with regard to its purity: <b>They found a pretext and deemed Eretz Yisrael ritually pure.</b> Apparently, one does not presume ritual impurity in Eretz Yisrael. Why, then, does the mishna declare that every mound of dirt near a city or a path is impure? <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> The word <b>city</b> in the mishna is referring to <b>a city adjacent to the cemetery, and</b> the word <b>path is</b> referring to the <b>path</b> leading <b>to the cemetery.</b> Therefore, the concern that a corpse may be buried in the mound is a reasonable one.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to a mound located adjacent to <b>the path</b> leading <b>to the cemetery,</b> there is concern that a corpse is buried in the mound, <b>as sometimes one happens</b> to go to bury the corpse on Shabbat eve <b>at twilight,</b> and to avoid desecrating Shabbat, <b>it happened that they buried</b> the corpse <b>in a mound</b> on the path. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a city adjacent to the cemetery, everyone goes to the cemetery</b> to bury their dead. Why would anyone bury a corpse in a mound adjacent to the city?
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> The mounds could be impure, <b>since women bury their stillborn</b> babies adjacent to the city, as there is no funeral in that case, <b>and</b> because those <b>afflicted with boils</b> bury <b>their arms</b> that withered and fell from their bodies. <b>Until</b> a distance of <b>fifty cubits</b> from the city, the woman <b>goes alone</b> and buries the stillborn in a mound. <b>More</b> than that distance, <b>she takes a person with her,</b> as she fears going alone, <b>and she goes to the cemetery. Therefore, we are not presuming</b> the existence of <b>ritual impurity in Eretz Yisrael.</b> The case of the mounds is an exception, as there is basis for deeming them impure.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: Conclude from</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who established a time limit beyond which a mound is considered an old mound, that with regard to <b>testimony, until sixty years</b> have passed, it is <b>remembered,</b> and if <b>more</b> than sixty years have passed, it is <b>not remembered. And</b> the Gemara rejects that conclusion: <b>That is not</b> so. <b>There,</b> with regard to the mounds, <b>it is</b> a case <b>where</b> responsibility to attest to the status of the mound <b>was not imposed upon him,</b> and the matter is forgotten after the passage of sixty years. <b>However, here,</b> with regard to testimony in general, <b>since</b> responsibility to testify <b>was imposed upon him,</b> he remembers the testimony <b>even</b> after <b>a greater</b> period of time than sixty years has passed.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>this</b> witness whose name is signed on a document <b>says:</b> This is <b>my handwriting and this is the handwriting of my fellow</b> witness, <b>and that</b> witness <b>says: This is my handwriting and that is the handwriting of my fellow</b> witness, <b>these</b> witnesses <b>are deemed credible</b> and the document is ratified, as together they provide testimony authenticating both signatures. If <b>this</b> witness <b>says: This is my handwriting, and that</b> witness <b>says: This is my handwriting,</b> and neither testifies with regard to the signature of the other, <b>they must add another</b> witness <b>with them</b> who will authenticate the signatures of the two witnesses, as otherwise, each of the witnesses would be testifying with regard to half the sum in the document; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And the Rabbis say: They need not add another</b> witness <b>with them. Rather, a person is deemed credible to say: This is my handwriting.</b> The testimony of the two signatories about their own signatures is sufficient.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara says: <b>When you analyze</b> the reasoning for the opinions of the <i>tanna’im</i>, <b>say</b> that according <b>to</b> the <b>statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi,

Daf 21a

the witnesses <b>are testifying about their handwriting</b> and authenticating their own signatures. Therefore, if each witness testifies only with regard to his own handwriting, there is only one witness authenticating each signature. According <b>to the Rabbis,</b> the witnesses <b>are testifying about</b> the sum of <b>one hundred dinars that is in the document</b> and are not authenticating the signatures at all. Therefore, the testimony of the two witnesses who signed the document is sufficient to ratify the document.
The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious.</b> No analysis is necessary to arrive at this explanation of the dispute. The Gemara answers: The analysis is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that according to <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi there is <b>uncertainty whether they are testifying about their handwriting or</b> whether the witnesses <b>are testifying about</b> the sum of <b>one hundred dinars that is in the document,</b> and due to the possibility that the purpose of the testimony is to authenticate their handwriting, he requires two witnesses for each signature.
<b>And the practical difference</b> between whether the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is based on certainty or uncertainty is in a case <b>where one of</b> the witnesses who signed the document <b>died.</b> If his opinion is based on certainty that they are testifying about the signatures, one other witness testifying to the authenticity of both signatures would suffice, as both that other witness and the surviving signatory would testify to authenticate each signature. However, if his opinion is based on uncertainty, <b>let them require two</b> other witnesses <b>from the street to testify about</b> the signature of the deceased witness.
<b>That</b> is due to the fact that <b>if</b> it is <b>so</b> that the witnesses are testifying about the sum of one hundred dinars that is in the document and only one other witness joined the surviving witness in testifying with regard to that signature, the result would be that the entire sum <b>of money, less one-quarter, is collected</b> based <b>on the testimony of a single witness.</b> The surviving signatory authenticates his signature and thereby facilitates collection of half the sum. In addition, his testimony together with the testimony of the witness from the street authenticating the signature of the deceased signatory facilitates collection of the other half. Based on the verse: “At the mouth of two witnesses…shall a matter be established” (Deuteronomy 19:15), each witness is responsible for half the sum.
<b>And</b> one would have thought that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi would rule <b>stringently here:</b> When both signatories are alive they must add another witness with them to authenticate the signatures of the two witnesses, as perhaps they are testifying about their handwriting; <b>and</b> he would rule <b>stringently here:</b> When one of the signatories died they must add two witnesses, as perhaps the witnesses are testifying about the sum of one hundred dinars that is in the document.
Therefore, the Gemara <b>teaches us that</b> the matter <b>was clear to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, that they are testifying about their handwriting, and he ruled accordingly <b>both leniently,</b> requiring only one additional witness when one of the signatories died, <b>and stringently,</b> requiring an additional witness when both signatories are alive. <b>As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>two</b> witnesses <b>who were signatories to a document and one of them died, they require two</b> others <b>from the street</b> to <b>testify about</b> the signature of the one who died, and <b>in this</b> case, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi rules <b>leniently</b> and requires only one additional witness, <b>and the Rabbis</b> rule <b>stringently</b> and require two additional witnesses.
The Gemara asks: <b>And if there are not two</b> witnesses capable of authenticating each signature, <b>but only one, what</b> can be done to ratify the document? <b>Abaye said: Let</b> the surviving witness <b>write his signature on an earthenware</b> shard <b>and cast it into the court. And the court</b> then <b>ratifies</b> the document <b>by seeing</b> that it is <b>his</b> signature. <b>And</b> then <b>he does not need to testify</b> and authenticate <b>his signature. But he and this</b> other witness <b>go and testify</b> to authenticate <b>the other</b> signature of the deceased witness. In that case, even according to the Rabbis, one additional witness is sufficient.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> he writes his signature for the purpose of comparison <b>specifically on an earthenware</b> shard, <b>but not on parchment,</b> due to the concern that <b>perhaps an unscrupulous person will find it and write on it whatever he wants,</b> e.g., the undersigned owes him money. <b>And we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 175b): If a creditor <b>produced</b> a document <b>about</b> another written in the other person’s <b>handwriting,</b> in which it is written <b>that</b> the other person <b>owes him</b> money, even if there are no witnesses he is obligated to pay, and the claimant <b>may collect</b> payment <b>from unsold property.</b> One can collect repayment of a loan that is documented on a promissory note signed by two witnesses even from the borrower’s land that was sold. With the document signed by the debtor, the creditor may collect payment from unsold property. Due to the potential for deceit with a signature on parchment, one provides a signature sample written on earthenware.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis</b> in the mishna that each of the two signatories need testify only about his own signature to ratify the document. The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious,</b> as the principle is: In a dispute between <b>an individual</b> Sage <b>and multiple</b> Sages, <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is ruled <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>multiple</b> Sages. The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that just as there is a principle: <b>The <i>halakha</i></b> is ruled <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi in disputes <b>with his colleague,</b> there is also a principle that the <i>halakha</i> is ruled in accordance with his opinion <b>even</b> when he disagrees <b>with his</b> multiple <b>colleagues;</b> therefore, Rav Yehuda <b>teaches us</b> that Shmuel said that the principle applies only to disputes with an individual colleague.
§ The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the names and patronyms of the <i>amora’im</i> associated with the statement cited below: <b><i>Nun ḥet</i></b> for Rav Ḥinnana bar Ḥiyya, <b><i>nun dalet</i></b> for Rav Huna bar Yehuda, and <b><i>ḥet dalet</i></b> for Rav Ḥiyya bar Yehuda. <b>Rav Ḥinnana bar Ḥiyya said to Rav Yehuda, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Huna bar Yehuda</b> who <b>said</b> it <b>to Rav Yehuda, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Yehuda</b> who <b>said</b> it <b>to Rav Yehuda: And did Shmuel say that</b> the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis?
