<b>But wasn’t</b> there <b>that document that emerged from the court of Master Shmuel, and it was written with regard to</b> that document: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that Rav Anan bar Ḥiyya came</b> before the court <b>and testified about his signature and about</b> the signature <b>of the one who</b> signed the document <b>with him, and who was that</b> other signatory, <b>Rav Ḥanan bar Rabba; and from</b> the fact <b>that Rav Ḥanan bar Rabba came</b> before the court <b>and testified about his signature and about</b> the signature <b>of the one who</b> signed the document <b>with him, and who was that</b> other signatory, <b>Rav Anan bar Ḥiyya; we certified and ratified</b> this document <b>as appropriate.</b> If Shmuel ruled in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis there would have been no need for each to testify about the signature of his fellow witness.
Rav Yehuda <b>said to him: That was a document for</b> the benefit of <b>orphans, and Shmuel was concerned</b> about the potential <b>for an error of the court. And Shmuel thought: Perhaps there is</b> a court <b>that holds</b> that in general, <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is ruled <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi in disputes <b>with his colleague but not</b> in disputes <b>with his</b> multiple <b>colleagues, and in this</b> case, the <i>halakha</i> is ruled in accordance with his opinion <b>even</b> in disputes <b>with his</b> multiple <b>colleagues,</b> and the court will not ratify the document if each witness testifies only about his own signature. Therefore <b>he thought: I will perform</b> ratification of the document in an <b>expansive</b> manner, in accordance with all opinions, to ensure <b>that the orphans will not lose</b> money to which they are entitled.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> If a document came before a court and the court ratified it, and then the document was produced in order to collect the debt, at which time the borrower contested its validity and claimed that it was forged, one <b>witness</b> who was a signatory on the document <b>and a judge</b> who ratified the document <b>join</b> together to testify that the document is valid.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said: How excellent is this <i>halakha</i>. Rava said:</b> In <b>what</b> way is that <b>excellence</b> manifested? <b>That which the witness testifies,</b> i.e., authenticating his signature and confirming the incident that he witnessed, <b>the judge does not testify,</b> as the judge testifies that the document was ratified. <b>And that which the judge testifies, the witness does not testify.</b> There are not two witnesses testifying to either matter.
<b>Rather, when Rami bar Yeḥezkel came, he said: Do not listen to those principles that my brother</b> Rav <b>Yehuda</b> bar Yeḥezkel <b>established in the name of Shmuel</b> with regard to a witness and a judge joining together to testify.

Daf 21b

The Gemara relates: <b>Ravnai, brother of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, happened to</b> come and <b>sell sesame, and he said</b> that <b>this</b> is what <b>Shmuel said: A witness and a judge join</b> together to testify. <b>Ameimar said: How excellent is this <i>halakha</i>. Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: Due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> Rami bar Ḥama, <b>father of your mother, praised it, you also praise</b> [<b><i>mekallesat</i></b>] <b>it? Rava already refuted</b> that statement and proved it incorrect.
§ <b>Rav Safra said</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Yitzhak bar Shmuel bar Marta said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said;</b> and some say that <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>three</b> judges <b>who convened to ratify a document,</b> and <b>two</b> of them <b>recognize the signatures of the witnesses</b> on the document, <b>and one does not recognize</b> them; <b>as long as</b> the two judges <b>did not</b> yet <b>sign</b> to ratify the document, they <b>testify</b> and authenticate the signatures <b>before</b> the third judge, and based on that testimony, the third judge <b>signs</b> the document of ratification together with the first two judges. However, <b>once</b> the two judges <b>signed</b> the ratification, <b>they may not testify before him and</b> have him <b>sign</b> the ratification. The formula of the ratification is: We verified and ratified this document in a forum of three. Since when the first two judges signed the ratification, they were not a forum of three, the ratification is invalid.
The Gemara asks: <b>And do we write</b> the ratification of a document before all of the judges verify the signatures of the witnesses? <b>But didn’t Rav Pappi say in the name of Rava: This ratification of judges that was written before the witnesses related</b> testimony <b>about their signatures is invalid,</b> even if the witnesses later authenticate their signatures, as <b>it seems like a lie,</b> since when they drafted the ratification they were not yet aware that they would be able to ratify the document? <b>Here too,</b> when the judges drafted the ratification before the third judge can verify the signatures, <b>it seems like a lie.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> emend the statement and <b>say: As long as</b> the two judges <b>did not</b> yet <b>write</b> the ratification of the document, they <b>testify</b> and authenticate the signatures <b>before</b> the third judge, and based on that testimony, the third judge <b>signs</b> the ratification together with the first two judges. However, <b>once</b> the two judges <b>have written</b> the ratification, <b>they may not testify before him and</b> have him <b>sign</b> the ratification.
The Gemara notes: <b>Conclude from</b> the statement of Rav Huna <b>three</b> <i>halakhot</i>: <b>Conclude from it that a witness</b> can <b>become a judge,</b> as the two judges who testified to authenticate the signatures signed the ratification as judges and were not disqualified due to a conflict of interest. <b>And conclude from it</b> that <b>judges who recognize the signatures of</b> the <b>witnesses do not require</b> other witnesses <b>to testify before them. And conclude from it</b> that in cases involving <b>judges who do not recognize the signatures of the witnesses,</b> witnesses <b>are required to testify before each and every one of them,</b> and no judge may issue a ruling based on testimony brought before the other judges.
<b>Rav Ashi</b> strongly <b>objects</b> to the conclusions drawn by the Gemara. <b>Granted,</b> the fact that <b>a witness</b> can <b>become a judge we</b> can <b>conclude from</b> the statement of Rav Huna. <b>However,</b> the fact that <b>judges who recognize the signatures of witnesses do not require</b> other witnesses <b>to testify before them</b> cannot be concluded from the statement of Rav Huna. <b>Perhaps, I will say to you</b> that <b>actually</b> judges <b>require</b> witnesses to testify before them; <b>and here,</b> in this case, <b>it is different, as</b> the requirement of the <b>statement</b> of testimony <b>is fulfilled with</b> the testimony of the two judges before the <b>one</b> judge who did not recognize the signatures. However, in a case where there is no statement of testimony at all, there could be no ratification of the document.
<b>And</b> furthermore, with regard to the conclusion that in cases of <b>judges who do not recognize the signatures of the witnesses,</b> witnesses <b>are required to testify before each and every one</b> of them, <b>perhaps, I will say to you</b> that <b>actually,</b> in general, witnesses <b>are not required</b> to testify before each and every judge; <b>and here,</b> in this case, <b>it is different, as</b> were it not for the testimony of the two judges before the third judge, the requirement of the <b>statement</b> of testimony would <b>not be fulfilled</b> at all. In a case where there is other testimony, perhaps one may rely on the knowledge of others in order to ratify the document.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Abba sat and stated this <i>halakha</i> that a witness</b> can <b>become a judge. Rav Safra raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Abba</b> from a mishna (<i>Rosh HaShana</i> 25b): If <b>three</b> people <b>saw</b> the new moon <b>and they</b> constitute <b>a court, two</b> of them <b>should stand and seat two of their colleagues</b> to sit <b>near</b> the remaining <b>individual</b> judge. <b>And</b> the two <b>should testify before</b> the three judges, <b>and they should</b> then <b>recite</b> the standard formula for sanctifying the month: <b>Sanctified is the month, sanctified.</b> Two others must join the original judge to form a tribunal of three judges, <b>as an individual</b> judge <b>is not deemed credible</b> to sanctify the month <b>by himself. And if it enters your mind</b> to say <b>that a witness</b> can <b>become a judge, why do I</b> need <b>all this? Let</b> the three judges remain <b>seated in their place and sanctify</b> the month, as they can be both witnesses and judges.
Rabbi Abba <b>said to</b> Rav Safra: That mishna <b>was difficult for me</b> to understand <b>as well, and I asked Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta</b> about <b>it, and Rav Yitzḥak</b> asked <b>Rav Huna, and Rav Huna</b> asked <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav, and Ḥiyya bar Rav</b> asked <b>Rav, and</b> Rav <b>said to them: Leave</b> the case of <b>testimony</b> to sanctify <b>the month, as</b> it is mandated <b>by Torah</b> law, and the guidelines are more stringent, <b>and</b> the requirement of <b>ratification of documents is</b> mandated <b>by rabbinic</b> law, where the guidelines are more lenient. In that case a witness can become a judge.
§ <b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In the case of <b>three</b> judges <b>who convened</b> as a tribunal <b>to ratify a document, and</b> a person <b>raised a challenge</b> with regard to the fitness <b>of one of them</b> to serve as a judge, thereby preventing ratification of the document, <b>as long as they did not</b> yet <b>sign</b> the ratification, the other two judges <b>may testify about</b> the acceptability of the judge whose fitness was challenged, and <b>he</b> then <b>signs</b> the ratification. However, <b>once they signed</b> the ratification, <b>they may no</b> longer <b>testify about his</b> fitness <b>and</b> thereby enable him to <b>sign</b> the ratification. Once they sign, their testimony is no longer impartial because there is a conflict of interest as they seek to avoid being associated with a tribunal tainted by an unfit judge.
The Gemara elaborates: With regard to <b>a challenge of what</b> sort was this <i>halakha</i> stated? <b>If</b> it was <b>a challenge</b> based on an allegation <b>of theft,</b>

Daf 22a

the witnesses who testified that he is unfit and the judges who testified that he is fit <b>are two</b> witnesses <b>and two</b> witnesses who contradict them, and in that case, the allegation of theft is not completely eliminated. <b>If</b> it was <b>a challenge</b> based on an allegation of <b>flawed lineage,</b> e.g., he is a Canaanite slave and therefore unfit to serve as a judge, that <b>is a mere revealing of a matter</b> that will ultimately be revealed in any case and does not require actual testimony. Therefore, there is no conflict of interest preventing the judges from asserting his fitness after they signed. The Gemara concludes: <b>Actually, I will say to you</b> that it was <b>a challenge</b> based on an allegation <b>of theft, and these</b> judges <b>say: We know about him that he repented</b> and is now fit to serve as a judge. In that case, their testimony does not contradict the original testimony that he was guilty of theft.
§ <b>Rabbi Zeira said: This matter, I heard from Rabbi Abba, and if it was not for Rabbi Abba of Akko, I would have forgotten it.</b> With regard to a case of <b>three</b> judges <b>who convened</b> as a tribunal <b>to ratify a document, and one of them died</b> before signing the ratification, the surviving judges <b>must</b> emend the standard formula of the ratification and <b>write: We were</b> convened <b>in a session of three</b> judges, <b>and one</b> of the judges <b>is no longer</b> alive. In that way it is clear that although only two judges signed, the document was ratified by three judges.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: And if</b> the judges <b>wrote in</b> the ratification: <b>This document was produced before us, the court;</b> they <b>no longer need</b> to add that they were three judges, as, when unmodified, the term court connotes a tribunal of three judges. The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps it was an impudent court, and</b> that is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, as Shmuel said: Two</b> judges <b>who</b> convened a tribunal and <b>judged, their verdict is a</b> binding <b>verdict; however,</b> because they contravened the rabbinic ordinance mandating that a court be comprised of three judges, <b>they are called an impudent court.</b> Therefore, writing: Before us, the court, does not rule out the possibility that the document was ratified by fewer than three judges.
The Gemara answers: It is clear that the document was ratified by the requisite three judges, <b>as it is written in</b> the ratification: Before us, <b>the court of our</b> teacher <b>Rav Ashi,</b> which presumably conforms to rabbinic protocol. The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps the Rabbis of the court of Rav Ashi hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel</b> and they convened an impudent court, whose ruling is binding. The Gemara answers: It is clear, <b>as it is written in</b> the ratification: Before us, the court of our teacher Rav Ashi, <b>and our</b> teacher <b>Rav Ashi said to us</b> how to ratify the document.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a woman who said: I was a married woman and</b> now <b>I am a divorcée, she is deemed credible</b> and permitted to remarry, <b>as the mouth that prohibited</b> and established that she was married <b>is the mouth that permitted,</b> and established that she is divorced. <b>However, if there are witnesses that she was a married woman, and she says: I am a divorcée, she is not deemed credible.</b> Similarly, with regard to a woman who <b>said: I was taken captive but I am pure,</b> as I was not raped in captivity, <b>she is deemed credible</b> and permitted to marry a priest, <b>as the mouth that prohibited</b> and established that she was taken captive <b>is the mouth that permitted</b> and established that she was not defiled. <b>But if there are witnesses that she was taken captive, and she says: I am pure, she is not deemed credible. And if witnesses came after she married, this</b> woman need <b>not leave</b> her husband.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Asi said: From where in the Torah</b> is the principle: <b>The mouth that prohibited is the mouth that permitted,</b> derived? It is derived <b>as it is stated: “I gave my daughter to this man [<i>la’ish hazeh</i>] as a wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:16). When the father said that he married her off <b>“to the man [<i>la’ish</i>]”</b> without revealing his identity, <b>he rendered her forbidden</b> to all men. When he then says <b>“this [<i>hazeh</i>],”</b> thereby identifying the man to whom he married her off, <b>he renders her permitted</b> to her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need to derive this from <b>the verse? It is</b> based on <b>logic: He rendered her forbidden and he rendered her permitted. Rather, where this verse is necessary, is</b> in order <b>to</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> <b>that Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said, as Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: From where in the Torah</b> is it derived that <b>a father is deemed credible to render his daughter forbidden?</b> It is derived <b>as it is stated: “I gave my daughter to the man [<i>la’ish</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:16). The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the subsequent term <b>“this [<i>hazeh</i>]”?</b>
The Gemara explains: The verse <b>is necessary to</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> that <b>Rabbi Yona taught; as Rabbi Yona taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that in the verse: <b>“I gave my daughter to this man,”</b> written in the context of a husband slandering his wife, <b>“this”</b> is written to infer: The <i>halakhot</i> in this passage apply to a man who slanders his wife and <b>not to the <i>yavam</i>,</b> in the case of levirate marriage.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> with regard to <b>the woman who said: I am a married woman, and then said: I am unmarried,</b> that <b>she is deemed credible.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t she render herself an entity of prohibition?</b> When she said that she was married she rendered herself forbidden to all men. How then can she abrogate the prohibition? The Gemara answers that <b>Rava bar Rav Huna said:</b> It is referring to a case <b>where she provided a rationale [<i>amatla</i>] for her</b> initial <b>statement</b> and explained why she said that she was a married woman. <b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to <b>the woman who said: I am a married woman, and then said: I am unmarried,</b> that <b>she is not deemed credible. And if she provided a rationale for her</b> initial <b>statement, she is deemed credible.</b>
<b>And there was also an incident involving an important woman who was outstanding in beauty, and</b> many <b>men were clamoring to betroth her. And she said to them: I am</b> already <b>betrothed. Sometime later she arose and betrothed herself</b> to a man. <b>The Sages said to her: What did you see</b> that led you <b>to do so? She said to them: Initially, when unscrupulous people approached me</b> seeking to marry me, <b>I said: I am betrothed. Now that scrupulous people approached me, I arose and betrothed myself</b> to one of them. <b>And</b> the Gemara notes: <b>This <i>halakha</i> was raised by Rav Aḥa Sar HaBira before the Sages in Usha,</b> the seat of the Sanhedrin, <b>and</b> the Sages <b>said: If she provided a rationale for her statement, she is deemed credible.</b>
<b>Shmuel raised a dilemma before Rav:</b> If a woman <b>said</b> to her husband: <b>I am ritually impure</b> as I am menstruating, <b>and then said: I am pure, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is she permitted based on her latter statement, or did she render herself an entity of prohibition with her first statement and therefore remains forbidden? Rav <b>said to him: Even in that</b> case, <b>if she provided a</b>

Daf 22b

<b>rationale for her statement, she is deemed credible.</b> The Gemara relates: Shmuel <b>learned</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from him forty times</b> to ensure that he would not forget it, <b>and even so,</b> when confronted with a similar situation, <b>Shmuel did not</b> rely on that lenient ruling and did not <b>take action with regard to himself</b> and his wife.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> that if <b>two</b> witnesses <b>say:</b> The husband <b>died, and two</b> witnesses <b>say: He did not die;</b> or if <b>two</b> witnesses <b>say:</b> This woman <b>was divorced, and two</b> witnesses <b>say: She was not divorced, this</b> woman <b>may not remarry</b> as there is no unequivocal testimony that she is unmarried. <b>And if she remarried,</b> she need <b>not leave</b> her husband. <b>Rabbi Menaḥem bar Yosei says:</b> She must <b>leave</b> her husband. And <b>Rabbi Menaḥem bar Yosei said: When do I say</b> that <b>she must leave</b> her husband? It is in a case <b>where witnesses came</b> to testify that she is still married <b>and she remarried thereafter. However, if she remarried and the witnesses came thereafter,</b> she need <b>not leave</b> her husband based on the uncertainty created by contradictory witnesses.
The Gemara asks: <b>After all, they are two</b> witnesses testifying that she is married <b>and two</b> witnesses testifying that she is not; how then can the ruling be that after remarrying she need not leave her husband? In that case, <b>one who engages in intercourse with her stands liable</b> to bring <b>a guilt-offering for uncertainty.</b> For any prohibition whose certain violation renders one liable to bring a sin-offering, its uncertain violation renders one liable to bring a guilt-offering for uncertainty. <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> This is a case <b>where she married one of her witnesses</b> who testified that she is unmarried. As far as he is concerned, there is no uncertainty. The Gemara asks: <b>She herself stands liable</b> to bring <b>a guilt-offering for uncertainty,</b> as she has no independent knowledge whether her husband died. The Gemara answers that this is a case <b>where she says: It is clear to me</b> that he died.
§ <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that if <b>two</b> witnesses <b>say:</b> The husband <b>died, and two</b> witnesses <b>say: He did not die, this</b> woman <b>may not remarry. And if she remarried</b> she need <b>not leave</b> her husband. If <b>two</b> witnesses <b>say:</b> This woman <b>was divorced, and two</b> witnesses <b>say: She was not divorced, this</b> woman <b>may not remarry. And if she remarried</b> she must <b>leave</b> her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> in <b>the first clause</b> of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, where, if she remarried, she need not leave her husband, <b>and what is the different</b> in <b>the second clause,</b> where, if she remarried, she must leave her husband? <b>Abaye said: Interpret</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement <b>in</b> a case where each testimony was given by <b>one witness.</b> If <b>one witness says:</b> The husband <b>died, the Sages</b> instituted an ordinance and <b>accorded him credibility like</b> that of <b>two</b> witnesses in order to enable his wife to remarry. <b>And</b> that is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ulla, as Ulla said: Wherever the Torah deemed one witness credible,</b> his legal status <b>there</b> is that of <b>two</b> witnesses. <b>And</b> the legal status of <b>that</b> second witness <b>who says: He did not die, is</b> that of <b>one</b> witness, <b>and the statement of one</b> witness has <b>no</b> validity <b>in a place</b> where there is the testimony of <b>two</b> witnesses. Therefore, she need not leave her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that this is a case of the testimony of two witnesses against the testimony of one witness, it should be permitted for her to remarry <b>even <i>ab initio</i>.</b> The Gemara answers that she may not remarry <i>ab initio</i> <b>due to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Asi, as Rav Asi said</b> that in any case of uncertainty, the verse <b>“Remove from you a crooked mouth, and perverse lips put far from you”</b> (Proverbs 4:24) applies. Although it is not a strictly prohibited action, it is, nevertheless, inappropriate.
In <b>the latter clause</b> of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, where <b>one witness says:</b> This woman <b>was divorced, and one witness says: She was not divorced, both of them are testifying</b> that she was <b>a married woman, and that</b> witness <b>who says: She was divorced, is one</b> witness, <b>and the statement of one</b> witness has <b>no</b> validity <b>in a place</b> where there is the testimony of <b>two</b> witnesses. Therefore, even if she remarried she must leave her husband.
<b>Rava</b> explained the difference between the two cases in Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement and <b>said: Actually</b> it is a case where <b>they are two</b> witnesses testifying that she is married <b>and two</b> testifying that she is not, <b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan saw the statement of Rabbi Menaḥem bar Yosei</b> as correct <b>in</b> the case of <b>divorce but did not see</b> it as correct <b>in</b> the case of <b>death. What is the reason</b> that he distinguishes between the two cases? In the case of <b>death,</b> if ultimately her husband returns alive, <b>she is unable to deny</b> that <b>he</b> is alive. Therefore, the woman’s decision to remarry is credible, as if she were not certain that he was dead, she would not have remarried. However, in the case of <b>divorce,</b> if her husband returns and claims that he did not divorce her, <b>she is able to deny his</b> claim. Therefore, her decision to remarry is suspect, and the Sages penalized her and established that she must leave her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is</b> the woman <b>impudent</b> to <b>that extent,</b> that she would lie in the presence of her husband and claim that he divorced her? <b>But didn’t Rav Hamnuna say</b> with regard to <b>a woman who said to her husband: You divorced me, she is deemed credible,</b> as there is a <b>presumption that a woman is not insolent in the presence of her husband?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> statement that she is not insolent <b>applies only</b> in a case <b>where there are no witnesses who are supporting her; however,</b> in a case <b>where there are witnesses who are supporting her, she would certainly be insolent.</b>
<b>Rav Asi</b> explained the difference between the two cases in Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement and <b>said</b> that it is a case <b>where the witnesses say: He died now,</b> or: <b>He divorced her now.</b> With regard to the husband’s <b>death, there is no</b> way <b>to</b> immediately <b>clarify</b> whether or not he is dead. With regard to <b>divorce there is</b> a way <b>to</b> immediately <b>clarify</b> whether or not he divorced her, <b>as we say to</b> the woman: <b>If it is so that this</b> is what happened, <b>show us your bill of divorce.</b> Since the testimony was that the divorce was now, it is not feasible that she lost the bill of divorce. If she fails to produce the bill of divorce, the witnesses that testify that she is divorced are apparently false witnesses. Therefore, even if she remarried she must leave her husband.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> In a case where <b>two</b> witnesses <b>say:</b> This woman <b>was betrothed, and two</b> witnesses <b>say: She was not betrothed, this</b> woman <b>may not marry</b> another, <b>and if she remarried,</b> she need <b>not leave</b> her husband. In a case where <b>two</b> witnesses <b>say:</b> This woman <b>was divorced, and two</b> witnesses <b>say: She was not divorced, this</b> woman <b>may not remarry. And if she remarried,</b> she must <b>leave</b> her husband.

Daf 23a

The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> in <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> with regard to betrothal, where, if she married another, she need not leave her husband; <b>and what is different</b> in <b>the second clause</b> with regard to divorce, where, if she remarried, she must leave her husband?
<b>Abaye said: Interpret</b> the <i>baraita</i> in a case <b>in</b> which each testimony was given by <b>one witness.</b> If <b>one witness says: She was betrothed, and one witness says: She was not betrothed, they are both testifying that she was unmarried. And that</b> witness <b>who says that she was betrothed is one</b> witness, <b>and the statement of one</b> witness has <b>no</b> validity <b>in a place</b> where there are <b>two</b> witnesses.
<b>In the latter clause,</b> if <b>one witness says: She was divorced, and one witness says: She was not divorced, they are both testifying that she was a married woman. And that</b> witness <b>who says that she was divorced is one</b> witness, <b>and the statement of one</b> witness has <b>no</b> validity <b>in a place</b> where there are <b>two</b> witnesses. Therefore, even if she remarried she must leave her husband.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Actually</b> it is a case where there are <b>two</b> witnesses testifying that she is betrothed and divorced, <b>and two</b> testifying that she is not betrothed and divorced. <b>And</b> in order to explain the difference between the first and latter clauses, <b>reverse</b> the two rulings. In the first clause, if <b>two</b> witnesses <b>say: We saw her that she was betrothed, and two</b> witnesses <b>say: We did not see her that she was betrothed, this</b> woman <b>may not marry, and if she marries</b> she must <b>leave</b> her husband.
The Gemara asks: In that case, it is <b>obvious</b> that she must leave her husband, as testimony that <b>we did not see her is not</b> effective <b>proof.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in a case where the woman and the witnesses <b>reside in one courtyard. Lest you say: If it is so</b> that she was <b>betrothed, the matter generates publicity,</b> and the fact that the neighbors did not see that she was betrothed indicates that she was not, therefore the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us that people are prone to betroth</b> a woman <b>in private,</b> with even their neighbors unaware of the betrothal.
In the <b>latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, if <b>two</b> witnesses <b>say: We saw her that she was divorced, and two</b> witnesses <b>say: We did not see her that she was divorced, this</b> woman <b>may not remarry, and if she remarries,</b> she need <b>not leave</b> her husband. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaching us?</b> In this case, too, the fact that the witnesses did not see the divorce proves nothing. The Gemara answers: It teaches that <b>although</b> the witnesses and the woman <b>live in one courtyard</b> and presumably the witnesses would know if she was divorced, their testimony proves nothing. The Gemara asks: <b>This is</b> identical to <b>that</b> novel element taught in the first clause, that neighbors are not necessarily aware of what transpires elsewhere in the courtyard.
The Gemara explains that there is a novel element in this <i>halakha</i>. <b>Lest you say</b> that it is <b>with regard to betrothal that people are prone to betroth</b> a woman <b>in private; however, with regard to divorce, if it is so that she was divorced, it would generate publicity,</b> as divorce is typically the culmination of a period of incompatibility that is often public. Therefore, the latter clause <b>teaches us that people are prone to</b> both <b>betroth and divorce in private.</b> Consequently, the fact that the witnesses did not see that she was betrothed and divorced proves nothing.
§ We learned in the mishna: <b>And if the witnesses came after she married, this</b> woman need <b>not leave</b> her husband. Two cases were cited in the mishna, one with regard to a divorcée and one with regard to a woman taken captive, and to which of these cases this <i>halakha</i> is referring is a matter of dispute. <b>Rabbi Oshaya taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> in reference <b>to the first clause</b> of the mishna, where the woman claims that she was divorced. <b>Rabba bar Avin taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> in reference <b>to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, where the woman claims that she was taken captive and remained pure.
The Gemara notes: <b>The one who taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> in reference <b>to the first clause</b> of the mishna, <b>all the more so</b> would he teach it in reference <b>to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, <b>as,</b> in general, with regard to the status of <b>a captive woman,</b> the Sages <b>were lenient,</b> because the prohibition is the result of suspicion and uncertainty as far as what transpired during her period of captivity. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the one who taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> in reference <b>to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, <b>however,</b> in reference <b>to the first clause</b> of the mishna, <b>no,</b> he would not necessarily teach this <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara explains: <b>Let us say</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> the presumption of <b>Rav Hamnuna</b> that these <i>amora’im</i> <b>disagree. The one who taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> in reference <b>to the first clause</b> of the mishna and maintains that if the witnesses came after she married, this woman need not leave her husband, <b>he holds</b> in accordance with the presumption of <b>Rav Hamnuna,</b> who said that a woman is not insolent in the presence of her husband, and therefore her claim that she was divorced is accepted. <b>And the one who taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> in reference <b>to the latter clause</b> of the mishna and rules that the woman taken captive need not leave her husband the priest, while the woman who claims that she was divorced must leave her husband, <b>he does not hold</b> in accordance with the presumption of <b>Rav Hamnuna.</b>
The Gemara rejects that explanation: <b>No,</b> actually <b>everyone holds</b> in accordance with the presumption <b>of Rav Hamnuna, and here</b> it is <b>with regard to this that they disagree, as one Sage,</b> who holds that the woman who claims that she was divorced must leave her husband, <b>maintains that when</b> the presumption of <b>Rav Hamnuna was stated,</b> it was stated specifically in a case where she was <b>in his presence; however,</b> when she is <b>not in his presence, she is insolent. And one Sage,</b> who holds that the woman who claims that she was divorced need not leave her husband, <b>maintains that</b> when <b>not in his presence she is also not insolent.</b> Therefore, her claim that she was divorced is accepted.
§ We learned in the mishna: <b>And if the witnesses came after she married,</b> this woman need not leave her husband. <b>The father of Shmuel said: Married</b> does <b>not</b> mean <b>actually married; rather, once</b> the court <b>permitted her to marry, although she has not</b> yet <b>married,</b> she need not leave her husband. The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach: She need not leave,</b> meaning that she need not leave her husband? The Gemara explains: That phrase in this context means that even if witnesses come, <b>she does not emerge</b> from <b>her initial permitted</b> status.
<b>The Sages taught</b> that if <b>she said: I was taken captive but I am pure, and I have witnesses</b> who were with me throughout captivity who can testify <b>that I am pure,</b> the court <b>does not say: We will wait until</b> those <b>witnesses come. Rather,</b> the court <b>permits her</b> to marry a priest <b>immediately.</b> If the court <b>permitted her</b> to marry a priest, <b>and witnesses came thereafter and said: We do not know</b> whether or not she remained pure, <b>this</b> woman <b>need not leave</b> her husband, as she was already permitted to marry a priest on the basis of her original statement. <b>And if witnesses that she was violated came</b> and testified, <b>even if she has several children,</b> she must <b>leave</b> the priest to whom she is married.
The Gemara relates: There were <b>these captive women who came to Neharde’a</b> with their captors so that the local residents would redeem them. <b>Shmuel’s father posted guards with them</b> to ensure that they would not enter into seclusion with gentiles. <b>Shmuel said to him: Until now who guarded them?</b> If there is concern about their status, it should be with regard to the possibility that they engaged in intercourse while in captivity before they were brought to Neharde’a. <b>He said to</b> Shmuel: <b>If they were your daughters, would you treat them with contempt to that extent?</b> They are no longer captives and deserve to be treated like any Jewish woman of unflawed lineage.
The statement by the father of Shmuel <b>was “Like an error that emerges from before the ruler”</b> (Ecclesiastes 10:5), <b>and</b> it was realized. <b>The daughters of Master Shmuel were taken captive, and</b> their captors <b>took them up to Eretz Yisrael</b> and sought to sell them or ransom them. Shmuel’s daughters left <b>their captors standing outside,</b> so that they would not come before the court, <b>and</b> the women <b>entered the study hall of Rabbi Ḥanina. This</b> daughter <b>said: I was taken captive, and I am pure, and that</b> daughter <b>said: I was taken captive, and I am pure, and</b> the court <b>permitted them</b> to marry into the priesthood.
<b>Ultimately, their captors came and entered,</b> and it was clear that they were the captors of Shmuel’s daughters. However, since the daughters made their claim first and the court permitted them to marry into the priesthood, this remained permitted to them. This is based on the <i>halakha</i> that if witnesses subsequently arrive, her initial permitted status need not be revoked. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> It is clear from their actions that they are the <b>daughters</b> of great halakhic <b>authorities,</b> as they knew how to conduct themselves in order to retain their presumptive status of purity. The Gemara relates: Ultimately, <b>the matter became clear, that they were the daughters of Master Shmuel.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina said to Rav Shemen bar Abba,</b> who was a priest: <b>Go out and tend to your relatives,</b> the daughters of Shmuel who were taken captive, and marry one of them. Rav Shemen <b>said to Rabbi Ḥanina: But aren’t there witnesses in a country overseas</b> who knew before the daughters appeared in court that they were taken captive? Rabbi Ḥanina <b>said to him: Now, in any event,</b> those witnesses <b>are not before us.</b> He then cited an adage: There are <b>witnesses in</b> the <b>north [<i>astan</i>] side,</b> i.e., in a distant place, <b>and</b> will the woman <b>be forbidden?</b> The Gemara infers from Rabbi Ḥanina’s statement: <b>The reason</b> that their testimony may be ignored <b>is</b> because <b>the witnesses did not come</b> to court. <b>However, were the witnesses</b> to <b>come</b> to court, Shmuel’s daughters <b>would be forbidden</b> to priests.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Shmuel’s father say: Once</b> the court <b>permitted</b> a woman <b>to marry, even if she has not</b> yet <b>married,</b> she remains permitted? <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The discussion between Rabbi Ḥanina and Rav Shemen <b>was stated</b> with regard to <b>witnesses</b> who witnessed their <b>violation.</b> In that case, were the witnesses to come to court and testify, even if she has several children, she must leave the priest to whom she is married.

Daf 23b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case where witnesses testify that there are <b>two women who were taken captive,</b> and <b>this</b> woman <b>says: I was taken captive but I am pure, and that</b> woman <b>says: I was taken captive but I am pure, they are not deemed credible. And when this</b> woman <b>testifies about that</b> woman that she is pure and vice versa, <b>they are deemed credible.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (2:2): If one of the women says: <b>I am tainted and my counterpart is pure, she is deemed credible</b> on both counts. If she says: <b>I am pure and my counterpart is tainted, she is not deemed credible</b> with regard to herself nor with regard to her counterpart. If she says: <b>I and my counterpart are</b> both <b>tainted, she is deemed credible with regard to herself but she is not deemed credible with regard to her counterpart.</b> If she says: <b>I and my counterpart are</b> both <b>pure, she is deemed credible with regard to her counterpart but she is not deemed credible with regard to herself.</b>
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that if she says: <b>I am pure and my counterpart is tainted, she is not deemed credible.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If there are no witnesses</b> that she was taken captive, <b>why is she not deemed credible with regard to herself?</b> If she is saying: <b>I was taken captive and I am pure,</b> she is deemed credible based on the principle that the mouth that prohibited is the mouth that permitted. Rather, it is <b>obvious that there are witnesses</b> that she was taken captive.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>say the middle clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: If she says: <b>I and my counterpart are</b> both <b>tainted, she is deemed credible with regard to herself but she is not deemed credible with regard to her counterpart. And if there are witnesses, why is she not deemed credible</b> with regard to her counterpart? Once there is testimony that she was taken captive, she no longer has the presumptive status of purity. Rather, it is <b>obvious that there are no witnesses</b> that she was taken captive, and therefore her presumptive status of purity is intact.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>say the last clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: If she says: <b>I and my counterpart are</b> both <b>pure, she is deemed credible with regard to her counterpart but she is not deemed credible with regard to herself. And if there are no witnesses</b> that they were taken captive, <b>why is she not deemed credible with regard to herself?</b> Rather, it is <b>obvious that there are witnesses.</b>
The Gemara asks: Is that to say that the <i>baraita</i> is formulated in an unusual fashion, with the <b>first clause and the last clause</b> pertaining to cases <b>where there are witnesses, and the middle clause</b> pertaining to a case <b>where there are no witnesses? Abaye said: Yes,</b> the <b>first clause and the last clause</b> pertain to cases <b>where there are witnesses, and the middle clause</b> pertains to a case <b>where there are no witnesses.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> in <b>its entirety</b> can be explained in a case <b>where there are witnesses, and there is one witness who is</b> testifying to the <b>reverse</b> of the woman’s claim. If the woman <b>said: I am tainted and my counterpart is pure, and one witness said to her: You are pure and your counterpart is tainted,</b> although the witness testified that she was pure, because she admitted that she was tainted <b>she rendered herself an entity of prohibition. Her counterpart is permitted on the basis of her</b> claim, which is accepted despite being contradicted by the witness.
If the woman said: <b>I am pure and my counterpart is tainted, and one witness said to her: You are tainted and your counterpart is pure,</b> then with regard to <b>her, since there are witnesses</b> testifying that she was taken captive, <b>it is not in her power</b> to permit herself on the basis of her claim. However, <b>her counterpart is permitted on the basis of the</b> testimony of the <b>witness.</b>
If the woman said: <b>I and my counterpart are</b> both <b>tainted, and one witness said to her: You and your friend are</b> both <b>pure, she rendered herself an entity of prohibition.</b> However, <b>her counterpart is permitted on the basis of the</b> testimony of the <b>witness.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>this additional</b> case? <b>This is</b> identical <b>to</b> that which was taught in the in the <b>first clause.</b> The principles governing the first two cases, i.e., she claims that she is tainted and thereby renders herself as an entity of prohibition, and her counterpart is permitted by the testimony of one witness even if that testimony is contradicted, also apply in this case.
The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that in this case, <b>both of them are</b> deemed <b>untainted</b> in accordance with the testimony of the witness, <b>and</b> the fact <b>that she said that</b> they are both tainted <b>was</b> because <b>she was acting</b> with the intention termed: <b>“Let me die with the Philistines”</b> (Judges 16:30), i.e., she was willing to implicate herself in order to bolster her credibility so that her testimony against her counterpart would be accepted, the <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that this is not a consideration.
If the woman said: <b>I and my counterpart are</b> both <b>pure, and one witness said to her: You and your counterpart are</b> both <b>tainted,</b> with regard to <b>her, since there are witnesses</b> testifying that she was taken captive, <b>it is not in her power</b> to permit herself on the basis of her claim. However, <b>her counterpart is permitted on the basis of her</b> claim. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>this additional</b> case? <b>This is</b> identical <b>to</b> that which was taught in the <b>first part of the first clause.</b> The principles governing the first two cases, i.e., her claim that she is pure is not accepted when the fact that she was taken captive was established by witnesses, and her counterpart is permitted on the basis of her claim even if that claim is contradicted, also apply in this case.
The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>when is she deemed credible</b> to permit her counterpart, it is only in a case <b>where she rendered herself unfit</b> to marry a priest, <b>but</b> in a case <b>where she rendered herself fit, say that she is not deemed credible</b> with regard to her counterpart; the <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that each segment of the testimony is assessed independently, based on the criteria taught in the first clause.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And likewise,</b> with regard to <b>two men</b> whose lineage is unknown, and <b>this</b> man <b>says: I am a priest, and that</b> man <b>says: I am a priest, they are not deemed credible. And when this</b> man <b>testifies about that</b> man that he is a priest and vice versa, <b>they are deemed credible. Rabbi Yehuda says: One does not elevate</b> a man <b>to priesthood on the basis of one witness.</b> Two witnesses are required for that purpose. <b>Rabbi Elazar says: When</b> is that the ruling? In a case <b>where there are challengers</b> to his claim that he is a priest. <b>However,</b> in a case <b>where there are no challengers, one elevates</b> a man <b>to priesthood on the basis of one witness. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says in the name of Rabbi Shimon, son of the deputy</b> High Priest: <b>One elevates</b> a man <b>to priesthood on the basis of one witness.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>all these</b> different cases cited in the <i>mishnayot</i> in this chapter? Aren’t they all based on the principle: The mouth that prohibited is the mouth that permitted? The Gemara answers: These cases are all <b>necessary, as, if</b> the <i>tanna</i> had <b>taught</b> only the case where <b>Rabbi Yehoshua concedes, in</b> a case where one says to another: This field, which is currently in my possession, belonged to your father, and I purchased it from him, then one might have thought that his claim is deemed credible <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that there is financial significance [<i>derara</i>]</b> in his contention that it belonged to the other’s father, and he would not have made that claim if it were not true. However, in the case of witnesses authenticating their signatures, <b>where there is no financial significance</b> for them in their testimony, <b>say no,</b> their claim is not accepted.
<b>And if</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taugh</b>t only the case of <b>witnesses,</b> one might have thought that their claim is deemed credible <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> their testimony is relevant <b>to others. However,</b> with regard to <b>him, whose</b> testimony is relevant <b>to himself,</b> as he claims that he purchased the field from the other’s father,

Daf 24a

<b>say no,</b> his claim is not accepted.
<b>And if</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us these two</b> cases, one might have thought that the claim is deemed credible <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the cases involve <b>monetary</b> matters; <b>however,</b> in the case of <b>a married woman</b> who claims that she was divorced, <b>which is a ritual</b> matter, <b>say no,</b> she is <b>not</b> deemed credible. Therefore, it was necessary for the <i>tanna</i> to teach us all three cases.
The Gemara asks: With regard to the case where one says: <b>I was taken captive and I am pure, why do I need</b> the <i>tanna</i> to teach that case? There is no novel element in that ruling, as it is merely another application of the same principle. The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> taught that case <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>sought to teach</b> based on it: <b>And if the witnesses came after she married, this</b> woman need <b>not leave</b> her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> works out <b>well according to the one who teaches</b> this <i>halakha</i> in reference <b>to the latter clause</b> of the mishna with regard to a woman taken captive. <b>However, according to the one who taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> in reference <b>to the first clause</b> of the mishna, with regard to a woman who claimed that she was married and divorced, <b>what is there to say?</b> According to that opinion, the ruling with regard to a woman taken captive who claims that she remained pure is superfluous. If a woman is deemed credible in the case where the concern is that she is a married woman, she is all the more so deemed credible when the concern pertains to a less severe prohibition, that of a woman who was violated in captivity marrying a priest. The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> taught the superfluous <i>halakha</i> that a woman claiming that she was taken captive and remained pure is deemed credible as an introduction, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he sought to</b> subsequently <b>teach</b> the case of <b>two women who were taken captive.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And why do I</b> need the <i>tanna</i> to teach the case of <b>two women who were taken captive?</b> What novel element is introduced in that case that did not exist in the case of one woman? The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say: Let us be concerned for collusion</b> between the women, that each would testify for the benefit of the other, the <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that this is not a concern.
The Gemara asks: <b>And why do I</b> need the <i>tanna</i> to teach the following case: <b>And likewise two men,</b> each testifying that the other is a priest? He already taught that if two women each testify that the other is pure, they are deemed credible. The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> taught the superfluous <i>halakha</i> with regard to two men as an introduction, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he sought to</b> subsequently <b>teach the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis,</b> concerning whether or not the testimony of a single witness is deemed credible to establish another’s presumptive status as a priest.
§ The Gemara elaborates: <b>The Rabbis taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of two men, each of whom says: <b>I am a priest and my counterpart is a priest,</b> each <b>is deemed credible</b> with regard <b>to enabling his</b> counterpart <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>. But he is not deemed credible</b> with regard to establishing his presumptive status as a priest of unflawed lineage <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>his marrying a woman until there are three</b> people, the two claiming to be priests and an additional witness, so <b>that</b> there are <b>two</b> witnesses <b>testifying</b> with regard <b>to</b> the status of <b>this</b> person <b>and two</b> witnesses <b>testifying</b> with regard <b>to</b> the status of <b>that</b> person. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Each <b>is not deemed credible even</b> with regard <b>to enabling his</b> counterpart <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i> until there are three</b> men, so <b>that</b> there are <b>two</b> witnesses <b>testifying</b> with regard <b>to this</b> person <b>and two</b> witnesses <b>testifying</b> with regard <b>to that</b> person.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that Rabbi Yehuda is concerned for collusion</b> between them, <b>and the Rabbis are not concerned for collusion? But didn’t we learn</b> that <b>they</b> said the <b>opposite? As we learned</b> in a mishna: In a case where there were <b>donkey drivers who entered a city, and one of them said: My</b> produce <b>is new</b> from this year’s crop, and it is not yet completely dry and therefore of lower quality, <b>and the</b> produce <b>of my counterpart is old</b> and dry and therefore more durable; or if he said: <b>My</b> produce <b>is not tithed and the</b> produce <b>of my counterpart is tithed, he is not deemed credible.</b> Presumably, there is collusion between the two merchants. In this city, one denigrates the quality of his own produce, enhancing his credibility, while praising the quality of the produce of his counterpart; and his counterpart says the same in the next city that they enter. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda says: He is deemed credible,</b> as apparently he is not concerned for collusion between the merchants.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The attribution of <b>the opinions is reversed</b> in one of the <i>mishnayot</i>, so that the opinions of the <i>tanna’im</i> are consistent in both the case of the priests and the case of the donkey drivers. <b>Abaye said: Actually, do not reverse</b> the attribution, and the fact that Rabbi Yehuda accepts the claim of the donkey driver is because <b>with regard to doubtfully tithed produce [<i>demai</i>]</b> the Sages <b>were lenient,</b> because <b>most <i>amei ha’aretz</i> tithe</b> their produce. The ordinance of the Sages classifying produce purchased from an <i>am ha’aretz</i> as doubtfully tithed produce and requiring its tithing is based on a far-fetched concern. Therefore, testimony of any sort is sufficient to permit its consumption. However, as a rule, Rabbi Yehuda is concerned about collusion.
<b>Rava said:</b> Is that to say that the contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and another statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda is difficult,</b> but the contradiction between one statement <b>of the Rabbis and</b> another statement <b>of the Rabbis is not difficult?</b> Clearly, the contradiction between the rulings of the Rabbis in the respective <i>mishnayot</i> is difficult. <b>Rather,</b> the contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and another statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda is not difficult, as we explained</b> above that Rabbi Yehuda was lenient with regard to doubtfully tithed produce. The contradiction between one statement <b>of the Rabbis and</b> another statement <b>of the Rabbis is</b> also <b>not difficult.</b> Fundamentally, the Rabbis are not concerned for collusion between the two parties. However, in the case of donkey drivers they are concerned, <b>as Rabbi Ḥama bar Ukva said</b> in another context that it is referring to a case <b>where one has the tools of his trade in his hand.</b>

Daf 24b

<b>Here too,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the second donkey driver comes <b>with the tools of his trade in his hand,</b> clearly indicating that he too came to sell his produce. Therefore, when the other driver praises his produce, there is room for concern that there was collusion and that in the next city their roles will be reversed. However, when there is no proof of collusion, the Rabbis were not concerned.
The Gemara asks: <b>And where</b> is the solution <b>of Rabbi Ḥama bar Ukva stated?</b> It is stated <b>concerning that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 7:1): In the case of <b>a potter who</b> fashioned his vessels in ritual purity, and <b>abandoned his pots, and descended to drink water from the river,</b> there is concern that in his absence ritually impure people came into contact with his pots. <b>The inner</b> pots <b>are pure, and the outer</b> pots <b>are impure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Both these</b> inner pots <b>and those</b> outer pots <b>are ritually impure? Rabbi Ḥama bar Ukva said:</b> That <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where <b>the tools of</b> the potter’s <b>trade are in his hand,</b> indicating that he intends to sell his pots. <b>Since all</b> potential buyers <b>touch</b> pots when examining them before purchase, the concern is that among those people there is one who is ritually impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: <b>Both these</b> inner pots <b>and those</b> outer pots <b>are ritually pure? Rabbi Ḥama bar Ukva said:</b> That <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where <b>the tools of</b> the potter’s <b>trade are not in his hand,</b> indicating that he does not intend to sell his pots. Therefore, strangers will not touch them at all.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, the ruling in the mishna: <b>The inner</b> pots <b>are pure and the outer</b> pots <b>are impure, under what</b> circumstances <b>can</b> this case <b>be found?</b> When the tools of the potter’s trade are in his hand, all the vessels are impure, and when the tools of the potter’s trade are not in his hand, all the vessels are pure.
The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> of the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the tools of the potter’s trade are not in his hand. However, he leaves his pots <b>adjacent to the public domain, and</b> in an area demarcated from the public domain <b>due to the stakes</b> or other objects that are placed on the sides of <b>the public domain</b> to distance passersby from the walls of the private domain, and due to crowding, people will be pushed to the sides and inadvertently render the outer pots impure. They do not pass close to the inner pots and will not touch the pots to examine them, because they are not for sale.
The Gemara proceeds to cite an additional resolution to the contradiction between the opinions of Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis, with regard to collusion in terms of the presumptive status of priests and in terms of produce merchants. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the dispute between <b>Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis</b> in the matter of presumptive priestly status is unrelated to collusion. Rather, it is <b>with regard to</b> whether <b>one elevates</b> one who eats <b><i>teruma</i> to</b> the presumptive status of priesthood <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>lineage</b> that <b>they disagree.</b> Rabbi Yehuda holds that one elevates from <i>teruma</i> to lineage and therefore requires full-fledged testimony by two witnesses to enable the person to partake of <i>teruma</i>. The Rabbis maintain that one does not elevate from <i>teruma</i> to lineage, and each matter is considered separately. For the purpose of partaking of <i>teruma</i>, any testimony is sufficient; for the purpose of lineage, full-fledged testimony by two witnesses is required.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to elevating from documents</b> indicating that one is a priest, <b>to</b> priestly <b>lineage?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If you say that it is written in</b> the document: <b>I, so-and-so, a priest, signed</b> as <b>a witness,</b> in that case <b>who is testifying about him</b> that he is a priest? He is the only source asserting his priesthood.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> this <i>halakha</i> is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where it is written in</b> the document: <b>I, so-and-so, a priest, borrowed one hundred dinars from so-and-so, and witnesses signed</b> the document, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do</b> the witnesses <b>testify</b> only <b>concerning the</b> loan of <b>one hundred dinars in the document? Or, perhaps they testify concerning the entire matter</b> and confirm with their signatures that every detail written in the document is true, including the fact that the borrower is a priest. With regard to the halakhic ruling, there is a dispute between <b>Rav Huna and Rav Ḥisda. One said: One elevates</b> from documents to priestly lineage, <b>and one said: One does not elevate.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to elevating from the lifting of hands</b> for the Priestly Benediction <b>to</b> priestly <b>lineage?</b> Is the presumptive status of a person who recites the Priestly Benediction in the synagogue that of a priest in terms of lineage as well? The Gemara notes: <b>Raise the dilemma</b> according <b>to the one who said: One elevates from <i>teruma</i> to lineage; and raise the dilemma</b> according <b>to the one who said: One does not elevate</b> from <i>teruma</i> to lineage.
The Gemara notes: <b>Raise the dilemma</b> according <b>to the one who said: One elevates</b> from <i>teruma</i> to lineage. In his opinion, perhaps <b>this applies only</b> to <b><i>teruma</i>, where</b> a non-priest who partakes of <i>teruma</i> performs <b>a transgression</b> whose punishment <b>is death</b> at the hand of Heaven. One would not partake of <i>teruma</i> and risk that punishment if he were not a priest. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>the Priestly Benediction,</b> where a non-priest who recites it violates <b>a prohibition</b> stated as <b>a positive mitzva, no,</b> one cannot be certain that one would not recite the blessing if he were not a priest. Therefore, one does not elevate from the lifting of hands to priestly lineage. <b>Or, perhaps</b> there is <b>no difference,</b> and in both cases because there is a transgression involved one can assume that he would not risk performing a transgression were he not a priest.
<b>Raise the dilemma</b> according <b>to the one who said: One does not elevate</b> from <i>teruma</i> to lineage. In his opinion, perhaps <b>this applies only</b> to <b><i>teruma</i> that is eaten in private.</b> Therefore, a non-priest might partake of <i>teruma</i> when he believes that no one is watching. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>the lifting of hands, which is</b> recited <b>in public [<i>parhesya</i>], if one is not a priest, he would not be insolent to</b> the <b>extent that</b> he would comport himself like a priest in public. Therefore, although partaking of <i>teruma</i> is not a clear indicator that he is a priest, reciting the Priestly Benediction is a clear indicator. <b>Or perhaps,</b> there is <b>no difference,</b> and due to the concern lest a non-priest partake of <i>teruma</i> in private and recite the Priestly Benediction in public, neither action can facilitate elevating the person to the presumptive status of a priest in terms of lineage.
There is a dispute with regard to the halakhic ruling between <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rabbi Avina. One said: One elevates</b> from the Priestly Benediction to lineage, <b>and one said: One does not elevate. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rava: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to elevating from the lifting of hands to lineage? Rava said to him:</b> There is <b>a dispute between Rav Ḥisda and Rabbi Avina.</b>
Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak asked Rava: <b>What is the <i>halakha</i>?</b> Rava <b>said to him: I know</b> and base the halakhic ruling on <b>a <i>baraita</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Great is</b> the legal authority of <b>presumptive status,</b> as one may rely upon it in determining halakhic practice, <b>as it is stated: “And of the children of the priests: The children of Habaiah, the children of Hakkoz, the children of Barzillai, who took a wife of the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite, and was called after their name. These sought their register of the genealogy, but it was not found; therefore were they deemed tainted and put from the priesthood. And the Tirshatha said unto them that they should not partake of the most sacred items, until there stood up a priest with Urim VeTummim”</b> (Ezra 2:61–63).
Rabbi Yosei explains: Nehemiah <b>said to</b> the priests whose status was uncertain: <b>You</b> maintain <b>your presumptive status. Of what did you partake in the</b> Babylonian <b>exile?</b> It was <b>the consecrated items</b> eaten in <b>the outlying areas,</b> i.e., <i>teruma</i>. <b>Here too,</b> you may continue to partake of the <b>consecrated items</b> eaten in <b>the outlying areas,</b> but you may not partake of offerings, with regard to which you have no presumptive status of priesthood. The Gemara asks: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> to say <b>that one elevates from the lifting of hands to lineage, they will come to elevate those</b> priests whose status was uncertain to priestly status in terms of lineage, <b>since they lifted their hands</b> and recited the Priestly Benediction in exile.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here it is different.</b> There was no concern lest they elevate them to lineage <b>because their presumptive status was undermined</b> by the fact that they did not partake of offerings like the other priests. <b>As, if you do not say that</b> one relies on the fact that their status was undermined, <b>according to the one who said: One elevates from <i>teruma</i> to lineage, since they partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> there should be concern lest <b>they come to elevate them</b> to lineage. <b>Rather,</b> is the reason that this is not a concern <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>their presumptive status was undermined,</b> and it is clear to all that there is uncertainty with regard to their status as priests? However, one may not infer from the time of Nehemiah to a time when all priests eat <i>teruma</i> and recite the Priestly Benediction, and there is no factor that indicates that they are anything less than full-fledged priests. Perhaps, then, one elevates from <i>teruma</i> and from the lifting of hands to lineage.

Daf 25a

The Gemara asks: <b>And what, then,</b> is the meaning of: <b>Great is</b> the legal authority of <b>presumptive status?</b> This is a standard case of presumptive status, as the practice of the priests remained as it was. There is nothing novel in the application of the principle of presumptive status in this case. The Gemara answers: <b>Initially,</b> in the Babylonian exile, they would <b>partake of <i>teruma</i></b> taken from produce obligated <b>by rabbinic</b> law. <b>Now,</b> upon their return to Eretz Yisrael, <b>they partake of <i>teruma</i></b> taken from produce obligated <b>by Torah</b> law: Grain, wine, and oil, based on their presumptive status.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Now too,</b> upon their return to Eretz Yisrael, <b>they partake of <i>teruma</i></b> taken from produce obligated <b>by rabbinic</b> law. However, <b>of <i>teruma</i></b> taken from produce obligated <b>by Torah</b> law <b>they may not partake. And when we elevate from <i>teruma</i> to lineage,</b> this is only <b>with regard to</b> one who partakes of <b><i>teruma</i> by Torah</b> law. However, in the case of one who partakes of <b><i>teruma</i> by rabbinic</b> law, <b>we do not elevate</b> him to priestly lineage. The Gemara asks: <b>And what,</b> then, is the meaning of: <b>Great is</b> the legal authority of <b>presumptive status?</b> The Gemara answers: It means that <b>although there is</b> reason <b>to issue a decree</b> in Eretz Yisrael prohibiting consumption of <i>teruma</i> by rabbinic law, <b>due to <i>teruma</i></b> that is forbidden <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>we do not issue that decree</b> because: Great is the legal authority of presumptive status.
The Gemara asks: <b>And did they</b> in fact <b>not partake of <i>teruma</i> by Torah</b> law? <b>But isn’t it written: “That they should not partake of the most sacred items [<i>kodesh hakodashim</i>]”</b> (Ezra 2:63), from which it may be inferred: It is <b>of the most sacred items,</b> i.e., offerings, <b>that they did not partake; of <i>teruma</i> by Torah</b> law, <b>they did partake.</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>this is</b> what the verse <b>is saying: Neither</b> did they partake <b>of items called <i>kodesh</i>, as it is written: “And no common man may eat of <i>kodesh</i>”</b> (Leviticus 22:10), referring to <i>teruma</i>, <b>nor</b> did they partake <b>of items called <i>kodashim</i>, as it is written: “And if a priest’s daughter be married to a common man, she shall not eat of <i>terumat hakodashim</i>”</b> (Leviticus 22:12). <b>The Master said</b> that this means: <b>Of</b> that which is <b>set aside from the offerings [<i>kodashim</i>]</b> to the priests, i.e., the loaves of the thanks-offering and the breast and the shoulder, <b>they may not partake.</b> According to neither explanation can any proof be cited from the <i>baraita</i> as to whether or not one elevates from <i>teruma</i> or from the Priestly Benediction to lineage.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Presumptive status for priesthood</b> is established by <b>the lifting of hands in Babylonia;</b> by <b>partaking of <i>ḥalla</i> in Syria; and</b> by <b>distributing</b> priestly <b>gifts,</b> i.e., the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw, <b>in the cities. In any event,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> that <b>the lifting of hands</b> establishes the presumptive status of priesthood. The Gemara asks: <b>What,</b> does <b>it not</b> establish presumptive status <b>for lineage?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it establishes presumptive status <b>for <i>teruma</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> lifting of hands <b>taught parallel to partaking of <i>ḥalla</i>? Just as</b> with regard to <b>partaking of <i>ḥalla</i></b> the <i>tanna</i> teaches that it establishes presumptive status <b>for lineage, so too</b> with regard to <b>the lifting of hands</b> the <i>tanna</i> teaches that it establishes presumptive status <b>for lineage.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No, partaking of <i>ḥalla</i> itself</b> establishes presumptive status only <b>for <i>teruma</i></b> and not for lineage. This <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that <b>today</b> the obligation to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> from dough <b>is by rabbinic</b> law <b>and</b> the obligation to separate <b><i>teruma</i> is by Torah</b> law. The <i>tanna</i> teaches that <b>we elevate from <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> which is an obligation <b>by rabbinic</b> law, to <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> which is <b>by Torah</b> law. <b>And</b> this explanation is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua,</b> cited below, <b>who reversed</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> and posited that <i>ḥalla</i> today is an obligation by rabbinic law.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come and hear</b> proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Presumptive status for priesthood</b> is established <b>in Eretz Yisrael</b> by <b>the lifting of hands and distribution</b> of <i>teruma</i> at the <b>threshing floors. And in Syria and everyplace</b> outside Eretz Yisrael <b>that emissaries</b> informing residents of the Diaspora of sanctification of <b>the New Moon arrive, the lifting of hands</b> constitutes <b>proof</b> of presumptive status for priesthood, as the court would investigate the lineage of everyone who recited the Priestly Benediction. <b>But distribution</b> of <i>teruma</i> at the <b>threshing floors</b> does <b>not</b> constitute proof of that status. Since there is no obligation of <i>teruma</i> by Torah law, the courts were not as resolute in examining the lineage of those to whom <i>teruma</i> was distributed.
<b>And</b> the status in <b>Babylonia</b> is <b>like</b> that in <b>Syria,</b> as there, too, there are permanent courts that examine the lineage of those reciting the Priestly Benediction. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Even Alexandria of Egypt initially</b> had the same status as Syria, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that there</b> was <b>a permanent court there</b> ensuring that the lifting of hands was performed only by a priest.
<b>In any event,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> that <b>the lifting of hands</b> establishes the presumptive status of priesthood. The Gemara asks: <b>What,</b> does <b>it not</b> establish presumptive status <b>for lineage?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the lifting of hands establishes presumptive status <b>for <i>ḥalla</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> the <i>halakha</i> of lifting of hands <b>taught parallel to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>distribution</b> of <i>teruma</i> at the <b>threshing floors? Just as distribution</b> of <i>teruma</i> at the <b>threshing floors</b> in Eretz Yisrael establishes presumptive status <b>for lineage, so too, the lifting of hands</b> establishes presumptive status <b>for lineage.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No, distribution</b> of <i>teruma</i> at the <b>threshing floors</b> establishes presumptive status only <b>for <i>ḥalla</i></b> but not for lineage. This <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that <b>today</b> the obligation to separate <b><i>teruma</i> is by rabbinic</b> law, <b>and <i>ḥalla</i> is by Torah</b> law. The <i>tanna</i> teaches that <b>we elevate from <i>teruma</i>,</b> which is an obligation <b>by rabbinic</b> law, to <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> which is <b>by Torah</b> law.
<b>And</b> the dispute with regard to the legal status of <i>teruma</i> and <i>ḥalla</i> today is <b>as</b> in the incident <b>where Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, found</b> that this is the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, as Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: I found the Sages in the</b> study <b>hall of Rav, who were sitting and saying: Even according to the one who said that <i>teruma</i> today is</b> an obligation <b>by rabbinic</b> law, the obligation to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i> is by Torah</b> law, <b>as</b> during the <b>seven</b> years <b>that</b> the Israelites <b>conquered</b> the land of Canaan led by Joshua <b>and</b> during the <b>seven</b> years <b>that they divided</b> the land, <b>they were obligated in <i>ḥalla</i> but were not obligated in <i>teruma</i>.</b> Today, too, although there is no obligation to take <i>teruma</i> in Eretz Yisrael by Torah law, the obligation to separate <i>ḥalla</i> is by Torah law.
<b>And I said to them: On the contrary, even according to the one who said that <i>teruma</i> today is</b> an obligation <b>by Torah</b> law, the obligation to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i> is by rabbinic</b> law, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse concerning <i>ḥalla</i>: <b>“When you come into the land</b>…from the first of your dough you should separate <i>teruma</i>” (Numbers 15:18–19). <b>If</b> the obligation is <b>when you come,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that it took effect <b>from</b> the moment <b>that two or three spies entered</b> the land, therefore <b>the verse states: “When you come,”</b> from which it is derived that God is saying: <b>I said</b> that the obligation takes effect <b>with the coming of all of you and not with the coming of some of you.</b> Separating <i>ḥalla</i> is an obligation by Torah law only when the entire Jewish people comes to Eretz Yisrael, <b>and when Ezra took them up</b> to Eretz Yisrael at the beginning of the Second Temple period,

Daf 25b

<b>not all of them ascended.</b> Since the majority of the people did not come to the land, separating <i>ḥalla</i> was not restored to the status of an obligation by Torah law.
The Gemara cites proof from another <i>baraita</i> to resolve the dilemma. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> The <b>presumptive status for priesthood</b> is established by <b>Lifting of the Hands</b> for the Priestly Benediction, <b>and</b> by <b>distribution</b> of <i>teruma</i> at the <b>threshing floors, and</b> by <b>testimony.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Does testimony</b> merely establish <b>presumptive status?</b> Testimony provides absolute proof of his status, not merely a presumption. <b>Rather is it not</b> that <b>this is what</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying: Lifting of the Hands</b> is <b>like testimony, just as testimony</b> that one is a priest elevates him to the priesthood <b>for lineage, so too Lifting of the Hands</b> establishes presumptive status <b>for lineage.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> when the <i>tanna</i> is referring to testimony, he is stating that the legal status of <b>testimony that is based on presumptive status is like</b> that of <b>presumptive status</b> itself.
<b>As</b> in the incident involving <b>a certain</b> man <b>who came before Rabbi Ami</b> and <b>said to him: That</b> man established <b>presumptive status</b> before <b>me that he is a priest.</b> Rabbi Ami <b>said to him: What did you see</b> that led you to that conclusion? <b>He said to</b> Rabbi Ami: I saw <b>that he</b> was called to the Torah and <b>read first in the synagogue.</b> Rabbi Ami asked him: Did he read first based <b>on the presumptive status that he is a priest, or</b> was it based <b>on the presumptive status that he is a great</b> man? The custom was that a priest would be called to the Torah first, unless there was a prominent Torah scholar among the worshippers. He said to Rabbi Ami: He read the Torah as a priest, <b>as after him a Levite read</b> the Torah. A Levite is called to the Torah second only when a priest is called first. <b>And Rabbi Ami elevated him to the priesthood, on the basis of his</b> statement.
The Gemara relates an incident involving <b>a certain</b> man <b>who came before Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> and <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: <b>That</b> man established the <b>presumptive status</b> before <b>me that he is a Levite.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>said to him: What did you see</b> that led you to that conclusion? <b>He said to</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: I saw <b>that he</b> was called to the Torah and that he <b>read second in the synagogue.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi asked him: Did he read second based <b>on the presumptive status that he is a Levite, or</b> was it based <b>on the presumptive status that he is a great</b> man? When there is no priest in the synagogue, people in the synagogue are called to the Torah in order of their prominence. Perhaps he was the second most prominent man in the synagogue. He said to Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: I am certain that he is a Levite, <b>as a priest read</b> the Torah <b>before him. And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi elevated him to Levite status, based on his</b> statement.
The Gemara relates another incident involving <b>a certain man who came before Reish Lakish</b> and <b>said to</b> Reish Lakish: <b>That</b> man established the <b>presumptive status</b> before <b>me that he is a priest.</b> Reish Lakish <b>said to him: What did you see</b> that led you to that conclusion? <b>He said to</b> Reish Lakish: I saw <b>that he</b> was called to the Torah and <b>read first in the synagogue.</b> Reish Lakish, based on his opinion that one’s presumptive status as a priest can be established only on the basis of his receiving <i>teruma</i>, <b>said to him: Did you see that he received a share</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>at the threshing floor? Rabbi Elazar said to</b> Reish Lakish: <b>And if there is no threshing floor there,</b> does <b>the priesthood cease</b> to exist? The testimony that he read from the Torah first is sufficient.
On another <b>occasion</b> Rabbi Elazar and Reish Lakish <b>sat before Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> A matter <b>similar</b> to <b>that incident,</b> where one testified that another is a priest based on his reading the Torah first, <b>came before</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan. <b>Reish Lakish said to</b> the person who testified: <b>Did you see that he received a share</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>at the threshing floor? Rabbi Yoḥanan said to</b> Reish Lakish: <b>And if there is no threshing floor there,</b> does <b>the priesthood cease</b> to exist? The Gemara relates that Reish Lakish <b>turned and looked at Rabbi Elazar harshly,</b> as he understood that on the previous occasion, Rabbi Elazar was citing verbatim a ruling that he heard from Rabbi Yoḥanan. Reish Lakish <b>said</b> to Rabbi Elazar: <b>You heard a statement of bar Nappaḥa,</b> the son of a blacksmith, an epithet for Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>and you did not say</b> it <b>to us in his name?</b> Had you done so, I would have accepted it from you then.
The Gemara relates with regard to <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> that <b>one elevated a son to priesthood on the basis of</b> the statement of <b>his father, and one elevated a brother to</b> the <b>Levite status on the basis of</b> the statement of <b>his brother.</b> It is unclear which of the Sages ruled in which case.
