The Gemara notes: <b>It may be concluded that Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi is the one who <b>elevated a son to priesthood on the basis of</b> the statement of <b>his father, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that if one <b>came and said: This is my son and he is a priest,</b> his statement is <b>deemed credible to enable</b> his son <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>, but</b> it <b>is not deemed credible to marry a woman</b> of superior lineage <b>to him,</b> as his testimony is not deemed credible for the purposes of lineage; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said to him: If you deem</b> the father <b>credible to enable</b> his son <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>, deem him credible to marry a woman to</b> his son. <b>And if you do not deem him credible to marry a woman to him, do not deem him credible</b> to enable his son <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b>
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: I deem him credible to enable</b> his son <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>, as it is within his purview to feed</b> his son <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> and one is deemed credible with regard to matters that are within his purview. <b>But I do not deem him credible to marry a woman to</b> his son, <b>as it is not within his purview to marry a woman to</b> his son, and therefore his testimony is not accepted. The Gemara determines: Indeed, it may be <b>concluded</b> that it is Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi who elevated a son to priesthood on the basis of the statement of his father. <b>And from</b> the fact <b>that</b> it is <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi who <b>elevated a son to priesthood on the basis of</b> the statement of <b>his father,</b> clearly it is <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> who <b>elevated a brother to Levite status on the basis of</b> the statement of <b>his brother.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya, what is different</b> in the case of <b>a son, where</b> a father is <b>not</b> deemed credible <b>because</b> the son <b>is a relative of his father,</b> and therefore the father is disqualified from testifying about his son? <b>A brother is also a relative of his brother,</b> and therefore the brother should have been disqualified from testifying about his brother. Rabbi Ḥiyya should accept the testimony in both cases or reject the testimony in both cases.

Daf 26a

The Gemara answers: Rabbi Ḥiyya is speaking <b>of</b> a case where the brother <b>speaks offhandedly</b> in the context of a conversation about a different topic. It was understood from this that his brother is a Levite. This is <b>similar to that which Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> There was <b>an incident involving a person who was speaking offhandedly and said: I remember when I was a child and</b> still young enough to be <b>carried on my father’s shoulder, and they took me out of school, and removed my cloak, and immersed me</b> to purify me from any possible ritual impurity, so that I would be able <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i> that evening.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> who related that incident, <b>concluded</b> the story and related that the man said: <b>And my friends distanced</b> themselves <b>from me, and would call me: Yoḥanan who partakes of <i>ḥallot</i>,</b> as it was prohibited for his friends, who were non-priests, to eat <i>ḥalla</i> and <i>teruma</i>. <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>elevated him to priesthood based on his</b> statement. Just as one’s offhanded statement is reliable, so too, is the offhanded statement of one’s brother.
§ <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Just as <i>teruma</i></b> establishes the <b>presumptive status for priesthood, so too</b> the <b>first tithe</b> establishes the <b>presumptive status for priesthood. And one who receives a share</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in court</b> does <b>not</b> establish the <b>presumptive status</b> of priesthood.
The Gemara asks: <b>First tithe is</b> given <b>to a Levite.</b> How does it establish the presumptive status of priesthood? The Gemara answers: This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b><i>Teruma</i> is</b> given <b>to a priest, first tithe is</b> given <b>to a Levite;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says: First tithe</b> is given <b>to a priest as well.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Say</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya said: To a priest as well. Did he</b> actually <b>say to a priest and not to a Levite?</b> Since it is given to both a Levite and a priest, first tithe cannot establish the presumptive status of priesthood.
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> first tithe can establish the presumptive status of priesthood. <b>After Ezra penalized</b> the Levites for failure to return to Eretz Yisrael from Babylonia, he decreed that the people should not give them first tithe. Although by Torah law first tithe may be given to both Levites and priests, after that decree, it was given only to priests. The Gemara asks: How can the presumptive status of priesthood be established? <b>But perhaps</b> in this case he was actually a Levite, and <b>by happenstance they gave him</b> first tithe. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: With what are we dealing here?</b> It is a case <b>where the father of that</b> man established the <b>presumptive status of priesthood before us, and a rumor emerged</b> about the son <b>that he is the son of a divorced woman or the son of a <i>ḥalutza</i>.</b> As a <i>ḥalal</i>, who is disqualified from the priesthood, his legal status is that of an Israelite. <b>And</b> it was seen that the son <b>himself received a share of</b> first <b>tithe at the threshing floor.</b>
Therefore, with regard to <b>Levite</b> status, it is clear <b>that he is not a Levite,</b> as his father is a priest. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> then <b>is there to say?</b> Is it that <b>he is the son of a divorced woman or the son of a <i>ḥalutza</i>? It is not necessary to say that</b> according <b>to the one who says</b> that <b>first tithe is forbidden to non-priests, they would not have given</b> first tithe to the son of the divorcée, as his legal status is that of a non-priest. <b>However, even according to the one who says that first tithe is permitted for non-priests,</b> and therefore the fact that he received first tithe proves nothing, <b>that</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>applies only</b> to the fact that it is permitted for one to whom first tithe produce was distributed <b>to provide</b> it to non-priests. <b>However, in the form of a share</b> of first tithe <b>at the threshing floor, one does not give</b> it <b>to</b> a non-priest. Therefore, according to Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, the fact that one receives a share at the threshing floor proves that he is a priest of unflawed lineage.
It is taught in the same <i>baraita</i>: <b>And one who receives a share</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>in court</b> does <b>not</b> establish the <b>presumptive status</b> of priesthood. The Gemara asks: <b>If in court it</b> does <b>not</b> establish the <b>presumptive status, where does it</b> establish the <b>presumptive status?</b> Isn’t court the place where matters are optimally clarified? <b>Rav Sheshet said</b> that <b>this is what</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying: One who receives a share of <i>teruma</i> from his father’s property with his brothers in court</b> as his portion of the inheritance, in doing so does <b>not</b> establish <b>presumptive status</b> of priesthood. Even if he is a <i>ḥalal</i> and therefore a non-priest, it could be that he owns the <i>teruma</i> as part of his inheritance.
The Gemara asks: It <b>is obvious</b> that receiving <i>teruma</i> in court does not establish the presumptive status. The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>from</b> the fact <b>that these</b> brothers receive the <i>teruma</i> <b>to partake</b> of it, it can be deduced that <b>that</b> brother <b>also</b> receives the <i>teruma</i> <b>to partake</b> of it, the <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that <b>these</b> brothers receive the <i>teruma</i> <b>to partake</b> of it and <b>that</b> brother receives it <b>to sell it.</b> The fact that he may not eat the <i>teruma</i> does not prevent him from selling it.
§ We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One does not elevate</b> a man <b>to priesthood on the basis of one witness.</b> Rabbi Elazar says: In a case where there are no challengers, one elevates a man to priesthood on the basis of one witness. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: One elevates a man to priesthood on the basis of one witness. The Gemara asks: The opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel is</b> identical to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> as they agree that one elevates a man to priesthood on the basis of one witness when there are no challengers. <b>And if you would say that there is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> in a case where there is <b>a challenge</b> posed by <b>one</b> witness, <b>as Rabbi Eliezer holds: A challenge</b> posed by <b>one</b> witness is sufficient to undermine one’s presumptive status of priesthood and two witnesses are required to overcome that challenge, <b>and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds:</b> An effective <b>challenge</b> requires <b>two</b> witnesses, <b>didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: Everyone agrees</b> that <b>there is no</b> effective <b>challenge</b> with <b>fewer than two</b> witnesses?
<b>Rather, with what</b> case <b>are we dealing here?</b> It is in a case <b>where the father of that</b> man established his <b>presumptive status of priesthood before us, and a rumor emerged about</b> the son <b>that he is the son of a divorced woman or the son of a <i>ḥalutza</i>, and</b> therefore <b>we downgraded him</b> from the presumptive status of priesthood. <b>And one</b> witness <b>came and said: I know that he is a priest</b> of unflawed lineage,

Daf 26b

<b>and</b> therefore <b>we elevated</b> him back to the priesthood, as one witness is sufficient to negate the rumor. <b>And</b> then <b>two</b> witnesses <b>came and said: He is the son of a divorced woman or the son of a <i>ḥalutza</i>, and</b> then <b>we downgraded him</b> from the priesthood, as two witnesses negated the testimony of one witness. Then <b>one</b> witness <b>came and said: I know that he is a priest</b> of unflawed lineage. <b>And everyone agrees</b> that the two single witnesses <b>join</b> together and constitute two witnesses <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>testimony</b> that he is a priest of unflawed lineage, and fundamentally his presumptive status of priesthood should be restored.
<b>And here</b> it is <b>with regard to concern</b> that it will lead <b>to contempt for the court</b> that <b>they disagree. The first <i>tanna</i>,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds: Once we downgraded him</b> from the priesthood, <b>we do not</b> then <b>elevate him. We are concerned</b> that it will lead <b>to contempt for the court,</b> as the reversal in the court decisions create the impression that the court does not know what it is doing. <b>And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds: We downgrade him</b> from the priesthood <b>and we</b> then <b>elevate him, and</b> as for the possibility that it will lead <b>to contempt for the court, we are not concerned</b> about it. The primary concern is that the matter be determined based on the relevant testimonies.
<b>Rav Ashi</b> strongly <b>objects: If so,</b> if they disagree with regard to contempt for the court, why is it necessary to establish the dispute in a case where the witnesses who testified that he is a priest of unflawed lineage came individually? <b>If so,</b> then <b>even</b> if <b>two</b> witnesses testify together that he is unfit for the priesthood, and the court downgraded him, <b>and two</b> witnesses testify together that he is fit for the priesthood, and the court elevated him, the <i>tanna’im</i> would <b>also</b> disagree, as the same concern for contempt of court applies.
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi said:</b> It is <b>with regard to</b> whether two single witnesses <b>join</b> together and constitute two witnesses <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>testimony</b> that <b>they disagree, and</b> it is <b>in the dispute</b> between <b>these <i>tanna’im</i></b> that they disagree, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The testimony</b> of individual witnesses <b>merges</b> into the testimony of two witnesses <b>only if the two of them saw</b> the incident transpire together, <b>as one. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa says:</b> Their testimony merges <b>even in</b> a case where <b>this</b> witness saw the incident <b>after that</b> witness; <b>however, the testimony</b> of witnesses <b>is validated in court only</b> if <b>the two of them testify</b> together <b>as one.</b>
<b>Rabbi Natan says:</b> They need not even testify together, but even if the court <b>hears the statement of this</b> witness <b>today, and when his fellow</b> witness <b>comes tomorrow</b> the court <b>hears his statement,</b> their testimonies merge. Rabbi Eliezer holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa, and therefore the testimony of the second witness cannot be merged with the testimony of the first witness and the person remains a <i>ḥalal</i>. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds that the testimony of the two witnesses that he is a priest of unflawed lineage is merged, and his presumptive status of priesthood is restored, as it was already established that his father is a priest.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a woman who was imprisoned by gentiles due to a monetary</b> offense committed by her husband, once she is released after he pays his debt, <b>she is permitted to her husband,</b> even if he is a priest. There is no concern that they violated her because their objective is to coerce the husband to pay his debt in exchange for her release. Were they to abuse her, it is possible that he would be unwilling to pay. However, if a woman was imprisoned <b>due to a capital</b> offense and sentenced to death, once she is released <b>she is forbidden to her husband</b> even if he is not a priest due to the concern that perhaps her captors violated her, and she acquiesced to one of them.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>Rav said: They taught</b> this mishna <b>only</b> in a case <b>where the authority of the Jewish people is dominant over the nations of the world,</b> and the gentiles are law-abiding citizens. <b>However, when the authority of the nations of the world is dominant over themselves,</b> a euphemism for dominance over the Jewish people, <b>even</b> a woman who was imprisoned <b>due to a monetary</b> offense <b>is forbidden to her husband,</b> as there is nothing preventing her jailers from violating her.
<b>Rava raised an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Eduyyot</i> 8:2): <b>Rabbi Yosei the priest and Rabbi Zekharya ben HaKatzav testified about a Jewish woman</b> about <b>whom</b> witnesses testified that <b>she was taken as collateral</b> for a debt <b>in Ashkelon. And the members of her family,</b> who suspected that she engaged in intercourse there, <b>distanced themselves from her, but her witnesses testified about her that she neither entered into seclusion nor was violated. And the Sages said</b> to the members of the family: <b>If you deem</b> the witnesses <b>credible</b> to testify <b>that she was taken as collateral, deem</b> the witnesses <b>credible</b> to testify <b>that she neither entered into seclusion nor was violated. And if you do not deem</b> the witnesses <b>credible</b> to testify <b>that she neither entered into seclusion nor was violated, do not deem</b> the witnesses <b>credible</b> to testify <b>that she was taken as collateral</b> at all. In either case, she is permitted to her husband.
Rava asks: <b>But</b> this took place in <b>Ashkelon, which</b> is a place <b>where the authority of the nations of the world is dominant over themselves,</b> as it was a city of gentiles, <b>and it is taught:</b>

Daf 27a

<b>If she was taken as security,</b> in a case where her husband stipulated that if he fails to pay a debt the gentiles may take his wife and do with her as they please, <b>yes,</b> she requires witnesses to testify that she was not violated. However, if she was <b>imprisoned</b> by the authorities, <b>no,</b> she is deemed untainted even without witnesses. Apparently, the distinction is not based on the dominance of the Jewish people. Rather, it is based on the manner in which she was apprehended. The Gemara answers: <b>The same is true</b> that she is forbidden to her husband even <b>if she was imprisoned, and</b> the reason that the <i>tanna’im</i> testified about a case where she was taken as security is because <b>the incident that transpired, transpired</b> in <b>that</b> manner.
<b>Some say</b> a different version of this tradition. <b>Rava said</b> that <b>we too learn</b> a proof from a mishna for the statement that Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said that Rav said: <b>Rabbi Yosei the priest and Rabbi Zekharya ben HaKatzav testified about a Jewish woman</b> about <b>whom</b> witnesses testified that <b>she was taken as security</b> for a debt <b>in Ashkelon. And the members of her family,</b> who suspected that she engaged in intercourse there, <b>distanced themselves from her, and her witnesses testified about her that she neither entered into seclusion nor was violated. And the Sages said</b> to the members of the family: <b>If you believe</b> the witnesses <b>that she was taken as collateral, believe</b> the witnesses who say <b>that she neither entered into seclusion nor was violated. And if you do not believe</b> the witnesses <b>that she neither entered into seclusion nor was violated, do not believe</b> the witnesses <b>that she was taken as collateral</b> at all.
Rava asks: <b>But</b> in the case in <b>Ashkelon that was due to a monetary</b> offense, <b>the reason</b> that she was permitted is <b>that witnesses testified about her</b> that she was untainted. <b>However, if witnesses did not testify about her, no,</b> she would not be permitted to her husband, although she was taken due to a monetary offense. What, <b>is it not</b> that it <b>is no different</b> if she was <b>taken as collateral and</b> it <b>is no different</b> if she was <b>imprisoned?</b> Apparently, if the authority of the gentiles is dominant, even if she was imprisoned for the sake of money there is concern that she was violated. The Gemara rejects the proof: <b>No,</b> the case where the woman is <b>taken as collateral is different,</b> and only in that case, where her husband stipulated that the gentiles could take her, would the gentiles allow themselves to violate her. However, in a case where she is imprisoned there is no concern of that sort.
<b>Some raise it as a contradiction</b> between the sources. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: A woman who was taken hostage <b>due to a monetary</b> offense <b>is permitted to her husband. And they raise a contradiction</b> from the mishna in <i>Eduyyot</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> the priest and Rabbi Zekharya <b>ben HaKatzav testified</b> about a Jewish woman about whom witnesses testified that she was taken as collateral for a debt in Ashkelon. <b>But</b> this is not the case in <b>Ashkelon, which was due to a monetary</b> offense, <b>and it is taught</b> that <b>the reason</b> that the woman was permitted is <b>that witnesses testified about her</b> that she was untainted. <b>However, if witnesses did not testify about her, no,</b> she would not be permitted, although she was taken for the sake of money.
<b>And he answers</b> that <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> the mishna is referring to a period <b>when the authority of the Jewish people is dominant over the nations of the world.</b> Then, a woman taken hostage for the sake of money is permitted. <b>There</b> it is referring to a period <b>when the authority of the nations of the world is dominant over themselves</b> and over the Jewish people. Therefore, even a woman taken because of a monetary offense is forbidden unless witnesses testify that she is untainted.
§ We learned in the mishna: A woman who was imprisoned <b>because of a capital</b> offense <b>is forbidden to her husband. Rav said:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where the wives of thieves</b> are involved, as when thieves were apprehended and hanged, their wives were abandoned and made available to all, and they were not protected from potential rapists. <b>And Levi said:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where the wife of ben Donai,</b> a murderer, is involved, as in that case the government abandons his wife and makes her available to all, which is not the case when one is condemned for theft. <b>Ḥizkiyya said: And</b> this abandonment <b>is</b> only in a case <b>where</b> the husbands <b>were sentenced to death. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Although</b> their husbands <b>were not sentenced to death,</b> if the imprisonment is because of a capital offense, the women are abandoned and available to all.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a city that was conquered by</b> an army laying <b>siege, all the women</b> married to <b>priests located in</b> the city <b>are unfit</b> and forbidden to their husbands, due to the concern that they were raped. <b>And if they have witnesses, even</b> if the witness is <b>a slave, even</b> if the witness is <b>a maidservant,</b> both of whom are generally disqualified as witnesses, <b>they are deemed credible. And a person is not deemed credible</b> to establish his status <b>by his own</b> testimony. Therefore, a woman is not deemed credible to claim that she was not violated.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a mishna (<i>Avoda Zara</i> 70b): If there is <b>a</b> gentile <b>military unit that entered a city,</b> if it entered <b>during peacetime,</b> after the soldiers leave, the <b>open barrels</b> of wine are <b>forbidden</b> and the wine in them may not be drunk, due to suspicion that the gentile soldiers may have poured this wine as a libation for idolatry. The <b>sealed</b> barrels <b>are permitted.</b> However, if the unit entered <b>in wartime, both these and those are permitted because</b> in wartime <b>there is no respite to pour</b> wine for idolatry. One can be certain that the soldiers did not do so because the soldiers were preoccupied with preparations for a potential attack by the enemy. Why, then, is the mishna concerned that perhaps the soldiers laying siege to the city rape the women?
<b>Rav Mari said: To engage in intercourse there is respite; to pour</b> wine for idolatry <b>there is no respite. Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Elazar said in the name of Ḥizkiyya:</b> There is a different distinction between the cases. <b>There,</b> the mishna is referring <b>to the siege</b> of a city under the rule <b>of the same monarchy.</b> In that case, the soldiers, acting as the enforcement body of the monarchy, seek to minimize unnecessary damage to the city and will refrain from ruining the wine and raping the women. <b>Here,</b> the mishna is referring <b>to the siege</b> of a city under the rule <b>of a different monarchy.</b> Therefore, there are no restraints with regard to ruining the wine or raping the women.
The Gemara asks: <b>Even</b> in the siege of a city under the rule <b>of the same monarchy, it is impossible that one of</b> the soldiers <b>did not wander off</b> and rape a woman. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where</b> the <b>sentries see each other</b> and do not allow the soldiers to plunder the city. The Gemara asks: <b>It is impossible that</b> the sentries would <b>not doze a bit,</b> enabling some soldiers to enter and plunder the city. <b>Rabbi Levi said:</b> It is referring to a case <b>where they surround the city with chains, and dogs, and branches [<i>gavza</i>], and geese,</b> as obstacles preventing unauthorized entry.
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Zavda said: Rabbi Yehuda Nesia,</b> grandson of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, redactor of the mishna, <b>and the Rabbis dispute</b> this matter. <b>One said: There,</b> the mishna is referring <b>to the siege</b> of a city under the rule <b>of the same monarchy. Here,</b> the mishna is referring <b>to the siege</b> of a city under the rule <b>of a different monarchy, and it</b> was <b>not difficult for him at all,</b> as in that case there is no concern that perhaps an individual soldier would enter the city. <b>And for</b> the other <b>one, all these</b> questions <b>were difficult, and he answers:</b> It is referring to a case <b>where they surround the city with chains, and dogs, and branches, and geese.</b>
§ With regard to the ruling in the mishna, <b>Rav Idi bar Avin said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Ashyan said: If there is a single hideaway there</b> in the city, where the women could hide from the soldiers, <b>it saves all the women</b> married to <b>priests.</b> Due to the uncertainty, the presumption is that each of the women found the hideaway, and therefore they are not forbidden to their husbands.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> If the hideaway <b>holds only one</b> woman, <b>what is</b> the ruling? <b>Do we say that</b> with regard to <b>each</b> woman who appears before us, <b>this is</b> the one who hid there, and each is permitted to her husband? <b>Or, perhaps we do not</b> say that.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this <b>different from</b> the case of <b>two paths?</b> As we learned in a mishna: There were two paths, <b>one</b> that was <b>ritually impure</b> due to a corpse buried there <b>and one</b> that was <b>ritually pure. And</b> one <b>walked on one of them,</b> but he does not remember which, <b>and</b> afterward <b>engaged in</b> handling items of <b>ritual purity,</b> e.g., <i>teruma</i> or consecrated items. <b>And another</b> person <b>came and walked on the second</b> path, and he too does not remember which path it was, <b>and he</b> also <b>engaged in</b> handling items of <b>ritual purity.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If this</b> one <b>asked</b> a Sage <b>in and of himself, and that</b> one <b>asked</b> a Sage <b>in and of himself, they are</b> both <b>pure.</b> When considered separately, each person retains his presumptive status of ritual purity. However, if they <b>both</b> came to ask <b>at the same time, they are</b> both <b>ritually impure.</b> Since one of the two certainly passed on the impure path, although it is uncertain which, both are deemed impure due to that uncertainty. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: One way or another they are</b> both <b>ritually impure.</b>
<b>And Rava said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> who elaborates: If they came <b>at the same time, everyone agrees</b> that <b>they are ritually impure,</b> as even Rabbi Yehuda concedes that this is the <i>halakha</i>. If they came independently, <b>this</b> one <b>after that</b> one, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>they are ritually pure. They disagree only with regard to</b> a case where one <b>comes to ask about himself and about the other. One Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>likens it to</b> a case where they come to ask <b>at the same time, and Rabbi Yehuda likens it to</b> a case where <b>this</b> one comes <b>after that</b> one. The Gemara concludes the analogy: <b>And here too,</b> where there was room in the hideout for only one woman, although they came and asked individually, <b>since they</b> seek to render <b>all</b> the women married to priests <b>permitted</b> to their husbands based on that hideout, <b>it is tantamount to</b> asking about them all <b>at the same time,</b> and they should be deemed forbidden to their husbands.
The Gemara asks: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of the two paths, <b>there is certainly ritual impurity</b> in one of the paths, and therefore there is certainly one man who is impure. <b>Here, who says</b> any of the women <b>was violated?</b> Since there is uncertainty whether any woman was violated at all, one is more likely to rule that each woman was the one who hid than it is to rule that each of the men walked on the ritually pure path.
<b>Rav Ashi raises a dilemma:</b> If there was a hideaway in the city and a woman married to a priest says: <b>Neither did I hide nor was I violated, what is</b> the ruling? <b>Do we say</b> the principle:

Daf 27b

<b>Why would I lie</b> in so ineffectual a manner, and deem her credible? Had she wanted to lie, she could have claimed that she hid, which is a more effective claim. <b>Or perhaps we do not say</b> that principle.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this <b>different from that incident where a certain man who rented a donkey to his colleague said to</b> the renter: <b>Do not go on the path of the Pekod River, where there is water,</b> and the donkey is likely to drown. <b>Go on the path of Neresh, where there is no water. And he went on the path</b> along <b>the Pekod River and the donkey died.</b>
The renter <b>came before Rava</b> and <b>said to him: Yes, I went on the path</b> along <b>the Pekod River; however, there was no water</b> there. The donkey’s death was caused by other factors. <b>Rava said:</b> His claim is accepted based on the principle: <b>Why would I lie. If he wanted</b> to lie, he could have <b>said to him, I went on the path of Neresh. And Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>We do not say</b> the principle: <b>Why would I lie, in a situation</b> where there are <b>witnesses.</b> This principle, which is a form of <i>miggo</i>, is effective only when his claim does not contradict established facts. In this case, since it is known to all that there is water on the path along the Pekod River, his claim is not accepted. Similarly, as it is an established fact that the women taken captive were certainly raped, her claim is not accepted even though it is based on a <i>miggo</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of the donkey, <b>there are certainly witnesses</b> capable of confirming <b>that there is water</b> along that path. <b>Here,</b> in the case of the women, is it clearly established that she was <b>definitely defiled? It is</b> merely <b>a concern, and in a situation</b> where there is merely <b>a concern</b> and not an established fact <b>we say</b> the principle: Why would I lie, and her claim is accepted.
§ We learned in the mishna: <b>If</b> they <b>have witnesses, even</b> if the witness is <b>a slave and even</b> if the witness is <b>a maidservant, they are deemed credible.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is <b>even her</b> personal <b>maidservant deemed credible?</b> The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 73a): With regard to one who divorced his wife conditionally, and the condition was not yet fulfilled, the woman <b>may enter into seclusion with him only on the basis of</b> the presence of <b>witnesses,</b> due to the concern that they will engage in intercourse. If between the drafting of a bill of divorce and its taking effect the husband and wife enter into seclusion together, the bill of divorce must be discarded and a new document drafted in its place.
And she may enter into seclusion <b>even on the basis of</b> the presence of <b>a slave and on the basis of</b> the presence of <b>a maidservant, except for her</b> personal <b>maidservant, due to</b> the fact <b>that she is accustomed to her maidservant,</b> and her presence will not serve as an impediment that would prevent her from engaging in intercourse. Therefore, with regard to the woman taken captive as well, the testimony of the maidservant is not accepted to establish that she was not defiled. <b>Rav Pappi</b> resolved the contradiction and <b>said: With regard to a captive woman,</b> the Sages <b>ruled leniently.</b> Because the prohibition against intercourse with a captive woman is based on the concern that she was violated, the Sages relied on the testimony of her personal maidservant.
<b>Rav Pappa</b> resolved the contradiction and <b>said: This</b> <i>halakha</i> in the case of conditional divorce <b>is</b> stated <b>with regard to her maidservant,</b> who is not deemed credible even in the case of a captive woman. <b>That</b> <i>halakha</i> in the case of the captive woman, where they said even the testimony of the maidservant is accepted, <b>is</b> stated <b>with regard to his maidservant</b> to whom the woman is not so accustomed, and therefore her presence serves as an impediment.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is her maidservant not deemed credible? But isn’t it taught</b> in the mishna: <b>A person is not deemed credible</b> to establish his status <b>by his own testimony?</b> From that statement it may be inferred that the woman is not deemed credible to testify about herself, <b>but her maidservant is deemed credible.</b> The Gemara answers: The legal status of <b>her maidservant is like her own</b> status. Neither is deemed credible.
<b>Rav Ashi</b> resolved the contradiction and <b>said: Both</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>are</b> stated <b>with regard to her maidservant,</b> but there is a distinction between the cases. <b>A maidservant sees</b> what transpires <b>and is silent,</b> but does not testify falsely. Therefore, <b>there,</b> in the case of conditional divorce, <b>where</b> the maidservant’s <b>silence</b> with regard to whether her mistress engaged in intercourse <b>renders</b> the woman <b>permitted,</b> as it is sufficient for the maidservant to say merely: I was there, <b>she is not deemed credible</b> due to the concern lest she witnessed them engaging in intercourse and remained silent. However, <b>here,</b> in the case of the captive woman, <b>where</b> the maidservant’s <b>silence would render</b> her mistress <b>forbidden,</b> as a captive woman is presumed to have been violated and the only way to render her permitted is by saying: She was not defiled, <b>she is deemed credible.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Here too</b> there should be concern that <b>she will come and lie</b> for the benefit of her mistress. The Gemara answers: She would <b>not perform two</b> acts of dishonesty. Although there is suspicion that she will refrain from telling the truth, there is no suspicion that she will lie as well. Therefore, if she relates that her mistress was not defiled, she is deemed credible.
Proof that one is not suspected of both concealing the truth and lying is cited, <b>as</b> in <b>that</b> case <b>of Mari bar Isak, and some say</b> it was <b>Ḥana bar Isak,</b> where someone claiming to be his <b>brother came to him from Bei Ḥoza’a,</b> a district located far from the Jewish population centers in Babylonia. This brother <b>said to him: Apportion me</b> a share <b>in my father’s property.</b> Mari <b>said to him: I do not know you.</b> The brother <b>came before Rav Ḥisda</b> seeking a legal remedy. Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him:</b> Your brother <b>is speaking well</b> and his response is well founded, <b>as it is written: “And Joseph recognized his brothers but they recognized him not”</b> (Genesis 42:8). This <b>teaches that</b> Joseph <b>left</b> the land of Canaan <b>without the trace of a beard and came</b> to meet his brothers <b>with the trace of a beard.</b>
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: Go bring witnesses that you are his brother. He said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>I have witnesses, but they are afraid of</b> Mari, <b>who is a violent man,</b> and will not testify. Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Mari: <b>Go bring witnesses that he is not your brother.</b> Mari <b>said to him: Is that the <i>halakha</i>?</b> Isn’t the guiding principle in cases of this sort: <b>The burden of proof</b> rests <b>upon the claimant?</b> Let the man claiming part of my inheritance bring proof supporting his claim. Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: This is how I render judgment for you and for all your fellow violent</b> men; I place the burden of proof upon them. The Gemara asks: <b>Now too,</b> witnesses <b>will come and lie</b> in fear of Mari, and what is accomplished by requiring Mari to bring the witnesses? Apparently, one is <b>not</b> suspected of <b>performing two</b> acts of dishonesty, to both conceal the truth and to lie.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the opinions of the <i>amora’im</i> with regard to the testimony of her maidservant are <b>subject to</b> this dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> It is taught in one <i>baraita</i>: <b>This testimony</b> that a captive woman was not defiled with regard to which <b>a man and a woman, a male child or a female child,</b> the woman’s <b>father, and her mother, and her brother, and her sister</b> are deemed credible, <b>but not her son and her daughter,</b> and <b>not her slave or maidservant. And it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>All are deemed credible to testify</b> with regard a captive woman, <b>except for her and her husband.</b>
The Gemara notes: The opinion <b>of Rav Pappi and</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ashi</b> are certainly <b>subject to</b> the dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as they hold that her maidservant is deemed credible contrary to the first <i>baraita</i> cited. However, with regard to the opinion <b>of Rav Pappa,</b> who distinguishes between her maidservant, who is not deemed credible, and his maidservant, who is, <b>do we say</b> that <b>it is</b> subject to the dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>?</b> Perhaps the <i>tanna</i> in each <i>baraita</i> holds that her maidservant is not deemed credible, and the <i>baraita</i> that deems everyone credible except for the woman and her husband could be explained in another manner, e.g., the legal status of her maidservant is like her own status.
The Gemara says: There is no proof that Rav Pappa’s opinion is contingent upon the tannaitic dispute, as <b>Rav Pappa</b> could have <b>said to you: When that</b> <i>baraita</i> that deems everyone credible except for the woman and her husband <b>is taught,</b> it is taught <b>in</b> a case where <b>she is making an unconsidered, incidental remark</b> in the context of a conversation about an unrelated matter. However, direct testimony of her maidservant is not accepted.
<b>As</b> in <b>that</b> case <b>when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia; <b>he said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥanan of Carthage relates: An incident came before Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> for judgment; <b>and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi relates: An incident came before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>with regard to a person who was making an unconsidered, incidental remark, and said: My mother and I were taken captive among the gentiles.</b> When <b>I went out to draw water, my thoughts were about my mother; to gather wood, my thoughts were about my mother.</b> We were never separated. <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deemed her</b> fit to <b>marry into the priesthood on the basis</b> of those remarks, even though with regard to testimony about his mother, a son is disqualified as a witness. The same is true of the woman’s maidservant.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Zekharya ben HaKatzav said:</b> I swear by <b>this abode</b> of the Divine Presence that my wife’s <b>hand did not move from my hand from the time that the gentiles entered Jerusalem until they left,</b> and I know for a fact that she was not defiled. The Sages <b>said to him: A person cannot testify about himself.</b> The legal status of one’s wife is like his own status in this regard. Therefore, your testimony is not accepted, and your wife is forbidden to you.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>And even so,</b> despite the fact that the Sages ruled his wife forbidden to him because he was a priest, he did not divorce her. <b>He designated a house in his courtyard for her,</b> but did not enter into seclusion with her, <b>and when she</b> would <b>go out</b> of the courtyard <b>she</b> would <b>go out before her sons</b> so that she would not be alone in the courtyard with her husband, <b>and when she</b> would <b>enter</b> the house, <b>she</b> would <b>enter after her sons,</b> for the same reason.
<b>Abaye raises a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> regarding whether we have <b>to do likewise with a divorcée?</b> Can a priest who divorces his wife designate a house for her in the courtyard and rely on the children to ensure that the couple will not enter into seclusion? <b>Is it</b> specifically <b>there,</b> in the case of Rabbi Zekharya ben HaKatzav <b>because with regard to a captive woman</b> the Sages <b>ruled leniently,</b> since the prohibition is based on suspicion and not certainty; <b>however here,</b> in the case of a divorcée, where there is a certain Torah prohibition, <b>no,</b> he may not designate a residence for her in the courtyard? <b>Or perhaps,</b> the case of a divorcée <b>is no different.</b>
The Gemara cites proof to resolve the dilemma: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who divorces his wife, she may not marry</b> and live <b>in his</b> immediate <b>vicinity,</b> i.e., his courtyard, due to the concern that because of the intimacy they once shared, her living there will lead to transgression.

Daf 28a

<b>And if he was a priest she may not live with him</b> even <b>in</b> one <b>alleyway</b> that opens into several courtyards, even if she did not remarry, as she is forbidden to him forever. What is the ruling <b>if it was a small village?</b> May she live with her ex-husband in the same village? The Gemara relates that <b>this</b> case of his divorcée and a small village <b>was an incident</b> that transpired <b>and</b> the Sages <b>said: A small village is judged as</b> his immediate <b>proximity.</b>
The Gemara asks: In cases where they may not reside in the same courtyard or alleyway, <b>who is ousted in favor of whom?</b> Which of them must leave? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>She is ousted in favor of him,</b> and leaves, <b>and he is not ousted in favor of her. But if it was her courtyard, he is ousted in favor of her.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised</b> before the Sages: If <b>it was a courtyard</b> belonging <b>to both of them, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>; who is ousted in favor of whom? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>She is ousted in favor of him.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>With what</b> circumstances <b>are we dealing? If we say</b> that the subject of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>with regard to his courtyard,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that she is ousted. <b>But rather,</b> is it <b>with regard to her courtyard? Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If it was her courtyard, he is ousted in favor of her? Rather, is it not</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is dealing with <b>a case like this,</b> where it was a courtyard belonging to both of them? The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Perhaps</b> the <i>baraita</i> is teaching that even in a case <b>where he rented</b> the courtyard she is ousted in his favor. Therefore, the dilemma with regard to a courtyard belonging to both of them is unresolved.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> halakhic conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about</b> this matter? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from the verse: <b>“The Lord will dislocate you the dislocation of a man”</b> (Isaiah 22:17), <b>and Rav said:</b> This indicates that <b>the dislocation of a man is more difficult</b> for him <b>than</b> the dislocation of <b>a woman</b> is for her. Therefore, the woman is ousted.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to a priest who <b>borrowed from</b> his wife <b>from</b> usufruct <b>property</b> that she inherited from <b>her father</b> and then he divorced her, <b>she is repaid only by means of another</b> person and not directly from her husband, to prevent them from engaging in business dealings. <b>Rav Sheshet said: And if</b> after engaging in business dealings they <b>came before us for judgment, we do not attend to them</b> because by engaging in those dealings they were in violation of a transgression. <b>Rav Pappa said: We excommunicate them</b> for violating that transgression. <b>Rav Huna, the son of Rav Yehoshua, said: We also flog them</b> with lashes. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>taught in <i>Evel Rabbati</i>,</b> one of the minor tractates that deals primarily with the <i>halakhot</i> of mourning: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is in a case <b>where she was divorced from marriage. However, when she was divorced from betrothal, she is repaid</b> even directly <b>by means of</b> receiving the money <b>herself, because,</b> in that case, <b>he is not</b> yet <b>accustomed to her.</b> Since they never shared intimacy, there is no concern that it will lead to transgression.
The Gemara relates: There was an incident concerning <b>this</b> divorced, <b>betrothed man and his betrothed who came before Rava</b> for judgment, and <b>Rav Adda bar Mattana was sitting before him</b> at the time. <b>Rava placed an intermediary</b> to separate <b>between them. Rav Adda bar Mattana said to</b> Rava: <b>But didn’t Rav Naḥman say:</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>taught in <i>Evel Rabbati</i></b> that if she was divorced from betrothal she is paid directly? Rava <b>said to him:</b> This applies only in a case where they are not accustomed to each other. However, with regard to these people, <b>we see that they are accustomed to each other,</b> and therefore they must be separated.
<b>Some say</b> that <b>Rava did not place an intermediary</b> to separate <b>between them. Rav Adda bar Mattana said to</b> Rava: <b>Let the Master place an intermediary</b> to separate <b>between them.</b> Rava <b>said to</b> Rav Adda bar Mattana: <b>But didn’t Rav Naḥman say:</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>taught in <i>Evel Rabbati</i></b> that if she was divorced from betrothal she is paid directly? Rav Adda bar Mattana <b>said to</b> Rava: <b>This applies only</b> in a case <b>where they are not accustomed to each other. However,</b> with regard to <b>these</b> people, <b>we see that they are accustomed to each other,</b> and therefore they must be separated.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these are deemed credible to testify in their majority</b> with regard to <b>what they saw in their minority. A person is deemed credible to say: This is my father’s handwriting, and</b> to say: <b>This is my teacher’s handwriting; and</b> to say: <b>This is my brother’s handwriting,</b> even though he never saw their handwriting after reaching majority.
§ Similarly, one is deemed credible to say: <b>I was reminded of</b> the wedding of <b>so-and-so, who went out with a <i>hinnuma</i>, or</b> with <b>her hair uncovered</b> in a manner typical of virgins, and therefore, her marriage contract is two hundred dinars; <b>and</b> to say <b>that so-and-so would leave school to immerse</b> in order <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>, and that he would share</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>with us at the threshing floor</b> and therefore he is a priest. Similarly, one is deemed credible to say: <b>This place is a <i>beit haperas</i>,</b> a field with a grave that was plowed, scattering the bones, and rendering the field a place of uncertain ritual impurity; <b>and</b> to say: <b>Until here we would come on Shabbat</b> and thereby determine the Shabbat boundary.
<b>However, a person is neither deemed credible to say: So-and-so had a path in this place;</b> nor to say: <b>So-and-so had</b> a tract of land where they would perform the ritual of <b>standing</b> and sitting <b>and</b> deliver <b>a eulogy in that place,</b> thereby attesting that the land belongs to that person. The reason he is not deemed credible in those cases is that full-fledged testimony is required to remove property from the possession of its presumptive owner.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: And</b> the mishna said that one is deemed credible to testify about handwriting he saw as a minor only <b>when there is</b> a witness who saw the handwriting as an <b>adult</b> testifying <b>with him.</b>
<b>And</b> all of these cases are <b>necessary,</b> as one could not have been derived from the other. <b>As, if</b> the <i>tanna</i> had <b>taught us</b> the case of <b>his father’s</b> handwriting, one might have thought that he is deemed credible <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he is</b> often <b>found with his</b> father and is familiar with his handwriting; <b>but</b> with regard to <b>his teacher’s</b> handwriting, <b>no,</b> he is not deemed credible. <b>And if</b> the <i>tanna</i> had <b>taught us</b> the case of <b>his teacher’s</b> handwriting, one might have thought that he is deemed credible <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he has</b> a sense of <b>awe of his teacher</b> and therefore pays attention to his handwriting; <b>but</b> with regard to <b>his father’s</b> handwriting, <b>no,</b> he is not deemed credible.
<b>And if</b> the <i>tanna</i> had <b>taught us these two</b> cases, one might have thought that he is deemed credible with regard to <b>his father’s</b> handwriting due to the fact <b>that he is</b> often <b>found with him, and his teacher’s</b> handwriting due to the fact <b>that he has</b> a sense of <b>awe of him. But</b> with regard to <b>his brother’s</b> handwriting, <b>which has neither this</b> factor <b>nor that</b> factor, <b>say no,</b> he is not deemed credible. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us: Since ratification of documents is</b> required <b>by rabbinic</b> law, as by Torah law, the signatories are sufficient proof of a document’s validity; <b>the Sages deemed him credible</b> to testify in cases that he witnessed as a minor in matters that are <b>by rabbinic</b> law, including the case of his brother.
<b>And</b> the mishna states that one is deemed credible to say: <b>I was reminded of</b> the wedding of <b>so-and-so, who went out with a <i>hinnuma</i>, or</b> with <b>her hair uncovered. What is the reason</b> that he is deemed credible? <b>Since most women are married as virgins,</b> her presumptive status is that of a virgin even without his testimony. His testimony with regard to what he saw as a minor <b>is merely revealing of a matter</b> already presumed true, not actual testimony.
<b>And</b> the mishna states that one is deemed credible to say <b>that so-and-so would leave school to immerse</b> in order <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> and therefore he is a priest. The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps he is the slave of a priest,</b> who is also eligible to partake of <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara notes: This mishna provides <b>support for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: It is prohibited for a person to teach his slave Torah.</b> Since the testimony is that he was in school, apparently he is not a slave. Therefore, the fact that he partook of <i>teruma</i> indicates that he is a priest.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> may one <b>not</b> teach his slave Torah? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A slave <b>whose master borrowed from him, or whose master made him</b>

Daf 28b

<b>steward</b> over his property, <b>or</b> who <b>donned phylacteries in his master’s presence, or</b> who <b>read three verses</b> from the Torah scroll <b>in the synagogue, did not</b> necessarily <b>emerge to freedom.</b> Apparently, there are slaves who learn Torah to the extent that they are capable of reading the Torah in the synagogue, and conceivably that Torah is learned in school. The Gemara answers that there is no proof from the <i>baraita</i>, as <b>there</b> it is a case <b>where the slave read at his own initiative,</b> and conceivably he taught himself to read the Torah as well. <b>When we say</b> in the mishna that it is proof that he is a priest, it is in a case <b>where he treats him</b> with <b>treatment</b> typical of <b>children,</b> not slaves, and sends him to school. 
When the mishna states that he is deemed credible to testify that as a minor he saw that others went <b>to immerse</b> in order <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> the Sages permit them only to partake <b>of <i>teruma</i> by rabbinic</b> law. <b>And</b> the mishna states that he is deemed credible to say that they saw <b>that</b> so-and-so <b>would share</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>with us at the threshing floor,</b> and therefore he is a priest. The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps he is the slave of a priest?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>We learned</b> the mishna <b>according to the one who says: One distributes <i>teruma</i> to a slave only if his master is with him.</b> Therefore, it is clear that the one sharing <i>teruma</i> with them was a priest, not a slave, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of the son of a priest’s wife and the son of a priest’s maidservant who were intermingled at birth, both mothers go to the threshing floor together based on the principle: <b>One distributes <i>teruma</i> to a slave only if his master is with him;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> It is <b>possible that each will say: If I am a priest, give me</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>for my own sake, and if I am the slave of a priest, give me</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>for the sake of my master.</b>
The dispute in the <i>baraita</i> is based on the fact that <b>in the place of Rabbi Yehuda, they would elevate</b> one who eats <b><i>teruma</i> to</b> the presumptive status of priesthood <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>lineage.</b> Therefore, he permitted distributing <i>teruma</i> to the slave of a priest only if his master is present, due to the concern that if he were given <i>teruma</i> directly, he would be elevated to priesthood. <b>In the place of Rabbi Yosei, they would not elevate from <i>teruma</i> to lineage.</b> Therefore, he permitted distributing <i>teruma</i> directly to the slave of a priest, as there is no concern that the slave would be mistaken for a priest.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, said: In all my days, I never</b> had occasion <b>to testify</b> in court. <b>One time I testified, and</b> the court <b>elevated a slave to priesthood on the basis of my</b> testimony. The Gemara asks: <b>Does it enter your mind that they</b> actually <b>elevated</b> the slave to priesthood? <b>Now, just as</b> with regard to <b>the animals of the righteous the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not engender a pitfall on their account,</b> as the Gemara relates with regard to the donkey of Rabbi Pinḥas ben Yair that it would not eat untithed produce (<i>Ḥullin</i> 7a), <b>all the more so</b> will He not engender a pitfall on account of <b>the righteous themselves.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara emends the statement of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei: <b>They sought to elevate a slave to priesthood on the basis of my</b> testimony, but ultimately they did not. Rabbi Elazar <b>saw</b> <i>teruma</i> distributed directly to the slave of a priest <b>in the place of Rabbi Yosei,</b> where one does not elevate from <i>teruma</i> to priesthood, <b>and he went and testified</b> about what he saw <b>in the place of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> where one elevates from <i>teruma</i> to priesthood.
<b>And</b> the mishna states that one is deemed credible to testify in his adulthood that as a minor he saw <b>that this place is a <i>beit haperas</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that he is deemed credible to testify what he witnessed as a minor? The Gemara answers: The ritual impurity of a <b><i>beit haperas</i></b> is <b>by rabbinic</b> law, <b>as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: A person</b> who passes through <b>a <i>beit haperas</i> may blow</b> on the dust before taking each step, so that if there is a bone beneath the dust he will expose it, avoid it, <b>and proceed.</b> One may not rely on that method of examination with regard to impurity by Torah law. <b>And Rav Yehuda bar Ami, in the name of Rav Yehuda, said: A <i>beit haperas</i> that has been trodden</b> underfoot, creating a path, <b>is pure. What is the reason?</b> It is that <b>it is impossible for a bone</b> the size <b>of</b> a grain of <b>barley,</b> whose possible presence led to the decree of impurity, <b>not to have been trodden underfoot</b> and rendered smaller. This presumption is possible only in cases of impurity by rabbinic law.
<b>And</b> the mishna states that one is deemed credible to testify, in his adulthood, that he saw as a minor: <b>Until here we would come on Shabbat.</b> The Gemara explains: This <i>tanna</i> <b>maintains</b> that the Shabbat <b>boundaries,</b> beyond which one may not go outside the city on Shabbat, are mandated <b>by rabbinic</b> law, and the Sages deemed him credible in matters of rabbinic law.
<b>And</b> the mishna states that <b>one is neither deemed credible to say: So-and-so had a path in this place;</b> nor to say: <b>So-and-so had</b> a tract of land where they would perform the ritual of <b>standing</b> and sitting <b>and</b> deliver <b>a eulogy in that place.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that he is not deemed credible? It is due to the fact that <b>we do not remove money</b> from the possession of its presumptive owner on the basis of testimony about a matter that he witnessed as a minor.
<b>The Sages taught: A child is deemed credible to say</b> when he reaches majority that <b>this is what my father told me</b> when I was a minor: <b>This family is pure, that family is impure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> that his father said <b>pure and impure?</b> What do those concepts mean with regard to a family? <b>Rather,</b> his father said to him: <b>This family is</b> of <b>unflawed</b> lineage, <b>and this family is</b> of <b>flawed</b> lineage.
<b>And</b> he is deemed credible to say <b>that we ate at the <i>ketzatza</i></b> that took place to publicize that the marriage <b>of the daughter of so-and-so to so-and-so</b> was unsuitable; <b>and</b> to say <b>that we would bring <i>ḥalla</i> and</b> priestly <b>gifts to so-and-so,</b> who is a <b>priest.</b> In that case, he is deemed credible only to testify that he brought the <i>ḥalla</i> <b>by himself, but not by means of another,</b> as one is certain of matters that he performed himself, even as a minor. However, he is not deemed credible to testify about actions performed by others when he was a minor. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all these</b> testimonies, <b>if he was a gentile and he converted,</b> or <b>a slave and he was liberated, they are not deemed credible</b> to testify after their conversion and liberation about matters that transpired beforehand when they were disqualified as witnesses. <b>And one is neither deemed credible to say</b> that he remembers that when he was a minor, <b>so-and-so had a path in this place;</b> nor that <b>so-and-so had</b> a tract of land where they would perform the ritual of <b>standing</b> and sitting <b>and</b> deliver <b>a eulogy in that place. Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says:</b> They are <b>deemed credible.</b>
The Gemara asks: With regard <b>to which</b> clause in the <i>baraita</i> is <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka</b> disputing? <b>If we say</b> he is disputing the <b>last clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, which concerns testimony about a path or a place for mourning, <b>it is</b> a case of <b>removing money</b> from the possession of its presumptive owner. How could his testimony be deemed credible? <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka is certainly disagreeing with the <b>former clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all these</b> testimonies, <b>if he was a gentile and he converted,</b> or <b>a slave and he was liberated, they are not deemed credible.</b> It is with regard to that <i>halakha</i> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says:</b> They are <b>deemed credible.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara explains that <b>the first <i>tanna</i> maintains: Since he was a gentile, he was not exacting</b> in scrutinizing the matter, as it was irrelevant to him. Therefore, even after he converted he is not deemed credible. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka maintains: Since it was his intention to convert,</b> he took interest in Judaism and <b>he was exacting</b> in scrutinizing the matter, and he is deemed credible.
The Gemara asks about a term employed in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b><i>ketzatza</i>?</b> It is <b>as the Sages taught: How is <i>ketzatza</i></b> performed? If a situation where <b>one of the brothers who married a woman who is unsuited for him,</b> due to flawed lineage, occurs, <b>the family members come and bring</b> with them <b>a barrel full of fruits, and break it in the middle of</b> a public <b>square</b> to publicize the matter, <b>and they say: Our brothers, the house of Israel, listen. Our brother so-and-so married a woman who is unsuited for him, and we fear lest his descendants become intermingled with our descendants.</b> In order to further underscore the matter, they continue: <b>Come and take for yourselves a sample</b> as an indicator <b>for</b> future <b>generations, so that his descendants will not intermingle with our descendants.</b> The gathering of the large crowd to take the fruit generates publicity. <b>And this is the <i>ketzatza</i> that a child</b> who witnessed it <b>is deemed credible to testify about it</b> when he is an adult.

Daf 29a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>These</b> are the cases of <b>young women for whom there is a fine</b> paid <b>to their</b> fathers by one who rapes them: <b>One who engages in intercourse with a <i>mamzeret</i>, or with a Gibeonite woman [<i>netina</i>],</b> who are given [<i>netunim</i>] to the service of the people and the altar (see Joshua 9:27), <b>or with a Samaritan woman [<i>kutit</i>].</b> In addition, the same applies to <b>one who engages in intercourse with a female convert, or with a captive woman, or with a maidservant,</b> provided <b>that</b> the captives <b>were ransomed,</b> or <b>that</b> the converts <b>converted, or that</b> the maidservants <b>were liberated</b> when they were <b>less than three years and one day old,</b> as only in that case do they maintain the presumptive status of a virgin.
Similarly, <b>one who engages in intercourse with his sister,</b> i.e., he rapes her, <b>or with his father’s sister, or with his mother’s sister, or with his wife’s sister, or with his brother’s wife, or with his father’s brother’s wife</b> after they divorced, <b>or with a menstruating woman, there is a fine</b> paid. <b>Although there is <i>karet</i> for</b> engaging in relations with any of the women enumerated in this list, one is liable to pay the fine because <b>there is no court</b>-imposed <b>capital punishment.</b> In cases where there is a court-imposed death penalty, the rapist would be exempt from paying the fine.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara wonders: Is it <b>these young women</b> with <b>flawed</b> lineage listed in the mishna, <b>for whom there is a fine</b> paid if they are raped, while for young women with <b>unflawed</b> lineage, <b>no,</b> there is no fine? The Gemara explains that <b>this</b> is what the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying: These are</b> the <b>young women</b> with <b>flawed</b> lineage <b>for whom there is a fine</b> paid if they are raped. This is not a comprehensive list; rather, the <i>tanna</i> enumerates those young women for whom a fine is paid despite their flawed lineage: <b>One who has relations with a <i>mamzeret</i>, or with a Gibeonite woman, or with a Samaritan woman.</b>
The mishna teaches the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a young woman, from which the Gemara infers: With regard to <b>a young woman, yes,</b> one is liable to pay the fine if he rapes her, but with regard to <b>a minor, no,</b> one is not liable to pay the fine. <b>Who is</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> who maintains that one is liable for raping a young woman but not a minor?
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>is Rabbi Meir, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>With regard to a minor from</b> the age of <b>one day old until she grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs, there is</b> the possibility of <b>sale for her,</b> as her father may sell her as a Hebrew maidservant, <b>but there is no fine</b> paid <b>for her</b> if she is raped. <b>And once she grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs,</b> from that point <b>until she matures</b> into a grown woman <b>there is a fine for her,</b> as during that period she is a young woman, with regard to whom the Torah law of a rapist and a seducer applies, <b>but there is no</b> possibility of <b>sale for her.</b> Once she grows two hairs she is no longer under her father’s control and can no longer be sold. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir, as Rabbi Meir would state</b> a principle: <b>Any place where there is a sale, there is no fine; and any place where there is a fine, there is no sale.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: With regard to a minor from</b> the age of <b>three years and one day old until she matures</b> into a grown woman, <b>there is a fine for her.</b> The Gemara asks: Is that to say that a <b>fine, yes,</b> there is, but a <b>sale, no,</b> there is not? Do the Rabbis maintain that the father has no right to sell his minor daughter? The Gemara emends the text: <b>Say:</b>

Daf 29b

There is a <b>fine even in a place</b> where there is <b>sale.</b> That is, not only can a minor girl from the age of three be sold until she matures, but she also receives payment of the fine.
§ The Gemara questions the basic <i>halakha</i> that one who rapes young women of flawed lineage is liable to pay the fine: <b>And are these</b> young women <b>entitled</b> to the <b>fine? But why? I read here</b> with regard to a rapist: <b>“And to him she shall be as a wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29), from which the Sages derived that only <b>a wife who is suitable for him</b> is eligible to receive payment of a fine from a rapist. <b>Reish Lakish said</b> that one verse states: “If a man finds a young woman” (Deuteronomy 22:28), and another states: “And he shall give to the father of the young woman” (Deuteronomy 22:29). This is tantamount to three mentions: <b>Young woman, young woman, the young woman,</b> as the superfluous definite article is interpreted as a third mention of the term. <b>One</b> mention is required <b>to</b> teach the matter <b>itself,</b> that one who rapes a young woman is liable to pay a fine; <b>and one</b> is <b>to include</b> payment of a fine to those young women for whose rape one is <b>liable for</b> violating <b>prohibitions; and one</b> is <b>to include</b> payment of a fine to those young women for whose rape one is <b>liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> This is derived from the <i>halakha</i> of the seducer, as the verses state: “And if a man seduce a virgin…he shall weigh money like the dowry of the virgins” (Exodus 22:15–16). This is tantamount to three mentions: <b>Virgin, virgins, the virgins. One</b> mention is required <b>to</b> teach the matter <b>itself; and one</b> is <b>to include</b> those young women for whose rape one is <b>liable for</b> violating <b>prohibitions; and one</b> is <b>to include</b> those young women for whom one who rapes them is <b>liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rav Pappa, what is the reason</b> that <b>he did not cite</b> the source <b>as Reish Lakish</b> did? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> derivation from the three instances of the term young woman is <b>required by him to</b> teach <b>in accordance with that</b> which <b>Abaye</b> said, <b>as Abaye said:</b> If one <b>engaged in</b> forced <b>intercourse with</b> a young woman <b>and she died</b> before he stood trial, he is <b>exempt</b> from paying the fine, <b>as it is stated: “And he shall give to the father of the young woman”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29). From the fact that the verse does not simply say: To her father, it is inferred: <b>To the father of the young woman and not to the father of a dead</b> woman. He is liable only if the young woman is still alive.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Reish Lakish, what is the reason</b> that <b>he did not cite</b> the source <b>as Rav Pappa</b> did? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> derivation from the three instances of the term virgin is <b>required by him to</b> derive <b>a verbal analogy, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that it is written with regard to a seducer: <b>“He shall weigh [<i>yishkol</i>] money like the dowry of the virgins”</b> (Exodus 22:16), from which it is derived <b>that this</b> fine of a seducer <b>should be</b> a sum of fifty <i>sela</i> <b>like the dowry of the virgins</b> specified in the case of a rapist; <b>and the dowry of the virgins must be</b> paid in <i>sela</i> <b>like this</b> fine of the seducer. Therefore, Reish Lakish holds that no additional matters may be derived from the term virgins. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> for <b>Reish Lakish too,</b> isn’t it <b>required by him to</b> teach <b>in accordance with that</b> which <b>Abaye</b> said? <b>And</b> similarly, for <b>Rav Pappa,</b> isn’t it <b>required by him to</b> derive <b>a verbal analogy?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> there are <b>six verses written,</b> and both Reish Lakish and Rav Pappa derive matters from all of them. In the two passages discussing the rapist and the seducer, it is written: <b>Young woman, young woman, the young woman; virgin, virgins, the virgins. Two</b> mentions are required <b>to</b> teach the matters <b>themselves,</b> the basic <i>halakhot</i> of a rapist and a seducer; <b>one</b> mention is needed <b>to</b> teach <b>in accordance with that</b> which <b>Abaye</b> said; <b>and one</b> mention is necessary <b>to</b> derive <b>a verbal analogy</b> with regard to the dowry of virgins. <b>Two</b> mentions of the term <b>remain for him; one</b> is <b>to include</b> those young women for whose rape one is <b>liable for</b> violating <b>prohibitions, and one</b> is <b>to include</b> those young women for whom one who rapes them is <b>liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b> Reish Lakish and Rav Pappa do not disagree; the derivation of each complements that of the other.
§ The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> the mishna comes <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that it is written: <b>“And to him she shall be [<i>tihye</i>] as a wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29). <b>Shimon HaTimni says:</b> This is referring to <b>a woman for whom there is betrothal [<i>havaya</i>].</b> If one betroths a woman with whom relations are punishable by <i>karet</i>, the betrothal does not take effect. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya says:</b> This is referring to <b>a woman who is suitable for</b> him to <b>sustain,</b> whom he need not divorce due to her flawed lineage.
The Gemara begins its analysis of the <i>baraita</i> with the question: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> the statements of Shimon HaTimni and Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya? The Gemara explains that <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> The difference <b>between their</b> opinions is with regard to <b>a <i>mamzeret</i> or a Gibeonite woman,</b> or any other woman who is forbidden but for whom betrothal takes effect. <b>According to the one who said</b> that the criterion is whether <b>there is betrothal,</b> for <b>this</b> woman <b>there is also betrothal.</b> If a Jewish man betroths a <i>mamzeret</i> or a Gibeonite woman, although it is prohibited to do so, the betrothal takes effect. However, <b>according to the one who said</b> that the criterion is whether the woman is <b>suitable for</b> him to <b>sustain, this</b> woman <b>is not suitable for</b> him to <b>sustain,</b> since due to the prohibition he is obligated to divorce her.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabbi Akiva, who said: Betrothal does not take effect for</b> women for whose rape one is <b>liable for</b> violating <b>prohibitions, what is</b> the difference <b>between them?</b> According to his opinion, betrothal of a <i>mamzeret</i> does not take effect either. The Gemara answers: The difference <b>between their</b> statements is the case of <b>a widow</b> raped <b>by a High Priest, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Simai, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Simai says: Rabbi Akiva deems</b> children <b>from all</b> illicit relations <b><i>mamzerim</i>, except for a</b> child born <b>from a widow to a High Priest, as the Torah said:</b> “A widow and a divorcée <b>he shall not take…and he shall not profane [<i>yeḥallel</i>]</b> his seed among his people” (Leviticus 21:14–15), from which it is derived: If he has a child with a widow <b>he creates <i>ḥillulin</i>,</b> i.e., the male offspring of those relations is a <i>ḥalal</i>, disqualified from the priesthood, and the female offspring is a <i>ḥalala</i>, unfit to marry a priest, <b>but he does not create <i>mamzerim</i>.</b> Apparently, in that case, the betrothal does take effect.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabbi Yeshevav, who said: Come, let us scream at Akiva ben Yosef,</b> who is proliferating <i>mamzerim</i>, <b>as he would say:</b> With regard to <b>anyone who does not have</b> the possibility of permitted <b>relations in the Jewish people,</b> including a widow with a High Priest, <b>the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>, what is</b> the difference <b>between their</b> opinions, between the one who said that a fine is paid to women with whom the betrothal takes effect and the one who said that a fine is paid to women suitable for one to sustain? Rabbi Yeshevav maintains that betrothal does not take effect even in the case of a widow to a High Priest. The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to

Daf 30a

intercourse with women for which one is <b>liable for</b> violating a <b>positive</b> mitzva, e.g., <b>an Egyptian</b> convert <b>and an Edomite</b> convert (see Deuteronomy 23:8–9). If he raped a first- or second-generation Egyptian or Edomite convert, even Rabbi Yeshevav agrees that the child is not a <i>mamzer</i>, as the betrothal takes effect. On the other hand, it is prohibited for him to sustain her as a wife.
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> works out <b>well according to Rabbi Yeshevav if he is coming to reject the opinion of Rabbi Simai.</b> If Rabbi Yeshevav merely takes issue with Rabbi Simai, who said that all offspring of forbidden relations are <i>mamzerim</i> according to Rabbi Akiva except for those resulting from relations between a widow and a High Priest, then it may <b>well</b> be explained that Rabbi Yeshevav holds that Rabbi Akiva rules that betrothal does not take effect and that there is <i>mamzerut</i> when one violates the prohibitions of the priesthood. <b>However, if he is stating his own opinion,</b> independent of Rabbi Simai’s statement, his ruling is more comprehensive and leads to the conclusion that in the case of relations with <b>anyone who does not have</b> the possibility of permitted <b>relations among the Jewish people, the child is a <i>mamzer</i>, and</b> this is true <b>even</b> of women for relations with whom one is <b>liable for</b> violating <b>positive</b> mitzvot, e.g., Egyptian or Edomite converts. In that case, <b>what is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the opinions of Shimon HaTimni and Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya?
The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> in the case of <b>a non-virgin</b> raped <b>by a High Priest. And</b> the Gemara asks: Here, too, she is a woman for relations with whom one is liable for violating a positive mitzva, as the High Priest fails to fulfill the mitzva “But a virgin of his own people shall he take to wife” (Leviticus 21:14). If Rabbi Akiva rules that betrothal does not take effect when a positive mitzva is violated, <b>what is different</b> about this case? The Gemara answers: It is different <b>because it is a positive</b> mitzva <b>whose</b> application <b>is not equal for all.</b> There are two lenient aspects to this mitzva: It is a positive mitzva and not a prohibition, and it applies only to the High Priest and not to all Jews. Even Rabbi Yeshevav would agree that according to Rabbi Akiva, a child born from relations between a High Priest and a non-virgin is not a <i>mamzer</i>. However, the High Priest may not sustain the woman as his wife. Therefore, this case is the practical difference between the statements of Shimon HaTimni and Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya.
§ <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Everyone agrees with regard to one who engaged in</b> forced <b>intercourse with a menstruating woman that he pays</b> the <b>fine.</b> He elaborates: <b>According to the one who says</b> that the criterion is whether <b>there is betrothal,</b> for <b>this</b> woman <b>too there is betrothal. According to the one who says</b> that the criterion is whether the woman is <b>suitable for</b> him to <b>sustain, this</b> woman <b>is suitable for</b> him to <b>sustain.</b>
§ The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> the mishna’s ruling that one who has relations with his sister is liable to pay the fine comes <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana would render Yom Kippur like Shabbat with regard to payment</b> for damages. <b>Just as</b> one who intentionally desecrates <b>Shabbat is liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty <b>and</b> is therefore <b>exempt from</b> the obligation of <b>payment</b> for damages caused while desecrating Shabbat, <b>so too,</b> one who intentionally desecrates <b>Yom Kippur is liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty <b>and</b> is therefore <b>exempt from</b> the obligation of <b>payment</b> for damages caused while desecrating Yom Kippur.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana? Abaye said: It states</b> the word <b>harm at the hands of man,</b> in the verse “But if any harm follow, then you shall give a soul for a soul” (Exodus 21:23) and <b>it states</b> the word <b>harm at the hand of Heaven,</b> in the verse in which Jacob states: “My son shall not descend with you…and harm befalls him on the way” (Genesis 42:38). <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>harm that is stated at the hands of man,</b> e.g., one who kills and is liable to be executed, one is <b>exempt from the</b> associated <b>payment, so too,</b> with regard to <b>harm that is stated at the hand of Heaven,</b> one is <b>exempt from the</b> associated <b>payment.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava</b> strongly <b>objects to this: From where</b> is it derived <b>that when Jacob is warning his sons</b> he is warning them <b>about cold and heat [<i>tzinim paḥim</i>], which are at the hand of Heaven? Perhaps</b> he was warning them <b>about a lion and thieves, which are</b> harm <b>at the hands of man,</b> meaning that unlike heat and cold, these dangers are not calibrated by God. The Gemara refutes this: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>Jacob warned</b> them <b>about this</b> harm at the hand of man, but <b>about that</b> harm at the hand of Heaven <b>he did not warn</b> them? <b>Jacob warned</b> them <b>about all</b> potentially harmful <b>matters</b> that might befall Benjamin, not merely one particular form of catastrophe.
The Gemara asks: <b>And are cold</b> and <b>heat at the hand of Heaven?
