Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All</b> matters are <b>at the hand of Heaven except for cold</b> and <b>heat, as it is stated: “Cold</b> and <b>heat are on the path of the crooked, he who guards his soul shall keep far from them”</b> (Proverbs 22:5)? This indicates that cold and heat are forms of harm caused by man, from which one can protect himself. <b>And furthermore, are a lion and thieves</b> forms of harm <b>at the hands of man? But didn’t Rav Yosef say, and similarly,</b> didn’t <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya teach</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From the day that the Temple was destroyed, although the Sanhedrin was abolished</b> the <b>four death</b> penalties <b>were not abolished?</b> The Gemara asks: Were they <b>not abolished?</b> It is clear <b>that they were abolished,</b> as today there is neither Sanhedrin nor capital punishment. <b>Rather,</b> it means that although there are no court-imposed executions,

Daf 30b

the <b>punishment</b> of the <b>four death</b> penalties <b>was not abolished.</b> How so? <b>One who was liable</b> to be executed by <b>stoning either falls from the roof or a beast tramples him.</b> That is similar to stoning, which involves being pushed off an elevated place and then stoned. <b>And one who was liable</b> to be executed by <b>burning either falls into a conflagration or a snake bites him,</b> which creates a burning sensation. <b>And one who was liable</b> to be executed by <b>decapitation</b> is <b>either handed over to the</b> ruling <b>monarchy</b> for execution by sword, <b>or bandits attack</b> and kill <b>him. And one who was liable</b> to be executed by <b>strangulation either drowns in a river, or dies of diphtheria [<i>serunki</i>]. Rather, reverse</b> the order of the previous statement: <b>A lion and thieves</b> are cases of harm <b>at the hand of Heaven,</b> while <b>cold and heat</b> are cases of harm <b>at the hands of man.</b>
<b>Rava said</b> an additional explanation: <b>The rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana is from here.</b> It is written that one who gives his children to Molech is liable to be executed by stoning: <b>“And if the people of the land do at all hide their eyes from that man, when he gives of his seed to Molech,</b> and do not put him to death; <b>then I will set My face against that man and against his family, and will cut him off [<i>vehikhrati</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 20:4–5). Through the juxtaposition in this verse <b>the Torah said: My <i>karet</i></b> is <b>like your death</b> penalty; <b>just as</b> one who is liable to receive <b>your death</b> penalty <b>is exempt from the</b> associated <b>payments, so too,</b> one who is liable to receive <b>My <i>karet</i> is exempt from the</b> associated <b>payments.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> practical difference <b>is there between</b> the opinions of <b>Rava and Abaye</b> with regard to the rationale for the opinion of Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to <b>a non-priest who</b> intentionally <b>ate <i>teruma</i>.</b> According <b>to Abaye</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from paying the priest the value of the <i>teruma</i>, as a non-priest who ate <i>teruma</i> is liable to receive death at the hand of Heaven. Abaye maintains that the legal status of all forms of death at the hand of Heaven is equivalent to that of death at the hands of man, and therefore, one is exempt from payment. <b>And</b> according <b>to Rava,</b> who derives the rationale from the juxtaposition between <i>karet</i> and death at the hands of man, since a non-priest who ate <i>teruma</i> is not liable to receive <i>karet</i>, he is <b>liable</b> to pay the priest for the <i>teruma</i> that he ate.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Abaye,</b> is a non-priest actually <b>exempt</b> from payment for the <i>teruma</i>? <b>But didn’t Rav Ḥisda say</b> that <b>Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana concedes with regard to</b> one who <b>steals another’s</b> forbidden <b>fat and eats it that he is obligated</b> to pay for the fat, even though he is liable to receive <i>karet</i>, <b>as he was already liable for theft before he came</b> to violate <b>the prohibition</b> against eating forbidden <b>fat? Apparently, from the moment he lifts</b> the fat to steal <b>it he acquired it,</b> and he bears responsibility to repay it, but <b>he is liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty <b>only when he eats it. Here, too,</b> with regard to a non-priest who ate <i>teruma</i>, <b>at the moment he lifts</b> the <i>teruma</i> <b>he acquired it</b> and is responsible to repay it, and <b>he is liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty <b>only when he eats it.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> It is a case <b>where another inserted</b> the <i>teruma</i> <b>into his mouth.</b> In that case, acquisition and liability to receive the death penalty are simultaneous.
The Gemara asks: <b>Ultimately, once he chewed</b> the <i>teruma</i> <b>he acquired it</b> and is liable to pay, and <b>he is liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty <b>only when he swallows it.</b> Since the two are not simultaneous, he should be liable to pay. The Gemara answers: It is a case <b>where</b> another <b>inserted it into the pharynx,</b> so the liability for payment and liability for the death penalty were both achieved through swallowing. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> it is <b>possible to retrieve</b> the <i>teruma</i> by removing it without ruining it, <b>let him retrieve</b> it. If one does so, he would not be liable to pay. If he fails to do so, liability or payment precedes liability for the death penalty. <b>If</b> it is <b>not possible to retrieve</b> the <i>teruma</i>, <b>why</b> is he <b>liable?</b> He did nothing; another person inserted the food in his throat. The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary only</b> in a situation <b>where</b> it is <b>possible to retrieve</b> the <i>teruma</i> <b>under duress,</b> with great effort.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It is referring to a case <b>where another inserted liquids of <i>teruma</i> into his mouth.</b> As soon as the liquid enters his mouth, it is ruined. Therefore, the acquisition and his enjoyment are simultaneous. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> It is referring <b>to a non-priest who partook of his own <i>teruma</i>,</b> e.g., if the non-priest inherited <i>teruma</i> from a priest, or acquired ownership from a priest. In that case, he did not steal the <i>teruma</i> and there is no payment for it, but he is liable to receive the death penalty for eating <i>teruma</i>,

Daf 31a

<b>and</b> at the same time <b>he tore another’s silk [<i>shira’in</i>].</b> The question is whether the liability to receive the death penalty exempts him from the liability for payment incurred at precisely the same moment.
§ The Gemara analyzes <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rav Ḥisda said: Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana concedes in</b> the case of one who <b>steals another’s</b> forbidden <b>fat and eats it that he is obligated</b> to pay for the fat, <b>as he is already liable for theft before he comes to</b> violate <b>the prohibition</b> against eating forbidden <b>fat.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Let us say</b> that Rav Ḥisda <b>disagrees</b> with <b>Rabbi Avin, as Rabbi Avin said: One who shoots an arrow from the beginning of four</b> cubits <b>to the end of four</b> cubits in the public domain on Shabbat, thereby performing a prohibited labor for which he is liable to receive a court-imposed death penalty, <b>and</b> the arrow <b>ripped silk as it proceeds, is exempt</b> from the obligation to pay for the silk because he is liable for the more severe punishment for desecrating Shabbat. Although the silk was ripped prior to completion of the prohibited labor, as the arrow had not yet come to rest, he is nevertheless exempt, <b>as lifting is a prerequisite for placement.</b> The prohibited labor of carrying on Shabbat is comprised of lifting of the object and placement. Once he shot the arrow, its movement through the air is a continuation of his act of Shabbat desecration, for which he is liable to be executed. <b>Here, too,</b> say that <b>lifting</b> the fat <b>is a prerequisite for eating,</b> and therefore he should be exempt from payment.
The Gemara refutes this argument: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of the arrow, <b>placement is impossible without lifting,</b> as placement without lifting is not a labor prohibited on Shabbat. Therefore, lifting and placement are a single unit. In contrast, <b>here, eating is possible without lifting as, if one wishes,</b> he could <b>bend down and eat</b> without lifting the food to his mouth. <b>Alternatively,</b> there is another difference between the cases: <b>There,</b> in the case of the arrow, even <b>if he seeks to take back</b> the arrow after shooting it, <b>he cannot take it back;</b> therefore, lifting and placement constitute one action. <b>Here, he could replace</b> the fat after lifting it.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> practical difference <b>is there between this formulation,</b> where the criterion is whether the second stage could be performed independent of the first stage, <b>and that formulation,</b> where the criterion is whether the second stage is inevitable after performing the first stage? The Gemara responds: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> with regard to <b>one who carries a knife in the public domain and tears silk as he proceeds. According to that formulation, where you said: Lifting is a prerequisite for placement, here too, lifting is a prerequisite for placement.</b> As these two stages are inexorably connected, they constitute one action, and the one carrying the knife is exempt from paying the damages. Conversely, <b>according to that formulation where you said: He cannot take back</b> the arrow and that is why they are considered one action, <b>here, he can take back</b> the knife; therefore, lifting and placement are separate actions and he is not exempt from punishment for the damages that he caused.
§ The Gemara analyzes <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rabbi Avin said:</b> With regard to <b>one who shoots an arrow from the beginning of four</b> cubits <b>to the end of four</b> cubits <b>and</b> the arrow <b>rips silk as it proceeds, he is exempt, as lifting is a prerequisite for placement. Rav Beivai bar Abaye raised an objection</b> from that which is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who steals a purse on Shabbat is liable</b> for the theft <b>because he was already liable for theft</b> as soon as he lifted the purse. This took place <b>before he came to</b> violate <b>the prohibition</b> against performing prohibited labor on Shabbat by carrying it into the public domain, a violation punishable by <b>stoning.</b> However, if he did not lift the purse but <b>was dragging</b> it on the ground <b>and exiting</b> the private domain, <b>dragging and exiting, he is exempt, as the prohibition</b> against <b>theft and the prohibition of Shabbat</b> are violated <b>simultaneously</b> when he drags the purse out of the owner’s property and into the public domain.
Rav Beivai concludes: <b>But why</b> is he liable if he carried the purse? <b>Here, too, let us say</b> that <b>lifting is a prerequisite for carrying out,</b> and therefore the theft was performed in the course of performance of the prohibited labor and he is exempt. The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where he lifted</b> the pouch <b>in order to conceal it</b> in the same domain, not to carry it out into the public domain, <b>and he reconsidered</b> his plan with regard to the purse <b>and carried it out.</b> In that case the act of lifting was not performed for the purpose of carrying out. Therefore, he is not exempt from the obligation to pay for the theft.
The Gemara asks: <b>And in a case like that,</b> where he reconsidered, <b>is</b> one <b>liable</b> for carrying out an object on Shabbat? <b>But didn’t Rav Simon say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who moves objects from</b> one <b>corner</b> of his house to another <b>corner</b> on Shabbat, <b>and he reconsidered</b> his plan in <b>their</b> regard after lifting them <b>and carried them out</b> into the public domain, he is <b>exempt, as the</b> act of <b>lifting was not initially</b> performed <b>for that</b> purpose of carrying from one domain to another. Here, too, since the thief did not lift the pouch with the intention of carrying it out, he is not liable to be stoned.
The Gemara emends the previous answer: <b>Do not say</b> that he lifted it <b>in order to conceal it; rather, say</b> that he lifted it <b>in order to carry it out.</b> Nevertheless, the case of shooting the arrow and the case of stealing the purse are different, as <b>with what</b> case <b>are we dealing here?</b> It is a case <b>where he stopped</b> in the courtyard before taking the pouch out to the public domain. Therefore, the initial lifting is exclusively theft and not the start of a prohibited labor, as by stopping, he separated the lifting from the carrying out.
The Gemara asks: This is a case where he <b>stopped. For what</b> purpose did he stop? <b>If</b> he stopped in order <b>to</b> adjust the burden on his <b>shoulder,</b> that <b>is</b> the typical <b>manner</b> of proceeding and would not be considered an interruption in the process of carrying out the object. <b>Rather,</b> it must be <b>in</b> a case of one who <b>stopped to rest,</b> and when he resumes moving he initiates a separate action. The Gemara infers: <b>But</b> if he stopped in order <b>to</b> adjust the burden on his <b>shoulder, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>?

Daf 31b

He would be <b>exempt.</b> If that is the case, <b>rather than teaching:</b> If <b>he was dragging and exiting, dragging and exiting, he is exempt, let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>distinguish and teach</b> the distinction <b>within</b> the case of carrying <b>itself,</b> as follows: <b>In what</b> case <b>are these matters stated?</b> It is <b>in</b> a case where <b>he stopped to rest; however,</b> if <b>he stopped to</b> adjust the burden on his <b>shoulder,</b> he is <b>exempt.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains why one is liable in the case where he carries the purse. In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion was <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> taught? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>ben Azzai,</b> who <b>said:</b> The legal status of <b>one who walks is like</b> that of <b>one who stops,</b> as each step constitutes a pause between the actions of lifting and placement. Therefore, the initial lifting is not part of the prohibited labor of carrying out. The Gemara infers: <b>But</b> if <b>one throws</b> the object into another domain, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? He would be <b>exempt</b> from payment, as the lifting is the start of the prohibited labor of carrying out. If so, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>distinguish and teach</b> the distinction <b>within</b> the case <b>itself,</b> without resorting to the case of dragging and exiting, as follows: <b>In what</b> case <b>are these matters stated?</b> It is in the case of <b>one who walks,</b> so that there is separation between lifting and carrying out, and therefore the theft and the desecration of Shabbat are not simultaneous. <b>However, one who throws</b> is <b>exempt</b> from payment, as liability for carrying out and for theft are incurred simultaneously.
The Gemara answers: According to the opinion of ben Azzai, that would in fact be a more appropriate distinction; however, the case of one who was <b>dragging and exiting was necessary for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to teach because it includes a novel element, as <b>it might enter your mind to say</b> that <b>this is not</b> a typical <b>manner of carrying out,</b> and one is not liable to be executed for performing a prohibited labor in an atypical manner. Therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that this too is a manner of carrying out.
<b>And</b> the Gemara asks: <b>In what</b> case is this so? <b>If</b> it is <b>in</b> the case of <b>large</b> purses, obviously dragging <b>is its</b> typical <b>manner,</b> and there is nothing novel in this. <b>If</b> it is <b>in</b> the case of <b>small</b> purses, dragging <b>is</b> certainly <b>not its</b> typical <b>manner,</b> and one would certainly not be liable. <b>Rather,</b> it must be referring <b>to intermediate</b>-sized purses. Although they are not always carried out in this manner, since they are sometimes dragged, the novelty is that he is liable for desecrating Shabbat and exempt from the payment.
The Gemara continues: <b>And</b> in this case, <b>to where</b> did <b>he carry out</b> the pouch? <b>If he carried it out</b> from the owner’s private domain <b>to the public domain, there is</b> violation of the <b>prohibition of Shabbat;</b> however, <b>there is no</b> violation of the <b>prohibition</b> against <b>theft,</b> as one does not acquire an item by pulling it into the public domain. <b>If he carried it out</b> from the owner’s private domain <b>to</b> his own <b>private domain, there is</b> violation of the <b>prohibition</b> against <b>theft;</b> however, <b>there is no</b> violation of the <b>prohibition of Shabbat.</b> The Gemara answers: This ruling <b>is necessary only</b> in a case <b>where he carried it out to the sides of the public domain.</b> This is referring to the area in the public domain adjacent to the houses located on its sides, demarcated from the thoroughfare by small pegs and not by a full-fledged partition.
The Gemara asks: <b>And in accordance with whose</b> opinion is this taught? <b>If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who said:</b> The legal status of <b>the sides of the public domain is like</b> that of <b>the public domain, there is</b> violation of the <b>prohibition of Shabbat;</b> however, <b>there is no</b> violation of the <b>prohibition</b> against <b>theft. If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who said:</b> The legal status of <b>the sides of the public domain is not like</b> that of <b>the public domain, there is</b> violation of the <b>prohibition</b> against <b>theft;</b> however, <b>there is no</b> violation of the <b>prohibition of Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, and when Rabbi Eliezer said:</b> The legal status of <b>the sides of the public domain is like</b> that of <b>the public domain, that applies only with regard to the liability for</b> performing prohibited labor on <b>Shabbat, as occasionally the multitudes crowd and enter there. However,</b> with regard <b>to the matter of acquiring</b> an object, one <b>acquires</b> it by dragging it there. <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? It is due to the fact <b>that the public is not</b> typically <b>found</b> there, and acquisition can be effected in a place where the multitudes are not typically found.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> Actually, one is exempt when one dragged the object into the public domain in a case <b>where he joined his hand</b> to his other hand at a height <b>below three handbreadths</b> off the ground <b>and received</b> the purse by passing it from one hand into the other as soon as he brought it into the public domain. This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, as Rava said: A person’s hand is considered like four by four</b> handbreadths <b>for him.</b> Therefore, an object placed in one’s hand is considered placed with regard to Shabbat, and since his hand is his personal domain he has also acquired the stolen item. <b>Rav Aḥa taught</b> the entire discussion <b>this way,</b> as above.
<b>Ravina taught</b> otherwise: <b>Actually,</b> it is a case <b>where one carried out</b> the object <b>to the public domain, and in the public domain he also acquires</b> the stolen object by removing it from the owner’s domain, even if he does not transfer it to his own domain. The Gemara comments: <b>And the two of them,</b> Rav Aḥa and Ravina <b>disagree with regard to the inference of this mishna, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Kamma</i> 79a) with regard to one who stole an animal: If he <b>was pulling</b> the animal <b>and exiting, and it died in the domain of the owner,</b> the thief is <b>exempt</b> from payment because he did not yet acquire the animal and therefore did not assume liability for its death through circumstances beyond his control. If <b>he lifted it or took it out of the owner’s domain,</b> thereby acquiring the animal, <b>and it died,</b> the thief is <b>liable</b> to pay its value because it died in his possession.
<b>Ravina inferred</b> his conclusion <b>from the first clause</b> of the mishna, <b>and Rav Aḥa inferred</b> his conclusion <b>from the latter clause. Ravina inferred</b> his conclusion <b>from the first clause:</b> If he <b>was pulling</b> the animal <b>and exiting, and it died in the domain of the owner,</b> the thief is <b>exempt</b> from payment. <b>The reason</b> that the thief is exempt <b>is that</b> the animal <b>died in the owner’s domain; by inference,</b> if <b>he took it out of the owner’s domain and it died,</b> he is <b>liable</b> because the thief acquires the item by its very removal from the owner’s property, even to the public domain. <b>Rav Aḥa inferred</b> his conclusion <b>from the latter clause</b> of the mishna: If <b>he lifted it or took it out of the owner’s domain,</b> he is liable. Based on the juxtaposition of the two, <b>taking</b> the animal <b>out is similar to lifting</b> it: <b>Just as lifting</b> is an act of acquisition through which the animal <b>comes into his domain, so too, taking</b> it <b>out</b> is referring to a case <b>where it comes into his domain.</b>
The Gemara observes: <b>For Rav Aḥa the first clause</b> of the mishna <b>is difficult,</b> while <b>for Ravina the latter clause is difficult.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The first clause is not difficult for Rav Aḥa,</b> as he could explain it as follows: <b>As long as</b> the animal <b>has not come into one’s domain,</b> even if it has left the owner’s property, <b>we</b> continue to <b>call it the owner’s domain.</b> Similarly, <b>the latter clause is not difficult for Ravina,</b> as in his opinion <b>we do not say: Taking</b> the animal <b>out is similar to lifting</b> it. Therefore, the mishna’s ruling is that the thief acquires the animal merely through its removal from the owner’s property.
§ The mishna continues: Similarly, <b>one who has</b> forced <b>relations with his sister,</b> i.e., he rapes her, <b>or with his father’s sister,</b> or with his mother’s sister, or with his wife’s sister, or with his brother’s wife, or with his father’s brother’s wife after they divorced, or with a menstruating woman, there is a fine paid. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raised a contradiction</b> from the following mishna (<i>Makkot</i> 13a): <b>And these</b> people <b>are flogged: One who has relations with his sister, or with his father’s sister, or with his mother’s sister, or with his wife’s sister, or with his brother’s wife, or with his father’s brother’s wife, or with a menstruating woman.</b> Anyone who intentionally has relations with any of these women is punished with lashes.

Daf 32a

<b>And</b> since <b>we maintain</b> in general <b>that one is not</b> both <b>flogged and</b> liable to <b>pay,</b> if one receives lashes for having relations with his sister, why must he pay the fine as well? <b>Ulla said:</b> This is <b>not difficult; here,</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna is <b>with regard to his sister</b> who is a <b>young woman,</b> for whom one pays a fine and is not flogged, whereas <b>there,</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna is <b>with regard to his sister</b> who is a <b>grown woman,</b> for whom one does not pay a fine.
The Gemara asks: In the case of one who has relations with <b>his sister</b> who is a <b>grown woman, too,</b> although he does not pay a fine, <b>isn’t there</b> compensation for <b>humiliation and degradation?</b> He should be exempt from lashes in that case as well. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna is <b>with regard to</b> his sister who is <b>an imbecile,</b> with regard to whom there is no humiliation or degradation beyond her status as an imbecile. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> there payment for <b>pain</b> even in the rape of an imbecile? The Gemara responds: The <i>halakha</i> is <b>with regard to a seduced woman,</b> who is not entitled to payment for pain, as she engaged in relations willingly.
The Gemara comments: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> explanation that the mishna is referring to a seduced woman, the mishna can be understood <b>even if you say</b> it is referring <b>to his sister</b> who is <b>a young woman.</b> The reason that the seducer does not pay the fine is that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>with regard to</b> one who is <b>an orphan and a seduced woman.</b> Were her father alive, he would receive the payment. Because he died, the payment goes to her. Since she willingly participated in the relations, she relinquished her right to the payment, and the seducer is therefore liable to receive lashes.
The Gemara observes: <b>Apparently, Ulla maintains</b> that in <b>any</b> case <b>where there is</b> liability to both pay <b>money and</b> receive <b>lashes,</b> e.g., one who has forced relations with his sister who is a young woman, one <b>pays money</b> but <b>is not flogged.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where does Ulla</b> derive <b>this</b> principle? The Gemara answers: He <b>derives</b> it <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>of one who injures another. Just as</b> with regard to <b>one who injures another where there is</b> liability to both pay <b>money</b> for the injury <b>and</b> receive <b>lashes</b> for violating the prohibition “Lest he continues to strike him” (Deuteronomy 25:3), the <i>halakha</i> there is that one <b>pays money</b> but <b>is not flogged, so too,</b> in <b>any</b> case <b>where there is</b> liability to both pay <b>money and</b> receive <b>lashes,</b> one <b>pays money</b> but <b>is not flogged.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the basis for the comparison between other cases and the case of <b>one who injures another?</b> One who injures another cannot serve as a paradigm for cases of liability for both money and lashes because the case of one who injures another is particularly stringent, <b>as he is liable</b> to pay <b>five types</b> of indemnity: Injury, pain, medical costs, loss of livelihood, and humiliation. <b>And if</b> payment of <b>money</b> is a more <b>lenient</b> form of punishment than lashes, one could infer <i>a fortiori</i>: If in the stringent case of injuring another, one receives the more lenient punishment, all the more so would he receive the more lenient punishment in less stringent cases; nevertheless, one who injures another cannot serve as a paradigm for cases of liability for both money and lashes. The reason is that there is also a lenient aspect with regard to injuring another, <b>as</b> it is <b>permitted,</b> in departure <b>from its norm, in court.</b> The court administers lashes, injuring those convicted. The leniency is that its application is selective.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara states that Ulla <b>derives</b> this principle <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of false, <b>conspiring witnesses. Just as</b> with regard to <b>conspiring witnesses, where there is</b> liability to both pay <b>money,</b> if they falsely testified to render one liable for payment, <b>and</b> receive <b>lashes,</b> for violating the prohibition “You shall not bear false witness against your neighbor” (Exodus 20:13), and the <i>halakha</i> is that one <b>pays money</b> but <b>is not flogged, so too,</b> in <b>any</b> case <b>where there is</b> liability to both pay <b>money and</b> receive <b>lashes,</b> one <b>pays money</b> but <b>is not flogged.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the basis for the comparison of other cases to the case of <b>conspiring witnesses?</b> Conspiring witnesses cannot serve as a paradigm for cases of liability for both money and lashes because the case of conspiring witnesses is particularly stringent, <b>as they do not require forewarning.</b> As a rule, the courts administer punishment only to one who was forewarned not to perform the transgression. The fact that this is not a requirement in the case of conspiring witnesses indicates that it is a particularly stringent prohibition. Therefore, no proof can be cited from the case of conspiring witnesses to other cases with regard to monetary payment instead of lashes. <b>And if</b> payment of <b>money</b> is a more <b>lenient</b> form of punishment than lashes, the case of conspiring witnesses also has a lenient aspect, <b>as they did not perform an action</b> but merely spoke.
<b>Rather,</b> Ulla <b>derives</b> the principle <b>from both of them,</b> the cases of one who injures another and of conspiring witnesses. <b>The common denominator of</b> both cases <b>is that there is</b> liability to both pay <b>money and</b> receive <b>lashes</b> and the <i>halakha</i> is that one <b>pays money</b> but <b>is not flogged; so too,</b> in <b>any</b> case <b>where there is</b> liability to both pay <b>money and</b> receive <b>lashes,</b> one <b>pays money</b> but <b>is not flogged.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the basis for the comparison of other cases to <b>the common denominator of</b> both cases, <b>as they have an element of stringency</b> that does not exist in other prohibitions in that one who injures another pays five types of indemnity, and conspiring witnesses are flogged without forewarning? <b>And if</b> payment of <b>money</b> is a more <b>lenient</b> form of punishment than lashes, other cases cannot be derived from it, <b>as they have an element of leniency</b> that does not exist in other prohibitions. The prohibition in the case of one who injures another is selectively applied, as it is permitted, in departure from its norm, in court, and the case of conspiring witnesses is lenient because they performed no action.

Daf 32b

<b>Rather, Ulla derives</b> the fact that one pays and is not flogged by means of a verbal analogy between the terms <b>for</b> and <b>for.</b> The verse <b>states</b> with regard to rape: “And the man who lay with her shall give to the father of the young woman fifty shekels of silver, and to him she shall be as a wife, <b>because [<i>taḥat</i>] he tormented her”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29), <b>and it states there,</b> with regard to injury: <b>“An eye for [<i>taḥat</i>] an eye”</b> (Exodus 21:24). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to injury, one <b>pays money</b> and <b>is not flogged,</b> so too, in <b>any</b> case <b>where there is</b> liability to both pay <b>money and</b> receive <b>lashes,</b> one <b>pays money</b> but <b>is not flogged.</b>
§ In proposing a different resolution to the apparent contradiction between the mishna here that rules that one pays a fine for raping his sister and the mishna in <i>Makkot</i> that rules that one is flogged in that case, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even if you say</b> that both <i>mishnayot</i> are referring to <b>his sister</b> who is <b>a young woman, there</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the witnesses <b>forewarned him,</b> and therefore the rapist is flogged; <b>here,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the witnesses <b>did not forewarn him.</b> Since no lashes are administered without forewarning, the rapist pays the fine.
The Gemara observes: <b>Apparently, Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains</b> that in <b>any</b> case <b>where there is</b> liability to both pay <b>money and</b> receive <b>lashes, and</b> the witnesses <b>forewarned him, he is flogged</b> but does not <b>pay money.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where does Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> derive <b>this</b> principle? The Gemara explains that he derives it from that which <b>the verse states</b> with regard to one sentenced to lashes in the court: “The judge shall cause him to lie down, and to be beaten before him, <b>according to the measure of his wickedness”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:2), from which it is inferred: <b>For one</b> act of <b>wickedness,</b> i.e., punishment, <b>you can render him liable, but you cannot render him liable for two</b> acts of <b>wickedness. And juxtaposed to</b> this it states: <b>“Forty he shall strike him”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:3), indicating that the punishment that is administered when one is liable to receive two punishments is lashes and not payment.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what of the case of <b>one who injures another where there is</b> liability to both pay <b>money and</b> receive <b>lashes,</b> in which case one <b>pays money</b> but <b>is not flogged? And lest you say</b> that <b>this applies only when</b> the witnesses <b>did not forewarn him, but if they forewarned him</b> before he struck his friend he <b>is flogged</b> but <b>does not pay money, didn’t Rabbi Ami say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> If one <b>struck</b> another with <b>a blow that</b> does <b>not</b> cause damage that amounts to <b>the value of a <i>peruta</i>,</b> he is <b>flogged?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of that case? <b>If</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the witnesses <b>did not forewarn him, why is he flogged?</b> No lashes are administered without forewarning. <b>Rather, obviously</b> it is a case <b>where they forewarned him, and the reason</b> he is flogged is that <b>there is not</b> damage that amounts to <b>the value of a <i>peruta</i>.</b> The damages are not quantifiable. The Gemara infers: However, if <b>there is</b> damage that amounts to <b>the value of a <i>peruta</i>,</b> he <b>pays money</b> and <b>is not flogged,</b> even though he was forewarned.
The Gemara answers that the fact that conspiring witnesses pay money can be explained <b>in accordance with that</b> which <b>Rabbi Ile’a said</b> in a different context: <b>The Torah explicitly amplified</b> the case of <b>conspiring witnesses</b> to include liability <b>for payment.</b> The Torah employed language indicating that conspiring witnesses who testified falsely in order to render one liable for payment must pay the sum and are not flogged. <b>Here, too,</b> with regard to injury, <b>the Torah explicitly amplified</b> the case of <b>one who injures another</b> to include liability <b>for payment.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And where is this</b> statement <b>of Rabbi Ile’a stated?</b> The Gemara answers that it is stated <b>concerning this</b> mishna (<i>Makkot</i> 4a). If witnesses said: <b>We testify that so-and-so owes another two hundred dinar, and</b> these witnesses <b>were discovered</b> to be <b>conspiring</b> witnesses; <b>they are flogged and pay, as the source [<i>shem</i>] that brings them to</b> liability to receive <b>lashes does not bring them to</b> liability for <b>payment.</b> Each liability has an independent source; the source for lashes is: “You shall not bear false witness against your neighbor,” (Exodus 20:13) while the source for payment is: “You shall do unto him as he conspired” (Deuteronomy 19:19). This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: Anyone who pays is not flogged.</b>
<b>And</b> with regard to that mishna, the Gemara asks: <b>Let us say,</b> on the contrary, that <b>anyone who is flogged does not pay. Rabbi Ile’a said: The Torah explicitly amplified</b> the case of <b>conspiring witnesses for payment,</b> not lashes. The Gemara asks: <b>Where did the Torah amplify</b> the case of conspiring witnesses? The Gemara explains: <b>Now, since it states</b> with regard to conspiring witnesses: <b>“And you shall do unto him as he conspired to do unto his brother”</b> (Deuteronomy 19:19); <b>why do I</b> require the Torah to state in his punishment: <b>“A hand for a hand”</b> (Deuteronomy 19:21)? This indicates that the punishment that takes precedence is one in which there is <b>an item that is given from hand to hand, and what is that</b> item? It is <b>money.</b>
The same can be said with regard to <b>one who injures another. Now, since it states:</b> “And a man who places a blemish upon his counterpart, <b>as he has done so shall be done to him”</b> (Leviticus 24:19), <b>why do I</b> require the Torah to state: “As one who places a blemish upon a man, <b>so shall be placed [<i>yinnaten</i>] upon him”</b> (Leviticus 24:20)? This teaches that this is referring to <b>an item that involves giving [<i>netina</i>], and what is that</b> item? It is <b>money.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan, what is the reason</b> that <b>he did not say</b> the same <i>halakha</i> <b>as Ulla,</b> that where there is liability to both pay money and receive lashes, one pays money but is not flogged? The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> if that were the case, <b>you have rendered moot</b> the prohibition <b>“The nakedness of your sister…you shall not uncover”</b> (Leviticus 18:9) in that contrary to the standard prohibitions, no lashes would be administered for its violation.

Daf 33a

The Gemara asks: Based on that reasoning, the same would hold true for <b>one who injures another as well; if so,</b> if he pays and is not lashed, <b>you have rendered moot</b> the prohibition “Forty he shall strike him; <b>he shall not exceed, lest if he should exceed”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:3). The same would hold true for <b>conspiring witnesses as well; if so, you have rendered moot</b> the verse interpreted as addressing the matter of conspiring witnesses: <b>“And it shall be if the wicked man deserves to be flogged”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:2). <b>Rather,</b> with regard to <b>conspiring witnesses,</b> that verse <b>can be fulfilled</b> in the case <b>of the son of a divorcée or the son of a <i>ḥalutza</i>.</b> If witnesses testified that a priest is the son of a divorcée or a <i>ḥalutza</i> and were discovered to be conspiring witnesses, there is no payment and they are flogged. With regard to <b>one who injures another as well,</b> the verse <b>can be fulfilled</b> in a case <b>where he struck him</b> with <b>a blow that</b> does <b>not</b> cause damage amounting to <b>the value of a <i>peruta</i>.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: If so, with regard to <b>one’s sister as well,</b> the lashes <b>can be fulfilled</b> in the case of one who had forced relations <b>with his sister</b> who is <b>a grown woman.</b> Since there is no fine in that case, he is flogged and the verse is not moot. The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> could have <b>said to you</b> that he does not agree with Ulla because <b>this</b> verse: <b>“Because he tormented her”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29), is not available for a verbal analogy, as <b>he requires it to</b> derive <b>in accordance with that</b> which <b>Abaye</b> said, <b>as Abaye said</b> that <b>the verse states:</b> The fine of fifty dinar is payment <b>“because he tormented her”; by inference</b> one may conclude <b>that</b> beyond the fine, <b>there is</b> compensation for <b>humiliation and degradation.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And Ulla,</b> who uses this verse to derive a verbal analogy, from where does he derive the <i>halakha</i> stated by Abaye? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives it from</b> the statement of <b>Rava,</b> who derives that <i>halakha</i> from the same verse, <b>as Rava said</b> that <b>the verse states: “And the man who lay with her shall give to the father of the young woman fifty shekels of silver”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29). The superfluous phrase “who lay with her” teaches that it is for <b>the pleasure of lying</b> with her that he pays <b>fifty</b> shekels, i.e., fifty <i>sela</i>; <b>by inference</b> one may conclude <b>that</b> beyond the fine, <b>there is</b> compensation for <b>humiliation and degradation.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The reason that <b>conspiring witnesses pay money but are not flogged</b> is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that they are not subject to forewarning,</b> and without forewarning there are no lashes. <b>Rava said: Know</b> that this is true, since there is no practical manner to forewarn them, as <b>when</b> would <b>we forewarn them?</b> Perhaps <b>let us forewarn them initially,</b> before they come to testify; in that case, the forewarning would be ineffective because they could <b>say: We forgot</b> the forewarning. Then <b>let us forewarn them at the moment of the action,</b> just before they testify; in that case they will <b>leave and not testify</b> at all, as concern for potential repercussions will intimidate them into silence. Or, <b>let us forewarn them at the end</b> after their testimony; in that case <b>that which was, was,</b> and forewarning at that point is pointless.
<b>Abaye</b> strongly <b>objects to this: And let us warn them within</b> an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the time <b>of speaking,</b> during the brief period after they completed their statements, at which time the testimony is not yet considered to have concluded. Since they can still retract or amend their testimony during that period, a warning delivered at that point would be timely and effective. <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika,</b> also strongly <b>objects to this: And let us forewarn them initially,</b> before they testify, <b>and gesture to them</b> during the actual testimony, reminding them of the forewarning so they will be unable to claim that they forgot it.
<b>Abaye then said: That which I stated is not</b> a significant <b>matter.</b> Instead, <b>if it enters your mind</b> that <b>conspiring witnesses require forewarning, when we do not forewarn them we do not kill them.</b> However, <b>is there a matter in which they sought to kill</b> the defendant <b>without forewarning</b> him, as their testimony was false, <b>and</b> in order to punish them <b>they require forewarning? Don’t we require</b> that their punishment reflect the verse <b>“And you shall do unto him as he conspired to do unto his brother”</b> (Deuteronomy 19:19)? <b>And</b> if they require forewarning that <b>is not</b> the case.
<b>Rav Samma, son of Rav Yirmeya,</b> strongly <b>objects to this: However, if</b> what you say is <b>so,</b> when witnesses falsely accuse a priest of being <b>the son of a divorcée or the son of a <i>ḥalutza</i>, as</b> their punishment <b>is not amplified from</b> the verse <b>“As he conspired”</b> but rather they are punished for violating the prohibition “You shall not bear false witness against your neighbor,” <b>let them require forewarning.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states: “You shall have one manner of law”</b> (Leviticus 24:22), meaning that there must be <b>a law equal for all of you.</b> Since in standard cases of conspiring witnesses no forewarning is required, even in exceptional cases like testimony that a priest is the son of a divorcée or a <i>ḥalutza</i>, forewarning is not required.
§ <b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said:</b> The fact that in the case of <b>one who injures another as well he pays money and is not flogged</b> is derived not by means of a verbal analogy but <b>from here: “If men quarrel and hurt a pregnant woman so that her child departs from her,</b> and yet no harm follow, he shall be punished as imposed upon him by the woman’s husband” (Exodus 21:22). <b>And Rabbi Elazar said: The verse is speaking of a quarrel that involves death,</b> i.e., they sought to kill each other, <b>as it is written: “And if any harm follow, then you shall give a soul for a soul”</b> (Exodus 21:23).
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If they did not forewarn one</b> not to kill the other, <b>why is he killed</b> if the death of his opponent ensues? <b>Rather, obviously</b> it is a case <b>where they forewarned him, and</b> the principle is that <b>one who is forewarned with regard to a severe matter,</b> murdering his counterpart, <b>is forewarned with regard to a lesser matter,</b> injuring his counterpart. <b>And</b> although he is forewarned against injuring another, which violates a prohibition and is punishable by lashes, <b>the Merciful One states: “And yet no harm follow, he shall be punished”</b> (Exodus 21:22), indicating that one pays and is not flogged.
<b>Rav Ashi</b> strongly <b>objects to this</b> proof. First of all, with regard to your initial assumption, <b>from where</b> do you ascertain <b>that one who is forewarned with regard to a severe matter is forewarned with regard to a lesser matter? Perhaps he is not</b> considered forewarned with regard to the lesser matter. Furthermore, even <b>if you say</b> that one <b>is</b> in fact forewarned with regard to a lesser matter, <b>from where</b> do you ascertain <b>that</b> the <b>death</b> penalty is a more <b>severe</b> punishment than lashes?

Daf 33b

<b>Perhaps</b> the punishment of <b>lashes is</b> more <b>severe, as Rav said: Had they flogged Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah</b> (see Daniel, chapter 3) instead of casting them into the fiery furnace, these three <b>would have</b> been induced to <b>worship the</b> graven <b>image.</b> Apparently, the punishment of lashes is more severe than death. <b>Rav Samma, son of Rav Asi, said to Rav Ashi, and some say Rav Samma, son of Rav Ashi,</b> said <b>to Rav Ashi: And</b> is <b>there no difference to you between flogging that has a limit,</b> e.g., forty lashes by Torah law, which is a less severe punishment, <b>and flogging that does not have a limit,</b> i.e., flogging administered to induce compliance, which is more severe?
With regard to the basic proof from the case of the two men quarreling, <b>Rav Ya’akov from Nehar Pekod</b> strongly <b>objects to this. This</b> works out <b>well according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who said</b> that the verse “And you shall give a soul for a soul” (Exodus 21:23) is referring to <b>an actual life,</b> and that if he caused the woman’s death he is executed. <b>However, according to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said</b> that if he did not intend to injure the woman he is not liable to be executed and instead pays <b>money</b> as indemnity for causing her death, <b>what can be said?</b> According to that opinion, there was no forewarning for lashes at all, and the only liability is payment for injuring another.
<b>Rather, Rav Ya’akov from Nehar Pekod said in the name of Rava</b> that the <i>halakha</i> that one pays and is not flogged is derived <b>from here.</b> With regard to one who struck another with a stone or his fist and did not kill him but caused him to be bedridden, it is written: <b>“If he rises and walks outside with his staff, he who struck him is absolved”</b> (Exodus 21:19). <b>And could it enter your mind that this</b> victim <b>is walking in the marketplace and that</b> aggressor <b>is executed</b> as a murderer? <b>Rather,</b> the verse <b>teaches that one imprisons</b> the aggressor while the injured party recuperates, <b>and if he dies</b> due to the blow he received, <b>we kill him. And if he does not die</b> and recovers, the aggressor’s punishment is based on the verse <b>“His loss of livelihood he shall give, and he shall cause him to be thoroughly healed”</b> (Exodus 21:19).
The Gemara elaborates: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> the witnesses <b>did not forewarn him, why is</b> the offender <b>killed</b> if the victim dies? <b>Rather, obviously</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the witnesses <b>forewarned him, and one who is forewarned for a severe matter,</b> such as the potential death penalty, <b>is</b> also <b>forewarned for</b> the <b>lesser matter</b> of injuring another, for which he is liable to be flogged, <b>and</b> nevertheless <b>the Merciful One states: “His loss of livelihood he shall give, and he shall cause him to be thoroughly healed.”</b> Apparently, despite his liability to be flogged, he pays and is not flogged.
<b>Rav Ashi</b> strongly <b>objects to this</b> proof: First of all, with regard to your initial assumption, <b>from where</b> do you ascertain <b>that one who is forewarned with regard to a severe matter is forewarned with regard to a lesser matter? Perhaps he is not</b> considered forewarned with regard to the lesser matter. Furthermore, even <b>if you say</b> that one <b>is</b> in fact forewarned with regard to a lesser matter, <b>from where</b> do you ascertain <b>that</b> the <b>death</b> penalty is a more <b>severe</b> punishment than lashes? <b>Perhaps</b> the punishment of <b>lashes is</b> more <b>severe, as Rav said: Had they flogged Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah,</b> instead of casting them into the fiery furnace, <b>they would have</b> been induced to <b>worship the</b> graven <b>image.</b> Apparently, the punishment of lashes is more severe than death.
<b>Rav Samma, son of Rav Asi, said to Rav Ashi, and some say Rav Samma, son of Rav Ashi,</b> said <b>to Rav Ashi: And</b> is <b>there no difference to you between flogging that has a limit,</b> e.g., forty lashes by Torah law, which is a less severe punishment, <b>and flogging that does not have a limit,</b> administered to induce compliance, which is more severe?
<b>Rav Mari</b> strongly <b>objects to this</b> proof that one pays and is not flogged: <b>From where</b> do you ascertain <b>that</b> this is referring to one who struck another <b>intentionally,</b> and that the verse “He who struck him shall be absolved” means that he <b>shall be absolved of</b> the <b>death</b> penalty? <b>Perhaps</b> the verse is referring to one who struck another <b>unwittingly, and</b> the verse means that he <b>shall be absolved of exile?</b> In that case, there would be no forewarning. Therefore, no proof may be cited from here that one who injures another pays and is not flogged. The Gemara concludes: This is <b>difficult,</b> and no proof may be cited from here.
§ The Gemara cites another resolution of the apparent contradiction between the mishna here, which obligates one who rapes his sister to pay a fine, and the mishna in <i>Makkot</i>, which rules him liable to be flogged. <b>Reish Lakish said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna taught? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said: One is flogged and pays.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, even</b> if one raped <b>his daughter</b> he should <b>also</b> be obligated to pay the fine. However, the mishna lists only those who raped women for whom one is liable to be punished for violating a prohibition or liable to receive <i>karet</i>, not those for whom one is liable to receive court-imposed execution.
<b>And lest you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir is of</b> the opinion that <b>one is flogged and pays,</b> but <b>is not of</b> the opinion that <b>one dies</b> by execution <b>and pays; and isn’t</b> he of the opinion that one who is executed pays? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>stole</b> an animal <b>and slaughtered</b> it <b>on Shabbat,</b> or <b>stole</b> it <b>and slaughtered</b> it <b>for idolatry,</b> or <b>stole an ox that</b> was sentenced to be <b>stoned,</b> from which one may derive no benefit and is therefore worthless, <b>and slaughtered it, he pays</b> the owner <b>a payment of four or five</b> times the principal, as he would in any case of stealing and slaughtering an animal? This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis exempt him</b> from payment because he is liable to receive the death penalty for slaughtering on Shabbat or for idolatry. Apparently, Rabbi Meir maintains that one is obligated to pay even when he is liable to receive the death penalty.
The Gemara refutes this: <b>Wasn’t it stated concerning</b> this <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Ya’akov said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said, and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said,</b> that <b>Rabbi Avin and Rabbi Ile’a and the entire group said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> That case is referring <b>to one who slaughters by means of another?</b> The thief himself did not slaughter the animal; rather, it was his agent. Consequently, the thief pays because the capital crime was committed by his agent. Therefore, this source is unrelated to Rabbi Meir’s opinion with regard to the question of whether one is executed and pays.
The Gemara analyzes Rabbi Yoḥanan’s explanation: <b>And does this</b> agent <b>sin and that</b> thief <b>is liable</b> to pay four and five times the principal? This violates the principle: There is no agent for matters of transgression. The Gemara explains that this is a <i>halakha</i> unique to this case. <b>Rava said</b> that <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “If a man steal an ox or a sheep <b>and slaughter it or sell it”</b> (Exodus 21:37). Based on the juxtaposition of slaughter and sale, Rava continues: <b>Just as sale</b> is performed <b>by means of another,</b> as there is no sale without a buyer, <b>so too,</b> one is liable to be punished for <b>slaughter by means of another.</b> Although there is no agent for transgression, here there is a Torah decree that one is liable by means of another.
The Sages <b>of the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> a different source for the <i>halakha</i> that one is liable for slaughter by means of an agent. It is written: “And slaughter it or sell it”; the term <b>“or”</b> comes <b>to include an agent.</b> The Sages <b>of the school of Rabbi Ḥizkiyya taught</b> a different proof from the same verse: “He shall pay…for an ox…for a sheep”; the term <b>“for”</b> comes <b>to include an agent.</b>
<b>Mar Zutra</b> strongly <b>objects to this</b> <i>halakha</i>. <b>Is there</b> any <b>matter</b> with regard to <b>which if one performs</b> it himself, he is not <b>liable, and</b> yet if his <b>agent performs</b> it he is <b>liable?</b> Had he slaughtered the animal himself on Shabbat he would have been exempt from payment. How, then, is he liable if he does so by means of an agent? The Gemara answers: <b>He</b> is exempt <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that he is not liable</b> for the slaughter; <b>rather,</b> he is exempt <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he receives the greater of</b> the two punishments, the death penalty, for his desecration of Shabbat. He is liable for both the slaughter and the desecration of Shabbat. In practice, he receives the more severe punishment. However, when he appoints an agent, there is no liability for the desecration of Shabbat, and therefore he must pay for the slaughter.
The Gemara returns to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s explanation of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>If</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the case <b>of</b> one <b>who slaughtered by means of another, what is the</b> rationale for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis, who exempt</b> him from payment? As the thief did not perform a transgression for which he is liable to receive the death penalty, why is he exempt from payment for slaughtering the animal? The Gemara answers: <b>Who are the Rabbis</b> who disagree with Rabbi Meir in this case?

Daf 34a

<b>It is Rabbi Shimon, who said:</b> The legal status of <b>slaughter that is improper,</b> in that it does not render the meat fit to be eaten, <b>is not that of slaughter.</b> Therefore, one is not liable for slaughter of the animal. The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> works out <b>well</b> with regard to <b>idolatry and</b> the <b>ox that is stoned,</b> as their slaughter is ineffective in rendering the meat fit to be eaten; <b>however, the slaughter on Shabbat is a proper</b> act of <b>slaughter, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ḥullin</i> 14a): In the case of <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal <b>on Shabbat or on Yom Kippur, although he is liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty for desecrating Shabbat, <b>his slaughter is valid</b> and the meat may be eaten.
The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> under discussion <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan HaSandlar, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <br>With regard to <b>one who cooks on Shabbat,</b> if he did so <b>unwittingly, he may eat</b> the food he cooked; if he did so <b>intentionally, he may not eat</b> it at all. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> <br><b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If he cooked <b>unwittingly he may eat at the conclusion of Shabbat,</b> as the Sages penalized even one who sinned unwittingly in that they prohibited him from deriving immediate benefit from the dish that he cooked; if he sinned <b>intentionally, he may not eat</b> from it <b>ever.</b> <br><b>Rabbi Yoḥanan HaSandlar says:</b> If he did so <b>unwittingly,</b> the food <b>may be eaten at the conclusion of Shabbat by others but not by him;</b> if he did so <b>intentionally, it may not be eaten ever, neither by him nor by other</b> Jews. According to Rabbi Yoḥanan HaSandlar, food prepared by means of intentional desecration of Shabbat is unfit to be eaten. That is true with regard to cooking food on Shabbat and with regard to slaughtering an animal on Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan HaSandlar?</b> The Gemara explains: It is <b>as Rabbi Ḥiyya taught at the entrance to the house of the <i>Nasi</i>.</b> It is written: <b>“And you shall observe Shabbat, for it is sacred to you;</b> he who profanes it shall be put to death” (Exodus 31:14); <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>a sacred</b> item consecrated to the Temple, <b>eating</b> it <b>is prohibited, so too,</b> with regard to food produced through <b>action</b> that desecrates <b>Shabbat, eating</b> it <b>is prohibited.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> so, perhaps the analogy should be extended to include the following: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a sacred item,</b> deriving <b>benefit</b> from it <b>is prohibited, so too,</b> with regard to the product of <b>an action</b> that desecrates <b>Shabbat,</b> deriving <b>benefit</b> from it should be <b>prohibited.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states:</b> “It is sacred <b>to you”</b> (Exodus 31:14), indicating that <b>it shall be yours</b> in the sense that one may derive benefit from it.
The Gemara asks: Based on the analogy between actions that desecrate Shabbat and sacred items, one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> if the action was performed <b>unwittingly</b> it should be prohibited to eat its product, as is the case with regard to sacred items. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “He who profanes it shall be put to death”</b> (Exodus 31:14), indicating that it is <b>with regard to</b> one who desecrates Shabbat <b>intentionally</b> that <b>I stated to you</b> this analogy to sacred items, as the verse is clearly referring to one who is liable to receive the death penalty, <b>and not with regard to</b> one who desecrates Shabbat <b>unwittingly,</b> who is not executed.
The Gemara comments: <b>Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagree with regard to</b> this matter. <b>One said:</b> The product of <b>an action</b> that desecrates <b>Shabbat</b> is prohibited <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>and one said</b> that it is prohibited <b>by rabbinic</b> law. With regard to the <b>one who said</b> that it is prohibited <b>by Torah</b> law, it is <b>as we said,</b> that it is based on the verse interpreted by Rabbi Ḥiyya. <b>And</b> the <b>one who said</b> that it is prohibited <b>by rabbinic</b> law holds that <b>the verse states: “It is sacred,”</b> from which he infers: <b>It is sacred, but</b> the product of <b>its actions is not sacred,</b> and therefore, by Torah law it may be eaten.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the <b>one who said</b> it is prohibited <b>by rabbinic</b> law, <b>what is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis who exempt</b> the thief from payment for the slaughter performed by his agent on Shabbat? By Torah law, the slaughter is valid. The Gemara answers: <b>When the Rabbis exempt</b> the thief from payment, it is with regard <b>to the rest</b> of the cases, i.e., one who slaughters for idolatry or an ox sentenced to stoning, not with regard to Shabbat.
The Gemara asks the following question with regard to Rabbi Meir’s opinion that <b>one who slaughters for idolatry</b> is liable to pay the owner for the animal. <b>Once he slaughtered</b> the animal <b>a bit,</b> at the very start of the act of slaughter, <b>it is prohibited for him</b> to derive benefit from the animal because it is an animal sacrificed to idolatry; <b>and when he slaughters the rest,</b> it is <b>not</b> the animal that belongs <b>to its owner</b> that he <b>is slaughtering.</b> Since it is prohibited to derive benefit from the animal, it has no value and there is no ownership. <b>Rava said:</b> It is referring <b>to one who says,</b> prior to the slaughter, that <b>he is worshipping</b> the idol only <b>at the completion of the slaughter,</b> and therefore the prohibition takes effect only then.
The Gemara asks the following question with regard to Rabbi Meir’s opinion that one who slaughters <b>the ox that is stoned</b> is liable to pay for the slaughter. Why is he liable? It is <b>not</b> the owner’s ox that <b>he is slaughtering,</b> since once the ox is sentenced to be stoned it is prohibited to derive benefit from it. <b>Rabba said: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> the owners <b>entrusted</b> the ox <b>to a bailee and</b> the ox <b>injured</b> another person while <b>in the bailee’s house, and it was sentenced</b> to be stoned while <b>in the bailee’s house, and</b> the <b>thief</b> then <b>stole it from the bailee’s house</b> and slaughtered it.
<b>And</b> this solution is based on the fact that <b>Rabbi Meir holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ya’akov and holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. He holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ya’akov, who said: Even after</b> the ox <b>was sentenced</b> to be stoned, if the <b>bailee returned it to its owners, it is returned.</b> Despite the fact that the ox is now worthless, as no benefit may be derived from it, since the bailee returned an ox that is physically intact the owner has no claim against him. <b>And</b> Rabbi Meir <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> that the legal status of <b>an object that effects monetary</b> loss <b>is like</b> that of <b>money.</b> Even in the case of an object that is worthless, if its elimination causes monetary loss because it must be replaced, it is considered to have value. In this case, although the ox has no value in and of itself, slaughtering the animal prevents the bailee from returning it intact to the owner, requiring him to pay the owner the value of the ox before it was sentenced to be stoned. Consequently, the thief must reimburse the bailee, as the ox has value for the bailee.
<b>Rabba said: Actually,</b> contrary to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s explanation of the <i>baraita</i>, it is referring <b>to one who slaughters</b> the animal <b>himself,</b>

Daf 34b

<b>and Rabbi Meir is of</b> the opinion that one <b>is flogged and pays,</b> but <b>is not of</b> the opinion that one <b>dies</b> by execution <b>and pays. And these</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>are different, as it is a novel element that the Torah innovated with regard to</b> the halakhic category of <b>fines; although he is killed, he pays. And Rabba followed his</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> stated elsewhere, <b>as Rabba said:</b> If one <b>had a stolen kid</b> in <b>his</b> possession that he had stolen previously, <b>and he slaughtered it on Shabbat,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to pay five times the principal for slaughtering the kid, <b>as he was already liable for stealing before he came to</b> violate <b>the prohibition</b> against performing labor on <b>Shabbat.</b> Although he slaughtered the goat on Shabbat, a capital crime, he is liable for the payment because it is a fine. However, if <b>he stole</b> the goat <b>and slaughtered</b> it <b>on Shabbat,</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from the payment of five times the principal <b>as, if</b> there is <b>no</b> payment for <b>theft,</b> due to his liability to receive the death penalty for desecrating Shabbat, and his obligation to repay the theft is not a fine, there is <b>no</b> liability for <b>slaughter and</b> there is <b>no</b> liability for <b>sale.</b>
<b>And Rabba said:</b> If one <b>had a stolen kid</b> in <b>his</b> possession that he had stolen previously, <b>and he slaughtered it in</b> the course of an act of <b>burglary,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to pay four or five times the principal, <b>as he was already liable for theft before he came to</b> violate <b>the prohibition</b> against <b>burglary.</b> However, if <b>he stole and slaughtered</b> an animal <b>in</b> the course of an act of <b>burglary,</b> he is <b>exempt.</b> Because the owner of the house is permitted to kill the burglar, the status of the burglar is tantamount to one liable to receive the death penalty. <b>As, if</b> there is <b>no</b> payment <b>for theft,</b> there is <b>no</b> liability for <b>slaughter and</b> there is <b>no</b> liability for <b>sale.</b> Rabba’s statements indicate that one pays the fines for slaughter or sale even if he is liable to receive the death penalty.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it was <b>necessary</b> for Rabba to state this <i>halakha</i> with regard to both Shabbat and burglary; <b>as, if he</b> had <b>taught us</b> that one is exempt from payment only with regard to <b>Shabbat,</b> it is <b>because</b> Shabbat is severe since punishment for violation of <b>its prohibition is an eternal prohibition,</b> as whenever witnesses testify that one desecrated Shabbat, he can be executed. <b>However,</b> in the case of <b>burglary,</b> as punishment for violating its <b>prohibition is transitory,</b> e.g., it is permitted for the homeowner to kill the burglar only as long as the burglar remains on his property, <b>say</b> that he is <b>not</b> exempt from payment. <b>And if he taught us</b> the exemption only with regard to <b>burglary,</b> that would be <b>because his burglary is his forewarning.</b> Because he certainly intends to kill the homeowner, it is permitted for the homeowner to kill him without forewarning. In that respect, burglary is a severe prohibition and exempts one from payment. <b>However, Shabbat, which requires forewarning,</b> is a less severe prohibition, and in that case, <b>say</b> that one <b>is not</b> exempt from payment. Therefore, it was <b>necessary</b> for Rabba to state the exemption in both cases.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> If one <b>had a stolen cow</b> in <b>his</b> possession that he had stolen previously <b>and he slaughtered it on Shabbat,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to pay four or five times the principal <b>as he was already liable for theft before he came to</b> violate <b>the prohibition of Shabbat.</b> If <b>a cow was lent to him and he slaughtered it on Shabbat,</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from paying the fine. <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> Is <b>Rav Pappa coming to teach us</b> the case of <b>a cow?</b> In other words, what did Rav Pappa add that was not already clear from Rabba’s statement? The same principle applies with regard to both a kid and a cow. If one was liable to pay for the theft when he stole the animal, he is liable to pay the fine for slaughter as well, even if he is liable to receive the death penalty.
Rav Ashi <b>said to him: Rav Pappa is coming to teach us</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a <b>borrowed</b> cow, as <b>it could enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since Rav Pappa said:</b> It is <b>from the moment of pulling</b> the animal into his domain <b>that</b> the borrower <b>is obligated to</b> provide the animal’s <b>sustenance,</b> then <b>here too, from the moment of borrowing he is liable</b> to pay <b>for its unavoidable accidents.</b> From that point, the animal is legally in his possession and therefore, even if he slaughtered the animal on Shabbat he should be liable. Therefore, <b>he teaches us</b> that one assumes liability for unavoidable accidents only when they actually occur, and if that is on Shabbat, he is exempt.
<b>Rava said:</b> If <b>their father</b> died and <b>left them a borrowed cow, they may use it</b> for <b>the entire</b> duration of the <b>period</b> for which <b>it was borrowed.</b> The right to use a borrowed article continues even after the borrower himself dies. However, if the cow <b>died, they are not liable</b> to pay <b>for its unavoidable accident,</b> as they did not borrow the animal themselves. Similarly, if <b>they thought</b> the cow <b>was their father’s and they slaughtered it and ate it, they pay only a reduced</b> assessment of the <b>price of the meat.</b> They are required to pay only for the benefit they received, not the damage they caused the owner. However, if <b>their father left them property</b> as a <b>guarantee</b> for return of the borrowed item, i.e., there was a lien on the father’s property during his lifetime, <b>they are obligated to pay</b> the entire sum of the damage.
The Gemara comments: <b>Some teach this</b> statement, that if the father left property as a guarantee his heirs are liable to pay the entire damage, <b>with regard to the first clause</b> of this <i>halakha</i>, <b>and some teach it with regard to the latter clause.</b> The Gemara elaborates: According to the <b>one who teaches it with regard to the first clause,</b> when the animal died, <b>all the more so</b> would he teach this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to the latter clause,</b> as since they slaughtered the animal they must pay full damages. <b>And</b> this approach <b>differs</b> with the opinion <b>of Rav Pappa,</b> who said that a borrower is liable for accidents only when the incident occurs. <b>And</b> according to the <b>one who teaches it with regard to the latter clause,</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies only when they slaughtered and ate it; <b>however, with regard to the first clause,</b> when it died, they would <b>not</b> be liable, as the <i>tanna</i> too maintains that liability for unavoidable accidents begins only when the incident occurs, not from when the cow was borrowed. <b>And this is</b> consistent with the ruling <b>of Rav Pappa.</b>
Several possible solutions were proposed to resolve the apparent contradiction between the mishna here that says that one who rapes his sister pays a fine and the mishna in <i>Makkot</i> that says that he is flogged. The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who explains the mishna as referring to a case where he was not forewarned, <b>did not state</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish,</b> who explains that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, <b>as he establishes</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> a preferable option, as that aligns the unattributed mishna with the <i>halakha</i>. <b>However, what is the reason</b> that <b>Reish Lakish didn’t state</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan?</b> The Gemara answers: Reish Lakish could have <b>said to you: Since if they forewarned him</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from payment, <b>when they did not forewarn him,</b> he is <b>exempt as well.</b>
<b>And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish each <b>follow their</b> standard lines of <b>reasoning</b> in this regard, <b>as when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said:</b> With regard to <b>those</b> who <b>unwittingly</b> performed a transgression for which one is <b>liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty, or <b>those</b> who <b>unwittingly</b> performed a transgression for which one is <b>liable</b> to receive <b>lashes, and</b> that transgression also involved <b>another matter,</b> monetary payment, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> He is <b>liable</b> to pay; since he sinned unwittingly he did not receive the severe punishment. <b>And Reish Lakish said</b> he is <b>exempt.</b> The Gemara clarifies the rationales for their statements. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> he is <b>liable; since they did not forewarn him,</b> he sinned unwittingly. <b>Reish Lakish said</b> he is <b>exempt; since if they forewarned him</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from payment, <b>when they did not forewarn him,</b> he is <b>exempt as well.</b>
<b>Reish Lakish raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> from the following verse, which describes a case where two people fought and during their struggle they hurt a pregnant woman, causing her to miscarry: <b>“And yet no harm follow, he shall be punished</b> as imposed upon him by the woman’s husband” (Exodus 21:22).

Daf 35a

<b>Is</b> this <b>not</b> referring to <b>actual harm,</b> i.e., the woman’s death? And the verse states that he pays only if she did not die, but if she died is he exempt, even if he was not forewarned? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the verse can be explained to mean: If there is no <b>sentence of harm.</b> If the court does not actually sentence him to death, he pays the damages for the miscarried fetus. He is exempt from payment only if he is actually executed. <b>Some say</b> a different version of this exchange: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish: “And yet no harm follow, he shall be punished”</b> (Exodus 21:22); <b>is</b> this <b>not</b> referring to <b>a sentence of harm?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the verse can be explained to mean: If there is no <b>actual harm.</b>
<b>Rava said: Is there anyone who said</b> that <b>those</b> who <b>unwittingly</b> performed a transgression for which one is <b>liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty <b>are obligated</b> to pay? <b>But didn’t</b> the Sage <b>of the school of Ḥizkiyya teach:</b> The verse speaks of <b>one who smites a person, and</b> the verse speaks of <b>one who smites an animal.</b> The two cases are juxtaposed in the verse “And one who smites an animal shall pay for it, and one who smites a person shall die” (Leviticus 24:21).
<b>Just as in</b> the case of one <b>who smites an animal, you did not distinguish between</b> one who did so <b>unwittingly and</b> one who did so <b>intentionally, between</b> one who acted <b>with intent and one who</b> acted <b>with no intent, between</b> one who smites <b>in</b> the course of <b>a downward motion and</b> one who smites <b>in</b> the course of <b>an upward motion,</b> and in all those cases it is not <b>to exempt</b> him from paying <b>money but rather to obligate him to</b> pay <b>money; so too, in</b> the case of one <b>who smites a person, do not distinguish between</b> one who did so <b>unwittingly and</b> one who did so <b>intentionally, between</b> one who acted <b>with intent and one who</b> acted <b>with no intent, between</b> one who smites <b>in</b> the course of <b>a downward motion and</b> one who smites <b>in</b> the course of <b>an upward motion.</b> In all those cases as well it is not <b>to obligate him</b> to pay <b>money but rather to exempt him</b> from paying <b>money.</b> The <i>halakha</i> in both cases is unconditional; when he smites an animal he is always liable to pay and when he smites a person he is always exempt from payment, regardless of whether or not he is actually executed.
<b>Rather, when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said:</b> With regard to <b>those</b> who <b>unwittingly</b> performed a transgression for which one is <b>liable to</b> receive the <b>death penalty, everyone agrees that</b> they <b>are exempt,</b> as per the derivation of the Sages of the school of Ḥizkiyya. <b>When they disagree</b> it is <b>with regard to those</b> who <b>unwittingly</b> performed a transgression for which one is <b>liable to</b> receive <b>lashes, and another matter,</b> for which he is liable to pay money. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that he is <b>obligated</b> to pay, as <b>those liable to</b> receive the <b>death penalty are juxtaposed</b> to cases of monetary payment and are unconditionally exempt from payment. However, <b>those liable</b> to receive <b>lashes are not juxtaposed.</b> Therefore, in the case of one who is liable to receive lashes, unless one is actually flogged, he is obligated to pay for the damage he inflicted. <b>Reish Lakish said:</b> He is <b>exempt, as the Torah explicitly included those liable to</b> receive <b>lashes, like those liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty, and unconditionally exempted them from payment.
The Gemara asks: <b>Where did</b> the <b>Torah include</b> those liable to be flogged? <b>Abaye said:</b> It is <b>derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between the term <b>wicked</b> in the verse “That he is wicked and liable to die” (Numbers 35:31), and the term <b>wicked</b> in the verse “That he is wicked and liable to be flogged” (Deuteronomy 25:2). <b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between the term <b>smites</b> in one verse and the term <b>smites</b> in another verse. <b>Rav Pappa said to Rava:</b> To <b>which</b> term <b>smites</b> are you referring? <b>If we say</b> that it is the verse <b>“And one who smites an animal shall pay for it, and one who smites a person shall die”</b> (Leviticus 24:21), clearly that is not so, as <b>that is written with regard to death.</b> Smiting a person in that verse is referring to murder. <b>Rather,</b> it is to <b>this</b> term <b>smites</b> that Rava is referring: <b>“And he who smites an animal shall pay for it, a life for a life”</b> (Leviticus 24:18), <b>and juxtaposed to it,</b> it is written: <b>“And a man who places a blemish upon his counterpart, as he has done so shall be done to him”</b> (Leviticus 24:19). The verses liken those liable to receive lashes to those obligated to pay money, from which it is derived that those liable to receive lashes are exempt from payment.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But this</b> term that appears in the latter verse <b>is</b> “places a blemish,” <b>not smites.</b> How, then, can one derive a verbal analogy? The Gemara answers: This is not a verbal analogy based on identical terms; rather, it is based on identical concepts. <b>We are saying</b> that it is a verbal analogy between <b>smiting</b> an animal in the first verse and <b>smiting</b> a person in the latter verse. The Gemara asks: <b>However, when</b> the second verse <b>is written, it is written with regard to one who injures another, and one who injures another is subject to payment</b> and not to lashes. This undermines the proof, as lashes are not mentioned in either verse. The Gemara answers: <b>If it is not a matter of smiting that</b> causes damage equivalent to the <b>value of a <i>peruta</i>,</b> in which case he would pay and would not be flogged, <b>apply it</b> to the <b>matter of smiting that</b> causes damage that is not equivalent to the <b>value of a <i>peruta</i>.</b> Since in that case there is no payment for the injury, one is flogged for striking that blow.

Daf 35b

The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Ultimately,</b> one who injured another and is flogged <b>is not subject to payment,</b> as he inflicted damage worth less than a <i>peruta</i>. How then can a principle be derived that one who is liable to receive lashes does not pay even when he is not actually flogged? The Gemara answers: The juxtaposition of the verses is <b>necessary only</b> with regard to a situation <b>where at the</b> same <b>time that he struck him he tore his silk.</b> In that case, where he performed a transgression for which he is liable to be flogged and is also liable to pay damages, it is derived that he would be exempt from paying damages even if he is not actually flogged.
