§ <b>Rav Ḥiyya said to Rava: And according to the</b> derivation <b>of</b> the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Ḥizkiyya, who said:</b> The verse speaks of <b>one who smites a person, and</b> the verse speaks of <b>one who smites an animal. From where</b> does that <i>tanna</i> know <b>that it is written with regard to a weekday and</b> therefore <b>there is no</b> reason <b>to distinguish</b> between an unwitting and a purposeful sinner; <b>perhaps</b> this case <b>is stated with regard to</b> one who injured an animal on <b>Shabbat, when concerning the animal itself there is</b> reason <b>to distinguish</b> between one who did so unwittingly and one who did so intentionally. In the case of one who acted unwittingly, he is not liable to receive the death penalty and should therefore be obligated to pay, whereas one who acted intentionally is exempt from payment because he receives the death penalty for desecrating Shabbat. If so, there is no source to exempt from payment one who is not actually executed.
The Gemara answers: That notion <b>should not enter your mind, as it is written: “And one who smites an animal shall pay for it, and one who smites a person shall die”</b> (Leviticus 24:21). <b>What are the circumstances</b> discussed in this verse? <b>If</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the witnesses <b>did not forewarn him,</b> i.e., when <b>one who smites a person</b> is not forewarned, <b>why should he be executed?</b> There is no corporal punishment, neither lashes nor execution, without forewarning. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious that they forewarned him. And if</b> the verse is referring to one who sinned <b>on Shabbat</b> after forewarning, would <b>one who smites an animal</b> be obligated to <b>pay for it?</b> He is executed and certainly exempt from payment. <b>Rather, isn’t</b> the verse clearly referring to a case <b>during the week?</b>
§ <b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: According to Rabba,</b> who <b>said: It is a novel element that the Torah innovated with regard to</b> the halakhic category of <b>fine, and even though he is executed he pays</b> the fine; <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>does</b> Rabba <b>establish the mishna? If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> it is <b>difficult;</b> why is he exempt if he raped <b>his daughter?</b> According to Rabba, Rabbi Meir is of the opinion that even one liable to receive the death penalty pays the fine. <b>If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana,</b> it is <b>difficult,</b> as why does the mishna rule that he pays the fine for raping <b>his sister?</b> Rabbi Neḥunya holds that one liable to receive <i>karet</i> is exempt from the fine, like those liable to receive the death penalty. <b>If</b> the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak,</b> who rules that lashes are not administered to those liable to receive <i>karet</i> and therefore they are obligated to pay the fine; however, one who is flogged is exempt from payment, it is <b>difficult,</b> as why did the mishna rule that he is obligated to pay the fine for raping <b>a <i>mamzeret</i>,</b> for which he is liable to receive lashes?
<b>This</b> works out <b>well if</b> Rabba <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who says that one who did not receive forewarning is obligated to pay even if he performed a transgression for which he is liable to be flogged, as <b>he can explain</b> the mishna <b>as well, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> that he is obligated to pay in cases where there was no forewarning. <b>However, if he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish,</b> that one who violated a prohibition for which one is liable to be flogged is exempt from payment even if he was not forewarned, <b>how does</b> he <b>explain</b> the mishna? The mishna does not correspond to any of the aforementioned opinions. The Gemara answers: <b>You</b> must say <b>perforce</b> that <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> in this regard.
<b>Rav Mattana said to Abaye: According to Reish Lakish, who said</b> that <b>the Torah explicitly included those</b> who are <b>liable to</b> receive <b>lashes</b> and accorded them legal status <b>like those</b> who are <b>liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty, unconditionally exempting them from payment; <b>who is the <i>tanna</i> who disagrees with Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana</b> and obligates one who is liable both to receive <i>karet</i> and to be flogged to pay, and the lashes do not exempt him from payment? The Gemara answers: He holds in accordance with <b>either Rabbi Meir,</b> who says that one who is liable to receive lashes is liable to pay a fine, <b>or Rabbi Yitzḥak,</b> who rules that those liable to receive <i>karet</i> are not flogged.
§ The Gemara turns its attention to a related issue. <b>The Sages taught:</b> Women who are <b>forbidden relatives and secondary forbidden relatives</b> receive <b>neither</b> payment of <b>a fine</b> for rape <b>nor</b> payment of a fine for <b>seduction.</b> Similarly, a girl <b>who refuses</b> to remain married to her husband receives <b>neither</b> payment of <b>a fine</b> for rape <b>nor</b> payment of a fine for <b>seduction.</b> Because she was married, she no longer has the presumptive status of a virgin. <b>A sexually underdeveloped woman [<i>ailonit</i>]</b> who will never reach puberty and therefore her legal status is not that of a young woman, receives <b>neither</b> payment of <b>a fine</b> for rape <b>nor</b> payment of a fine for <b>seduction. And one who leaves</b> her husband <b>due to a bad reputation</b> receives <b>neither</b> payment of <b>a fine</b> for rape <b>nor</b> payment of a fine for <b>seduction.</b>
The Gemara elaborates. <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>forbidden relatives, and what is</b> the meaning of <b>secondary forbidden relatives</b> in the context of this <i>baraita</i>? <b>If we say</b> that <b>forbidden relatives</b> means

Daf 36a

<b>actual forbidden relatives</b> prohibited by Torah law, and <b>secondary relatives</b> means, as it does in most cases, relatives prohibited <b>by rabbinic law,</b> that cannot be, for <b>since</b> those secondary relatives <b>are suitable for him</b> to marry and are not prohibited <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>why do they not</b> receive <b>a fine</b> if they are raped or seduced? <b>Rather,</b> the meaning of these terms in this context is different: <b>Forbidden relatives</b> are <b>those</b> for which one is <b>liable</b> to receive a <b>court-imposed death</b> penalty; <b>secondary relatives</b> are <b>those</b> for which one is <b>liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i>,</b> which are relatively less severe than those for which one is executed. <b>However, those liable for</b> violating regular <b>prohibitions</b> receive payment of a <b>fine</b> if they are raped or seduced. <b>And</b> according to <b>whose</b> opinion is the <i>baraita</i> taught? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Shimon HaTimni,</b> who exempts from paying a fine only one who rapes a woman with whom betrothal is ineffective.
<b>Some say</b> that we can explain <b>that forbidden relatives</b> refers to all relatives with whom relations are forbidden by severe prohibitions, both <b>those</b> for which one is <b>liable to death</b> by the <b>court and those</b> for which he is <b>liable to <i>karet</i>,</b> and <b>secondary</b> relatives refers to <b>those</b> relatives with whom one who engages in relations is <b>liable for</b> violating regular <b>prohibitions.</b> According to this approach, <b>whose</b> opinion does this follow? <b>It is</b> that of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya,</b> who maintains that even a woman raped by a man forbidden to her by a regular prohibition is not entitled to the fine, despite the fact that betrothal is effective in that case.
§ The <i>baraita</i> stated: A girl <b>who refuses</b> to remain married to her husband receives <b>neither</b> payment of <b>a fine</b> for rape <b>nor</b> payment of a fine for <b>seduction,</b> because she was married and therefore lost her presumptive status as a virgin. The Gemara infers: But <b>an ordinary minor</b> girl <b>has</b> a fine for rape. If so, in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is the <i>baraita</i> taught? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say: A minor</b> girl <b>has</b> a fine for rape. The Gemara asks: <b>Say the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>A sexually underdeveloped woman [<i>ailonit</i></b>] <b>has neither a fine</b> for rape <b>nor</b> a fine for <b>seduction,</b> as she will not develop the signs of puberty and her legal status is that of a minor until she is twenty, at which point she assumes the status of a grown woman. In that <i>halakha</i>, the <i>baraita</i> <b>comes to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said: A minor</b> girl <b>does not have</b> a <b>fine</b> for rape, <b>and</b> the same is true for <b>this</b> <i>ailonit</i>, who <b>emerged from her</b> status as a <b>minor</b> at the age of twenty <b>to</b> the status of <b>a grown woman,</b> skipping the stage of a young woman. <b>The first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and the latter clause is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And if you say</b> that <b>the entire</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, and with regard to</b> a girl <b>who refuses</b> to remain married Rabbi Meir <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> that not only a minor girl but a young woman may also end her marriage through refusal, and the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a young woman and not to a minor; <b>but does he maintain that</b> opinion? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that he disagrees with Rabbi Yehuda in this matter? It was taught: <b>Until when can a girl refuse</b> to remain married? <b>Until she develops two</b> pubic <b>hairs,</b> signs of puberty rendering her a young woman; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> She can refuse <b>until</b> the area covered by the <b>black</b> pubic hairs <b>is greater than the white</b> skin of the genital area. That occurs approximately six months later, at which point she becomes a grown woman.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara suggests: The <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and with</b> regard to <b>a minor</b> girl, <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who says</b> that a minor girl does not receive payment of a fine for rape, and therefore, an <i>ailonit</i> is not entitled to payment. The Gemara asks: <b>But does he maintain that</b> opinion? <b>But didn’t Rav Yehuda say</b> that <b>Rav said</b> with regard to the mishna below (40b), which states: Any case where there is the right of a father to effect the sale of his daughter as a Hebrew maidservant, i.e., when she is a minor, there is no fine if she is raped, <b>this is the statement of Rabbi Meir? And if it is so</b> that Rabbi Yehuda maintains that opinion, Rav <b>should have</b> said: <b>This is the statement of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda.</b> Rather, <b>this <i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir with regard to one</b> <i>halakha</i>, that there is no fine for the rape of a minor, <b>and disagrees with him with regard to one</b> <i>halakha</i>, that a young woman may conclude her marriage through refusal.
<b>Rafram said:</b> This entire <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, and <b>what is</b> the meaning of the statement: With regard to a girl <b>who refuses,</b> there is neither a fine for rape nor a fine for seduction? It is referring to <b>one who is fit to refuse,</b> i.e., as long as she is a minor she is not entitled to the fine. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if that is the case, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> simply <b>teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a minor.</b> Why teach a simple <i>halakha</i> in so convoluted a manner? The Gemara concludes: Indeed, this is <b>difficult.</b>
§ The <i>baraita</i> stated: <b>An <i>ailonit</i> has neither a fine</b> for rape <b>nor</b> a fine for <b>seduction. And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A deaf-mute, an imbecile, and an <i>ailonit</i> have</b> a <b>fine</b> for rape <b>and they have a claim concerning virginity.</b> If one of these women married with the presumptive status of a virgin and received a corresponding marriage contract, her husband can cause her to lose her marriage contract by claiming that she was not a virgin. The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>And what</b> is the <b>contradiction</b> in <b>this?</b> It can be explained simply: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i>, in which it was taught that the <i>ailonit</i> receives no fine, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir; that</b> <i>baraita</i>, in which it was taught that the <i>ailonit</i> receives a fine, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> The Gemara is puzzled: <b>And</b> as the resolution is so obvious, <b>he who raised</b> the contradiction, <b>why did he raise it?</b> The dispute between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis in this matter is known.
The Gemara answers: He cited this <i>baraita</i> <b>due to the fact that he has another</b> <i>baraita</i> from which <b>to raise as a contradiction to it: A deaf-mute, and an imbecile, and a grown woman, and a woman whose hymen was torn</b> not in the course of sexual relations, <b>do not have a claim concerning virginity,</b> as they do not have the presumptive status of a virgin. However, <b>a blind</b> woman <b>and an <i>ailonit</i> have a claim concerning virginity. Sumakhos says in the name of Rabbi Meir: A blind</b> woman <b>does not have a claim concerning virginity.</b> The <i>baraitot</i> contradict each other with regard to the claim concerning virginity of a deaf-mute and an imbecile.
<b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel,</b> who holds that a woman who, in response to a claim concerning her virginity, is believed if she says that she was raped after her betrothal and therefore does not lose her marriage contract. <b>And that</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who says that a woman is not believed if she makes that claim, and therefore she loses her marriage contract. The Gemara asks: <b>Say that you heard</b> that <b>Rabban Gamliel</b> accepts her contention in a case <b>where she claims</b> that she was raped after the betrothal; however, in a case <b>where she did not claim</b> that that was the case, <b>did you hear</b> that <b>he</b> accepts her contention? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, since Rabban Gamliel said</b> she is <b>believed</b> when she states that she was raped after betrothal, the deaf-mute and the imbecile are also believed even though they are unable to make the claim, as in a cases <b>like that,</b> it <b>is</b> a case of: <b>“Open your mouth for the mute”</b> (Proverbs 31:8). When a person lacks the capacity to proffer the claim on his own, the court makes the claim on her behalf.
§ The <i>baraita</i> stated: <b>A grown woman does not have a claim concerning virginity</b> because of changes as her body matures, her hymen is no longer completely intact. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rav say:</b> The Sages <b>give a grown</b> woman who had relations on her wedding night, <b>the</b> entire <b>first night,</b> during which she may have relations with her husband several times? Any blood seen during that night is attributed to the blood of her hymen, which is ritually pure, and not menstrual blood. Apparently, even a grown woman has her hymen intact.

Daf 36b

The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> he <b>proffers a claim</b> that there was no <b>blood</b> after consummating the marriage, <b>indeed</b> he can cause her to lose her marriage contract with that claim. However, <b>with what are we dealing here</b> in the <i>baraita</i>? We are dealing <b>with</b> one <b>who proffers a claim</b> that he encountered an <b>open entrance,</b> i.e., there was no hymen. As the hymen of an adult woman is no longer completely intact, the claim is of no consequence.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Sumakhos says in the name of Rabbi Meir: A blind</b> woman <b>does not have a claim concerning virginity.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the rationale</b> for the statement <b>of Sumakhos? Rabbi Zeira said: Due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> a blind woman <b>is struck</b> by falling <b>onto the ground,</b> causing her hymen to break. The Gemara asks: <b>All</b> girls tend <b>to be struck</b> by falling onto the ground <b>as well;</b> what is unique about blind girls? The Gemara answers: When <b>all of</b> the other girls fall, they <b>see</b> the blood flow <b>and show</b> it to <b>their mother.</b> The mother would then examine them and discover that her hymen was broken. <b>This</b> blind girl <b>does not see</b> the flow of blood <b>and</b> therefore <b>does not show</b> it too <b>her mother.</b> Due to that possibility, the man who married the blind woman must have considered the likelihood that her hymen is not intact, and therefore he cannot make a claim concerning virginity.
§ The previous <i>baraita</i> concluded: <b>And one who leaves</b> her husband <b>due to a bad reputation has neither a fine</b> for rape <b>nor</b> a fine for <b>seduction.</b> The initial understanding is that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a young betrothed woman who leaves her husband because she committed adultery. The Gemara asks: <b>One who leaves</b> her husband <b>due to a bad reputation is subject to stoning</b> as an adulteress; clearly she is not entitled to the fine. <b>Rav Sheshet said: This is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: One about whom a bad reputation emerged in her youth</b> that she engaged in sexual relations <b>has neither a fine</b> for rape <b>nor</b> a fine for <b>seduction,</b> as the assumption is that she is no longer a virgin.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Conclude from it</b> with regard to <b>this tainted document</b> whose authenticity was compromised that <b>we do not collect</b> a debt <b>with it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If you say that a rumor emerged about it that it is a forged document,</b> and in <b>the corresponding</b> case <b>here,</b> the case of a bad reputation, <b>that a rumor emerged about her that she engaged in</b> promiscuous <b>sexual relations; but didn’t Rava say:</b> If <b>a rumor emerged about</b> a woman <b>in a town</b> as <b>one who engaged in</b> promiscuous <b>sexual relations, one</b> need <b>not be concerned about it?</b> The assumption is that it is insubstantial, as a reputation based on rumor is disregarded.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>that two</b> witnesses <b>came and said: She propositioned us</b> to engage <b>in forbidden</b> relations, and in <b>the corresponding</b> case <b>here</b> with regard to a document, it is a case <b>where two</b> people <b>came and said</b> that <b>he said to us: Forge</b> a document <b>for me.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, there,</b> in the case of the rumor of promiscuity, <b>immoral men are common,</b> and even if they refused her, presumably she found someone willing to engage in relations with her. <b>However, here,</b> with regard to forgery, even <b>if he assumed presumptive status</b> as one seeking a forgery, <b>do all the Jewish people assume presumptive status</b> as forgers? Why is the assumption that the document was forged? The Gemara answers: <b>Here too, since he is</b> actively <b>seeking a forgery, say that</b> he <b>forged</b> the document <b>and wrote</b> it. Even if others are not suspected of cooperating with him, there is suspicion with regard to the document. Therefore, the case of the tainted document and the woman with a bad reputation are comparable.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these</b> are the cases of young women <b>who do not</b> have <b>a fine</b> paid to their fathers when they are raped or seduced: <b>One who has intercourse with a convert or with a captive</b> woman <b>or with a</b> gentile <b>maidservant, who were redeemed, converted, or emancipated</b> when they were <b>more than three years and one day</b> old, as presumably they are no longer virgins. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: A captive</b> woman <b>who was redeemed</b> remains <b>in her</b> state of <b>sanctity even though</b> she is <b>an adult,</b> as it cannot be stated that she certainly engaged in intercourse.
The mishna resumes its list of the cases of young women who are not entitled to a fine when raped or seduced by the following men: In the case of <b>one who engages in intercourse with his daughter, with his daughter’s daughter, with his son’s daughter, with his wife’s daughter, with her son’s daughter,</b> or <b>with her daughter’s daughter; they do not</b> receive payment of <b>a fine.</b> That is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he is liable</b> to receive the <b>death</b> penalty, and <b>that their death</b> penalty is administered by <b>the court, and anyone who is liable</b> to receive the <b>death</b> penalty <b>does not pay money, as it is stated: “And yet no harm follow, he shall be punished”</b> (Exodus 21:22). This verse indicates that if a woman dies and the one who struck her is liable to receive the death penalty, he is exempt from payment.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Dosa said one</b> and the same <b>thing</b> with regard to a captive woman. The statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> is <b>that</b> which <b>we said</b> in the mishna. The statement of <b>Rabbi Dosa</b> is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A captive</b> daughter or wife of a priest, who was redeemed, <b>partakes of <i>teruma</i>;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Dosa.</b> In explanation, <b>Rabbi Dosa said: And what did this Arab</b> who took her captive <b>do to her? And due to</b> the fact <b>that he</b> lasciviously <b>squeezed between her breasts,</b> did he <b>render her unfit</b> to marry into <b>the priesthood?</b> Although he may have taken liberties with her, there is no concern that he had relations with her.
<b>Rabba said: Perhaps that is not so,</b> and their opinions differ. Perhaps <b>Rabbi Yehuda states</b> his opinion <b>only here</b> with regard to payment of a fine, <b>so that</b> the <b>sinner will not profit</b> through exemption from the fine because this girl was taken captive in her youth. <b>However, there,</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i>, <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and she is unfit to marry a priest. <b>Alternatively,</b> there is another distinction between their opinions. Perhaps <b>Rabbi Dosa stated</b> his opinion <b>only there, with regard to <i>teruma</i></b> whose legal status today is <b>by rabbinic</b> law, and therefore he rules leniently. <b>However,</b> with regard to payment of a <b>fine,</b> which is mandated <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and the rapist is exempt from payment based on the principle: The burden of proof is incumbent upon the claimant, and she cannot prove that her captors did not engage in intercourse with her and that she is a virgin.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rabba: <b>And is the rationale</b> for the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda here,</b> in the case of a fine, to ensure <b>that</b> the <b>sinner will not profit? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: A captive</b> woman <b>who was taken captive</b> remains <b>in her</b> state of <b>sanctity</b> with the presumptive status of a virgin? <b>Even</b> if she was in captivity when she was <b>ten years old, her marriage contract is two hundred</b> dinars. <b>And there,</b> in that case, <b>what</b> relevance <b>is there</b> for the rationale: To ensure <b>that</b> the <b>sinner will not profit?</b> That <i>baraita</i> refers to a marriage contract and no transgression is involved. The Gemara answers: <b>There too,</b> Rabbi Yehuda issues the same ruling for a different reason. She receives the marriage contract of a virgin because if she didn’t, <b>perhaps men would refrain and not marry her,</b> due to their suspicion that her captors violated her.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi Yehuda maintain</b> that a captive woman remains <b>in her</b> state of <b>sanctity? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who redeems a captive may marry her,</b> even if he is a priest, but if he <b>testifies</b> that <b>she</b> did not engage in sexual relations while in captivity, <b>he may not marry her? Rabbi Yehuda says: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case, where he redeemed her, <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case, where he testified, <b>he may not marry her,</b> lest she was violated and rendered unfit to marry a priest. The Gemara comments: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>itself is difficult.</b> On the one hand <b>you said: One who redeems a captive may marry her, and then it was taught:</b> If he <b>testifies</b> that <b>she</b> did not engage in sexual relations while in captivity, <b>he may not marry her.</b> Is that to say that <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he</b> also <b>testifies</b> that <b>she</b> was not violated <b>he may not marry her?</b>
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: One who redeems a captive</b> woman <b>and testifies</b> that <b>she</b> was not violated <b>may marry her.</b> However, if he <b>only testifies</b> that <b>she</b> was not violated <b>he may not marry her.</b>
With regard to the apparent contradiction between the two statements of Rabbi Yehuda, the Gemara says: <b>In any case,</b> this <i>baraita</i> is <b>difficult</b> according <b>to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> as contrary to his earlier statement, he states that a captive woman does not retain the presumptive status of a virgin. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> Emend the text and <b>say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case and in <b>that</b> case <b>he may marry her. Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, says: Actually,</b> do not emend the <i>baraita</i> and learn it <b>as it was taught.</b> In the <i>baraita</i>, <b>Rabbi Yehuda spoke to them</b> according <b>to the statement of the Rabbis.</b> According <b>to my</b> opinion, that the presumptive status of a redeemed captive woman is that of a virgin, <b>both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case <b>he may marry her. However,</b> according <b>to your</b> opinion that there is concern lest she was violated, the <i>halakha</i> <b>should be</b> that <b>both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case <b>he may not marry her.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> explain their ruling? They explain: <b>One who redeems a captive</b> woman and <b>testifies</b> that <b>she</b> was not violated <b>may marry her,</b> as <b>a person does not throw</b> away <b>money for nothing.</b> If he paid the ransom to redeem her, he must be certain that she is a virgin. One who <b>only testifies</b> that <b>she</b> was not violated <b>may not marry her, lest he had his eye on her</b> to marry her and is prepared to lie to facilitate that marriage.
<b>Rav Pappa bar Shmuel raised a contradiction before Rav Yosef:</b>

Daf 37a

<b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi Yehuda maintain</b> that a captive woman <b>remains in her</b> state of <b>sanctity? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a female <b>convert who converted and saw</b> the flow of menstrual <b>blood</b> on that same day, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Deeming <b>her</b> impure from the <b>hour</b> that she saw the menstrual flow <b>is sufficient for her.</b> There is no decree of retroactive impurity on objects that she touched earlier, due to the concern that the blood flow might have started earlier. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Her</b> legal status <b>is like</b> that of <b>all</b> of <b>the</b> Jewish <b>women, and she</b> therefore <b>transmits impurity</b> retroactively <b>for a twenty-four hour period</b> following her conversion, or <b>from examination to examination,</b> i.e., from the last time she examined herself.
<b>And</b> a convert <b>is required to wait three months</b> after her conversion before marrying a Jew, due to the concern that she is pregnant, leading to confusion whether the child was conceived before or after her conversion; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei permits her to be betrothed and to be married immediately.</b> Clearly, Rabbi Yehuda is concerned that she engaged in sexual relations prior to her conversion. Rav Yosef <b>said to</b> Rav Pappa bar Shmuel: <b>Are you raising a contradiction</b> from the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a convert to</b> that of <b>a captive</b> woman? <b>A convert does not protect herself</b> from engaging in sexual relations before conversion, whereas <b>a captive protects herself,</b> as she is conscious of the sanctity of the Jewish people and does not want to be violated.
<b>And</b> Rav Pappa bar Shmuel <b>raised a contradiction from</b> one <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a captive to</b> another <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a captive, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The convert, or the captive</b> woman <b>or the</b> gentile <b>maidservant, who were redeemed, converted, or emancipated</b> when they were <b>more than three years and one day</b> old, <b>are required to wait three months</b> before marrying; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei permits</b> these women <b>to be betrothed and to be married immediately.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda is concerned that she engaged in sexual relations prior to her redemption, contradicting his opinion here. Rav Yosef <b>was silent,</b> unable to respond.
Later, Rav Yosef <b>said to him: Have you heard anything with regard to this</b> matter? Rav Pappa bar Shmuel <b>said to him: This</b> is what <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> Rabbi Yehuda is referring to a captive <b>whom</b> witnesses <b>saw engage in intercourse.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what is the rationale</b> for the ruling of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> that she may marry immediately? Shouldn’t he be concerned lest she is pregnant? <b>Rabba said: Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b>a woman who engages in</b> promiscuous <b>sexual relations has relations with</b> a contraceptive <b>resorbent</b> at the entrance of her womb, so <b>that she will not become pregnant.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, a convert</b> uses the resorbent; <b>since it is her intention to convert, she protects herself</b> from pregnancy. <b>A captive too</b> uses the resorbent because <b>she does not know where they are taking her,</b> and she does not want to become pregnant. <b>A maidservant</b> uses the resorbent <b>too, as she heard from her master</b> that he intends to free her, and she seeks to avoid confusion with regard to the lineage of her offspring. <b>However,</b> with regard a maidservant who <b>emerges</b> from slavery <b>with</b> the extraction by her master of her <b>tooth or</b> her <b>eye, what is there to say?</b> She has no advance knowledge that she will be freed and therefore would not take precautions to avoid becoming pregnant, and Rav Sheshet explained that this is a case where she was seen engaging in sexual relations.
<b>And if you say</b> that with regard to <b>any</b> situation that occurs <b>on its own,</b> without advance knowledge, <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> concedes to Rabbi Yehuda and <b>did not say</b> that it is permitted for her to marry immediately, that cannot be so. There is the case of <b>a raped or seduced</b> woman, which happens <b>on its own</b> without advance knowledge, <b>and it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A raped woman and a seduced woman must wait three months</b> before marrying; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda; Rabbi Yosei permits</b> these women <b>to be betrothed and to be married immediately.</b>
<b>Rather, Rabba said:</b> The rationale for the ruling of Rabbi Yosei is not because the woman uses a contraceptive resorbent that she inserts before engaging in relations. Rather, <b>Rabbi Yosei holds: A woman</b> who <b>engages in</b> promiscuous <b>sexual relations turns over</b> at the conclusion of the sexual act so <b>that she will not become pregnant.</b> Therefore, even if she engaged in unplanned sexual relations, she can take steps afterward to prevent unwanted pregnancy. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Yehuda respond to this contention? The Gemara answers: <b>We are concerned lest</b> the semen remain in her womb because <b>she did not turn over properly,</b> and she will become pregnant.
§ The mishna states that one liable to receive the death penalty is exempt from payment, <b>as it is stated: “And yet no harm follow, he shall be punished, etc.”</b> (Exodus 21:22). The Gemara asks: <b>And is this</b> principle <b>derived from here?</b> Actually, <b>it is derived from there:</b> “And to be beaten before his face <b>according to the measure of his iniquity”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:2). From the term: His iniquity, it is inferred: <b>You can hold</b> one who performs one action <b>liable for one iniquity,</b> i.e., punishment for violating one prohibition, <b>but you do not hold him liable for two iniquities,</b> i.e., punishments for violating two prohibitions.
The Gemara answers: <b>One</b> of these derivations, from the verse “And yet no harm follow” is stated <b>with regard to</b> one who performed an action for which he is liable to receive the <b>death</b> penalty <b>and</b> to pay <b>money,</b> and the liability to be executed exempts him from payment. <b>And one</b> of these derivations, from the verse “According to the measure of his iniquity,” is stated <b>with regard to</b> one who performed an action for which he is liable to receive <b>lashes and</b> to pay <b>money,</b> and he receives only one punishment. The Gemara elaborates: <b>And</b> both derivations <b>are necessary, as if</b> the Torah <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>death and money,</b> one would assert that the exemption from payment is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that there is loss of life,</b> the ultimate punishment, leaving no room for additional punishment; <b>however,</b> in the case of <b>lashes and money, where there is no loss of life, say no,</b> there is no exemption and he is flogged and pays.
<b>And if</b> the Torah <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>lashes and money,</b> one would assert that the exemption from payment is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>prohibition</b> that he violated <b>is not severe,</b> as it is punishable by lashes, and for violating a prohibition that is not severe one does not receive two punishments. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>death and money, where</b> the <b>prohibition</b> that he violated <b>is severe, say no,</b> he is not exempt from receiving two punishments. Therefore, it was <b>necessary</b> for the Torah to teach both derivations.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that one <b>is flogged and pays</b> in cases where he violated a prohibition punishable by both, <b>why do I</b> require <b>two</b> derivations teaching that one does not receive the death penalty and pay? The Gemara answers: <b>One</b> derivation is <b>with regard to death and money,</b> exempting one liable to be executed from payment,

Daf 37b

<b>and one</b> derivation is <b>with regard to death and lashes,</b> exempting one liable to be executed from lashes. The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> both verses <b>are necessary, as if</b> the Torah <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>death and monetary</b> payment, one would assert that the exemption from payment is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that we do not administer one</b> punishment <b>to his body and one to his money. However, with regard to death and lashes, that both this,</b> death, <b>and that,</b> lashes, are administered <b>to his body, say it is an extended death</b> penalty <b>and let us administer</b> lashes and then the death penalty <b>to him</b> so that his death will ensue from affliction.
<b>And if</b> the Torah <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>death and lashes,</b> one would assert that the exemption from lashes is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that we do not administer two</b> punishments <b>to his body. However,</b> with regard to <b>death and money, where one</b> is administered <b>to his body and one</b> is administered <b>to his money, say: Let us administer</b> both <b>to him.</b> Therefore, both verses are <b>necessary,</b> to teach that one receives only one punishment in both cases.
The Gemara asks with regard to the verse <b>“And you shall take no ransom for the life of a murderer,</b> who is guilty of death” (Numbers 35:31), which means that one does not take payment from a person sentenced to death, <b>why do I</b> require this verse, if that principle was already derived from another verse? The Gemara explains <b>that the Merciful One says: Do not take money from him and exempt him from</b> the <b>death</b> penalty. Similarly, the following verse: “And <b>you shall take no ransom for him that is fled to his city of refuge”</b> (Numbers 35:32), <b>why do I</b> require this verse? The Gemara explains <b>that the Merciful One says: Do not take money from him and exempt him from exile.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And why do I</b> require <b>two verses</b> to teach the same principle? The Gemara explains: <b>One</b> verse refers <b>to</b> one who killed <b>unwittingly, and one</b> verse refers <b>to</b> one who killed <b>intentionally.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> both verses <b>are necessary, as if</b> the Torah <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>an intentional</b> murderer, one would assert that payment is not accepted <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>prohibition</b> that <b>he</b> violated <b>is severe. However,</b> with regard to <b>an unwitting</b> killer, <b>where</b> the <b>prohibition is not severe, say no,</b> he may pay in lieu of exile. <b>And if</b> the Torah <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>an unwitting</b> killer, one would assert that payment is not accepted <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that there is no loss of life,</b> as the killer is not executed, and therefore, there is no reason to allow payment in lieu of exile. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>an intentional</b> killer, <b>where there is loss of life,</b> as he will be executed, <b>say no,</b> he may pay in lieu of execution. Therefore, both verses are <b>necessary.</b>
The Gemara asks with regard to the following verse: <b>“And no expiation can be made for the land for the blood that is shed therein, but by the blood of him that shed it”</b> (Numbers 35:33), which also indicates that he cannot be exempted by money, <b>why do I</b> require another verse to teach that one cannot absolve himself from the death penalty by means of payment?
The Gemara explains: <b>It is necessary to</b> teach <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the matter of the calf that is beheaded. If a corpse whose murderer is unknown is found between two towns, the elders of the town nearest to the corpse bring a heifer and behead it in a riverbed, after which they pray for atonement for this murder. The <i>baraita</i> states: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that if the calf was beheaded and the murderer was found thereafter,</b> it is derived <b>that one does not exempt him</b> from punishment? It is <b>as it is stated: “And no expiation can be made for the land for the blood that is shed therein,</b> but by the blood of him that shed it” (Numbers 35:32), from which it is inferred: And not by the blood of the calf.
The Gemara asks: What about the following verse, from the conclusion of the chapter of the heifer: The verse <b>“And so shall you put away the innocent blood from your midst”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:9) appears to be teaching the very same <i>halakha</i>, that a murderer must be executed. <b>Why do I</b> need it? The Gemara answers that <b>it is necessary to</b> teach <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> with regard to <b>those executed by sword,</b> e.g., murderers, their execution <b>is</b> administered <b>from the neck,</b> and nowhere else? <b>The verse states: “And so shall you put away the innocent blood from your midst”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:9), <b>likening all spillers of blood to the beheaded calf</b> brought for an unresolved murder. <b>Just as there,</b> the calf is beheaded <b>from the neck, so too, murderers</b> are beheaded <b>from the neck.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, just as there,</b> in the case of the beheaded calf, it is beheaded <b>with a cleaver [<i>kofitz</i>] and at the nape of the neck, here too</b> the court executes murderers <b>with a cleaver and at the nape of the neck. Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said</b> that <b>the verse says: “And you shall love your neighbor as yourself”</b> (Leviticus 19:18), from which it is derived: <b>Choose for him an agreeable death.</b> It is prohibited to abuse a guilty person while executing him, and chopping off his head with a cleaver is an unseemly death. The murderer is beheaded from the neck, not with a cleaver, and not by the other methods employed in beheading the calf.
The Gemara asks with regard to the following verse: <b>“Anything dedicated [<i>ḥerem</i>], that may be dedicated of men, shall not be redeemed;</b> he shall surely be put to death” (Leviticus 27:29), which is interpreted here as: Anyone sentenced to be executed shall not be redeemed; this appears to teach the same <i>halakha</i> as above, so <b>why do I need</b> it? The Gemara explains: <b>It is necessary</b> to teach <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to</b> one <b>taken to be executed, and one</b> person <b>said: His valuation is upon me</b> to donate to the Temple, <b>that he did not say anything</b> and his vow is not binding?
It is derived <b>as it is stated: “Anything dedicated [<i>ḥerem</i>], that may be dedicated of men [<i>yoḥoram</i>], shall not be redeemed”</b> (Leviticus 27:29). This verse is taken to mean that anything dedicated, through which a man who is condemned [<i>yoḥoram</i>] is valuated, shall not be redeemed, as the person in question is already considered dead. One <b>might</b> think that <b>even before his verdict</b> is issued this should be <b>so,</b> and that one who said: The valuation of so-and-so on trial for murder is upon me, said nothing of consequence. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “That may be dedicated <b>of men,”</b> implying “of men,” <b>but not entire men.</b> If it is valuation of an entire man, one not yet sentenced to death, it is binding. If it is valuation of a partial man, one sentenced to death, it is not binding.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya,</b> who <b>said</b> that even a person taken to his execution <b>is valuated,</b> and the vow is binding, <b>because</b> the <b>money</b> of <b>his</b> valuation <b>is fixed.</b> The sum of the valuation established in the Torah is not based on the worth of the individual; rather, there is a fixed sum determined by age and gender. Therefore, one may be valuated as long as he is alive. According to that opinion, the question remains with regard to <b>this</b> verse: <b>“Anything dedicated,” what does</b> he derive from <b>it?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>He requires it</b> to teach <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: Because we found with regard to those executed at the hand of Heaven,</b> and not through court-administered execution, <b>that they give money and their</b> sins <b>are atoned, as it is stated:</b> “The ox shall be stoned, and its owner shall also be put to death. <b>If there be laid upon him a ransom</b> then he shall give for the redemption of his life whatsoever is laid upon him” (Exodus 21:29–30). One whose ox kills a person is essentially liable to receive the death penalty at the hand of Heaven, and pays money instead. You <b>might</b> think that <b>even</b> with regard to those liable to receive the death penalty <b>at the hands of man</b> it is <b>so,</b> and one can pay in lieu of execution. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Dedicated of men shall not be redeemed”</b> (Leviticus 27:29). One who is executed by man cannot be redeemed with money.
<b>And I have</b> derived this restriction <b>only</b> with regard to prohibitions punishable by <b>severe</b> penalties of <b>death,</b> e.g., striking one’s father, <b>for which no atonement is designated</b> in the Torah <b>for their unwitting</b> violation. However, with regard to prohibitions punishable by <b>less severe</b> penalties of <b>death,</b> e.g., performing labor on Shabbat, <b>for which atonement,</b> a sin-offering, <b>is designated</b> in the Torah <b>for their unwitting</b> violation, <b>from where</b> is it derived that there is no payment in lieu of execution? <b>The verse states: “Anything dedicated,”</b> to include all prohibitions punishable by court-administered execution.
The Gemara asks: <b>And didn’t you incidentally learn</b> the following conclusion <b>from</b> the verse <b>“And you shall take no ransom</b> for the life of a murderer, who is guilty of death” (Numbers 35:31): <b>Do not take money from him and exempt him</b> from death? <b>Why,</b> then, <b>do I</b> require the phrase: <b>Any <i>ḥerem</i>? Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> It is <b>necessary,</b> as <b>it might enter your mind to say</b>

Daf 38a

<b>this</b> principle, that one cannot pay in lieu of execution, <b>applies only when one</b> intentionally <b>killed him in an upward motion, for which no atonement is designated</b> in the Torah <b>for its unwitting</b> performance. <b>However,</b> with regard to one who intentionally <b>killed him in a downward motion, for which atonement,</b> i.e., exile, <b>is designated</b> in the Torah <b>for its unwitting</b> performance, <b>say: Let us take money from him and exempt him.</b> Therefore, the phrase “any <i>ḥerem</i>” <b>teaches us</b> that even in that case there is no payment in lieu of execution.
<b>Rava said to him: That</b> principle <b>is derived</b> from that which the Sage <b>of the school of Ḥizkiyya taught, as</b> the Sage <b>of the school of Ḥizkiyya taught:</b> The verse juxtaposes the cases of <b>one who smites a person, and one who smites an animal</b> (Leviticus 24:21).
<b>Just as in</b> the case of one <b>who smites an animal, you did not distinguish between</b> one who did so <b>unwittingly and</b> one who did so <b>intentionally; between</b> one who acted <b>with intent and one who</b> acted <b>with no intent; between</b> one who smites <b>in</b> the course of <b>a downward motion and</b> one who smites <b>in</b> the course of <b>an upward motion;</b> and in all those cases it is not <b>to exempt</b> him from paying <b>money but rather to obligate him to</b> pay <b>money; so too in</b> the case of one <b>who smites a person: Do not distinguish between</b> one who did so <b>unwittingly and</b> one who did so <b>intentionally; between</b> one who acted <b>with intent and one who</b> acted <b>with no intent; between</b> one who smites <b>in</b> the course of <b>a downward motion and</b> one who smites <b>in</b> the course of <b>an upward motion;</b> and in all those cases it is not <b>to obligate him</b> to pay <b>money but rather to exempt him</b> from paying <b>money.</b> Apparently, one who kills another in any manner is exempt from payment, and therefore no additional verse is required to derive that principle.
<b>Rather, Rami bar Ḥama said</b> that the phrase “any <i>ḥerem</i>” (Leviticus 27:29) is <b>necessary, as it might enter your mind to say</b> that <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>, that one who is liable to be executed is exempt from payment, <b>applies only</b> in a case <b>where one blinded</b> another’s <b>eye and killed him with</b> that same blow. <b>However,</b> in a case <b>where one blinded</b> another’s <b>eye and killed him by</b> means of a <b>different</b> blow, <b>say: Let us take money from him</b> to pay the damage inflicted to the eye. Therefore, the verse teaches that this is not the case. <b>Rava said to him: This</b> case of one who blinded another’s eye and killed him <b>is also derived from</b> that which <b>another <i>tanna</i></b> of <b>the school of Ḥizkiyya</b> taught, <b>as</b> the Sage <b>of the school of Ḥizkiyya taught</b> that the verse states: <b>“An eye for an eye”</b> (Exodus 21:24), from which it may be inferred, <b>but not an eye and a life for an eye.</b> When he gives his life for killing another while blinding him, he need not pay the worth of the eye as well.
<b>Rather,</b> after the Gemara rejected the above explanations, <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The phrase “any <i>ḥerem</i>” is nonetheless <b>necessary,</b> as <b>it might enter your mind to say: Since it is a novel element that the Torah introduced with regard to</b> the payment of <b>a fine,</b> which is not payment for any damage caused but is a Torah decree, in that case, <b>even though he is killed he pays</b> the fine. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that one who is executed is exempt from payment of the fine. The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabba, who said</b> that this is indeed the <i>halakha</i>: Since <b>it is a novel element that the Torah introduced with regard to</b> the payment of <b>a fine, even though he is killed he pays</b> the fine, <b>what does</b> he <b>do with this</b> phrase: <b>“Any <i>ḥerem</i>”?</b> The Gemara answers: Rabba <b>holds</b> with regard <b>to</b> this matter <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> who disagrees with <b>Rabbi Ḥananya ben Akavya</b> and explains that the phrase “Any <i>ḥerem</i>” teaches that the vow one takes to donate the valuation of one being taken to his execution is not binding.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a young woman who was betrothed and divorced,</b> and then raped, <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: She does not</b> receive payment of a <b>fine</b> for her rape. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: She</b> receives payment of a <b>fine</b> for her rape <b>and her fine</b> is paid <b>to herself,</b> not her father, as since she was betrothed and divorced she is no longer subject to her father’s authority.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What is the rationale</b> for the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili?</b> It is as <b>the verse states:</b> “If a man finds a young woman who is a virgin <b>who was not betrothed”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:28), from which it may be inferred: If <b>she was betrothed she does not have</b> a <b>fine</b> for rape. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> explain this verse? The Gemara answers that the verse states: If it is a young woman <b>who was not betrothed,</b> the fine is paid <b>to her father,</b> from which it may be inferred: If <b>she was betrothed,</b> the fine is paid <b>to</b> the betrothed woman <b>herself.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But if</b> that is <b>so,</b> that the inference from the verse is that the fine is levied on one who rapes <b>a young woman and not</b> on one who rapes <b>a grown woman, so too,</b> there is the <i>halakha</i> in the latter case that the fine is paid <b>to</b> the grown woman <b>herself.</b> Similarly, with regard to the inference that the fine is levied on one who rapes <b>a virgin and not</b> on one who rapes <b>a non-virgin, so too,</b> there is the <i>halakha</i> that in the latter case the fine is paid <b>to</b> the non-virgin <b>herself.</b> A distinction of that kind has never been encountered. <b>Rather,</b> with regard to a grown woman and a non-virgin, the rapist is <b>completely</b> exempt from paying the fine; <b>here too,</b> with regard to a betrothed woman, the rapist is <b>completely</b> exempt from paying the fine.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> could have <b>said to you</b> that <b>this</b> verse: <b>“Who was not betrothed,” is required by him</b> to teach another <i>halakha</i> <b>that is taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>. <b>“Who was not betrothed”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:28) comes to <b>exclude a young woman who was betrothed and divorced</b> and establish <b>that she does not</b> receive payment of a <b>fine</b> for her rape; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Rabbi Akiva says: She</b> receives payment of a <b>fine</b> for her rape, <b>and her fine</b> goes <b>to her father,</b> contrary to the ruling attributed to Rabbi Akiva in the mishna. <b>And</b> ostensibly, no verse is required to derive this <i>halakha</i>, as <b>logic dictates</b> that it is so: <b>Since her father is entitled to the money of her betrothal</b> if she is betrothed before she becomes a grown woman, <b>and</b> likewise <b>her father is entitled to the money of her fine; just as the money of her</b> subsequent <b>betrothal</b> as a young woman, <b>even though she was betrothed and divorced,</b> is paid <b>to her father, so too, the money of her fine, although she was betrothed and divorced,</b> is paid <b>to her father.</b>
<b>If so,</b> and the <i>halakha</i> can be logically inferred, <b>why does the verse state: “Who was not betrothed”?</b> This verse is <b>free,</b> as it is superfluous in its own context, <b>and</b> it is written <b>to liken</b> another case to it, <b>and to derive from it a verbal analogy: It is stated here</b> with regard to a woman who was raped: <b>“Who was not betrothed,” and it is stated below:</b> “And if a man seduce a virgin <b>who was not betrothed”</b> (Exodus 22:15). <b>Just as here,</b> with regard to rape, the Torah specifies that the payment is <b>fifty</b> silver pieces (Deuteronomy 22:29), <b>so too below,</b> with regard to seduction, the payment is <b>fifty. And just as below,</b> with regard to seduction, the payment is in <b>shekels,</b> as it is written: “He shall weigh [<i>yishkol</i>] money” (Exodus 22:16), <b>so too here,</b> the payment is in <b>shekels.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Akiva, what did you see</b> that led you to utilize the phrase: <b>“Who was not betrothed” for a verbal analogy, and</b> the term <b>“virgin” to exclude a non-virgin</b> from the fine?

Daf 38b

<b>Say</b> to the contrary; the term <b>“virgin,”</b> written with regard to both rape and seduction, is <b>to</b> derive <b>a verbal analogy,</b> and not to exclude a non-virgin, <b>and</b> the phrase <b>“Who was not betrothed”</b> will be interpreted as Rabbi Yosei HaGelili interpreted it, to <b>exclude a young woman who was betrothed and divorced.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>It stands to reason</b> that the phrase <b>“Who was not betrothed”</b> is utilized <b>to</b> derive <b>a verbal analogy,</b> and not to exclude one who was betrothed and divorced, <b>as</b> even after the divorce <b>I can</b> still <b>read</b> the phrase <b>“A young woman who is a virgin”</b> as applying <b>to her.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>On the contrary,</b> utilize the term <b>virgin to</b> derive <b>a verbal analogy, as</b> even if she is not a virgin, <b>I can</b> still <b>read</b> the phrase <b>“Who was not betrothed”</b> as applying <b>to her.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It stands to reason</b> that the term “virgin” excludes a non-virgin, and the phrase “Who was not betrothed” is utilized to derive a verbal analogy, as <b>this</b> woman who engaged in relations, <b>her body changed, and that</b> woman who was betrothed and divorced, <b>her body did not change,</b> and therefore her status with regard to the fine should similarly not change.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where</b> does <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili</b> derive <b>this conclusion</b> with regard to the amount of the payment for seduction and the type of money used in the payment for rape? The Gemara responds: <b>He derives it from that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that it is written with regard to seduction: <b>“He shall weigh money like the dowry of the virgins”</b> (Exodus 22:16), from which it is derived <b>that this</b> fine for seduction <b>will be like the dowry</b> paid <b>to the virgins</b> elsewhere for rape, fifty silver coins, <b>and the dowry</b> paid <b>to the virgins</b> for rape <b>will be like this</b> fine for seduction in shekels.
§ The Gemara comments: It is <b>difficult</b> as there is a contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Akiva</b> and another statement <b>of Rabbi Akiva.</b> In the mishna he ruled that the fine for the rape of a young woman who was betrothed and divorced is paid to the woman, and in the <i>baraita</i> he ruled that it is paid to her father. The Gemara answers: These are conflicting traditions of <b>two <i>tanna’im</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b>
The Gemara observes: <b>Granted,</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Akiva of the mishna</b> is reasonable, as <b>a verbal analogy does not come and divert the verse from its plain meaning entirely.</b> The plain meaning of the phrase: “Who was not betrothed” is that there is a difference between a young woman who was betrothed, who receives payment of the fine, and one who was not, whose father receives payment of the fine. <b>However,</b> according <b>to Rabbi Akiva of the <i>baraita</i>,</b> does <b>a verbal analogy come and divert the verse from its plain meaning entirely,</b> and teach that there is no difference at all between a young woman who was betrothed and one who was not?
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Interpret the verse</b> as: <b>Who is not betrothed.</b> It does not mean that the young woman was not betrothed in the past, rather, that she is not currently betrothed. The Gemara asks: There is no need for a verse to derive that the rapist is exempt from paying a fine if the young woman is betrothed, as the rape of <b>a betrothed</b> young woman <b>is</b> punishable <b>by stoning,</b> and the rapist is certainly exempt from paying the fine. The Gemara answers: As <b>it might enter your mind to say: Since it is a novel element that the Torah introduced with regard to</b> the payment of <b>a fine, even though he is killed he pays</b> the fine. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that one who is executed is exempt from payment of the fine.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabba, who said</b> that this is indeed the <i>halakha</i>: Since <b>it is a novel element that the Torah introduced with regard to</b> the payment of <b>a fine, even though he is killed he pays</b> the fine, <b>what is there to say?</b> What is derived from the verse that says that there is no fine if the young woman is betrothed? The Gemara answers: Rabba <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva of the mishna,</b> who interpreted the verse as it is written, meaning that it is referring to one who was betrothed and divorced.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to a young woman who was raped, <b>to whom</b> is <b>her fine</b> paid? It is paid <b>to her father; and some say:</b> It is paid <b>to her.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>To her? Why?</b> The verse explicitly states that the fine is paid to her father. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Here we are dealing with a young woman who was betrothed and divorced, and</b> these <i>tanna’im</i> in the <i>baraita</i> <b>disagree in the dispute between Rabbi Akiva of the mishna and Rabbi Akiva of the <i>baraita</i>,</b> with regard to whom the rapist pays the fine in that case.
§ <b>Abaye said:</b> If <b>one had intercourse with</b> a young woman, <b>and she died</b> before he was sentenced, he is <b>exempt</b> from paying the fine, <b>as it is stated: “And</b> the man who lay with her <b>shall give to the father of the young woman”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29), from which it is inferred, <b>and not to the father of a dead</b> girl. The Gemara comments: This <b>matter that</b> was <b>obvious to Abaye</b> was <b>raised as a dilemma to Rava.</b>
<b>As Rava raised a dilemma: Is there</b> achievement of <b>grown-woman status in the grave or is there not</b> achievement of <b>grown-woman status in the grave?</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that if a young woman is raped and the rapist did not pay the fine until she became a grown woman, the rapist pays the fine to her and not to her father. Rava’s dilemma is in a case where a young woman dies and her rapist was convicted only after the time elapsed that were she alive she would have reached grown-woman status. <b>Is there</b> achievement of <b>grown-woman status in the grave, and</b> therefore she is entitled to the fine and <b>it is</b> the property of <b>her son</b> as his mother’s heir? <b>Or perhaps there is no</b> achievement of <b>grown-woman status in the grave, and the fine is</b> the property of <b>her father,</b> as she was a young woman when she died.

Daf 39a

Rava’s dilemma is based on the assumption that a rape victim is able to conceive before she is a grown woman. The Gemara asks: <b>And can</b> a minor <b>conceive? But didn’t Rav Beivai teach</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Naḥman:</b> It is permitted for <b>three women</b> to <b>engage in relations with a</b> contraceptive <b>resorbent. These are they: A minor, and a pregnant woman, and a nursing woman.</b> The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: <b>A minor</b> may do so <b>lest she conceive and die; a pregnant</b> woman, <b>lest her</b> existing <b>fetus</b> be crushed by another fetus and <b>assume</b> the shape of <b>a sandal</b> fish if she conceives a second time; and <b>a nursing</b> woman, <b>lest</b> she conceive, causing her milk to spoil, which will lead <b>her</b> to <b>wean her son</b> prematurely, endangering his health.
<b>And</b> the <i>baraita</i> further states: <b>What is a minor girl?</b> A minor girl is a girl <b>from eleven years and one day old until twelve years and one day old.</b> If she was <b>less than that</b> age or <b>more than that</b> age, <b>she proceeds and engages in relations in her usual manner;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: Both this</b> woman <b>and that</b> woman, i.e., in the cases of all these women, <b>she proceeds and engages in relations in her usual manner, and from Heaven they will have mercy</b> and prevent any mishap, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it is stated: “The Lord preserves the simple”</b> (Psalms 116:6). Apparently, a minor is unable to conceive.
<b>And if you say that she conceived when she was a young woman,</b> twelve years old, <b>and gave birth when she was a young woman,</b> and died before she reached the status of a grown woman, can a woman <b>give birth in six months</b> after conception? <b>But didn’t Shmuel say: There are only six months between</b> becoming <b>a young woman and</b> becoming <b>a grown woman? And if you say</b> that Shmuel is saying that it is <b>less</b> than six months <b>that there is not</b> transition from young woman to grown woman status; however, <b>more</b> than six months <b>there is</b> transition, as different women develop differently, and therefore she could conceive and give birth while she is a young woman, that is not so, <b>as</b> Shmuel <b>said: Only,</b> indicating that the period is neither less nor more than six months.
<b>Rather,</b> Rava’s dilemma is unrelated to whether or not her son inherits the fine payment. <b>This is his dilemma: Is there</b> achievement of <b>grown-woman status in the grave and</b> therefore the right of the <b>father</b> to receive payment of the fine <b>lapsed;</b> and since there is no one claiming the payment, the rapist need not pay? <b>Or perhaps there is no</b> achievement of <b>grown-woman</b> status <b>in the grave, and</b> the right of the <b>father did not lapse. Mar bar Rav Ashi raised the dilemma</b> in <b>this</b> manner: Does <b>death effect grown-woman status or does it not effect grown-woman status?</b> No resolution was found for this dilemma, and the Gemara concludes that the dilemma <b>stands</b> unresolved.
On a similar note, <b>Rava inquired of Abaye:</b> If he forcibly <b>had intercourse with</b> a young woman <b>and she was</b> later <b>betrothed, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Abaye <b>said to him: Is it written: And he shall give to the father of the young woman who is not betrothed?</b> Actually it is written: “If a man finds a young woman…who was not betrothed” (Deuteronomy 22:28), which indicates that the determining factor is whether she was betrothed before the rape and not whether she is engaged at the moment of payment. Rava asked him: <b>And according to your reasoning, that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If he forcibly <b>had intercourse</b> with a young woman <b>and she</b> later <b>married,</b> the fine is paid <b>to her,</b> not to her father. There too, ask: <b>Is it written: And he shall give to the father of the young woman who is not married?</b> Even though the verse does not address the moment of payment, if she married the fine is paid to her.
Abaye retorted: <b>How can</b> these cases be <b>compared? There,</b> in the case of marriage, there is reason to diverge from the plain meaning of the verse, <b>as grown-woman status removes her from</b> the <b>authority of the father and marriage removes her from</b> the <b>authority of the father. Just as</b> with regard to <b>grown-woman status,</b> if he forcibly <b>had intercourse with her and she became a grown woman,</b> the fine is paid <b>to her,</b> as it is written: “And he shall give to the father of the young woman” (Deuteronomy 22:29); <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>marriage,</b> if he forcibly <b>had intercourse with her and she</b> later <b>married,</b> the fine is paid <b>to her. However,</b> with regard to <b>betrothal, does</b> it <b>remove</b> her <b>from</b> the <b>authority of the father entirely? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Nedarim</i> 66b): With regard to <b>a betrothed young woman, her father and her husband</b> together <b>nullify her vows?</b> Apparently, betrothal does not remove her entirely from her father’s authority, and therefore, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to betrothal cannot be derived from the <i>halakha</i> with regard to grown-woman status. Therefore, Rava’s question is not difficult.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The seducer gives</b> the father of his victim <b>three things, and the rapist</b> gives the father <b>four.</b> The mishna specifies: <b>The seducer gives</b> the father payments for <b>humiliation, degradation, and</b> the <b>fine. A rapist adds</b> an addition to <b>his</b> payments, <b>as he</b> also <b>gives</b> payment for the <b>pain. What</b> are the differences <b>between</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a rapist and</b> that of <b>a seducer? The rapist gives</b> payment for <b>the pain, and the seducer does not give</b> payment for <b>the pain. The rapist gives</b> payment <b>immediately, and the seducer</b> does not pay those payments immediately but only <b>when he releases</b> her. <b>The rapist drinks from his vessel [<i>atzitzo</i>],</b> i.e., marries the woman he raped, perforce, <b>and the seducer, if he wishes to release</b> her, <b>he releases</b> her.
The mishna clarifies: <b>How does</b> the rapist <b>drink from his vessel? Even if</b> the woman he raped <b>is lame, even if she is blind, and even if she is afflicted with boils,</b> he is obligated to marry her and may not divorce her. However, if <b>a matter of licentiousness is found in her,</b> e.g., if she committed adultery, <b>or if she is unfit to enter the Jewish people,</b> e.g., if she is a <i>mamzeret</i>, <b>he is not permitted to sustain her</b> as his wife, <b>as it is stated: “And to him she shall be as a wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29), from which it is inferred that she must be <b>a woman who is</b> legally <b>suitable for him.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna taught that a rapist pays for the pain that he caused. The Gemara asks: <b>For what pain</b> is he obligated to pay? <b>Shmuel’s father said:</b> It is for the <b>pain that</b> he caused when <b>he slammed her onto the ground</b> while raping her. <b>Rabbi Zeira</b> strongly <b>objects to this: But if</b> what you say is <b>so,</b> if <b>he slammed her onto silk, so too</b> is the <i>halakha</i> <b>that</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from payment for pain? <b>And if you say indeed</b> that it is <b>so, but isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon: A rapist does not pay</b> for <b>the pain due to</b> the fact

Daf 39b

<b>that she will ultimately suffer</b> the same pain during intercourse when <b>under</b> the authority of <b>her husband? They said to him: One who has intercourse against</b> her <b>will is not comparable to one who has intercourse willingly.</b> Apparently, the pain associated with rape is a direct result of the forced intercourse and not of some associated cause. <b>Rather, Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> It refers to the <b>pain of spreading</b> her <b>legs</b> during intercourse. <b>And likewise,</b> the verse <b>says: “And you opened your legs to every passerby”</b> (Ezekiel 16:25).
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, a seduced woman</b> should <b>also</b> be obligated to make that payment as well. <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh stated a parable: To what can</b> this <b>matter</b> of a seducer <b>be compared?</b> It can be compared <b>to a person who said to another: Tear my silk and be exempt</b> from payment. Since she engaged in relations of her own volition, she certainly absolved him of payment for the pain. The Gemara asks: Tear <b>my</b> silk? It is not her silk, and therefore she may not waive payment for damage to it; <b>it is</b> the silk <b>of her father,</b> as the fine and the other payments are paid to him. <b>Rather, Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said</b> that <b>the clever</b> women <b>among them say</b> that <b>a seduced woman has no pain</b> during intercourse, as she is a willing participant.
The Gemara asks: <b>But don’t we see that</b> even a married woman <b>has</b> pain when she engages in sexual relations for the first time? <b>Abaye said: My</b> foster <b>mother told me</b> that the pain is <b>like hot water on the head of a bald</b> man. <b>Rava said:</b> My wife, <b>Rav Ḥisda’s daughter, told me</b> that it is <b>like the stab of a bloodletting knife. Rav Pappa said:</b> My wife, <b>Abba Sura’s daughter, told me</b> that it is <b>like</b> the feeling of <b>hard bread on the gums.</b> When a woman engages in intercourse willingly, the pain is negligible. Therefore, the seducer is not obligated to pay for pain.
§ The mishna continues: <b>The rapist gives</b> payment <b>immediately, and the seducer when he releases her, etc.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>When he releases</b> her? Is <b>she his wife?</b> He did not yet marry her, so how can the mishna use the language of divorce? <b>Abaye said: Say</b> that he gives payment <b>when</b> he opts <b>not</b> to <b>marry</b> her. If he marries her he need not pay. <b>That</b> opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Although they said</b> that <b>the seducer gives</b> the fine <b>when</b> he opts <b>not</b> to <b>marry</b> her, the compensation for her <b>humiliation and degradation he gives immediately.</b> The <i>baraita</i> continues: Although <b>both the rapist and the seducer</b> are obligated to marry their victim, <b>both she and her father are able to prevent</b> the marriage.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to <b>a woman who was seduced, it is written: “If her father refuses [<i>maen yemaen</i>]</b> to give her to him” (Exodus 22:16), and the Sages interpreted: <b>I have only</b> derived that <b>her father</b> can prevent the marriage; <b>from where do we</b> derive that <b>she herself</b> can do so? <b>The verse states:</b> <i>Maen <b>yemaen</b></i><b>,</b> a double verb indicating that the marriage can be prevented <b>in any case,</b> i.e., she too may do so.
<b>However,</b> from where is it derived that they can prevent the marriage in the case of <b>a rapist? Granted, she</b> herself can prevent the marriage, as <b>it is written: “And to him she shall be</b> as a wife” (Deuteronomy 22:29), and the term “shall be” indicates <b>with her consent. However, from where do we</b> derive that <b>her father</b> can prevent the marriage?
<b>Abaye said:</b> No verse is necessary as it stands to reason that the father too can prevent the marriage <b>so that a sinner will not profit.</b> If her father could not prevent the marriage, the rapist would acquire the right to marry the young woman despite the father’s refusal, a right not accorded to one who seeks to betroth a young woman in a conventional manner. <b>Rava said</b> it is derived through <b>an <i>a fortiori</i> inference: Just as</b> in the case of <b>a seducer, who contravened only her father’s will,</b> as she acquiesced to his proposition, nevertheless <b>both she and her father can prevent</b> the marriage; in the case of <b>a rapist, who contravened</b> both <b>her father’s will and her own will, all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> so that both she and her father can prevent the marriage?
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rava did not say in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Abaye,</b> as <b>since</b> the rapist <b>pays the fine he is not a sinner</b> who <b>profits,</b> as he too must pay the dowry of a virgin even if he marries her. Likewise, <b>Abaye did not say in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rava</b> because in the case of <b>a seducer, where</b> the seducer himself <b>can prevent</b> the marriage, <b>her father can also prevent</b> the marriage. In the case of <b>a rapist, where</b> the rapist himself <b>cannot prevent</b> the marriage, <b>her father also cannot prevent</b> the marriage.
<b>It was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>Although</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that <b>the rapist gives</b> payment <b>immediately, when he releases</b> her <b>she has no</b> claim <b>upon him.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>When he releases</b> her? <b>Can he release her?</b> It is prohibited by Torah law for him to do so. Rather, emend the <i>baraita</i> and <b>say: When she leaves,</b> if she seeks to divorce him and demands a bill of divorce, <b>she has no</b> monetary claim <b>upon him.</b> Similarly, if <b>he died,</b> the <b>money of her fine offsets her marriage contract.</b> The fine, which was the equivalent of the dowry of virgins, replaces her marriage contract. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> Even a rape victim <b>has a marriage contract</b> of <b>one hundred dinars,</b> like the marriage contract of all non-virgin wives.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>The Rabbis maintain: What is the reason</b> that <b>the Sages instituted a marriage contract</b> for the woman? They instituted it <b>so that she will not be inconsequential in his eyes,</b> enabling him <b>to</b> easily <b>divorce her.</b> Because divorcing her will cost money, he will not do so rashly. <b>And this</b> woman whom he raped, <b>he cannot release her</b> by Torah law, obviating the need for a marriage contract. <b>And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, maintains:</b> With regard to <b>this</b> woman <b>too,</b> although he cannot divorce her, he can <b>torment her until she says: I do not want you.</b> When she initiates the divorce, he can divorce her. Therefore, the Sages instituted that she receives the marriage contract of a non-virgin to prevent him from doing so.
The mishna continues: <b>A rapist drinks from his vessel,</b> and the seducer is not obligated to marry the woman he seduced. <b>Rava from Parzakya said to Rav Ashi: Since</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of a rapist and a seducer <b>are derived from each other</b> with regard to the sum of the fine,

Daf 40a

<b>for this matter too,</b> marrying the woman against his will, <b>let them be derived from each other.</b> Rav Ashi replied that <b>the verse says</b> with regard to a seducer: <b>“He shall pay a dowry for her to be a wife to him”</b> (Exodus 22:15); <b>“to him”</b> means <b>in accordance with his will.</b>
§ The mishna continues: <b>How does</b> the rapist <b>drink from his vessel?</b> The mishna proceeds to explain that he is obligated to marry her despite the physical flaws she might have. However, if the marriage is prohibited, either due to the fact that she committed adultery or due to her flawed lineage, he is not obligated to marry her, and therefore he may not marry her. <b>Rav Kahana said: I stated</b> this <b><i>halakha</i> before Rav Zevid of Neharde’a,</b> and I asked him: Let the <b>positive</b> mitzva: “And to him she shall be as a wife” (Deuteronomy 22:29), <b>come and override</b> the <b>prohibition</b> of marriage to a woman who is forbidden to him, according to the principle that positive mitzvot override prohibitions.
<b>He said to me: Where do we say</b> the principle that <b>a positive</b> mitzva <b>comes and overrides a prohibition?</b> It is in a case <b>where</b> one performs <b>circumcision</b> of a foreskin afflicted <b>with leprosy.</b> Although there is a prohibition against removing leprous skin, the positive mitzva of circumcision overrides that prohibition, <b>as it is not possible to fulfill the positive</b> mitzva without violating the prohibition. <b>However, here,</b> in the case of the rapist, <b>if</b> she <b>says: I do not want him</b> as a husband, <b>is there a positive</b> mitzva <b>at all?</b> Since in that case the mitzva need not be performed, as it is negated when the woman refuses to marry him, it does not override the prohibition.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>an orphan who was betrothed and divorced, Rabbi Elazar says: One who rapes</b> her <b>is obligated</b> to pay the fine, as she is a virgin young woman, <b>and one who seduces her is exempt</b> from payment. Because she is an orphan, or because she was betrothed and divorced, she is independent, and by consenting to the seduction she forgoes her right to the fine.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Rabbi Elazar stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, his teacher, as</b> with regard to a young woman who was betrothed and divorced and then raped, Rabbi Akiva <b>said</b> in an earlier mishna: <b>She is entitled to</b> a <b>fine</b> for rape <b>and her fine</b> is paid <b>to her.</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: She is not entitled to a fine for rape. <b>And from where</b> do we know that Rabbi Elazar’s opinion corresponds to the opinion of his teacher? <b>From</b> the fact <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> with regard to <b>an orphan</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: One who rapes</b> her <b>is obligated</b> to pay the fine <b>and one who seduces</b> her <b>is exempt</b> from payment.
The Gemara asks: <b>An orphan?</b> That is <b>obvious,</b> as she has no father and is not subject to the authority of anyone else.
