Clearly the seducer is exempt from payment because she was complicit. <b>Rather, this</b> is what the mishna is <b>teaching us: That</b> the legal status of <b>a young woman who was betrothed and divorced,</b> even if her father is alive, is <b>like</b> that of <b>an orphan: Just as</b> with regard to <b>an orphan,</b> payment of the fine is <b>to her, so too,</b> with regard to <b>a young woman who was betrothed and divorced,</b> payment of the fine is <b>to her.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Sheila said</b> that <b>Rav Hamnuna the Elder said</b> that <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said</b> that <b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar. Rav</b> would <b>exclaim about Rabbi Elazar:</b> He is the <b>happiest of the Sages,</b> as he held that the <i>halakha</i> was ruled in accordance with his opinion in many instances.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>What is humiliation?</b> How is the payment for humiliation during rape or seduction assessed? It is <b>all based on the one who humiliated and the one who was humiliated.</b> The price will vary depending on the lineage of the family of the rape victim and the nature of the attacker. How is her <b>degradation</b> assessed? <b>One considers her as though she were a maidservant sold in the marketplace,</b> and assesses <b>how much she was worth</b> beforehand <b>and how much she is</b> currently <b>worth,</b> after the rape or seduction. The sum of the <b>fine is equal for all people, and</b> the principle is: <b>Any</b> payment <b>that has a fixed</b> sum <b>by Torah law is equal for all people,</b> regardless of the lineage and the physical state of the attacker or the victim.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> that <b>the Merciful One said</b> that the payment is <b>fifty <i>sela</i> from all</b> these <b>matters,</b> i.e., the fine, degradation, humiliation, and pain. <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> That cannot be, as <b>they will say:</b> If <b>one who engaged in forced intercourse with a daughter of kings</b> pays a sum of <b>fifty</b> <i>sela</i>, does <b>one who engaged in forced intercourse with the daughter of commoners [<i>hedyotot</i>]</b> also pay <b>fifty</b> <i>sela</i>? <b>Abaye said to him:</b> This is not a decisive argument, as <b>if so, with regard to a</b> Canaanite <b>slave</b> killed by an ox, the Torah says that the owner of the ox pays the master of the slave thirty <i>sela</i>. There too, <b>they will say:</b> For <b>a slave who pierces</b> precious <b>pearls [<i>margaliyyot</i>],</b> a valuable skill, the fine is <b>thirty</b> <i>sela</i>, and for <b>a slave who performs</b>

Daf 40b

the <b>needlecraft</b> of a tailor, a common, less valuable skill, is the fine also <b>thirty</b> <i>sela</i>? Rather, just as with regard to the slaves, the sum is not dependent on the standing of the victim, so too with regard to a woman who was raped.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Zeira said</b> a different proof: <b>Had two</b> men <b>engaged in forced intercourse with her, one vaginal intercourse, and one anal intercourse, they will say:</b> If one who <b>engaged in forced intercourse</b> with <b>an untainted</b> virgin pays <b>fifty</b> <i>sela</i>, does one who <b>engaged in forced intercourse</b> with her when she is <b>tainted,</b> i.e., after she has engaged in anal intercourse, also pay <b>fifty</b> <i>sela</i>? Apparently, the fifty <i>sela</i> is the fixed sum of the fine, while the rest of the payment varies on a case-by-case basis. <b>Abaye said to him:</b> This too is no proof, as <b>if so, with regard to a slave as well, they will say</b> if one whose ox gored <b>a healthy slave</b> pays <b>thirty</b> <i>sela</i>, does one whose ox gored <b>a slave afflicted with boils</b> also pay <b>thirty</b> <i>sela</i>?
<b>Rather, Abaye said</b> a different proof. <b>The verse says:</b> “Fifty shekels of silver…<b>because he tormented her”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29); <b>these</b> fifty <i>sela</i> are the fine paid <b>because he tormented her.</b> From which it <b>may be inferred that there are</b> the additional payments of <b>humiliation and degradation</b> beyond that sum mentioned in the verse. <b>Rava said</b> an alternative proof. <b>The verse says: “And the man who lay with her shall give to the father of the young woman fifty shekels of silver”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29). For <b>the pleasure of lying</b> with her he pays <b>fifty</b> <i>sela</i>; from which it <b>may be inferred that there are</b> the additional payments of <b>humiliation and degradation,</b> beyond payment of the fine.
The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> that these additional payments are paid <b>to her?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>the verse says:</b> “Between a father and his daughter, <b>being in her young womanhood, in her father’s house”</b> (Numbers 30:17), from which it is derived that <b>all profits</b> of <b>her young womanhood</b> go <b>to her father.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>that</b> which <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the handiwork of the daughter</b> goes <b>to her father?</b> It is <b>as it is stated: “And if a man sells his daughter as a maidservant”</b> (Exodus 21:7), juxtaposing his daughter to a maidservant: <b>Just as a maidservant, her handiwork</b> belongs <b>to her master,</b> as she was sold for that purpose; <b>so too a daughter, her handiwork</b> goes <b>to her father. Why do I</b> need this complicated proof? <b>Let him derive it</b> directly from the verse <b>“Being in her young womanhood, in her father’s house.” Rather,</b> this cannot be derived from that verse because <b>that</b> verse <b>is written with regard to the nullification of vows.</b> A young woman is subject to her father’s authority with regard to her vows, which he has the right to nullify. The matter of monetary rights is not addressed in that verse.
<b>And if you say: Let us derive</b> monetary matters <b>from</b> vows, i.e., just as she is subject to her father’s authority with regard to vows the same is true with regard to monetary matters, <b>we do not derive monetary</b> matters <b>from ritual</b> matters. <b>And if you say: Let us derive</b> that her father receives payment <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a fine,</b> i.e., just as the fine is paid to her father, as explicitly stated in the Torah, so too, other payments are also paid to her father, <b>we do not derive monetary</b> matters <b>from fines.</b> The payment of a fine is a novel element decreed by the Torah and cannot serve as a paradigm for standard monetary matters. <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains that <b>it is reasonable that</b> the payments of humiliation and degradation are paid <b>to her father, as if he wished</b> to do so he could <b>give her</b> hand in marriage <b>to a repulsive</b> man <b>or one afflicted with boils,</b> thereby humiliating her. Since her humiliation is under his control, payment for her humiliation is similarly his.
The mishna continues: How is her <b>degradation</b> assessed? <b>One considers her as though she were a maidservant sold</b> in the marketplace, and assesses how much she would have been worth beforehand and how much she would be worth currently. The Gemara asks: <b>How do we assess her</b> value? <b>Shmuel’s father said: One estimates</b> the difference <b>between how much a person is willing to give</b> to purchase <b>a virgin maidservant and</b> how much he is willing to give <b>to</b> purchase <b>a non-virgin maidservant to serve him.</b>
The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>a non-virgin maidservant to serve him;</b> if he purchases her for service, <b>what difference is there to him</b> whether or not she is a virgin? <b>Rather,</b> the difference <b>between a maidservant who engaged in intercourse and a maidservant who did not engage in intercourse</b> is with regard to how much one is willing <b>to marry her to his slave.</b> The Gemara further asks: <b>And</b> with regard to marrying her <b>to his slave, what difference is there to him</b> whether or not she is a virgin? The Gemara answers: It is <b>with regard to a slave from whom his master has</b> a sense of <b>satisfaction,</b> and he seeks a virgin for the slave in order to reciprocate. The difference between the price that the master is willing to pay for each of the maidservants is the degradation that the offender pays the victim.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Any place where there is sale</b> by a father of his minor daughter as a Hebrew maidservant, <b>there is no fine</b> if she is raped. <b>And any place where there is a fine,</b> when a young woman is raped; <b>there is no sale</b> by the father. The Gemara specifies: <b>A minor is subject to sale</b> by her father, <b>and she is not entitled to a fine</b> if she is raped. <b>A young woman is entitled to a fine</b> if she is raped <b>and is not subject to sale. A grown woman is neither subject to sale nor entitled to a fine.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: This</b> <i>halakha</i> in the mishna is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir, but the Rabbis say: She is entitled to a fine</b> even <b>where</b> there is <b>a sale, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A minor</b> girl, <b>from one day old until she grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs, is subject to sale and is not entitled to a fine. From when she grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs</b> and becomes a young woman <b>until she matures</b> into a grown woman, <b>she is entitled to a fine and she is not subject to sale;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir, as Rabbi Meir would state</b> the principle: <b>Any place where there is a sale there is no fine, and any place where there is a fine there is no sale. And the Rabbis say: A minor</b> girl <b>from the age of three years and one day until she matures</b> into a grown woman <b>is entitled to a fine.</b>
The Gemara questions the statement of the Rabbis in the <i>baraita</i> with regard to a girl more than three years of age: <b>A fine, yes, but sale, no?</b> Do the Rabbis maintain that a father cannot sell his minor daughter as a Hebrew maidservant? Rather, emend the text and <b>say:</b> She <b>is even entitled to a fine where</b> she is subject to <b>sale. Rav Ḥisda said: What is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir?</b> It is as <b>the verse says</b> with regard to a rapist: “And the man who lay with her shall give to the father of the young woman fifty <i>sela</i>, <b>and to him she shall be as a wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29). <b>The verse is speaking with regard to one</b> halakhically competent to <b>marry</b> by <b>herself,</b> which means she must be a young woman. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what is the rationale for the opinion of <b>the Rabbis? Reish Lakish said</b> that <b>the verse says “young woman [<i>na’ara</i>]”;</b> however, although the term is pronounced <i>na’ara</i>, it is written as <i>na’ar</i>, without the letter <i>heh</i>, and <b>even a minor girl is indicated</b> by that term.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Pappa, son</b> of <b>Rav Ḥanan, from</b> a place called <b>Bei Keloḥit, heard</b> this <i>halakha</i> and <b>went and said it before Rav Shimi bar Ashi.</b> Rav Shimi <b>said to him: You teach this</b> statement <b>concerning that</b> matter. <b>We,</b> based on our traditions, <b>teach it concerning this</b> matter, as <b>Reish Lakish said: One who slanders a minor girl,</b> falsely claiming that she was not a virgin on the wedding night, <b>is exempt</b> from paying the fine, <b>as it is stated: “And they shall give them to the father of the young woman [<i>na’ara</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:19). <b>The verse spoke of <i>na’ara</i>,</b> not only pronounced but written <b>in full,</b> indicating that this payment is in effect only with regard to a young woman, not a minor girl. However, in places where the term is written <i>na’ar</i>, even a minor girl would be included.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava</b> strongly <b>objects to this: The reason is that the Merciful One writes “<i>na’ara</i>”</b> with a <i>heh</i>. Is that to say that <b>if that were not the case I would have said that</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even</b> to <b>a minor girl?</b> How is that possible? <b>But isn’t it written: “And if this matter was true, that the hymen of this young woman was not found intact; then they shall remove the young woman to the entrance of her father’s house and stone her”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:20–21). <b>And</b> this verse clearly refers to a young woman old enough to be punished, as <b>a minor is not subject to punishment. Rather, here,</b> with regard to the payment of a slanderer, the verse speaks of <b>a <i>na’ara</i>,</b> written with a <i>heh</i>, and a minor is excluded. This is a paradigm from which <b>it may be inferred</b> that in any place <b>that it is stated “<i>na’ara</i>”</b> without a <i>heh</i>, <b>even a minor girl is indicated.</b>

Daf 41a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who says: I seduced the daughter of so-and-so, pays</b> compensation for <b>humiliation and degradation</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission, <b>but does not pay</b> the <b>fine.</b> Similarly, <b>one who says: I stole, pays the principal,</b> the value of the stolen goods, <b>based on his own</b> admission, <b>but does not pay</b> the <b>double payment and</b> the <b>payment four and five</b> times the principal for the slaughter or sale of the sheep or ox that he stole. Likewise if he confessed: <b>My ox killed so-and-so, or:</b> My ox killed <b>an ox</b> belonging to <b>so-and-so, this</b> owner <b>pays</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission. However, if he said: <b>My ox killed a slave</b> belonging to <b>so-and-so, he does not pay</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission as that payment is a fine. <b>This is the principle: Anyone who pays more than what he damaged,</b> the payments are fines and therefore <b>he does not pay</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission. He pays only based on the testimony of others.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to one who said: <b>I raped</b> the daughter of so-and-so. Why did the mishna cite the case of seduction? The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> <b>is speaking</b> employing the style: <b>It is not necessary. It is not necessary</b> for the mishna to cite the case of one who says: <b>I raped</b> her, <b>where he does not tarnish her</b> reputation and merely incriminates himself, as it is obvious that <b>he pays</b> compensation for <b>humiliation and degradation</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission. <b>However,</b> in the case of one who says: <b>I seduced</b> her, <b>where he tarnishes her</b> reputation as he testifies that she willingly engaged in relations with him, and he is not deemed credible to do so, <b>say</b> that <b>he does not pay</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that even in the case of seduction he pays compensation for humiliation and degradation based on his own admission.
The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon: Even</b> the payments of <b>humiliation and degradation, he does not pay</b> them based <b>on his own</b> admission as <b>it is not within his power to tarnish</b> the reputation of <b>the daughter of so-and-so</b> based merely on his confession. Consequently, unless his account is corroborated by the testimony of others, his admission that she was complicit in her seduction is rejected.
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye:</b> According to Rabbi Shimon, if <b>she herself is amenable</b> to his claim, and admits that his version of the events is accurate, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is he exempt from payments of humiliation and degradation in that case as well? Abaye responded: <b>Perhaps her father is not amenable</b> to his daughter’s reputation being tarnished. We therefore do not rely on his statement even in this case. Rav Pappa continued: If <b>her father is</b> also <b>amenable</b> to his claim, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Abaye responded: <b>Perhaps her</b> other <b>family members are not amenable,</b> as the reputation of the entire family would be tarnished. Rav Pappa asked: If the <b>family members</b> too are <b>amenable, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Abaye answered: Even if all the local relatives are amenable, <b>it is impossible that there</b> will <b>not</b> be at least <b>one</b> relative <b>in a country overseas who is not amenable</b> to his claim.
The mishna continues. <b>One who says: I stole, pays the principal,</b> but does not pay the double payment and the payment four and five times the principal. <b>It is stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to the payment of <b>half the damage</b> that the owner of an innocuous ox, which was not yet witnessed goring a person or an ox three times, must pay to the owner of the ox that he gored. <b>Rav Pappa said: Half the damage</b> is considered a payment of <b>money,</b> compensation for the damage caused. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said</b> that <b>half the damage</b> is considered payment of a <b>fine.</b>
The Gemara elaborates. <b>Rav Pappa said: Half the damage</b> is considered a payment of <b>money,</b> as <b>he maintains: Standard oxen do not exist in the presumptive status of safety,</b> and therefore are likely to cause damage. <b>And by right,</b> the owner <b>should pay the entire</b> damage caused by his animal, <b>and it is the Merciful One that has compassion on him, as his ox is not yet forewarned</b> until it has gored a person or an animal three times. Fundamentally, the payment is for damage that the animal caused. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said</b> that <b>half the damage</b> is payment of a <b>fine,</b> as <b>he maintains: Standard oxen exist in the presumptive status of safety,</b> and are not dangerous. <b>And by right,</b> the owner <b>should not pay at all,</b> as the ox goring could not have been anticipated, and therefore the owner bears no responsibility. <b>And it is the Merciful One that penalized him so that he would guard his ox.</b> The sum that he pays is a fine.
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the proofs cited with regard to this dispute: <b>Damaged; what; and killed; principle. We learned</b> in a mishna that if an innocuous ox gored and killed another’s ox, both <b>the damaged and the damager</b> share <b>in the payments. Granted, according to the one who said</b> that <b>half the damage</b> is a payment of <b>money; that</b> is how the <b>damaged party shares in the payments.</b> By right, the owner of the dead ox should be compensated for his entire loss. However, since the ox that gored his ox was innocuous, the owner of the gored ox bears half the costs. The mishna characterizes him as sharing in the payments. <b>However, according to he who said</b> that <b>half the damage</b> is payment of <b>a fine,</b> by right, the injured party himself is entitled to nothing. <b>Now,</b> the owner <b>takes</b> half the damage <b>that</b> by right <b>is not his;</b> can <b>he</b> be characterized as sharing <b>in the payments?</b>
The Gemara answers: This <i>halakha</i> is <b>necessary only for the degradation of the carcass.</b> Initially, half the damage is assessed by calculating the difference between the value of a living ox and the value of its carcass when the owner of the ox that gored the other ox stands trial. The degradation in the value of the carcass from when it was gored until the owner is able to sell it is borne by the owner of the carcass. The owner thereby shares in the payment, as he loses that sum. The Gemara asks: <b>We</b> already <b>learned</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the degradation of the carcass</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in <i>Bava Kamma</i> (10b) in which it is taught that the passage in the mishna: I have become liable to pay <b>payments of damage, teaches that the owners tend to the carcass</b> and bear the costs of its degradation.
The Gemara answers: <b>One</b> of these <i>halakhot</i> is <b>with regard to an innocuous</b> ox <b>and one</b> is <b>with regard to a forewarned</b> ox. The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach both <i>halakhot</i>, <b>as if</b> the mishna <b>had taught us</b> only with regard to <b>an innocuous</b> ox, one would understand that its owner is treated with leniency and the owner of the carcass bears the cost of degradation <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the ox <b>has not yet been forewarned; however,</b> with regard to <b>a forewarned</b> ox, <b>that was forewarned, say no,</b> the owner of the carcass does not bear the cost of degradation. <b>And if</b> the mishna <b>had taught us</b> only with regard to <b>a forewarned</b> ox, one would understand that its owner is treated with leniency and the owner of the carcass bears the cost of degradation <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that he pays</b> for the <b>entire damage,</b> and therefore, the relatively insignificant cost of degradation is overlooked. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>an innocuous</b> ox, <b>say no,</b> since the owner pays only half the damage, he must bear the cost of degradation. Therefore, it was <b>necessary</b> to state the <i>halakha</i> in both cases. Therefore, there is no proof from this mishna whether half the damage is payment of money or payment of a fine.
The Gemara continues. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an additional proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between an innocuous and a forewarned</b> ox? The difference is <b>that</b> the owner of <b>an innocuous</b> ox <b>pays half</b> of the <b>damage from its body.</b> Compensation for the damage may be collected only from the body of the ox that gored another ox. If the ox that gored another ox is worth less than half the damage, e.g., if an inexpensive ox killed an expensive one, the injured party receives less than half the damage. <b>And</b> the owner of <b>a forewarned</b> ox <b>pays the entire damage from the</b> owner’s <b>property,</b> and the value of the ox that gored another ox has no effect on the payment. The <i>tanna</i> <b>did not teach</b> an additional difference that the owner of <b>an innocuous</b> ox <b>does not pay</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission <b>and</b> the owner of <b>a forewarned</b> ox <b>pays</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission. Apparently, the half damage is a payment of money and not a fine.
The Gemara refutes this claim: This <i>baraita</i> is no proof, as the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> some cases <b>and omitted</b> others and did not list all the differences between innocuous and forewarned oxen. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> else <b>did he omit that he omitted this?</b> The failure to include an item in a list can be deemed insignificant only if it is one of at least two omissions. If there is only one omission, apparently it was omitted advisedly. The Gemara replies: <b>He omitted</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>half ransom</b> as well. If a forewarned ox killed a person, its owner pays a ransom, and if an innocuous ox killed a person, the owner does not pay even half the ransom. The Gemara rejects this claim: <b>If</b> it is <b>due to</b> the <b>half ransom</b> that the failure to list the difference with regard to payment based on one’s own admission is insignificant, it <b>is not an omission.</b>

Daf 41b

As it can be explained: According to <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i> taught? <b>It is</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who said:</b> The owner of <b>an innocuous</b> ox <b>pays half</b> the <b>ransom.</b> According to his opinion, the only differences between innocuous and forewarned oxen are those specified in the mishna.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an additional proof from the mishna. One who said: <b>My ox killed so-and-so, or:</b> My ox killed <b>an ox</b> belonging to <b>so-and-so, this</b> owner <b>pays</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission. <b>What, is</b> this <b>not</b> referring <b>to an innocuous</b> ox, for which he pays half the damage, proving that it is a payment of money and not a fine? The Gemara rejects the proof: <b>No,</b> the <i>tanna</i> is referring <b>to a forewarned</b> animal.
The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> in the case <b>of an innocuous</b> ox, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? If it is that <b>he does not pay</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission, then, <b>rather than teaching the latter clause</b> of the mishna: One whose ox <b>killed a slave</b> belonging to <b>so-and-so does not pay</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission, <b>let him distinguish and teach</b> the distinction <b>within the case itself: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is <b>with regard to a forewarned</b> ox; <b>however,</b> the owner of <b>an innocuous</b> ox <b>does not pay</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission. The Gemara rejects this proof: The <b>entire</b> mishna <b>is speaking of a forewarned</b> ox, and does not address the <i>halakha</i> of an innocuous ox at all. Therefore, no proof can be cited with regard to the nature of half the payment.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an additional proof from the mishna: <b>This is the principle: Anyone who pays more than what he damaged,</b> the payments are fines, and therefore <b>he does not pay</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission. The Gemara infers: If he pays <b>less than what he damaged, he pays</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission. Apparently, payment of half the damage is a payment of money, not a fine. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Do not</b> infer and <b>say:</b> If he pays <b>less than what he damaged,</b> he pays based on his own admission. Infer and <b>say:</b> If he pays precisely <b>what he damaged, he pays</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to that explanation, if he pays <b>less</b> than the damage he caused, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? If it is that <b>he does not pay</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> a more general principle: <b>This is the principle: Anyone who does not pay</b> the amount <b>that he damaged does not pay</b> based <b>on his own</b> admission, <b>as</b> that formulation both <b>indicates</b> one who pays <b>less and indicates</b> one who pays <b>more</b> than the damage he inflicted. The Gemara concludes: This is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, that payment of half the damage is a fine.
The Gemara further concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that payment of <b>half the damage</b> is <b>a fine.</b> The Gemara asks: Is there <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, <b>and</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is in accordance with that opinion? The Gemara responds: <b>Yes,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his opinion, as, <b>what is the reason</b> that his opinion <b>was conclusively refuted?</b> It is <b>because</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>does not teach:</b> This is the principle: Anyone who does not pay the amount <b>that he damaged.</b> However, the reason the <i>tanna</i> did not employ that formulation <b>is not clear-cut for him, since there is</b> the payment of <b>half</b> the <b>damage</b> caused by <b>pebbles</b> dispersed by an animal proceeding in its usual manner. <b>As it is a <i>halakha</i> transmitted</b> to Moses from Sinai <b>that</b> the payment for pebbles <b>is a monetary</b> payment, not a fine; it is <b>due to that</b> fact that the <i>tanna</i> <b>did not teach</b> the principle: Anyone who does not pay the amount that he damaged does not pay based on his own admission. In the case of pebbles, although he does not pay the amount that he damaged, he pays based on his own admission.
Based on that ruling, the Gemara concludes: <b>And now that you said</b> that payment of <b>half the damage</b> is <b>a fine, this dog that ate lambs, and a cat that ate large roosters, is unusual</b> damage, for which the owner is liable to pay only half the damage if the animal was innocuous, <b>and</b> therefore, <b>we do not collect</b> it <b>in Babylonia.</b> The payment for unusual damage is a fine, and fines cannot be collected in Babylonia, as there are no ordained judges authorized to adjudicate cases involving fines. <b>However,</b> if the cat ate <b>small</b> roosters, that <b>is its usual manner, and we collect</b> the damages in Babylonia, as it is a payment of money.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> in cases of fines, <b>if</b> the injured party <b>seized</b> property from the offender in the amount of the fine, even in Babylonia <b>we do not repossess it from him,</b> as according to the letter of the law he is entitled to that payment, and the party from whom he seized the property cannot claim that he does not owe that payment. <b>And if</b> the injured party <b>said: Set me a time</b> to go <b>to</b> a court <b>in Eretz Yisrael,</b> where cases of fines are adjudicated, <b>we set</b> a time <b>for him, and if</b> the other disputant <b>does not go</b> to Israel as demanded, <b>we excommunicate him.</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>Either way,</b> whether or not he agrees to go to Eretz Yisrael, if he keeps the cause of the damage, <b>we</b> in Babylonia <b>excommunicate him, as we say to him: Remove your</b> cause of <b>damage,</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a person may not raise a vicious dog in his house, and may not place an unsteady ladder in his house?</b> It is <b>as it is stated:</b> “And you shall make a parapet for your roof <b>that you shall not place blood in your house”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:8). It is prohibited to leave a potentially dangerous object in one’s house, and one who refuses to remove it is excommunicated.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a young woman who was seduced,</b> the compensation for <b>her humiliation and her degradation and her fine</b> belong <b>to her father. And</b> the same applies to the compensation for <b>pain in</b> the case of a woman who was <b>raped.</b> If the young woman <b>stood trial</b> against the seducer or rapist <b>before the father died, these</b> payments belong <b>to her father,</b> as stated above. If <b>the father died</b> before he collected the money from the offender, the payments belong <b>to</b> her <b>brothers.</b> As the father’s heirs, they inherit the money to which he was entitled before he passed away.
However, if <b>she did not manage to stand in judgment before the father died,</b> and she was subsequently awarded the money, the compensation belongs <b>to her,</b> as she is now under her own jurisdiction due to the fact that she no longer has a father. If <b>she stood trial before she reached majority,</b> the payments belong <b>to her father,</b> and if <b>the father died, they</b> belong <b>to</b> her <b>brothers,</b> who inherit the money notwithstanding the fact that she has become a grown woman since the trial. If <b>she did not manage to stand in judgment before she reached majority,</b> the money belongs <b>to her. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> Even <b>if</b> she stood trial in her father’s lifetime but <b>did not manage to collect</b> the payments <b>before the father died,</b> the brothers do not inherit this money, as it belongs <b>to her.</b>

Daf 42a

By contrast, with regard to <b>her earnings and</b> the lost <b>items</b> that <b>she</b> has <b>found, although she has not collected</b> them, e.g., she had yet to receive her wages, if <b>the father died they</b> belong <b>to</b> her <b>brothers.</b> These payments are considered the property of their father, as he was entitled to them before he passed away.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the mishna <b>teaching us? We</b> already <b>learned</b> this in a mishna (<i>Ketubot</i> 39a): <b>The seducer pays three types of indemnity and the rapist</b> pays <b>four. The seducer pays</b> compensation for his victim’s <b>humiliation and degradation and</b> for the <b>fine</b> the Torah imposes on a seducer. <b>A rapist adds an additional</b> payment, <b>as he pays</b> compensation for <b>the pain</b> she suffered. The Gemara answers: It <b>is necessary for</b> the mishna to teach that the money is given <b>to her father.</b> The Gemara asks: It <b>is also obvious</b> that the money goes <b>to her father, from</b> the fact <b>that a seducer pays</b> these types of indemnity, <b>as, if</b> one claims that the money goes <b>to her, why does a seducer pay</b> her at all? After all, <b>he acted with her consent;</b> how can she then claim compensation?
The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary for</b> the mishna to mention these cases in order to address the case where she <b>stood for judgment</b> before her father died, and then he died before collecting payment. In this case, there is <b>a dispute between Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis</b> as to whether the sons inherit these payments from the father or whether the money belongs to the young woman.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Shevuot</i> 36b) that if someone said to another: <b>You raped</b> my daughter, <b>or: You seduced my daughter, and</b> the other <b>says: I did not rape and I did not seduce,</b> to which the father replied: <b>I administer an oath to you, and</b> the defendant <b>said: Amen, and afterward he admitted</b> that he had raped or seduced the man’s daughter, he is <b>obligated</b> both in the payments of a rapist or a seducer as well as an additional one-fifth, and he must bring an offering for swearing falsely that he did not owe the money.
<b>Rabbi Shimon exempts</b> him, <b>as he does not pay</b> the <b>fine on his own</b> admission. The accused individual is not considered to have taken a false oath in denial of a monetary charge because he would not have been obligated to pay the fine on the basis of his own admission of guilt. The Rabbis <b>said to him: Although he does not pay</b> the <b>fine on his own</b> admission, <b>indeed he does pay</b> compensation for <b>the humiliation and degradation on his own</b> admission. Consequently, he has denied a monetary claim, and therefore his false oath obligates him to add one-fifth and to bring an offering. This concludes the mishna.
In light of this mishna, <b>Abaye raised a dilemma before Rabba:</b> With regard to <b>one who says to another: You raped</b> my daughter, <b>or: You seduced my daughter, and I made you stand in judgment</b> for your actions, <b>and you were found obligated</b> to pay <b>me money</b> but you did not do so, <b>and</b> the defendant <b>says: I did not rape, or: I did not seduce, and you did not make me stand in judgment, and I was not found obligated</b> to pay <b>you money, and</b> the defendant <b>took an oath</b> that he was telling the truth <b>and</b> subsequently <b>admitted</b> his guilt, <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>?
Abaye explains the two sides of the dilemma: <b>Since he stood trial</b> and was found liable, <b>is</b> this considered a regular <b>monetary</b> obligation, <b>and</b> therefore <b>he is liable to</b> bring the <b>offering</b> for taking a false <b>oath</b> to deny a monetary claim? <b>Or perhaps</b> one can argue that <b>although he stood trial</b> and the court ordered him to pay, the payment <b>is</b> in essence <b>a fine.</b> Rabba <b>said to him:</b> Since he has already stood trial, <b>it is</b> considered a regular <b>monetary</b> payment, <b>and he is liable to</b> bring the <b>offering of an oath.</b>
Abaye <b>raised an objection to</b> Rabba from the following <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that in the case of <b>one who says to another: You raped</b> my daughter, <b>or: You seduced my daughter, and he says: I did not rape</b> her, <b>or: I did not seduce</b> her, or if he claimed: <b>Your ox killed my slave, and he says:</b> It <b>did not kill</b> him, <b>or if his slave said to him: You knocked out my tooth, or: You blinded my eye</b> and you are therefore obligated to emancipate me, <b>and he says: I did not knock</b> it <b>out, or: I did not blind</b> your eye, <b>and he takes an oath but</b> later <b>admitted</b> to the truth of the accusation, one <b>might</b> have thought that he <b>should be liable</b> to bring an offering for a false oath denying a monetary claim.
Therefore, with regard to the offering for a false oath in denial of a monetary claim, <b>the verse states:</b> “If anyone sin, and commit a trespass against the Lord <b>and deal falsely with his neighbor in a matter of a deposit or of a pledge or of a robbery or have oppressed his neighbor, or have found that which was lost and deal falsely with it, and swear to a lie”</b> (Leviticus 5:21–22). <b>Just as</b> all these <b>matters</b> listed in the verse <b>are unique</b> in <b>that they are monetary</b> obligations equal in value to the loss one has caused another individual, <b>so too,</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>all</b> obligations <b>that are monetary</b> claims, which <b>excludes these</b> payments of a rapist, a seducer, and the like, <b>as they are fines.</b>

Daf 42b

<b>What, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where he has stood trial,</b> and yet Rabbi Shimon does not render him liable for the oath as the payment was originally a fine? Rabba refutes this argument: <b>No,</b> that <i>baraita</i> is referring to a situation <b>where he has not stood trial.</b>
Abaye persists: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> deals <b>with</b> one <b>who has stood trial,</b> it follows that the <b>latter clause also</b> deals <b>with</b> one <b>who has stood trial. As</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> in its <b>first clause: I have</b> derived the <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> for <b>matters for which one pays the principal.</b> With regard to <b>the payments</b> that are <b>double</b> the principal, and <b>payments</b> that are <b>four and five</b> times the principal, and those of <b>the rapist, and the seducer, and the defamer, from where</b> is it derived that all these are included in the liability to bring an offering for falsely taking an oath on a deposit? <b>The verse states:</b> “If anyone sin <b>and commit a trespass [<i>ma’ala ma’al</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 5:21). The doubled usage of the word trespass serves to <b>amplify</b> and include any false oath taken in denial of monetary liability.
Abaye analyzes this statement: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> this is referring to a situation <b>when he has not stood trial, is there double</b> payment in that case? Everyone agrees that one who admits his guilt is exempt from the double payment, and yet this obligation is mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rather,</b> it <b>is obvious</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> it is claimed that he has already <b>stood trial</b> and was declared liable to pay the double payment, and the accused individual denies this claim. Abaye summarizes his question: <b>And from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>first clause</b> of this <i>baraita</i> deals <b>with</b> one <b>who has stood trial,</b> the <b>latter clause also</b> deals <b>with</b> one <b>who has stood trial,</b> and even so Rabbi Shimon does not deem him liable to bring an offering for his oath.
Rabba <b>said to him: I could answer you</b> that the <b>first clause</b> deals <b>with</b> one <b>who</b> is accused of already having <b>stood trial</b> and been deemed liable, <b>and</b> the <b>latter clause</b> deals <b>with</b> one <b>who has not stood trial, and</b> this <b>entire</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> According to this answer, Rabbi Shimon concedes that after one has been deemed liable in court, the double payment attains the status of a regular monetary obligation rather than a fine, and therefore in the first case in the <i>baraita</i> he is liable to bring an offering and a payment for his admission. <b>But I will not answer you a far-fetched answer, for if</b> it is <b>so,</b> that the entire <i>baraita</i> represents the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, <b>you</b> could <b>say to me: Let</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> either <b>teach</b> explicitly in the <b>first clause: Rabbi Shimon says, or let him teach</b> in the <b>latter clause:</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon.</b>
Rabba continued: <b>Rather,</b> I will say that the <b>entire</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> one <b>who has stood trial, and</b> as for the difference in <i>halakha</i>, the <b>first clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who deem one liable to bring the offering of an oath in a case where the plaintiff says that the defendant stood trial, was found liable, and swore falsely. <b>And</b> the <b>latter clause</b> represents the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who exempts one who confesses from bringing the offering of an oath.
<b>And I concede to you,</b> Abaye, <b>with regard to</b> the liability to bring <b>an offering</b> for falsely taking <b>an oath</b> on a deposit, <b>that the Merciful One exempts him</b> from this offering here, <b>based upon</b> the verse <b>“And deal falsely</b> with his neighbor in a matter of a deposit,” (Leviticus 5:21), which indicates that one is liable to bring an offering only if he lied about a claim that was originally a monetary obligation.
<b>And when I say</b> that Rabbi Shimon maintains that after one is declared liable in court his obligation to pay <b>is</b> considered a regular <b>monetary</b> payment rather than a fine, that is not to say that he is liable to bring an offering for falsely denying a monetary claim, but rather <b>to</b> say that the recipient of the payment <b>bequeaths it to his sons.</b> Unlike a fine, which does not pass by inheritance to one’s heirs, this is classified as a regular monetary payment. Consequently, if the perpetrator was deemed liable in court and ordered to pay the father of the girl he raped or seduced, and the father died before receiving payment, his sons inherit the right to that payment.
Abaye <b>raised an objection to</b> this last point from the mishna. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: If</b> the daughter <b>did not manage to collect</b> the payments <b>before the father died, they</b> belong <b>to her. And if you say</b> that this fine <b>is a monetary</b> payment <b>to</b> the extent that one can <b>bequeath it to his sons</b> after the trial, <b>why</b> does the money belong <b>to her?</b> Since the trial has taken place, it <b>should be</b> the property of <b>the brothers</b> by inheritance from their father, as it is already considered a regular monetary obligation that is owed to the father.
<b>Rava said: This matter was difficult for Rabba and Rav Yosef</b> for <b>twenty-two years without resolution, until Rav Yosef sat at the head</b> of the academy <b>and resolved it</b> in the following manner: <b>There,</b> in the case of a rape, <b>it is different, as the verse states: “And the man who laid with her shall give the young woman’s father fifty shekels of silver”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29), from which it is inferred: <b>The Torah entitled the father</b> to this money <b>only from the time of giving.</b> Consequently, if the father dies before receiving the money, he does not bequeath his right to the money to his sons. Instead, the daughter is considered to take her father’s place as the plaintiff, because she was the victim, and the money is paid to her.
<b>And when Rabba said</b> that the fine imposed by a court <b>is</b> considered a regular <b>monetary obligation</b> with regard to one’s ability <b>to bequeath it to his sons,</b> he was not referring to this particular case of a rapist or seducer, but only <b>to other fines,</b> which do have the status of regular monetary obligations after the court delivers its verdict.
The Gemara asks: <b>However, if</b> that is <b>so,</b> that the verb “give” is explained in this manner, <b>with regard to</b> an ox that killed <b>a slave, where it is written: “He shall give to their master thirty shekels of silver”</b> (Exodus 21:32), <b>so too</b> will you say that <b>the Torah entitled the master only from the time of giving?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>“Shall give [<i>yiten</i>],” is distinct,</b> and <b>“shall give [<i>venatan</i>],” is distinct.</b> The first expression, which is stated with regard to an ox that killed a slave, does not indicate that the recipient acquires the right to the money only from the moment it is given, whereas the formulation employed in the case of rape does indicate that this is the case.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> that the main source for this <i>halakha</i> is the phrase “shall give [<i>venatan</i>],” when it was taught in the <i>baraita</i> that a man who rapes or seduces a woman is not liable to bring the offering for a false oath in denial of a monetary claim, rather than saying that this is derived from the fact that <b>the verse states “and deal falsely,”</b> he <b>should have</b> said that it is derived from the fact that <b>the verse states “shall give,”</b> as this is the phrase that teaches that the payment is considered a fine even after he has stood trial.
In answer to this question, <b>Rava said: When it was necessary</b> to cite a proof from <b>“and deal falsely,”</b> it was with regard to a situation <b>where</b> the young woman’s case was <b>brought to trial,</b> and the court ruled in her favor, <b>and she reached majority and</b> subsequently <b>died</b> before the money was paid. The reason that “and deal falsely” is necessary in that case is because <b>there, when the father inherits,</b> it is <b>from her</b> that <b>he inherits.</b>
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>If so,</b> the language of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Excluding these, as they are a fine,</b> is inaccurate, as <b>it is</b> a regular <b>monetary</b> payment, not a fine. In answer to this question, <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> that this phrase means: <b>Excluding these, as they are originally a fine,</b> and it is only once the court orders the man to pay that they are viewed as regular monetary payments.
Abaye <b>raised an objection to</b> this explanation of the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, based upon the mishna in <i>Shevuot</i> cited above (42a), which states: <b>Rabbi Shimon exempts</b> him, <b>as he does not pay a fine on his own</b> admission. The Gemara infers: <b>The reason that</b> he is not liable to bring a guilt-offering is because <b>he has not stood trial.</b> However, if <b>he has stood trial</b> and been found guilty, <b>in which case he pays on his own</b> admission when he later admits that he was already convicted in court, <b>he should also be liable to</b> bring <b>an offering</b> if he denies that he was convicted in court and takes <b>an oath</b> to that effect. This contradicts the claim that, according to Rabbi Shimon, even after one is convicted in court, the payment is still considered a fine.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Shimon stated</b> his opinion <b>to them in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis</b> themselves, as follows: <b>According to my</b> opinion, <b>although he has stood trial, the Merciful One exempts him</b> from the offering, as derived <b>from</b> the verse: <b>“And deal falsely</b> with his neighbor in a matter of a deposit” (Leviticus 5:21), which indicates that he is liable only for a claim that originally concerned a regular monetary payment. <b>However, according to your</b> opinion, you should <b>at least concede to me</b> in a case <b>where he has not stood trial, that when one claims</b> the money, he <b>claims a fine</b> and not a regular monetary payment.

Daf 43a

<b>And</b> the principle is that <b>one who admits</b> that he is liable to pay <b>a fine is exempt.</b> Since the man would not have been liable to pay even if he had admitted his guilt, his denial of guilt is not considered a denial of monetary liability, and even if he swears falsely that he is not liable, he still does not become liable to bring an offering. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>when</b> the father <b>claims</b> payment in court, it is the compensation for the <b>humiliation and degradation</b> that <b>he claims.</b> His main focus is not on the fine, and therefore the denial refers to a regular monetary claim.
The Gemara asks: If this explanation is correct, <b>with regard to what do</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree? Rav Pappa said: Rabbi Shimon holds</b> that <b>a person does not leave</b> aside <b>something that</b> is <b>fixed,</b> e.g., a fine, <b>and claim something that</b> is <b>not fixed,</b> e.g., the compensation for humiliation and degradation, which need to be assessed by the court. Consequently, a claim of rape is essentially a demand for the fine. <b>And</b> conversely, <b>the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>a person does not leave</b> aside <b>something that, if</b> the defendant <b>admits to it, he is not exempt</b> from payment, e.g., humiliation and degradation, <b>and claim something that, if</b> the defendant <b>admits to it, he is exempt</b> from payment. Consequently, they contend that the lawsuit is mainly focused on the compensation for the humiliation and degradation.
§ <b>Rabbi Avina raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet:</b> With regard to <b>a daughter who is sustained by</b> her <b>brothers,</b> i.e., an orphan whose brothers provide her with her sustenance from their father’s estate, in accordance with the stipulation in the marriage contract between their parents that requires the father to pay for his daughter’s sustenance from his property, <b>to whom do her earnings</b> belong?
Rabbi Avina explains the sides of the dilemma. One might say that the brothers <b>stand in place of</b> the <b>father: Just as there,</b> if their father is alive, <b>her earnings</b> go <b>to the father, here too her earnings</b> go <b>to the brothers. Or perhaps</b> this is <b>not similar</b> to the case of a living <b>father.</b> Why not? Because <b>there, she is sustained from his</b> own property, and therefore he is entitled to receive her earnings, whereas <b>here, she is not sustained from their</b> possessions but from the estate of their father, and consequently they should not receive her earnings.
Rav Sheshet <b>said to him: You</b> already <b>learned</b> the answer to this dilemma from a mishna (<i>Ketubot</i> 81a): <b>A widow is sustained from the property of the orphans, and her earnings are theirs.</b> This indicates that although a widow receives her sustenance from the estate of her deceased husband, in accordance with the stipulations of the marriage contract, the orphans are nevertheless entitled to her earnings. The same reasoning should apply to an orphan sustained by her brothers.
The Gemara refutes this argument: <b>Are</b> the two situations <b>comparable?</b> In the case of <b>his widow,</b> the deceased <b>is not</b> necessarily <b>amenable</b> to <b>her</b> living <b>in comfort.</b> Consequently, she is entitled only to the minimum guaranteed to her in the marriage contract, while her earnings go to his heirs. Conversely, with regard to <b>his daughter, he is amenable</b> and is interested <b>in her</b> living in <b>comfort,</b> and therefore he allows her to retain her earnings so that she can have the extra money.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that</b> the welfare of <b>his daughter is</b> more <b>preferable to him than</b> that of <b>his widow? But didn’t Rabbi Abba say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei said:</b> The Sages <b>established</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a widow with regard to the daughter,</b> who is also entitled to sustenance from the estate, <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a daughter with regard to</b> the <b>brothers in</b> a case of <b>a small estate</b> that is insufficient for the livelihoods of both the girl and her brothers?
Rabbi Abba explains: <b>Just as</b> in the case of <b>a daughter with regard to</b> the <b>brothers,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>the daughter is sustained</b> from the father’s estate, <b>and</b> if <b>the brothers</b> have nothing to eat they must go and <b>beg</b> for charity <b>at</b> people’s <b>doors, so too,</b> in the case of <b>a widow with regard to the daughter, the widow is sustained and the daughters beg</b> for charity <b>at</b> people’s <b>doors.</b> This indicates that a man is more concerned for his widow than his daughter. The Gemara explains: The two cases are not comparable. <b>With regard to degradation, one’s widow is preferable to him,</b> i.e., if one of them must be forced to go around requesting handouts, a man would rather it be his daughter than his widow. By contrast, <b>with regard to comfort,</b> the comfort of <b>his daughter is</b> more <b>preferable to him</b> than that of his widow.
<b>Rav Yosef raised an objection</b> to Rav Sheshet’s conclusion that the orphan girl’s earnings belong to the brothers, from the mishna: With regard to <b>her earnings and</b> the lost <b>items</b> that <b>she</b> has <b>found, although she has not collected</b> them, if <b>the father died, they</b> belong to <b>her brothers.</b> Rav Yosef infers: <b>The reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i> is that she acquired her earnings <b>in</b> her <b>father’s lifetime,</b> which indicates that the money she earns <b>after the father’s death</b> belongs <b>to her. What, is it not</b> referring even <b>to</b> a daughter <b>who is sustained</b> from his estate? The Gemara refutes this claim: <b>No,</b> it deals <b>with</b> a daughter <b>who is not sustained</b> from his property but who sustains herself through her own earnings.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the mishna is speaking <b>of</b> one <b>who is not sustained</b> from his estate, <b>what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this? It is obvious that this is the <i>halakha</i>, as <b>even according to the one who said</b> that <b>a master can say to</b> his <b>slave: Work for me but I will not feed you,</b> i.e., a master is not legally obligated to provide sustenance to his slave, <b>this applies only to a Canaanite slave, with regard to whom it is not written</b> in the Torah: <b>“With you,”</b> and therefore his master is not obligated to feed him.
<b>However,</b> in the case of <b>a Hebrew slave, as it is written with regard to him: “With you”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:16), which indicates that he is entitled to live with his master as an equal, the master <b>may not</b> compel the slave to serve him unless he feeds him. <b>All the more so</b> concerning <b>his daughter,</b> it cannot be the case that this young woman has to work and give her wages to the brothers if they are not obligated to sustain her at the same time.
<b>Rabba bar Ulla said:</b> It is <b>necessary only for the surplus.</b> The mishna is not implying that the brothers can take her earnings produced after the father's death and not sustain her, leaving her with nothing. Rather, the question concerns a young woman whose earnings provide her with more than she needs for her sustenance, leaving her with a surplus. It is this surplus that belongs to her, and not to her brothers. <b>Rava said</b> in response to Rabba bar Ulla’s explanation: Is it possible that <b>a man</b> as <b>great as Rav Yosef does not know that there is</b> an explanation according to which the implied case of the mishna is referring to the <b>surplus, and</b> in his ignorance <b>he raises a refutation</b> against Rav Sheshet? This certainly cannot be the case.
<b>Rather, Rava said: The mishna itself</b> poses <b>a difficulty to</b> the opinion of Rav Sheshet, and this difficulty led <b>Rav Yosef</b> to his conclusion. This is <b>as</b> the mishna <b>teaches: Her earnings and</b> the lost <b>items</b> that <b>she</b> has <b>found, although she has not collected</b> them. Rava analyzes this statement: With regard to <b>items</b> that <b>she</b> has <b>found, from whom does she collect</b> them? The concept of collecting is inappropriate in this case.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> the case that <b>this is what</b> the mishna <b>said: Her earnings</b> are <b>like items she</b> has <b>found: Just as items she</b> has <b>found in</b> her <b>father’s lifetime</b> belong <b>to</b> her <b>father,</b> and <b>after the father’s death</b> they belong <b>to her, so too,</b> the same rule applies to <b>her earnings as well: In the father’s lifetime,</b> they go <b>to the father,</b> and <b>after the father’s death</b> they belong <b>to her,</b> even when she is sustained from the inheritance. The Gemara concludes: We can <b>learn from this</b> inference that the mishna deals with her earnings themselves, not their surplus, in contrast to the interpretation of Rav Sheshet.
This <i>halakha</i> <b>was also stated</b> by <i>amora’im</i>, as <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In the case of <b>a daughter who is sustained by the brothers, her earnings</b> nevertheless belong <b>to her. Rav Kahana said: What is the reason</b> for this? <b>As it is written</b> with regard to slaves: <b>“And you may make them an inheritance for your sons after you”</b> (Leviticus 25:46), from which it is inferred: It is <b>them,</b> slaves alone, that you bequeath <b>to your sons, and</b> you do <b>not</b> bequeath <b>your daughters to your sons.</b> This verse <b>teaches that a man does not bequeath a right</b> that he has over his <b>daughter to his son.</b> All the rights a man possesses over his daughter are personal rights, which are not transferable by inheritance.
<b>Rabba</b> strongly <b>objects to this</b> explanation that the verse is referring to a man’s rights to his daughter’s earnings: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that <b>the verse is speaking of the</b> fine that a father is paid in the case of the <b>seduction of</b> his <b>daughter, and</b> the <b>fines</b> paid to him if she is raped, <b>and</b> compensation due to him for <b>injuries</b> that she suffered, and the verse indicates that these rights are not bequeathed to his heirs. <b>And Rav Ḥanina likewise</b> explicitly <b>taught</b> that <b>the verse is speaking of</b> payments a father is paid in the case of <b>the seduction of</b> his <b>daughter, and</b> the <b>fines</b> due to him if she is raped, <b>and</b> compensation for <b>injuries</b> she has suffered.
The Gemara questions this interpretation: With regard to <b>injuries, they are</b> the result of <b>her bodily pain,</b> and the guiding principle is that any compensation for a daughter’s physical pain does not belong to her father, who merely keeps it in trust for her. If so, the category of injuries should not have been included in this list. <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said:</b>

Daf 43b

We are dealing with a case <b>when he injured her in her face,</b> and therefore he must also pay for the loss of her value, a sum that belongs to her father. <b>Rav Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav Mattana said</b> that <b>Rav said, and some say Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav Mattana said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>a daughter who is sustained by the brothers, her earnings</b> belong <b>to her, as it is written: “And you may make them an inheritance for your sons after you”</b> (Leviticus 25:46), which indicates: It is <b>them,</b> slaves, that you bequeath <b>to your sons, and not your daughters to your sons.</b> This verse <b>teaches that a man does not bequeath a right</b> that he has over his <b>daughter to his son.</b>
<b>Avimi bar Pappi said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: <b>Shakud said</b> this <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>Who is Shakud?</b> This is a nickname for <b>Shmuel.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rav say it?</b> The Gemara answers: One should <b>say</b> that Avimi bar Pappi meant that <b>even Shakud said it,</b> i.e., Shmuel also agreed with this ruling. <b>Mar bar Ameimar said to Rav Ashi:</b> The Sages <b>of Neharde’a say as follows: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Sheshet,</b> that brothers who are sustaining their sister are entitled to her earnings. <b>Rav Ashi said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> that her earnings belong to her. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who betroths his</b> minor <b>daughter</b> to a man, <b>and</b> the man subsequently <b>divorces her,</b> and her father then <b>betroths her</b> to another, <b>and she is widowed,</b> the payment specified in <b>her marriage contract,</b> even from her second husband, <b>is his,</b> i.e., it belongs to the father. However, if her father <b>married her</b> off <b>and</b> her husband <b>divorced her,</b> and her father then <b>married her</b> to another man <b>and she was widowed,</b> even the payment specified in <b>her marriage contract</b> from her first marriage <b>is hers. Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that the payment specified in <b>the first</b> marriage contract belongs <b>to</b> the <b>father. They said to him: If</b> it <b>was after he married her</b> off, even the first time, <b>her father no</b> longer <b>has authority over her.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara infers from the language of the mishna: The <b>reason</b> is <b>that</b> he <b>married her</b> off, <b>and</b> the husband <b>divorced her,</b> and he <b>married her</b> off to another man, <b>and she was widowed. However,</b> if <b>she was widowed twice she is no longer fit to be married,</b> due to the concern that she is the cause of her husbands’ early demise. The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> the <b><i>tanna</i> incidentally</b> teaches <b>an unattributed</b> opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said</b> that <b>presumption is</b> established <b>by two occasions.</b> Consequently, she is already considered a danger after two husbands have passed away, as opposed to the opinion that three incidents are required to establish a presumption.
§ The mishna taught that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> the payment specified in <b>the first</b> marriage contract belongs <b>to</b> the <b>father.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason of Rabbi Yehuda?</b> The Gemara explains that <b>Rabba and Rav Yosef both say: Since the father is entitled to</b> the payments of the marriage contract <b>from the time of</b> her <b>betrothal,</b> when the first husband obligated himself to pay her marriage contract, as the girl was under her father’s authority at the time, the father receives the money. Although the money is actually paid only after the girl was married and divorced, at which time she is under her own jurisdiction, her father acquired his right to the marriage contract from the time of her betrothal, when she was under his authority.
<b>Rava raised an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that the payment specified in <b>the first</b> marriage contract belongs <b>to</b> her <b>father. And Rabbi Yehuda concedes</b> in the case <b>of one who betroths his daughter when she is a minor, and she matures and subsequently marries, that her father no</b> longer <b>has authority over her</b> once she becomes an adult, and he does not retain his rights to her marriage contract. According to the above explanation, <b>why</b> does Rabbi Yehuda agree in that case? <b>Here too, let him say: Since the father is entitled to</b> the payment of her marriage contract <b>from the time of</b> her <b>betrothal,</b> he receives the payment even if she married after she reached majority.
<b>Rather, if</b> this statement <b>was stated, it was stated as follows: Rabba and Rav Yosef both say: Since</b> the amounts of the marriage contract <b>are written under his authority,</b> as the marriage contract is drafted right before the marriage, at which point the girl was still under her father’s jurisdiction, he is therefore entitled to the money. This explains why the ruling is different if she reached majority before her marriage. In this case, the marriage contract was written when she was no longer under her father’s jurisdiction, and therefore her father is not entitled to the payment of her marriage contract.
<b>And</b> now that it has been established that even according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, the rights to a marriage contract are determined based upon the time of marriage and not the time of betrothal, despite the fact that its sum is fixed at that time, the Gemara asks: <b>From when</b> does the husband’s property become liened to ensure <b>collection</b> of his wife’s marriage contract? Does the monetary claim take effect at the time of betrothal, so that there is a lien on any property he owned at that time, or is there a lien only on property that the husband owned at the time of marriage?
<b>Rav Huna said:</b> With regard to the <b>one hundred dinars</b> for a non-virgin and the <b>two hundred</b> for a virgin, the basic sums of a marriage contract instituted by the Sages, she has a lien on her husband’s property <b>from the</b> time of the <b>betrothal,</b> as she acquired this amount when she was betrothed, <b>but</b> with regard to the <b>addition,</b> i.e., additional sums of money stipulated by the husband himself, the wife’s lien on his property takes effect only <b>from</b> the time of <b>the marriage. And Rav Asi said:</b> The lien for <b>both this and that</b> take effect only <b>from the</b> time of their <b>marriage.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And did Rav Huna</b> actually <b>say this,</b> that a woman has a lien on her husband’s property from the time of betrothal with regard to payment of the one hundred or two hundred dinars that constitute the main sum of her marriage contract? <b>But wasn’t it stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> discussed the case of a woman who <b>produced against</b> her husband, upon their divorce, <b>two marriage contracts,</b> written at different times, <b>one of two hundred</b> dinars <b>and</b> the other <b>one of three hundred? And Rav Huna said:</b> Since she can claim only one marriage contract, if <b>she came to collect</b> the first sum of <b>two hundred</b> dinars, <b>she</b> can <b>collect</b> that amount even <b>from</b> property her husband sold after <b>the first</b> point in <b>time,</b> when this marriage contract was written, and if she wishes to collect the one worth <b>three hundred</b> dinars, <b>she</b> can <b>collect from</b> property her husband sold after <b>the second</b> point in <b>time.</b>
The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>And if it is so,</b> that Rav Huna maintains that the lien for the basic sum and the addition can be ascribed to different dates, <b>let her collect two hundred</b> dinars <b>from</b> property sold after <b>the first</b> point in <b>time,</b> as she was already entitled to the basic sum of her marriage contract from that day, <b>and</b> she can collect <b>the</b> additional <b>one hundred</b> dinars <b>from</b> property sold after <b>the second</b> point in <b>time.</b>
The Gemara refutes this argument: <b>And</b> even <b>according to your reasoning, let her collect the entire five hundred</b> dinars, the sum of both marriage contracts. She should be able to collect <b>two hundred from</b> property sold after <b>the first</b> point in <b>time</b> and <b>three hundred from</b> property sold after <b>the second</b> stipulated <b>time.</b>
<b>Rather, what is the reason</b> that <b>she may not collect</b> the entire sum of <b>five hundred</b> dinars? <b>Since</b> he did <b>not write to her</b> in the second marriage contract: <b>I chose</b> to <b>add to</b> the payment of <b>your</b> marriage contract, and therefore I am writing a contract for <b>three hundred</b> dinars in addition <b>to</b> the first <b>two hundred</b> dinars, it is apparent that <b>this is what he</b> meant to <b>say to her</b> by writing a second marriage contract: <b>If you collect from</b> property sold after <b>the first</b> point in <b>time, you may collect two hundred</b> dinars; <b>if you collect from</b> property sold after <b>the second</b> point in <b>time, you may collect three hundred</b> dinars.

Daf 44a

<b>Here too, this is the reasoning</b> for the ruling <b>that she does not collect</b> the additional one hundred dinars from the second stipulated time, <b>as he did not write to her</b> in the second marriage contract: <b>I added one hundred</b> dinars <b>to your</b> original marriage contract <b>of two hundred</b> dinars. Evidently, he did not add to the existing marriage contract. Rather, <b>she forgave</b> her rights <b>to the first</b> marriage contract, including the <b>lien</b> on his property from the date it was written, in order to accept the second marriage document.
§ After clarifying Rav Huna’s opinion, the Gemara turns its attention to a more general issue, connected to his last statement. <b>The Master,</b> i.e., Rav Huna, <b>said,</b> as indicated in the above discussion, that <b>if she wishes</b> she can <b>collect</b> the sum specified in <b>this</b> marriage contract, and <b>if she wishes</b> she can <b>collect</b> the sum specified in <b>that</b> marriage contract. The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say</b> that this opinion <b>disagrees</b> with <b>that</b> of <b>Rav Naḥman? As Rav Naḥman said:</b> With regard to <b>two documents</b> that pertain to the same issue and <b>that are produced one after the other,</b> e.g., a pair of documents that ascribe the transfer of ownership over a particular field to different times, the <b>second,</b> later document <b>nullifies the first.</b> Here too, the second marriage contract should negate the first one entirely.
The Gemara refutes this suggestion: <b>Was it not stated with regard to</b> this <i>halakha</i> of Rav Naḥman that <b>Rav Pappa said: And Rav Naḥman concedes that if he added</b> so much as <b>a palm tree in</b> the second document, this shows that <b>he wrote it as an addition,</b> and therefore the second document does not cancel the first, but adds to its sum? <b>Here too, he added something for her,</b> as the sum of money specified in the second marriage contract is larger than that specified in the first.
§ Since the Gemara has mentioned the statement of Rav Naḥman, it discusses this matter <b>itself: Rav Naḥman said:</b> With regard to <b>two documents that are produced one after the other,</b> the <b>second nullifies the first. Rav Pappa said: And Rav Naḥman concedes that if he added a palm tree to it, he wrote it as an addition.</b> The Gemara analyzes this <i>halakha</i> in detail. It <b>is obvious</b> that if the <b>first</b> document was a document <b>of a sale, and the second</b> stated that the same field was given <b>as a gift,</b> the second document does not negate the first, as <b>he wrote</b> the additional document of a gift <b>to improve the rights</b> of the recipient <b>due to the <i>halakha</i></b> of <b>one</b> whose field <b>borders</b> the field of his neighbor.
<b>And all the more so,</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> if he wrote the <b>first</b> document <b>as a gift and the second</b> in the form <b>of a sale, as we say</b> it was <b>due to the <i>halakha</i></b> of <b>a creditor that he wrote</b> it in <b>this way.</b> Out of concern that his creditor might come and snatch the field from the recipient and leave him without redress, he writes a document of sale for the recipient, so that he can return and collect this sum from him.
<b>Rather,</b> Rav Naḥman meant that <b>if both of them</b> were documents <b>of sale</b> or <b>both of them</b> were documents <b>of gifts,</b> the <b>second nullifies the first.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? <i>Amora’im</i> argued over this matter. <b>Rafram said: Say</b> that the recipient of the field <b>admitted to him</b> that the first document was invalid, e.g., it was forged, and he therefore wrote a second, valid document. <b>Rav Aḥa said: Say</b> that the recipient <b>forgave him his lien</b> from the date of the first document. Consequently, if the seller’s creditors collect this field as payment for the debt owed to them, which necessitates the seller reimbursing the buyer for the purchase price of the field, the buyer has a lien only on property owned by the seller from the time of the second document.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> these two explanations? The Gemara explains: <b>The</b> practical difference <b>between them</b> involves several cases. First, there is the issue of whether this serves to <b>impair</b> the reliability of the <b>witnesses:</b> According to Rafram, who assumes that the first document was of questionable validity, the witnesses who signed on that document are likewise under suspicion, and therefore their testimony and signature in other cases are of questionable value.
<b>And</b> there is also a difference with regard <b>to paying</b> for the <b>produce</b> of the property between the dates specified in the two documents. According to Rafram, the transfer of ownership did not take place at the date specified in the first document. Consequently, the recipient of the field must compensate the original owner for the field’s produce that he consumed between the two dates. According to Rav Aḥa, the transfer of ownership took place at the time specified in the first document. <b>And</b> finally, there is a difference <b>with regard to</b> the payment of <b>the land tax [<i>taska</i>].</b> If the first document was invalid, the previous owner must pay all taxes due during the period between the two documents.
§ The above discussion came in the wake of the dispute between Rav Huna and Rav Asi with regard to whether the lien on a husband’s property to ensure payment of his wife’s marriage contract applies from the time of betrothal or the time of marriage. The Gemara returns to that issue. <b>What</b> halakhic conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about</b> this matter of <b>a marriage contract?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the following ruling, <b>as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon:</b> The lien on his property with regard to the <b>one hundred dinars</b> or <b>two hundred</b> dinars that comprise the basic sum of a marriage contract applies <b>from</b> the time of <b>the betrothal, and the</b> lien with regard to the <b>additional</b> sum applies <b>from</b> the time of <b>the marriage.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The lien with regard to <b>both this and that</b> takes effect only <b>from</b> the time of <b>the marriage.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that with regard to <b>both this and that,</b> the lien takes effect <b>from</b> the time of <b>the marriage,</b> in accordance with the majority opinion of the Rabbis.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a female <b>convert whose daughter converted with her and</b> later, as a young woman, the daughter <b>engaged in licentious sexual relations</b> when she was betrothed, <b>she is</b> executed <b>by strangulation,</b> not stoning, the method of execution that would be employed had she been born Jewish. <b>She has neither</b> the <i>halakha</i> of being executed at the <b>entrance to</b> her <b>father’s house,</b> as in the case of a woman who was born Jewish who committed this crime, <b>nor</b> does she receive <b>one hundred <i>sela</i></b> if her husband defamed her by falsely claiming that she had committed adultery. The reason is that the verses state “Israel” (Deuteronomy 22:19, 21) with regard to these <i>halakhot</i>, indicating that these <i>halakhot</i> apply only to those born as Jews.
However, if the daughter’s <b>conception occurred</b> when her mother <b>was not</b> yet <b>in</b> a state of <b>sanctity,</b> i.e., when she was still a gentile, <b>but her birth</b> took place when her mother was <b>in</b> a state of <b>sanctity,</b> as her mother converted during her pregnancy, <b>this</b> daughter is punishable <b>by stoning</b> if she committed adultery as a betrothed young woman. However, <b>she has neither</b> the <i>halakha</i> of being executed at the <b>entrance to</b> her <b>father’s house, nor</b> the right to <b>one hundred <i>sela</i></b> if it turns out that her husband defamed her. If <b>her conception and birth occurred</b> when her mother <b>was in</b> a state of <b>sanctity,</b> i.e., after she converted, <b>she is like a</b> regular <b>Jewish woman in all matters.</b>
If a young woman who is betrothed commits adultery and <b>she has a father but does not have an entrance to</b> her <b>father’s house,</b> i.e., if her father does not possess a house of his own, or if <b>she has an entrance to</b> her <b>father’s house but does not have a father,</b> as he has passed away, <b>she is</b> nevertheless executed <b>via stoning, as</b> the requirement that she is to be executed at the <b>entrance to her father’s house is stated only for a mitzva</b> but it is not an indispensable requirement.

Daf 44b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Since the rulings of the mishna are based on the principle that the special <i>halakhot</i> of a betrothed young woman who committed adultery apply only to a woman who was born Jewish, the Gemara questions the <i>halakha</i> that a woman who was conceived when her mother was a gentile but born when her mother was Jewish is executed via stoning: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Reish Lakish said: As the verse states:</b> “And the men of her city shall stone her with stones <b>that she die”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:21). The phrase “that she die” is superfluous and comes <b>to include</b> one <b>whose conception</b> occurred when her mother <b>was not</b> yet <b>in</b> a state of <b>sanctity but her birth</b> took place when her mother was <b>in</b> a state of <b>sanctity.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> if the verse equates her to a regular Jewish woman, <b>let</b> her husband <b>also be flogged</b> if he defames her, <b>and let him also pay</b> the <b>one hundred <i>sela</i>.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states: “That she die”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:21), which indicates that <b>she was included with regard to</b> the <b>death</b> penalty <b>but not with regard to</b> the <b>fine.</b> The Gemara asks another question: <b>Say</b> that this verse comes <b>to include</b> only a girl <b>whose conception and birth</b> both occurred when her mother was <b>in</b> a state of <b>sanctity.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>That</b> girl <b>is a full-fledged Jewish woman,</b> and there is no difference between her and any other Jewish woman.
The Gemara asks a question from the opposite perspective: <b>And say</b> that the verse comes <b>to include</b> even one <b>whose conception and birth</b> both occurred when her mother was <b>not in</b> a state of <b>sanctity.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> the phrase <b>“in Israel”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:21), <b>what purpose does it</b> serve? This expression indicates that this <i>halakha</i> applies only to a woman who was born Jewish.
§ <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said: The defamer of an orphan</b> girl <b>is exempt, as it is stated:</b> “And they shall fine him a hundred shekels of silver, <b>and give them to the father of the young woman”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:19), which <b>excludes this one who does not have a father.</b>
