The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Naḥman was sitting, and Ulla and Avimei bar Rav Pappi</b> were sitting as well, <b>and Rav Ḥiyya bar Ami was sitting with them,</b> when <b>a certain man came</b> before them <b>whose betrothed</b> wife <b>had died. They said to him: Go</b> and <b>bury</b> her, <b>or give her</b> heirs the sum stipulated in <b>her marriage contract. Rav Ḥiyya said to them,</b> in surprise at their response: But <b>we learned</b> that with regard to <b>one’s betrothed wife</b> he <b>neither</b> assumes the status of <b>an acute mourner nor becomes ritually impure for her</b> if he is a priest, <b>and similarly, she neither</b> assumes the status of <b>an acute mourner nor becomes ritually impure for him.</b> If <b>she died he does not inherit</b> from <b>her,</b> and if <b>he died she collects</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract.</b>
Rav Ḥiyya infers the following from this statement: The <b>reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i> is that <b>he died,</b> from which it may be inferred that if <b>she died she does not have a marriage contract,</b> nor any of the stipulations of a marriage contract. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that her marriage contract is canceled upon her death? <b>Rav Hoshaya said:</b> The reason is <b>that I do not read with regard to her</b> the condition stated in the marriage contract: <b>When you marry another he may take what is written for you,</b> as she cannot marry another.
The Gemara relates another incident: <b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia he said that <b>Reish Lakish said: A betrothed woman who died does not have a marriage contract. Abaye said to</b> the scholars who recited this <i>halakha</i> in Ravin’s name: <b>Go,</b> and <b>say to</b> Ravin:

Daf 53b

<b>Your good is taken</b> and <b>cast on thorns,</b> i.e., we do not owe you a debt of gratitude for informing us of this statement, as <b>Rav Hoshaya</b> himself <b>already interpreted</b> and ruled this <b><i>halakha</i></b> of yours <b>in Babylonia.</b>
§ The mishna taught that one of the stipulations of the marriage contract is the clause: Any <b>female children you will have from me</b> will be sustained from my property. The Gemara notes that <b>Rav</b> would <b>teach</b> that the daughters are entitled to sustenance <b>until they are taken</b> as wives <b>by men, and Levi</b> would <b>teach</b> that they are entitled to sustenance <b>until they become grown women.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> are daughters entitled to sustenance <b>even though they have become grown women,</b> if they are still unmarried? Yet how can this be correct? After all, adult daughters are no longer under their father’s jurisdiction even in his lifetime. <b>And</b> can <b>Levi</b> possibly maintain that <b>even though they are married</b> they still receive sustenance from their father’s estate until they become grown women?
<b>Rather,</b> in a case where <b>they became grown women and were not married,</b> or were <b>married and had not become grown women, everyone agrees</b> that they are not entitled to sustenance. <b>When they disagree</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> a daughter <b>who was betrothed and had not become a grown woman.</b> Levi maintains that as she is still unmarried she remains under her father’s jurisdiction. <b>And Levi likewise taught</b> the following version of this stipulation <b>in his <i>baraita</i>: Until they become grown women and the time arrives for their marriage.</b> The Gemara asks: Are these <b>two</b> conditions both necessary? She leaves her father’s domain when one of these conditions is fulfilled. <b>Rather,</b> Levi means that they can continue to receive sustenance <b>either</b> until <b>they become grown women or their time arrives for marriage.</b>
The Gemara observes: The dispute between Rav and Levi is <b>like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> As we have learned: <b>Until when is a daughter sustained</b> from her father’s property? <b>Until she is betrothed. In the name of Rabbi Elazar they said: Until she becomes a grown woman. Rav Yosef taught</b> the version: <b>Until they become</b> married. The meaning of the expression: Until they become married, is unclear, and therefore <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the scholars: Does this refer to <b>becoming betrothed or</b> to <b>becoming married?</b> No answer was found, and the Gemara states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said to Rav Yosef: Have you heard</b> anything <b>from Rav Yehuda</b> with regard to whether <b>a betrothed</b> orphan <b>has sustenance</b> from the brothers’ inheritance of their father’s estate, <b>or</b> whether <b>she does not have sustenance?</b> Rav Yosef <b>said to him:</b> As for <b>hearing, I have not heard</b> anything, <b>but by logical</b> reasoning I can conclude that <b>she does not have</b> sustenance from the inheritance. The reason is that <b>since</b> her husband <b>has betrothed her it is not satisfactory for him that she be demeaned</b> by having to request her sustenance from the inheritance, when he himself can provide for her.
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>If you have not heard</b> this <i>halakha</i>, <b>by logical</b> reasoning <b>she</b> should <b>have</b> sustenance from the brothers. The reason is that <b>since</b> her husband <b>is not sure</b> that he will marry <b>her, he will not throw away money for nothing.</b>
<b>And some say</b> a different version of this discussion. Rav Yosef <b>said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: As for <b>hearing, I have not heard</b> anything, but <b>by logical</b> reasoning I would say that <b>she does have</b> sustenance from the brothers: <b>Since he is not sure</b> that he will marry <b>her, he will not throw away money for nothing.</b> In response, Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: If you have not heard</b> this <i>halakha</i>, <b>by logical</b> reasoning <b>she</b> should <b>not have</b> sustenance from the inheritance: <b>Since he has betrothed her it is not satisfactory for him that she be demeaned</b> by having to ask the brothers for food, and he would rather provide for her himself.
§ The Gemara states <b>a mnemonic</b> device <b>for</b> the <b>men,</b> i.e., the Sages, who appear in the following discussion: <b><i>Shin</i>, <i>kuf</i>, <i>zayin</i>, <i>reish</i>, <i>peh</i>.</b> This refers to Rav Sheshet, Reish Lakish, Rabbi Elazar, Rava, and Rav Pappa. The dilemmas themselves are listed in the following mnemonic: <b>She refused, and a <i>yevama</i>, a secondary</b> forbidden <b>relationship, a betrothed woman, and a woman who was raped.</b>
The Gemara analyzes these cases one by one: The Sages <b>raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet:</b> With regard to <b>one who refused,</b> i.e., a minor orphan girl who was married off by her brothers or mother and then refused her husband, thereby nullifying the marriage, does <b>she have sustenance</b> from her father’s inheritance <b>or</b> does <b>she not have sustenance?</b> Is she considered to have been married, and therefore her right to sustenance has lapsed, or does her refusal nullify the marriage to the extent that it is as though she were never married at all, and therefore she is still entitled to sustenance?
<b>Rav Sheshet said to them: You learned it</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a widow in her father’s house, or a divorcée in her father’s house, or a widow awaiting her <i>yavam</i> in her father’s house, she has sustenance. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If <b>she is still in her father’s house she has sustenance;</b> if <b>she is not in her father’s house she does not have sustenance.</b>
Rav Sheshet analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: The opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda is</b> to all appearances the same as that of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>.</b> What is their dispute? <b>Rather, is it not</b> the case that <b>there is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> concerning a girl <b>who refused</b> her husband, <b>as the first <i>tanna</i> maintains</b> that <b>she has</b> sustenance, as her marriage has been annulled and it is as though it never occurred, <b>and Rabbi Yehuda maintains</b> that <b>she does not have</b> sustenance, as she permanently forfeited this right when she left her father’s house in marriage.
<b>Reish Lakish raised a dilemma:</b> With regard to the <b>daughter</b> of <b>a <i>yevama</i>,</b> i.e., a woman who married her <i>yavam</i> in levirate marriage and gave birth to a daughter before he passed away, does <b>she have sustenance</b> from the property of the <i>yavam</i>, i.e., the girl’s father, <b>or</b> does <b>she not have sustenance?</b>
The Gemara clarifies the sides of the dilemma: <b>Since the Master said</b> that the payment of the <b>marriage contract</b> of a <i>yevama</i> is taken <b>from the property of her first husband,</b> not that of the <i>yavam</i>, her daughter should therefore <b>not have</b> rights to sustenance from the property of the <i>yavam</i>. Her sustenance is a stipulation of the marriage contract, which does not apply to the <i>yavam</i>. <b>Or perhaps, since if she does not have</b> enough to cover the amount of her marriage contract <b>from the</b> property of the <b>first</b> husband, <b>the Sages enacted for her</b> a marriage contract <b>from the second</b> one, i.e., the <i>yavam</i>. Therefore, her daughter should <b>have</b> sustenance from his property. No answer was found, and the Gemara states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rabbi Elazar raised a dilemma:</b> With regard to the <b>daughter</b> of <b>a secondary</b> forbidden <b>relationship,</b> i.e., a girl born to a man and women forbidden to each other by rabbinic law, whose mother is penalized by being deprived of a marriage contract, does her daughter <b>have sustenance or</b> does <b>she not have sustenance?</b>

Daf 54a

Once again the Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: <b>Since</b> the Sages penalized the mother and declared that <b>she does not have a marriage contract,</b> the daughter <b>does not have sustenance</b> either, as her sustenance is guaranteed by her mother’s marriage contract. <b>Or perhaps,</b> with regard to <b>her mother, who violated a prohibition, the Sages penalized her</b> by depriving her of her marriage contract, whereas in the case of the daughter, <b>who did not violate a prohibition, the Sages did not penalize her.</b> Once again the Gemara states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> In the case of the <b>daughter of a betrothed woman,</b> i.e., a man betrothed a woman, fathered a daughter with her, and then died, does the daughter <b>have</b> the right to receive <b>sustenance</b> from his estate, <b>or</b> does <b>she not have</b> the right to receive <b>sustenance? Since</b> the mother <b>has a marriage contract,</b> as in this case the man wrote her a marriage contract after betrothing her, it may be argued that the daughter <b>has</b> the right to receive sustenance. <b>Or perhaps, since the Sages did not enact</b> any requirement for a man to provide his wife with <b>a marriage contract until the time of marriage,</b> the stipulations of the marriage contract do not apply until then, and therefore the daughter of this woman <b>does not have</b> the right to receive sustenance. Again, the Gemara states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Pappa raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>the daughter</b> of <b>a raped</b> woman, i.e., a man raped a young woman, married her, had a child, and died, does <b>she have</b> the right to receive <b>sustenance</b> from her father’s estate <b>or</b> does <b>she not have</b> the right to receive <b>sustenance</b> from his estate? The Gemara comments: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, do not raise this dilemma, as he said</b> that a raped woman <b>has a marriage contract of one hundred dinars,</b> and therefore she is entitled to the stipulations of a marriage contract, one of which is that if she has a daughter with her husband, the daughter receives sustenance from the husband’s estate.
Rather, <b>let the dilemma be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say</b> that the <b>money of her fine fulfilled</b> his obligation to provide <b>her</b> with a <b>marriage contract,</b> i.e., since she has already received the fine in compensation for the rape, she is not entitled to further payment in the form of a marriage contract. According to this opinion, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara elaborates: It may be argued that <b>since</b> the mother <b>does not have a marriage contract,</b> the daughter <b>does not have</b> the right to receive <b>sustenance</b> from her father’s estate. <b>Or perhaps</b> one should consider the following: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>the marriage contract</b> was enacted? <b>So that</b> his wife <b>will not be demeaned in his eyes such that</b> he will easily <b>divorce her. And this one,</b> his rape victim, <b>he cannot divorce her</b> by Torah law, as it is stated: “He may not send her away all his days” (Deuteronomy 22:29). It was therefore unnecessary for the Sages to require that he provide the woman with a marriage contract. However, the reasons for the stipulations included in a marriage contract, e.g., that his daughter receives sustenance from his estate, still apply in this case. Consequently, the Sages stipulated that these provisions still be granted. Yet again the Gemara states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna taught that one of the stipulations of a marriage contract is: <b>You will sit in my house</b> and be sustained from my property all your days as a widow. <b>Rav Yosef taught: In my house, and not in my hovel [<i>bikati</i>].</b> If there is no room for her in his house, the heirs are not obligated to allow her to stay there. <b>However,</b> even in this case, <b>she has</b> the right to receive her <b>sustenance</b> from the heirs. <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi said: She does not even have</b> the right to receive her <b>sustenance,</b> as she is entitled to sustenance only when she lives in her husband’s house. If she resides elsewhere, for whatever reason, she does not receive this payment. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi.</b>
§ <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> If a man <b>proposed to marry</b> a widow <b>and she agreed,</b> even if she has not yet married him, <b>she no</b> longer <b>has</b> the right to receive <b>sustenance</b> from the heirs of her previous husband. The Gemara comments: It may be inferred from here that if she had <b>not agreed,</b> even if the man had proposed marriage, <b>she</b> still <b>has</b> the right to receive <b>sustenance. Rav Anan said: It was explained to me personally by Mar Shmuel</b> that the <i>halakha</i> varies in different cases. If <b>she said:</b> I will not marry you <b>due to so-and-so, my</b> deceased <b>husband,</b> i.e., she still feels connected to him, <b>she</b> still <b>has</b> the right to receive <b>sustenance</b> from his estate. However, if she refused the offer <b>because</b> the men who approached her are <b>people who are unsuitable for her, she does not have</b> the right to continue to receive <b>sustenance,</b> as she has shown that in principle she is willing to remarry.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> If <b>she engaged in licentious sexual relations she does not have</b> the right to continue receiving <b>sustenance</b> from his estate, as she is not acting in a manner befitting a widow. <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> If <b>she painted</b> her eyes <b>and dyed</b> her hair she has clearly done so to attract men for the purposes of marriage, and therefore <b>she does not have</b> the right to receive <b>sustenance</b> from her husband’s estate.
The Gemara comments: According to <b>the one who says</b> that a widow who <b>engaged in licentious sexual relations</b> loses her sustenance, <b>all the more so</b> if <b>she painted</b> her eyes <b>and dyed</b> her hair she loses her sustenance, as her intention to marry is evident. However, according to <b>the one who says</b> that if a widow <b>painted</b> her eyes <b>and dyed</b> her hair she forfeits her right to receive sustenance from her husband’s estate, this ruling applies only to that particular situation. <b>However,</b> if <b>she engaged in licentious sexual relations she</b> still <b>has</b> the right to receive sustenance from his estate. <b>What is the reason?</b> Her evil <b>inclination forced her,</b> i.e., she did not make a decision to remarry but merely succumbed to temptation.
The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with all of these statements. Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>is, in accordance with that which Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: One who claims</b> the payment specified in <b>her marriage contract in court does not have</b> the right to continue receiving <b>sustenance,</b> as she has thereby demonstrated her desire to sever her ties with her late husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does she <b>not</b> receive sustenance? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who sold her marriage contract, or used her marriage contract as collateral, or established her marriage contract as designated repayment [<i>apoteiki</i>] for</b> a debt owed to <b>another</b> individual, <b>she does not have</b> the right to receive <b>sustenance</b> from her husband’s estate? The Gemara infers from this <i>baraita</i>: In <b>these</b> cases, <b>yes,</b> she forfeits her right to continue to receive sustenance. <b>However,</b> in the case of a widow who <b>claims</b> her marriage contract, <b>no,</b> she does not lose the right to continue to receive sustenance.
The Gemara answers that this argument is incorrect, and one should make the following inference instead: In <b>these</b> cases listed in the <i>baraita</i>, she forfeits her marriage contract <b>whether</b> she took the action <b>in court</b> or <b>whether</b> she did <b>not</b> do so <b>in court.</b> However, with regard to <b>one who claims</b> her marriage contract, if she issues this claim <b>in court, yes,</b> she loses the right to continue to receive her sustenance, but if her claim was <b>not</b> issued <b>in court, no,</b> she has not forfeited this right.
§ The mishna taught: <b>And the residents of Jerusalem</b> and of the Galilee <b>would</b> write the marriage contract <b>in this manner,</b> i.e., that if the woman is widowed, she may remain in her husband’s house and receive her sustenance from his property throughout her widowhood. Conversely, the residents of Judea would write that she may live in his house and be sustained from his estate until the heirs decide to give her the marriage contract. <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> argued over this issue. <b>Rav said</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the custom of <b>the residents of Judea, and Shmuel said</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the custom of <b>the residents of the Galilee</b> and Jerusalem.
The Gemara comments: <b>Babylonia and all</b> of its surrounding <b>towns [<i>parvadaha</i>] act in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav; Neharde’a and all</b> of its <b>towns act in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel.</b> The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain woman of Meḥoza who was married to</b> a man from <b>Neharde’a. They came before Rav Naḥman</b> to discuss her marriage contract. <b>He heard from her voice that she was from Meḥoza,</b> whose residents had a distinctive accent.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to them: Babylonia and all</b> of its <b>towns act in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav. They said to him: But she is marrying</b> a resident of <b>Neharde’a. He said to them: If so, Neharde’a and all</b> of its <b>towns act in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And until where</b> is the boundary of <b>Neharde’a? Up to</b> any place <b>where the <i>kav</i></b> measurement <b>of Neharde’a is used.</b> The entire area that utilizes the system of Neharde’a measurements is considered part of its surroundings for the purposes of this <i>halakha</i>.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> also argued about the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a widow. Rav said:</b> When she receives the payment of her marriage contract, the court <b>appraises</b> the clothes <b>that are upon her</b> and deducts their value from the payment she receives. <b>And Shmuel said</b> that the court <b>does not appraise</b> the clothes <b>that are upon her. Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin said: And the reverse</b> is the case <b>with regard to a hired worker.</b> With regard to a hired laborer who lived with his employer and the latter bought clothes for him, Rav and Shmuel disagreed as to whether these garments are appraised and their value deducted from the worker’s salary when he leaves his employer’s service. However, in this case Rav claims that his clothes are not appraised, whereas Shmuel maintains that they are appraised.
Conversely, <b>Rav Kahana</b> would <b>teach: And likewise with regard to a hired worker,</b> their respective opinions are the same in this case as well. Rav rules that one appraises the garments, while Shmuel claims that one does not. <b>And he would apply a mnemonic</b> device for Rav’s opinion: <b>An orphan and a widow, disrobe and remove</b> them. In other words, Rav maintains that both a widow and a hired worker, dubbed an orphan due to his typical poverty, should disrobe, as it were, when the court evaluates the payment to which they are entitled.
<b>Rav Naḥman said: Even though we learned in a mishna in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Arakhin</i> 24a): With regard to <b>both one who consecrates his property and one who valuates himself</b> by donating his fixed value to the Temple, the Temple treasurer has the right to take <b>neither his wife’s clothing, nor his children’s clothing, nor</b> new <b>dyed</b> clothing <b>that he dyed</b> specially <b>for them,</b> even if they have yet to wear them, <b>nor new sandals that he bought for them.</b> This mishna is apparently in accordance with the opinion of Shmuel that a woman’s garments are not considered her husband’s property.
<b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman: Once we have learned a mishna in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, why is the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav? He said to him: It would seem [<i>likhora</i>]</b> that this mishna agrees <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel</b> when it is <b>skimmed through</b> and read superficially. However, <b>when you examine it</b> you will see that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is</b> in fact <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>When he bought her</b> these clothes he did so <b>with the intention that she should stand before him</b> and wear them when she is with him. <b>He did not buy</b> them for <b>her with the intention that she should take</b> them <b>and leave</b> him. The reason for the mishna’s ruling is in fact that the husband acquires the clothes on behalf of his wife, but this applies only if she is living with him. Consequently, if she is living with him, the treasurer has no right to them. However, if she leaves him, she has no right to them, in accordance with the opinion of Rav.
§ The Gemara relates: The <b>daughter-in-law of the house of the son of Elyashiv was claiming</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract from the orphans,</b> and <b>she was</b> in the process of <b>bringing them to the court.</b> The orphans <b>said</b> to her: It is <b>demeaning for us that you should go</b> dressed <b>in this manner,</b> in house clothes. We would rather you come in more suitable attire. <b>She went</b> and <b>dressed and covered herself with all of her clothes. They came before Ravina, who said to them: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> who <b>said</b> that with regard to <b>a widow,</b> the court <b>appraises</b> the clothes <b>that are upon her.</b> Therefore, the court takes everything she is wearing into account in the calculation of her marriage contract payment.
The Gemara relates another incident: <b>A certain</b> person <b>said to</b> his heirs, in his will: Give <b>a dowry to</b> my <b>daughter.</b> There was an established custom for the amount of money spent on a dowry, including clothing and jewelry. In the meantime, the cost of <b>a dowry depreciated,</b> i.e., all these items could be acquired with less money. The question arose concerning the difference between the amount the father wished to give her when he wrote the will and the sum they paid in practice. <b>Rav Idi bar Avin said:</b> The <b>profit [<i>purna</i>],</b> i.e., this difference in price, goes <b>to the</b> male <b>orphans,</b> not to the daughter.
The Gemara cites a related incident: <b>A certain</b> person <b>said to</b> his heirs, in his will:

Daf 54b

<b>Four hundred dinars of</b> this <b>wine</b> you should give <b>to</b> my <b>daughter,</b> and <b>the wine</b> subsequently <b>appreciated</b> in value, so that some money remained. <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> The <b>gain</b> goes <b>to the</b> male <b>orphans,</b> i.e., they are entitled to the leftover sum.
The Gemara relates: <b>The relatives of Rabbi Yoḥanan had a wife of</b> their <b>father who would diminish</b> his resources by spending wastefully on her <b>sustenance. They came before Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> to ask his advice. <b>He said to them: Go and say to your father that he should set aside</b> a certain portion of <b>land for her sustenance.</b> If she agrees to accept this land for her sustenance she has thereby relinquished her claim to the rest of the estate.
After their father died, <b>they came before Reish Lakish</b> for his ruling, and he <b>said to them: All the more so, he has increased</b> the sources of <b>sustenance</b> available <b>to her.</b> In other words, they are still obligated to support her from their father’s estate according to the lifestyle she is accustomed to living, and if they do not, she may use the field to supplement what they give her. <b>They said to him: But Rabbi Yoḥanan did not say so. He said to them: Go</b> and <b>give her</b> all she requires, <b>and if not, I will remove for you Rabbi Yoḥanan from your ears,</b> i.e., I will treat you so harshly that you will forget Rabbi Yoḥanan’s ruling. <b>They approached Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> to complain, but <b>he said to them: What can I do?</b> I cannot impose my opinion, <b>as</b> a man <b>equal to me disagrees with me.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> This matter <b>was explained to me personally by Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> All depends on the husband’s description of the land. If <b>he said</b> that he is giving her land <b>for</b> her <b>sustenance, he has</b> thereby <b>increased</b> the sources of <b>sustenance</b> available <b>to her.</b> He will continue to provide her sustenance, but if that amount is insufficient he has also set aside an area of land specifically for that purpose. However, if <b>he said</b> to her that he is designating the land <b>as</b> her <b>sustenance, he has</b> thereby <b>fixed</b> this plot of land as the only source of <b>sustenance</b> available <b>to her,</b> and she can take no more.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Although they said</b> as a principle that <b>a virgin collects two hundred</b> dinars as payment for her marriage contract <b>and</b> that <b>a widow</b> collects <b>one hundred dinars, if</b> the husband <b>wishes to add even</b> an additional <b>ten thousand</b> dinars, <b>he may add</b> it. If <b>she is</b> then <b>widowed or divorced, whether from betrothal</b> or <b>whether from marriage, she collects the entire</b> amount, including the additional sum. <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says:</b> If she is widowed or divorced <b>from marriage, she collects the total</b> amount, but if she is widowed or divorced <b>from betrothal, a virgin collects two hundred</b> dinars <b>and a widow one hundred</b> dinars. This is <b>because he wrote</b> the additional amount <b>for her</b> in the marriage contract <b>only in order to marry her.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> a related <i>halakha</i> with regard to the marriage contract: <b>If he wishes, he may write for a virgin a document for two hundred</b> dinars as is fitting for her, <b>and she may</b> then <b>write</b> a receipt stating: <b>I received one hundred dinars from you.</b> Even though she has not actually received the money, the receipt serves as a means for her to waive half of the amount due to her for her marriage contract. According to Rabbi Yehuda, the financial commitment in the marriage contract is a right due to the wife, which she may waive if she chooses to do so. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>for a widow</b> he may write <b>one hundred dinars</b> in the contract <b>and she may write</b> a receipt stating: <b>I received from you fifty dinars.</b> However, <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> It is prohibited to do this, as <b>anyone who reduces</b> the amount of the marriage contract to less than <b>than two hundred</b> dinars <b>for a virgin or one hundred dinars for a widow, this</b> marital relationship amounts to <b>licentious sexual relations</b> because it is as if he did not write any marriage contract at all.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that if he wishes to add to the obligation in the marriage contract, he may do so. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> it <b>obvious</b> that if he wishes to add he may do so? The Gemara explains: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>the Sages instituted a fixed</b> ceiling on the amount one may designate in the marriage contract, in order <b>not to embarrass one who does not have</b> sufficient funds, the mishna therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the Sages were not specific about this. If he wishes to add to the amount, he may do so.
§ The mishna states that <b>if he wishes to add</b> even ten thousand dinars to the marriage contract, he may do so. The Gemara comments: <b>It does not teach: He wishes to write for her, rather: He wishes to add.</b> This language indicates that the additional sum he wrote is added to the marriage contract itself, as opposed to being an independent obligation. <b>This supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Aivu,</b> who said what <b>Rabbi Yannai said, as Rabbi Aivu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai said: The stipulation in the marriage contract</b> as well as additional amounts he chooses to add to the contract <b>are comparable to the marriage contract</b> itself.
This principle produces <b>a practical difference</b> with regard to many issues. It is relevant <b>to one who sells</b> her marriage contract, indicating that such a sale includes the additional sum of the marriage contract; <b>and to one who waives</b> her marriage contract to her husband or his heirs, teaching that the additional sum is included in this relinquishing of rights to payment of the contract; and <b>to a rebellious</b> woman, from whom the court deducts a specific amount from her marriage contract each week until there is nothing left. These deductions come from the additional sum as well.
<b>And</b> this principle also results in a practical difference <b>to one who vitiates</b> her marriage contract, as one who states that she received part of the payment for her marriage contract does not receive the remainder without taking an oath, and the additional sum is included in this <i>halakha</i>; <b>to one who demands</b> payment for her marriage contract, as the Sages ruled that from the time she begins to demand the payment she waives her right to further sustenance, and this applies with regard to one who demands the additional sum as well; <b>and to one who violates the precepts</b> of <i>halakha</i> or of Jewish custom, who may be divorced without receiving payment for her marriage contract, including the additional sum.

Daf 55a

It is also relevant <b>to an increase in value,</b> as she does not collect the main or additional sums from the increased value of the property in a case where the husband’s estate was not sufficient at the time of his death to pay the entire cost of her marriage contract but the heirs later increased the value of the property; <b>to an oath,</b> because if the wife is required to take an oath in order to receive her marriage contract, the additional sum is also included in that oath; <b>and to the Sabbatical Year,</b> as the marriage contract is not annulled with other debts in the Sabbatical Year, and this includes the additional sum as well.
<b>And</b> with regard <b>to one who writes</b> a document transferring <b>all of his property to his sons</b> and leaves his wife a specific plot of land for her marriage contract, this teaches that she receives both the main and the additional sums of her contract only from that land. The aforementioned <i>halakha</i> also teaches that she <b>collects</b> the payment only <b>from land, and</b> specifically <b>from land of inferior quality; and</b> that a widow loses her ability to collect the main and additional sums <b>as long as she is in her father’s home</b> for more than twenty-five years after her husband’s death; <b>and</b> the principle also applies <b>to</b> the stipulation in the <b>marriage contract</b> that the <b>male offspring</b> inherit their mother’s dowry when her husband passes away in addition to the inheritance they receive together with their other brothers. These <i>halakhot</i> apply equally to the additional sum of the marriage contract.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that there was a debate among the Sages with regard to the stipulation in the <b>marriage contract</b> that the <b>male offspring</b> inherit the sum stipulated in their mother’s marriage contract. The Sages of <b>Pumbedita say: It is not seized from liened</b> property that has been sold by the father. This is because <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (52b) that the text of the stipulation is: <b>They will inherit</b> the money set aside for their mother’s marriage contract. From this phrase it is clear that the stipulation follows the <i>halakhot</i> of inheritance, and therefore their inheritance can be taken only from property in the father’s possession at the time of his death, but not from property that he had sold.
<b>The residents of Mata Meḥasya say: It is seized from liened</b> property that has been sold. Their tradition is that <b>the mishna states</b> that the text of the stipulation is: <b>They will take</b> the money set aside for their mother’s marriage contract. It is as if the husband transferred this property to the sons, and as their acquisition precedes those of the other buyers, they may seize the sold property from the buyers. The Gemara concludes that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is that it is not seized from liened</b> property that has been sold, as <b>the mishna states: They will inherit.</b>
There is another dispute between the Sages of Pumbedita and the residents of Mata Meḥasya, with regard to one who set aside payment for his wife’s marriage contract from <b>movable property, and</b> these objects <b>are in their pure,</b> unadulterated state at the time of the execution of the marriage contract after the husband’s death. In this case, all agree that the widow may take them <b>without an oath</b> that confirms that her husband did not leave her any other money for the payment of her marriage contract, as it is clear that he set aside these objects for that purpose.
However, if the movable objects <b>are not in their pure,</b> unadulterated state, e.g., they were lost, the Sages of <b>Pumbedita say</b> that she takes the payment for her marriage contract from other property, as all of the husband’s property is liened to the marriage contract <b>without an oath. The residents of Mata Meḥasya say</b> she takes her payment only <b>with an oath,</b> because of a concern that she may have already received other property as payment for her marriage contract. <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is</b> that she may take it <b>without an oath,</b> in accordance with the opinion of the Sages of Pumbedita.
If <b>he set aside land for her,</b> which he demarcated <b>on</b> all <b>four of its borders,</b> she seizes the land <b>without an oath.</b> If he demarcated it <b>on</b> only <b>one border,</b> which is not as clear an indication, the Sages of <b>Pumbedita say</b> she takes it <b>without an oath,</b> and <b>the residents of Mata Meḥasya say</b> she takes it <b>with an oath. And the <i>halakha</i> is</b> that she takes it <b>without an oath.</b>
Furthermore, they had a dispute in a case where someone <b>told witnesses: Write and sign</b> a deed of gift <b>and give it to</b> the intended recipient of the gift. In such a case, if the witnesses <b>acquired it from him</b> on behalf of the recipient by performing a formal act of acquisition, <b>they do not need to consult with him</b> again, as there can be no retraction after a formal acquisition. But if <b>they did not acquire it from him,</b> the Sages of <b>Pumbedita say they do not need to consult with him</b> again, and <b>the residents of Mata Meḥasya say they must consult with him. And the <i>halakha</i> is that they must consult with him</b> again.
§ The mishna states that <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya</b> says that a woman who collects the payment for her marriage contract after marriage receives the main and additional sums, while one who collects it after betrothal receives only the main sum. <b>It was stated: Rav and Rabbi Natan</b> differed with regard to this issue. <b>One said</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. And one said</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.</b>
<b>It may be concluded that Rabbi Natan is the one who said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, as we have heard that Rabbi Natan follows</b> the principle of <b>assessing</b> intention. Even if one did not make an explicit statement, the court assesses what his intention must have been and decides the <i>halakha</i> based on that assessment. It is clear that he follows this principle, <b>as Rabbi Natan said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon Shezuri in</b> the case of an ill person <b>in danger.</b> If this person says: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, that is understood as: Write it and give it to her, as his intention is to absolve her from the requirement of levirate marriage by means of the bill of divorce. Although he did not explicitly state this, Rabbi Natan holds that in such a situation the court assesses that this was the husband’s intent and follows it.

Daf 55b

<b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> is also in accordance with his opinion <b>with regard to the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe from doubtfully tithed produce [<i>demai</i>].</b> Produce purchased from a common, uneducated person [<i>am ha’aretz</i>] is considered <i>demai</i> and by rabbinic law it is regarded as uncertain whether the seller separated tithes and <i>teruma</i> of the tithe from it. Rabbi Natan rules in accordance with Rabbi Shimon Shezuri’s opinion in a case where, after one bought <i>demai</i> and separated <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, this <i>teruma</i> becomes mingled with the produce from which it was separated. If all of the produce were treated as actual <i>teruma</i>, the only solution would be to sell all of the produce to a priest at low cost, as he is the only one who may use it. Rabbi Shimon Shezuri, however, rules that in the case of <i>demai</i>, the owner may ask the fruit seller if he properly separated the tithes. If the seller responds that he did, the owner may rely on that, despite the fact that the seller is an <i>am ha’aretz</i>, as the Sages do not apply their decree in a case where it would cause significant financial loss.
Having established that Rabbi Natan follows the principle of assessment, the Gemara asks: <b>And does Rav not follow</b> this principle of <b>assessing</b> intention? <b>But it was stated</b> that Rav and Shmuel disagreed about a specific case with regard to the <b>gift</b> of a person <b>on his deathbed, in which</b> it was also <b>written</b> that the gift was given with an act of <b>acquisition.</b> There is a rabbinic ordinance that one on his deathbed can effect the transfer of property without the ordinarily required act of acquisition, but in this case such an act was performed anyway. <b>In the school of Rav, they say in the name of Rav: He had him ride on two horses,</b> meaning that he gave him a gift with a document strengthened in two different ways. <b>And Shmuel said: I do not know what to decide about it.</b>
The Gemara explains the two opinions: <b>In the school of Rav, they say in the name of Rav: He had him ride on two horses,</b> meaning that he performed the transfer in a manner that took advantage of two separate <i>halakhot</i> to strengthen its validity. In one aspect, <b>it is similar to</b> the <b>gift of a healthy</b> person, <b>and</b> in a different way <b>it is similar to</b> the <b>gift</b> of a person <b>on his deathbed.</b> Both of these aspects act to strengthen the transfer.
On the one hand, <b>it is similar to</b> the <b>gift of a healthy</b> person in <b>that if he arose</b> from the bed and recovered <b>he cannot retract it,</b> since he performed a proper act of acquisition. On the other hand, <b>it is like</b> the <b>gift</b> of a person <b>on his deathbed</b> in <b>that if he said: My loan,</b> i.e., money owed to me, is transferred <b>to so-and-so</b> as a gift, <b>his loan</b> is in fact transferred <b>to so-and-so.</b> Although ordinarily ownership of a debt cannot be transferred without a formal transference of the promissory note, the verbal statement is sufficient to effect the transfer since this is a gift of a person on his deathbed.
<b>And Shmuel said: I do not know what to decide about it. Perhaps</b> his performance of an act of acquisition indicates that <b>he resolved to transfer it</b> to him <b>only with a bill</b> of sale. <b>And</b> since his intention is that the sale not take effect until he also gives a bill of sale, the transfer does not take effect, as a <b>bill</b> of sale is not effective <b>after the death</b> of the owner.

Daf 56a

In any case, it has been established that Rav also follows the principle of assessing one’s intention, which calls into question the conclusion that Rabbi Natan is the one who said that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara concludes: <b>Both</b> Rav and Rabbi Natan <b>follow</b> the principle of <b>assessing</b> intention, and the debate can be explained in a different way.
According to <b>the one who says</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, this works out <b>well.</b> According to <b>the one who says</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is not</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, <b>here too, this is an assessment</b> of his <b>intention.</b> Why did he give her the additional sum of the marriage contract? <b>It was due to a sense of intimacy</b> between them, as they were betrothed and were planning to get married. Since <b>he did</b> demonstrate <b>a sense of intimacy</b> with her, the assessment is that he intended to give her the additional sum.
<b>Rav Ḥanina,</b> who was known for teaching biblical verses, <b>sat before Rabbi Yannai and said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.</b> Rabbi Yannai <b>said to him: Go out</b> and <b>read your verses outside.</b> Your area of expertise is biblical verses, not <i>halakha</i>. What you said is incorrect and should not be said in the study hall, as the <b><i>halakha</i> is</b> actually <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.</b>
<b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi said in the name of our teacher,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.</b>
<b>And Rav Naḥman</b> also <b>said his</b> own statement: The <b><i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. And</b> the Sages <b>of Neharde’a say in the name of Rav Naḥman:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And although Rav Naḥman cursed</b> them <b>and said: Any judge who rules in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, such and such</b> unspecified misfortune <b>will happen to him, even so</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.</b> Since the Gemara presented a number of different opinions, it concludes: <b>And the practical <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.</b>
§ Since the practical <i>halakha</i> is that a woman who was divorced or widowed after betrothal receives the main sum of her marriage contract but not the additional sum, <b>Ravin asks: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a woman who <b>entered the wedding canopy and</b> is then widowed or divorced <b>without having had sexual intercourse?</b> Does the <b>affection</b> manifest in the <b>wedding effect</b> the marriage, and therefore she receives the additional sum as a married woman? <b>Or,</b> is it the <b>affection</b> manifest in the <b>intercourse</b> that <b>affects</b> the marriage, and consequently this woman is no different than a betrothed woman for the purpose of this <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear that Rav Yosef taught</b> the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>He wrote</b> the additional sum in the marriage contract <b>for her only on account of the affection</b> characteristic <b>of the first night</b> of the marriage. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that the <b>affection</b> manifest in the <b>wedding affects</b> the marriage, <b>this is</b> why <b>it says the</b> affection characteristic of <b>the first night,</b> as the wedding ceremony is performed on the first night only. <b>But if you say</b> that the <b>affection</b> manifest in the <b>intercourse affects</b> the marriage, <b>is there intercourse</b> only <b>on the first night</b> and then <b>from this</b> point <b>forward there is none?</b> Consequently, the <i>baraita</i> implies that the affection manifest in the wedding affects the marriage, and from that point on she is entitled to the additional sum of the marriage contract.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>But rather, what</b> is the advantage of interpreting the expression: Affection characteristic of the first night, as a reference to the <b>wedding? Is there a wedding</b> only <b>at night</b> and <b>not during the day?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>And according to your reasoning, is there intercourse</b> only <b>at night</b> and <b>not during the day?</b> Didn’t <b>Rava say</b> that although the Sages generally prohibited engaging in intercourse during the day, <b>if it was in a dark house</b> it is <b>permitted?</b> The Gemara rejects this question: <b>This</b> is <b>not difficult.</b> By employing this phrase, <b>it teaches us the ordinary mode of behavior,</b> i.e., <b>that intercourse</b> generally takes place <b>at night.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the opinion that the expression is a reference to the <b>wedding is difficult,</b> as a wedding does not have to take place at night. The Gemara responds: <b>The wedding</b> reference is <b>also not difficult, since</b> a reference to <b>a wedding without specification</b> means a wedding that <b>takes place</b> in order to lead directly <b>to intercourse.</b> By using this phrase, <b>it</b> similarly <b>teaches us the ordinary mode of behavior,</b> i.e., that intercourse generally takes place <b>at night.</b> Consequently, this <i>baraita</i> cannot be used as a proof for either possibility.
<b>Rav Ashi asks</b> a question similar to Ravin’s: If the bride <b>entered the wedding canopy and began menstruating,</b> and the husband then died without ever engaging in intercourse with his wife, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the additional sum of the marriage contract? <b>If you say</b> that the <b>affection</b> manifest in the <b>wedding affects</b> the marriage, does this refer specifically to <b>a wedding</b> in which the couple is <b>fit to</b> engage in <b>intercourse,</b> which involves greater affection, <b>and a wedding</b> in which the couple <b>is not fit to</b> engage in <b>intercourse</b> does <b>not</b> affect the marriage? <b>Or, perhaps it is not different.</b> The Sages could not answer this, so the question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna states: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If <b>he wishes, he may write</b> a marriage contract <b>for a virgin</b> for two hundred dinars, and she may then write a receipt as if he had paid part of that sum. They ask: <b>And</b> did <b>Rabbi Yehuda hold</b> that one <b>writes a receipt</b> for partial payment of a debt? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 170b): In the case of <b>one who repaid part of his debt, Rabbi Yehuda says: He should exchange</b> the original promissory note for a new one that states the amount still owed, and <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The lender <b>should write him a receipt</b> for the money he received? According to Rabbi Yehuda, a new note is preferable to a receipt because if the borrower loses the receipt, the lender is still in possession of a promissory note for the full amount and can collect a second time.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> In the mishna, Rabbi Yehuda is referring to a case <b>where the receipt is</b> written <b>within</b> the marriage contract itself and not as a separate document. The husband is therefore not required to hold on to a receipt, and consequently Rabbi Yehuda’s restriction against writing a receipt is not necessary.
<b>Abaye said: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the mishna is referring to a case <b>where the receipt is not</b> written <b>within it,</b> it is logical that Rabbi Yehuda would make an exception in this case. <b>Granted, there,</b> in an ordinary case of a receipt, <b>it is certain</b> that the borrower <b>repaid</b> part of the loan, and consequently there is concern that <b>perhaps</b> he <b>will lose the receipt</b> and the lender will <b>take out the</b> promissory <b>note and return and collect</b> the entire payment <b>again.</b> But <b>here,</b> in the mishna, did the husband <b>definitely give</b> the wife part of the payment for the marriage contract? The receipt <b>merely</b> amounts to <b>something she said to him</b> in order to waive part of the payment, although she did not actually receive it. <b>If he saved</b> the receipt, <b>he saved it; if he did not save it, it is he himself who will lose.</b> Therefore, in this case, Rabbi Yehuda agrees that one writes a receipt.
They ask: <b>Granted,</b> it is understandable why <b>Abaye did not say</b> his explanation <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yirmeya,</b> as the mishna <b>does not teach</b> explicitly that the <b>receipt is</b> written <b>within</b> the marriage contract. <b>However, what is the reason</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya did not say</b> an explanation <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abaye?</b> Why does Rabbi Yirmeya limit the mishna to a case where the receipt was written within the marriage contract? The Gemara responds: Although this is an unusual case, as there is no concern that the receipt may be lost, there is nevertheless a rabbinic <b>decree</b> with regard to <b>this receipt due to the typical</b> case of <b>receipts.</b> Therefore, Rabbi Yehuda would not allow a receipt unless it was written into the marriage contract itself.
With regard to the crux of the issue, the Gemara notes: <b>The reason</b> that Rabbi Yehuda holds that the wife can waive part of the main sum of her marriage contract <b>is</b> specifically because <b>she wrote him</b> a receipt. <b>However,</b> if she said it <b>verbally, no,</b> it is not effective, even according to Rabbi Yehuda. The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> not? <b>This is a monetary matter, and we</b> have <b>heard that Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> With regard to <b>monetary matters</b> in which someone makes a verbal stipulation, <b>his stipulation stands.</b>
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Kiddushin</i> 3:7): In the case of <b>one who says to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me on the condition that you have no</b> ability to claim <b>from me food, clothing, or conjugal rights, she is betrothed and his stipulation is void;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>monetary matters,</b> such as food and clothing, <b>his stipulation stands;</b> therefore, if she verbally waives part of the marriage contract, and thereby makes a stipulation about a monetary matter, it should be effective.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds:</b> The <b>marriage contract is a rabbinic</b> law, <b>and the Sages reinforced their pronouncements with greater</b> force <b>than Torah law.</b> Therefore, if the wife waives part of the main sum of the marriage contract, Rabbi Yehuda holds that her declaration has no force unless it is written down. However, a Torah obligation, such as food and clothing, does not require this reinforcement, and consequently the wife may waive it with a verbal stipulation.
The Gemara challenges this answer: The husband’s entitlement to the <b>produce</b> of his wife’s property <b>is a rabbinic</b> decree, <b>and</b> nevertheless <b>the Sages did not reinforce</b> his rights to <b>them, as we learned</b> in a mishna (83a): <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Even if the husband wrote that he waived his rights to the produce of his wife’s property, <b>he may actually consume the produce of the produce</b> of her property, meaning that he could invest the produce in additional property, which would also belong to his wife, but he would consume its produce. This applies <b>unless he</b> explicitly <b>writes</b> to <b>her: I do not have any claim to your property, its produce, or the produce of its produce, forever.</b>

Daf 56b

<b>And we maintain</b> on this issue: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>Writes?</b> It means: <b>Says.</b> In order to relinquish one’s claim to produce of the produce of his wife’s property, he does not necessarily need to write this in a document; it is sufficient to say it verbally in front of witnesses. It seems, therefore, that Rabbi Yehuda holds that a verbal stipulation is sufficient for a monetary matter of rabbinic law.
<b>Abaye said:</b> There is a distinction between the two cases. <b>Every</b> married woman <b>has a marriage contract, but not all</b> husbands <b>have</b> the right to <b>produce,</b> as not every woman brings property with her into the marriage. Therefore, in relation to <b>a common matter,</b> such as a marriage contract, <b>the Sages reinforced</b> their pronouncements <b>about it</b> by insisting that any stipulations to change the terms must be in writing. However, with regard to <b>an uncommon matter,</b> such as the produce of property, <b>the Sages did not reinforce</b> their pronouncements <b>about it,</b> and a verbal declaration is sufficient.
The Gemara challenges this answer: But with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of <b>donkey drivers, which is a common</b> matter, Rabbi Yehuda does <b>not</b> hold that <b>the Sages reinforced</b> their pronouncements <b>about it.</b>
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Demai</i> 4:7): In the case of <b>donkey drivers who entered a city</b> to sell their wares, <b>and one of them said: My</b> produce <b>is</b> from the <b>new</b> crop and is still moist and not as good, <b>but my associate’s</b> produce <b>is</b> from the <b>old</b> crop, or he said: <b>Mine is not fit</b> for use, i.e., tithes have not been separated, <b>but my associate’s</b> produce <b>is fit</b> for use, the drivers <b>are not afforded credibility.</b> There is a suspicion that they may be lying. They may have an arrangement between them where one will make this statement in one city and in the next city they will alternate, in order to appear credible, so that one will always be able to sell his wares. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: They are deemed credible.</b> This indicates that Rabbi Yehuda holds that a verbal stipulation is sufficient even for a common monetary matter of rabbinic law.
<b>Abaye said:</b> There is a distinction between the cases. With regard to <b>a certain</b> matter <b>involving a rabbinic</b> decree, such as the main sum of the marriage contract, <b>the Sages reinforced</b> their pronouncements, but with regard to <b>an uncertain</b> matter <b>involving a rabbinic</b> decree, such as the case of the donkey drivers, the <b>Sages did not reinforce</b> their pronouncements. <b>Rava said: The Sages</b> did not reinforce their pronouncements in the case of the donkey drivers because, in general, <b>they were lenient about</b> questions concerning the prohibition of <b>doubtfully tithed produce [<i>demai</i>],</b> since the <i>halakha</i> of <i>demai</i> is itself a stringency, as most <i>amei ha’aretz</i> separate tithes from their produce.
§ The mishna says: <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> In the case of <b>anyone who reduces</b> the amount of the marriage contract to less than two hundred dinars for a virgin or one hundred dinars for a widow, this marriage amounts to licentious sexual intercourse. The Gemara makes an inference from the language of the mishna: The phrase: <b>Anyone who reduces</b> the amount of the marriage contract, means <b>even if</b> he made <b>a stipulation</b> and she agreed. <b>Apparently,</b> Rabbi Meir <b>held</b> that <b>his stipulation</b> in this case <b>is void and she has</b> the ability to collect the entire amount set by the Sages, <b>but</b> nevertheless <b>since he said to her: You have only one hundred</b> dinars, <b>she does not rely</b> on the marriage contract and does not see it as a true marriage, <b>and</b> therefore the intercourse <b>becomes licentious sexual intercourse.</b>
<b>But we</b> have <b>heard</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir said</b> that <b>anyone who stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah, his stipulation is void.</b> This implies that if someone makes a stipulation <b>on a rabbinic</b> law <b>his stipulation</b> does <b>stand,</b> and therefore there is still a question as to why the stipulation about the marriage contract is void, as a marriage contract is a rabbinic ordinance. The Gemara responds: <b>Rabbi Meir holds</b> that <b>a marriage contract is</b> a requirement of <b>Torah</b> law. Consequently, if one made a stipulation to reduce the amount of the marriage contract, this is a stipulation counter to that which is written in the Torah, and it is void.
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> In the case of <b>anyone who reduces</b> the amount of the marriage contract to lower <b>than two hundred</b> dinars <b>for a virgin or one hundred</b> dinars <b>for a widow, this</b> marriage amounts to <b>licentious sexual intercourse. Rabbi Yosei says: One is permitted</b> to reduce the amount by making a verbal stipulation, provided the wife agrees. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If one wishes, he may write for a virgin a document for two hundred</b> dinars, <b>and she may write him</b> a receipt stating: <b>I received one hundred</b> dinars <b>from you. And</b> similarly, <b>for a widow</b> one may write <b>one hundred</b> dinars <b>and she may write</b> for <b>him: I received fifty dinars from you.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> actually <b>hold</b> that <b>he is permitted</b> to reduce the amount? The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> based on a <i>baraita</i>: Collection of <b>a woman’s marriage contract may not be made</b> dependent upon <b>movable property.</b> This is a rabbinic decree enacted <b>for the betterment of the world. Rabbi Yosei said: What betterment of the world is</b> accomplished <b>by this</b> decree? The price of the movable property <b>is not fixed,</b> and therefore it might <b>become devalued.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the text of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The first <i>tanna</i> also said:</b> A marriage contract may <b>not be made</b> dependent on movable property. What is Rabbi Yosei’s disagreement with him? <b>Rather, is it not</b> that <b>this is what</b> the first <i>tanna</i> <b>said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case where <b>one did not provide a guarantee</b> for the movable property. <b>But</b> if <b>one did provide a guarantee,</b> the marriage contract <b>may be made</b> dependent on it. <b>And Rabbi Yosei comes to say:</b> Even <b>if one provided a guarantee, why can</b> the marriage contract <b>be made</b> dependent on it? The price <b>is not fixed, and</b> it may <b>become devalued.</b>
<b>Now</b> that the meaning of the <i>baraita</i> has been clarified, the Gemara asks: <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of movable property, where <b>perhaps it</b> will <b>be devalued, Rabbi Yosei is concerned</b> that the wife might not receive the full value of her marriage contract, <b>here,</b> where it <b>will definitely be devalued,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> clear that he would be concerned? The Gemara responds: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There, she does not know</b> if her marriage contract will be devalued, and there is no reason to suppose <b>that she will waive</b> his obligation to her. But <b>here, she knows and she waived</b> it.
The Gemara relates: <b>The sister of Rami bar Ḥama was married to Rav Avya.</b>

Daf 57a

<b>Her marriage contract was lost,</b> and the woman and her husband <b>came before Rav Yosef</b> to ask what they should do. <b>He said to them: This is</b> what <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: That</b> ruling, that if someone reduces his wife’s marriage contract by even a small amount, their marriage amounts to licentious sexual intercourse, <b>is the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> According to that opinion, the husband and wife were forbidden to each other because she was not in possession of a valid marriage contract.
<b>But the Rabbis say:</b> Since the woman relies on the fact that she will eventually collect payment for her marriage contract, <b>a man may maintain his wife for</b> as long as <b>two or three years without</b> a written <b>marriage contract.</b> There is no urgent need to write a new one, since the husband’s obligation remains intact. <b>Abaye said to him:</b> But <b>didn’t Rav Naḥman say</b> that <b>Shmuel said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> with regard to all of <b>his decrees?</b> Since Rabbi Meir’s statement about marriage contracts was a form of decree, the <i>halakha</i> should be in accordance with his opinion. Rav Yosef responded: <b>If so, go and write her</b> a new marriage contract.
§ The Gemara relates that <b>when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> said <b>in the name of bar Kappara:</b> This <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei concerning whether one may make a verbal stipulation with a woman to reduce her marriage contract is referring only <b>to the beginning</b> of the process. <b>But</b> with regard <b>to the end, all agree</b> that <b>she cannot waive</b> her rights by verbal confirmation alone, and she must instead write a receipt. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Both in this</b> case <b>and in that</b> case there is <b>a dispute. Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> This <b>was explained to me</b> personally <b>by Rabbi Yoḥanan himself,</b> who said: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi and I do not</b> actually <b>disagree with one another.</b> We merely used different language to express the same <i>halakha</i>.
<b>What is</b> the meaning of the term: <b>To the beginning, which Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said?</b> It is referring to <b>the beginning of the wedding</b> ceremony. <b>And what is</b> meant by the <b>end?</b> It is referring to the <b>end of intercourse;</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi’s opinion is that after the marriage has been consummated, Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei agree that the wife cannot relinquish her rights verbally. <b>And when I said</b> that <b>both in this</b> case <b>and in that</b> case there is <b>a dispute,</b> I was referring to <b>the beginning</b> of the <b>wedding</b> ceremony <b>and the end</b> of the <b>wedding</b> ceremony, <b>which is</b> also <b>the beginning of</b> the time designated for <b>intercourse.</b> Consequently, according to Rav Dimi, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi and Rabbi Yoḥanan agree that the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei applies only until the consummation of the marriage. After that point, all agree that she cannot waive her rights verbally.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael, he reported this matter differently than Rav Dimi did: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said in the name of bar Kappara:</b> This <b>dispute</b> is referring only to <b>the end</b> of the process, <b>but</b> with regard <b>to the beginning, all agree</b> that <b>she can waive</b> her rights verbally. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Both in this</b> case <b>and in that</b> case there is <b>a dispute. Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> This <b>was explained to me</b> personally <b>by Rabbi Yoḥanan himself,</b> who said: <b>I and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi do not disagree with one another. What is</b> the meaning of: <b>The end, which Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said?</b> The <b>end of the wedding</b> ceremony. <b>And what is</b> the meaning of the <b>beginning?</b> The <b>beginning of the wedding</b> ceremony. <b>And when I said</b> that <b>both in this</b> case <b>and in that</b> case there is a <b>dispute,</b> I was referring to the <b>beginning of intercourse and</b> the <b>end of intercourse.</b>
Consequently, according to Ravin, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi and Rabbi Yoḥanan agree that at the time of the wedding ceremony the wife can verbally waive her rights, and the dispute of the <i>tanna’im</i> is referring to the time after the ceremony, which is also the beginning of the time for consummation of the marriage. <b>Rav Pappa said: Had Rabbi Abbahu not said:</b> This <b>was explained to me</b> personally <b>by Rabbi Yoḥanan himself, that I,</b> i.e. Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi do not disagree with one another, I,</b> i.e., Rav Pappa, <b>would have said</b> that the way to understand the various texts is that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> do <b>disagree</b> with one another, whereas <b>Rav Dimi</b> and <b>Ravin do not disagree</b> with one another, but rather they both cited the same tradition from Eretz Yisrael.
I would have explained it in the following manner: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the word <b>end, which Ravin said?</b> It is referring to the <b>end</b> of the <b>wedding</b> ceremony. <b>And what is</b> the meaning of the word <b>beginning, which Rav Dimi said?</b> It is referring to the <b>beginning of</b> the time designated for <b>intercourse,</b> which begins at the end of the wedding ceremony. It would then follow that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi and Rabbi Yoḥanan disagreed about the explanation of the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei, whereas Rav Dimi and Ravin both said the same thing.
<b>What is</b> Rav Pappa <b>teaching us?</b> Since he accepts Rabbi Abbahu’s statement, he acknowledges that his alternate way of reading the sources is not correct. What, then, is the point of telling us that he would have explained Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi’s and Rabbi Yoḥanan’s words differently?
The Gemara explains: It <b>teaches us this:</b> If we were discussing the meaning of an amoraic dispute about which we have different traditions, it is better to explain <b>that two <i>amora’im</i> disagree with regard to their own reasons</b> and not that <b>two <i>amora’im</i> disagree according to</b> the opinion of <b>another <i>amora</i>,</b> as it is more plausible to say that there is a dispute about logical reasoning than that there is a dispute about the correct transmission of a <i>halakhic</i> tradition. Consequently, had Rabbi Abbahu not declared that he was told otherwise by Rabbi Yoḥanan, it would have been preferable to explain that there is a logical dispute between Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi and Rabbi Yoḥanan, rather than saying that the dispute is about the details of the tradition received by Rav Dimi and Ravin.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One <b>gives a virgin twelve months from</b> the time <b>the husband asked</b> to marry <b>her</b> after having betrothed her, in order <b>to prepare herself</b> with clothes and jewelry for the marriage. <b>And just as</b> one <b>gives a woman</b> this amount of time, <b>so too</b> does one <b>give a man</b> an equivalent period of time <b>to prepare himself,</b> as he too needs time to prepare for the marriage. <b>However, in</b> the case of <b>a widow,</b> who already has items available from her previous marriage, she is given only <b>thirty days</b> to prepare. If <b>the</b> appointed <b>time</b> for the wedding <b>arrived and they did not get married</b> due to some delay on the part of the husband, then the woman <b>may partake of his</b> food. <b>And</b> if her husband is a priest, <b>she may partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> even if she is an Israelite woman.
The <i>tanna’im</i> disagree about the permission granted to a priest to sustain his betrothed with <i>teruma</i> before she is married to him. <b>Rabbi Tarfon says: He may give her all</b> of her required sustenance from <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> During her periods of impurity, e.g., menstruation, when she cannot partake of <i>teruma</i>, she may sell the <i>teruma</i> to a priest and use the proceeds to buy non-sacred food. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> He must give her <b>half</b> of her needs from <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>and half</b> may be from <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> so that she can eat from the non-sacred food when she is ritually impure.
The mishna continues: A priest who is a <b><i>yavam</i>,</b> i.e., his brother died childless after betrothing a woman, <b>does not enable</b> his <i>yevama</i> <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i></b> by virtue of her relationship with him. <b>If she</b> had <b>completed six months</b> of the twelve-month wait for marriage <b>under the aegis of the husband,</b> and then he died, <b>and</b> she waited <b>six</b> more <b>months under the aegis of the <i>yavam</i>; or even</b> if she completed <b>all of</b> the necessary time <b>under the aegis of the husband except for one day</b> that she was <b>under the aegis of the <i>yavam</i>; or</b> if she completed <b>all of</b> the necessary time <b>under the aegis of the <i>yavam</i> except for one day</b> that she was <b>under the aegis of the husband,</b> she still <b>may not partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b>
<b>This</b> set of rulings, concerning the permission granted a betrothed woman whose wedding date has arrived to partake of <i>teruma</i>, is in accordance with <b>the initial</b> version of the <b>mishna.</b> However, <b>a court</b> that convened <b>after them,</b> in a later generation, <b>said:</b>

Daf 57b

<b>A woman may not partake of <i>teruma</i> until she has</b> actually <b>entered the wedding canopy.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived, that a virgin is given twelve months to prepare for her wedding? <b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> it is based on the fact <b>that the verse states</b> with regard to Rebecca: <b>“And her brother and mother said: Let the damsel abide with us for days, or ten”</b> (Genesis 24:55).
The Gemara first analyzes the language of the verse: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>“days”? If we say two days,</b> the minimum number justifying the use of the plural, does <b>a person</b> really <b>speak like this?</b> Rebecca’s relatives <b>said to</b> Abraham’s servant that they wanted her to stay for <b>two days,</b> after which <b>he said to them no,</b> as he did not want to wait even that long. If so, is it possible that after that <b>they said to him</b> that they wanted her to stay for <b>ten days?</b> Consequently, it is impossible to explain the word “days” as two days and “ten” as ten days. <b>Rather, what</b> is the meaning of <b>“days”?</b> It means: <b>A year, as it is written: “For days he shall have redemption”</b> (Leviticus 25:29), and there it is explained that “days” is referring to a year. Consequently, in the verse <b>“And her brother and mother said: Let the damsel abide with us for days, or ten”</b> (Genesis 24:55), “days” refers to a year, and “ten” refers to a shorter period of similar magnitude, i.e. ten months, in order to prepare for her wedding.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> let us <b>say</b> that “days” means <b>a month, as it is written: “But</b> a whole <b>month of days”</b> (Numbers 11:20), and the verse about Rebecca might then have meant that her family wanted to wait for a month, or at least for ten days. <b>They say: One derives</b> the meaning of an <b>unspecified</b> use of the term <b>“days” from</b> another <b>unspecified</b> instance of the term <b>“days,”</b> which means a year. <b>And one does not derive</b> the meaning of <b>an unspecified</b> use of the term <b>“days” from</b> an instance of the term <b>“days,” about which</b> the term <b>“month” is stated.</b> Consequently, it can be derived from the verse that the ordinary amount of time required for a virgin to prepare for marriage is twelve months.
§ <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> It was <b>taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Ketubot</i> 5:1) with regard to <b>a minor girl: Either she or her father may delay</b> the wedding until she has reached majority. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, she,</b> the girl herself, <b>may delay</b> the wedding if she feels she is not ready, as she is the one who will be directly affected, <b>but</b> why should <b>her father</b> be allowed to delay her wedding? <b>If it is suitable for her</b> to get married, <b>what difference does it make to her father?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He thinks:</b> Perhaps she agrees to get married <b>now</b> because <b>she does not</b> fully <b>know</b> what she is doing. But <b>tomorrow, she will</b> realize the marriage was a mistake, <b>rebel, and leave</b> her husband, <b>and</b> then <b>she will come</b> back <b>and become</b> a burden <b>to me.</b> Therefore, her father prefers that she wait until she has reached majority and marry when she is completely aware of what is involved.
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Levi said: One may not finalize</b> an agreement to marry <b>a minor girl</b> in order <b>to marry her while she is</b> still <b>a minor, but one may finalize</b> an agreement to marry <b>a minor girl</b> in order <b>to marry her when she</b> becomes <b>an adult woman.</b> With regard to the latter <i>halakha</i>, the Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> that <b>obvious?</b> If he will marry her when she becomes an adult woman, there is nothing unusual about this case. The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that one <b>should be concerned</b> that <b>she might become afraid</b> of marriage <b>from</b> making plans <b>now, and</b> this <b>will</b> cause her resolve to <b>weaken,</b> and then even when she becomes an adult she will maintain reservations about the matter, Rabbi Abba bar Levi therefore <b>teaches us</b> that one need not be concerned about this. One may finalize an agreement to marry her as an adult even when she is a minor girl.
§ <b>Rav Huna said:</b> If <b>she has reached her majority,</b> even for just <b>one day, and</b> then <b>she is betrothed,</b> she is <b>given her thirty days</b> to prepare for her wedding, <b>like a widow,</b> since prior to reaching adulthood she presumably had already prepared everything needed for her marriage. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>she grew up, she is similar to</b> a betrothed woman <b>who has been asked</b> to marry her betrothed. <b>What, is it not</b> that she is <b>similar to a virgin who has been asked</b> to marry, and she has twelve months to prepare? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it means that she is <b>similar to a widow who has been asked</b> to marry her betrothed, who gets only thirty days to prepare. Only young women who have not reached majority and who are virgins get a year to prepare; after majority, all women, regardless of whether they are virgins, get thirty days.
The Gemara attempts another refutation of Rav Huna’s statement: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a mishna (<i>Nedarim</i> 73b): <b>If a grown woman waited twelve months</b> since betrothal and is still not married, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Since her husband is obligated</b> to provide <b>for her sustenance, he may</b> also <b>nullify</b> her vows (see Numbers, chapter 30). It can be inferred from this that the waiting period for a grown woman is also twelve months. The Gemara responds by emending the text of the mishna: <b>Say</b> that <b>if a grown woman</b> waited thirty days <b>or</b> a young woman <b>waited twelve months, Rabbi Eliezer says: Since her husband is obligated</b> to provide <b>for her sustenance, he may nullify</b> her vows.
The Gemara attempts another refutation of Rav Huna’s statement: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If someone betrothed a virgin, whether the husband asks</b> to marry <b>her and she delays</b> the process because she says that she requires more time <b>or whether she asks</b> to marry him <b>and</b> the <b>husband delays</b> the process because he is not yet ready, <b>she</b> is <b>given twelve months from the time</b> the <b>request</b> was issued <b>but not from the time of the betrothal,</b> even if that was much earlier, and <b>a grown woman is similar to one who has been asked</b> to marry. <b>How</b> is this <b>so?</b> If <b>she has reached her majority</b> for <b>one day, and she is</b> then <b>betrothed, she</b> is <b>given twelve months</b> from the day of her betrothal, because it is the same as the day of her majority. <b>One who was</b> already <b>a betrothed woman</b> when she reached majority is given <b>thirty days.</b> Therefore, <b>the refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rav Huna is a conclusive refutation.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by the words: <b>And one who was</b> already <b>a betrothed woman</b> is given <b>thirty days? Rav Pappa said: This is what it is saying:</b> With regard to <b>a grown woman who has been an adult for twelve months and is</b> then <b>betrothed, she</b> is <b>given thirty days, like a widow,</b> and not another twelve months.
