§ The mishna states: <b>If the</b> appointed <b>time</b> for the wedding <b>arrived and they did not get married,</b> she may partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>Ulla said: By Torah law, the daughter of a non-priest betrothed</b> to a priest <b>may partake of <i>teruma</i></b> immediately, even before the wedding date arrives, <b>as it is stated: “If a priest buy any soul, the acquisition of his money,</b> he may eat of it” (Leviticus 22:11), <b>and this</b> woman <b>is also an acquisition of his money</b> through the betrothal. Therefore, she is entitled to partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>What,</b> then, <b>is the reason</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that <b>she may not partake?</b> It is <b>lest someone pour her a cup</b> of <i>teruma</i> wine while she is <b>in her father’s house.</b> Although she may drink it as the betrothed of a priest, since she is still living in her father’s house there is a concern that <b>she will give her brother or sister to drink</b> from the wine, which is prohibited, as they are non-priests.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> then <b>if the time arrived and they did not get married,</b> there should <b>also</b> be concern that she might give it to members of her family, as she is still in her father’s house. Why, then, does the mishna say that she is permitted to partake of <i>teruma</i> at that time? The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> after the time for the wedding has arrived, <b>he designates</b> a specific <b>place for her.</b> Since her husband is obligated to provide for her sustenance, he will want to ensure that she receives her food in a particular place so that she not use it to feed her family. This mitigates the concern that she may inadvertently give it to her brother or sister to drink.
The Gemara asks: <b>However, if that is so,</b> then the <i>halakha</i> should also be that <b>a gleaner</b> who is <b>a priest</b> and is employed <b>by an Israelite may not partake of <i>teruma</i>, lest</b> the other members of the household <b>come to eat with him</b> from the <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Now,</b> even though the members of the Israelite household <b>feed</b> the priest <b>from their</b> food, as he is their employee, <b>would they eat from his</b> food? They would not. Therefore, there is no reason for concern and no reason to prohibit him from eating <i>teruma</i>. This is Ulla’s opinion.
However, <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yehuda said:</b> The reason for the rabbinic decree is <b>due to abrogation [<i>simfon</i>],</b> cancellation of the contract. It may become known after the betrothal that she has blemishes that can retroactively annul the betrothal, and it would then become apparent that she had partaken of <i>teruma</i> unlawfully.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> if the rabbinic decree that prohibits a woman betrothed to a priest from partaking of <i>teruma</i> is due to concern for possible abrogation of the marriage, then a woman who <b>entered the wedding canopy but has not</b> yet <b>engaged in sexual intercourse</b> should <b>also</b> be prohibited from partaking of <i>teruma</i>, as the husband does not yet know whether she has blemishes. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in that situation, <b>he investigates her</b> through the agency of his female relatives <b>and</b> only <b>then enters</b> the wedding canopy. Consequently, there is no longer any concern about abrogation.
The Gemara asks: <b>However, if that is so,</b> then according to this rationale, <b>a priest’s slave whom</b> the priest <b>purchased from an Israelite should not partake of <i>teruma</i>, due to</b> concern of <b>abrogation.</b> Perhaps the priest will discover a defect in the slave, resulting in the retroactive cancellation of the acquisition and causing the slave to return to his Israelite master after he had mistakenly eaten <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>There is no abrogation with regard to slaves,</b> since no type of defect could cause the cancellation of the transaction. The reason for this is <b>that if</b> the defect <b>is external, then he sees it</b> at the point of sale and accepts it. <b>And if</b> the defect <b>is internal,</b> since <b>he needs him for labor, concealed</b> defects <b>do not concern him.</b> With regard to other types of defects, e.g., if <b>he was discovered</b> to be <b>a thief or</b>

Daf 58a

<b>a gambler [<i>kuvyustus</i>], it has come to him,</b> meaning that the seller has caught the buyer in a binding transaction, and he cannot annul the sale due to this kind of defect, as these characteristics are common in slaves. <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if it was discovered that the slave was <b>an armed bandit or</b> that <b>the king</b> had <b>signed</b> his death warrant, and there is a danger that the government will catch him and execute him? These are serious and uncommon defects that in principle could invalidate a sale. However, <b>these</b> defects <b>generate publicity.</b> In such unusual and severe circumstances, everyone is aware of them. Therefore, it is assumed that the buyer knew about them as well and nevertheless acquiesced to buy the slave. Consequently, there is no reason to revoke the sale of a slave.
The Gemara asks: <b>After all, according to this Sage,</b> Ulla, <b>and according to that Sage,</b> Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yehuda, <b>she may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, so <b>what is</b> the difference <b>between them?</b> The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them is</b> in cases where <b>he accepted,</b> or <b>he transferred or went.</b> If the husband explicitly accepted her blemishes, there is no concern with regard to abrogation, but there is still a concern that she will give her family members <i>teruma</i> wine. Conversely, if the father transferred his daughter to the agents of the husband and entrusted her to their care, or if the father’s own agents went with the girl and the agents of the husband, there is no longer concern that she might give her family members <i>teruma</i>, as she is not with them, but there is still a concern about abrogation.
§ The mishna states that there is a dispute with regard to how a priest must provide for the sustenance of his betrothed once the appointed time for the marriage arrives. <b>Rabbi Tarfon says: He may give her everything</b> from <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> Rabbi Akiva says: He must give her half non-sacred food and half may be <i>teruma</i>. <b>Abaye said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> is referring <b>to a daughter</b> of <b>a priest</b> betrothed <b>to a priest. But</b> with regard to <b>an Israelite woman</b> who was betrothed <b>to a priest, all agree</b> that he must give her <b>half non-sacred</b> food <b>and half</b> may be <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> A priest’s daughter is familiar with the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>teruma</i> and knows how to handle it when she is ritually impure, but when an Israelite woman is not yet familiar with these procedures, there is concern that she might defile the <i>teruma</i>. Consequently, she is given some non-sacred food to use as well.
<b>And Abaye</b> also <b>said</b> that this <b>dispute</b> is referring only to <b>a betrothed woman</b> whose wedding date has arrived, <b>but</b> with regard to <b>a married woman, all agree</b> that her husband must give her <b>half</b> of her needs from <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>and half</b> may be <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> as it is not appropriate for his wife to have to go to the trouble of selling <i>teruma</i> in order to obtain non-sacred food.
<b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Tarfon says: He may give her everything</b> from <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> and <b>Rabbi Akiva says: Half</b> must be <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>and half</b> may be <b><i>teruma</i>. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> With regard to <b>a daughter</b> of <b>a priest</b> betrothed <b>to a priest. But</b> with regard to <b>an Israelite woman</b> betrothed <b>to a priest, all agree</b> that she gets <b>half non-sacred</b> food <b>and half</b> may be <b><i>teruma</i>. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? With regard to a betrothed woman, but with regard to a married woman, all agree</b> that he must give <b>half non-sacred</b> food <b>and half</b> may be <b><i>teruma</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says:</b> He need not give half and half, but rather <b>he may give her two parts <i>teruma</i> and one</b> part <b>non-sacred</b> food. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He may give her all</b> of it <b>in <i>teruma</i>, but</b> as the value of <i>teruma</i> is lower than that of non-sacred food, the amount must suffice so that when <b>she sells</b> <i>teruma</i> during the days when she is ritually impure, <b>she can buy</b> a sufficient quantity of <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>with the money. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Wherever <i>teruma</i> is mentioned, he</b> must <b>give her double</b> the amount that she would receive <b>of non-sacred food,</b> so that she will not have difficulty locating buyers for her <i>teruma</i>. <i>Teruma</i> is less popular and its price is significantly lower, since its use is restricted. But if she receives a large amount of <i>teruma</i>, she will be able to sell it at an even lower price and locate a buyer more easily.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the opinions of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel? The Gemara answers: <b>The</b> practical difference <b>between them</b> is with regard to <b>effort.</b> According to Rabbi Yehuda, she must make an effort to find buyers who will provide her with enough non-sacred food for her needs, and consequently, according to him the husband must provide an amount of <i>teruma</i> that is equal in value to the amount of non-sacred food to which she is entitled. In contrast, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel adds additional <i>teruma</i> to her allotment beyond this amount, so that she will not be forced to go to as much trouble to sell it.
§ The mishna states that <b>a <i>yavam</i> does not enable</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>The Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“The acquisition of his money”</b> (Leviticus 22:11) may partake of <i>teruma</i>, <b>but this</b> woman <b>is his brother’s acquisition</b> and not his, since a <i>yavam</i> does not complete his marriage to the <i>yevama</i> until he consummates the marriage.
§ The mishna said that if <b>she completed six months</b> from the time of the request for marriage <b>under the aegis of the husband</b> and another six months under the aegis of the <i>yavam</i>, she may not partake of <i>teruma</i>. It then says that this is also true if she completed most of the year under the aegis of the husband, and then it says that this is also true if she completed most of the time under the aegis of the <i>yavam</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> that <b>you say</b> that if she completed most of the time <b>under the aegis of the husband</b> this does <b>not</b> enable her to partake of <i>teruma</i>, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to say that the same is true if she spent most of the time <b>under the aegis of the <i>yavam</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> the mishna employing the style: <b>This, and it is unnecessary to say that,</b> meaning that the cases are organized from the less obvious to the more obvious.
§ The mishna states that <b>this</b> ruling, that a woman betrothed to a priest may partake of <i>teruma</i> while she is still in her father’s house if the time for her wedding has arrived, is according to the <b>initial</b> version of the <b>mishna.</b> But that according to the final version, she may not partake of <i>teruma</i> until she has actually entered the wedding canopy. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this later ruling? <b>Ulla said, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda</b> said, that it is <b>due to</b> concern about <b>abrogation,</b> as the woman may have some blemish that will cause the annulment of the marriage, and it will then be clear that she consumed <i>teruma</i> unlawfully.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Ulla, the first</b> ruling that the Sages taught in the initial version of the mishna, namely that she may not partake of <i>teruma</i> in her father’s house immediately after betrothal, is because Ulla was concerned <b>lest</b> someone <b>pour her a cup</b> of <i>teruma</i> wine while she would be <b>in her father’s house. And the latter</b> ruling, that she may not partake of <i>teruma</i> until she actually enters the wedding canopy, even after the time for marriage arrives, is <b>due to</b> concern about <b>abrogation.</b> Consequently, there are two different reasons for the two different rulings.

Daf 58b

<b>However,</b> according <b>to Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda, the first</b> ruling was <b>due to abrogation and the latter</b> ruling was also <b>due to abrogation.</b> If so, <b>what is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the reasoning of the initial version of the mishna and the decision of the court that convened after them?
The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to <b>superficial investigation,</b> i.e., the investigation that could have been conducted on his behalf by his female relatives, which could have been only a superficial investigation. One <b>Sage holds</b> that <b>superficial investigation is considered</b> a valid <b>investigation,</b> and therefore once he requested to marry her and the marriage date arrived, there is no concern of a later abrogation, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage holds</b> that <b>superficial investigation is not considered</b> a valid <b>investigation,</b> and consequently there is still concern that when he consummates the marriage he will find some blemish on her and abrogate the marriage.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>If one consecrates his wife’s earnings,</b> meaning anything she produces, such as thread that she spins from wool, which, according to the Sages’ ordinance, belongs to her husband, <b>she may work and sustain</b> herself from her earnings, as the consecration is ineffective. However, there is a dispute with regard to <b>the surplus,</b> meaning any earnings she produces in excess of the amount she is required to produce for her husband. <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> The surplus is <b>consecrated</b> property, and <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan the Cobbler says:</b> The surplus is also <b>non-sacred.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: A woman may say to her husband: I will not be sustained</b> by you and, in turn, <b>I will not work,</b> i.e., you will not keep my earnings. <b>He holds</b> that <b>when the Sages instituted</b> the various obligations and rights of a husband and wife, the husband’s obligation to provide for the wife’s <b>sustenance</b> was <b>the primary</b> one, <b>and</b> they then decreed that <b>her earnings</b> belong to him in return, <b>due to</b> concern about <b>animosity.</b> If he would be obligated to provide for her sustenance but she would be allowed to work and keep her earnings, he would resent her. Since her right to sustenance is the primary one, <b>if she says: I will not be sustained</b> by you and, in turn, <b>I will not work,</b> i.e., you will not keep my earnings, <b>she has permission to</b> do so. As the arrangement was established for her benefit, she may cancel it if it is not suitable for her.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>They instituted</b> the husband’s responsibility for her <b>sustenance in exchange for</b> his right to <b>her earnings.</b> This indicates that the primary enactment is the husband’s right to his wife’s earnings, and the ordinance that requires him to provide her with sustenance comes as a result. According to this, the wife would not be allowed to waive the arrangement, contrary to Rav Huna’s statement. The Gemara responds: Emend the text of the <i>baraita</i> and <b>say</b> instead: <b>They instituted her earnings in exchange for</b> the husband’s responsibility for her <b>sustenance.</b>
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>Let us say that</b> the mishna <b>supports</b> Rav Huna’s opinion, as it is taught: <b>If one consecrates his wife’s earnings, she may work and sustain</b> herself from her earnings. <b>What, is it not</b> discussing a woman <b>who is sustained</b> by her husband, meaning that he is willing to sustain her, although she relinquishes her right to sustenance in accordance with Rav Huna’s principle? Therefore, her earnings do not belong to him to consecrate. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is discussing a woman <b>who is not sustained</b> by her husband, as he does not have sufficient funds to sustain her. Consequently, there is no proof with regard to Rav Huna’s statement.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> it is discussing a woman <b>who is not sustained, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> that he may not consecrate her earnings? <b>Even according to the one who says</b> that <b>a master can say to</b> his <b>slave: Work for me</b> but <b>I will not sustain you, this applies</b> only to <b>a Canaanite slave, about whom it is not written: “With you.” But</b> with regard to <b>a Hebrew slave about whom it is written:</b> “It is good for him <b>with you”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:16), this does <b>not</b> apply, and the master must sustain him just as he sustains the members of his own household. <b>And</b> this is true <b>all the more so</b> with regard to <b>his wife,</b> as there is a specific obligation of sustenance. Consequently, if he does not do so, he certainly has no right to her earnings.
The Gemara answers: This <i>halakha</i> did not need to be stated, but <b>the latter clause was necessary,</b> as it contains a novelty with regard to <b>the surplus: Rabbi Meir says</b> that the surplus is <b>consecrated</b> property, and <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan the Cobbler says</b> it is <b>non-sacred.</b>
The Gemara comments: This opinion of Rav Huna <b>disputes</b> that <b>of Reish Lakish, as Reish Lakish said: Do not say</b> that <b>the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> is that <b>since he maintains</b> that <b>a person may consecrate an object that has not</b> yet <b>come into the world,</b> the consecration can take effect even on her future earnings. <b>Rather,</b> say that <b>the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> is that <b>since he can compel her</b> to produce <b>her earnings</b> for him, it is as if he had a certain legal claim to the products of her hands, i.e., her earnings. Consequently, <b>he is considered as if he had said to her: Your hands are consecrated to the One Who made them,</b> and the consecration can therefore take effect on something that already exists. Since Reish Lakish said that he may compel her to produce earnings for him, the implication is that she may not say: I will not be sustained and I will not work.
With regard to Reish Lakish’s statement, the Gemara asks: <b>But he did not say this to her;</b> rather, he said that he was consecrating her earnings. The Gemara answers: <b>Since we heard</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir said: A person does not say things for naught,</b> and according to this principle, when one says something that has no halakhic meaning, it is interpreted as if he had said something that does have halakhic relevance, <b>he is considered as if he had said to her: Your hands are consecrated to the One Who made them.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Does Rabbi Meir hold</b> that <b>a person may not consecrate an object that has not</b> yet <b>come into the world? Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that if a gentile <b>says to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me after I convert; or</b> if she was a gentile and he said to her: You are hereby betrothed to me <b>after you convert;</b> or if he was a slave and said to her: <b>After I am emancipated;</b> or if she was a maidservant and he said to her: <b>After you are emancipated;</b> or if she was married and he said to her: <b>After your husband dies; or</b> if he was married to her sister and he said: <b>After your sister dies,</b> as at that point the betrothal could take effect; <b>or</b> if she was a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i> and he said to her: <b>After your <i>yavam</i> performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with you, Rabbi Meir says:</b> If any of these cases occurred, <b>she is betrothed.</b> Apparently Rabbi Meir maintains that betrothal can take effect even on something that has not yet come into being.
The Gemara answers: Actually, <b>from that</b> <i>baraita</i>, <b>one can</b> learn that this is Rabbi Meir’s opinion, but Reish Lakish merely wanted to say that <b>no</b> inference is <b>to be learned from this</b> mishna, as it is possible to explain Rabbi Meir’s words in another way, based on the principle that a person does not say things for naught.
§ The mishna states that with regard to <b>the surplus, Rabbi Meir says: It is consecrated</b> property. The Gemara asks: According to this opinion, <b>when</b> does the surplus amount become <b>consecrated? Rav and Shmuel both said: The surplus is consecrated</b> only <b>after</b> the woman’s <b>death. Rav Adda bar Ahava said: The surplus is consecrated while</b> she is still <b>alive.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa discussed it,</b> as he was perplexed by this dispute: With regard <b>to what</b> do they argue? <b>If we say</b> that the husband <b>provides for her sustenance and</b> additionally <b>provides her with a silver <i>ma’a</i></b> coin every week <b>for</b> the rest of <b>her needs,</b> as he is obligated to do (see 64b), then <b>what is the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said it is consecrated</b> only <b>after</b> her <b>death?</b> As the husband has fulfilled all of his obligations and is consequently the owner of his wife’s earnings, he should be capable of consecrating them.
<b>And</b> if we <b>rather</b> say that <b>he does not provide for her sustenance and does not provide her with a silver <i>ma’a</i> for her needs,</b> and she must consequently support herself entirely, then <b>what is the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that <b>it is consecrated in her lifetime?</b> It is possible that at some point she will not find sufficient employment, and since her husband does not provide for her sustenance or her other needs, she will need the money for herself and there will not be any surplus at all.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> one must explain that they are discussing a situation where <b>he provides for her sustenance, but does not provide her with a silver <i>ma’a</i> for her needs,</b> and this is their dispute: <b>Rav and Shmuel maintain</b> that the main enactment was that <b>they established</b>

Daf 59a

<b>sustenance in exchange for her earnings, and</b> the <b>silver <i>ma’a</i></b> coin that he must give her <b>in exchange for the surplus</b> that she continues to make beyond her quota. <b>And since he does not give her a silver <i>ma’a</i> the surplus is hers,</b> unless some of it is left after her death, in which case the husband inherits it. <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava maintains</b> that <b>they established sustenance in exchange for the surplus, and a silver <i>ma’a</i> in exchange for her earnings. And since he provides her with sustenance, the surplus is his,</b> and therefore the sanctity takes effect on it immediately when she produces the surplus.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what do they disagree?</b> The Gemara explains: One <b>Sage,</b> i.e., Rav and Shmuel, <b>holds that</b> they established <b>something common</b> in exchange <b>for something common.</b> Consequently, they established sustenance, which is common, in exchange for earnings, which are also common. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav Adda bar Ahava, <b>holds that</b> they established <b>something</b> with <b>a fixed amount</b> in exchange <b>for something</b> with a <b>fixed amount.</b> Consequently, since a silver <i>ma’a</i> is a fixed amount and the quota of a woman’s earnings is also fixed, they established one in exchange for the other.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav Adda bar Ahava’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>They established sustenance in exchange for her earnings.</b> Apparently, sustenance is not in exchange for the surplus. The Gemara answers by emending the text of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Say:</b> They established sustenance <b>in exchange for the surplus of her earnings.</b>
The Gemara attempts another proof from a mishna (64b): <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: If he does not give her a silver <i>ma’a</i> for her needs, her earnings</b> belong <b>to her.</b> This indicates that the earnings were established in exchange for the silver <i>ma’a</i>, as Rav Adda bar Ahava contended. The Gemara rejects this by emending the text of the mishna: <b>Say: The surplus of her earnings</b> belongs <b>to her.</b> The Gemara challenges the emendation: <b>But it is taught</b> in the continuation <b>of this</b> mishna: <b>What</b> is the fixed amount that <b>she</b> must <b>earn for him?</b> She must spin the <b>weight</b> of <b>five <i>sela</i></b> of threads of the <b>warp in Judea,</b> which is the equivalent of ten <i>sela</i> according to the measurements of the Galilee. This clause implies that the mishna is not discussing the surplus but rather the quota of her required earnings.
The Gemara answers: <b>This is what it is saying: How much is</b> the required amount of <b>her earnings,</b> so <b>that</b> one <b>can know how much</b> of what she produces constitutes <b>the surplus,</b> and to this the mishna replied: <b>The weight</b> of <b>five <i>sela</i></b> of threads of the <b>warp in Judea, which is</b> the equivalent of <b>ten <i>sela</i></b> according to the measurements of <b>the Galilee.</b>
§ <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan the Cobbler.</b> A husband may not consecrate his wife’s earnings at all, as they have not yet come into being.
The Gemara asks: <b>And did Shmuel</b> actually <b>say this?</b> But <b>didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Nedarim</i> 85a): If a woman said: <b>What I make to feed you,</b> i.e., what I earn for you, <b>is</b> forbidden <b>like an offering</b> [<b><i>konam</i></b>], the husband <b>does not need to nullify</b> this vow. She has a prior obligation to work for him, and therefore the <i>konam</i> cannot take effect on something that does not belong to her. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> Even so, the husband <b>should nullify</b> the vow, <b>lest she produce more</b> earnings <b>than is appropriate for him,</b> and the <i>konam</i> will then take effect on the surplus amount. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said: He should nullify</b> the vow for a different reason, <b>lest he divorce her.</b> Since she rendered her earnings forbidden to him, <b>she will be prohibited from remarrying</b> him after her divorce, as it would then be impossible for him to avoid benefiting from his wife’s earnings.
<b>And Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri,</b> who maintains that the wife can render her future earnings prohibited to her husband before these earnings have come into being, with the prohibition to go into effect after she divorces. This would imply that Shmuel holds that it is possible to consecrate an object that has not yet come into the world, contrary to what Rabbi Yoḥanan the Cobbler said. The Gemara answers: <b>When Shmuel said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri,</b> he was referring only to <b>the surplus.</b>
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>let him say</b> explicitly that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri with regard to the surplus,</b> or <b>alternatively,</b> he should say that the <b><i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> or <b>alternatively,</b> he should simply say: The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabbi Akiva,</b> who is concerned about the surplus amount.
<b>Rather,</b> explain it differently, as <b>Rav Yosef said: Did you speak</b> about <b><i>konamot</i></b> to prove your contention that one can consecrate objects that have not yet come into the world? <b><i>Konamot</i> are different,</b> as they have a special status, <b>since a person can prohibit another’s produce to himself.</b> If one says to another: Your produce is <i>konam</i> to me, it is prohibited for him to eat that produce, although it does not belong to him and the prohibition will apply to it only when it reaches his domain. This indicates that a <i>konam</i> has unique power that enables <b>a person</b> to <b>consecrate an object that has not</b> yet <b>come into the world,</b> which according to Rabbi Yoḥanan the Cobbler is an exception to the principle. Consequently, Shmuel’s ruling in accordance with Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri with regard to <i>konamot</i> is not relevant to his opinion on the issue of a wife’s earnings.
<b>Abaye said to him:</b> This analogy cannot serve as a proof. <b>Granted, a person can prohibit another’s produce to himself,</b> but this is possible <b>because a person can prohibit his own produce to another.</b> In both cases there is at least one aspect of the prohibition that is in his domain, either when he forbids another’s produce to himself, or when he forbids produce in his own possession to others. However, one cannot <b>prohibit an object that has not</b> yet <b>come into the world to another, since a person cannot prohibit another’s produce to another.</b> Just as he cannot make a <i>konam</i> and render prohibited to another person produce that is not in his possession, he also cannot render prohibited to another person produce that has not yet come into the world. If so, how can a woman render her earnings prohibited to her husband by a <i>konam</i> if those earnings have not yet come into the world?
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects that explanation and instead explains as <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> The mishna does not refer to a case where she said: My earnings are <i>konam</i> to you, but rather to one <b>when she says: My hands are consecrated to the One Who made them,</b> and this <i>konam</i> can take effect <b>because the hands</b> do <b>exist in the world.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>When she says this</b> in such terms <b>does it become consecrated? She is subjugated to</b> her husband with regard to her earnings, so how can she consecrate that which is not hers? The Gemara answers: <b>She says</b> that the consecration will take effect <b>when she will get divorced</b> from her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is there anything</b> one would do <b>that if</b> done <b>at present,</b> the <b>consecration</b> could <b>not</b> take effect <b>and in the future</b> the <b>consecration</b> could take effect? <b>Rabbi Elai said: Why not? If one told another: This field that I am selling to you will be consecrated when I buy it</b> back <b>from you, doesn’t</b> that field <b>become consecrated</b> when he buys it back? It appears that one can cause an item to become consecrated in the future although at present he cannot consecrate it.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya objects to this: Are</b> these cases <b>comparable? There,</b> with regard to a field, since the field that he is selling belongs to him at the time of the sale, <b>it is in his power to consecrate it</b> now. Therefore, he can effect sanctity on it at a later point as well. But <b>here, it is not in her power to divorce herself.</b> Consequently, the analogy is invalid. Rather, <b>this is comparable only to</b> a different case, when <b>one says to another: This field that I</b> already <b>sold to you will be consecrated when I buy it</b> back <b>from you.</b> In that case the field <b>is not consecrated,</b> as, when he said this the field was not in his possession, and one cannot consecrate an object that has not yet come into the world.
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this: Is</b> Rav Yirmeya’s analogy <b>comparable? There,</b> the field <b>itself and</b> its <b>produce</b> are <b>in the possession of the buyer,</b> and therefore the seller cannot consecrate them. <b>Here, her body is in her possession,</b> as she owns her hands. Rather, <b>this is comparable only to</b> a case where <b>one says to another:</b>

Daf 59b

<b>This field that I mortgaged to you</b> and from whose produce you are benefiting <b>will be consecrated when I redeem it from you.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is <b>that it is consecrated,</b> since the field itself was not transferred to another’s ownership.
<b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, objects to this: Is it comparable? There,</b> in the case where he mortgaged the field, <b>it is in his power to redeem it,</b> whereas <b>here,</b> with regard to a woman who renders her earnings prohibited to her husband, <b>it is not in her power to divorce herself</b> from her husband. <b>This is only comparable to one who says to another: This field that I have mortgaged to you for ten years will be consecrated when I redeem it from you.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is <b>that it is consecrated.</b> Similarly, in this case, despite the fact that her earnings belong to her husband, when she will be divorced they will revert to her, and since her hands have always belonged to her, she can consecrate her earnings.
<b>Rav Ashi objects to this: Is it comparable? There,</b> after <b>ten years in any case it will be in his power to redeem it,</b> whereas <b>here,</b> with regard to a woman, <b>it is never in her power to divorce herself</b> from her husband. Consequently, there is no way for her to consecrate her future earnings.
<b>Rather,</b> the contradiction between the two rulings of Shmuel must be resolved in a different manner. <b>Rav Ashi said: Did you speak</b> about <b><i>konamot</i>? <i>Konamot</i> are different,</b> since <b>they are</b> a type of <b>inherent sanctity,</b> and therefore the <i>konam</i> can take effect on an item that is subjugated to another person, <b>in accordance with</b> the <i>halakha</i> articulated by <b>Rava. As Rava said: Consecration,</b> the prohibition of <b>leavened bread</b> on Passover, and the <b>liberation</b> of a slave <b>can</b> all <b>abrogate a lien on property.</b> If property was mortgaged to another person, and then the owner consecrated it, or if leavened bread was mortgaged and Passover arrived and it became prohibited to benefit from it, or if a slave was mortgaged and then liberated by his owner, the lien is abrogated. Since <i>konam</i> is a form of consecration, it can take effect on an item even when it is subjugated to another when the owner prohibited it, similar to the case of mortgaged property.
The Gemara asks: If it is so, that a <i>konam</i> can remove the lien on property, <b>let her earnings become consecrated from now,</b> even before her husband divorces her. The Gemara answers: <b>The Sages reinforced the husband’s lien in order that it not become consecrated now.</b> However, since in general a <i>konam</i> can take effect on mortgaged items, it can take effect on her earnings after she leaves her husband’s jurisdiction.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these are tasks that a wife</b> must <b>perform for her husband: She grinds</b> wheat into flour, <b>and bakes, and washes clothes, cooks, and nurses her child, makes</b> her husband’s <b>bed, and makes</b> thread <b>from wool</b> by spinning it. <b>If she brought him one maidservant,</b> i.e., brought the maidservant with her into the marriage, the maidservant will perform some of these tasks. Consequently, the wife <b>does not</b> need to <b>grind, and does not</b> need to <b>bake, and does not</b> need to <b>wash clothes.</b> If she brought him <b>two</b> maidservants, <b>she does not</b> need to <b>cook and does not</b> need to <b>nurse her child</b> if she does not want to, but instead may give the child to a wet nurse. If she brought him <b>three</b> maidservants, <b>she does not</b> need to <b>make his bed and does not</b> need to <b>make</b> thread <b>from wool.</b> If she brought him <b>four</b> maidservants, <b>she may sit in a chair [<i>katedra</i>]</b> like a queen and not do anything, as her maidservants do all of her work for her.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Even if she brought him a hundred maidservants, he can compel her to make</b> thread <b>from wool, since idleness leads to licentiousness.</b> Consequently, it is better for a woman to be doing some kind of work. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Even one who vows</b> that <b>his wife</b> is prohibited <b>from doing</b> any <b>work must divorce</b> her <b>and give</b> her the payment for her <b>marriage contract, since idleness leads to idiocy.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the mishna’s choice of terminology the Gemara asks: <b>Could it enter your mind</b> that she <b>grinds</b> the wheat into flour? Ordinarily, grinding is performed in a mill using millstones that are rotated by water or by animals, so the woman herself does not actually grind the wheat. The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, say</b> that <b>she supervises the grinding</b> by bringing wheat to the mill and ensuring that it is ground properly. Alternatively, <b>if you wish, say</b> instead: She can grind the wheat herself <b>with a hand mill.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya, as Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches: A wife is only for beauty,</b> and <b>a wife is only for children,</b> but not for household tasks. <b>And Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches: A wife is only for</b> wearing <b>a woman’s finery. And Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> similarly <b>teaches: One who wishes to beautify his wife should clothe her</b> in <b>linen garments,</b> and <b>one who wishes to whiten his daughter</b> so that she will have a fair complexion, <b>should feed her young chickens, and should give her milk to drink toward the time of her maturity.</b>
§ The mishna mentions among a wife’s obligations that she <b>nurses her child.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman <b>took a vow not to nurse her child, Beit Shammai say:</b> Since she vowed, <b>she</b> must <b>remove</b> her <b>nipple from his mouth</b> and not nurse him. <b>Beit Hillel say:</b> Her husband <b>can compel her, and she</b> must <b>nurse</b> the child even against her will. However, if <b>she was divorced</b> and therefore had no further obligations to her husband, <b>he cannot compel her.</b> Nevertheless, <b>if</b> the baby <b>recognized her,</b> then even after the divorce, her husband may <b>pay her a salary</b> as a wet nurse <b>and compel her to nurse due to</b> the <b>danger</b> that the child will starve if he refuses to nurse from another woman. This <i>baraita</i> indicates that according to Beit Shammai a woman has no obligation to nurse her child. If she had a prior obligation to her husband to nurse the child, the vow would not take effect.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the mishna is also in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where she made</b> this <b>vow and</b> her husband <b>ratified</b> it <b>for her</b> by refraining from nullifying it. <b>Beit Shammai maintain</b> that in that case it is considered as if <b>he had placed his finger between her teeth,</b> i.e., he caused the vow to be in effect, meaning that in that case the responsibility lies with him. Since he declined the opportunity to nullify the vow, her obligation to nurse is canceled. <b>Beit Hillel maintain</b> that in that case <b>she put her finger between her</b> own <b>teeth,</b> i.e., she caused the vow to remain in effect. Consequently, although he ratified her vow, the responsibility rests on her, and for this reason her obligation is not annulled.
The Gemara asks: If so, that the dispute is about who is responsible when a woman vows and her husband ratifies the vow, and it is not specifically about her obligation to nurse her child, then <b>let them dispute about a marriage contract in general,</b> with regard to whether or not a woman is entitled to payment for her marriage contract if she vows to prohibit her husband from deriving benefit from her. <b>And furthermore, it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>that Beit Shammai</b> explicitly <b>say</b> with regard to all women, not specifically in the context of vows: <b>She does not</b> need to <b>nurse</b> if she does not want to. <b>Rather, it is clear</b> that <b>the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai.</b>
The Gemara above quotes a <i>baraita</i> where it is taught that <b>if</b> the baby <b>recognized her,</b> her husband can compel her to continue nursing even after she is divorced, but he must pay her for nursing.

Daf 60a

The Gemara asks: <b>How old</b> does the child have to be so that one can assume that he already recognizes his mother? <b>Rava said</b> that <b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rav said: Three months, and Shmuel said: Thirty days, and Rabbi Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Fifty days. Rav Shimi bar Abaye said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> what <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> are in dispute with regard to the difference between fifty days and three months, as it is possible that <b>each</b> baby varies <b>according to its intelligence,</b> as one baby is sufficiently developed at fifty days, while another knows his mother at only three months. <b>However, according to Shmuel, can you find a case like this,</b> a one-month-old baby who recognizes his mother?
The Gemara relates: <b>When Rami bar Yeḥezkel came</b> from Eretz Yisrael, <b>he said: Do not listen to,</b> i.e., do not accept, <b>those principles that my brother Yehuda said in the name of Shmuel,</b> as Shmuel did not establish a particular time with regard to this matter. Rather, <b>this is what Shmuel said: Whenever he recognizes her,</b> i.e., there is no fixed age at which this occurs. One must check each baby to see whether he recognizes his mother.
The Gemara relates: <b>A certain</b> divorcée <b>came before Shmuel,</b> as she did not wish to nurse her son. <b>He said to Rav Dimi bar Yosef: Go and check her,</b> i.e., verify whether the child recognizes his mother. <b>He went, placed her in a row of women, and took her son</b> in his arms <b>and passed him near them</b> to see how the child would react. <b>When</b> the child <b>reached her, he looked at her face with joy,</b> and <b>she averted her eyes from him,</b> as she did not want to look at him. <b>He said to her: Lift up your eyes, get up and take your son,</b> as it is obvious that he knows you. The Gemara asks: If this is so, then <b>how does a blind</b> baby <b>know</b> and recognize his mother? <b>Rav Ashi said: Through smell and through the taste</b> of her milk.
§ Apropos the period of time during which a child nurses, the Gemara continues to debate different aspects of this matter. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A child may continue to nurse until</b> the age of <b>twenty-four months,</b> and <b>from this</b> point <b>forward,</b> if he continues to nurse, he is <b>like one who nurses</b> from <b>a non-kosher animal,</b> as a woman’s milk is forbidden to anyone other than a small child; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> A child may continue to nurse <b>even</b> for <b>four or five years,</b> and this is permitted. However, <b>if he ceased,</b> i.e., was weaned, <b>after twenty-four months and</b> then <b>resumed</b> nursing, he is <b>like one who nurses</b> from <b>a non-kosher animal.</b>
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>From this</b> point <b>forward</b> he is <b>like one who nurses from a non-kosher animal.</b> The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that the <b>milk</b> of <b>bipeds,</b> i.e., humans, <b>would be non-kosher</b> like that of a non-kosher animal, based on a <b>logical derivation: Just as</b> with regard to a non-kosher <b>animal, where you were lenient with regard to its contact,</b> meaning that it does not render people or items impure through contact when it is alive, <b>you were stringent with regard to its milk,</b> which is prohibited, even more so should this be true with regard to a person. An <i>a fortiori</i> inference would indicate that with regard to <b>a person, where you were stringent about contact,</b> as people can render other people and objects impure even when they are alive, one should be stricter. So <b>isn’t it logical that you should be stringent with regard to his milk?</b>
This is as <b>the verse states:</b> “But this you shall not eat, of those that only chew the cud, or of those that only part the hoof; <b>the camel, because it chews the cud</b> but does not part the hoof, it is impure for you” (Leviticus 11:4). The somewhat superfluous word “it” teaches that <b>it</b> alone <b>is impure, but</b> the <b>milk</b> of <b>bipeds is not impure; rather,</b> it is <b>kosher.</b> Furthermore, one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>I should exclude the milk</b> of humans from the prohibition against consumption, as this issue <b>does not apply equally to everyone,</b> since only women produce milk, but <b>I should not exclude</b> from the prohibition human <b>blood, which</b> does <b>apply equally to everyone.</b> Consequently, <b>the verse states “it”</b> with regard to a camel, to say that <b>it</b> alone <b>is impure,</b> whereas the <b>blood</b> of <b>bipeds is not impure,</b> but <b>rather</b> is <b>kosher.</b>
<b>And Rav Sheshet said</b> about this ruling: <b>There is not even a</b> rabbinic <b>command to refrain</b> from consuming human milk. Therefore, this presents a contradiction to the statement that a child who nurses beyond a certain age is like one who nurses from a non-kosher animal.
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> statement that the milk is permitted is referring to <b>when it</b> has been <b>removed</b> from the woman’s body, and <b>that</b> statement, that the milk is forbidden, is referring to <b>when it</b> has <b>not</b> been <b>removed.</b> Fundamentally, human milk is a permitted substance. However, it is prohibited by rabbinic law for anyone other than a very young child to nurse directly from a woman’s breasts, and one who does so is considered like one who consumes milk from a non-kosher animal.
<b>And the opposite</b> applies <b>to blood:</b> Human blood that has been removed from the body is forbidden, but if it has not yet been removed, it is permitted. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If some human <b>blood was on a loaf</b> of bread, one <b>scrapes off</b> the blood <b>and</b> then he may <b>eat</b> the bread. Since the blood was detached from the body, it is forbidden by rabbinic law, but if blood <b>was between</b> the <b>teeth, he may suck it</b> and swallow it <b>without concern,</b> as the blood is permitted if it has not been removed from the body.
<b>The Master said</b> in the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> A child may continue to nurse <b>even</b> for <b>four or five years. But isn’t it taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: Even if</b> he can carry <b>his package on his shoulder</b> he can continue to nurse? The Gemara answers: This is not a contradiction, since <b>both this and that are one,</b> the same, <b>measure,</b> and the difference between them is only semantic. <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
On the same topic <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Marinos says: One who is coughing</b> due to an illness that requires milk but did not have milk available <b>may suck milk</b> directly from an animal’s udders <b>on Shabbat,</b> although milking is a prohibited labor on Shabbat. <b>What is the reason? Sucking</b> the milk in this way constitutes an act of <b>extracting in an unusual manner.</b> Although milking is an example of the labor of extracting, a subcategory of the primary category of threshing, it is prohibited by Torah law only when the labor is performed in its typical manner. One who nurses from an animal is extracting the milk in an unusual manner. Such labor is prohibited by rabbinic law, <b>but in a situation</b> involving <b>pain,</b> like one who is coughing, <b>the Sages did not issue a decree. Rabbi Yosef said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Marinos.</b>
A ruling similar to the previous <i>halakha</i> <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Naḥum of Galia says:</b> If <b>a</b> drainage <b>pipe is blocked by weeds [<i>kashkashin</i>]</b> and grass, preventing water from running through the pipe, <b>one may crush them with his foot in private</b> on Shabbat <b>without concern</b> that he is performing the labor of preparing a vessel. The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> for this leniency? <b>This is</b> an example of <b>repairing</b> a vessel <b>in an unusual manner,</b> since it is uncommon to fix an item without using a tool or one’s hands. Performing labor in an unusual manner is ordinarily prohibited by rabbinic decree, <b>but in a situation</b> involving financial <b>loss, the Sages did not issue a decree. Rabbi Yosef said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Naḥum of Galia.</b>
The Gemara continues discussing the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>, which states: If the child <b>ceased</b> nursing <b>after twenty-four months and</b> then <b>resumed,</b> he is <b>like one who nurses</b> from <b>a non-kosher animal.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>How long</b> must he cease nursing to be considered weaned? <b>Rav Yehuda bar Ḥaviva said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Three days. There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that this was not an amoraic statement, but rather a <i>baraita</i> that <b>is taught</b> by <b>Rav Yehuda bar Ḥaviva before Shmuel:</b> Weaning takes effect after <b>three days.</b>
§ The Gemara discusses other <i>halakhot</i> relating to nursing. <b>The Sages taught: A nursing woman whose husband died within twenty-four months</b> of her child’s birth <b>may not be betrothed and may not get married</b>

Daf 60b

<b>until twenty-four months</b> from the day the child was born. The reason for this decree is to protect the child. If she remarries she may become pregnant and may not be able to continue nursing, but her second husband will not be obligated to support the child who is not his son. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And Rabbi Yehuda permits</b> getting married <b>after eighteen months. Rabbi Natan bar Yosef said: These</b> words <b>are the same</b> as <b>the statement of Beit Shammai, and those</b> words <b>are the same</b> as <b>the statement of Beit Hillel,</b> i.e., this is an ancient dispute, <b>as Beit Shammai say: Twenty-four months, and Beit Hillel say: Eighteen months.</b>
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: I will decide. According to the one who says twenty-four months, she may marry after twenty-one months,</b> since even if she gets pregnant, for the first three months of pregnancy she can still continue to nurse. <b>According to the one who says eighteen months, she may marry after fifteen months, since the milk becomes spoiled</b> due to pregnancy <b>only after three months.</b>
<b>Ulla said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. And Mar Ukva said: Rabbi Ḥanina allowed me to marry</b> a nursing woman <b>after fifteen months.</b> It is related that <b>Abaye’s tenant farmer came before Abaye</b> to ask a question. <b>He said to him: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>betrothing</b> a nursing woman <b>after fifteen months?</b> Abaye <b>said to him: One</b> reason it is permitted is that in disputes between <b>Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda. And furthermore,</b> this is actually a dispute between earlier <i>tanna’im</i>, and when <b>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel</b> dispute, <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Beit Hillel. And</b> in addition, <b>Ulla said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda. And Mar Ukva said: Rabbi Ḥanina allowed me to marry after fifteen months, and</b> therefore <b>all the more so you</b> are permitted to betroth her, as you are only <b>betrothing</b> and not marrying her.
<b>When</b> Abaye <b>came before Rav Yosef</b> and told him of the incident, Rav Yosef <b>said to him</b> in response: <b>Rav and Shmuel both say: She must wait twenty-four months</b> before even becoming betrothed, <b>excluding the day that</b> the child <b>was born and excluding the day she became betrothed.</b> When Abaye heard this, <b>he ran three parasangs</b> after his tenant farmer, <b>and some say</b> that he ran <b>one parasang [<i>parsa</i>] through sand.</b> He wanted to inform him that he should not rely on the leniency, but rather he should act in accordance with Rav and Shmuel, who prohibited the betrothal, <b>but he did not</b> succeed in <b>catching up to him.</b>
<b>Abaye said</b> that he learned from this situation <b>that which the Sages said: A person should not permit even</b> eating <b>an egg in <i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> a dish made with milk, <b>in his teacher’s vicinity.</b> This is a very simple ruling, as an egg is not meat and may unquestionably be eaten with milk. There are no stringencies that apply to this case, but nevertheless one should not rule even on such a <i>halakha</i> in his teacher’s vicinity. Abaye explained that this is <b>not because it appears disrespectful</b> to teach <i>halakha</i> in one’s teacher’s vicinity, as this is a simple matter that does not require great knowledge of <i>halakha</i>, <b>rather because he will not be successful in saying the matter</b> correctly. An illustration of this principle is what just happened, <b>since I had learned this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>of Rav and Shmuel,</b> and <b>even so I was unsuccessful in saying it</b> correctly, as I ruled in the vicinity of my teacher, Rav Yosef.
§ <b>The Sages taught: If</b> a woman <b>gave her child to a wet nurse</b> during the waiting period, <b>or weaned him, or</b> the child <b>died, she is permitted to marry immediately.</b> It is related that <b>Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, thought to act in accordance with this <i>baraita</i>.</b> However, <b>a certain old woman said to them: There was an incident in which I</b> was involved with regard to this issue <b>and Rav Naḥman prohibited it for me.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rav Naḥman permit this for</b> the members of <b>the Exilarch’s household?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The Exilarch’s household is different,</b> since people employed by them <b>do not renege</b> out of fear of the consequences. Consequently, if a woman from that household arranges a wet nurse for her child, it is certain that the wet nurse will keep her commitment, whereas with other people there is a danger that if the mother remarries the child might be left without anyone to feed him.
<b>Rav Pappi said to</b> Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua: <b>And do you not maintain</b> that such a marriage is prohibited <b>from that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If</b> a woman <b>frequently went to her father’s house</b> and had been there for a long time; <b>or she had been angry with her husband</b> and separated from him while still <b>in</b> his <b>house; or her husband had been incarcerated in prison; or</b> her husband <b>had gone overseas; or her husband had been old or ill; or if she was a barren woman, or elderly,</b> or <b>a sexually underdeveloped woman, or a minor girl; or if she had miscarried after the death of her husband; or if she was unfit to give birth</b> for any other reason, although in any of these cases there is no concern that she might be pregnant, <b>they must all wait</b> at least <b>three months.</b> The Sages said that a woman must wait for three months between marriages, so there would be no doubt as to who is the father of any child she may give birth to, and they did not distinguish between different women with regard to this decree. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
However, <b>Rabbi Yosei permits</b> all the aforementioned women <b>to be betrothed and to marry immediately,</b> since there is no concern that they may be pregnant. <b>And Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> with regard to all of <b>his decrees.</b> In every place where Rabbi Meir was stringent so as to avoid possibility of error, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his opinion. Consequently, this ruling should apply also to a nursing mother who wishes to remarry; the restriction should apply equally to a woman who had given her child to a wet nurse, or who had weaned him, or whose child had died.
<b>They answered him:</b> The matter <b>was not in our mind,</b> meaning that we had forgotten this principle. Nevertheless, the Gemara concludes: <b>The <i>halakha</i></b> is that if a nursing mother’s child <b>died,</b> the mother <b>is permitted</b> to marry immediately, but if <b>she had weaned him,</b> she <b>is prohibited</b> from marrying, lest she forcibly wean him prematurely. <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi said: Even if</b> the child <b>died, she is also prohibited</b> from marrying, because if it were permitted when the child dies, there would be concern that <b>she might kill him and</b> then <b>go and get married.</b> It is related that <b>there was an incident</b> where <b>a woman strangled</b> her child for this reason. The Gemara concludes that <b>that is not so,</b> i.e., this incident does not affect the <i>halakha</i>. <b>That woman was insane,</b> and since <b>women do not</b> ordinarily <b>strangle their children,</b> one need not be concerned about this happening.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> If <b>someone gave a child</b> to a wet nurse, and she agreed <b>to nurse</b> him for payment, <b>she may not nurse her</b> own <b>child or another</b> woman’s <b>child</b> together <b>with him,</b> in order that she not take away milk from the child she is being paid to nurse. Even <b>if she fixed a small</b> allowance for food with the payment for nursing, <b>she must</b> nevertheless <b>eat large</b> quantities so that she will have enough milk. And <b>she may not eat</b> together <b>with him,</b> i.e., while she is nursing the child, <b>things</b> that are <b>bad for</b> her <b>milk.</b>
The Gemara asks about this <i>baraita</i>: <b>Now</b> that <b>you said</b> that she may <b>not</b> nurse <b>her own child</b> together with her client’s child, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to say that she cannot nurse <b>another woman’s child?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that the prohibition is limited to <b>her child, as</b> there is a concern that since <b>she favors him, she will feed him more</b> milk than the other child, <b>but</b> with regard to <b>another</b> woman’s <b>child, if she did not have surplus</b> milk <b>she would not feed him,</b> and therefore it should be permitted, the <i>baraita</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> not to distinguish between the cases.
The <i>baraita</i> said that even <b>if she fixed a small</b> allowance for food, <b>she must eat large</b> quantities. The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> should she get this food if the allowance cannot cover it? <b>Rav Sheshet said: From her own</b> funds. Because she accepted an obligation to nurse the child, she must take the necessary steps to fulfill her obligation.
The <i>baraita</i> said: <b>She may not eat</b> together <b>with him things</b> that are <b>bad for</b> her milk. The Gemara asks: <b>What are these</b> foods that are detrimental for milk? <b>Rav Kahana said: For example, hops; and young, green grain</b> sprouts; <b>small fish; and soil. Abaye said: Even pumpkin and quince. Rav Pappa said: Even pumpkin and palm branches</b> with small, unripe dates. <b>Rav Ashi said: Even <i>kutaḥ</i> [<i>kamka</i>] and small</b> fried <b>fish.</b> All these items are bad, as <b>some cause milk to dry up</b> and <b>some cause milk to spoil.</b>
The Gemara cites other possible consequences of a mother’s behavior that could affect her children: <b>A woman who engages in intercourse in a mill will have epileptic children;</b> one who <b>engages in intercourse on the ground will have long-necked children;</b> one who <b>steps on a donkey’s dung</b> when pregnant <b>will have bald children;</b> one who <b>eats mustard</b> during pregnancy <b>will have gluttonous children;</b> one who <b>eats garden cress [<i>taḥlei</i>] will have tearful children;</b> one who <b>eats</b> fish <b>brine [<i>moninei</i>] will have children with blinking eyes;</b> one who <b>eats soil will have ugly children;</b> one who <b>drinks intoxicating liquor will have black children;</b> one who <b>eats meat and drinks wine</b> during pregnancy <b>will have children</b> who are

Daf 61a

<b>healthy;</b> one who <b>eats eggs will have large-eyed children;</b> one who <b>eats fish will have graceful children;</b> one who <b>eats celery will have beautiful children;</b> one who <b>eats coriander [<i>kusbarta</i>] will have corpulent children;</b> and one who <b>eats <i>etrogim</i> will have sweet-smelling children.</b> It is related with regard to <b>the daughter of King Shapur</b> of Persia, that <b>her mother ate <i>etrogim</i></b> while pregnant with her and <b>they used to place her in front of her father on top of all the spices,</b> as she was so fragrant.
§ <b>Rav Huna said: Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana tested us,</b> by asking: <b>If she says</b> that she wants <b>to nurse and he says</b> that he <b>does not</b> want her <b>to nurse</b> but rather to give the child to a wet nurse, <b>we accede to her</b> desires, as <b>she is the one suffering</b> from engorgement of her breasts. However, if <b>he says</b> that he wants her <b>to nurse and she says</b> that she does <b>not</b> want <b>to nurse, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? He then narrowed the scope of the question: <b>Anywhere that she is not accustomed,</b> as the women of her family generally do not nurse their children but give them to wet nurses instead, <b>we accede to her</b> desires. However, <b>if she is accustomed</b> to nursing <b>and he is not accustomed,</b> i.e., the women of her family generally nurse their babies but the women in his family do not, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>: Do <b>we follow his</b> wishes to follow her family custom <b>or do we follow her</b> wishes to follow his family custom?
<b>And we answered his</b> question <b>from this</b> amoraic statement: When a woman marries a man, <b>she ascends with him</b> to his socioeconomic status, if it is higher than hers, <b>but she does not descend with him</b> if his status is lower. Consequently, if his family is not accustomed to nurse, she is not obligated to nurse either. <b>Rav Huna said: What is the verse</b> from which this is derived? It is derived from: <b>“She is a man’s wife”</b> (Genesis 20:3). The Gemara explains: The word used here for “wife [<i>be’ula</i>]” hints through similar spelling that she ascends in status <b>with the ascension [<i>aliya</i>] of her husband but does not</b> descend <b>with the descent of her husband. Rabbi Elazar said:</b> There is a hint to this principle <b>from here: “As she was the mother of all living”</b> (Genesis 3:20), which indicates that <b>she was given</b> to her husband <b>for living</b> with him, <b>but was not given to</b> suffer <b>pain</b> with him.
§ The mishna states that <b>if she brought him one maidservant</b> into the marriage with her, she does not need to grind wheat, bake, or wash clothes. The Gemara infers from this statement that <b>she</b> must nevertheless <b>perform the other</b> tasks. The Gemara asks: <b>Let</b> the wife <b>say to him: I brought you a woman in my place [<i>baḥarikai</i>]</b> who can perform all the tasks I am supposed to do, and the wife should be completely exempt. The Gemara answers: This is not a valid argument <b>because</b> the husband <b>can say to her: This</b> maidservant <b>toils for me and for herself</b> like any other woman, but <b>who will toil for you?</b> It is necessary for the wife to do some work in order to cover some of her own expenses.
The mishna further said that if she brought him <b>two</b> maidservants, <b>she does not</b> need to <b>cook and does not need to nurse</b> her child. The Gemara infers: <b>She</b> must nevertheless <b>perform the other</b> tasks. The Gemara asks: <b>Let</b> the wife <b>say to him: I brought you another woman who can toil for me and for herself, and one</b> who can toil <b>for you and for herself.</b> Consequently, I do not need to do any work at all. The Gemara answers: This is also not a valid argument <b>because he can say to her: Who is going to toil for the guests and wayfarers</b> who will come because we are a large household? There are still other tasks that need to be performed.
The mishna further said that if she brought him <b>three</b> maidservants, <b>she does not</b> need to <b>make his bed</b> or make thread from wool. The Gemara infers: <b>She</b> must nevertheless <b>perform the other</b> tasks. The Gemara asks: <b>Let her say to him: I brought you another</b> woman to toil <b>for the guests and wayfarers,</b> in addition to one to toil for herself and for me, and another to toil for herself and for you. Therefore, I do not need to do any work at all. The Gemara answers: This is also not a valid argument <b>because he can say to her:</b> When <b>the members of the house increase,</b> the number <b>of guests and wayfarers</b> also <b>increases</b> and therefore there is still more work to be done.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> then <b>even</b> if she brought him <b>four</b> maidservants <b>as well,</b> she should also have to work, as there will be many more guests. But the mishna says that if she brought four maidservants she does not need to do anything. The Gemara answers: When there are <b>four, since there are many</b> of them, <b>they assist one another</b> and can complete all the necessary tasks.
<b>Rav Ḥana, and some say Rav Shmuel bar Naḥmani, said:</b> This does <b>not</b> necessarily mean <b>that she actually brought him</b> maidservants. <b>Rather, once she is able to bring</b> him maidservants, i.e., once her dowry is sufficiently large to buy maidservants, then she is exempt from performing the tasks, <b>although she did not</b> actually <b>bring him</b> maidservants. The Sages <b>taught: Whether she brought him</b> actual maidservants or <b>whether she reduced her own needs</b> in order to release enough money to bring a maidservant to work, she is exempt from the tasks.
§ The mishna says that if she brought him <b>four</b> maidservants, <b>she may sit in a chair</b> and not do anything. <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Ḥananya said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said: Although they said</b> that <b>she may sit in a chair</b> and does not need to work, <b>she</b> should still <b>pour his cup; and make his bed; and wash his face, hands, and feet,</b> as these responsibilities are not household tasks that can be delegated to a maidservant. Rather, they are gestures of affection toward her husband.
<b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Ḥananya</b> also <b>said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said</b> a similar <i>halakha</i>: <b>All tasks that a wife performs for her husband, a menstruating woman may</b> similarly <b>perform for her husband, except for: Pouring</b> his <b>cup; and making</b> his <b>bed; and washing</b> his <b>face, hands, and feet.</b> As explained above, these are acts of affection. If she is menstruating she should not perform them, so as not to lead to forbidden intercourse.
<b>And</b> with regard to the prohibition against <b>making</b> the husband’s <b>bed, Rava said: We said</b> this <b>only</b> if she made the bed <b>in front of him, but</b> if it was <b>not in front of him, we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b> With regard to the prohibition against <b>pouring</b> his <b>cup,</b> the Gemara comments: <b>Shmuel’s wife would change</b> her practice <b>toward him</b> during her menstruation period and pour <b>with her left hand,</b> since if she made some change in the manner of pouring, this would serve as a reminder of her status and mitigate the concern that it might lead to intimacy. <b>Abaye’s</b> wife would <b>place</b> his cup <b>on top of a barrel, Rava’s</b> wife would place it <b>on his pillow,</b> and <b>Rav Pappa’s</b> wife would place it <b>on the bench</b> to create a change.
§ Apropos statements by Rav Yitzḥak ben Ḥananya, the Gemara cites other statements in his name. <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Ḥananya said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said: All</b> foods may be <b>withheld from before the waiter,</b> as one who is a waiter at the meal must wait until the guests have eaten from every food and only then may he eat, <b>except for meat and wine,</b> as these foods arouse the appetite more and the waiter would suffer if he could not eat them together with the other participants. <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> This is referring only to <b>fatty meat and aged wine. Rava said:</b> It applies to <b>fatty meat all year round</b> but <b>aged wine</b> only <b>during the season of Tammuz,</b> in the summer. Due to the heat, the aroma of the wine is more pervasive at that time.
<b>Rav Anan bar Taḥalifa said: I was</b> once <b>standing before Mar Shmuel, and they brought him a cooked dish of mushrooms, and if he had not given me</b> some, <b>I would have been endangered</b> due to the craving that I suffered. <b>Rav Ashi said: I was</b> once <b>standing before Rav Kahana, and they brought him slices [<i>gargelidei</i>] of turnip in vinegar, and if he had not given me</b> some, <b>I would have been endangered. Rav Pappa said: Even a fragrant date</b> should be offered to the waiter. The Gemara concludes: <b>The principle of the matter</b> is: One should offer some of <b>everything that</b> either <b>has an aroma or</b> that <b>has a sharp taste</b> to whomever is present when it is served, so that no one suffer by being unable to partake of these foods.
It is related about two Sages, <b>Avuh bar Ihi and Minyamin bar Ihi,</b> that <b>one of them</b> was accustomed <b>to give</b> his waiter <b>from every type</b> of food that he ate, while the other <b>one would give</b> him only <b>one of the types</b> of food that he ate. The Gemara says: <b>Elijah spoke with</b> this <b>Sage, but Elijah did not speak with that Sage,</b> since he did not act with piety and caused his waiter to suffer.
Similarly, the Gemara relates an incident with regard to <b>two pious men, and some say</b> they were <b>Rav Mari and Rav Pineḥas, the sons of Rav Ḥisda:</b> One <b>Sage would give</b> the waiter something to eat <b>before</b> the meal, and the other <b>Sage would give</b> the waiter something to eat <b>after</b> the guests had eaten. With regard to the one <b>who gave</b> it to him <b>earlier, Elijah spoke with him. But</b> with regard to the one <b>who gave</b> it to him <b>later, Elijah did not speak with him.</b>
The Gemara relates another incident with regard to this matter: <b>Ameimar and Mar Zutra and Rav Ashi were sitting at the entrance to the house of King Izgur. The king’s chief butler was passing by</b> with various foods. <b>Rav Ashi saw Mar Zutra’s</b>

Daf 61b

<b>face blanch</b> because he craved the food, so he <b>took</b> some of the food <b>with his finger</b> and <b>put it in</b> Mar Zutra’s <b>mouth.</b> The chief butler <b>said to him: You have spoiled the king’s meal,</b> as now he will not eat from it. The king’s soldiers who were there <b>said to him: Why did you do this? He said to them: The one who makes such</b> awful dishes is the one who actually <b>spoiled the king’s food. They said to him: Why</b> do you say this? <b>He said to them: I saw something else,</b> i.e., a leprous infection, <b>in this</b> meat. <b>They checked and didn’t find anything. He took his finger and placed it on</b> the food and <b>said to them: Did you check here? They</b> then <b>checked</b> that spot and <b>found</b> the infection. <b>The Sages said to</b> Rav Ashi: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>you relied on a miracle</b> and assumed that leprosy would in fact be found there? <b>He said to them: I saw a leprous spirit hovering over</b> the food and realized that it had this defect.
The Gemara relates another incident with regard to a similar subject: <b>A certain Roman said to a certain woman: Will you marry me? She said to him: No.</b> In order to convince her, <b>he went and brought pomegranates and peeled them and ate</b> them <b>in front of her</b> and did not give her any of them. The aroma of the pomegranates caused her mouth to water, so <b>she swallowed all</b> of the <b>saliva that caused her anguish, but he did not give her</b> any <b>until she became ill</b> and bloated. <b>Ultimately, he said to her: If I cure you, will you marry me? She said to him: Yes. He went and brought pomegranates, peeled them and ate</b> them <b>in front of her. He said to her: All</b> of <b>the saliva that causes you anguish, spit it out, spit it out.</b> She did this <b>until</b> something <b>like a green leaf came out of her, and</b> then <b>she was cured.</b>
§ The mishna says that a wife must <b>make</b> thread <b>from wool.</b> The Gemara infers: She <b>must</b> make thread <b>from wool,</b> but she is <b>not</b> obligated to do so <b>from flax.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in the <b>mishna? It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A husband <b>may not compel</b> his wife <b>to stand before his father</b> and serve him, <b>or to stand before his son</b> and serve him, <b>or to place straw before his animals,</b> i.e., horses and donkeys, <b>but he can compel her to place straw before his cattle,</b> i.e., cows and bulls. <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: He also cannot compel her to make</b> thread <b>from flax, because flax,</b> while it is being spun, <b>causes the mouth to smell</b> foul <b>and the lips to stiffen.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>This applies only to Roman flax,</b> which causes the most damage.
§ The mishna continues: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Even if she brought him a hundred maidservants,</b> he may compel her to make thread from wool, since idleness leads to licentiousness. <b>Rav Malkiyyu said</b> that <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina, son of Rav Ika, said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> discussed in tractate <i>Beitza</i> (28b) that <b>a skewer</b> that had been used for roasting meat but no longer has an olive-bulk of meat on it may be moved to a corner on a Festival; the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>maidservants</b> in the mishna here; <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> discussed in tractate <i>Nidda</i> (52a) that if a girl has two hair <b>follicles</b> in her pubic region, even if there are no hairs growing from them, she is considered to have reached majority and may perform <i>ḥalitza</i>; these three <i>halakhot</i> were all stated by <b>Rav Malkiyyu.</b>
However, the <i>halakha</i> discussed in tractate <i>Avoda Zara</i> (29a) that a Jew who cuts the hair of a pagan must stop at a distance of three fingerbreadths on every side before he reaches his <b>forelock,</b> as the pagans would grow their forelocks for idolatry and the Jew must not appear as if he were dressing the forelock for idolatrous purposes; and the <i>halakha</i> discussed in tractate <i>Makkot</i> (21a) that one may not place <b>burnt ashes</b> on a wound, as it looks like a tattoo; <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> discussed in tractate <i>Avoda Zara</i> (35b) that <b>cheese</b> made by a gentile is forbidden, because gentiles smooth the surface of their cheese with lard; these three <i>halakhot</i> were all stated by a different Sage named <b>Rav Malkiya.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The <i>halakhot</i> mentioned above that relate to <b>a mishna or a <i>baraita</i></b> were stated by <b>Rav Malkiya,</b> whereas amoraic statements of <b><i>halakhot</i></b> that are not related to a mishna or <i>baraita</i> were taught by <b>Rav Malkiyyu. And your mnemonic</b> to remember this <b>is: The mishna is a queen [<i>malketa</i>],</b> indicating that the comments that are referring to a mishna were made by Rav Malkiya, whose name is similar to the Aramaic term for queen. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> Rabbi Ḥanina, son of Rav Ika, and Rav Pappa? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> with regard to the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>maidservants.</b> According to Rabbi Ḥanina, this <i>halakha</i> was stated by Rav Malkiyyu, whereas Rav Pappa holds that it was taught by Rav Malkiya, since it is referring to a dispute in a mishna.
§ The mishna says: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> Even one who vows that his wife is prohibited from doing any work must divorce her and give her the payment for her marriage contract, since idleness leads to idiocy. The Gemara asks: <b>This is</b> essentially the same as the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, who said that idleness leads to licentiousness. The Gemara answers: <b>The</b> practical difference <b>between them is</b> in a case when <b>she plays with small dogs [<i>guriyyata kitanyata</i>] or</b> with <b>games [<i>nadrashir</i>]</b> like chess. Since there is something occupying her she is not in danger of idiocy, but occupying oneself with diversions of this type may still lead to licentiousness.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who vows</b> that <b>his wife</b> may not derive benefit <b>from marital relations</b> with him, <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> He may maintain this situation for up to <b>two weeks,</b> but beyond that he must divorce her and give her the payment for her marriage contract. <b>Beit Hillel say:</b> He must divorce her if it continues beyond <b>one week.</b>
Apropos the husband’s obligation to his wife regarding marital relations, the Gemara mentions other aspects of this issue: <b>Students may leave</b> their homes and travel in order <b>to learn Torah without</b> their wives’ <b>permission</b> for up to <b>thirty days,</b> and <b>laborers</b> may leave their homes without their wives’ permission for up to <b>one week. The set interval</b> defining the frequency of a husband’s conjugal obligation to his wife <b>stated in the Torah</b> (see Exodus 21:10), unless the couple stipulated otherwise, varies according to the man’s occupation and proximity to his home: <b>Men of leisure,</b> who do not work, must engage in marital relations <b>every day, laborers</b> must do so <b>twice a week, donkey drivers once a week, camel drivers once every thirty days,</b> and <b>sailors once every six months.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
