Noting that the first case in the <i>baraita</i> is where a man betrothed a woman in error, Abaye asks: <b>But here</b> in this <i>baraita</i>, <b>where</b> the first case <b>is an error</b> concerning <b>one woman, and</b> the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda <b>disagree; what, is it not that</b> the intention of the phrase: <b>Betrothed</b> her in error, is referring to an <b>error</b> in the condition with regard to <b>vows,</b> where he mistakenly believed she didn’t have any vows incumbent upon her? This would constitute a refutation of Rabba’s statement that all agree that in a case of an error concerning one woman she is betrothed.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> here it is referring to a halakhic <b>error,</b> that he betrothed a woman with an item worth <b>less than the value of a <i>peruta</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: Concerning the case where the betrothal is with an item worth <b>less than the value of a <i>peruta</i>,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches it explicitly</b> as a separate case with the following words: If <b>he betrothed her in error, or</b> if he betrothed her with an item worth <b>less than the value of a <i>peruta</i>.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is explaining</b> what it stated earlier: <b>What is</b> the case of one who <b>betrothed her in error? For example, when he betrothed her with</b> an item worth <b>less than the value of a <i>peruta</i>,</b> as he did not engage in sexual intercourse with her based on such a betrothal.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>a person knows that betrothal does not take effect with</b> an item worth <b>less than the value of a <i>peruta</i>. Consequently,</b> he <b>decides to engage in sexual intercourse for the purpose of betrothal</b> and therefore acquires the woman as his wife through these relations. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that <b>a person does not know that betrothal does not take effect with</b> an item worth <b>less than the value of a <i>peruta</i>, and when he</b> later <b>engages in sexual intercourse, he does so on the basis of the original betrothal,</b> so no new betrothal takes place.
Abaye again <b>raised an objection to</b> Rabba’s statement from a <i>baraita</i>: If a man said to a woman: <b>I am engaging in sexual intercourse with you</b> for the purpose of betrothal <b>on condition that</b> my <b>father will desire</b> our betrothal, and then he married her without specification, <b>although the father did not desire</b> it, <b>she is</b> nevertheless <b>betrothed</b> through this act of intercourse. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon:</b> If <b>the father desires</b> it, <b>she is betrothed,</b> and if <b>the father does not desire</b> it, <b>she is not betrothed,</b> since he engaged in intercourse with her based on the initial condition. <b>But here it is similar to a mistake</b> concerning <b>one woman, and they disagree</b> whether the betrothal is valid.
The Gemara responds: <b>There, they disagree about this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds that: On condition that</b> my <b>father will desire</b> it, means: <b>On condition that</b> my <b>father is silent. Consequently,</b> if his father does not protest, the betrothal is valid, <b>and he was</b> indeed <b>silent about it. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that it means: <b>On condition that</b> my <b>father says yes, and he did not say yes.</b> Therefore, the dispute is about the significance of the father’s silence in this case.
Abaye again <b>raised an objection to</b> Rabba’s statement from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Rabbis concede to Rabbi Eliezer concerning a minor girl who was married off by her father and</b> then <b>divorced</b> while she was still a minor, <b>and is</b> therefore treated by the <i>halakha</i> as <b>an orphan in the lifetime of the father,</b> since the <i>halakha</i> is that the father is no longer able to marry her off to someone else, <b>and</b> while she was still a minor, her former husband <b>remarried her,</b> and he then died without children, <b>that she performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and may not</b> instead <b>enter into levirate marriage.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: This is <b>because her divorce was a full-fledged divorce,</b> since the father has authority to receive her bill of divorce from her husband, <b>and her return</b> to her husband afterward <b>is not a full-fledged return,</b> since she remarries her husband while still a minor, and her father no longer has authority to marry her off, and marriage to a minor girl by her own consent is not considered a full-fledged marriage. She is consequently prohibited from entering into a levirate marriage based on the prohibition against a divorcée marrying her former husband’s brother.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? When he divorced her while she was</b> still <b>a minor girl and</b> then <b>remarried her while she was</b> still <b>a minor girl. But</b> if <b>he divorced her while she was</b> still <b>a minor girl, and</b> then <b>remarried her when she was an adult woman, or</b> if <b>he remarried her while she was</b> still <b>a minor girl and she became an adult woman</b> while married <b>to him,</b> the second marriage is binding, and she has the status of a full-fledged married woman. <b>And</b> therefore, if <b>he died, either she performs <i>ḥalitza</i> or she enters into levirate marriage</b> like any other widow.

Daf 74a

<b>In the name of Rabbi Eliezer they said</b> that even in this case <b>she performs <i>ḥalitza</i>, but she may not enter into levirate marriage.</b> This dispute seems to hinge on whether, when he engaged in sexual intercourse with her as an adult, he did so for the purpose of betrothal, or whether he relied upon the invalid betrothal performed when she was a minor. <b>But here,</b> this should be considered <b>similar to an error</b> concerning <b>one woman, and</b> yet they <b>disagree.</b>
The Gemara refutes this claim: This is not the nature of the disagreement. Rather, <b>there too</b> they <b>disagree</b> over a possible halakhic error: One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>a person knows that the betrothal of a minor girl is nothing, and</b> consequently, after she reaches adulthood, <b>he decides to engage in sexual intercourse for the purpose of betrothal.</b> Therefore, if the husband dies she may enter into levirate marriage. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds that a person does not know that the betrothal of a minor girl is nothing, and</b> therefore <b>when he engages in sexual intercourse</b> with her after she reaches adulthood, <b>he does so on the basis of the initial betrothal,</b> which is not effective according to Torah law, and therefore she cannot enter into levirate marriage.
<b>It was also stated</b> in accordance with Rabba’s opinion, that there is no dispute with regard to an error concerning one woman: <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who betrothed</b> a woman <b>conditionally and engaged in sexual intercourse</b> without specifying that he is voiding the condition, <b>all agree</b> that <b>she does not require a bill of divorce from him. Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, son of</b> Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov’s <b>sister, raised an objection to</b> his opinion from a <i>baraita</i> that states: <b>A mistaken <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid.</b> The <i>amora’im</i> asked: <b>What is</b> meant by the term: <b>A mistaken <i>ḥalitza</i>? Reish Lakish said: Any</b> situation <b>when</b> someone <b>says to</b> a man whose married brother died childless [<i>yavam</i>] not well versed in <i>halakha</i>: <b>Perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with her and by</b> doing <b>so you will</b> thereby <b>marry her.</b> Although he did not intend to release their bond with this <i>ḥalitza</i>, it is nevertheless effective.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: I teach</b> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>ḥalitza</i>: <b>Whether he intended</b> to release her through <i>ḥalitza</i> <b>and she did not intend</b> it, or <b>whether she intended</b> this outcome <b>and he did not intend</b> it, <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i> is invalid;</b> it will always be invalid <b>until they both intend</b> the appropriate outcome. <b>And you say</b> that in that case, when he intended to marry her and not to release her, that <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid? Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that in fact, in such a case, the <i>ḥalitza</i> would be invalid, and the term: A mistaken <i>ḥalitza</i>, concerns <b>any</b> situation <b>where</b> someone <b>says to</b> the <i>yavam</i>: <b>Perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with her on condition that she gives you two hundred dinars</b> as payment, and afterward she refuses to give him the money.
The Gemara returns to our issue: <b>Apparently,</b> it can be seen from here that <b>since he performed an action,</b> the <i>halakha</i> views this as though <b>he</b> explicitly <b>waived his condition,</b> for although he stipulated a condition, once he actually performs <i>ḥalitza</i> the condition is ignored. If so, <b>here too,</b> with regard to a conditional betrothal, <b>since he engaged in sexual intercourse, he has waived his condition,</b> which contradicts Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov’s view.
<b>He said to him: Student of the academy,</b> have <b>you spoken well?</b> The reason why the <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid is not because he waived his condition, but rather because the condition was invalid to begin with. <b>After all, from where</b> do <b>we learn</b> through tradition <b>all</b> the laws of <b>conditions? From the conditions</b> made with <b>the descendants of Gad and the descendants of Reuben.</b> Moses made a condition with the tribes of Gad and Reuben: If they would go with the rest of the nation to fight in the battles for the land of Canaan on the western side of the Jordan, they would receive their inheritance on the eastern side, as they requested (see Numbers, chapter 32).
The Gemara derives the <i>halakhot</i> of contractual conditions from that incident, and these include the rule that <b>a condition that can be fulfilled by means of an agent, as</b> was done <b>there,</b> when Moses transferred responsibility for implementing the condition to Joshua and the Elders, and such <b>a condition is</b> a valid <b>condition.</b> Whereas a condition <b>that cannot be fulfilled by means of an agent as</b> was done <b>there is not</b> a valid <b>condition.</b> Accordingly, since <i>ḥalitza</i> cannot be performed by means of an agent, the condition is of no effect and the <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid. There is therefore no proof from here that a husband who performs an action waives his condition.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But sexual intercourse</b> is something <b>that cannot be fulfilled by means of an agent as</b> was done <b>there,</b> in the case of the descendants of Gad and the descendants of Reuben, <b>and</b> yet <b>it is</b> considered a valid <b>condition.</b> If a man says that he is engaging in intercourse with a woman for the purpose of betrothal on condition that a certain stipulation be fulfilled, if that condition is broken the betrothal is invalid.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of betrothal, there is a special reason for this law, <b>because</b> the different ways of <b>becoming</b> betrothed <b>are juxtaposed to each other.</b> The Torah describes betrothal with the term becoming, as in the expression: “And she becomes another man’s wife” (Deuteronomy 24:2). Betrothal can be performed through the transference of money or an item of value, through a document, or through sexual intercourse. All three forms are juxtaposed with one another. Conditions can be stipulated for betrothal performed via transference of money or through a document, since these methods of betrothal can be fulfilled through an agent. Therefore, a condition may also be stipulated for betrothal through sexual intercourse, although that cannot be fulfilled through an agent.
<b>Rav Ulla bar Abba said</b> that <b>Ulla said</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> In the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan</b> by forgiving a debt she owes him, which does not effect betrothal, <b>and</b> subsequently <b>engages in sexual intercourse</b> with her; or one who betroths a woman <b>conditionally</b> and the condition was not fulfilled, <b>and</b> he subsequently <b>engages in sexual intercourse</b> with her; or one who betroths a woman <b>with</b> an item worth <b>less than the value of a <i>peruta</i>, and</b> he subsequently <b>engages in sexual intercourse</b> with her, in all of these cases, <b>all agree</b> that <b>she requires a bill of divorce from him.</b> Although the initial betrothal was invalid, they are betrothed due to the subsequent sexual intercourse.
<b>Rav Yosef bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Menaḥem said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami said:</b> In the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with</b> an item worth <b>less than the value of a <i>peruta</i> and</b> subsequently <b>engages in sexual intercourse</b> with her, <b>she requires a bill of divorce from him.</b> This is because <b>it is in this</b> matter <b>that he does not err.</b> He knows that betrothal must be performed with an item worth at least a <i>peruta</i>, and he therefore must have engaged in intercourse with her for the purpose of betrothal. <b>But with regard to</b> those <b>other</b> cases, i.e., a loan or a condition, he does <b>err.</b> He engages in intercourse based upon his initial betrothal, and therefore she does not require a bill of divorce.
<b>Rav Kahana said in the name of Ulla:</b> In the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>conditionally</b> and the condition was not fulfilled, <b>and</b> he subsequently <b>engages in sexual intercourse</b> with her, <b>she requires a bill of divorce from him,</b> in accordance with Rabbi Elazar. The Gemara relates: <b>This was an incident</b> that actually occurred. A man betrothed a woman conditionally and then engaged in sexual intercourse with her without specification, <b>and the Sages did not have</b> the <b>power to allow her to leave</b> her husband <b>without a bill of divorce,</b> since they could not definitively rule that the betrothal was invalid. Therefore, they forced him to give her a bill of divorce.
The Gemara comments: This statement comes <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of this <i>tanna</i>,</b> as <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Yishmael:</b> The verse states with regard to a woman suspected by her husband of having been unfaithful [<i>sota</i>]: <b>“And she was not seized”</b> (Numbers 5:13), i.e., she was not raped. That is, she is <b>forbidden</b> to her husband since she willingly committed adultery with another man. <b>Consequently,</b> a woman who in fact <b>was seized</b> is <b>permitted</b> to her husband. <b>And you have another</b> woman <b>who, although she was not seized</b> but rather engaged in sexual intercourse willingly, is nevertheless <b>permitted</b> to her husband and is not considered a <i>sota</i>. <b>And who is this?</b> This is referring to one <b>whose betrothal was a mistaken betrothal, as even if her son</b> from this marriage <b>is riding on her shoulders,</b>

Daf 74b

<b>she may refuse</b> her husband <b>and go</b> on <b>her</b> way. According to this opinion, the marriage did not take effect at all, despite the fact that they engaged in sexual intercourse, because the betrothal involved an error.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> If a man betroths a woman on condition that there are no vows incumbent upon her to fulfill, but there are vows incumbent upon her, and <b>she goes to a halakhic authority and he dissolves her</b> vows, <b>she is betrothed.</b> However, if he betroths her on condition that she has no blemishes, but she does have blemishes, and she goes <b>to a doctor and he heals her</b> blemishes, <b>she is not betrothed.</b> The Gemara inquires: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between a halakhic authority and a doctor?</b> The Gemara explains: When <b>a halakhic authority</b> dissolves a vow, he <b>uproots the vow retroactively.</b> It is as if she had never vowed at all, and therefore she was in fact not bound by vows at the time of their betrothal. <b>But a doctor only heals from here onward.</b> Since she had blemishes at the time of betrothal, she is in breach of his condition.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i> that if she goes <b>to a halakhic authority and he dissolves her</b> vows, or <b>to a doctor and he heals her</b> blemishes, <b>she is not betrothed? Rava said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> for <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> follows the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> and <b>that</b> one follows <b>Rabbi Elazar.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that if her vows were dissolved by a halakhic authority she is betrothed, is in accordance with <b>Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that <b>a man is willing for his wife to be degraded</b> by going <b>to court</b> to have her vow dissolved. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i> follows the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who said</b> that <b>a man is not willing for his wife to be degraded in court.</b> Consequently, even if she went to a halakhic authority and he dissolved her vows, such a solution is unacceptable to her husband, as he did not want her to go to court. Therefore, the betrothal is invalid even after the dissolution of the vow.
The Gemara poses a question: <b>What is</b> this fundamental dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Elazar? The Gemara answers: <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 45b): If a man <b>who divorces his wife due to a vow</b> that she took subsequently regrets his decision and wants to take her back, <b>he may not remarry</b> her. Similarly, if he divorces her <b>due to a bad reputation</b> she has acquired, <b>he may not remarry</b> her. This is because if he were allowed to take her back if the vow is dissolved by a halakhic authority or after discovering that the rumors about her were false, he might say that had he known this he never would have divorced her. Such a statement would retroactively cast doubt on the validity of the bill of divorce and could potentially cause her children from a second marriage to have the status of <i>mamzerim</i>. He is therefore informed that if he divorces her due to a vow or a bad reputation he can never remarry her.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>any vow that is known by many</b> people and therefore cannot be nullified, <b>he may not remarry</b> her. If <b>it is not known by many</b> people, but rather is a private matter between them, <b>he may remarry</b> her. <b>Rabbi Meir says: Any vow that requires investigation by a halakhic authority,</b> that is, the husband cannot nullify it himself and she needs a halakhic authority to analyze the vow carefully to find an opening that will permit its dissolution, <b>he may not remarry</b> her, for he can claim that had he known the vow could be dissolved he would never have divorced her, thereby undermining the bill of divorce. <b>And</b> with regard to a vow <b>that does not require the investigation by a halakhic authority,</b> which he knows he can nullify himself, <b>he may remarry</b> her. There is no concern that he might impair the bill of divorce, as he knew he could dissolve the vow and yet he chose to divorce her regardless.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says: Both</b> in the case of a vow that <b>requires</b> investigation by a halakhic authority <b>and one that does not require</b> it, <b>he may not remarry</b> her. <b>Rabbi Elazar said</b> in explanation of his view: <b>They prohibited</b> remarrying a woman who was bound by a vow that <b>requires</b> investigation by a halakhic authority <b>only due to</b> a vow <b>that does not require</b> such investigation. The Gemara explains the respective opinions: <b>What is the reason for Rabbi Yehuda’s</b> statement? <b>As it is written:</b>

Daf 75a

<b>“And the children of Israel did not smite them, for the princes of the assembly had sworn to them”</b> (Joshua 9:18), and since this oath was uttered in the presence of many people, it could not be rescinded, although it was undertaken in error because the Gibeonites had deceived the people of Israel. The Gemara poses a question: <b>And how many</b> people are considered <b>many</b> for the purposes of this law? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Three,</b> as can be learned from the laws of a woman who experiences a discharge of uterine blood after her menstrual period [<i>zava</i>]: <b>“Days”</b> indicates <b>two,</b> which is the minimal number justifying use of the plural noun. The term <b>“many</b> days” (Leviticus 15:25) therefore indicates a total of <b>three. Rabbi Yitzḥak said: Ten, as</b> the term <b>“assembly” is written in relation to the</b> Gibeonites, and it is taught elsewhere that an assembly is comprised of at least ten members.
The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> In the case of <b>any vow that requires investigation by a halakhic authority, he may not remarry</b> her. <b>Rabbi Elazar says: They prohibited</b> remarrying a woman who was bound by a vow that <b>requires</b> investigation by a halakhic authority <b>only due to</b> a vow <b>that does not require</b> such investigation. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle do <b>they disagree? Rabbi Meir holds</b> that <b>a man is willing for his wife to be degraded in court,</b> by going to have her vow dissolved. There is concern that the husband might say that had he known the vow could be dissolved he would not have divorced his wife. Such a claim would cast doubt on the validity of the bill of divorce. <b>Rabbi Elazar maintains</b> that <b>a man is not willing for his wife to be degraded in court</b> at all. Therefore, he cannot undermine the bill of divorce. The Sages prohibited him from remarrying her only due to a case that does not need investigation, as the husband can claim he did not know the vow could be dissolved.
Returning to the earlier discussion, <b>Rava said</b> a different explanation of the <i>baraita</i> that rules that if she went to a halakhic authority who dissolved her vow she is nevertheless not betrothed: <b>Here we are dealing with an important woman,</b> i.e., a woman from an important family. The husband does not want her due to her habit of vowing, but since she is from an important family he is reluctant to give her a bill of divorce, <b>as he says: It is not amenable to me to be forbidden to</b> all <b>her relatives.</b> He wants to retain ties of marriage with this family, and once he has married this woman, even if he divorces her, he will be forbidden to her mother or sisters. He therefore prefers that the betrothal be entirely dissolved.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> consider <b>the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>which teaches: But</b> if he betroths her on condition that there are no vows incumbent upon him or that he has no blemishes, and he does have vows or blemishes, but then <b>he goes to a halakhic authority and he dissolves his</b> vows, or <b>to a doctor and he heals him, she is betrothed.</b> Yet according to Rava, in that case too <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> that <b>she is not betrothed, and let</b> us likewise <b>say</b> that <b>here we are dealing with an important person,</b> from an important family, <b>as she says: It is not amenable to me to be forbidden to his relatives.</b>
The Gemara answers: There is a difference between a man and a woman in this regard, for <b>it is amenable to her</b> to be <b>with any</b> man, flawed though he may be, <b>as</b> taught by <b>Reish Lakish: As Reish Lakish said</b> that women say: <b>It is better to dwell</b> together <b>as two</b> [<b><i>tan du</i></b>] <b>than to dwell</b> alone as if <b>a widow.</b> Women will prefer any marriage to remaining single. Similarly, <b>Abaye said</b> that women say: One <b>whose husband is</b> small <b>as an ant,</b> nevertheless <b>places her seat among the noblewomen,</b> as she considers herself important by virtue of the mere fact that she is married.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> a different maxim expressing a similar idea: One <b>whose husband is a wool comber</b> [<b><i>nafsa</i></b>], a lowly occupation, <b>calls him to sit</b> with her <b>at the entrance to the house,</b> as she is proud of him and happy to be married. Similarly, <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> Even one <b>whose husband</b> is <b>lowly</b> [<b><i>kalsa</i></b>] <b>does not require lentils for her pot.</b> She is so happy with the simple fact that she is married that she does not mind even if he does not provide her with food. The Gemara comments that it is <b>taught: And all of these</b> women who have lowly husbands yet appear so satisfied with their marriage <b>commit adultery and attribute</b> the birth of the children <b>to their husbands.</b> This is another reason why they are so keen to be married.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>all blemishes that disqualify</b> priests disqualify women’s betrothal as well. The Sage <b>taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Ketubot</i> 87:9): <b>To these, they added</b> several additional blemishes applying only to women: <b>Sweat, a mole, and</b> a foul <b>odor from the mouth.</b> The Gemara poses a question: <b>And</b> do <b>these</b> blemishes <b>not</b> also <b>disqualify priests? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna with regard to blemishes of animals (<i>Bekhorot</i> 41a): <b>The old, the sick, and the filthy? And it was taught</b> in a different mishna (<i>Bekhorot</i> 43a): <b>These blemishes</b> stated concerning animals, <b>whether</b> they are <b>permanent</b> or <b>whether</b> they are <b>temporary,</b> render <b>people,</b> i.e., priests, <b>disqualified</b> as well. This shows that filth and sweat disqualify priests too.
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where the <i>baraita</i> states that these blemishes do not disqualify priests, it is referring to <b>removable sweat,</b> which can be washed off. <b>There,</b> the mishna that considers it is a disqualifying blemish for priests, it is speaking <b>of sweat that is not removable.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that the entire question is unsubstantiated. <b>Have you raised a contradiction between</b> a ruling concerning <b>sweat</b> and a ruling concerning <b>filth?</b> The term filthy indicates that there is a permanently foul odor, which disqualifies both animals and priests. But <b>there, with regard to priests</b> who suffer from foul odors due to sweat, <b>it is possible to remove it</b> in the short term <b>by</b> use of <b>wine vinegar. And</b> the priest can <b>also</b> temporarily cure himself <b>from</b> a foul <b>odor of the mouth,</b> as it is <b>possible to hold pepper in his mouth</b> to alleviate the odor <b>and</b> proceed to <b>perform the service. But with regard to a woman it is not possible</b> for her to utilize these remedies on a constant basis. Consequently, this blemish disqualifies women and not priests.
The <i>baraita</i> stated that a mole is a blemish for a woman but not for a priest. The Gemara poses a question: <b>What are the circumstances</b> with regard to <b>this mole? If it has hair</b> growing <b>in it,</b> both <b>here and there,</b> with regard to both women and priests, it <b>is disqualifying. If it does not have hair in it,</b> the following distinction applies: <b>If it is a large mole,</b> both <b>here and there</b> it <b>is disqualifying. If it is a small mole,</b> both <b>here and there</b> it <b>is not disqualifying, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A mole that has hair in it, this is a blemish.</b> With regard to one that <b>does not have a hair in it,</b> if it is <b>large, this is a blemish.</b> If it is <b>small, this is not a blemish.</b> The <i>tanna</i> proceeds to ask: <b>And what is</b> considered <b>large? Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel explained: As</b> large as the size <b>of an Italian <i>issar</i>,</b> a small coin.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> The case in the <i>baraita</i> discusses a mole <b>that is positioned on her forehead.</b> Despite the mole’s small size, its prominent location makes her appear very ugly. The Gemara asks: If it is on <b>her forehead, it is</b> something that he has <b>seen and accepted.</b> Since it is visible, he knew about it before agreeing to marry her. Therefore, he cannot later divorce her due to a blemish of this kind. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a mole <b>that is positioned under</b> the <b>cap</b> that is on top <b>of her head. Sometimes it is visible and sometimes it is not visible,</b> and he may not have seen it in advance. It is necessary to teach us that a mole of this kind is considered a blemish.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: I heard this matter from a great man, and who was</b> this great man? <b>Rabbi Sheila</b> was the great man. He said: If <b>a dog bit</b> a woman, <b>and the place</b> of the wound <b>developed into a scar, this is a blemish. Rav Ḥisda</b> further <b>said: A deep voice in a woman, this is a blemish, as it is stated: “For your voice is sweet and your appearance pleasant”</b> (Song of Songs 2:14). <b>Rabbi Natan Bira’a taught: A handbreadth between a woman’s breasts.</b> The <i>amora’im</i> have a dispute concerning the meaning of Rabbi Natan Bira’a’s statement: <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, thought to say before Rav Ashi</b> that this means <b>a handbreadth</b> between a woman’s breasts <b>is perfection</b> and considered beautiful. <b>Rav Ashi said to him:</b> This <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught with regard to blemishes,</b> and it means that if her breasts are separated by a gap this wide, it is a blemish. The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> of a gap is considered normal? <b>Abaye said:</b> The width of <b>three fingers.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Natan says: Any woman whose breasts are larger than those of other</b> women, <b>this is a blemish.</b> The Gemara poses a question: <b>And how much</b> larger must they be to be considered a blemish? <b>Rabbi Meyasha, son of the son of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi:</b> If they are <b>a handbreadth</b> larger than the norm. The Gemara inquires: <b>And is there a case like this?</b> Is it possible for a woman to have such large breasts? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, as Rabba bar bar Ḥanna said: I</b> once <b>saw a certain Arab woman who flung her breasts behind her and nursed her child.</b>
§ Since the Gemara quoted a statement of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi’s grandson, the Gemara cites another exposition in his name. The verse states: <b>“And of Zion it shall be said, this man and this man were born in her, and the Most High shall establish her”</b> (Psalms 87:5). <b>Rabbi Meyasha, son of the son of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, said: Both the</b> man who was actually <b>born in</b> Zion <b>and</b> the <b>one who looks forward to seeing her</b> are equally considered sons of Zion. <b>Abaye said: And one of</b> the inhabitants of Eretz Yisrael <b>is superior to two of us,</b> Babylonians. <b>Rava said: And one of us</b> Babylonians, <b>when he ascends to</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>is superior to two</b> people born and raised in Eretz Yisrael. The Gemara cites a proof for Rava’s claim: <b>As Rabbi Yirmeya, when he was here,</b> in Babylonia, <b>did not</b> even <b>know what the Sages say.</b> He was not considered an important scholar. But <b>when he ascended there,</b> it was <b>he</b>, and not the other Sages of Eretz Yisrael, who <b>called us foolish Babylonians</b>. Evidently, he became even greater than they were.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>she has blemishes and she is still in her father’s house,</b> as she has not yet gotten married, <b>the father must bring proof that these blemishes appeared on her after she became betrothed, and</b> therefore <b>his field was flooded,</b> i.e., it is the husband’s misfortune, since she developed the problem after the betrothal. But if she has already gotten married and <b>entered the husband’s domain</b> when her blemishes are discovered, <b>the husband must bring proof that she had these blemishes before she was betrothed, and</b> consequently <b>the transaction</b> of betrothal <b>was a mistaken transaction.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. But the Rabbis say: In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that a husband can claim to have found blemishes in his wife, on account of which he wants to void the betrothal, <b>said? With regard to hidden blemishes.</b>

Daf 75b

<b>But with regard to visible blemishes, he cannot claim</b> that the betrothal was in error, as he presumably saw and accepted them before the betrothal. <b>And if there is a bathhouse in the city,</b> where all the women go to bathe, <b>even</b> with regard to <b>hidden blemishes he cannot</b> make this <b>claim, because he examines her through</b> the agency of <b>his female relatives.</b> He would have asked one of his relatives to look over the woman he is about to marry.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that if the woman had blemishes while she was in her father’s house, the father must bring proof that they developed after the betrothal. The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> the father’s claim is accepted is due to the fact <b>that the father brings proof, but if the father does not bring proof</b> then <b>the husband is deemed credible</b> when he claims the betrothal was a mistaken transaction because the blemishes predated it. The Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this mishna? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, who said</b> in a mishna (12a) with regard to a case when the wife claims that she was raped after her betrothal while her husband says it happened beforehand, that <b>we don’t live from,</b> i.e., we don’t rely on the words of <b>her mouth,</b> but rather she must substantiate her claim.
The Gemara continues: Now <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: If she had <b>entered the husband’s domain, the husband must bring proof.</b> Again the Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> his claim is accepted <b>is</b> due to the fact <b>that the husband brings proof, but if the husband does not bring proof</b> then <b>the father is deemed credible. We arrive at</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel, who said</b> that the woman is <b>deemed credible</b> when she says that the incident occurred after the betrothal. Consequently, the first and last clauses of the mishna appear to contradict one another. <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> This mishna is <b>disjointed,</b> and does not follow a single opinion; the <i>tanna</i> <b>who taught this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>did not teach that</b> <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rava said: Do not say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua does not follow the presumptive status of the body at all,</b> that is, it should not be assumed that Rabbi Yehoshua fundamentally rejects the idea that one’s body is presumed to remain in its initial, intact state until proven otherwise. <b>Rather,</b> say <b>that Rabbi Yehoshua does not follow the presumptive status of the body</b> only <b>when there is an</b> opposing claim of <b>monetary possession.</b> An example of this is the case in the mishna where the woman seeks to extract money from her husband for payment of her marriage contract by claiming that she was raped after the betrothal. Since acceptance of her claim would mean her husband has to pay, Rabbi Yehoshua maintains that the presumptive status of her body alone is not sufficient.
<b>But when there is no possession of money,</b> as in the mishna, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua</b> does in fact <b>follow the presumptive status of the body. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the halakhot of leprosy: <b>If</b> the <b>bright white</b> leprous <b>spot preceded the white hair</b> then the one afflicted is <b>ritually impure; if the white hair preceded the bright white spot</b> he is <b>pure.</b> If it is <b>uncertain</b> which came first, he is <b>impure. And Rabbi Yehoshua says: Dull.</b> They asked: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>dull? Rabba said</b> that <b>dull</b> means it is <b>ritually pure,</b> as though the plague was of a dull shade, which is not impure. This shows that in an uncertain case where there is no issue of monetary possession, Rabbi Yehoshua accepts the presumptive status of the body, and therefore, the one afflicted is ritually pure.
<b>Rava said</b> a different answer to the contradiction in the mishna: In the <b>first clause</b> of the mishna, where the blemishes were discovered while she was still in her father’s house, the assumption is that since <b>they were discovered here, they were</b> also created <b>here.</b> In other words, since the blemishes were found while she was still in her father’s house, there is a presumption that they were also present at the earlier stage, prior to the betrothal. Consequently, the burden of proof is on the father who claims the blemishes developed at a later stage. In the <b>latter clause</b> of the mishna <b>as well,</b> since the blemishes were discovered when she was in the husband’s house, it is assumed that since <b>they were discovered here,</b> in the husband’s domain, <b>they were</b> also created <b>here,</b> after the marriage.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rava’s opinion from the mishna: If she had <b>entered the husband’s domain</b> when the blemishes were discovered, <b>the husband must bring proof that she had these blemishes before she was betrothed, and</b> therefore <b>his transaction</b> of betrothal <b>was a mistaken transaction.</b> The Gemara infers: If he brought proof that these blemishes were there <b>before she was betrothed</b> then <b>yes,</b> his claim is accepted, but if he proved that the blemishes were present <b>from</b> a point in time after <b>she was betrothed,</b> even if she was still in her father’s house, his claim is <b>not</b> accepted. <b>But why?</b> Even if his proof concerns the period after the betrothal, <b>let us say</b> that since <b>they were discovered here, they were</b> also created <b>here,</b> and she presumably had these blemishes before the betrothal.
Rava <b>said to him:</b> With regard to a case where the blemishes were found to have been present <b>from</b> a point in time after <b>she was betrothed,</b> there is a reason why one does not assume that they were there beforehand: <b>Because it can be said</b> that there is <b>a presumption</b> that <b>a person does not drink from a cup unless he</b> first <b>examines it.</b> In other words, one does not betroth a woman unless he first investigates her to determine if she is acceptable to him. <b>And</b> consequently <b>this</b> man <b>has</b> undoubtedly <b>seen</b> her blemishes <b>and been appeased</b> about them. Therefore, in the event that the blemishes did exist at the time of betrothal, it can be assumed that the husband knew about them and accepted the situation.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If that is so,</b> then even if he brought proof that the blemishes existed <b>before she was betrothed,</b> we should <b>also</b> rely on the above presumption and say that he must have been aware of them and betrothed her regardless. But this is not the <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>we say</b> there is an opposing <b>presumption</b> that <b>a person does not become appeased with regard to blemishes.</b> Therefore, it must be proven that he saw these blemishes and did not object. <b>Here too,</b> we should say there is a <b>presumption</b> that <b>a person does not become appeased with regard to blemishes.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the mishna must be explained differently: If he brought proof that she had these blemishes <b>from</b> a point in time after <b>she was betrothed,</b> his claim of a mistaken betrothal is not accepted <b>because there are two</b> presumptions opposing it. There is a <b>presumption</b> of: <b>Establish the</b> state of the woman’s <b>body</b> according <b>to its presumptive,</b> unblemished <b>status</b> and consequently assume that the blemishes were not present at the time of betrothal, <b>and</b> additionally there is the <b>presumption</b> that <b>a person does not drink from a cup unless he</b> first <b>examines it, and this</b> man <b>has</b> undoubtedly <b>seen</b> her blemishes <b>and been appeased. What do you say</b> in opposition to this argument, that there is a <b>presumption</b> that <b>a man does not become appeased with regard to blemishes?</b> Even so, <b>it is</b>

Daf 76a

<b>one</b> presumption <b>opposed by two</b> others. <b>And we do not say</b> that <b>one</b> presumption is decisive when it is <b>opposed by two.</b> However, if the husband brings proof that that she was blemished <b>before she was betrothed, we cannot say: Establish the</b> state of the woman’s <b>body</b> according <b>to its presumptive status,</b> since it has been established that the blemishes existed prior to the betrothal. <b>What</b> claim <b>is there</b> in the woman’s favor? Only the <b>presumption that a person does not drink from a cup unless he</b> first <b>examines it, and this</b> man <b>has</b> undoubtedly <b>seen</b> her blemishes <b>and been appeased.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>On the contrary,</b> there is a <b>presumption</b> that <b>a person does not become appeased with regard to blemishes, and</b> therefore the <b>money is established</b> according <b>to its presumptive status</b> and we do not obligate the husband to pay for the marriage contract.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that the contradiction between the first and last clauses of the mishna can be resolved in the following manner: The <b>first clause</b> is similar to a claim made by one who says: My <b>father has one hundred dinars in your possession.</b> When the blemishes were discovered he had not yet married her, and therefore the payment for the marriage contract would go to the woman’s father, and not to her. <b>And the latter clause</b> is referring to a married woman who claims the marriage contract for herself, and it is therefore as though she says: <b>I have one hundred dinars in your possession.</b> The presumptive status of her body enables her to claim money only for herself, not on behalf of someone else, including her father.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, raised an objection to Rav Ashi’s</b> opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Meir concedes with regard to blemishes that naturally come with her from her father’s house,</b> and which did not develop after the marriage, <b>that the father must bring proof</b> that she did not have them before the betrothal, even if she was already married when they were discovered. <b>But why</b> does Rabbi Meir agree in that case? <b>It is</b> similar to the case where someone says: <b>I have one hundred dinars in your possession,</b> along with the presumptive status of her body; therefore, the burden of proof should be upon the husband.
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here? With</b> a case of a woman who has <b>an additional</b> toe. She was obviously born with that blemish. The Gemara is puzzled by this response: If the <i>baraita</i> is speaking about <b>an additional</b> toe, <b>what proof</b> could the father possibly <b>bring</b> to argue that the toe grew after the marriage? The Gemara answers: He can provide <b>proof that</b> the husband <b>saw</b> the extra toe before the betrothal <b>and he became appeased</b> about it.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to one <b>who exchanges a cow for a donkey,</b> where the two animals involved in this transaction are not in the same location, one of the parties acquires one of the animals by means of pulling it, which transfers the other animal to the other party through acquisition by means of the exchange. <b>And</b> in this case <b>the owner of the donkey pulled the cow, but before the owner of the cow could pull the donkey</b> in turn, <b>the donkey died.</b> The owner of the cow claimed that the donkey died before the other one pulled the cow, which means the exchange transaction never took effect. In that case, <b>the owner of the donkey must bring proof that his donkey was alive at the time when the cow was pulled.</b> If he is unable to bring proof to this effect, the owner of the cow retains his animal.
Rav Yehuda adds: <b>And the <i>tanna</i></b> of the mishna also <b>taught</b> along similar lines with regard to <b>a bride.</b> Shmuel learned this <i>halakha</i> concerning an acquisition by means of barter from the case of a bride. The Gemara inquires: <b>Which</b> <i>halakha</i> involving <b>a bride</b> serves as the basis for the <i>halakha</i> that Shmuel taught? <b>If we say</b>

Daf 76b

that his proof is from the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a bride</b> who is still <b>in her father’s house,</b> when the burden of proof is upon the father, <b>is</b> it <b>comparable? There, the father brings proof and takes</b> money away from the husband, whereas <b>here, the owner of the donkey brings proof and maintains</b> possession of the cow. Consequently, perhaps this case is different, and he should not be obliged to provide proof.
<b>Rabbi Abba said:</b> The proof is from the case of <b>a bride in her father-in-law’s house,</b> that is, one who has entered her husband’s domain. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>And</b> yet the cases <b>are still not comparable: There, the husband brings proof and undermines the presumption</b> that was in favor <b>of the father,</b> i.e., the presumptive status of the daughter’s body, whereas <b>here, the owner of the donkey brings proof and</b> thereby <b>maintains the presumptive status</b> of the donkey’s body and consequently maintains the cow <b>in his possession.</b> Perhaps, therefore, he should not have to bring proof.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> Shmuel’s proof is from the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a bride in her father’s house, but with regard to</b> the money used for <b>betrothal,</b> not for the marriage contract. The father must bring proof in order to retain the betrothal money.
Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak explains: <b>And do not say</b> that this is only <b>according to the one who says</b> in general that <b>betrothal</b> money <b>was not given</b> with the understanding that it is <b>to be lost,</b> that is, the money was handed over only for the purpose of betrothal and it must be returned if the betrothal is canceled. <b>Rather,</b> say that this is <b>even according to the one who says</b> that in the case of <b>betrothal</b> money that <b>was given to be lost, this applies only</b> to <b>a betrothal</b> whose status is <b>certain.</b> According to this opinion, if a husband later divorces his wife or dies she does not have to restore the betrothal money. <b>But</b> with regard to a <b>mistaken betrothal, if</b> the father <b>brings proof</b> then <b>yes,</b> he may keep the money; <b>if</b> he does <b>not</b> bring proof he may <b>not</b> retain ownership of the betrothal money. This supports Shmuel’s opinion that in an uncertain case the one in possession of the money must bring proof in order to retain his ownership.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Shmuel’s opinion with regard to presumptions from a <i>baraita</i> about a different issue: In a case of <b>a needle that is found in the thick wall of</b> a slaughtered animal’s <b>second stomach,</b> if it has pierced the stomach <b>from</b> only <b>one side,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b> If the stomach is pierced <b>from both sides,</b> meaning that the needle pierced a hole completely through the wall of the stomach, it has the status of <b>an animal with a condition that will cause it to die within twelve months</b> [<b><i>tereifa</i></b>], and one is consequently prohibited to eat from it. Furthermore, if <b>a drop of</b> congealed <b>blood is found on top of</b> the needle, <b>it is certain that</b> the perforation was created <b>before</b> the <b>slaughtering</b> of the animal, and it is therefore a <i>tereifa</i>. If <b>no drop of blood is found on it, it is certain that it</b> occurred <b>after</b> the <b>slaughtering,</b> which means the animal is kosher.
If <b>a scab appeared over the wound</b> on that spot, <b>it is certain that</b> the incident happened <b>three days before</b> the <b>slaughtering.</b> The significance of this fact is that if the animal was sold to a butcher after this point in time, the butcher can claim that the transaction was performed in error, as he did not intend to purchase a <i>tereifa</i> animal. If <b>a scab did not appear over the wound,</b> and the seller claims that the animal was injured while in the possession of the butcher who purchased the animal, while the butcher claims that it was wounded when he bought it, <b>the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. And</b> therefore, <b>if</b> the <b>butcher had</b> already <b>given the money, he needs to bring proof and</b> then he can <b>take</b> his money back from the seller.
The Gemara returns to Shmuel’s opinion: <b>But why</b> should this be the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Let</b> the <b>owner of the animal,</b> i.e., the seller, <b>bring proof and establish</b> the validity of the sale, just as the owner of the donkey must provide proof in order to maintain possession of the cow. Why is the burden of proof upon the butcher?
The Gemara answers: This <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where the butcher had not</b> yet <b>given</b> the <b>money,</b> but was going to pay at a later time. Therefore, the seller is the one claiming money from the butcher, and he must offer proof in order for the transaction to be upheld. The Gemara poses a question: <b>Why</b> was it stated <b>without qualification?</b> The wording of the <i>baraita</i> implies that either side must bring proof. This <i>baraita</i> appears to refute the opinion of Shmuel.
<b>Rather, when Rami bar Yeḥezkel came, he said: Pay no attention to those rules formulated by my brother Yehuda in the name of Shmuel.</b> In actuality, <b>this is</b> what <b>Shmuel said:</b> In <b>whosesoever’s domain the uncertainty came into being, the burden of proof rests upon him.</b> In the case of the exchange of the cow for the donkey, it is the owner of the cow who must provide proof. <b>And the <i>tanna</i></b> of the mishna also <b>taught</b> along similar lines with regard to <b>a bride.</b> If the bride was in her father’s domain he must provide proof; if she was living with her husband the burden of proof is upon him.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection: A needle that is found in the thick wall of</b> an animal’s <b>second stomach…</b>the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. <b>And if</b> the <b>butcher had not</b> already <b>given the money,</b> the <b>owner of the animal needs to bring proof, and</b> only then can he <b>take</b> his money. The Gemara asks: <b>But why? The uncertainty was formed in</b> the <b>butcher’s possession.</b> According to Rami Bar Yeḥezkel’s opinion, it should be the butcher’s responsibility to provide proof.
The Gemara answers: This <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where the butcher had</b> already <b>given the money.</b> Since the butcher is the one demanding money from the seller, he must provide proof. The Gemara poses a question: <b>But why</b> was it stated <b>without qualification?</b> How is it known that the <i>tanna</i> was referring to this particular case? The Gemara answers: <b>The ordinary situation</b> is that <b>as long as a person has not given money,</b> the other <b>person will not give</b> him <b>the animal.</b> It can therefore be assumed that the butcher paid for the animal before he was allowed to slaughter it, which means it is he who is claiming the return of the money.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And the Rabbis say: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? With regard to hidden blemishes.</b> But he cannot claim to have been unaware of visible blemishes. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b>

Daf 77a

<b>And an epileptic is considered like a hidden blemish,</b> for it is possible that nobody is aware of her ailment. The Gemara comments: <b>And this applies</b> only <b>if</b> the sickness comes <b>at regular intervals,</b> as the woman and her family can conceal her illness. <b>But</b> if the attacks do <b>not</b> appear <b>at regular</b> intervals and can occur at any time, this <b>is considered like a visible blemish,</b> as it is impossible that her condition is unknown to others.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a man who developed blemishes</b> after marriage, the court <b>does not force him to divorce</b> his wife. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to minor blemishes. However, with regard to major blemishes,</b> which will be defined later in the Gemara, the court <b>does force him to divorce</b> her.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda teaches</b> the mishna in accordance with the version quoted above: The man <b>developed</b> blemishes after marrying his wife. Conversely, <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav teaches:</b> The man <b>had</b> blemishes prior to the marriage. The Gemara clarifies the difference between the two opinions: <b>The one who says</b> that the man who <b>developed</b> blemishes after marriage does not have to divorce his wife says that the same <i>halakha</i> applies <b>all the more so</b> to one who <b>had</b> blemishes beforehand, <b>as she was aware</b> of them <b>and accepted</b> them. However, <b>the one who says</b> that the mishna is referring to one who <b>had</b> blemishes prior to his marriage would say that only in that case he is not compelled to divorce her, <b>but</b> if <b>they developed</b> after the marriage this is <b>not</b> the <i>halakha</i>, as she did not marry him under such conditions.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> This is said <b>with regard to minor blemishes, but with regard to major blemishes</b> the court <b>forces him to divorce</b> her. The Gemara poses a question: <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that the correct version is: <b>Developed</b> blemishes, <b>this is</b> the reason <b>that there is a difference between major and minor</b> blemishes, as only major blemishes are grounds for divorce. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that the correct version is: <b>Had</b> blemishes, <b>what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> whether they were <b>major</b> blemishes, and <b>what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> whether they were <b>minor</b> ones? Either way, <b>she was aware</b> of them <b>and accepted</b> them.
The Gemara answers: In the case of major blemishes she can claim <b>that she</b> initially <b>thought that she could accept</b> a husband with such blemishes, <b>but now</b> that she is married she realizes that she <b>cannot accept</b> such an arrangement. The Gemara inquires: <b>And what are</b> these <b>major blemishes</b> of a husband that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel considers grounds for divorce? <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel explained: For example,</b> if <b>his eye was blinded,</b> or <b>his hand cut off, or his leg broken.</b>
<b>It was stated: Rabbi Abba bar Yaakov</b> said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. Rava</b> said that <b>Rav Naḥman said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis</b> that there is no difference between minor and major blemishes.
The Gemara poses a question: <b>And did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say so,</b> that the <i>halakha</i> follows Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel? <b>But Rabba bar bar Ḥanna said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Wherever Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel taught in our Mishna, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with him, apart from</b> three cases: The <i>halakha</i> of <b>a guarantor</b> (<i>Bava Batra</i> 173b); the <i>halakha</i> he stated with regard to the divorce case in <b>Sidon</b> (<i>Gittin</i> 74a); and the <b>latter</b> of his disputes with the Rabbis with regard to the halakhot of <b>evidence</b> (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 31a). Since Rabbi Yoḥanan issued a statement that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel in all but three exceptional cases, why would it be necessary for him to issue a special ruling in the present discussion? The Gemara answers: <b>They are <i>amora’im</i>, and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> Rabbi Abba bar Yaakov maintains that Rabbi Yoḥanan did not issue a general directive, but rather provided a separate ruling for each case.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these</b> are the defects <b>for which</b> the court <b>forces him to divorce</b> her: One <b>afflicted with boils; or one who has a polyp; or one who</b> works as <b>a gatherer, or one who</b> works as <b>a melder of copper, or one who</b> works as <b>a tanner</b> of hides, all of whose work involves handling foul-smelling materials. <b>Whether</b> he <b>had</b> these defects <b>before they</b> got <b>married, or whether they developed after they</b> got <b>married,</b> the court forces them to divorce. <b>And with regard to all of these, Rabbi Meir said: Even though he stipulated with her</b> ahead of time that he suffers from this particular ailment or this is his line of work, <b>she can</b> nevertheless demand a divorce and <b>say: I thought I could accept</b> this issue <b>but now</b> I realize <b>I cannot accept</b> it.
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> If she initially agreed <b>she must accept it against her will, apart from</b> a situation in which her husband is <b>afflicted with boils.</b> In that case the Rabbis concede that he must divorce her, <b>because</b> the disease <b>consumes</b> his flesh when they engage in marital relations. The mishna relates an additional account: <b>An incident</b> occurred <b>in Sidon involving a certain tanner who died</b> childless, <b>and he had a brother</b> who was also <b>a tanner.</b> This brother was required to enter into levirate marriage with the widow. <b>The Sages said: She can say: I could accept</b> living with a tanner <b>for your brother but I cannot accept it for you,</b> and therefore he must perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with her.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara inquires about several unclear terms which appear in the mishna: <b>What is one who has a polyp? Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> This is one who has <b>a</b> foul <b>odor of the nose. It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>:</b> A polyp is <b>a</b> foul <b>odor of the mouth. Rav Asi teaches the reverse,</b> that Shmuel is the one who said a polyp is odor of the mouth. <b>And he provided a mnemonic</b> device <b>for</b> his opinion: <b>Shmuel did not close his mouth from our entire chapter,</b> meaning that he studied it and commented on it extensively. This statement was formulated in a way that contains a hint that Shmuel’s opinion involves the mouth.
The mishna taught, in the list of defects for which the husband is forced to divorce his wife: <b>Or one who</b> works as <b>a gatherer.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>a gatherer? Rav Yehuda said: This</b> is referring to <b>one who gathers dog excrement</b> for use in tanning. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A gatherer, this</b> is <b>a tanner.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>And according to your reasoning, the mishna</b> itself <b>should present a difficulty for you,</b> as it states: <b>One who</b> works as <b>a gatherer, or one who</b> works as <b>a melder of copper, or one who</b> works as <b>a tanner</b> of hides, which indicates that the mishna holds that the gatherer and the tanner are not the same.
The Gemara explains: <b>Granted, the mishna</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as one can say that <b>here,</b> where the tanner is listed separately from the one who gathers, it is referring <b>to a large</b>-scale <b>tanner,</b> and <b>there,</b> when the <i>baraita</i> states that a gatherer is a tanner, it is speaking <b>of a</b> small-scale <b>tanner. But according to Rav Yehuda it is difficult.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A gatherer, this</b> is <b>a tanner, and some say: This</b> is <b>one who gathers dog excrement.</b> Rav Yehuda follows this latter opinion.
The mishna teaches: <b>And a coppersmith and a tanner.</b> The Gemara poses a question: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>a coppersmith? Rav Ashi said: A kettle smith,</b> that is, one who beats copper in order to make kettles; his handling of copper leaves him with a bad odor. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥanna said: This is one who hews copper from its source</b> in the ground. The Gemara comments: It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥanna: Who is a coppersmith? This is one who hews copper from its source.</b>
§ As the mishna discusses situations in which the court forces the husband to divorce his wife, the Gemara mentions a similar case. <b>Rav said:</b> A husband <b>who says: I will not sustain</b> my wife <b>and I will not provide a livelihood</b> for her, <b>must divorce</b> her <b>and give her</b> the payment of her <b>marriage contract. Rabbi Elazar went</b> and <b>recited</b> this <b><i>halakha</i> before Shmuel.</b> Shmuel <b>said: Feed [<i>akhsuha</i>] barley,</b> animal fodder, <b>to Elazar.</b> In other words, he has spoken nonsense, as <b>rather than forcing him to divorce</b> her, it would be better for them <b>to force him to sustain</b> his wife.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rav</b> respond to this argument? He bases his ruling on the principle that <b>a person does not reside in a basket,</b> i.e., in close quarters, <b>with a snake.</b> In other words, a woman cannot share her life with a man who provides for her needs only when compelled to do so by the court. The Gemara relates: <b>When Rabbi Zeira ascended</b> to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he found Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet sitting and reciting</b> this <i>halakha</i> of Rav’s <b>in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan. He said to him: On account of this</b> matter <b>they fed Elazar with barley in Babylonia.</b>
§ The Gemara continues to discuss cases in which a husband is compelled to divorce his wife. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav Asi said:</b> The court <b>forces</b> men to divorce their wives <b>only</b> if they were married <b>to</b> women <b>unfit</b> to marry them. <b>When I recited this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>before Shmuel, he said:</b> This applies to cases such as, <b>for example, a widow</b> married <b>to a High Priest, a divorcée or a <i>yevama</i> who underwent <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>]</b> married <b>to a common priest, a daughter born from an incestuous or adulterous relationship [<i>mamzeret</i>], or a Gibeonite woman</b> married <b>to an Israelite,</b> or <b>a daughter of an Israelite</b> married <b>to a Gibeonite or to a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> In all of these cases the marriage is prohibited by Torah law. <b>But</b> if someone <b>married a woman and stayed with her</b> for <b>ten years and she did not give birth,</b> although he is guilty of neglecting the mitzva to be fruitful and multiply, the court <b>does not force him</b> to divorce her.
<b>And Rav Taḥalifa bar Avimi</b> said that <b>Shmuel said: Even</b> in the case of someone who <b>married a woman and stayed with her</b> for <b>ten years and she did not give birth,</b> the court <b>forces him</b> to divorce her, as he is in violation of a positive mitzva. The Gemara poses a question: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>And these are</b> the defects <b>for</b> which the court <b>forces him to divorce</b> his wife: One <b>afflicted with boils or one who has a polyp. Granted, according to Rav Asi,</b> only cases in which the court compels a divorce <b>by rabbinic</b> law <b>are taught</b> in the mishna, but those that are <b>by Torah</b> law, such as a widow married to a High Priest, <b>are not taught. However, according to Rav Taḥalifa bar Avimi, let</b> the mishna also <b>teach</b> that if he <b>married a woman and stayed with her</b> for <b>ten years and she did not give birth,</b> the court <b>forces him</b> to divorce her, as this is also a rabbinic enactment.
<b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> as in <b>this</b> case the mishna discusses someone who is forced to divorce his wife <b>by verbal</b> means alone, but in <b>that</b> case it is referring to compelling him <b>by</b> beating him with <b>rods.</b> Although the court does compel a man to divorce his wife if she has not had children, the court does so only by speaking with him. <b>Rabbi Abba strongly objects to this:</b> Can there be a <i>halakha</i> of coercion by verbal means alone? But the verse states: <b>“A servant will not be corrected by words”</b> (Proverbs 29:19). <b>Rather, Rabbi Abba said:</b> Both <b>this and that</b> are referring to coercion <b>by</b> beating him with <b>rods,</b>

Daf 77b

but <b>there,</b> with regard to the blemishes specified in the mishna, <b>if she says: I</b> want <b>to be with him, we leave her</b> alone with him and do not force a divorce, whereas <b>here,</b> in the case of a woman who has not given birth, <b>even though she says: I</b> want <b>to be with him, we do not leave her</b> alone, as her husband is neglecting the mitzva to be fruitful and multiply. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> there is the case of a husband <b>afflicted with boils, where even though she says: I</b> want <b>to be with him, we do not leave her</b> alone with him. <b>As we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>Apart from</b> a situation where her husband is <b>afflicted with boils, because</b> it <b>consumes</b> his flesh. <b>And</b> yet this <i>halakha</i> <b>is taught</b> in the same mishna as the others, which indicates that our above analysis is incorrect.
The Gemara answers: Even so, there is a difference between these cases, as <b>there,</b> with regard to a man with boils, <b>if she says: I</b> am willing to <b>live with him</b> under the supervision <b>of witnesses;</b> that is, I will not seclude myself with him but I will nevertheless remain his wife, <b>we leave her</b> alone. However, <b>here, even though she says: I</b> will <b>live with him</b> under the supervision <b>of witnesses, we do not leave her</b> alone, but rather force him to divorce her.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei said: A certain Elder from</b> among <b>the residents of Jerusalem told me</b> that there <b>are twenty-four</b> types of patients <b>afflicted with boils, and</b> with regard to <b>all of them the Sages said</b> that <b>sexual relations are harmful to them, and</b> those <b>afflicted with <i>ra’atan</i>,</b> a severe skin disease characterized by extreme weakness and trembling, <b>are harmed</b> even more <b>than all of the</b> others. The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> and how does this disease <b>come about?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>who let blood and</b> immediately afterward <b>engaged in sexual relations will have weak</b> [<b><i>vitaykin</i></b>] <b>children.</b> If <b>both of them let blood and</b> then <b>engaged in sexual relations, he will have children afflicted with <i>ra’atan</i>. Rav Pappa said</b> in response: <b>We said</b> this <b>only if he did not taste anything</b> between bloodletting and intercourse, <b>but</b> if <b>he tasted something we have no</b> problem <b>with it,</b> as it is not dangerous.
The Gemara inquires: <b>What are the symptoms</b> of <i>ra’atan</i>? <b>His eyes water, his nose runs, drool comes out of his mouth, and flies rest upon him.</b> The Gemara further inquires: <b>And what is his cure</b> to remove the insect found in his head, which is associated with this illness? <b>Abaye said:</b> One takes <b><i>pila</i> and ladanum</b> [<b><i>lodana</i></b>], which are types of grasses; <b>and the ground shell of a nut; and shavings of smoothed hides; and artemisia [<i>kelil malka</i>]; and the calyx of a red date palm. And</b> one <b>cooks them together and brings</b> the patient <b>into a marble house,</b> i.e., one that is completely sealed. <b>And if there is no marble house</b> available, the one performing the treatment <b>brings</b> the patient <b>into a house</b> whose walls have the thickness <b>of seven bricks and</b> one <b>small brick.</b>
<b>And</b> the one performing the treatment <b>pours three hundred cups</b> of this mixture <b>on</b> the patient’s <b>head until his skull is soft, and</b> then he <b>tears</b> open the patient’s skull <b>to</b> expose <b>his brain, and brings four myrtle leaves and lifts up each</b> time <b>one foot</b> of the insect that is found on the patient’s brain, <b>and places one</b> leaf under each foot of the insect so as to prevent it from attempting to cling to his brain when it is forcibly removed, <b>and</b> subsequently <b>takes</b> it <b>with tweezers. And</b> he then <b>burns</b> the insect, <b>because if</b> he does <b>not</b> burn it, it <b>will return to him.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> would <b>announce: Be careful of the flies</b> found <b>on those afflicted with <i>ra’atan</i>,</b> as they are carriers of the disease. <b>Rabbi Zeira would not sit</b> in a spot where the <b>wind</b> blew from the direction of someone afflicted with <i>ra’atan</i>. <b>Rabbi Elazar would not enter</b> the <b>tent</b> of one afflicted with <i>ra’atan</i>, and <b>Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi would not eat eggs from an alley</b> in which someone afflicted with <i>ra’atan</i> lived. Conversely, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> would <b>attach himself</b> to <b>them and study Torah, saying</b> as justification the verse: “The Torah is <b>a loving hind and a graceful doe”</b> (Proverbs 5:19). <b>If</b> it <b>bestows grace on those who learn it,</b> does <b>it not protect</b> them from illness?
<b>When</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>was</b> on the verge of <b>dying, they said to the Angel of Death: Go</b> and <b>perform his bidding,</b> as he is a righteous man and deserves to die in the manner he sees fit. The Angel of Death <b>went</b> and <b>appeared to him.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>said to him: Show me my place</b> in paradise. <b>He said to him: Very well.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>said to him: Give me your knife</b> that you use to kill mortals, <b>lest you frighten me on the way. He gave it to him. When he arrived there,</b> in paradise, <b>he lifted</b> Rabbi Yehoshua so he could see his place, and <b>he showed it to him.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>jumped</b> and <b>fell into that</b> other <b>side,</b> thereby escaping into paradise.
The Angel of Death <b>grabbed him by the corner of his cloak.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>said to him: I swear that I will not come</b> with you. <b>The Holy One, blessed be He, said: If he</b> ever in his life <b>requested</b> dissolution <b>concerning an oath</b> he had taken, <b>he must return</b> to this world with the Angel of Death, as he can have his oath dissolved this time also. <b>If</b> he did <b>not</b> ever request dissolution of an oath, he need <b>not return.</b> Since Rabbi Yehoshua had in fact never requested dissolution of an oath, he was allowed to stay in paradise. The Angel of Death <b>said to him:</b> At least <b>give me my knife</b> back. However, he <b>did not give</b> it <b>to him,</b> as he did not want any more people to die. <b>A Divine Voice emerged and said to him: Give</b> it <b>to him, as</b> it <b>is necessary to</b> kill <b>the created</b> beings; death is the way of the world. <b>Elijah</b> the Prophet <b>announced before him: Make way for the son of Levi, make way for the son of Levi.</b>
Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>went</b> and <b>found</b> in paradise <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai sitting on thirteen golden stools [<i>takhtekei</i>].</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai <b>said to him: Are you the son of Levi? He said to him: Yes.</b> Rabbi Shimon said to him: Was <b>a rainbow</b> ever <b>seen in your days? He said: Yes.</b> Rabbi Shimon retorted: <b>If so, you are not the son of Levi,</b> as he is a completely righteous man. During the lifetimes of completely righteous people no rainbows are visible, as they are a sign that the world deserves to be destroyed by a flood; whereas the merit of the righteous protects the world from such things. The Gemara comments: <b>And that is not so, for there was no</b> rainbow seen <b>at all</b> during the lifetime of Rabbi Yehoshua, <b>but</b> he <b>thought: I do not want to take credit for myself</b> by presenting myself as such a righteous person.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: <b>Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa was a friend</b> of the Angel of Death and would see him frequently. <b>When</b> Rabbi Ḥanina <b>was</b> on the verge of <b>dying, they said to the Angel of Death: Go</b> and <b>perform his bidding. He went before him and appeared to him. He said to</b> the angel: <b>Leave me</b> for <b>thirty days until I have reviewed my studies, for they say: Happy is he who comes here,</b> to paradise, <b>with his learning in his hand. He left him,</b> and <b>after thirty days he</b> again <b>went</b> and <b>appeared to him. He said to</b> the Angel of Death: <b>Show me my place</b> in paradise. <b>He said to him: Very well.</b> Rabbi Ḥanina <b>said to him: Give me your knife, lest you frighten me on the way.</b> The Angel of Death <b>said to him:</b> Do <b>you wish to do to me as your friend</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi did, and escape?
<b>He said to him: Bring a Torah scroll and see: Is there anything written in it that I have not fulfilled?</b> I am therefore worthy of entering Paradise alive, as did Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi. <b>He said to him: But did you attach yourself to those afflicted with <i>ra’atan</i> and study Torah,</b> as he did? The Gemara comments: <b>And even so,</b> despite the fact that he was not equal to Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, <b>when he passed away a pillar of fire separated him from everyone. And</b> it <b>is learned</b> as a tradition <b>that a pillar of fire separates</b> in this manner <b>only for one in a generation or for two in a generation.</b>
Due to the pillar of fire they could not go near Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa to attend to his burial. <b>Rabbi Alexandri approached him</b> and <b>said: Make</b> the pillar of fire disappear <b>in honor of the Sages.</b> He did <b>not pay attention</b> to him. He said: <b>Make</b> it go away <b>in honor of your father.</b> Again he did <b>not pay attention</b> to him. Finally he said: <b>Make</b> it go away <b>in your own honor,</b> at which point the pillar <b>disappeared. Abaye said:</b> The purpose of the pillar of fire is <b>to exclude</b> him <b>from</b> the company of <b>those who have not fulfilled even one letter</b> of the Torah. <b>Rav Adda bar Mattana said to him:</b> It comes <b>to exclude</b> him <b>from the Master</b> himself, <b>who does not have a guardrail for his roof.</b> Rav Adda bar Mattana took this opportunity to rebuke Abaye. The Gemara comments: <b>And that is not so</b> as he in fact <b>did have</b> a guardrail, <b>but the wind had</b> just <b>blown it off at that time.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: For what reason are there no people afflicted with <i>ra’atan</i> in Babylonia? Because</b> the Babylonians <b>eat beets [<i>teradin</i>] and drink beer made from the <i>hizmei</i></b> plant. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: For what reason are there no lepers in Babylonia? Because they eat beets, drink beer, and bathe in the waters of the Euphrates,</b> all of which are good for the body.

Daf 78a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to a <b>woman to whom property was bequeathed before she was betrothed,</b> and she was then betrothed, <b>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel agree that she may sell or give</b> the property as a gift, <b>and</b> the transaction <b>is valid.</b> However, if the property <b>was bequeathed to her after she was betrothed, Beit Shammai say: She may sell</b> it as long as she is betrothed, <b>and Beit Hillel say: She may not sell</b> it. Both <b>these,</b> Beit Shammai, <b>and those,</b> Beit Hillel, <b>agree that if she sold</b> it <b>or gave</b> it away as a gift, the transaction is <b>valid.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that <b>the Sages said before Rabban Gamliel: Since he acquired the woman</b> herself through betrothal, will he <b>not acquire the property</b> from the moment of their betrothal? Why, then, is her transaction valid? Rabban Gamliel <b>said to them: With regard to the new</b> property that she inherited after marriage, <b>we are ashamed,</b> because it is unclear why she cannot sell it, as it is hers; <b>and you</b> also seek to <b>impose upon us</b> a prohibition with regard to <b>the old</b> property that she owned beforehand?
If the property <b>was bequeathed to her after she was married,</b> both <b>these,</b> Beit Shammai, <b>and those,</b> Beit Hillel, <b>agree that if she sold</b> the property <b>or gave</b> it away, <b>the husband may repossess</b> it <b>from the purchasers.</b> If she inherited the property <b>before she was married and</b> then <b>was married, Rabban Gamliel says: If she sold or gave</b> the property away, the transaction is <b>valid. Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akavya said</b> that the Sages <b>said before Rabban Gamliel: Since he acquired the woman</b> through marriage, will he <b>not acquire the property?</b> Rabban Gamliel <b>said to them: With regard to the new</b> property <b>we are ashamed, and you</b> also seek to <b>impose upon us</b> a prohibition with regard to <b>the old</b> property?
<b>Rabbi Shimon distinguishes between</b> one type of <b>property and</b> another type of <b>property: Property that is known to the husband she may not sell</b> once she is married, <b>and if she sold</b> it <b>or gave</b> it away, the transaction is <b>void.</b> Property <b>that is unknown to the husband she may not sell, but if she sold</b> it <b>or gave</b> it away, the transaction is <b>valid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> in the <b>first clause</b> of the mishna, when she inherited property before she was betrothed, such <b>that</b> Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <b>do not disagree, and what is different</b> in <b>the latter clause,</b> when she inherited property after betrothal, such <b>that they disagree?</b> If the dispute concerns the right to her property after she is betrothed, what difference does it make whether her ownership began before or after the betrothal?
The Gemara answers that the Sages <b>of the school of Rabbi Yannai say: In the first clause,</b> where she inherited the property before her betrothal, the inheritance <b>was bequeathed</b> to her during a period when <b>she</b> had <b>rights</b> to her property, whereas <b>in the latter clause,</b> the inheritance <b>was bequeathed</b> to her during a period when <b>he</b> had <b>rights</b> to her property.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If,</b> in the latter clause the property <b>was bequeathed</b> to her when <b>he</b> had <b>rights</b> to it, <b>why</b> is the transaction <b>valid when she sold</b> it <b>or gave</b> it away? <b>Rather,</b> in <b>the first clause,</b> where she inherited the property before her betrothal, it <b>certainly was bequeathed</b> to her when <b>she</b> had <b>rights</b> to it and it therefore fully belongs to her.
