However, in <b>the latter clause,</b> where she inherited it after her betrothal, one can <b>say</b> that perhaps during this time <b>she has rights</b> to it, or <b>say</b> that perhaps during this time <b>he has rights</b> to it. Since the ownership of the property is a matter of uncertainty, Beit Hillel rule that <b>she may not sell <i>ab initio</i>,</b> but <b>if she sold</b> it <b>or gave</b> it away, the transaction is <b>valid.</b>
§ The mishna states that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that the Sages <b>said before Rabban Gamliel:</b> Since he acquired the woman herself through betrothal, will he not acquire the property from the moment of their betrothal? <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: When <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> cited this question of the Sages, was he referring <b>to</b> her selling the property <b><i>ab initio</i>,</b> which is permitted only according to Beit Shammai, <b>or</b> was he referring <b>to</b> the sale <b>after the fact,</b> which is valid even according to Beit Hillel?

Daf 78b

The Gemara replies: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an answer to this question, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that <b>they said before Rabban Gamliel: Since this</b> one, when she is fully married, is legally <b>his wife, and that one,</b> when she is merely betrothed, is legally <b>his wife,</b> therefore, just as for <b>this</b> married one <b>her sale is void, so</b> too, for <b>this</b> betrothed one <b>her sale</b> should be <b>void.</b> Rabban Gamliel <b>said to them: With regard to the new</b> property, which she inherited after marriage, <b>we are ashamed</b> of this ruling, <b>while you</b> seek to <b>impose upon us</b> the same ruling even with regard to <b>the old</b> property that she owned beforehand? <b>Learn from this</b> that Rabbi Yehuda <b>stated</b> his question with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of a case brought <b>after the fact,</b> as they claim that the sale should be void. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from this</b> that it is so.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akavya said</b> that <b>Rabban Gamliel did not respond to the Sages in that</b> manner. <b>Rather, this</b> is what <b>he replied to them: No, if you said</b> that the sale is void <b>with regard to a married</b> woman, concerning whom the husband has many rights, <b>as her husband is entitled to</b> items she has <b>found and to her earnings and to</b> the right to <b>nullify her vows, will you say</b> the same <b>with regard to a betrothed woman, whose husband is not entitled to</b> items she has <b>found, nor</b> to <b>her earnings, nor</b> to the right of <b>nullification of her vows?</b>
The Sages <b>said to him: My teacher,</b> this reasoning is accepted if <b>she sold</b> it <b>for herself before she was married,</b> but if <b>she was married and afterward sold</b> the property she had earlier inherited, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rabban Gamliel <b>said to them: Even this one may sell</b> the property <b>and give</b> it away, <b>and</b> her action is <b>valid. They said to him: Since he acquired the woman, will he not acquire the property? He said to them: With regard to the new</b> property she inherited later <b>we are ashamed, and</b> now <b>you impose upon us the old</b> property?
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: If she inherited property <b>before she was married and was</b> later <b>married, Rabban Gamliel says: If she sold</b> it <b>or gave</b> the property away, the transaction is <b>valid.</b> The wording of the <i>baraita</i>, in contrast, indicates that she may sell or give the property away <i>ab initio</i>.
<b>Rav Zevid said: Teach</b> the text of the mishna as follows: <b>She may sell and give</b> away the property, <b>and</b> her transaction is <b>valid. Rav Pappa stated</b> another answer: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> mishna is consistent with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel,</b> but <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> is consistent with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akavya according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel.</b> The Gemara poses a question: If so, then apparently <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akavya</b> agrees <b>with Beit Shammai,</b> as Beit Hillel maintain that she may not sell the property <i>ab initio</i> even while she is betrothed; yet it is well known that the <i>halakha</i> is ruled in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel. The Gemara answers: <b>This is what</b> Rabbi Ḥanina <b>is saying: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree with regard to this matter</b> of property that a woman inherited before marriage, as they agree she may sell it <i>ab initio</i>.
The Gemara cites the opinions of <b>Rav and Shmuel, who both say: Whether property was bequeathed to her before she was betrothed,</b> or <b>whether property was bequeathed to her after she was betrothed and she was</b> then <b>married,</b> and after her marriage she sold it or gave it away, <b>the husband may repossess</b> the property <b>from the purchasers.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>According to whose</b> opinion was this stated? It is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda and not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akavya,</b> who both maintain that the sale is valid. The Gemara answers: <b>They,</b> i.e., Rav and Shmuel, <b>say</b> so, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>our Rabbis. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Our Rabbis returned and voted</b> after discussing this issue and decided that <b>whether property was bequeathed to her before she was betrothed,</b> or <b>whether property was bequeathed to her after she was betrothed and she was</b> subsequently <b>married, the husband may repossess</b> it <b>from the purchasers.</b>
§ It was taught in the mishna that if she inherited the property <b>after she was married,</b> both <b>these,</b> Beit Shammai, <b>and those,</b> Beit Hillel, <b>agree</b> that the husband may repossess it from the buyers. The Gemara comments: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> in the mishna about <b>the</b> rabbinic <b>ordinance</b> instituted in <b>Usha.</b> As <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: In Usha they instituted</b> an ordinance that in the case of <b>a woman who sold her usufruct property,</b> i.e., property that she alone owns and her husband benefits only from the dividends, <b>in her husband’s lifetime and</b> then <b>died, the husband repossesses</b> it <b>from the purchasers.</b> This appears to be the same <i>halakha</i> stated by the mishna.
The Gemara responds: This is not so, as <b>the mishna</b> is discussing the husband’s claim <b>during her lifetime, and</b> it is referring only <b>to</b> the value of <b>the produce</b> that the husband collects from the purchasers if she sold the land during their marriage, as the produce of usufruct property belongs to him but the land itself remains fully in the possession of the buyer. <b>The ordinance of Usha,</b> in contrast, applies even <b>to the land itself, and</b> even <b>after</b> the <b>death</b> of his wife he may repossess it because he inherits it.
§ The mishna further taught that <b>Rabbi Shimon distinguishes between property</b> that is known to the husband and property that is unknown to him. The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> properties <b>are</b> deemed <b>known and which</b> properties <b>are</b> deemed <b>unknown? Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> Property that is <b>known</b> is referring to <b>land,</b> which cannot be concealed. The husband knew that she would inherit it, and he married her with the intention of using its produce. Property <b>that is unknown</b> is referring to <b>movable property. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Both <b>these,</b> land, <b>and those,</b> movable property, <b>are</b> deemed <b>known</b> property. <b>And these are unknown</b> properties: They are properties in <b>any</b> case <b>where she resides here and property was bequeathed to her overseas.</b> Since the husband did not consider this property when marrying her, the sale is binding after the fact.
The Gemara comments: <b>That</b> opinion <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>. The <i>baraita</i> states: <b>These are unknown</b> properties: They are properties in <b>any</b> case <b>where she resides here and property was bequeathed to her overseas.</b>
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain woman</b> who was about to remarry after she was divorced or widowed, <b>who sought to distance</b> the rights to <b>her property from her</b> future <b>husband. She</b> therefore <b>wrote</b> a document stipulating that her property be given as a gift <b>to her daughter</b> before marriage. Ultimately, the mother <b>was married and</b> then <b>divorced.</b> She wanted her daughter to return the property, and her daughter claimed that it was given to her as a gift.

Daf 79a

The mother <b>came before Rav Naḥman</b> for judgment. <b>Rav Naḥman tore the document,</b> accepting her claim that she did not intend to transfer ownership of her property. <b>Rav Anan went before Mar Ukva,</b> the Exilarch, and <b>said to him:</b> Let <b>the Master observe Naḥman the farmer, how</b> he <b>tears people’s documents.</b> Rav Anan was upset that Rav Naḥman destroyed a legitimate document. <b>Mar Ukva said to him: Tell me, please, what was the actual incident?</b>
Rav Anan <b>said to</b> Mar Ukva: <b>This and that transpired;</b> i.e., he apprised him of all the details. Mar Ukva <b>said to him: Are you saying</b> it was <b>a document of evasion? This</b> is what <b>Rav Ḥanilai bar Idi said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: I am</b> an authority who <b>issues rulings</b> and have issued the following directive: <b>If a document of evasion comes to my hand, I will tear it,</b> as it is clear that it was not intended for the actual transfer of property but merely to distance it from someone else.
After seeing Rav Naḥman tear the document, <b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman: What is the reason</b> for your actions? Is it that you assume that it was not a wholehearted gift <b>because a person does not abandon his own</b> interests <b>and give</b> a gift <b>to others? That applies</b> only when it is given <b>to others</b> who are strangers, <b>but to her daughter</b> a mother would <b>give</b> property wholeheartedly. Rav Naḥman replied: <b>Even so, where</b> her interests clash with those <b>of her daughter, her own</b> interests <b>are preferable to her,</b> and therefore she did not intend to waive her rights.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection:</b> With regard to <b>one who seeks to distance her property from her husband, how does she proceed? She writes</b> in <b>a document of agreement</b> that her property should be given <b>to others,</b> who agree not to acquire the property. This document prevents her husband from gaining access to her property. This is <b>the statement of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> This solution is flawed, because if the recipient <b>wishes, he can deceive her</b> and retain the property by virtue of the valid document in his possession. That possibility cannot be avoided <b>until she writes to him</b> in the document that the gift is granted <b>from today and</b> the gift is in effect only <b>while I</b> still <b>wish</b> to give it. In that case, if the one to whom she gave the gift comes to take possession of it, she can say that she no longer wants to give the gift and can thereby invalidate the document.
The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> she can ultimately retain her property is due to the fact <b>that she wrote this to him; but if she did not write this to him, the purchaser has acquired</b> it. This indicates that a document of evasion is legally valid.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this,</b> the ruling that the document of evasion is void, is in a case where the document was written <b>about all</b> of the property, as clearly a person does not give away all his property as a gift and leave himself with nothing. Conversely, <b>that</b> ruling that the document is not canceled is in a case where the document was written <b>about</b> only <b>part of</b> the property, and therefore a clause must be added ensuring that the recipient cannot retain possession of the gift.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>And</b> in the case where the document is invalid because all of the property was included, <b>if the purchaser does not acquire</b> the property, <b>the husband should acquire it. Abaye said:</b> The Sages <b>rendered</b> this property given as a gift <b>like property that is unknown to the husband, and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> in the mishna that if she sold such property after her marriage, the sale is valid. Therefore, the husband does not have access to the property.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>money was bequeathed to</b> a woman as an inheritance while she was married, <b>land is acquired with it, and</b> the husband <b>consumes the produce</b> of the land while the principal remains hers. If she inherited <b>produce that is detached from the ground,</b> it is considered like money; therefore, <b>land is acquired with it and he consumes the produce</b> of the land.
With regard to <b>produce that is attached to the ground, Rabbi Meir says: One evaluates how much</b> the land is <b>worth with</b> the <b>produce, and how much it is worth without</b> the <b>produce, and</b> the difference between these sums is the <b>surplus</b> value that belongs to the woman. <b>Land is</b> then <b>acquired with</b> the surplus <b>and he consumes the produce. And the Rabbis say: That which is attached to the ground is his,</b> as he is entitled to the produce from her property and he may therefore eat from it. <b>And that which is detached from the ground</b> is <b>hers,</b> like all other money she brings to the marriage, <b>and land is acquired with it and he consumes the produce.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In a <b>case where his right is superior upon her entrance</b> to the marriage, <b>his right is inferior upon her exit</b> if he divorces her. Conversely, in a <b>case where his right is inferior upon her entrance, his right is superior upon her exit. How so?</b> With regard to <b>produce that is attached to the ground,</b> if she married while owning such produce, <b>upon her entrance</b> it is <b>his,</b> in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, <b>and upon her exit,</b> when he divorces her, it is <b>hers,</b> as it is considered part of her property. <b>But</b> in the case of produce <b>that is detached from the ground, upon her entrance</b> it is <b>hers, and</b> if such produce is detached before their divorce, <b>upon her exit</b> it is <b>his,</b> as he was already entitled to all the produce of her property.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara observes that in the cases in the mishna where land is bought with the money, it is <b>obvious</b> that if one spouse proposes acquiring <b>land and</b> the other proposes buying <b>houses,</b> they must buy <b>land,</b> because it is a more secure purchase. If the decision is between <b>houses and palm trees,</b> they should acquire <b>houses.</b> If the decision is between <b>palm trees or</b> other types of <b>trees,</b> they should buy <b>palm trees.</b> If the decision is between regular <b>trees or grapevines,</b> they should purchase <b>trees.</b> The principle is that they acquire that which lasts longer and will not deteriorate over time.
If the wife inherited <b>a forest [<i>abba</i>]</b> of <b>hawthorn [<i>zeradeta</i>]</b> trees, whose produce is inferior, <b>or a fishpond,</b> their status is a matter of dispute: <b>Some say</b> they are considered like <b>produce, and some say</b> they are like the <b>principal,</b> as they do not replenish themselves but eventually wear out. <b>The principle of the matter</b> is as follows: Any tree or plant whose <b>trunk renews</b> itself and grows again after it is cut is considered <b>produce,</b> whereas any tree or plant whose <b>trunk does not renew</b> itself is considered part of the <b>principal.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai said, and some say Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai said: One who steals</b>

Daf 79b

the <b>offspring</b> of <b>an animal of</b> a woman’s <b>usufruct</b> property <b>must pay payment of double</b> the principal <b>to the woman.</b> Apparently this ruling is based on the assumption that the offspring is not treated as the produce of her property but as the principal, which belongs to the woman.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion was this <i>halakha</i> stated? It is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and not in accordance with</b> that of <b>Ḥananya.</b> The Gemara explains the dispute alluded to here: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The offspring</b> of <b>a usufruct animal</b> belongs <b>to the husband,</b> whereas <b>the child</b> of <b>a usufruct maidservant</b> belongs <b>to the wife. And Ḥananya, son of Yoshiya’s brother, said: They made</b> the status of the <b>child</b> of <b>a usufruct maidservant like</b> that of <b>the offspring</b> of <b>a usufruct animal,</b> which belongs to the husband. Both opinions in the <i>baraita</i> agree that the offspring of a usufruct animal belongs to the husband. Why, then, must the thief pay the double payment to the woman?
The Gemara answers: <b>You</b> can <b>even say</b> that <b>all agree</b> with Rabbi Yannai’s ruling, as there is a difference between the general use of property and the double payment. This is because <b>the Sages instituted for</b> the husband to consume the <b>produce,</b> but <b>the Sages did not institute for him</b> to consume the <b>produce of</b> the <b>produce.</b> The double payment does not have the status of the offspring itself but of produce resulting from its theft, which is considered the produce of the produce and therefore is given to the woman.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to Ḥananya,</b> who equates the <i>halakha</i> of a maidservant’s child to that of an animal’s offspring, <b>this is because we are not concerned about</b> the <b>death</b> of the mother. Therefore, the mother is the principal while its offspring is considered the produce.
<b>But</b> according to <b>the Rabbis, if</b> they <b>are concerned about</b> the <b>death</b> of the mother, and this is why a maidservant’s child belongs to the wife, <b>even</b> the <b>offspring</b> of <b>a usufruct animal</b> should <b>not</b> have the status of produce <b>either.</b> Rather, it should have the status of principal, because if the usufruct animal dies the woman will be left with nothing. Therefore, the offspring should be viewed as a replacement for its mother. <b>And if</b> they <b>are not concerned about</b> the <b>death</b> of the mother, <b>even the child of a usufruct maidservant</b> should <b>also</b> belong to the husband as the produce of her property. Why, then, do they distinguish between these two cases?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the Rabbis <b>are concerned about death, but</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>an animal is different, as there is</b> still <b>its hide,</b> which remains after death. Therefore, the principal is not entirely lost even if the animal dies.
<b>Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya</b> that the child of a maidservant belongs to the husband. <b>Rava said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said: Although Shmuel said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya, Ḥananya concedes that if</b> the woman <b>was divorced, she pays money and takes</b> the children of her maidservants, <b>because</b> they are <b>assets of her paternal family,</b> and it is unfitting for the children of her family’s slaves to belong to someone else.
<b>Rava said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said: If she brought in</b> to the marriage <b>for him a goat for its milk, or a sheep for its shearings, or a hen for its eggs, or a palm tree for its produce,</b> the husband <b>continues to consume</b> the produce <b>until the principal is consumed,</b> and there is no concern that the woman will remain with nothing of value. Similarly, <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> If <b>she brought in for him a cloak</b> as her usufruct property, it <b>is produce,</b> and <b>he may cover</b> himself <b>with it until</b> it <b>is consumed.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this ruling? It is <b>in accordance with this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a wife’s usufruct property includes a location on the shore from which <b>salt and sand</b> are extracted, <b>this</b> extract <b>is</b> deemed <b>produce.</b> As for <b>a quarry of sulfur</b> or <b>a mine of alum, Rabbi Meir says:</b> These are deemed <b>principal,</b> as the mine contains a finite amount of substance, <b>and the Rabbis say:</b> Extractions from such locations are <b>produce,</b> while the location of the mine is the principal. Rav Naḥman’s ruling that the cloak is deemed produce is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis that the extractions are deemed produce.
§ The mishna stated that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In a <b>case where his right is superior</b> upon her entrance, his right is inferior upon her exit if he divorces her. Conversely, in the case where his right is inferior upon her entrance, his right is superior upon her exit. The Gemara asks: The statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon is</b> identical to that of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., the Rabbis. Why, then, are both necessary? <b>Rava said:</b> The practical difference <b>between</b> them is the status of produce that was <b>attached at the time of</b> her <b>departure</b> from the marriage. The Rabbis, who did not directly address this issue, maintain that it belongs to him, whereas Rabbi Shimon says it belongs to her.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>elderly slaves or maidservants were bequeathed to her, they are sold and land is acquired with them, and</b> the husband <b>consumes the produce</b> of the land. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: She</b> need <b>not sell</b> these slaves and maidservants, <b>because they are assets of her paternal family,</b> and it would be shameful to the family if they were sold to others. Likewise, if <b>old olive</b> trees <b>or grapevines were bequeathed to her, they are sold and land is acquired with them, and he consumes the produce. Rabbi Yehuda says: She</b> need <b>not sell</b> them, <b>because they are assets of her paternal family.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Kahana said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> concerning olive trees and grapevines is referring to a case <b>when they were bequeathed</b> to her <b>in her field,</b> as they are assets of her paternal family, and therefore Rabbi Yehuda rules that she need not sell them. <b>But</b> if she received them <b>in a field that is not hers, everyone agrees</b> that <b>she must sell</b> them <b>because</b> the <b>principal</b> will be <b>consumed.</b> Since these trees will not yield much produce, they will eventually be uprooted, and transitory property is not included in the category of assets of her paternal family.
<b>Rav Yosef objects to this: But</b> elderly <b>slaves and maidservants are considered like a field that is not hers,</b> as nothing will remain of the principal, <b>and</b> yet Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and the first <i>tanna</i> <b>disagree</b> over this case. The Gemara retracts: <b>Rather,</b> if the above statement of Rav Kahana <b>was stated, it was stated as follows: Rav Kahana said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> with regard to olive trees and vines is referring to when they are located <b>in a field that is not hers, but</b> if they are located <b>in her field, everyone agrees</b> that <b>she</b> need <b>not sell</b> them, <b>because</b> they are <b>assets of her paternal family.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who pays expenditures for his wife’s property</b> in an effort to improve it, if <b>he paid a large</b> amount in expenditures <b>and ate</b> only <b>a small</b> amount of produce before he divorced her, or if he paid <b>a small</b> amount in expenditures <b>and ate a large</b> quantity of produce, <b>that which he spent he has spent, and that which he ate he has eaten.</b> Therefore, none of it need be returned. However, if he <b>paid</b> expenditures for the property <b>and did not eat</b> any part of it, <b>he takes an oath</b> with regard to <b>how much he paid and</b> then <b>takes</b> his expenditures.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>And how much is</b> a <b>small</b> amount? <b>Rabbi Asi said:</b> It is <b>even one dried fig, provided he ate it in a dignified manner</b> befitting the owner of the produce and did not eat it by snatching the produce. It was <b>said</b>

Daf 80a

by <b>Rabbi Abba</b> that in <b>the school of Rav they say:</b> It is <b>even a cluster of dates</b> stuck together. <b>Rav Beivai asks:</b> If one ate <b>dough</b> made <b>of dates, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is this considered dignified consumption? The Gemara concludes: The question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara asks: If <b>he did not eat it in a dignified manner, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? How much must he eat to be deemed a proper act of consumption? <b>Ulla said: Two <i>amora’im</i> in the West,</b> i.e., Eretz Yisrael, <b>disagree</b> about <b>this</b> matter. <b>One said:</b> He ate the amount <b>of an <i>issar</i>, and one said:</b> He ate the measure <b>of a dinar.</b>
<b>The judges of Pumbedita say: Rav Yehuda took action</b> in a case <b>of a bundle of branches.</b> A husband took them from his wife’s property and fed them to his animals, and Rav Yehuda ruled that this was treated as consumption of her property. The Gemara comments: <b>Rav Yehuda</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning.</b> As <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> If one took possession of a plot of land and <b>consumed</b> some of the produce of its trees that was forbidden due to the <b>prohibition against eating the fruit of a tree during the first three years after its planting</b> [<b><i>orla</i></b>] or produce of <b>the seventh year,</b> or a forbidden mixture of <b>diverse kinds, this</b> is considered <b>taking possession</b> of the land, as he was allowed to benefit from the permitted branches.
§ <b>Rav Yaakov said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> With regard to <b>one who outlays expenditures for</b> the <b>property of his wife</b> who is a <b>minor girl</b> and was married off by her mother or brothers, he is <b>considered like one who outlays</b> expenditures <b>for the property of someone else.</b> Therefore, if she performed refusal upon reaching maturity, thereby annulling the marriage, he takes the value of the improvement. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>The Sages enacted this ordinance in order that he should not</b> let her property <b>depreciate.</b> If he is not guaranteed reimbursement for his expenses if she refuses him as her husband, he will not attend to the upkeep of her property, causing its value to decline.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain woman who had four hundred dinars bequeathed to her</b> in <b>Bei Ḥozai,</b> a remote location in Babylonia. The <b>man,</b> her husband, <b>went</b> and <b>took</b> with him <b>six hundred</b> of his own dinars for travel expenses and <b>brought</b> back with him <b>four hundred. While he was coming</b> back <b>he required one dinar, which he took from</b> the money he had collected. <b>He came before Rabbi Ami</b> for a ruling. Rabbi Ami <b>said to him: That which he spent he has spent, and that which he ate he has eaten.</b> He has benefited from one dinar of her money and spent six hundred of his own, and neither amount can be claimed.
<b>The Rabbis said to Rabbi Ami: This applies</b> only <b>where</b> he <b>consumes</b> the <b>produce</b> of his wife’s property, but <b>this</b> one <b>ate</b> from the <b>principal, and it is</b> merely <b>expenditures.</b> He replied: <b>If so, this is</b> a case of one who pays expenditures <b>and did not eat,</b> and the <i>halakha</i> is that in such a case <b>he takes an oath</b> with regard to <b>how much he paid and</b> then <b>takes</b> that amount.
§ The mishna states: <b>He takes an oath</b> with regard to <b>how much he spent and takes</b> this sum. <b>Rabbi Asi said: And this</b> applies only <b>if there is enhancement</b> to the property <b>corresponding to</b> his <b>expense.</b> The Gemara asks: With regard <b>to what <i>halakha</i></b> was this stated? Is this a stringency for the husband that if the value of enhancement is less he may not reclaim all his expenses, or is it a leniency that if the value is greater he need not take an oath? <b>Abaye said:</b> It means <b>that if</b> the value of <b>enhancement was greater than</b> the <b>expense, he takes the expense without an oath.</b>
<b>Rava said to him: If so, he will come to deceive,</b> as he can always say that he spent slightly less than the value of the enhancement and thereby receive this amount without having to take an oath. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> It means <b>that if the expense was greater than the enhancement, he has</b> rights to reclaim the <b>expense only</b> up to the <b>amount of</b> the <b>enhancement,</b> but no more, <b>and</b> even this amount he can claim only <b>by an oath.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>a husband who engaged sharecroppers</b> to work his wife’s property <b>in his stead, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does a sharecropper <b>begin work</b> on the land <b>with the intention</b> to work <b>for the husband,</b> so that if <b>the husband departs</b> the property, e.g., if he divorces his wife, <b>they</b> too <b>depart</b> as sharecroppers and do not receive their share of the profits from the land? <b>Or perhaps</b> a sharecropper <b>begins work with the intention</b> to work <b>the land, and the land, as it stands, stands</b> to be worked <b>by sharecroppers?</b> Since their involvement is directly with the land, it makes no difference who hired them, and they would stay on the land.
<b>Rava bar Rav Ḥanan objects to this</b> line of inquiry: In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from</b> that <b>of one who entered the field</b> of another <b>and planted it without permission?</b> In such a situation <b>one evaluates</b> his expenses <b>for him</b> and the value of his enhancement of the field, <b>and he is at a disadvantage.</b> Therefore, he always receives the smaller sum, whether it is equal to his expenses or the enhancement of the property. In this case too, even if the sharecroppers are viewed as unauthorized occupiers of the land, why shouldn’t they be treated like one who entered another’s field without permission and receive at least the smaller sum?
The Gemara answers: The two cases are not comparable: <b>There,</b> when one enters another’s land, <b>there is no one</b> else <b>that</b> will <b>exert</b> himself for it, and therefore it is reasonable that the one who invested in this property should at least be compensated for the lesser value. However, <b>here, there is a husband who exerts</b> himself for the land. Since the sharecroppers act in his stead, they are entitled to remain on the land only as long as he is present.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about</b> it, i.e., the original question? <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: We examine</b> the matter: <b>If</b> this <b>husband is a sharecropper</b> himself and possesses sufficient knowledge of working the land to perform the task himself, then when <b>the husband departs</b> from the property <b>they</b> too <b>depart,</b> as they are taking his place. <b>If</b> the <b>husband is not a sharecropper, the land is ready for sharecroppers,</b> as the husband would not have performed the work himself. Since the wife was in need of sharecroppers, they are not considered to have acted on behalf of the husband and do not forfeit their share.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to a <b>husband who sold</b> his wife’s <b>land for produce,</b> i.e., rights to the produce were sold to one who agrees to work the land in exchange, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say: That which belongs to</b> the husband <b>he has transferred</b> to others, and therefore the sale of the produce is valid, <b>or perhaps</b> the principle is <b>that when the Sages instituted</b> that the <b>produce</b> goes <b>to the husband,</b>

Daf 80b

they did so <b>for</b> the <b>gain of the house,</b> as more food is available when he brings produce home, <b>but</b> in order for him <b>to sell</b> it they did <b>not</b> institute their decree? Two opinions were stated with regard to this issue: <b>Yehuda Mar bar Mareimar said in the name of Rava: What he did is done,</b> i.e., takes effect. <b>Rav Pappa said in the name of Rava: He did not do anything.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said: This</b> statement <b>of Yehuda Mar bar Mareimar was not stated explicitly</b> in Rava’s name. <b>Rather,</b> it <b>was stated from an inference</b> based on an incident that occurred in <b>which a certain woman brought in for</b> her <b>husband two maidservants</b> as part of her dowry. The <b>man went</b> and <b>married another woman</b> in addition to the first. <b>He</b> subsequently <b>brought in to</b> the second wife <b>one of</b> the maidservants to attend to her needs.
The first wife <b>came before Rava</b> and <b>cried</b> about the injustice done to her, but <b>Rava took no notice of her,</b> claiming she had no right to complain. <b>He who observed</b> this incident <b>thought</b> that Rava ruled this way <b>because he holds</b> that <b>what he did is done,</b> i.e., takes effect, and a husband may sell his wife’s usufruct property and use its produce as he sees fit. <b>But that is not so,</b> as the Sages instituted the ordinance that a husband owns the rights to the produce of his wife’s property <b>for the gain of the house, and</b> here <b>the house does gain</b> from his action, as the maidservant also performs work for the house.
The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>a husband who sold land for produce did not do anything.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the rationale</b> for this ruling? <b>Abaye said: We are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the land itself <b>will deteriorate</b> over time, as the purchaser has acquired only its produce and has no incentive to take proper care of the land. <b>Rava said:</b> This is <b>because</b> there is no <b>gain of the house</b> here.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference between</b> these two explanations? The Gemara explains: <b>The practical difference between them</b> is, e.g., <b>land that is close to</b> the <b>town,</b> as one can check at any time whether the land is being cared for properly. <b>Alternatively,</b> the difference involves <b>a husband</b> who <b>is a sharecropper</b> and works the land himself but sold the rights of the produce to someone else. As a sharecropper, the husband retains part of the produce and will also ensure that the land does not deteriorate. <b>Alternatively,</b> the difference concerns a husband who receives <b>money</b> for the produce <b>and does business with it,</b> which provides gain for the house.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> When a married man dies childless, his brother, the <i>yavam</i>, is obligated to perform levirate marriage or release the widow, the <i>yevama</i>, through a ceremony known as <i>ḥalitza</i>. With regard to <b>a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i> who</b> had <b>property bequeathed to her, Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel agree that she may sell or give</b> this property away, <b>and</b> the transaction is <b>valid.</b>
If this woman <b>died, what should they do with her marriage contract and with the property that comes and goes with her,</b> i.e., her usufruct property? <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> Since she was not yet remarried, <b>the husband’s heirs,</b> such as his brothers or father, <b>divide</b> the property <b>with</b> her <b>father’s heirs. And Beit Hillel say: The property</b> retains <b>its</b> previous ownership <b>status, and</b> therefore the <b>marriage contract</b> is <b>in the possession of the husband’s heirs,</b> as they are responsible for its payment. As for the <b>property that comes and goes with her,</b> it is <b>in the possession of the heirs of the</b> woman’s <b>father,</b> as it belongs to the woman.
If <b>his</b> deceased <b>brother left money</b> as part of his estate, <b>land</b> to be used as a lien on her marriage contract <b>is acquired with it, and</b> the <i>yavam</i> <b>consumes the produce.</b> Similarly, if the deceased brother left <b>produce that is detached from the ground, land is acquired with it and</b> the <i>yavam</i> <b>consumes the produce.</b>
If he left behind produce <b>that is attached to the ground, Rabbi Meir says: One evaluates</b> the properties to determine <b>how much they are worth with</b> the <b>produce, and how much they are worth without</b> the <b>produce. And</b> as for <b>the surplus,</b> which is the value of the produce, <b>land is acquired with it and</b> the <i>yavam</i> <b>consumes the produce.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: Produce that is attached to the ground</b> is <b>his.</b> Therefore, it is not used in the purchase of land, but the <i>yavam</i> may eat it. As for the produce <b>that is detached from the ground,</b> which is not mortgaged to her marriage contract, <b>whoever</b> takes possession <b>first has acquired it.</b> If the <i>yavam</i> takes possession of the property <b>first,</b> he <b>has acquired</b> it and may use it as he wishes, but if <b>she</b> is <b>first, land is acquired with it and he consumes the produce.</b>
After the <i>yavam</i> has <b>married her, her</b> legal status is <b>that of his wife in every sense, except that</b> the responsibility for payment of <b>her marriage contract</b> is carried out <b>through</b> mortgaging <b>the property of her first husband,</b> not that of the <i>yavam</i>.
Therefore, the <i>yavam</i> <b>may not say to her: Your marriage contract is placed on the table.</b> He may not set aside a designated sum of money for this payment. <b>Rather, all</b> of the first husband’s <b>property is mortgaged for her marriage contract</b> as long as he has not divorced her. <b>And similarly,</b> in general <b>a man may not say to his wife: Your marriage contract is placed on the table. Rather, all his property is mortgaged for her marriage contract.</b>
If the <i>yavam</i> <b>divorced her</b> after performing levirate marriage, <b>she has only her marriage contract,</b> as she does not retain any rights to the rest of her first husband’s property. If he subsequently <b>remarried her, she is like all women, and she has nothing but her marriage contract.</b> In this case, the property of her first husband is no longer pledged for the payment of her marriage contract.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: In the case of <b>a widow awaiting her <i>yavam</i> who dies, who buries her?</b> Who is obligated to bear the expenses of her burial? Must the <b>husband’s heirs bury her, as they inherit the marriage contract, or perhaps</b> her <b>father’s heirs</b> are obligated to <b>bury her, as they inherit</b> the <b>property that comes and goes with her? Rav Amram said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i> who dies,</b>

Daf 81a

<b>her heirs,</b> i.e., <b>the heirs of her marriage contract, are obligated in her burial.</b> This indicates that her husband’s heirs, who inherit her marriage contract, must attend to her burial. <b>Abaye said: We too learn</b> in a mishna (95b): <b>A widow is sustained from the property of the orphans, and her earnings are theirs, and</b> they <b>are not obligated in her burial.</b> Instead, <b>her heirs, the heirs of her marriage contract, are obligated in her burial. And who is the widow who has two</b> sets of <b>heirs,</b> necessitating the ruling that only the heirs of her marriage contract are obligated in her burial? <b>You must say</b> that <b>this</b> is <b>a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i>,</b> as the <i>yavam</i> inherits her marriage contract.
<b>Rava said: But let</b> the <i>yavam</i> <b>say: I inherit</b> my <b>brother,</b> and I am therefore entitled to this marriage contract as my brother’s heir, while <b>his wife I</b> am <b>not</b> obligated to <b>bury,</b> as I have no connection to her. <b>Abaye said to him:</b> This claim is not valid <b>because they come upon him from two sides,</b> by force of two complementary claims: <b>If he inherits his brother</b> he should inherit his duties as well as his rights, and <b>he should bury his wife. If he does not bury his wife,</b> as he does not wish to take his brother’s place, <b>he should give her marriage contract</b> to her.
Rava <b>said to him: I say as follows:</b> The <i>yavam</i> claims that <b>I inherit</b> my <b>brother,</b> and <b>his wife I</b> will <b>not bury,</b> as this is not my responsibility. <b>And if</b> the brother should be responsible <b>due to</b> her <b>marriage contract, a marriage contract cannot be collected during</b> the husband’s <b>lifetime</b> but only after his death. The <i>yavam</i> is the first husband’s replacement, as he is prepared to perform levirate marriage with the woman, and therefore she is not entitled to her marriage contract, which means he is also not obligated to bury her. This assumption that a marriage contract may not be claimed during the husband’s lifetime is derived from a close reading of the wording of the marriage contract, which states: When you may marry another you may claim this marriage contract, which indicates that if the woman is unable to marry another man because her husband is still alive she is not entitled to her marriage contract.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who did you hear who is of</b> the opinion that <b>one expounds the marriage contract</b> and infers <i>halakhot</i> from its exact language, like expositions from the Torah? It is the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, and</b> yet <b>we have heard that Beit Shammai say a document that is ready to be collected is considered collected.</b> Here too, it should be considered as though she had already claimed her marriage contract, and he cannot claim to be acting as his brother’s heir.
The proof of this is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Sota</i> 24a): <b>If the husbands</b> of women suspected of being unfaithful <b>died before</b> their wives <b>drank</b> from the bitter waters in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> of a <i>sota</i>, and it was never established whether they had engaged in relations with another man, <b>Beit Shammai say: They take the marriage contract and do not drink, and Beit Hillel say: Either they drink or they do not take the marriage contract.</b>
The Gemara digresses to express puzzlement at the wording of this mishna: <b>Either they drink?</b> How can they drink the bitter waters? <b>The Merciful One states: “Then shall the man bring his wife to the priest”</b> (Numbers 5:15), <b>and there is no</b> way to fulfill that verse after the husband has died. <b>Rather,</b> Beit Hillel’s ruling should be understood as follows: <b>Since they do not drink,</b> as they have no husband who can compel them to drink the waters, <b>they do not take the marriage contract,</b> in case they were in fact unfaithful.
That mishna stated that <b>Beit Shammai say: They take the marriage contract and do not drink. But why</b> do they collect the marriage contract? <b>It is a</b> case of <b>uncertainty: Perhaps she committed adultery; perhaps she did not commit adultery.</b> If she was unfaithful she is not entitled to the marriage contract, <b>and</b> yet, although her position cannot be verified, Beit Shammai maintain that her <b>uncertain</b> claim <b>comes and supersedes</b> the <b>certain</b> claim of the heirs, as they are certainly the rightful heirs of their father.
It must therefore be concluded that <b>Beit Shammai maintain: A document that is ready to be collected is considered collected.</b> Consequently, the sum of the marriage contract is already considered in the woman’s possession, which means that when the heirs do not wish to pay the sum of the marriage contract they are actually trying to claim money due to an uncertainty.
The Gemara questions the earlier statement that the marriage contract may not be collected during the husband’s lifetime due to the exposition of the language of the document: <b>But</b> even if the language of a marriage contract is not expounded, the simple meaning of its words indicates that she may not claim it during the lifetime of the <i>yavam</i>, as <b>we require</b> the fulfillment of the clause: <b>When you</b> may <b>marry another you</b> may <b>take that which is written to you, and this is not</b> the case here, as the <i>yevama</i> may not marry anyone else before she takes part in <i>ḥalitza</i>. How, then, can the two claims come upon him, as Abaye suggested?
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The <b><i>yavam</i> is also considered like another</b> man, and it is as though she were about to marry another. Therefore, she is entitled to the marriage contract.
The above discussion took place when Abaye and Rava were learning this <i>halakha</i> together. Sometime later, <b>Rava sent Abaye</b> the following related difficulty <b>by way of Rav Shemaya bar Zeira: And can</b> the <b>marriage contract</b> of a <i>yevama</i> <b>be collected during</b> his <b>lifetime?</b>
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Abba says: I asked Sumakhos:</b> With regard to a <i>yavam</i> <b>who wants to sell his brother’s property</b> but is unable to do so because all his brother’s possessions are mortgaged to the <i>yevama</i>, <b>how can he proceed?</b> He replied: <b>If he is a priest,</b> who is prohibited from remarrying his divorced wife, <b>he should prepare a feast</b> for his wife after <i>yibbum</i> has been performed, <b>and</b> during the feast he should <b>persuade</b> her to allow him to sell the late brother’s property. <b>If he is a</b> regular <b>Israelite,</b> who may remarry his divorced wife, he can <b>divorce</b> her <b>with a bill of divorce,</b> at which point he is obligated to pay her only the sum of her marriage contract, and the rest of the property is then no longer mortgaged for it. While they are divorced he may sell the property <b>and</b> subsequently <b>remarry</b> her.

Daf 81b

<b>And if it enters our mind</b> that <b>a marriage contract can be collected during</b> his <b>lifetime,</b> why is all this necessary? <b>Let him set aside for her</b> part of the property that corresponds to <b>the amount of the marriage contract, and the rest let him sell.</b> Abaye replied: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> rather than asking this question based on a <i>baraita</i>, <b>let him raise</b> this difficulty <b>from the mishna,</b> which teaches that <b>he may not say to her: Your marriage contract is placed on the table for you. Rather, all his property is mortgaged for her marriage contract.</b> Why can’t he designate property equivalent to the sum of her marriage contract and sell the rest?
The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> in the mishna <b>there teaches us good advice,</b> i.e., that one should not do so <i>ab initio</i>, so as to ensure that the amount set aside for her marriage contract is not lost, which would necessitate writing a new marriage contract. However, it should not be inferred from the mishna that it is prohibited to do so. <b>As, if you do not say so,</b> that it is merely good advice, consider <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna, <b>which teaches: And similarly, a man may not say to his wife: Your marriage contract is placed on the table. Rather, all his property is mortgaged for her marriage contract. If he wants to sell, here too, may he not sell? Rather,</b> in that case the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us good advice,</b> and therefore <b>here too,</b> with regard to a <i>yevama</i>, <b>he teaches us good advice.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, the question is raised once again, as the statement <b>of Rabbi Abba</b> said in the name of Sumakhos <b>is difficult.</b> Why is it necessary for the husband to divorce his wife when he can set aside the sum of her marriage contract? The Gemara answers: That teaching <b>of Rabbi Abba</b> is <b>also not difficult,</b> as the reason one may not do so is not that he cannot designate a sum as her marriage contract but <b>due to enmity.</b> If he were to set aside a certain portion for her marriage contract, she would perceive this as a sign that he desires to be rid of her. If he divorces and remarries her, she would realize it is only a ploy to allow him to sell the property and does not indicate his desire to divorce her.
The Gemara relates: <b>A certain man had a <i>yevama</i> who happened</b> before <b>him</b> for levirate marriage <b>in</b> the city of <b>Pumbedita. His brother wanted to disqualify her from him by</b> means of <b>a bill of divorce,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> is that if one of the potential <i>yevamin</i> gives the <i>yevama</i> a bill of divorce she may no longer enter into levirate marriage with the others.
The brother who wished to perform levirate marriage <b>said to him: What is your opinion?</b> Why are you doing this? Is it <b>due to the property,</b> as you are jealous that his property will belong to me, in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> that the brother who performs levirate marriage inherits the late brother’s property, whereas if the <i>yevama</i> receives <i>ḥalitza</i> or a bill of divorce all the brothers share the inheritance equally? <b>I will divide the property with you.</b> Upon hearing this, the brother consented to him performing levirate marriage. However, when he married the woman, the husband refused to give his brother anything, and the case came before the court.
<b>Rav Yosef said: Since the Sages</b> have <b>said</b> that one <b>may not sell</b> the property of a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i> before marrying her, <b>although he sold</b> it, <b>his sale is not</b> a valid <b>sale.</b> So too, his promise to give half the property to his brother, which is equivalent to a sale in this case, is of no consequence. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who died and left a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i> and</b> also <b>left</b> behind <b>property</b> worth the value <b>of one hundred <i>maneh</i>,</b> equivalent to ten thousand dinars, <b>although her marriage contract is</b> worth <b>only</b> one <b><i>maneh</i>,</b> or one hundred dinars, the <i>yavam</i> <b>may not sell</b> any part of his possessions, <b>as all of his property is mortgaged for her marriage contract.</b> The Sages prohibited him from selling it. Therefore, if he did so the transaction is void.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>And anywhere that the Sages said</b> that one <b>may not sell,</b> is it the <i>halakha</i> that <b>although he sold, his sale is no sale? But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna (78a) with regard to a betrothed woman selling property: <b>Beit Shammai say: She may sell, and Beit Hillel say: She may not sell;</b> both <b>these,</b> Beit Shammai, <b>and those,</b> Beit Hillel, <b>agree that if she sold</b> it <b>or gave</b> it away, the transaction is <b>valid?</b> Evidently, even Beit Hillel agree that despite the violation of the Sages’ injunction, the sale is valid. Abaye therefore rejects Rav Yosef’s ruling. <b>They sent</b> this problem <b>before Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappi,</b> who <b>sent</b> back the following reply: The <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Yosef.</b>
<b>Abaye said</b> in response: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappi has hung jewelry upon it,</b> i.e., this ruling? His blunt declaration that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rav Yosef’s opinion without a logical explanation adds nothing to the discussion, and his decision should be rejected. <b>They sent</b> this inquiry <b>before Rav Minyumi, son of Rav Naḥumi,</b> who <b>sent</b> back the following written reply: The <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Abaye, but if Rav Yosef states a different reason for it, send</b> his reasoning <b>to me</b> and I will reconsider the matter.
<b>Rav Yosef went, examined</b> the <i>mishnayot</i> carefully, <b>and found</b> the following source for his opinion. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If one claimed</b> money <b>from his brother</b> that he had previously lent him, <b>and</b> then the lender <b>died and left</b> behind <b>a widow waiting for her <i>yavam</i>,</b> then the <i>yavam</i> who borrowed money <b>may not say: Since I inherit</b> my brother’s property by means of the <i>yevama</i>, <b>I</b> may also <b>take possession</b> of the debt, and I do not have to restore it to the other brothers. <b>Rather, one appropriates</b> the sum of the debt <b>from the <i>yavam</i>, and he purchases land with it</b> for the woman’s marriage contract, <b>and he eats the produce.</b> This serves as proof for Rav Yosef’s opinion that a <i>yavam</i> may not sell his brother’s property or take possession of a debt he owed his brother.
<b>Abaye said to him: Perhaps they did for him</b> that <b>which is good for him.</b> In other words, the <i>baraita</i> that states that one should purchase land and eat the produce is merely good advice to prevent the money from being lost. Rav Yosef <b>said to him: The <i>tanna</i> teaches: One appropriates,</b> i.e., against his will, <b>and you say that they did for him</b> that <b>which is good for him?</b> The language indicates that this is an obligation, not a matter of advice.
<b>They</b> once <b>again sent</b> this question <b>before Rav Minyumi, son of Rav Naḥumi. He said to them: So said Rav Yosef bar Minyumi</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said: This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is not a mishna</b> and therefore is not authoritative. Consequently, no proof may be adduced from it.
The Gemara inquires: <b>What is the reason</b> that this <i>baraita</i> is rejected? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>because</b> the money he owes <b>is</b> considered <b>movable property,</b> as it is not present, <b>and movable property is not mortgaged to a marriage contract,</b> as only land can be mortgaged for this purpose, such an argument does not negate the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Perhaps it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that <b>movable property is mortgaged to a marriage contract.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the reason for doubting the reliability of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>because he says to her: You are not my litigant.</b> There is no legal dispute between the man and the <i>yevama</i>. He claims that she is not a party to this suit, as he owes money to his late brother. Therefore, she cannot claim the money from him by arguing that it is mortgaged for her marriage contract.

Daf 82a

However, this still does not prove conclusively that the <i>baraita</i> is corrupt, as <b>perhaps it is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> in the case of one who <b>claims one hundred dinars of another, and the other</b> claims money <b>of another, that one appropriates</b> the money <b>from this one,</b> the last borrower, <b>and gives it to this one,</b> the first lender, without each party claiming the money from the one with whom he did business? <b>The verse states: “And he shall give it to him in respect of whom he has been guilty”</b> (Numbers 5:7). The words “whom he has been guilty” are expounded to mean that the borrower pays the one who is owed by his creditor, since the borrower is a party to this case despite the fact that he never incurred direct liability to him. It is possible to explain the <i>baraita</i> cited by Rav Yosef based on this reasoning as well.
<b>Rather,</b> a different justification exists for rejecting the <i>baraita</i>: <b>We have not found a <i>tanna</i> who is stringent</b> with these <b>two stringencies with regard to a marriage contract. Rather,</b> one rules <b>either in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> that movable property is mortgaged for a marriage contract, <b>or in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan.</b> No one accepts both of these stringencies, and yet this <i>baraita</i> can be explained only by a combination of the two opinions. It must therefore be rejected as non-authoritative.
<b>Rava said: If so, that</b> is the meaning of that <b>which I heard from Abaye, who said: This is not a mishna, and I did not know what it is.</b> Rava initially did not understand why the teaching should be dismissed, but he subsequently realized what Abaye was saying.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: There was <b>a certain man who had a <i>yevama</i> happen before him</b> for levirate marriage <b>in</b> the town of <b>Mata Meḥasya,</b> and <b>his brother wanted to disqualify her from him by</b> means of <b>a bill of divorce.</b> The man <b>said to</b> his brother: <b>What is your opinion?</b> Why are you doing this? <b>If</b> you are doing this <b>due to the property</b> of the dead brother, <b>I will divide the property with you.</b> The brother <b>said to him: I am scared that you will do to me like the swindler from Pumbedita did,</b> in the above story, when the man from Pumbedita promised he would share the inheritance and later retracted. The man <b>said to him: If you wish, divide it for yourself from now.</b> I am prepared for you to take the property already, although the acquisition will take effect only after I marry the <i>yevama</i>.
<b>Mar bar Rav Ashi said</b> that <b>although when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said: In the case of <b>one who says to another: Go and pull this cow and it will be acquired for you only after thirty days, after thirty days he has acquired</b> it through the act of pulling, <b>and</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if at the end of the thirty days the cow <b>was standing in a meadow,</b> i.e., a distant place that does not belong to the one acquiring the cow. This indicates that the present act of pulling is effective for later. Despite this <i>halakha</i>, Mar bar Rav Ashi claims that a difference exists between that case and the one currently under discussion.
Mar bar Rav Ashi elaborates: <b>There,</b> with regard to the cow, it is <b>in</b> the seller’s <b>power</b> to transfer ownership at the present time, when the instruction to pull the cow is given, and therefore he can delay the acquisition. <b>Here,</b> however, it is <b>not in his power</b> to divide up the property, as he has yet to perform levirate marriage and the brother’s property does not belong to him. Consequently, he cannot transfer its ownership at the present time.
The Gemara asks: <b>But when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said: If one is instructed to pull a cow, but the acquisition will take effect only after thirty days, he has <b>not acquired</b> it. This contradicts Rabbi Yoḥanan’s own ruling. The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> case, when one acquires it, is referring to a situation <b>when he says to him: Acquire</b> it <b>from now,</b> so that once thirty days have passed it should belong to him retroactively, but <b>that</b> case, when one does not acquire it, is <b>when he did not say to him: Acquire</b> it <b>from now.</b> If the acquisition does not take effect now, it cannot take effect later.
<b>They inquired of Ulla:</b> If the <i>yavam</i> <b>performed levirate marriage</b> with the woman <b>and afterward divided</b> the property he promised to share with his brother, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? He replied: <b>He has done nothing.</b> They further asked: If <b>he divided</b> the property <b>and afterward performed levirate marriage, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? He once again responded: <b>He has done nothing.</b>
<b>Rav Sheshet objects to this</b> version of the discussion: <b>Now</b> if, when <b>he performed levirate marriage and afterward divided</b> the property when it was in his possession, Ulla answered that <b>he has done nothing,</b> then in a case where he <b>divided</b> it <b>and afterward performed levirate marriage, is it necessary</b> to inquire as to the <i>halakha</i>? It is obvious that such an action is of no consequence. The Gemara answers: Ulla was not asked these two questions on the same occasion. Rather, <b>there were two incidents</b> in which people raised these issues before Ulla, and he answered each inquiry separately.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said</b> that <b>Reish Lakish</b> said: <b>Whether he performed levirate marriage and afterward divided</b> the property, or <b>whether he divided</b> the property and <b>afterward performed levirate marriage, he has done nothing.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the</b> practical <b><i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>he has done nothing.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>And the Rabbis say: Produce that is attached to the ground is his.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> is this so? <b>Doesn’t all of his property</b> serve as a <b>guarantee and security for her marriage contract? Reish Lakish said:</b> Emend the text and <b>teach:</b> Produce that is attached to the ground is <b>hers.</b>
The mishna further stated that if <b>he married her, she is like his</b> regular <b>wife.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> was this stated? <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> The mishna means <b>to say that he divorces her with a bill of divorce and</b> that <b>he may remarry her</b> afterward without violating a prohibition. The Gemara asks: The <i>halakha</i> that <b>he divorces her with a bill of divorce</b> is <b>obvious;</b> how else can he divorce her?
The Gemara explains: It is necessary to state this <b>lest you say</b> that since <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: “And he will take her to him to be his wife <b>and consummate the levirate marriage”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5), <b>and</b> here the status of <b>the first levirate marriage is still upon her,</b> this would mean that <b>it should not suffice for her</b> to leave <b>by a bill of divorce, but</b> rather she can leave him only <b>by</b> performing <b><i>ḥalitza</i></b> as well. The <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that <i>ḥalitza</i> is not required, as once he has married her she is like any other woman, who can be divorced by a bill of divorce alone.
The Gemara asks with regard to the second part of the interpretation of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, that <b>he may remarry her:</b> It is <b>obvious</b> that he may remarry her if the couple chooses to do so.

Daf 82b

The Gemara explains: It is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that <b>he has performed</b> the <b>mitzva the Merciful One placed upon him</b> by means of levirate marriage, <b>and now</b> that he has divorced her <b>she should</b> once again <b>stand</b> in relation <b>to him with the prohibition</b> proscribing <b>a brother’s wife,</b> which was her status before the mitzva of levirate marriage came into effect. The <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that since he performed levirate marriage with her, the prohibition proscribing a brother’s wife no longer applies at all.
The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> that <b>indeed,</b> the prohibition proscribing a brother’s wife should be in force once again. The Gemara explains: <b>The verse states: “And he will take her to him to be his wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5), which indicates that once <b>he has taken her, she has become like his</b> regular <b>wife</b> in all respects.
§ The mishna taught: She has the status of his wife in all respects after levirate marriage, <b>except that</b> the responsibility for <b>her marriage contract is upon the property of her first husband.</b> The Gemara inquires: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is that <b>from Heaven they acquired a wife for him.</b> Since he did not choose her but married her by force of a Torah commandment, he is not obligated to set aside for her a marriage contract of his own. Rather, he relies upon his brother’s marriage contract.
The Gemara adds: <b>And if she does not have</b> anything <b>from the first</b> husband, e.g., if he owned no property, <b>she</b> nevertheless <b>has</b> a marriage contract <b>from the second</b> one, for the same reason that any wife is entitled to a marriage contract in the first place: <b>So that she will not be demeaned in his eyes such that</b> he will easily <b>divorce her.</b>
The mishna further stated that the <i>yavam</i> <b>may not say to her: Here is your marriage contract,</b> and similarly, a man may not make such a statement to his wife. Rather, all of his property is mortgaged for her marriage contract. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the relevance of the phrase: <b>And similarly,</b> here? The <i>halakha</i> in both cases appears to be identical.
The Gemara explains: It is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that this <b>is</b> the <i>halakha</i> only <b>there,</b> with regard to a <i>yevama</i>, <b>where</b> the <i>yavam</i> did <b>not write</b> a marriage contract <b>for her</b> and therefore never wrote: All property <b>that I have bought and that I will buy</b> is mortgaged to the marriage contract. <b>But here,</b> with regard to a regular wife, <b>where he did write</b> a marriage contract <b>for her</b> that included the clause: <b>That I have bought and that I will buy, say that she relies</b> upon that which he has set aside, and therefore there is no need for a full lien on all his property. The <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case.
§ The mishna states that if <b>he divorced her she has only her marriage contract.</b> There is no lien upon the property, and he may therefore sell it. The Gemara infers: If <b>he divorced her, yes,</b> that is the case, but if <b>he did not divorce her, no,</b> it is not. The <i>tanna</i> here <b>teaches us</b> indirectly that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with Rabbi Abba,</b> who claims that the only way he can gain full control of all the property is by divorcing her.
It was further taught in the mishna that if he <b>remarried her, she is like all women, and she has nothing other</b> than <b>her marriage contract.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaching us</b> by mentioning the possibility that he <b>remarried her? We</b> already <b>learned</b> this: With regard to <b>one who divorces a woman and remarries her, he remarries her on the basis of</b> her <b>first marriage contract,</b> and he need not write her a new one. Why is it necessary to emphasize this <i>halakha</i> in the case of a <i>yevama</i>?
The Gemara answers: It is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that <b>it is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the case of <b>a wife, since he writes for her a marriage contract from him,</b> and therefore when he remarries her he does so on the basis of the first marriage contract. <b>But</b> as for <b>his <i>yevama</i>, where he did not write for her</b> the marriage contract but it was written by his brother, in a case <b>where he divorced her and remarried her, say</b> that <b>her marriage contract</b> should be <b>from him</b> and he should write a new one using his own property. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not required.
§ The Gemara discusses the background for the rule that the husband’s property is mortgaged for the marriage contract. <b>Rav Yehuda said: At first they would write for a virgin two hundred</b> dinars <b>and for a widow one hundred dinars.</b> They would then demand that this amount be available in cash, <b>and</b> then the men <b>would grow old and would not marry women,</b> as they did not all possess such large sums of money, <b>until Shimon ben Shataḥ came and instituted</b> an ordinance that a man need not place the money aside in practice. Rather, <b>all of his property is guaranteed for her marriage contract.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>That</b> opinion <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>At first they would write for a virgin two hundred and for a widow one hundred dinars, and they would grow old and would not marry women,</b> since the women were concerned that their marriage contract money would be wasted or lost, and they had no guarantee that it would be collected. The Sages therefore <b>instituted</b> an ordinance <b>that they should place it,</b> the sum of the marriage contract, <b>in her father’s house,</b> thereby ensuring its safekeeping. <b>And still</b> problems arose, as <b>when he was angry at</b> his wife, he would <b>say to her: Go to your marriage contract,</b> as it was too easy for them to divorce.
Therefore, the Sages <b>instituted</b> an ordinance <b>that they would place it in her father-in-law’s house,</b> i.e., in her husband’s house. And <b>wealthy</b> women <b>would craft</b> their marriage contract money into <b>baskets of silver and of gold,</b> while <b>poor</b> ones <b>would craft it</b> into <b>a large vessel</b> for the collection <b>of urine,</b> as their marriage contract was large enough only for a small vessel.
<b>And still, when he was angry at her he</b> would <b>say to her: Take your marriage contract and leave, until Shimon ben Shataḥ came and instituted</b> an ordinance <b>that</b> he does not actually give her the money for her marriage contract. Rather, <b>he should write to her: All my property is guaranteed for her marriage contract,</b> and it is not localized to a particular place or object. Consequently, he would need to sell some of his property if he wished to divorce her, and would therefore think carefully before undertaking such a drastic course of action.

Daf 83a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who writes for his wife</b> in a document the declaration: <b>I have no legal</b> dealings <b>or involvement with your property,</b> thereby relinquishing his rights to her possessions, <b>may</b> nevertheless <b>consume the produce</b> of her property <b>in her lifetime. And if she dies</b> before him, <b>he inherits</b> from <b>her. If</b> this is <b>so,</b> if he still retains his rights, <b>why</b> would he <b>write for her: I have no legal</b> dealings <b>or involvement with your property?</b> The result of this declaration is <b>that if she sold or gave</b> away her property, the transaction is <b>binding,</b> and he cannot claim it.
If <b>he writes for her: I have no legal</b> dealings <b>or involvement with your property or with its produce, he may not consume the produce</b> of her property <b>during her lifetime, but if she dies he</b> still retains the right to <b>inherit</b> from <b>her. Rabbi Yehuda says: He always consumes the produce of the produce.</b> Although he has waived his rights to consume the produce itself, it becomes her usufruct property, whose yield belongs to him. He remains entitled to the produce of the produce <b>until he writes for her: I have no legal</b> dealings <b>or involvement with your property, or with its produce, or with the produce of its produce forever.</b>
If <b>he writes for her: I have no legal</b> dealings <b>or involvement with your property or with its produce, or with the produce of its produce, in your lifetime and after your death, he may not consume the produce</b> of her property <b>in her lifetime. And if she dies, he does not inherit</b> from <b>her. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: If she dies, he does inherit</b> from <b>her, because</b> he <b>stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah.</b> According to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, a husband inherits from his wife by Torah law, <b>and whoever stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah, his stipulation is void.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who says to his wife;</b> he did not teach: One who writes for his wife, as the mishna stated. This indicates that this condition can be stated verbally and does not need to be written in a contract.
The Gemara asks about the ruling of the mishna: <b>And if he wrote this to her, what of it?</b> How does such a stipulation, written or otherwise, take effect? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who says,</b> whether verbally or by written communication, <b>to another</b> person with whom he shares property: <b>I have no legal</b> dealings <b>or involvement with this field, or I have no dealings with it, or my hands are removed from it, has not said anything?</b> This is because statements that waive rights without transferring them to another have no legal standing.
The Sages from <b>the school of Rabbi Yannai say:</b> The mishna is referring <b>to one who writes</b> such a statement <b>for her while she is still betrothed.</b> Since the property was not yet in the husband’s possession when he wrote this condition, he was able to forgo any rights that he would later receive. This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Kahana, as Rav Kahana said:</b> Concerning <b>an inheritance that comes to a person from another place,</b> i.e., he did not inherit it directly but rather through his wife or by means of a gift, <b>the person can stipulate with regard to it that he will not inherit it.</b> In this case, his statement is effective, although one cannot waive a right one already has. <b>And</b> this ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, as Rava said:</b> With regard to <b>one who says: I do not want</b> to avail myself of <b>an ordinance of the Sages</b> that was instituted for my benefit, <b>such as this</b> one, one <b>listens to him.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by: <b>Such as this</b> one? The Gemara explains: Rava is referring to <b>that</b> statement <b>of Rav Huna,</b> who said that <b>Rav said</b> a certain ruling. <b>As Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> that <b>a woman is able say to her husband: I will not be sustained</b> by you and, in turn, <b>I will not work,</b> i.e., you will not keep my earnings. The Sages instituted that a husband must provide sustenance for his wife, and in exchange is entitled to her wages. Since this was instituted for the benefit of the wife, she is able to opt out of this arrangement. Similarly, the husband may opt out of the arrangement granting him the right to the produce of his wife’s land.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> and Rava’s opinion that one can waive a right instituted by the Sages for his own benefit is accepted, then <b>even</b> if he relinquished his rights to his wife’s property once she was already <b>married,</b> his stipulation should <b>also</b> be valid. Why, then, was it necessary for Rabbi Yannai to explain that the stipulation in the mishna was made only in the case of a betrothed woman?
<b>Abaye said:</b> In the case of <b>a married</b> woman, <b>his hand,</b> i.e., his right to the property, <b>is like her hand.</b> Since the husband is considered a partner in her property, he cannot forfeit his ownership by declaration. <b>Rava said:</b> If they are married, <b>his hand is preferable to her hand,</b> i.e., he has more rights to her property than she does. The Gemara comments: The <b>practical difference</b> between the opinions of Rava and Abaye concerns the case <b>of a widow awaiting her brother-in-law [<i>yavam</i>]</b> to perform levirate marriage. If the husband’s rights are greater than the wife’s, then the rights of the <i>yavam</i> can be judged to be at least equal to that of the wife. If the husband and wife have equal rights in her property, then the rights of the <i>yavam</i> are inferior to the wife’s.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if one not only wrote a declaration relinquishing his rights to his partner’s property, but they also <b>performed an act of acquisition</b> transferring the rights <b>from him? Rav Yosef said: They acquired from him</b> only his promise of: <b>I have no legal</b> dealings <b>or involvement</b> with your property. Therefore, the transaction is no more effective than the promise itself. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The transaction is effective and <b>they acquired the land itself from him. Abaye said:</b> The <b>statement of Rav Yosef is reasonable</b>

Daf 83b

<b>in</b> the case of <b>one who</b> immediately <b>objects</b> when the other comes to claim the portion he was promised, saying that he wrote what he did only in order to avoid a quarrel. <b>However, in</b> the case of <b>one who waits</b> while the other takes possession of the land before regretting his decision and requesting its return, the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>one acquired from him the land itself,</b> as he cannot retract his statement at this late stage.
<b>Ameimar said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>one acquired from him the land itself. Rav Ashi said to Ameimar:</b> Do you mean to teach this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to one who</b> immediately <b>objects or with regard to one who waits?</b> The Gemara comments: <b>With regard to what</b> opinion <b>is</b> there <b>a practical difference?</b> There is a difference according <b>to</b> Abaye’s explanation of the opinion <b>of Rav Yosef.</b> However, according to Rav Naḥman, in either case the other retains possession of the land. Ameimar <b>said to him: I did not hear</b> about Abaye’s explanation of the opinion of Rav Yosef. <b>That is to say, I do not hold</b> in accordance with it. I do not distinguish between these two cases.
§ The mishna taught that if a husband says: I have no claim to your property, then he has not relinquished his right to benefit from the produce of the property or to inherit from his wife. The mishna asks: <b>If</b> this is <b>so,</b> and he still retains his rights, <b>why</b> would he <b>write for her:</b> I have no legal dealings or involvement with your property, and explains that his statement grants her permission to sell the property if she so wishes? The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> why does the wife not <b>say to him: You removed yourself from everything?</b> He wrote a general statement, which could be understood as a renouncement of all of his rights. <b>Abaye said:</b> There is a principle that <b>the owner of the document is at a disadvantage.</b> A document is always interpreted as narrowly as possible, to impose only the most limited obligations. Therefore, in this case, the husband is assumed to have relinquished only some of his rights.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if this is so, why not <b>say</b> that the husband has merely withdrawn his rights <b>from the produce?</b> A gift or sale of the entire land is a significant matter, certainly in relation to the minor value of its produce. Why, then, is his statement not understood as a renunciation of his rights to the produce? <b>Abaye said:</b> There is a proverb that <b>a cucumber</b> in one’s possession <b>is better than a gourd</b> one will have only later.
