There is an assumption that the husband’s current access to the produce is more important to him than the future ability to sell the field.
The Gemara continues to inquire: <b>And</b> why not <b>say</b> that the husband has withdrawn his rights <b>from the inheritance?</b> This is the least important right of the husband, as he might die before her. <b>Abaye said: Death</b> is <b>common,</b> whereas <b>a sale</b> is <b>not common,</b> as one does not usually sell one’s ancestors’ inheritance. <b>And when a person removes himself,</b> it is assumed that he does so <b>from an uncommon matter.</b> However, <b>a person does not remove himself from something that is common. Rav Ashi said</b> a different reason: The wording of the document is: I have no claim <b>to your property,</b> indicating: But I am <b>not</b> relinquishing my claim <b>to its produce.</b> Similarly, the statement: <b>To your property,</b> means during your lifetime, indicating: <b>But</b> I am <b>not</b> relinquishing my claim to it <b>after</b> your <b>death.</b>
§ The mishna taught that if a husband wrote: To your property and to its produce, he may not eat the produce. However, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He always consumes the produce of the produce. The Sages taught</b> with regard to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda: <b>Which is</b> considered the <b>produce, and which is</b> considered the <b>produce of the produce?</b> If <b>she brought</b> into the marriage <b>for</b> her husband <b>land that produced produce, this is produce.</b> If he <b>sold</b> the <b>produce and purchased land from their</b> sale, <b>and</b> this land <b>produced produce, this is the produce of the produce.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>According to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that the husband renounces his rights to his wife’s property by writing: To their produce and the produce of the produce forever, is it <b>specifically</b> the phrase <b>produce of the produce</b> that makes his statement effective, and it is sufficient if he writes only this phrase? <b>Or, perhaps</b> he must <b>specifically</b> write <b>forever,</b> and that alone is sufficient. <b>Or perhaps</b> it is effective only if he <b>specifically</b> writes <b>both of the</b> statements.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>If you say</b> that it is <b>specifically</b> the phrase <b>produce of the produce</b> that makes the statement of the husband effective, <b>why do I</b> need the mishna to include the word <b>forever?</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>This</b> word <b>teaches us</b> that <b>since he wrote to her: Produce of the produce, it is</b> considered <b>as though he wrote to her</b> the term <b>forever,</b> but it does not matter if in practice he omitted this word.
Conversely, the Gemara asks: <b>And if you say</b> that he must <b>specifically</b> write the word <b>forever, why do I</b> need the mishna to include the phrase: <b>Produce of the produce?</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>This</b> phrase <b>teaches us</b> that <b>although he wrote to her: Produce of the produce, if he</b> also <b>wrote to her</b> the word <b>forever,</b> then <b>yes,</b> he has renounced his rights. However, <b>if</b> he did <b>not</b> write this, then he has <b>not</b> withdrawn his rights from her property, and he may consume the produce of the produce of the produce.
<b>And if you say</b> that it is effective only if he <b>specifically</b> writes <b>both of the</b> statements, <b>why do I</b> need <b>two</b> expressions? The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary</b> to include both phrases, <b>for if he had written for her</b> only: <b>Produce of the produce, and not written for her: Forever, I would say</b> that <b>it is the produce of the produce that he may not consume, but the produce of the produce of the produce he may consume. For this</b> reason, it was <b>necessary</b> to also write <b>forever. And if he had written for her</b> only: <b>Forever, and</b> had <b>not written for her: Produce of the produce, I would say</b> that <b>forever is referring to the produce,</b> i.e., the husband permanently relinquishes his claim to the produce itself, but he retains his right to the produce of the produce. <b>For this</b> reason, it was also <b>necessary</b> to specify <b>produce of the produce.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If <b>the husband wrote to his wife: I have no claim to your property or to the produce of your produce, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the possibility <b>that he may consume the produce</b> itself? Has <b>he removed himself from the produce of the produce,</b> but <b>from the produce</b> itself, which he failed to mention, <b>he has not removed himself? Or perhaps he has removed himself from all matters,</b> as the produce of the produce includes the produce itself?
The Gemara answers: It is <b>obvious that he has removed himself from all matters, for if you say</b> that <b>he has removed himself</b> only <b>from the produce of the produce,</b> while <b>from the produce</b> itself <b>he has not removed himself, since he consumes the produce, from where</b> will there be <b>produce of the produce?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>But according to your reasoning,</b> the same question could be asked about the case discussed in the mishna, <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He always consumes the produce of the produce,</b> until he writes for her: Or to their produce, or to the produce of their produce forever. This indicates that if he did not write: To their produce, he would be allowed to consume the produce, just not the produce of the produce. Here too, it could be asked: <b>Since he consumes the produce, from where</b> will he have <b>produce of the produce? Rather,</b> it must be that this is referring <b>to one who left over</b> some of the produce, which he used to purchase land, of whose produce he consumes. If so, <b>here too,</b> this is a case <b>of one who left over</b> some of the produce, from which he acquired land, and it is the produce of this land to which he has no rights. The dilemma is left unresolved.
§ The mishna taught: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> Even if he wrote: I have no claim to your property, or to its produce, or to the produce of its produce, in your lifetime and after your death, he nevertheless inherits from her. This is because his condition is void, as it runs counter to what is written in the Torah. <b>Rav said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> that a husband inherits from his wife, <b>but not</b> because of <b>his</b> line of <b>reasoning.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of this statement: The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, but not</b> because of <b>his</b> line of <b>reasoning?</b> What does Rav mean? <b>If we say</b> that Rav agrees that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who said</b> that <b>if she dies he inherits</b> from <b>her, but</b> Rav maintains this opinion <b>not</b> because of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s line of <b>reasoning, as Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds</b> that if one <b>stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah, his condition is void, and</b> then <b>Rav</b> must <b>hold</b> that <b>his condition is valid. But</b> that is not so. Rav accepts Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s conclusion, <b>for he holds</b> that <b>the inheritance of a husband</b> is <b>by rabbinic</b> law, <b>and</b> for this reason his condition is void, as <b>the Sages reinforced their pronouncements with greater</b> severity <b>than</b> those of <b>Torah law</b> and decreed that the inheritance of a husband cannot be canceled in any manner.

Daf 84a

The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rav</b> actually <b>hold</b> that if one stipulates counter to Torah law, <b>his condition is valid? But it was stated: One who says to another:</b> I am selling this to you <b>on the condition that you have no</b> claim of <b>fraud against me,</b> i.e., though there is a prohibition against fraud by Torah law, the purchaser agrees to forgo his right to register a complaint on this basis. <b>Rav said: He does have</b> the right to a claim of <b>fraud against him,</b> and therefore the seller must reimburse the purchaser, as he cannot abrogate the Torah prohibition “And you shall not wrong one another” (Leviticus 25:17). <b>And Shmuel said: He does not have</b> the right to a claim of <b>fraud against him.</b> It is evident from here that according to Rav, one cannot make a stipulation that contradicts Torah law.
<b>Rather,</b> Rav said: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who said: One who stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah, his condition is void, but not</b> because of <b>his</b> line of <b>reasoning. As Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds</b> that if the wife <b>died, he inherits</b> from <b>her, and Rav holds</b> that if <b>she died he does not inherit from her.</b>
The Gemara asks: If this is what Rav meant, he should have said the opposite of what he said. <b>This</b> statement would be because of <b>his</b> line of <b>reasoning but not in accordance with his <i>halakha</i>,</b> whereas Rav said that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel but not because of his line of reasoning.
<b>Rather,</b> Rav said: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who said</b> that <b>if she died he inherits</b> from <b>her, but not</b> because of <b>his</b> line of <b>reasoning. As Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds</b> that <b>in</b> a case where one stipulated counter to <b>Torah</b> law <b>his condition is void,</b> indicating that <b>in</b> a case where his stipulation was counter to <b>rabbinic</b> law <b>his condition is valid; and Rav holds</b> that <b>even in</b> a case where one stipulated counter to <b>rabbinic</b> law, <b>his condition is void.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> statement would be <b>in accordance with his</b> line of <b>reasoning and in accordance with his <i>halakha</i>, and Rav is</b> merely <b>adding</b> a detail to the <i>halakha</i> of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.
<b>Rather,</b> Rav said: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who said</b> that <b>if she died he inherits</b> from <b>her, but not</b> because of <b>his</b> line of <b>reasoning. As Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds</b> that <b>the inheritance of a husband</b> is <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>and whoever stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah, his condition is void; and Rav holds</b> that <b>the inheritance of a husband</b> is <b>by rabbinic</b> law, but his stipulation is nevertheless void, as <b>the Sages reinforced their pronouncements with</b> the severity <b>of Torah law</b> and ruled that their laws cannot be abrogated.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rav hold</b> that <b>the inheritance of a husband</b> is <b>by rabbinic</b> law? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Bekhorot</i> 52b) that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka says: One who inherits</b> from <b>his wife must return</b> the property <b>to</b> her <b>family members</b> in the Jubilee Year <b>and deduct for them</b> part <b>of the monetary</b> value of the property? He can claim only part, but not all, of the property’s value from the wife’s relatives.
<b>And we discussed</b> this <i>halakha</i>: <b>What does</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka <b>hold? If</b> he <b>holds</b> that <b>the inheritance of a husband</b> is <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>why must he return</b> the property to his wife’s relatives? An inheritance is not given back in the Jubilee Year. <b>And if</b> he holds that the inheritance is <b>by rabbinic</b> law, <b>what is the purpose of</b> the <b>money</b> that he receives from his wife’s relatives in exchange for the land? By Torah law, the property belongs to the woman’s family and they should not have to pay him anything.
<b>And Rav said: Actually,</b> he <b>holds</b> that <b>the inheritance of a husband</b> is <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>and</b> he is discussing a case <b>where his wife bequeathed to him</b> her family’s <b>graveyard. Due to</b> the need to avoid <b>a family flaw,</b> i.e., harm to the family name if the wife’s family would have to be buried in plots belonging to others, <b>the Sages said</b> that <b>he should take compensation</b> from them <b>and return</b> the graveyard to them.
The Gemara continues: <b>And what is</b> the meaning of: <b>And deduct for them</b> part <b>of the monetary</b> value of the property? This is referring to the <b>monetary</b> value <b>of his wife’s grave.</b> A husband is obligated to pay for his wife’s burial, and therefore he must deduct the value of her burial plot from the value of the field. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that there are <i>halakhot</i> connected with burial to uphold family honor: In the case of <b>one who sells his grave, or</b> the <b>path</b> to <b>his grave,</b> or <b>the place</b> where visitors would <b>stand</b> to comfort the mourners, <b>or the place of his eulogies, the members</b> of his <b>family may come and bury him</b> in his ancestral plot <b>against</b> the purchaser’s <b>wishes due to</b> the need to avoid <b>a family flaw,</b> i.e., harm to the family name if a member of their family had to be buried in a graveyard of strangers. In any case, it is evident from here that Rav believes that the inheritance of a husband is by Torah law, in contrast to what the Gemara had said earlier.
The Gemara answers: This is not proof that Rav himself is of the opinion that the inheritance of a husband is by Torah law, as <b>Rav spoke in accordance with the reasoning of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka.</b> In other words, he was explaining the reason for the ruling of the <i>tanna</i>, <b>but he himself does not hold accordingly.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who died and left</b> behind <b>a wife, and a creditor</b> to whom he owed money, <b>and heirs,</b> all of whom claim payment from his property, <b>and he had a deposit or a loan in the possession of others, Rabbi Tarfon says:</b> The deposit or the loan <b>will be given to the weakest</b> one <b>of them,</b> i.e., the one most in need of the money. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: One is not merciful in judgment.</b> If the <i>halakha</i> is that it belongs to one party, one follows the <i>halakha</i> and leaves aside considerations of mercy. <b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that the money <b>will be given to the heirs, as all</b> people who wish to exact payment from orphans <b>require an oath</b> before they collect their debt, <b>but the heirs do not require an oath.</b> They therefore have a more absolute right than the others to their father’s property.
If the deceased <b>left</b> behind <b>produce</b> that was <b>detached from the ground, whoever first</b> took possession <b>of them</b> as compensation for what was owed, whether the creditor, the wife, or the heirs, <b>acquired</b> the produce. If the <b>wife acquired</b> this produce and it was worth <b>more than</b> the payment of <b>her marriage contract, or the creditor</b> acquired this produce and it was worth <b>more than</b> the value of <b>his debt,</b> what should be done with <b>the surplus? Rabbi Tarfon says:</b> It <b>will be given to the weakest</b> one <b>of them,</b> either the creditor or the wife, depending on the circumstances. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: One is not merciful in judgment. Rather, it will be given to the heirs, as all</b> people who wish to exact payment from orphans <b>require an oath</b> before they collect their debt, <b>but the heirs do not require an oath.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks about the wording of the mishna: <b>Why do I</b> need the <i>tanna</i> <b>to teach</b> this <i>halakha</i> in the case of <b>a loan,</b> and <b>why do I</b> need him <b>to teach</b> it in the case of <b>a deposit?</b> Either example alone would have sufficed. The Gemara explains: It is <b>necessary</b> to teach the <i>halakha</i> in both cases, <b>for if he</b> had <b>taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> only in the case of <b>a loan,</b> one could have said: <b>In that</b> case <b>Rabbi Tarfon says</b> what he says <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>a loan is given to be spent.</b> Since there is no already existing property here, but only an obligation to pay back the loan, it can be given to the weakest party. <b>However,</b> in the case of <b>a deposit, which exists in its pure,</b> unadulterated form and not just as an obligation, one might <b>say</b> that <b>he concedes to Rabbi Akiva</b> that it belongs to the heirs.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the <i>tanna</i> had <b>taught that</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in the case of a deposit, one could have said that <b>in that</b> case <b>Rabbi Akiva says</b> his ruling that the deposit belongs to the heirs. However, <b>in this</b> case of a loan, one could <b>say that he concedes to Rabbi Tarfon</b> that the loan is given to the weakest party. It is therefore <b>necessary</b> for the <i>halakha</i> to be taught in both cases.
The mishna taught that according to Rabbi Tarfon, the money should be given to the weakest party. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>To the weakest? Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says:</b> It means that the money is given <b>to the one</b> whose <b>proof</b> is the <b>weakest,</b> i.e., the one with the latest date on the document attesting to the debt. His document is the weakest, as one can collect from property that was sold by the deceased only if it was sold subsequent to his incurring the debt. Therefore, the others can collect from property that has been sold before the date listed on his document. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is referring <b>to the wife’s marriage contract.</b> The Sages instituted <i>halakhot</i> in marriage contracts that were to the advantage of women and to make them feel more secure in their marriages, <b>due to</b> the fact that they wanted men to find <b>favor</b> in the eyes of women.
The Gemara comments: This discussion is <b>like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>: Rabbi Binyamin says:</b> The money is given <b>to the one</b> whose <b>proof</b> is the <b>weakest, and this is</b> the <b>proper</b> way to act. <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> It is referring <b>to the wife’s marriage contract, due to</b> the fact that they wanted men to find <b>favor</b> with women.
§ The mishna taught that if the husband <b>left</b> behind <b>produce that was detached,</b> the claimant who first seizes it acquires it, and there is a dispute as to what should be done with the surplus. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Akiva, why</b> discuss <b>specifically</b> this case of the <b>surplus? All</b> of the produce, not only the surplus, <b>also</b> belongs to <b>the heirs,</b> as he holds that the entire property goes to the heirs, even if the others took possession of it first. The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is indeed so.</b> Certainly Rabbi Akiva does not distinguish between a deposit and detached produce, <b>but since Rabbi Tarfon spoke</b> of <b>a surplus, he also taught</b> his <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a surplus.</b> However, according to Rabbi Akiva, the <i>halakha</i> is the same with regard to detached produce.

Daf 84b

The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> is the <b>seizure</b> of a debtor’s assets by a creditor, though there are others who have a more immediate right to the assets, <b>not effective at all? Rava said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said: And this,</b> that Rabbi Akiva agrees that the seizure of assets is effective, is the case <b>provided that one seized</b> the property <b>from</b> the debtor while he was <b>alive.</b> However, after his death the assets belong to the heirs.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabbi Tarfon,</b> who holds that whoever first takes possession of the produce has acquired it, <b>where was</b> this produce <b>placed?</b> The Gemara presents a dispute: There is the opinion of <b>Rav and Shmuel, who both say: And this,</b> that whoever first takes possession of the produce has acquired it, is the <i>halakha</i> <b>provided that</b> the produce is <b>arranged in a pile and placed in the public domain.</b> Since the public domain is not a suitable location for an act of acquisition, anyone can take the produce and acquire it. <b>However,</b> if it is situated <b>in an alley [<i>simta</i>],</b> a place adjacent to the public domain that is rarely frequented by the public, the produce does <b>not</b> belong to the first one who obtains it. Because an acquisition can be performed in an alley, any items that had belonged to the deceased are immediately acquired by the heirs. <b>And</b> there is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish, who both say: Even</b> if one seizes produce left <b>in an alley,</b> he acquires it.
The Gemara relates: There were <b>judges</b> who <b>judged</b> a case of this kind <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Tarfon, and Reish Lakish reversed their action.</b> He dismissed the judges’ decision and restored the money to the heirs, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> criticized his ruling and <b>said to him: You acted</b> in this case <b>like</b> one acts with regard to a ruling <b>of Torah</b> law, where any incorrect action taken by the court must be corrected.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that they disagree about this: That</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Reish Lakish, <b>holds</b> that if one <b>erred in a matter</b> that appears in the <b>Mishna,</b> the decision is <b>revoked. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that if one <b>erred in a matter</b> that appears in the <b>Mishna,</b> the decision is <b>not revoked.</b>
The Gemara refutes this suggestion: <b>No,</b> it can be explained that according to <b>everyone,</b> where the judge <b>erred in a matter</b> that appears in the <b>Mishna,</b> the decision is <b>revoked, and here they disagree about this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> in his disputes with <b>his colleague, but not</b> in his disputes with <b>his teacher,</b> and Rabbi Tarfon was Rabbi Akiva’s teacher. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Reish Lakish, <b>holds</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva <b>even</b> in his disputes with <b>his teacher.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone</b> agrees that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> in his disputes with <b>his colleague but not</b> in his disputes with <b>his teacher. And here they disagree about this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>Rabbi Tarfon was</b> Rabbi Akiva’s <b>teacher, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Reish Lakish, <b>holds</b> that Rabbi Tarfon <b>was his colleague.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone</b> agrees that Rabbi Tarfon <b>was</b> Rabbi Akiva’s <b>colleague, and here they disagree about this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Reish Lakish, <b>holds</b> that the principle that the law is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva <b>was stated</b> as the <b><i>halakha</i>. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that what <b>was stated</b> was that <b>one is inclined</b> to follow the opinion of Rabbi Akiva. Therefore, although Rabbi Akiva’s opinion is followed <i>ab initio</i>, the <i>halakha</i> was never established conclusively in accordance with it. As such, if judges went against the principle that the <i>halakha</i> follows Rabbi Akiva in opposition to his colleague, the Sages do not revoke their decision.
The Gemara relates: <b>The relatives of Rabbi Yoḥanan seized a cow of orphans from an alley</b> because the orphans’ father owed them money. <b>They came before Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> for judgment, and <b>he said to them:</b> It <b>is well</b> that <b>you seized</b> the cow and it is yours, in accordance with the ruling of Rabbi Tarfon. <b>They</b> subsequently <b>came before Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> who <b>said to them: Go</b> and <b>return</b> the cow to the orphans. <b>They</b> again <b>came before Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> complaining that Reish Lakish had told them they must give back the cow, in opposition to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s ruling. <b>He said to them: What can I do, as one whose</b> stature <b>corresponds to my</b> stature <b>disagrees with me,</b> and I cannot dismiss his opinion.
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <b>a certain herdsman</b> caring for the cattle <b>of orphans from whom</b> a creditor <b>seized an ox</b> as payment for a debt of the orphans’ father. The <b>creditor said: I seized it from</b> the herdsman <b>while</b> the debtor was still <b>alive.</b> In such a case, the action is effective even according to Rabbi Akiva, as stated earlier. <b>And the herdsman said: He seized it after</b> the debtor’s <b>death. They came before Rav Naḥman</b> for a ruling. Rav Naḥman <b>said to</b> the herdsman: Do <b>you have witnesses that he seized</b> the ox <b>from you? He said to him: No.</b> Rav Naḥman <b>said to him:</b> In that case, <b>since</b> the claimant <b>can say: It</b> is <b>in my possession</b> because <b>it was purchased</b> by me, as there is no proof that he gained possession of the ox unlawfully, <b>he can also say: I seized it from</b> the herdsman <b>while</b> the deceased was still <b>alive.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Reish Lakish say</b> that <b>moving livestock,</b> e.g., sheep and oxen, provide <b>no presumption</b> of ownership to whoever is in possession of them? Since they wander from place to place, a person cannot claim that his mere possession of livestock demonstrates ownership, because it may have wandered into his property on its own. The Gemara answers: <b>An ox is different</b> from other livestock, <b>as</b> it <b>is handed over to a shepherd,</b> who does not let it wander off. Consequently, possession of an ox does establish a presumption of ownership.
The Gemara relates another incident: The members of <b>the house of the prince</b> of Eretz Yisrael <b>seized</b> hold of <b>a maidservant of orphans in an alley,</b> as payment for a debt owed to them by the orphans’ father. <b>Rabbi Abbahu and Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappi and Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa were sitting</b> as judges, <b>and Rabbi Abba was sitting with them.</b> Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to them:</b> It <b>is well</b> that <b>you seized</b> the maidservant. <b>Rabbi Abba said to</b> the judges: Just <b>because they are</b> members of <b>the house of the prince, will you curry favor with them</b> by rendering an incorrect verdict? Isn’t it the <i>halakha</i> that there were <b>judges</b> who <b>judged</b> a case of this kind <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Tarfon, and Reish Lakish reversed their action,</b> indicating that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Tarfon?
The Gemara relates another incident: A man called <b>Yeimar bar Ḥashu was owed money by a certain man</b> who <b>died and left</b> behind <b>a boat.</b> Yeimar bar Ḥashu <b>said to his agent: Go</b> and <b>seize</b> the boat <b>for me.</b> The agent <b>went</b> and <b>seized it. Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, encountered him. They said to him: You are seizing</b> assets <b>for a creditor in a situation</b> where your action will cause <b>a disadvantage for others,</b> as the debtor owed money to other people as well. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that <b>one who seizes</b> assets <b>for a creditor in a situation</b> that will result in <b>a disadvantage for others</b>

Daf 85a

<b>has not acquired</b> it. He cannot act to the detriment of others without their consent, and his acquisition harms the other creditors. Those Sages were also owed money by that same man, so <b>they</b> both <b>seized</b> the boat for himself. <b>Rav Pappa steered</b> it <b>with an oar,</b> while <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, pulled it with a rope.</b> This <b>Sage said: I acquired all of it; and</b> that <b>Sage said: I acquired all of it.</b>
<b>Rav Pineḥas bar Ami encountered them</b> and <b>said to them:</b> What of the opinion of <b>Rav and Shmuel, who both say: And this,</b> that whoever first takes possession has acquired them, is the <i>halakha</i> <b>provided that</b> the items are <b>arranged in a pile and placed in the public domain,</b> which is not the case with this boat? <b>They said to him: We too seized it from the current of the river,</b> i.e., the middle of the river, which has the status of a public domain.
<b>They came before Rava</b> to ask him who had acquired the boat. <b>He said to them:</b> You are <b>white geese [<i>kakei ḥivvarei</i>],</b> in reference to their white beards, <b>who remove people’s cloaks,</b> i.e., your actions were unlawful from the start. <b>This is what Rav Naḥman said: And this,</b> that whoever takes possession has acquired them, is the <i>halakha</i> <b>provided that one seized</b> them <b>from</b> the debtor <b>while</b> he was <b>alive.</b> In this case, however, the boat was seized after the debtor’s death, when the heirs had already taken possession of it.
The Gemara relates another incident: <b>Avimi, son of Rabbi Abbahu, owed money</b> to people from <b>Bei Ḥozai. He sent</b> the money <b>in the possession of Ḥama, son of Rabba bar Abbahu,</b> who <b>went</b> and <b>paid</b> the money that Avimi, son of Rabbi Abbahu, owed, and he then <b>said to</b> the people from Bei Ḥozai: <b>Give me</b> back <b>the document</b> that shows that the person who sent me owes you money. <b>They said to him:</b> The money that you paid us <b>was for side</b> debts, i.e., money from a different debt, which was not written in a document. We accepted the money from you as payment of that debt. We will therefore not return the document to you, as he has yet to pay off the debt listed in the document.
This case <b>came before Rabbi Abbahu. He said to</b> Ḥama, son of Rabba bar Abbahu: Do <b>you have witnesses that you paid them? He said to him: No.</b> Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him: He could have made a more advantageous claim [<i>miggo</i>]. Since they can say: These matters never occurred,</b> i.e., you never paid them anything, <b>they can also say: These are side</b> debts. Therefore, you cannot demand from them either the money or the document.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to the payment of the agent, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Must the agent reimburse the one who appointed him for his loss? <b>Rav Ashi said: We see</b> that <b>if</b> the one who appointed him <b>said to him: Take the document</b> from them <b>and give</b> them <b>money,</b> then the agent disobeyed his instructions by first paying the money and must <b>pay</b> back the one who appointed him. If, however, the one who appointed him said to the agent: <b>Give</b> the <b>money and take the document, he does not pay,</b> as the one who appointed him was not particular about instructing the agent to take the document before giving them money.
The Gemara comments: <b>And this is not so;</b> Rav Ashi’s ruling is not accepted as <i>halakha</i>. <b>Whether</b> the instructions were given in <b>this</b> manner <b>or whether</b> the instructions were given in <b>that</b> manner, the agent must <b>pay, as</b> the one who appointed him can <b>say to him: I sent you to</b> act for <b>my benefit, and not to my detriment.</b> His right to act as an agent did not extend to a case where it was to the detriment of the one who designated him.
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <b>a certain woman who had a bag [<i>meloga</i>]</b> full <b>of documents deposited with her. The heirs came</b> and <b>claimed it from her. She said to them: I seized</b> the bag of documents from the deceased <b>while</b> he was <b>alive,</b> as he owed me money. <b>They came before Rav Naḥman</b> for judgment. <b>He said to her:</b> Do <b>you have witnesses that</b> the deceased <b>claimed</b> the bag <b>from you while</b> he was <b>alive and you did not give it to him? She said to him: No,</b> I do not have witnesses to this effect. He replied: <b>If so, this is</b> considered a case of <b>seizing</b> property <b>after death, and seizing after death is nothing.</b> As stated earlier, seizing property to recover a debt is effective only when done during the lifetime of the debtor. It is ineffective once he is dead and others have inherited his property.
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <b>a certain woman who was obligated</b> to take <b>an oath</b> in order to avoid payment <b>in Rava’s court. The daughter of Rav Ḥisda said to</b> Rava, her husband: <b>I know that she is suspect with regard to</b> taking a false <b>oath. Rava reversed</b> the obligation of <b>the oath</b> so that it fell <b>onto the other</b> party, who now had the option of taking an oath that the woman owes him money and collecting his debt. This is how to act when the court does not trust the one who is obligated to take an oath.
The Gemara continues: <b>On</b> another <b>occasion, Rav Pappa and Rav Adda bar Mattana were sitting before</b> Rava. <b>A certain document was brought before</b> Rava to be examined in court. <b>Rav Pappa said to</b> Rava: <b>I know about this document, that it</b> records a debt that has already been <b>paid.</b> Rava <b>said to him: Is there another person</b> who can testify <b>with</b> the <b>Master</b> about the document? <b>He said to him: No,</b> I am the only one who knows. Rava <b>said to him: Although there is</b> the <b>Master</b> here who attests that the document has been paid, <b>one witness is nothing.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Mattana said to</b> Rava: <b>And should Rav Pappa not be</b> trusted <b>like Rav Ḥisda’s daughter,</b> who as a woman is disqualified from testimony? Rava replied: I relied on <b>Rav Ḥisda’s daughter</b> because <b>I know with certainty about her</b> that she is always truthful. However, I cannot rely on the <b>Master</b> because <b>I do not know with</b> the same degree of <b>certainty about him</b> that he is always truthful, and I cannot rule on the basis of one witness unless I have complete certainty.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Now that the Master,</b> Rava, <b>has said</b> that the claim: <b>I know with certainty about him, is</b> a significant <b>matter,</b> i.e., a claim that can be used in court, if a judge knows that someone is telling the truth, although under normal circumstances his testimony would be inadmissible, in this case it does have a certain legal validity. <b>For example,</b> if <b>Abba Mar, my son, about whom I know with certainty</b> always tells the truth, claims that a document that records a debt has already been paid, then <b>I</b> can <b>tear the document on</b> the basis of <b>his word.</b>
The Gemara asks: How can it <b>enter your mind</b> that the court can <b>tear</b> a document based on the word of a single witness? <b>Rather,</b> the statement should be that <b>I</b> can <b>weaken the document on</b> the basis of <b>his word,</b> by not allowing it to be used for claiming payment without further proof.
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <b>a certain woman who was obligated</b> to take <b>an oath</b> in <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye’s court.</b> The opposing <b>litigant said to</b> the judges: Let <b>her come and take an oath in the town. It is possible that she will be ashamed</b> of her lies <b>and will admit</b> that she is liable. <b>She said to</b> the judges: <b>Write</b> a document of <b>rights for me,</b> so <b>that when I take the oath they will give</b> it <b>to me,</b> and I will then be willing to take an oath in the town. <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye said to them: Write</b> the document <b>for her.</b>
<b>Rav Pappi said:</b> Is it <b>because you come from unfortunate people [<i>de’atitu mimmula’ei</i>]</b> that <b>you say unfortunate things?</b> Rav Beivai was from the house of Eli, whose descendants were sentenced to die at a young age.
Rav Pappi said that Rav Beivai bar Abaye was wrong to say what he said because of a statement of Rava. <b>Didn’t Rava say: This ratification of judges, which was written</b> on a document <b>before</b> the <b>witnesses had seen</b> and testified <b>about their signature, is invalid,</b> although the witnesses later attested that it was their signatures? <b>Apparently,</b> it has <b>the appearance of falsehood</b> because they affirmed the validity of a document before hearing the testimony. <b>Here too,</b> if the judges wrote a document of rights before the woman took her oath, the document would <b>have the appearance of falsehood,</b> and the court should not write a document of rights for her before she takes an oath.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> this <i>halakha</i> of Rava’s is <b>not</b> accepted <b>because of</b> a statement <b>of Rav Naḥman, as Rav Naḥman said: Rabbi Meir would say: Even if</b> the husband <b>found</b> a bill of divorce with names identical to those of his and his wife’s, <b>in the garbage, and he had it signed</b> by witnesses <b>and gave it to</b> his wife, it is <b>valid.</b> Rav Naḥman adds: <b>And the Rabbis do not disagree with Rabbi Meir, except</b> in the case of <b>bills of divorce of women, since</b> the Rabbis hold that <b>the writing</b> of the bill of divorce <b>needs</b> to be done <b>for the sake of</b> the woman getting divorced. <b>But for</b> all <b>other documents, they concede to him</b> that it makes no difference when the document was written.
The proof of this is <b>that Rav Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> With regard to <b>a document that one borrowed</b> money <b>based on it and</b> then <b>repaid</b> the debt, <b>he may not borrow money again based on it.</b> This is <b>because its lien has already been forgiven.</b> Once the debt has been repaid, the lien resulting from the loan is no longer in force. The witnesses did not sign the document at the time of the second loan, so the lien will not be in effect, and the loan will have the status of one by oral agreement. The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that he cannot reuse the document is <b>because its lien has been forgiven,</b> so that the document is no longer accurate; <b>but as</b> for the fact that it has the <b>appearance</b>

Daf 85b

<b>of falsehood,</b> as it was written prior to the second loan, <b>we are not concerned.</b> So too here, the fact that the judges wrote the document before the event is not a matter of concern.
The Gemara examines cases involving disputes concerning the property of the deceased. There was <b>a certain man who deposited seven pearls [<i>marganita</i>] tied up in a sheet</b> in <b>the house of Rabbi Meyasha, son of the son of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi. Rabbi Meyasha passed away without instructing</b> the members of his household on his deathbed, and without explaining to whom the gems belonged. Rabbi Meyasha’s family and the depositor <b>came before Rabbi Ami</b> to discuss the ownership of the gems. <b>He said to them:</b> They belong to the claimant, <b>first</b> of all, <b>since I know about Rabbi Meyasha, son of the son of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, that he is not wealthy</b> enough to be able to afford such gems. <b>And furthermore,</b> the depositor <b>has provided a distinguishing mark</b> that proves that he is the owner.
The Gemara comments: <b>And we said</b> that a distinguishing mark is effective <b>only</b> if the claimant <b>does not usually enter and exit there. But</b> if that person <b>usually enters and exits there,</b> one can <b>say</b> that <b>a different person</b> might have <b>deposited</b> the object, <b>and he</b> merely <b>saw</b> it there and was able to provide distinguishing marks.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: There was <b>a certain man who deposited a silver goblet</b> in <b>the house of</b> the Sage <b>Ḥasa. Ḥasa passed away without instructing</b> anything about the goblet. <b>They came before Rav Naḥman</b> to discuss the ownership of the goblet. <b>He said to them: I know about Ḥasa that he is not wealthy,</b> and this goblet would not have belonged to him. <b>And furthermore,</b> the depositor <b>has provided a distinguishing mark. And we said</b> so <b>only</b> if the claimant <b>does not usually enter and exit there. But</b> if that person <b>usually enters and exits there,</b> one can <b>say</b> that <b>a different person</b> might have <b>deposited</b> the object <b>and he</b> merely <b>saw</b> it there.
The Gemara relates another similar story: There was <b>a certain</b> man <b>who deposited silk [<i>metakesa</i>]</b> in <b>the house of Rav Dimi, brother of Rav Safra. Rav Dimi passed away without instructing</b> anything about the silk. <b>They came before Rabbi Abba</b> to discuss the ownership of the silk. He <b>said to them:</b> It belongs to the claimant, <b>first</b> of all, <b>since I know about Rav Dimi that he is not wealthy. And furthermore,</b> he <b>has provided a distinguishing mark. And we said</b> so <b>only</b> if he <b>does not usually enter and exit there. But</b> if that person <b>usually enters and exit there,</b> one can <b>say</b> that <b>a different person</b> might have <b>deposited</b> the object, <b>and he</b> merely <b>saw</b> it there.
The Gemara relates the story of <b>a certain</b> man <b>who said to</b> those present at his deathbed: <b>My property</b> should go <b>to Toviya.</b> He <b>passed away,</b> and <b>Toviya came</b> to claim his possessions. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Toviya has come,</b> and there is no need to be concerned that he might have meant a different Toviya.
The Gemara adds: If the deceased had <b>said:</b> My property should go to <b>Toviya, and Rav Toviya came</b> forward, it is assumed that this is not the person the deceased had in mind, for <b>he said:</b> My property should go <b>to Toviya. He did not say:</b> My property should go <b>to Rav Toviya. But if</b> Rav Toviya is <b>a person who is familiar with</b> the deceased, then it can be assumed that the deceased called him by his personal name and not by his title because <b>he was familiar with him.</b> If <b>two</b> men named <b>Toviya came</b> forward, and one of them was the deceased’s <b>neighbor</b> and the other <b>a Torah scholar</b> but not his neighbor, the <b>Torah scholar takes precedence.</b> Similarly, if one was <b>a relative and</b> the other <b>a Torah scholar, the Torah scholar takes precedence.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If two men have the same name and one was <b>a neighbor and</b> the other one was <b>a relative, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the solution from the following verse: <b>“A close neighbor is better than a distant brother”</b> (Proverbs 27:10). If <b>they</b> were <b>both relatives, or both neighbors, or both scholars,</b> there is no systematic way of determining who is entitled to the property, and the decision is left to <b>the discretion of the judges.</b>
§ <b>Rava said to the son of Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin: Come,</b> and <b>I will tell you something excellent that your father would say</b> about <b>that which Shmuel said:</b> Shmuel said that in the case of <b>one who sells a promissory note to another, and</b> the seller <b>went back and forgave</b> the debtor his debt, <b>it is forgiven,</b> since the debtor essentially had a non-transferable obligation to the creditor alone, <b>and even</b> the creditor’s <b>heir can forgive</b> the debt. With regard to this <i>halakha</i>, Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin said: <b>Shmuel concedes with regard to</b> a woman who <b>brings in a promissory note</b> to the marriage <b>for her husband, and she went back and forgave</b> the debtor his debt, <b>that</b> the debt <b>is not forgiven.</b> Why not? <b>Because his hand is like her hand,</b> i.e., the husband shares equal rights to her property, and she cannot unilaterally forgive the debt.
The Gemara relates an incident: <b>A relative of Rav Naḥman sold her marriage contract for financial advantage.</b> In other words, she received a sum of money and in exchange agreed that if she were to be divorced and become entitled to her marriage contract, the money would belong to the purchaser of the rights to her marriage contract. <b>She was</b> subsequently <b>divorced</b> from her husband <b>and died,</b> leaving the right to her marriage contract to her daughter. The purchasers <b>came</b> and <b>claimed</b> the value of the marriage contract <b>from her daughter. Rav Naḥman said to</b> the people around him: Is there <b>no</b> one <b>who can give</b> the daughter <b>advice,</b>

Daf 86a

that <b>she should go and forgive her mother’s marriage contract for her father, and she</b> will subsequently <b>inherit</b> the sum of the marriage contract <b>from him?</b> The marriage contract is a document of the debt owed by her father to her mother. The daughter, who has inherited the document from her mother, can forgo her father’s obligation, so rendering nugatory the right of the purchasers. The father then retains the amount owed to the purchasers of the marriage contract, and his daughter will inherit that amount when he dies. The daughter <b>heard</b> this, and <b>went and forgave</b> her father’s obligation in the marriage contract, as recommended by Rav Naḥman.
<b>Rav Naḥman</b> later <b>said</b> in regret: <b>We have made ourselves like advisors of judges.</b> We have acted like lawyers who give practical advice to litigants rather than like independent judges. The Gemara asks: <b>At the outset, what did he hold</b> when he intended the daughter to hear his advice, <b>and ultimately, what did he hold</b> that made him regret his action? The Gemara explains: <b>At the outset, he held</b> that the verse teaches: <b>“And you should not hide yourself from your own flesh”</b> (Isaiah 58:7), and therefore it is correct to give help and advice to relatives. <b>And ultimately he held that</b> in the case of <b>an important person</b> who must be very careful to avoid any impression of having favored his family in judgment, the situation <b>is different.</b>
Since the Gemara had previously mentioned a <i>halakha</i> stated by Shmuel, it turns its attention to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>one who sells a promissory note to another, and</b> the seller <b>went back and forgave</b> the debtor his debt, <b>it is forgiven,</b> since the debtor essentially had a non-transferable obligation to the creditor alone, <b>and even</b> the creditor’s <b>heir can forgive</b> the debt. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: And if</b> the purchaser of the document <b>is perspicacious,</b> and is wary of such a ploy, he should <b>jangle [<i>mekarkesh</i>] dinars</b> in the debtor’s ears, i.e., he should pay the debtor or promise him money, <b>and</b> the debtor will <b>write for him</b> a new promissory <b>note in</b> the purchaser’s <b>name,</b> thereby preventing the latter from losing out.
<b>Ameimar said: One who judges cases of liability for indirect damage</b> and maintains that someone whose actions cause damage is obligated to pay, even if he has not directly harmed another, <b>collects in this</b> case <b>the value</b> of <b>the proper document.</b> Since by forgiving the loan the creditor voided the document and caused the purchaser financial loss, he must compensate the purchaser for the amount recorded in the document. <b>One who does not judge cases of liability for indirect damage collects in this</b> case <b>only the value of the paper</b> on which the document was written.
The Gemara relates that <b>there was an incident</b> like this one, <b>and Rafram pressured Rav Ashi</b> by means of verbal persuasion to render an unequivocal ruling in this matter, <b>and</b> Rav Ashi <b>collected in this</b> case <b>as</b> if he damaged <b>a beam</b> used <b>for</b> crafting <b>a sculpture,</b> i.e., the full value of the debt listed in the promissory note.
<b>Ameimar said in the name of Rav Ḥama:</b> With regard to <b>one who has</b> incumbent <b>upon himself</b> the obligation of his <b>wife’s marriage contract and</b> also owes money to <b>a creditor, and</b> he <b>possesses land and possesses money,</b> the obligation <b>to the creditor is settled with</b> the payment of <b>money,</b> whereas the debt <b>to the woman</b> of her marriage contract <b>is settled with</b> the payment of <b>land, this one in accordance with his law, and that one in accordance with her law.</b> Since the creditor gave him money, it is fitting that he should receive ready cash in return. The woman, in contrast, did not give him anything but relied upon the lien on his land, so she is therefore given land.
<b>And if there is only one</b> plot of <b>land, and</b> it is <b>adequate for</b> the payment of <b>only one</b> debt, <b>we give it to the creditor,</b> and <b>we do not give it to the woman. What is the reason</b> for this? Even <b>more than a man wants to marry, a woman wants to be married.</b> Women do not get married because they wish to receive their marriage contract. It is better to give preference to the creditor so that he will not lose out, so as not to discourage people from lending money.
<b>Rav Pappa said to Rav Ḥama:</b> Is it <b>correct that you say in the name of Rava:</b> With regard to <b>one who owes money and has land, and the creditor comes and demands from him</b> his money, <b>and</b> the debtor <b>says to him: Go</b> and <b>take</b> the amount you are owed <b>from the land, we say to him: Go</b> and <b>sell the land yourself and give him</b> money? Rav Ḥama <b>said to him:</b> I did <b>not</b> say this in the name of Rava.
Rav Pappa replied: <b>Tell me the incident itself, what happened</b> and what exactly occurred that caused this opinion to be attributed to Rava. Rav Ḥama <b>said to him:</b> The debtor <b>was one who attached his money to a gentile.</b> He possessed money, but he claimed that this money belonged to a gentile and therefore could not be demanded from him. <b>This</b> man <b>acted improperly,</b> and <b>consequently,</b> the Sages <b>acted improperly with him</b> by forcing him to sell the land.
<b>Rav Kahana said to Rav Pappa: According to your</b> opinion, <b>that you say the repayment of a creditor</b> is <b>a mitzva,</b> if the debtor <b>said: It is not amenable to me to perform a mitzva, what</b> would be the <i>halakha</i>? If there is no obligation to repay a loan other than to perform a mitzva, then what happens if someone is not interested in performing the mitzva? <b>He said to him: We</b> already <b>learned</b> this <i>halakha</i> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said,</b> that one is liable to receive forty lashes for committing a transgression? It is said <b>with regard to negative mitzvot. However, with regard to positive mitzvot, for example, if</b> the court <b>says to</b> someone: <b>Perform</b> the mitzva of the <b><i>sukka</i>, and he does not do</b> so, or: Perform the mitzva of the <b>palm branch, and he does not do</b> so,

Daf 86b

the court <b>strikes him</b> an unlimited number of times, even <b>until his soul departs,</b> in order to force him to perform the mitzva. The payment of a debt is a positive mitzva, and one who refuses to pay a debt can be compelled to do so in this manner.
§ <b>Rami bar Ḥama inquired of Rav Ḥisda:</b> If a man said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce but you are divorced with it only after thirty days,</b> and she took the bill of divorce <b>and went and placed it in the sides of the public domain,</b> i.e., in a place that was open to the public domain but not an actual part of it, and the bill of divorce was still there after thirty days, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is she divorced?
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: She is not divorced.</b> This <i>halakha</i> is learned <b>from</b> the opinion <b>of Rav and Shmuel, as</b> it is <b>Rav and Shmuel who both say</b> with regard to the mishna: Any of the creditors of a deceased person can seize items of his movable property <b>provided that they are arranged in piles and placed in the public domain,</b> as in that case the heirs of the deceased do not receive it as part of their inheritance. Similarly, the woman will not acquire the bill of divorce after thirty days if it is in that location. Rav Ḥisda adds: <b>And the sides of the public domain are considered like the public domain.</b>
Rami bar Ḥama responded: <b>On the contrary, she is divorced,</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rav Naḥman, as Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> With regard to <b>one who says to his friend: Go</b> and <b>pull this cow</b> now <b>and it will be acquired by you only after thirty days, he has acquired</b> the cow. <b>And</b> this is true <b>even</b> if the cow <b>was standing</b> after those thirty days <b>in</b> an ownerless <b>meadow [<i>agam</i>].</b> Since the acquisition began properly at the start of the thirty-day period, it applies even after the thirty-day period. <b>What, is it not</b> the case that <b>this is</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a meadow and this is</b> also the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the sides of the public domain,</b> as the two places have a similar status? Rav Ḥisda rejects this argument: <b>No,</b> the case of <b>a meadow is discrete, and</b> the case of <b>the sides of the public domain is discrete,</b> as the latter is considered an actual part of the public domain, and an ownerless meadow is not.
<b>Some say</b> a different version of the dispute between Rami bar Ḥama and Rav Ḥisda, in which Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Rami bar Ḥama: <b>She is divorced,</b> based on the ruling of <b>Rav Naḥman</b> pertaining to acquiring a cow, <b>and the sides of the public domain are considered like a meadow.</b> In this version, it was Rami bar Ḥama who replied: <b>On the contrary, she is not divorced,</b> as can be learned <b>from</b> the opinion of <b>Rav and Shmuel</b> pertaining to seizing objects in the public domain. <b>What, is it not</b> the case that <b>this is</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the public domain and this is</b> similarly the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the sides of the public domain?</b> Rav Ḥisda responded: <b>No, the public domain is discrete and the sides of the public domain are discrete.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If there is <b>one who establishes his wife</b> as a <b>storekeeper</b> in his store, <b>or</b> if <b>he appointed her</b> as a <b>steward</b> to handle his property and workers, <b>this</b> one, i.e., the husband, can <b>administer an oath to her,</b> having her state that she did not appropriate any of his possessions, <b>whenever he wants. Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> He can administer an oath <b>even with regard to</b> the products of <b>her spindle and for her dough,</b> which are matters related to the household, and not her function as a storekeeper.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: When <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> says that a husband can administer an oath to her with regard to any item, is <b>he saying</b> that this is <b>by means of extension</b> of an oath, i.e., once he administers an oath to her in her capacity as his storekeeper he can extend the oath to cover other matters, <b>or,</b> is <b>he saying</b> that he can administer an oath to her <b><i>ab initio</i>?</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution from a <i>baraita</i>: The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Eliezer: A person does not reside in a basket with a snake.</b> A woman is not expected to live with a husband who constantly suspects her of stealing. The Gemara explains: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that Rabbi Eliezer is referring to an oath administered <b><i>ab initio</i>,</b> the Rabbis spoke <b>well. However, if you say</b> that the husband can administer an oath only <b>by means of an extension</b> of an oath, <b>what difference does it make to her?</b> As she must take an oath with regard to matters that concern the store, it does not cause any greater difficulty for her to take an oath with regard to the household matters.
The Gemara refutes this argument, as it is possible <b>that she says to him: Since you are so exacting with me, I cannot live with you.</b> Even if there is no additional oath, the sentiment engendered by his demand is grounds for dissatisfaction, and there is no proof that Rabbi Eliezer holds that he can administer an oath to her <i>ab initio</i>.
The Gemara suggests another proof. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who did not exempt his wife</b> in the marriage contract <b>from a vow and from an oath, and he established her</b> as his <b>storekeeper or appointed her</b> as his <b>steward, he</b> can <b>administer an oath to her whenever he wants.</b> If he <b>did not establish her</b> as his <b>storekeeper or appoint her</b> as his <b>steward,</b> he <b>cannot administer an oath to her.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Although he did not establish her</b> as his <b>storekeeper or appoint her</b> as his <b>steward, he</b> can <b>administer an oath to her whenever he wants, as you have no wife who did not become a steward</b> for <b>one hour in her husband’s lifetime</b> at least <b>for her spindle and for her dough.</b> The Rabbis <b>said to him: A person does not reside in a basket with a snake.</b> One can <b>conclude from this</b> that according to Rabbi Eliezer a husband can administer an oath to his wife with regard to her conduct, even <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Conclude from it</b> that it is so.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one wrote to</b> his wife in the marriage contract: <b>I do not have</b> the right to administer <b>a vow or an oath upon you,</b> he <b>cannot administer an oath to her. However, he can administer an oath to her heirs, and to those who come on her authority,</b> either as her representatives or because they purchased her marriage contract.
If the husband wrote: <b>I do not have</b> the right to administer <b>a vow or an oath upon you, or upon your heirs, or upon those who come on your authority,</b> he <b>cannot administer an oath</b> to <b>her; not to her, nor her heirs, nor those who come on her authority. But</b> the husband’s <b>heirs can administer an oath to her, and to her heirs, and to those who come on her authority.</b>
If he wrote: <b>Neither I, nor my heirs, nor those who come on my authority have</b> the right to administer <b>a vow or an oath upon you, or upon your heirs, or upon those who come on your authority,</b> he <b>cannot administer an oath</b> to <b>her</b> or to them; <b>not he, nor his heirs, nor those who come on his authority</b> may administer an oath, <b>not to her, nor</b> to <b>her heirs, nor</b> to <b>those who come on her authority.</b>
If a woman who was exempted from an oath by her husband <b>went from her husband’s grave,</b> immediately after her husband’s death, <b>to her father’s house,</b> without handling her late husband’s property, <b>or</b> in a case <b>where she returned to her father-in-law’s house and did not become a steward</b> over the property at all throughout this period, then <b>the heirs cannot administer an oath to her</b> with regard to her actions in their father’s lifetime, as the husband exempted her from an oath to the heirs. <b>And if she became a steward, the heirs may administer an oath to her about the future,</b> i.e., anything she did with the property after the death of her husband, <b>but they cannot administer an oath to her with regard to what</b> took place <b>in the past,</b> during her husband’s lifetime.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the purpose of an oath?</b> What oath can he administer to her that caused him to add this condition to her marriage contract? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b>

Daf 87a

It is referring <b>to</b> a woman <b>who became a steward during her husband’s lifetime,</b> as it was common for a man to leave his wife in charge of his property while exempting her from taking an oath. <b>Rav Naḥman</b> said that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> It is referring <b>to a woman who claims that she received partial payment of her marriage contract,</b> who must take an oath that she received no more than the amount she admits to. The mishna is referring to a husband who exempted his wife from this oath.
<b>Rav Mordekhai went</b> and <b>said</b> this <b><i>halakha</i> before Rav Ashi</b> and asked him the following question: <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that <b>it is referring to a woman who claims that she received partial payment of her marriage contract,</b> it makes sense <b>that it enters her mind</b> that this might happen, as she thinks: <b>Perhaps I will require money, and I will take</b> what I need <b>from my marriage contract</b> up front. <b>And she</b> therefore <b>says to him</b> before their marriage: <b>Write for me that you will not administer an oath to me</b> when I come to collect the rest of my marriage contract. <b>However, according to the one who says</b> that it <b>is referring to</b> a woman <b>who became a steward during her husband’s lifetime, did she know</b> beforehand <b>that</b> her husband <b>would establish her as a steward,</b> to know <b>to say to him: Write for me that you will not administer an oath to me?</b>
Rav Ashi <b>said to him: You teach this</b> <i>halakha</i> of Rav Yehuda <b>with regard to that</b> part of the mishna, and therefore you find it difficult. <b>We,</b> however, <b>teach it with regard to this</b> part of the mishna: If <b>she went from her husband’s grave to her father’s house</b> without handling her late husband’s property, <b>or</b> in a case <b>where she returned to her father-in-law’s house and did not become a steward</b> over the property at all throughout this period, then <b>the heirs cannot administer an oath to her</b> with regard to her actions in their father’s lifetime, as the husband exempted her from an oath to the heirs. <b>And if she became a steward, the heirs may administer an oath to her about the future,</b> i.e., anything she did with the property after the death of her husband, <b>but they cannot administer an oath to her with regard to what</b> took place <b>in the past,</b> during her husband’s lifetime.
It was with regard to this statement that the Gemara asked: <b>What is the purpose of</b> mentioning <b>the past?</b> What oath would they have wanted her to take with regard to the past? And it was in response to this question that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> It is referring <b>to</b> a woman <b>who became a steward during her husband’s lifetime.</b>
The Gemara presents a dispute as to what is considered the past, first continuing the quote from Rav Yehuda: <b>But they can administer an oath to her</b> with regard to her conduct <b>between</b> her husband’s <b>death and</b> his <b>burial. And Rav Mattana said: Even</b> concerning her actions <b>between</b> her husband’s <b>death and</b> his <b>burial, they cannot administer an oath to her, as</b> the Sages of <b>Neharde’a say: For</b> the purpose of paying <b>head tax [<i>karga</i>], and for</b> payment to provide for children’s <b>sustenance, and for burial, we sell</b> property inherited by orphans <b>without an announcement.</b> In these urgent matters, the court is not particular about a possible loss incurred by the heirs. Similarly, a woman need not take an oath with regard to how she conducted her affairs for her husband’s funeral, because in such a time of stress she cannot manage her accounts in a precise manner.
§ <b>Rabba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said:</b> If a husband wrote: <b>Not a vow and not an oath,</b> this means that <b>he cannot administer an oath to her, but</b> his <b>heirs can administer an oath to her.</b> If he wrote: She is <b>clear,</b> i.e., exempt, from <b>a vow</b> and <b>clear</b> from <b>an oath, neither he nor</b> his <b>heirs can administer an oath to her.</b> This is because in effect <b>this is what he is saying to her: You are clear</b> from <b>the oath,</b> no matter who seeks to administer it to you.
<b>But Rav Yosef</b> said that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said</b> the opposite ruling with regard to the second clause: If he wrote: <b>Not a vow and not an oath, he cannot administer an oath to her, but</b> his <b>heirs can administer an oath to her.</b> If he wrote: She is <b>clear</b> from <b>a vow</b> and <b>clear</b> from <b>an oath, either he or</b> his <b>heirs can administer an oath to her.</b> This is because in effect <b>this is what he is saying to her: Clear yourself</b> from any suspicion <b>by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zakkai sent</b> the following ruling <b>to Mar Ukva</b> from Eretz Yisrael: <b>Whether</b> he wrote: <b>Not an oath,</b> or <b>whether</b> he wrote: <b>Clear</b> from <b>an oath,</b> and <b>whether</b> he wrote: <b>Not a vow,</b> or <b>whether</b> he wrote: <b>Clear</b> from <b>a vow,</b> if he added the phrase: <b>With regard to my property, he cannot administer an oath to her, but</b> his <b>heirs can administer an oath to her.</b> However, if he added the phrase: <b>From these properties, neither he nor his heirs can administer an oath to her.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said in the name of Abba Shaul ben Imma Miriam: Whether</b> he wrote: <b>Not an oath,</b> or <b>whether</b> he wrote: <b>Clear</b> from <b>an oath,</b> and <b>whether</b> he wrote: <b>Not a vow,</b> or <b>whether</b> he wrote: <b>Clear</b> from <b>a vow,</b> and <b>whether</b> he added: <b>From my property,</b> or <b>whether</b> he added: <b>From these properties, neither he nor his heirs can administer an oath to her</b> according to the letter of the law. <b>However, what can I do, as the Sages said</b> that <b>one who comes to collect</b> a debt <b>from the property of orphans may collect</b> it <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath?</b> Therefore, she is compelled to take an oath in any case involving a claim from the orphans.
<b>And some say</b> this <i>halakha</i> in the form of <b>a <i>baraita</i>,</b> not as a quote from an <i>amora</i>: <b>Abba Shaul ben Imma Miriam said: Whether</b> he wrote: <b>Not an oath,</b> or <b>whether</b> he wrote: <b>Clear</b> from <b>an oath,</b> and <b>whether</b> he wrote: <b>Not a vow,</b> or <b>whether</b> he wrote: <b>Clear</b> from <b>a vow,</b> and <b>whether</b> he added: <b>From my property,</b> or <b>whether</b> he added: <b>From these properties, neither he nor his heirs can administer an oath to her</b> according to the letter of the law. <b>However, what can I do, as the Sages said</b> that <b>one who comes to collect</b> a debt <b>from the property of orphans may collect</b> it <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath?</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The practical <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>ben Imma Miriam.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A woman <b>who vitiates her marriage contract</b> by acknowledging that she has received partial payment <b>can collect</b> the rest of her marriage contract <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b> Similarly, if <b>one witness testifies that</b> her marriage contract <b>is paid, she can collect</b> it <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b> In any case where she seeks to claim her marriage contract <b>from the property of orphans, or from liened property</b> that has been sold to a third party, <b>or when not in</b> her husband’s <b>presence,</b> she <b>can collect</b> it <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b>
The mishna elaborates: With regard to a woman <b>who vitiates her marriage contract, how so,</b> how does this situation arise? If <b>her marriage contract was a thousand dinars, and</b> her husband <b>said to her: You</b> already <b>received your marriage contract, and she says: I received only one hundred dinars,</b> she has made a partial admission and <b>can collect</b> her marriage contract <b>only</b> by means of <b>an oath.</b>
If <b>one witness testifies that</b> her marriage contract <b>is paid, how so?</b> If <b>her marriage contract was a thousand dinars, and</b> her husband <b>said to her: You</b> already <b>received your marriage contract, and she says: I did not receive</b> payment, <b>and one witness testifies about</b> the marriage contract <b>that it is paid,</b> she <b>can collect</b> it <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b>
<b>From liened property, how so?</b> If while they were married the husband <b>sold his property to others, and she</b> comes to <b>collect</b> her marriage contract <b>from the purchasers, she can collect</b> it <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b> She may seize property from the purchasers because her husband’s obligation undertaken in the marriage contract predates his obligation in the document of sale.
<b>From the property of orphans, how so?</b> If the husband <b>died and left his property to orphans, and she</b> comes to <b>collect</b> her marriage contract <b>from the orphans,</b> she <b>can collect</b> it <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b>
<b>Or when not in his presence, how so?</b> If <b>he went</b> to <b>a country overseas and</b> sent her a bill of divorce, so that <b>she collects</b> her marriage contract <b>when not in his presence,</b> she <b>can collect</b> it <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b>

Daf 87b

<b>Rabbi Shimon says: Whenever she claims</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract, the heirs administer an oath to her. And if she does not claim</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract, the heirs do not administer an oath to her.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rami bar Ḥama thought to say</b> that the oath of a woman who vitiates her marriage contract is <b>an oath</b> required <b>by Torah</b> law, which is the oath of one who makes a partial admission, <b>as</b> the husband <b>claims</b> that he paid her <b>two hundred and she concedes to him with regard to one hundred. This is a partial admission of the claim, and</b> the principle is that <b>whoever admits to part of a claim must take an oath</b> according to Torah law to receive the remaining amount.
<b>Rava said:</b> There are <b>two answers in the matter,</b> in refutation of your argument: <b>One</b> response is <b>that anyone who</b> is obligated to <b>take an oath</b> that is enumerated <b>in the Torah takes an oath and does not pay.</b> By Torah law, one takes an oath only to exempt himself from payment, <b>and</b> in this case <b>she takes an oath and takes</b> her money. <b>And furthermore,</b> there is a principle that <b>one does not take an oath with regard to a denial of a lien on land.</b> The oaths of the Torah apply only to moveable property, not land. This means that if a claim involves a lien on land of any form, the oath of a partial admission does not apply, and a marriage contract includes a lien on land.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> This oath is <b>by rabbinic</b> law. It was instituted because the one <b>who pays is precise</b> and recalls that he paid his debt, whereas the one <b>who was paid is not precise.</b> When the husband claims to have paid her, he remembers clearly what happened, <b>and</b> therefore <b>the Sages imposed</b> the obligation of <b>an oath upon her, so that she should be precise</b> and remember exactly what occurred.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: In a case where <b>a woman vitiates her marriage contract</b> by accepting partial payment <b>in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Do we say that <b>if it is</b> so <b>that he has paid her</b> the rest of the marriage contract, <b>he would have paid her in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses,</b> and since he has no such witnesses, this is proof that she never received the rest of the money, and she is exempt from an oath? <b>Or perhaps he</b> simply <b>happened to have</b> witnesses for part of the payment, and he gave her the rest without witnesses, and she must take an oath with regard to the remainder of the sum?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from a mishna (<i>Shevuot</i> 44b): <b>Anyone who</b> is obligated to <b>take an oath</b> that is enumerated <b>in the Torah takes an oath and does not pay. And these take an oath and take</b> their payment: <b>The hired worker</b> who demands his wages from his employer; <b>and one who was robbed; and one who was injured,</b> who claims compensation from the one who caused him damage; <b>and</b> if <b>the one opposing him,</b> the other litigant in a case, was supposed to take an oath but he is <b>suspected with regard to oaths; and a storekeeper</b> who makes a claim <b>on</b> the basis of what is written in <b>his notebook [<i>pinkaso</i>]; and one who receives partial payment of his document not in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses.</b> Conclude from this last clause that if one received partial payment of a document <b>not in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses,</b> then <b>yes,</b> he is obligated to take an oath, but if he received the payment <b>in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses,</b> then <b>no,</b> he is not obligated to take an oath.
The Gemara refutes this argument: The mishna <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary: It is not necessary</b> to state that if part of the marriage contract was paid <b>in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses, she certainly requires an oath. However,</b> if a partial payment was made <b>not in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses,</b> one might <b>say</b> that her partial admission <b>should be like one who restores lost property.</b> Since there are no witnesses that the husband paid anything, when she concedes to part of the claim it is as though she has restored to him a lost item. <b>And she should</b> therefore <b>take</b> the rest of the money <b>without an oath,</b> in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> that one who returns lost property does not have to take an oath that he did not appropriate part of what he found for himself. The <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that even in this case an oath is required.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>a woman who vitiates her marriage contract</b> and details with precision every sum of money that she received, specifying not only large sums of money but also sums so small that they amounted to <b>less than the value of a <i>peruta</i>, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that <b>since she is precise to such an extent she</b> must be <b>telling the truth, or perhaps</b> she <b>is deceiving</b> us? This question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
Another <b>dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: In the case of a woman who <b>reduces her marriage contract</b> by saying that its sum was less than the usual amount, or less than the figure specified in the document, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that <b>this is</b> like the case of <b>a woman who vitiates</b> her marriage contract, and the <i>halakha</i> is the same in both instances? <b>Or perhaps</b> there is a difference between the two cases because <b>a woman who vitiates</b> her marriage contract <b>admits to part of</b> the claim, whereas <b>this one does not admit to</b> part of the claim. Here, she claims that she has received nothing at all, but that she is owed less than what was initially thought.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who reduces</b> her marriage contract <b>can collect</b> it <b>without an oath. How so?</b> If <b>her marriage contract was a thousand dinars, and</b> her husband <b>said to her: You have received your marriage contract, and she says: I have not received</b> my marriage contract, <b>but it is only one hundred dinars,</b> she <b>may collect</b> it <b>without an oath.</b>
The Gemara asks: If her claim is accepted, <b>with what does she</b> in fact <b>collect</b> payment? <b>With this</b> marriage contract <b>document? This document is merely</b> a shard of <b>earthenware,</b> as she herself admits that the document is not a valid document because it records a fictitious sum. <b>Rava, son of Rabba, said:</b> It is referring <b>to one who says: There was</b> an agreement of <b>trust between him and me</b> that although the marriage contract records a large sum, I will claim only part of it, but the document itself is genuine.
§ The mishna teaches that if <b>one witness testifies that</b> the marriage contract <b>was paid</b> she must take an oath. <b>Rami bar Ḥama thought to say</b> that this is <b>an oath</b> required <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>as it is written: “One witness shall not rise up against a man for any iniquity, or for any sin”</b> (Deuteronomy 19:15). From here it is inferred: <b>It is for any iniquity or for any sin that he may not rise up,</b> i.e., the testimony of one witness is not enough for these purposes, <b>but he may rise up for an oath. And the Master said:</b> In <b>any place,</b> i.e., situation, <b>where two</b> witnesses are able to <b>deem one liable</b> to pay <b>money,</b> the testimony of <b>one</b> witness <b>obligates him to take an oath.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> There are <b>two answers in the matter,</b> in refutation of your argument: <b>One</b> response is <b>that anyone who</b> is obligated to <b>take an oath</b> that is enumerated <b>in the Torah takes an oath and does not pay.</b> By Torah law, one takes an oath only to exempt himself from payment, <b>and</b> in this case <b>she takes an oath and takes</b> her money. <b>And furthermore,</b> there is a principle that <b>one does not take an oath with regard to a denial of a lien on land.</b>
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> That oath was instituted <b>by rabbinic</b> law, <b>in order to put the husband’s mind at ease.</b> Since a witness contradicts her claim, the Sages imposed an oath upon her so that the husband would be sure that he is not giving away his money for no reason.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b>

Daf 88a

<b>If</b> the husband <b>is perspicacious,</b> he can <b>induce her to</b> become obligated to take <b>an oath by Torah</b> law even in a case where only one witness saw the payment of the marriage contract, as follows: <b>He</b> now <b>gives her</b> the payment of <b>her entire marriage contract in the presence of one witness, and joins the first witness to the last witness,</b> so that there are now two witnesses to the payment of the entire marriage contract. <b>And</b> then, <b>he establishes this first</b> payment, about which the first witness had testified, <b>as a loan,</b> and claims payment of that sum from her, supported by the testimony of the first witness. With regard to this claim, her oath would serve the purpose of exempting her from payment, and it is not connected with a lien on land. Therefore, the witness can obligate her in an oath by Torah law.
<b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, objects to this: How can he join the first witness to the last witness</b> when their testimonies do not refer to the same action? <b>Rather, Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said: He</b> now <b>gives her</b> the payment of <b>her entire marriage contract in the presence of</b> both <b>the first witness and the last witness. And</b> then, <b>he establishes this first</b> payment, about which the first witness had testified, <b>as a loan,</b> and claims payment of that sum from her, supported by the testimony of the first witness.
