<b>Rav Ashi objects to this:</b> The woman <b>can still say: I had two marriage contracts.</b> She can claim that he wrote two marriage contracts and she collected the payments at two separate points in time, but there was never a loan. <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: It</b> is possible for him to obligate her to take an oath if <b>he informs</b> the two witnesseses that on this occasion he is paying her for the one marriage contract that he wrote. She is then unable to claim that it was a different marriage contract, and he can compel her to take an oath by Torah law about the first payment, which is now established as a loan.
§ The mishna teaches that if a woman comes to claim her marriage contract <b>from liened property</b> that had been sold to a third party, she must first take an oath. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Shevuot</i> 45a): <b>And similarly, orphans can collect</b> payment <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From whom</b> can the orphans collect payment only by means of an oath? <b>If we say</b> that they can collect payment only with an oath <b>from one who borrowed</b> money from their father, then it is difficult to understand how this can be so. <b>Now,</b> can it be that <b>their father,</b> the lender, had the right to <b>take</b> payment from the borrower <b>without an oath</b> by relying on the document, <b>and they,</b> the orphans, with regard to whom the Sages were lenient, can claim the loan only <b>by</b> means of <b>an oath? Rather, this is what</b> the mishna is <b>saying: And similarly, the orphans</b> of the lender who come to collect payment from <b>the orphans</b> of the borrower <b>can collect only by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b>
<b>Rav Zerika said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said: It was taught</b> that those who take an oath can collect a debt from orphans <b>only if</b> the borrower’s <b>orphans said:</b> Our <b>father said to us: I borrowed and repaid. However,</b> if the orphans <b>said:</b> Our <b>father said to us: I did not borrow,</b> then <b>they may not collect</b> from the orphans <b>even</b> with <b>an oath.</b>
<b>Rava objects to this: On the contrary,</b> there is a principle in the <i>halakhot</i> of claims that <b>anyone who says: I did not borrow is considered like one who says: I did not repay.</b> Therefore, when there is evidence that he did borrow, he must pay the entire amount without the lender having to take an oath.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara emends the above statement: <b>If it was stated, it was stated like this: Rav Zerika said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only if the orphans said:</b> Our <b>father said to us: I borrowed and repaid. However,</b> if <b>they said:</b> Our <b>father said to us: I did not borrow,</b> those who collect debts from them <b>can collect</b> even <b>without an oath, for anyone who says: I did not borrow is considered like one who says: I did not repay.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>one who</b> comes to <b>collect</b> her marriage contract <b>when not in</b> her husband’s <b>presence can collect</b> it <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath. Rav Aḥa Sar HaBira said: An incident came before Rabbi Yitzḥak in Antioch, and he said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only with regard to the wife’s marriage contract;</b> she may collect her marriage contract in her husband’s absence, <b>because</b> the Sages wanted men to find <b>favor</b> in the eyes of women. In order to ensure that women would want to marry, the Sages instituted decrees with regard to a marriage contract that are for the woman’s benefit. <b>However, a creditor</b> does <b>not</b> have the right to collect his debt even with an oath if the borrower is absent, in case he has already been paid.
<b>And Rava</b> said that <b>Rav Naḥman said: Even a creditor</b> can collect payment with an oath in the borrower’s absence, <b>so that each and every person will not take his friend’s money</b> by means of a loan <b>and go and reside in a country overseas</b> to prevent the lender from collecting the money from his property. <b>And</b> if that were to occur, <b>you would be locking the door in the face of borrowers,</b> as no one would be willing to lend them money.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Whenever she claims her marriage contract,</b> the heirs administer an oath to her. The Gemara asks: <b>To which</b> statement in the mishna is <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> referring? <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> He is referring <b>to this</b> statement: <b>And one who</b> comes to <b>collect</b> her marriage contract <b>when not in</b> her husband’s <b>presence can collect</b> it <b>only by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b> This implies that the <i>halakha</i> <b>is no different</b> if she comes to claim money from the orphans <b>for sustenance, and</b> it <b>is no different</b> if she demands payment <b>for</b> her <b>marriage contract. And Rabbi Shimon comes to say</b> that <b>whenever she claims her marriage contract</b> the <b>heirs</b> can <b>administer an oath to her</b> that she has not taken anything of theirs.

Daf 88b

If <b>she does not claim her marriage contract,</b> the <b>heirs do not administer an oath to her. And they disagree with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute of Ḥanan and the sons of the High Priests, as we learned</b> in a mishna (104b): With regard to <b>one who went to a country overseas and his wife claims</b> money for <b>sustenance, Ḥanan says: She takes an oath at the conclusion,</b> when she comes to claim her marriage contract, that her husband did not leave her with any money and that she took from his estate only what she needed for her sustenance. <b>And she does not take an oath at the beginning,</b> when she takes the allowance for her sustenance from his estate.
The mishna continues: <b>The sons of the High Priests disagreed with him, and said: She takes an oath</b> that her husband did not leave her any money <b>at the beginning,</b> when she comes to take money for sustenance, <b>and at the conclusion,</b> when she comes to claim her marriage contract. Rabbi Yirmeya suggests: <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> holds <b>like Ḥanan,</b> that she takes an oath only when she comes to collect her marriage contract. And <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree, hold <b>like the sons of the High Priests,</b> that she must also take an oath when she collects money for her sustenance.
<b>Rav Sheshet objects to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya’s statement: If the dispute is with regard to a woman who comes to collect money for her sustenance while her husband is away, why would the mishna employ <b>this</b> phrase: The <b>heirs administer an oath to her? It should</b> have said that <b>the court administers an oath to her,</b> as this oath would be administered by the court.
<b>Rather, Rav Sheshet said</b> that Rabbi Shimon’s statement is referring <b>to this</b> earlier mishna (86b): If a woman who was exempted from an oath by her husband <b>went from her husband’s grave,</b> immediately after her husband’s death, <b>to her father’s house,</b> without handling her late husband’s property, <b>or</b> in a case <b>where she returned to her father-in-law’s house and did not become a steward,</b> then <b>the heirs cannot administer an oath to her</b> with regard to her actions in their father’s lifetime. <b>And if she became a steward, the heirs may administer an oath to her about the future,</b> i.e., anything she did with the property after the death of her husband, <b>but they cannot administer an oath to her with regard to what</b> took place <b>in the past,</b> during her husband’s lifetime. <b>And Rabbi Shimon came to say</b> that <b>whenever she claims her marriage contract</b> the <b>heirs</b> can <b>administer an oath to her,</b> but if <b>she does not claim her marriage contract,</b> the <b>heirs do not administer an oath to her.</b>
Rav Sheshet explains: <b>And they disagree with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute of Abba Shaul and the Rabbis, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 52a): <b>A steward who was appointed</b> by <b>the father of orphans</b> to take care of their property <b>must take an oath</b> when the orphans come of age and he returns their property. He takes an oath that he did not appropriate anything for himself. If <b>the court appointed him</b> steward, he need <b>not take an oath.</b> The Sages exempted him from an oath so that people would not refrain from serving as stewards. <b>Abba Shaul says: The matters are reversed.</b> If the <b>court appointed him, he must take an oath;</b> if <b>the father of orphans appointed him,</b> he need <b>not take an oath.</b> It is an honor to be appointed steward by the court, and to receive this honor he would not mind being obligated to take an oath. If he was appointed by the father, it is clear that the father trusted him and relied on him.
Rav Sheshet completes his explanation: <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul,</b> as the woman is comparable to a steward appointed by the father of the orphans. Therefore, she cannot be compelled to take an oath about the future, unless she comes to claim her marriage contract. <b>And the Rabbis</b> here hold <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> there, that a steward appointed by the father is obligated to take an oath.
<b>Abaye objects to</b> Rav Sheshet’s statement: <b>This</b> phrase, that the heirs can administer an oath to her <b>whenever she claims her marriage contract,</b> is appropriate only if Rabbi Shimon is more stringent than the Rabbis, who exempt her from an oath in all cases. However, since according to Rav Sheshet his opinion is the more lenient one, <b>he should</b> have said: <b>If she claims,</b> meaning that she is required to take an oath only when she claims her marriage contract.
<b>Rather, Abaye said</b> that Rabbi Shimon’s statement is referring <b>to this</b> clause of the mishna (86b): If the husband <b>wrote for her: I do not have</b> the right to administer <b>a vow or an oath upon you,</b> he <b>cannot administer an oath to her.</b> If he wrote: <b>Neither I, nor my heirs, nor those who come on my authority have</b> the right to administer <b>a vow or an oath upon you, or upon your heirs, or upon those who come on your authority,</b> he <b>cannot administer an oath</b> to <b>her</b> or them; <b>not he, nor his heirs, nor those who come on his authority</b> may administer an oath, <b>not to her, nor her heirs, nor those who come on her authority. And Rabbi Shimon came to say</b> that <b>whenever she claims her marriage contract</b> the <b>heirs</b> can <b>administer an oath to her.</b>
Abaye explains: <b>And they disagree with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute of Abba Shaul ben Imma Miriam and the Rabbis. Rabbi Shimon</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul,</b> that even if the husband exempted her from an oath she must still take an oath before she can collect from the property of orphans. <b>And the Rabbis</b> here hold <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> there, that if he exempted her from all oaths she can collect payment without an oath.
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this: This</b> works out <b>well</b> in explaining Rabbi Shimon’s disagreement with the Rabbis, where he said that she must take an oath <b>whenever she demands</b> payment for <b>her marriage contract.</b> However, <b>what can be said</b> about the second part of Rabbi Shimon’s statement, where he speaks of one who <b>does not demand</b> payment for <b>her marriage contract?</b> According to Abaye’s explanation, that clause does not add or teach anything.
<b>Rather, Rav Pappa said</b> that Rabbi Shimon is not referring to that mishna. His opinion is <b>to the exclusion of Rabbi Eliezer and those who dispute him</b> (86b), all of whom agree that the woman can be compelled to take an oath that she did not appropriate anything from her husband’s property. The Rabbis hold that she can be compelled to take an oath only if she was appointed steward, whereas Rabbi Eliezer holds that she can always be compelled to take an oath. Rabbi Shimon, who disagrees with both opinions, contends that the heirs can administer an oath to her only when she comes to collect her marriage contract, at which point they can administer an oath about other matters, including the work done with her spindle. However, if she does not claim her marriage contract, they cannot administer an oath to her even with regard to her work as steward or storekeeper.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case where a woman <b>produced a bill of divorce and it</b> was <b>unaccompanied by a marriage contract,</b> and she demands that her husband pay her marriage contract,

Daf 89a

<b>she collects</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract,</b> and he cannot claim that he already paid it.
If she produced <b>a marriage contract, and it</b> was <b>unaccompanied by a bill of divorce,</b> and <b>she says: My bill of divorce was lost, and he says:</b> Just as your bill of divorce was lost, so too <b>my receipt</b> for the payment of your marriage contract <b>was lost; and likewise,</b> in a case of <b>a creditor who produced a promissory note</b> after the Sabbatical Year, <b>unaccompanied by a document that prevents the Sabbatical Year from forgiving an outstanding debt [<i>prosbol</i>],</b> and demanded payment of the debt, <b>these</b> debts <b>may not be collected.</b>
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: From the</b> time of <b>danger and onward,</b> after the ruling authorities banned the performance of mitzvot, people would destroy a bill of divorce or a <i>prosbol</i> immediately after they were signed, <b>a woman collects</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract without a bill of divorce, and a creditor collects</b> debts owed to him <b>without a <i>prosbol</i>.</b> The assumption is that due to the circumstances these documents were written but were not preserved.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Conclude from</b> the mishna that when one repays a debt, the creditor <b>writes a receipt</b> and gives it to the debtor as proof of payment, <b>as, if one does not write a receipt,</b> then in the case in the mishna where she receives payment of her marriage contract by producing her bill of divorce, <b>let us be concerned lest she produce her marriage contract</b> in a different court <b>and collect</b> payment <b>with it</b> a second time. In the absence of a receipt, the husband cannot prove that the debt was paid.
<b>Rav said:</b> That is no proof, as <b>we are dealing with a place where one does not write a marriage contract.</b> In those places, there is a general stipulation of the Sages that a husband must pay his wife the sum of the marriage contract even if no document was written. Therefore, there is no concern lest she produce the marriage contract at a later stage. <b>And Shmuel said</b> that the mishna is referring <b>even</b> to <b>a place where one writes a marriage contract,</b> which she claims to have lost.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Shmuel, does one</b> in fact <b>write a receipt? Rav Anan said: It was explained to me</b> personally <b>by the Sage Shmuel himself:</b> The mishna is addressing two different cases. In <b>a place where one does not write</b> a marriage contract <b>and</b> the husband <b>said: I wrote</b> a marriage contract, it is incumbent <b>upon him to bring proof</b> that he wrote one. In that case, she cannot collect payment without producing the document. In <b>a place where one writes</b> a marriage contract <b>and she said: He did not write</b> one <b>for me, she must bring proof</b> that he did not write a marriage contract. Only then can she collect payment without one.
<b>And even Rav retracted his</b> interpretation of the mishna, <b>as Rav said</b> the following ruling: <b>Both in a place where one writes</b> a marriage contract <b>and in a place where one does not write</b> a marriage contract, if she produces only <b>a bill of divorce, she collects the main</b> sum of the marriage contract. The Sages established minimum sums to serve as the principal payment of the marriage contract: Two hundred dinars for a virgin and one hundred for a non-virgin. If she produces <b>a marriage contract</b> that specifies a larger sum, <b>she collects</b> only <b>the additional</b> sum and not the main sum, as there is a concern that she collected the main sum previously by producing the bill of divorce. <b>And whoever wishes to challenge</b> this solution, <b>let him come and challenge</b> it. There is no longer any possibility of deceit, as she will gain nothing by producing the marriage contract in a second court after having collected her marriage contract by producing her bill of divorce in a first court.
The Gemara objects: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If she produced <b>a marriage contract, and it</b> was <b>unaccompanied by a bill of divorce,</b> and <b>she says: My bill of divorce was lost, and he says:</b> Just as your bill of divorce was lost, so too <b>my receipt</b> for the payment of your marriage contract <b>was lost; and likewise,</b> in a case of <b>a creditor who produced a promissory note</b> after the Sabbatical Year, <b>unaccompanied by a <i>prosbol</i>,</b> and demanded payment of the debt, <b>these</b> debts <b>may not be collected.</b>
The Gemara presents the question: <b>Granted, according to Shmuel,</b> this is reasonable. He <b>establishes</b> the mishna as referring to <b>a place where</b> the common practice is <b>that one does not write</b> a marriage contract, <b>and</b> the husband previously <b>had said: I wrote</b> one, and therefore did not want to pay the marriage contract when she produced the bill of divorce, as he was concerned that she would later produce the marriage contract and demand payment again. <b>As</b> in that case <b>we say to him,</b> according to Shmuel: <b>Bring proof</b> that you wrote a marriage contract, <b>and if he does not bring proof, we say to him: Go</b> and <b>pay</b> her based on the bill of divorce. Now, when she produces her marriage contract and the husband claims that he paid her by means of the bill of divorce and has lost the receipt, the mishna rules that this debt cannot be collected.
The Gemara completes the question: <b>However, according to Rav,</b> why does the mishna state that the debt cannot be collected? <b>Although she cannot</b> now <b>collect the main</b> sum of her marriage contract, because he can claim that she already received this sum in a different court by means of her bill of divorce, <b>she should</b> be able to <b>collect the additional</b> sum by virtue of the marriage contract, as she could not have received that by producing the bill of divorce alone.
<b>Rav Yosef said: With what are we dealing here?</b> It is a case <b>where there are no witnesses to the divorce</b> present <b>there. Since</b> the husband <b>can say: I did not divorce her</b> and she is entitled to nothing,

Daf 89b

he <b>can</b> also <b>say: I divorced her and gave her</b> the payment of <b>her marriage contract.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the last clause</b> of the mishna <b>teaches</b> that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: From the</b> time of <b>danger and onward, a woman collects</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract without a bill of divorce, and a creditor</b> collects payment <b>without a <i>prosbol</i>,</b> apparently <b>we are dealing with</b> a case <b>when there are witnesses to the divorce. As, if there are no witnesses to the divorce, with what</b> proof <b>does</b> she <b>collect</b> the marriage contract? The mishna must be referring to a case where there are witnesses present, and therefore the husband cannot claim that he never divorced her.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects the previous explanation and explains: <b>The entire</b> mishna <b>is</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, and</b> the mishna <b>is incomplete and is this is what it is teaching: These</b> debts <b>may not be collected. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is <b>when there are no witnesses to the divorce</b> present <b>there. However,</b> if <b>there are witnesses to the divorce</b> present <b>there, she collects</b> the <b>additional</b> sum listed in the document and not the main sum, lest she later produce the bill of divorce and demand payment a second time. <b>And</b> as for the <b>main</b> sum of the marriage contract, <b>if she produces a bill of divorce, she collects</b> it. <b>But if she does not produce a bill of divorce, she does not collect</b> it.
The Gemara continues the modified version of the mishna: <b>And from the</b> time of <b>danger and onward, even</b> if <b>she does not produce a bill of divorce, she collects</b> the main sum of her marriage contract as well, <b>as Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: From the</b> time of <b>danger and onward a woman collects</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract without a bill of divorce, and a creditor</b> collects payment <b>without a <i>prosbol</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said to Rav: According to your</b> opinion, <b>that you said</b> that a woman who produces <b>a bill of divorce collects</b> the <b>main</b> sum, then in the case of <b>a widow from marriage, with what</b> proof <b>does she collect</b> the main sum of her marriage contract, as she has no bill of divorce? She can claim the main sum <b>with witnesses to</b> his <b>death. But shouldn’t we be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps he divorced her</b> before he passed away, <b>and</b> after receiving her marriage contract by means of the witnesses to his death, she will <b>produce the bill of divorce</b> he gave her <b>and collect</b> payment <b>with it</b> a second time? Rav answered: She can collect payment with witnesses to her husband’s death only <b>when she was living under</b> the jurisdiction of <b>her husband</b> the entire time, and it is clear that he did not divorce her.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But perhaps he divorced her near his death,</b> in which case it is not known that she was divorced. She could then demand payment for her marriage contract twice. The Gemara answers: In that case, it is <b>he who</b> caused <b>his own loss,</b> by failing to inform others of the divorce, and it is not necessary to be concerned that such a situation could occur.
Rav Kahana and Rav Asi asked Rav another question: <b>With what</b> proof can <b>a widow from betrothal collect</b> her marriage contract? She can collect the payment <b>with witnesses</b> to his <b>death. But</b> once again, <b>shouldn’t we be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps he divorced her</b> beforehand, <b>and</b> after receiving her marriage contract based on the evidence of the witnesses, she will <b>produce the bill of divorce</b> he gave her <b>and collect</b> a second time with it? Since a betrothed woman does not live with her husband, there would be no indication that he had divorced her.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>wherever it is not possible</b> otherwise to know if a woman already received her marriage contract, <b>one writes a receipt, as if you do not say so</b> with regard to the <b>witnesses to</b> his <b>death themselves, we should be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps she will bring out witnesses to</b> his <b>death in this court and collect</b> payment for her marriage contract, <b>and again bring out</b> witnesses <b>in a different court and collect</b> payment for her marriage contract a second time. This could continue many times. <b>Rather,</b> it must <b>certainly</b> be the case that <b>wherever it is not possible</b> otherwise to know if a woman already received her marriage contract, <b>one writes a receipt.</b>
<b>Mar the Elder, son of Rav Ḥisda, said to Rav Ashi: From where do we</b> know that <b>a widow from betrothal has a marriage contract?</b> Perhaps the Sages instituted the marriage contract only for married women. <b>If we say</b> that it is derived <b>from this</b> mishna (54b): If a woman <b>is widowed or divorced, whether from betrothal</b> or <b>whether from marriage, she collects the entire</b> amount of her marriage contract, including the additional sum, this mishna is not proof. <b>Perhaps</b> the mishna is referring to a case where <b>he wrote</b> a marriage contract <b>for her</b> on his own accord. That does not prove that there is an enactment of the Sages that a husband must write a marriage contract for his betrothed.
<b>And if you would say</b> in response that <b>if</b> that mishna is referring to a case where <b>he wrote</b> the marriage contract <b>for her, what</b> is the purpose of <b>stating</b> that she collects the entire sum, since it is clear that she receives the full amount, as she has the document in her possession; perhaps this is meant to <b>exclude</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, who said</b> that a betrothed woman who was divorced or widowed is not entitled to the additional sum written in the marriage contract, <b>as</b> the groom <b>wrote</b> this additional amount <b>for her only in order to marry her.</b>
The Gemara comments: The language of the mishna <b>is also precise,</b> that it is referring to a case where he wrote the marriage contract for her, <b>as it teaches: She collects the entire</b> amount. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>he wrote</b> a marriage contract <b>for her,</b> it is <b>due to that</b> reason that <b>she collects</b> the <b>entire</b> amount, both the main sum and additional sum written in the marriage contract. <b>But if you say</b> that <b>he did not write</b> a marriage contract <b>for her,</b> and she collects a payment only because of the rabbinic ordinance, <b>what is</b> the meaning of: <b>She collects</b> the <b>entire</b> sum? <b>She has</b> only <b>one hundred dinars or two hundred</b> dinars, as enacted by the Sages, and no more. The phrase: Entire sum, is inappropriate according to this opinion.
<b>But rather,</b> the proof that a widow from betrothal receives a marriage contract is <b>from</b> that <b>which was taught</b> by <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin:</b> Upon the death of <b>one’s betrothed wife,</b> he does <b>not</b> receive the status of <b>an acute mourner,</b> one whose close relative has died but has not yet been buried, <b>nor become impure</b> if he is a priest. <b>And likewise, she neither</b> receives the status of <b>an acute mourner nor becomes impure for him.</b> If <b>she dies, he does not inherit</b> from <b>her.</b> If <b>he dies, she collects</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract.</b> This shows that a widow from betrothal receives a marriage contract.
The Gemara refutes this proof in the same manner as before: <b>Perhaps</b> this is referring to a case where he <b>wrote</b> a marriage contract <b>for her</b> on his own accord. <b>And if you would say</b> in response that <b>if</b> that mishna is referring to a case where <b>he wrote</b> the marriage contract <b>for her, what</b> is the purpose of <b>stating</b> that she collects the payment, as this is obvious and teaches nothing new; perhaps <b>it was necessary for him</b> to mention that despite the fact that the man wrote a marriage contract for her, if <b>she dies, he does not inherit</b> from <b>her.</b> The discussion concludes without a source for the <i>halakha</i> that a widow from betrothal receives a marriage contract.
<b>Rav Naḥman said to Rav Huna: According to Rav, who said</b> that if she produces <b>a bill of divorce she</b> can <b>collect the main</b> sum of her marriage contract, <b>shouldn’t there be a concern lest she produce the bill of divorce in this court and collect with it, and again produce it in a different court and collect</b> with it? <b>And should you say that we tear it,</b> as the court does to other documents that have been paid, she will not let us do so, for <b>she</b> will <b>say:</b> I do not want you to tear the bill of divorce because <b>I need</b> it, so that when I want <b>to marry</b> again I can prove <b>with it</b> that I am divorced.
Rav Huna responded: The solution is <b>that we tear it and write</b> the following <b>on its back: We tore this bill of divorce, not because it is an invalid bill of divorce, but</b> in order <b>that she not return and collect with it another time.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a woman had <b>two bills of divorce and two marriage contracts</b> as a result of her divorce and remarriage to the same man, the fact that she is in possession of these documents proves that she was never paid for her first marriage contract, and she <b>collects two marriage contracts.</b>
If she was in possession of <b>two marriage contracts and</b> only <b>one bill of divorce; or</b> if she had one <b>marriage contract and two bills of divorce; or</b> if she had <b>a marriage contract, a bill of divorce, and</b> witnesses to her husband’s <b>death</b> after their remarriage, <b>she collects</b> payment of <b>only one marriage contract.</b> This is because there is a presumption <b>that one who divorces his wife and remarries her, remarries her with the intention</b> of using her <b>first marriage contract,</b> and she agrees that she collects payment of only the original document. This is the presumption, unless he wrote another marriage contract for her.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that if she had two marriage contracts and one bill of divorce, she can collect only one marriage contract. However, it does not specify which marriage contract she can claim. Does this mean that <b>if</b> she <b>desires, she can collect</b> payment of the marriage contract <b>with this one, and if</b> she <b>desires, she can collect</b> payment <b>with that one?</b> In that case, if she prefers she can use the document that promises the larger sum, and if she prefers to use the marriage contract with the earlier date in order to be able to collect property that her husband had sold to others between the dates on the two documents, she may collect with that one.
The Gemara asks: If that is the case, <b>let us say that it is a conclusive refutation of</b> a statement that <b>Rav Naḥman</b> said that <b>Shmuel said, as Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> If there are <b>two documents that are issued one after the other,</b> each recording the same transaction of a sale or a gift and they are separated by a few days, it is assumed that the <b>second</b> document <b>cancels the first</b> one. Why not say in this case as well that the second marriage contract voids the first one?
The Gemara answers: <b>Was it not stated with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> Rav Naḥman quoted in the name of Shmuel that <b>Rav Pappa said: And Rav Naḥman concedes that if he added to</b> the transaction detailed in the second document <b>a palm tree</b> that was not mentioned in the first document, this shows that he did not intend to cancel the first document. Rather, <b>he wrote</b> the second document <b>as an addition</b> to the first document. <b>Here too,</b> the Gemara is dealing <b>with</b> a case <b>when he added</b> an additional sum <b>for her</b> in the second marriage contract. This proves that he wanted to add to the first marriage contract, and not to void it.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If <b>she produced a bill of divorce, a marriage contract, and</b> witnesses to her husband’s <b>death,</b>

Daf 90a

<b>if</b> the date of the <b>bill of divorce precedes</b> the date <b>of the marriage contract, she</b> collects payment for her <b>two marriage contracts.</b> She is entitled to the first marriage contract by virtue of the bill of divorce. She is entitled to the second one because she has shown that it was written for her when they remarried. If the date of the <b>marriage contract precedes</b> the date <b>of the bill of divorce, she collects</b> payment of <b>only one marriage contract.</b> This is because it is presumed <b>that one who divorces his wife and remarries her, remarries her with the intention</b> of using her <b>first marriage contract,</b> unless there is a reason to say otherwise.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a minor who was married</b> off <b>by his father,</b> the wife’s <b>marriage contract</b> that the minor wrote <b>is valid</b> even after the husband comes of age. He cannot excuse himself by saying that it was drafted when he was a minor, <b>as</b> it is <b>on this condition,</b> the terms of this marriage contract, that <b>he maintained her</b> as his wife upon his maturity. Similarly, in the case of <b>a convert whose wife converted with him,</b> the <b>marriage contract</b> that she had as a gentile <b>is valid, for on this condition he maintained her</b> as his wife.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Huna said: They taught</b> that the wife of a minor or convert receives payment <b>only</b> with regard to the main sum of <b>one hundred dinars</b> or <b>two hundred</b> dinars. <b>However, she does not have</b> the right to receive the <b>additional</b> sum that he wrote in her marriage contract, because this document is not legally binding, as it was written by a minor. She receives the main sum only as a result of an ordinance instituted by the Sages. <b>And Rav Yehuda said: She has even</b> the <b>additional</b> sum.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> against the opinion of Rav Yehuda from a <i>baraita</i>: If a minor who came of age or a gentile who converted then <b>introduced</b> an additional sum to the marriage contract, <b>she takes</b> the additional sum <b>that they introduced.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>Yes,</b> the woman receives <b>what they introduced.</b> However, if <b>they did not introduce</b> an additional sum, she does <b>not</b> collect, even if it was written in the original marriage contract.
The Gemara refutes this proof: <b>Say</b> that this means that she takes <b>even that which they introduced,</b> in addition to the entire amount of her original marriage contract. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>did not teach this,</b> and the continuation of the <i>baraita</i> states the opposite: If <b>they introduced</b> a new sum, <b>she takes</b> the additional sum <b>that which they introduced.</b> If <b>they did not introduce</b> a new sum, <b>a virgin collects two hundred</b> dinars <b>and a widow one hundred dinars.</b> She does not collect the additional sum listed in the marriage document. This provides <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the statement <b>of Rav Yehuda,</b> whose opinion is rejected.
The Gemara explains: <b>Rav Yehuda was misled by</b> the language of <b>the mishna</b> and reached an incorrect conclusion. <b>He thought</b> that the phrase: <b>Her marriage contract is valid, is referring to the entire matter,</b> the entire sum of the marriage contract. <b>But that is not so,</b> as it <b>is referring</b> only <b>to the main</b> sum of the marriage contract that was established by the Sages, and not to any additional sum.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who was married to two women and died, the first</b> woman he married <b>precedes the second</b> in collecting the payment specified in her marriage contract if there are insufficient funds to pay both, because her document is dated earlier. So too, if the wives died after their husband before they received payment for their marriage contracts, <b>the heirs of the first</b> wife <b>precede the heirs of the second</b> wife in collecting these payments.
If <b>he married a first</b> woman <b>and she</b> subsequently <b>died,</b> and he then <b>married a second</b> woman <b>and he</b> subsequently <b>died, the second</b> wife <b>and her heirs precede the heirs of the first</b> wife. This is because the marriage contract of the second wife is considered a debt that the estate of the deceased is required to pay, whereas the claim of the heirs of the first wife is based on the stipulation in the marriage contract that male children inherit their mother’s marriage contract. Heirs receive their share of the estate only from property that remains after all debts have been settled.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it teaches: The first</b> woman he married <b>precedes the second</b> in collecting the payment of her marriage contract, <b>and it does not teach</b> simply that <b>the first</b> woman <b>has</b> the right to receive payment of her marriage contract <b>and the second does not have</b> that right, the mishna thereby teaches <b>by inference that if the second preceded</b> the first <b>and seized</b> property in payment of her marriage contract, <b>we do not expropriate it from her,</b> because her rights to the property are not completely canceled.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Learn from</b> the mishna the following principle: In the case of <b>a creditor</b> holding a promissory note dated <b>later</b> than the notes of other creditors <b>who preceded</b> the other creditors <b>and collected</b> his debt, <b>whatever he collected, he has collected,</b> and it is not expropriated from him even if the debtor does not have the means to pay back all his creditors.
The Gemara rejects this conclusion: <b>Actually, I will say to you</b> that <b>what he collected, he has not collected,</b> i.e., he must restore the property to the debtor so that the latter can pay the other creditors. <b>And what</b> does the mishna mean when it teaches that the first wife <b>precedes</b> the second? It <b>teaches</b> that the first wife <b>completely</b> precedes the second and is granted exclusive rights to collect the payment of her marriage contract. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 115a): <b>A son precedes a daughter</b> in matters of inheritance. Were she to come first and take part of the inheritance, it would not become hers; the son completely precedes her, so that in cases where there is a male heir, the daughter receives nothing. The same understanding of the word precedes applies in this matter as well.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that the discussion was as follows: <b>From the fact that it does not teach: If the second</b> wife <b>preceded</b> the first wife <b>and seized</b> property <b>it is not expropriated from her,</b> it proves <b>by inference that if the second</b> wife <b>preceded</b> the first <b>and seized</b> property as payment for her marriage contract, <b>we do appropriate it from her.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Learn from</b> the mishna the following rule: In the case of <b>a creditor</b> holding a promissory note dated <b>later</b> than the notes of other creditors <b>who preceded</b> the other creditors <b>and collected</b> his debt, <b>whatever he collected, he has not collected,</b> i.e., it is expropriated from him.
The Gemara rejects this conclusion: <b>Actually, I will say to you</b> that <b>what</b> the later creditor <b>collected, he has collected,</b> but <b>since the mishna taught</b> later: <b>The second</b> wife <b>and her heirs precede the heirs of the first,</b> so that even if the heirs of the first wife seize property, they do not legally acquire it and it is expropriated from them, because they are collecting an inheritance rather than a debt,

Daf 90b

<b>it taught</b> the first clause <b>as well</b> with the same wording: <b>The first</b> woman <b>precedes the second,</b> without elaborating that the property would not be expropriated from the second if she were to seize it in payment of her marriage contract.
§ The mishna taught: If <b>he married the first</b> woman, etc. The Gemara notes: <b>Conclude three</b> conclusions <b>from this</b> statement: <b>Conclude from it</b> that if <b>one</b> of the man’s wives died <b>in his lifetime and</b> the other <b>one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> then the sons of the first wife <b>are entitled to</b> collect the <b>marriage contract concerning male children and we are not concerned</b> that this would lead to <b>quarreling.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is it known that this is correct? <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it teaches:</b> The <b>second</b> wife <b>and her heirs precede the heirs of the first</b> wife, it can be inferred that <b>they precede</b> the heirs of the first, <b>but</b> if <b>there are</b> enough funds in the estate for all the claims against it, then the children of the first wife do <b>take</b> their share of the dowry.
The second point one can <b>conclude from it is</b> that <b>one marriage contract becomes surplus for the other.</b> The Sages ruled that each son may claim his mother’s marriage settlement only when the value of the estate exceeds the sum total of the marriage contracts by at least one dinar, so that the biblical laws of inheritance can be fulfilled. Since the marriage settlement collected by the heirs of the second wife is considered a debt owed by the estate, this sum is considered to have been paid equally by all the heirs. The biblical laws of inheritance have thereby been fulfilled, and the sons of the first wife can claim the marriage contract concerning male children even if nothing will be left in the estate after they have collected their payment.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is it known that this is correct? The Gemara answers: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it does not teach</b> in the mishna: <b>If there is a surplus of a dinar</b> in addition to the value of all the marriage contracts.
<b>And conclude from it</b> a third point, that when one collects the payment for <b>the marriage contract concerning male children, he cannot seize liened</b> property that his father sold to others, as one can when collecting a debt. <b>As, if it should enter your mind that it can be repossessed from liened</b> property, then <b>let the sons of the first</b> wife <b>come and repossess</b> land already claimed <b>by the sons of the second</b> wife as payment for their mother’s marriage contract, since the land the sons of the second wife took was previously liened, due to the marriage contract of the first wife. Rather, the children of the first wife are viewed not as creditors but as heirs, who cannot repossess property sold by their father.
<b>Rav Ashi objects to</b> two of the three conclusions stated above: <b>From where</b> is it known that all of this is correct? <b>Perhaps I</b> could <b>actually say to you</b> that if <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> then <b>no one is entitled to</b> collect the <b>marriage contract concerning male children. And what does</b> the mishna mean when it says <b>precede?</b> It does not mean that if there are enough assets remaining, the sons of the first wife receive the sum of their mother’s marriage settlement. Rather, <b>it is teaching</b> that after the sons of the second wife receive the sum of their mother’s marriage settlement, the sons from both marriages <b>inherit</b> equal shares of the remaining estate.
<b>And if you would say</b> that if the mishna is referring to the inheritance of the remainder of the estate, <b>why do I</b> need the mishna to mention <b>the heirs of the first</b> wife; since it is teaching a <i>halakha</i> concerning their inheritance from their father and not their inheritance from their mother, why refer to them as the heirs of the first wife? One could reply that <b>since it taught: The second</b> wife <b>and her heirs,</b> the mishna <b>also taught</b> the parallel phrase: <b>The heirs of the first</b> wife, but no halakhic conclusions should be drawn from this.
<b>And concerning what you said</b> that <b>one marriage contract becomes surplus for the other,</b> this too can be rejected: <b>Perhaps I</b> could <b>actually say to you</b> that <b>one marriage contract does not become surplus for the other, and</b> that the case under discussion <b>here is where there is a surplus of</b> an additional <b>dinar,</b> and the reason why it was not explicitly mentioned is because it is not the subject of our mishna.
§ The Gemara notes that in a case where <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> there <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> if the sons of the wife who died in her husband’s lifetime are entitled to collect their mother’s marriage settlement. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>they died, one in his lifetime and one</b> following <b>his death, ben Nanas says: The sons of the first</b> wife <b>can say to the sons of the second</b> wife: <b>You are the children of a creditor,</b> so <b>collect your mother’s marriage contract and leave,</b> and we will inherit the rest of the estate due to the marriage contract concerning male children.
<b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> When the husband died, the <b>inheritance already eluded the sons of the first</b> wife <b>and came into</b> the possession of <b>the sons of the second</b> wife as an inheritance, i.e., the Sages did not institute the marriage contract concerning male children in a case where one of the wives was alive when the husband died. Consequently, after the sons of the second wife collect their mother’s marriage settlement, the remainder of the estate is divided evenly between all the man’s sons.
The Gemara comments: <b>What, is it not that they disagree about this: One Sage,</b> ben Nanas, <b>holds</b> that in a case where <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> the first wife’s sons <b>are entitled to</b> collect the <b>marriage contract concerning male children. And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that in a case where <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> the first wife’s sons <b>are not entitled to</b> collect the <b>marriage contract concerning male children.</b>
<b>Rabba said: I found the Sages of the school of Rav sitting and saying: Everyone agrees</b> that in a case where <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> the first wife’s sons <b>are entitled to</b> collect the <b>marriage contract concerning male children. Here,</b> however, <b>they disagree with regard to</b> the question of whether or not one <b>marriage contract becomes surplus for the other</b> in a case where there is no surplus of an additional dinar with which to fulfill the biblical laws of inheritance. <b>And the same is true</b> with regard to payment made <b>to a creditor,</b> i.e., they disagree whether paying a creditor of their father is a sufficient fulfillment of the biblical laws of inheritance to allow collection of the marriage contract concerning male children.
One <b>Sage,</b> ben Nanas, <b>holds</b> that one <b>marriage contract becomes surplus for the other, and the same is true</b> with regard to payment made <b>to a creditor, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that one <b>marriage contract does not become surplus for the other, and the same is true</b> with regard to the debt owed <b>to a creditor.</b>
Rabba continues: <b>And I said to them: With regard to</b> payment made to <b>a creditor, everyone agrees that it is</b> considered <b>surplus</b> and fulfills the biblical laws of inheritance, even given the lien attached to it. <b>When they disagree</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> whether <b>a marriage contract</b> can be considered surplus.
<b>Rav Yosef objects to this. If that is so,</b> then why did it say in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Akiva says: The inheritance already eluded</b> them? Rather, <b>it should have said: If there is a surplus of a dinar,</b> since that is the actual focal point of the disagreement.
<b>Rather, Rav Yosef said: They disagree with regard to</b> the basic issue of whether the Sages instituted the marriage contract concerning male children in a case where <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> as was explained initially.
<b>And these <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> ben Nanas and Rabbi Akiva, <b>are like those</b> other <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> who debated this very same point, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he married a first</b> woman <b>and she</b> subsequently <b>died,</b> and he then <b>married a second</b> woman <b>and he</b> subsequently <b>died, the sons of this</b> woman, i.e., the second wife, <b>come after</b> her <b>death and collect</b> payment of <b>their mother’s marriage contract</b> if she did not collect it while she was alive, while the rest of the estate is distributed equally between all the sons. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: If there is a surplus of a dinar, these</b> sons of the first wife <b>collect their mother’s marriage contract,</b> namely, the marriage contract concerning male offspring, <b>and these</b> sons of the second wife <b>collect their mother’s marriage contract, and if not, they divide</b> the entire estate <b>equally</b> among themselves.
<b>What, is it not</b> that <b>they disagree with regard to</b> the following: One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that in a case where <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> the sons of the first wife <b>are entitled to</b> collect the <b>marriage contract concerning male children; and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that in a case where <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> the sons of the first wife <b>are not entitled to</b> collect the <b>marriage contract concerning male children,</b> and only the second wife’s sons collect their mother’s marriage contract.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> it is possible to say that <b>everyone</b> agrees that in a case where <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> the sons of the first wife <b>are entitled to</b> collect the <b>marriage contract concerning male children,</b>

Daf 91a

<b>and here they disagree about a dinar’s worth</b> of <b>real estate:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that if the surplus was in the form of <b>real estate,</b> meaning that there was sufficient real estate to cover the sums specified in the marriage contracts and one dinar’s worth of land was still left over, then <b>yes,</b> each can claim his mother’s marriage contract, but if the surplus of the dinar was only in <b>movable property,</b> then <b>no,</b> they cannot; <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that the heirs may claim the marriage contracts <b>even</b> if the surplus is in <b>movable property.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But how can you say</b> that? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna (91a) that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Even if there is property that does not</b> serve as <b>a guarantee</b> for a loan, i.e., movable property, <b>it is considered as nothing, unless there is property that</b> serves as <b>a guarantee</b> for a loan with a promissory note, i.e., land, <b>exceeding the</b> value of the <b>two marriage contracts</b> by at least one additional <b>dinar.</b>
<b>Rather, here they disagree about a dinar of liened</b> property: One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that if the surplus was in the form of <b>unsold</b> property, then <b>yes,</b> each can claim the sum specified in his mother’s marriage contract, but if the surplus was only in <b>liened</b> property then <b>no,</b> he cannot. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that it is deemed a surplus <b>even</b> if it was in the form of <b>liened</b> property.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> the <i>baraita</i> should not have stated Rabbi Shimon’s opinion using the conditional: <b>Rabbi Shimon says: If there is a surplus of a dinar.</b> In this case such a surplus certainly exists, and therefore <b>it should have</b> said: <b>Since there is a surplus of a dinar.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the dispute can be explained differently: <b>They disagree about</b> a case where there is <b>less than a dinar</b> of surplus: One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that if the surplus was worth <b>a dinar,</b> then <b>yes,</b> each can claim his mother’s marriage contract, but if it was <b>less than a dinar</b> then <b>no,</b> he cannot. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that it is deemed a surplus <b>even</b> if it was <b>less than a dinar.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But Rabbi Shimon said:</b> If there is a surplus of <b>a dinar,</b> and not less. <b>And if you would say: Reverse</b> the interpretation of the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i> in the <i>baraita</i> cited above, that would be unacceptable, because the <b>first <i>tanna</i> of the mishna</b> (91a), who is presumably identical to the first <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>also said</b> that the surplus must be at least one <b>dinar.</b>
The Gemara concludes: <b>Rather,</b> the dispute in the <i>baraita</i> must be explained <b>according to those first two formulations</b> cited above, that they disagree about a surplus in movable property or about a surplus in liened property. <b>And reverse</b> the interpretation of the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>, so that he holds that the sons of the first wife may collect her marriage settlement if there is a surplus in their father’s estate of one dinar worth of movable property or liened property, whereas Rabbi Shimon holds that there must be a surplus of one dinar worth of land that is not liened.
<b>Mar Zutra said in the name of Rav Pappa: The <i>halakha</i></b> in the case where <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death</b> is that the sons of the first wife <b>are entitled to the</b> collect the <b>marriage contract concerning male children, and</b> furthermore, that one <b>marriage contract becomes surplus for the other.</b>
The Gemara wonders: <b>Granted, if</b> Mar Zutra <b>would have taught us</b> only that in a case where <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> the sons of the first wife <b>are entitled to</b> collect the <b>marriage contract concerning male children, and he</b> would <b>not have taught us</b> that one <b>marriage contract becomes surplus for the other, I would say</b> that <b>if there is a surplus of a dinar</b> after the payment of both marriage settlements, then <b>yes,</b> the sons of the first wife can claim their mother’s marriage settlement, but <b>if not,</b> then <b>no,</b> they cannot.
<b>However, let him teach us</b> only that one <b>marriage contract becomes surplus for the other, and I would know</b> that it is <b>due to</b> the fact that if <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died following <b>his death,</b> the sons of the first wife <b>are entitled to</b> claim payment of the <b>marriage contract concerning male children.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>If he</b> would have <b>taught us</b> only <b>that,</b> that a marriage contract can serve as a surplus, <b>I would say</b> that this applies specifically in a case <b>where</b> an individual <b>married three women, and two</b> of them <b>died in his lifetime and one</b> after <b>his death, and that</b> wife <b>who died</b> after <b>his death</b> had <b>given birth to a daughter</b> but no sons, <b>and the daughter does not inherit</b> any part of the estate. Although the daughter is entitled to be sustained from her father’s estate, she has no claim to a share in the inheritance. Consequently, there is no concern for quarreling, as all the heirs are in the same situation.
<b>However,</b> in a case where <b>one</b> wife died <b>in his lifetime and one</b> died after <b>his death, where the one who</b> died <b>after his death</b> had <b>given birth to a son</b> who is suing for his portion of the estate, one could <b>say</b> that there is a <b>concern about quarreling</b> arising from the complaints of the son of the second wife. Therefore, Mar Zutra mentions both <i>halakhot</i> explicitly in order <b>to teach us</b> that this concern is not taken into account.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who was married to two women and</b> the women <b>died, and subsequently he died, and the orphans</b> of one of the wives <b>are</b> now <b>seeking</b> to collect the payment specified in <b>their mother’s marriage contract,</b> i.e., the marriage contract concerning male children, <b>but there is only enough</b> in the estate to pay the value of the <b>two marriage contracts,</b> the marriage contract concerning male children cannot be collected, and the sons <b>distribute</b> the estate <b>equally</b> among themselves according to the biblical laws of inheritance.
If <b>there was a surplus of a dinar</b> left <b>there,</b> in the estate, beyond the value of the two marriage contracts, then <b>these</b> sons <b>collect their mother’s marriage contract and those</b> sons <b>collect their mother’s marriage contract,</b> and the remaining property valued at a dinar is divided equally among all the sons.
<b>If the orphans</b> who are entitled to receive the marriage settlement of greater value <b>say: We inflate</b> the value of <b>our father’s property by a dinar,</b> i.e., we agree to evaluate the property we will receive for our mother’s marriage settlement at a value higher than the market value so that there will be a dinar left in the estate after the two marriage contracts have been paid, <b>so that they can collect their mother’s marriage contract,</b> the court does <b>not listen to them. Rather,</b> the value of <b>the property is appraised in court,</b> and the distribution of the estate is based on that evaluation.
If <b>there was potential</b> inheritance <b>there,</b> meaning that there was no surplus of a dinar in the existing properties of the estate, but there was property that was expected to be paid to the estate and which would increase the overall value of the estate so that there would be a surplus of a dinar after the payment of the marriage contracts, these properties <b>are not</b> considered to be <b>in</b> the <b>possession</b> of the estate in determining the total value of the estate.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says: Even if there is property that does not</b> serve as <b>guarantee</b> for a loan, i.e., movable property, there in the estate, <b>it does not</b> have <b>any</b> impact on the value of the estate. The marriage contracts concerning male children are not collected <b>unless there is property that</b> serves as <b>a guarantee,</b> i.e., land, <b>exceeding the</b> value of the <b>two marriage contracts</b> by at least one additional <b>dinar.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>this</b> wife had a marriage contract valued at <b>one thousand</b> dinars and <b>that</b> wife had a marriage contract valued at <b>five hundred</b> dinars, <b>if there is a surplus of one dinar,</b> then <b>these</b> sons <b>collect their mother’s marriage contract and those</b> sons <b>collect their mother’s marriage contract. And if not, they divide</b> the inheritance <b>equally.</b>
The Gemara notes: It <b>is obvious</b> that if there were <b>abundant</b> properties, i.e., there was a surplus of a dinar above the value of the two marriage settlements at the time of the man’s death, <b>but they depreciated</b> before the sons collected the marriage settlements, <b>the heirs have already acquired rights to</b> the marriage settlements. However, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if the estate’s holdings were <b>few,</b> i.e., there was no surplus at the time of the man’s death, <b>but they appreciated</b> before the sons divided the estate, so that there was a surplus? Do the sons collect the mothers’ marriage settlements?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution based upon the following case: The <b>properties of the house of bar Tzartzur</b> were <b>few,</b> i.e., there was no surplus beyond his wives’ marriage settlements, <b>and they appreciated.</b> The sons of the two wives <b>came before Rav Amram</b> to discuss the matter. <b>He said to</b> the sons of the wife who had the more valuable marriage contract: <b>Go appease</b> the sons of the other wife and give them some of your share. <b>They did not heed</b> his advice.
<b>He said to them: If you will not appease them, I will strike you with a thorn [<i>silva</i>] that does not draw blood,</b> i.e., I will excommunicate you. <b>He sent them before Rav Naḥman.</b> Rav Naḥman <b>said to them: Just as</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that if the properties were <b>abundant but depreciated,</b>

Daf 91b

<b>the heirs acquired rights to</b> the mothers’ marriage contracts due to the value of the estate when their father died, <b>so too,</b> in a case where the properties were <b>few and</b> the value subsequently <b>appreciated, the heirs have acquired rights</b> to divide the entire estate equally, due to the value of the estate when their father died.
§ This is <b>a mnemonic</b> device for the following <i>halakhot</i>, which are connected in one way or another to the problem being dealt with in the mishna: <b>One thousand, and one hundred, mitzva, in the marriage contract, Ya’akov, set up, his fields, with words, disputants.</b>
There was <b>a certain man who</b> had a creditor with <b>a claim</b> of <b>one thousand dinars against him. He had two mansions [<i>appedanei</i>]. He sold them, one for five hundred and the other</b> one also <b>for five hundred. The creditor came and repossessed one of them</b> from the purchaser, as the repayment of part of his debt. <b>He subsequently</b> sought to <b>repossess the other</b> mansion as well, in payment for the remainder of his debt.
The purchaser <b>took one thousand dinars and went to</b> the creditor. <b>He said to him: If</b> the first mansion that you repossessed is <b>worth one thousand dinars to you, very well,</b> let it be yours in exchange for the entire sum that is owed to you, <b>and if not, take</b> these <b>one thousand dinars and abrogate</b> your rights to both of the mansions, leaving them both in my possession.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama thought to say</b> that <b>this</b> case <b>is</b> identical to that which is taught in <b>the mishna: If the orphans say: We inflate</b> the value of <b>our father’s property by a dinar,</b> the court does not listen to them. This appears to be the case here as well, and the value of the mansion should not be assessed at higher than its market value.
<b>Rava said to him: Are</b> the two cases <b>comparable? There,</b> in the mishna, <b>the</b> other <b>orphans</b> whose mother’s marriage contract was of lesser value will suffer a financial <b>loss</b> if the property is assessed at a value greater than it is actually worth. <b>Here,</b> in the case of the creditor, <b>does he incur a loss? He lent one thousand</b> dinars <b>and took one thousand</b> dinars; consequently, it would be cruel on his part to refuse to take the money and to insist on taking the second mansion from the purchaser.
The Gemara asks: If the creditor decided to hold on to the first mansion and to forgive the remainder of the debt, <b>what amount is written</b> in the document of <b>authorization to repossess</b> liened property, through which the purchaser will claim compensation from the seller? The purchaser had paid only five hundred dinars for the mansion that was repossessed, but the repossession of that mansion earned the seller one thousand dinars, as his entire debt was paid off.
<b>Ravina said:</b> It is written <b>for one thousand</b> dinars. <b>Rav Avira said:</b> It is written <b>for five hundred</b> dinars; the fact that the creditor forgave the full amount of the debt in exchange for this house was his own personal decision and does not reflect an increase in the property value of the house. The Gemara concludes: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is</b> that it is written <b>for five hundred</b> dinars.
It is also related that there was <b>a certain man who</b> had a creditor with <b>a claim</b> of <b>one hundred dinars against him. He had two small</b> tracts <b>of land. He sold one for fifty and</b> he also sold the other <b>one for fifty. The creditor came and repossessed one of them</b> from the purchaser as the collection of part of his debt. <b>He subsequently came,</b> seeking to <b>repossess the other</b> tract of land as well, as payment for the rest of the debt owed to him.
The purchaser <b>took one hundred dinars and went to</b> the creditor. <b>He said to him: If</b> this tract is <b>worth one hundred dinars to you, very well, and if not, take one hundred dinars and abrogate</b> your rights to both of the tracts, leaving them both in my possession.
<b>Rav Yosef thought to say</b> that this case <b>is</b> identical to that which is taught in <b>the mishna,</b> whereby <b>if the orphans say:</b> We inflate the value of our father’s property by a dinar, the court does not listen to them. <b>Abaye said to him: Are</b> the two cases <b>comparable? There,</b> in the mishna, <b>the</b> other <b>orphans</b> suffer <b>a</b> financial <b>loss</b> if the property is assessed at a value greater than it is actually worth; <b>here, what loss</b> does the creditor <b>incur? He lent one hundred</b> dinars <b>and took one hundred</b> dinars. It would be cruel on his part to refuse to take the money and to insist on taking the land from the purchaser.
The Gemara asks: If the creditor decided to hold on to the first tract of land and to forgive the remainder of the debt, <b>what amount is written</b> in the document of <b>authorization to repossess</b> liened property, through which the purchaser will claim compensation from the seller? <b>Ravina said</b> that it is written <b>for one hundred. Rav Avira said</b> it is written <b>for fifty.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is</b> that it is written <b>for fifty</b> dinars.
The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain man who</b> had a creditor with <b>a claim of one hundred dinars against him. He died</b> and <b>left a small</b> tract <b>of land worth fifty dinars. The creditor came and repossessed it. The orphans came</b> and <b>gave him fifty dinars</b> and redeemed the property from him. <b>He returned</b> and <b>repossessed it</b> again in order to collect the remainder of the debt.
<b>They came before Abaye</b> to complain. <b>He said to them: It is a mitzva for orphans to settle their father’s debt.</b> Consequently, with the money you paid the creditor <b>initially, you performed a mitzva,</b> as you partially settled a debt your father owed. However, this payment did not cancel the lien on the property, and so <b>now, when he repossesses</b> the land, <b>he is repossesses</b> it <b>lawfully.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And we said</b> this ruling only in a case <b>where</b> the orphans <b>did not say to</b> the creditor: <b>These fifty dinars are payment</b> for <b>the small</b> tract <b>of land. However,</b> if <b>they said to him: These fifty dinars are payment</b> for <b>the small</b> tract <b>of land, they have</b> successfully <b>removed him</b> from the land and he has no further claim to it.
§ The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain man who sold</b> the rights to <b>his mother’s marriage contract for</b> a certain <b>financial advantage,</b> i.e., he received a certain sum on the condition that if he would inherit his mother’s marriage contract, which would occur if his mother’s husband would die prior to his mother, the purchaser would obtain the right to collect the money. <b>And he told</b> the purchaser: <b>If</b> my <b>mother comes and objects</b> to the sale, <b>I will not reimburse you</b> for your purchase.
<b>His mother died</b> after her husband died, <b>and</b> had <b>not objected</b> to the sale. <b>He,</b> however, <b>came and contested</b> the sale. <b>Rami bar Ḥama thought to say</b> that <b>he stands in his mother’s place</b> and since he is her proxy, he has the right to object to the sale. <b>Rava said to him: Granted that he did not take upon himself</b> to <b>guarantee</b> the sale against his mother’s objections, but <b>did he not take upon himself</b> to <b>guarantee</b> it against <b>his own</b> objections? When he sold the right to collect the marriage contract, he most certainly guaranteed that he would not renege on the sale.
The Gemara relates a similar discussion. Rami <b>bar Ḥama said:</b> If <b>Reuven sold a field to Shimon without a guarantee, and Shimon came and sold</b> the field back <b>to Reuven,</b> but he sold it <b>with a guarantee</b> that if the field is repossessed, he will compensate the buyer for his loss,

Daf 92a

<b>and Reuven’s creditor came and repossessed</b> the field <b>from him,</b> i.e., from Reuven, <b>the law is that Shimon</b> must <b>go and compensate [<i>mefatzei</i>] Reuven,</b> since he sold him the field with a guarantee, while Reuven owes Shimon nothing, since he sold him the field without a guarantee.
<b>Rava said to him: Granted, that</b> Shimon <b>took upon himself</b> to <b>guarantee</b> the sale in <b>general,</b> i.e., if the field were to be repossessed by his own creditors or those of a previous owner of the field; <b>did he</b> also <b>take upon himself</b> to <b>guarantee</b> the sale if it were to be repossessed by the purchaser’s <b>own</b> creditors?
The Gemara notes: <b>And Rava concedes</b> to Rami bar Ḥama <b>in</b> the following case: <b>Reuven inherited a field from</b> his father, <b>Ya’akov, and sold it to Shimon with no guarantee. Shimon came and sold it</b> back <b>to Reuven with a guarantee.</b> Then, <b>Ya’akov’s creditor came and repossessed the field from</b> Reuven. In this case, Rava would concede that <b>the law is that Shimon</b> must <b>go and compensate</b> Reuven for his loss.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>Ya’akov’s creditor is comparable to a general</b> case of a creditor, i.e., a creditor of a previous owner. Even Rava would agree that this is not comparable to a case where Reuven’s creditor repossessed the field. Consequently, Shimon bears responsibility to compensate Reuven.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> Consider a case where <b>Reuven sold a field to Shimon with a guarantee</b> that if it is repossessed he will compensate Shimon for his loss. Shimon did not pay for the purchase, <b>and</b> instead <b>set up</b> the value of the field <b>as a loan</b> by writing a promissory note for this amount. <b>Reuven</b> subsequently <b>died, and a creditor of Reuven came and repossessed</b> the field <b>from Shimon.</b> Shimon, not wanting the creditor to take the field from him, tried to <b>appease him with money</b> so the creditor would allow him to keep the field.
<b>The law is that the sons of Reuven</b> can <b>say to</b> Shimon that he must pay them the money he owes for the field, and they are not required to pay Shimon if he demands compensation for the repossession of the field. They may say to him: <b>Our father left us movable property with you,</b> i.e., the money you owe us for the field, <b>and the movable property of orphans is not liened to a creditor.</b> The orphans can claim that the field belongs to Shimon, and as there is no land left for the orphans, there is no way for Shimon to recover the compensation that he is owed. The money he owes Reuven is considered movable property, and therefore he cannot recover his losses from these funds.
<b>Rava said</b> with regard to this case: <b>If the other</b> individual, Shimon, <b>is clever he will pay them</b> what he owes with <b>real estate</b> and not with money. Since they now have real estate inherited from their father’s estate, Shimon <b>can then collect</b> the field <b>from them</b> as compensation for the repossession of the original field that Reuven sold to Shimon. This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman, as Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> When <b>orphans collect real estate for a debt owed to their father</b> from one person, their father’s <b>creditor</b> can <b>come and seize this</b> land <b>from them.</b>
The Gemara addresses a similar matter. <b>Rabba said:</b> If <b>Reuven sold all his fields to Shimon,</b> and <b>Shimon then sold one field to Levi, and</b> then <b>Reuven’s creditor came</b> to repossess one of the fields that was mortgaged to him: If <b>he desires, he can collect from this one,</b> Shimon, and if <b>he desires, he can collect from that one,</b> Levi, since he has a lien that applies equally to all the properties that once belonged to Reuven.
<b>And we said</b> this <b>only</b> if Shimon <b>sold</b> Levi <b>land of intermediate quality, but</b> if <b>he sold</b> him <b>land of superior quality or inferior quality,</b> Levi <b>can say to</b> the creditor: It was <b>for this</b> reason that <b>I made an effort</b> to <b>buy land that is not fit for you,</b> as a creditor is supposed to repossess land of intermediate quality. Therefore, go to Shimon and collect your debt from the land of intermediate quality that is in his possession.
The Gemara notes further: <b>And</b> even if Shimon sold Levi <b>land of intermediate quality, we said</b> that the creditor may repossess Levi’s land <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> Levi <b>did not leave</b> Shimon with <b>equivalent land of intermediate quality.</b>

Daf 92b

<b>However,</b> if Levi <b>left similar land of intermediate quality</b> with Shimon, <b>he can say to</b> the creditor: <b>I have left you a place from which to collect;</b> go and collect from Shimon.
<b>Abaye said:</b> In a case <b>where Reuven sold a field to Shimon with a guarantee</b> that if the field is repossessed, he will compensate Shimon for his loss <b>and Reuven’s creditor comes and repossesses</b> the land <b>from</b> Shimon, <b>the law is that Reuven goes and rescues</b> Shimon by attempting to forestall the repossession, <b>and</b> the creditor <b>cannot say to</b> Reuven: <b>I am not legally answerable to you</b> since I am taking the field from Shimon. This is <b>because</b> Reuven <b>can retort: What you take from him comes back to me:</b> Since I guaranteed the sale and will ultimately have to compensate Shimon, you cannot claim that I am not a legal party in this matter.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>even</b> if Reuven sold Shimon the field <b>with no guarantee,</b> he can <b>also</b> join in the deliberations and attempt to forestall the repossession of the land. This is <b>because</b> Reuven can <b>say to</b> the creditor: It is <b>not amenable to me that Shimon will have a grievance against me</b> for having sold him land that was then repossessed.
<b>Abaye said:</b> In a case <b>where Reuven sold a field to Shimon with no guarantee, and it emerged</b> that <b>he had</b>

Daf 93a

<b>disputants</b> i.e., individuals who dispute Reuven’s ownership of the field, <b>as long as</b> Shimon <b>has not</b> yet <b>taken possession of it, he can renege</b> on the deal. However, <b>once he has taken possession,</b> Shimon <b>cannot renege</b> on the deal, <b>because</b> at that point the seller, Reuven, <b>can say to him: You agreed</b> to <b>a sack [<i>ḥaita</i>] of knots and you received it,</b> i.e., since you purchased the field with no guarantee, you understood that it was a risky investment. The Gemara asks: <b>And from when</b> is Shimon considered to have <b>taken possession of</b> the property? The Gemara answers: It is <b>from when he walks the boundaries</b> of the land to inspect it.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>even</b> if Reuven sold him the field <b>with a guarantee,</b> Shimon may not demand a refund immediately when he discovers that there are disputants, <b>as</b> Reuven <b>can say to</b> Shimon: <b>Show me your</b> document of <b>authorization to repossess</b> property from me, <b>and I will pay you.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who was married</b> to <b>three women and died</b> and <b>the marriage contract of this</b> wife was for <b>one hundred dinars and</b> the marriage contract <b>of this</b> second wife was for <b>two hundred</b> dinars, <b>and</b> the marriage contract <b>of this</b> third wife was for <b>three hundred,</b> and all three contracts were issued on the same date so that none of the wives has precedence over any of the others, <b>and</b> the total value of the estate is <b>only one hundred dinars,</b> the wives <b>divide</b> the estate <b>equally.</b>
If <b>there were two hundred</b> dinars in the estate, the one whose marriage contract was <b>for one hundred dinars takes fifty</b> dinars, while those whose contracts were <b>for two hundred and three hundred</b> dinars take <b>three</b> dinars <b>of gold each,</b> which are the equivalent of seventy-five silver dinars. If <b>there were three hundred</b> dinars in the estate, the one whose marriage contract was <b>for one hundred</b> dinars <b>takes fifty</b> dinars, the one whose contract was <b>for two hundred</b> dinars <b>takes one hundred</b> dinars, <b>and the one whose</b> contract was <b>for three hundred</b> dinars takes <b>six</b> dinars <b>of gold,</b> the equivalent of one hundred and fifty silver dinars.
<b>Similarly, three</b> individuals <b>who deposited</b> money <b>into a purse,</b> i.e., invested different amounts of money into a joint business venture: If they <b>incurred a loss or earned a profit,</b> and now choose to dissolve the partnership, <b>they divide</b> the assets <b>in this manner,</b> i.e., based upon the amount that each of them initially invested in the partnership.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks about the <i>halakha</i> in the case where the estate has two hundred dinars, in which case the wife whose marriage contract was for one hundred dinars receives fifty dinars. Why should the wife whose marriage contract was <b>for one hundred take fifty? She should have</b> the right to collect only <b>thirty-three and one-third</b> dinars. Since her claim is only for the first hundred dinars, and all three women have an equal right to this first hundred, it stands to reason that it should be divided equally between the three of them.
<b>Shmuel said:</b> This is a case <b>where</b> the wife <b>whose</b> contract <b>was for two hundred writes</b> a document <b>to</b> the wife <b>whose</b> contract <b>was for one hundred</b> dinars: <b>I do not have</b> any <b>legal</b> dealings <b>or involvement with you with regard to</b> the first <b>hundred dinars.</b> Since she relinquished her share in the first hundred dinars, only two claimants remain, the one whose contract was for one hundred and the one whose contract was for three hundred, and they divide it equally between them.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so, say the latter clause</b> of that very same statement in the mishna, where it states that the wife <b>whose</b> contract <b>was for two hundred and</b> the one <b>whose</b> contract <b>was for three hundred take three</b> dinars <b>of gold each.</b> This is difficult, because the wife whose contract was for three hundred <b>should</b> be able to <b>say to</b> the wife whose contract was for two hundred: <b>You have removed yourself from</b> the first hundred dinars, and so you have a claim only against the remaining hundred. It should follow that the wife whose contract was for three hundred should take one hundred in total, fifty from the first hundred and fifty from the second hundred, and the one whose contract was for two hundred should receive only fifty, which is half of the second hundred.
