However, if the error is less than this, it is enough if she returns the remainder to the orphans. <b>And</b> in the case of <b>a garden,</b> the sale is void if, had there been no error, there would have remained <b>an area required for sowing a half-<i>kav</i> of seed,</b> as this is the smallest size of garden worth working. <b>Or, according to the statement of Rabbi Akiva, an area required for sowing a quarter-<i>kav</i> of seed.</b>
If <b>her marriage contract was</b> worth <b>four hundred dinars, and she sold</b> property <b>to this</b> one <b>for one hundred dinars, and</b> she sold property <b>to that</b> one <b>for one hundred dinars,</b> and again to a third one, <b>and</b> she sold property <b>to the last one worth one hundred dinars and a dinar for</b> only <b>one hundred dinars,</b> the sale <b>of the last</b> property <b>is void,</b> as the price she charged was below the market value. <b>And all of the others, their sale is valid,</b> as they were sold for the correct price.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara questions the first <i>halakha</i> mentioned in the mishna, which teaches that if the widow sold property worth two hundred dinars for one hundred dinars, or if she sold property worth one hundred dinars for two hundred dinars, in either case she can no longer demand any payment of her marriage contract. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about the case where she sold property <b>worth two hundred</b> dinars <b>for one hundred dinars,</b> where the <i>halakha</i> is that she has received her entire marriage contract, <b>as</b> the heirs can <b>say to her: You</b> caused yourself to <b>lose out</b> since you received from the estate the value of your entire marriage contract, but because you sold it improperly, you did not receive its full value. Why then, in the case where she sold property <b>worth one hundred dinars for two hundred</b> dinars, can she not <b>also say</b> to the heirs: <b>I profited</b> from the sale, but I received only the value of one hundred dinars from the estate, and I am entitled to another one hundred dinars?
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b>

Daf 98b

<b>Here Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught,</b> i.e., it can be learned from this mishna that it is Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion that <b>everything</b> belongs <b>to the owner of the money.</b> If one earned a profit through the actions of his agent, the profit belongs to him and not to the agent, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> where the Sages debate this matter: In a case where one sent an agent to the marketplace to purchase merchandise at a certain price, if in addition to items that the agent purchased <b>they added for him one extra</b> item, <b>the entire</b> profit belongs <b>to the agent;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The owner of the money and the agent <b>split</b> the profit.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Everything</b> belongs <b>to the owner of the money? Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>an item that has a fixed</b> price. If the seller added something, it is clear that the additional item is a gift, but it is unclear if the gift is meant for the agent or for the owner of the money, so it is split between the two. Whereas <b>there,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>an item that does not have a fixed</b> price, and one can say that any additional items that were given were not intended for the agent, but were part of the overall deal and belong to the owner of the money.
<b>Rav Pappa said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>an item that has a fixed</b> price <b>is split,</b> and with regard to <b>an item that does not have a fixed</b> price, <b>the entire</b> profit belongs <b>to the owner of the money.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is he teaching us</b> with that statement? That is exactly what Rami bar Ḥama said. The Gemara explains: He wanted to say that <b>the answer that we taught is the</b> correct <b>answer,</b> and one can issue practical halakhic rulings based on it.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If <b>one said to</b> his agent: <b>Sell</b> on <b>my</b> behalf <b>a half-<i>kor</i>, and</b> the agent <b>went and sold for him a <i>kor</i>, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is <b>he</b> considered to be <b>adding to the words</b> of his employer? In that case, though he also performed an action that he was not assigned to do, part of his action was performing his assigned agency, and the buyer <b>at least acquired a half-<i>kor</i>. Or perhaps he is</b> considered to be <b>disregarding his</b> employer’s <b>words,</b> since he did not perform exactly what he was told to do, in which case the entire transaction was performed by his own volition, without the authorization of his employer, <b>and even the half-<i>kor</i> is not acquired</b> by the buyer.
<b>Rav Ya’akov of Pekod River said in the name of Ravina: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from a mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 20a): The mishna teaches with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of misuse of consecrated property: If <b>the host said to his agent: Give the guests a piece</b> of meat, <b>and</b> the agent went and <b>said</b> to the guests: <b>Take two</b> pieces, <b>and they</b> went and <b>took three,</b> and in the end it was ascertained that the meat was consecrated, <b>they are all guilty of misusing consecrated property.</b>
<b>Granted, if you say</b> that the agent <b>is adding to the words</b> of the host, this <i>halakha</i> is understandable, because then, when the agent said to the guests: Take two pieces, he presented one of the pieces as the agent of the host. It is <b>due to that</b> reason that <b>the host is guilty of misusing consecrated property. However, if you say</b> that the agent <b>is disregarding the words</b> of the host, <b>why</b> is <b>the host guilty of misusing consecrated property? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 20a): If <b>an agent who performed his</b> assigned <b>agency</b> caused consecrated property to be misused, it is <b>the host</b> who appointed him who <b>is guilty of misusing consecrated property;</b> however, if the agent <b>did not perform his</b> assigned <b>agency,</b> and did not act in accordance with his instructions, it is <b>the agent</b> who <b>is guilty of the misuse</b> and not the employer?
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> This is a case <b>where</b> the agent <b>said</b> explicitly <b>to</b> the guests: <b>Take one</b> piece <b>with the consent of the host, and one</b> piece <b>with my consent, and they took three</b> pieces. Since every piece of meat was taken with the consent of someone else, they are all guilty of the misuse of consecrated property.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an understanding of the mishna: If <b>her marriage contract was</b> worth <b>one hundred dinars, and she sold</b> property <b>worth one hundred dinars and a dinar for one hundred dinars, the sale is void.</b>
The Gemara interprets the case of the mishna: <b>What, is it not that she sold</b> property <b>worth one hundred dinars and a dinar for one hundred dinars and a dinar,</b> and there was no error in the sale? <b>And what</b> does it mean when the mishna says that she sold the property <b>for one hundred dinars?</b> It means that she sold it in order to receive the <b>one hundred dinars</b> owed to <b>her</b> because of her marriage contract. <b>And what</b> does it mean when it says in the mishna: <b>Even</b> if she says: I will return the one extra dinar to the heirs, nevertheless the sale is voided? It means that <b>even if she says: I will return the dinar to the heirs by</b> giving them <b>a dinar’s</b> worth <b>from my land,</b> the heirs will not be losing anything at all. The Gemara concludes the proof: <b>And</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> that even so the <b>sale is void,</b> implying that not just what she added is void, but the entire sale is voided.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, said: No,</b> the correct understanding of the mishna is not that she sold the land for its proper price. Rather, the mishna is referring to a situation <b>where she reduced</b> its price and sold the property for less than its worth, and there was an error in the sale itself.

Daf 99a

The Gemara asks: <b>Since the last clause</b> of the mishna deals with a case <b>where she reduced</b> the price, it stands to reason that <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna <b>is</b> a case <b>where she did not reduce</b> the price. Why would the mishna repeat itself for no reason? <b>As it teaches</b> in <b>the last clause</b> of the mishna: If <b>her marriage contract was</b> worth <b>four hundred dinars</b> and <b>she sold</b> property <b>to this</b> one <b>for one hundred dinars, and</b> she sold property <b>to that</b> one <b>for one hundred dinars,</b> and again to a third one, <b>and</b> she sold property <b>to the last one worth one hundred dinars and a dinar for</b> only <b>one hundred dinars, the</b> sale <b>of the last</b> property <b>is void. And</b> as for <b>all of the others, their sale is valid</b> because they were sold for the correct price.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> both the <b>first and the last clauses</b> discuss cases <b>where she reduced</b> the price of the land and sold it for less than its worth. <b>And the last clause teaches us this: The reason</b> that the sale is void is that in that case, since she had already received full payment of her marriage contract, <b>she reduced</b> the price in a sale that she made <b>with</b> property <b>of the orphans</b> and at their expense. However, when she reduced the price of the land <b>in</b> the sale of <b>her own</b> property, as in the earlier clauses of the mishna, <b>her sale is valid.</b>
The Gemara asks: How can it be that this is what the last clause of the mishna is teaching? It can already be <b>concluded from the first clause</b> of the mishna, which states: In the case of <b>a widow whose marriage contract was</b> worth <b>two hundred</b> dinars <b>and she sold</b> property that was <b>worth one hundred dinars for two hundred</b> dinars, <b>or</b> if she sold property <b>worth two hundred</b> dinars <b>for one hundred dinars, she has received</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract</b> and can demand nothing more. This teaches that although she reduced the price of her own property by half, the sale is valid.
The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say: There,</b> in the first clause of the mishna, the sale is valid because through the sale <b>she has left this house entirely,</b> i.e., she no longer has anything to do with her husband’s estate, as her entire claim has been paid off; <b>however, here,</b> in the latter clause, <b>decree</b> that the <b>first</b> sale for <b>one hundred dinars</b> will be void <b>due to the last one hundred dinars.</b> If the first sale is allowed to take effect, this may lead to the error of the last sale taking effect as well. Therefore, the first sale should be void if she reduces the price. Lest you make this argument, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case.
The Gemara returns to the question asked earlier (98b): <b>And there are</b> those <b>who say: Don’t raise this dilemma</b> in a case <b>where</b> the employer <b>said to</b> his agent: <b>Go</b> and <b>sell</b> on <b>my</b> behalf <b>a half-<i>kor</i>, and</b> the agent <b>sold for him a <i>kor</i>, as he was certainly adding to the</b> employer’s <b>words,</b> and the sale of the first half-<i>kor</i> is valid.
<b>Where you</b> should <b>raise the dilemma</b> is a case in <b>which</b> the employer <b>said to</b> his agent: <b>Go sell</b> on <b>my</b> behalf <b>a <i>kor</i>, and he went and sold for him a half</b>-<b><i>kor</i>. What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in that case? <b>Do we say</b> that the agent can <b>say to</b> the employer: <b>I did what is good for you</b> by not selling everything, because you now have the opportunity to determine if you are truly in need of more money. If you decide that you do not need the money then you will not have to sell more property, <b>because if</b> you will realize that <b>you do not need the money</b> after the sale has been completed, <b>you will not be able to reverse</b> the sale. I therefore did you a favor by selling as little as I could.
<b>Or perhaps</b> the employer can <b>say to</b> the agent: I do not agree to this. <b>I am not amenable</b> to the fact <b>that</b> this <b>will increase the</b> number of <b>bills</b> of sale that <b>I</b> have because I will have to write a separate promissory note for each sale, and if I will have to go to court then I may earn a reputation as someone who has many mortgages.
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina of Sura said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the mishna for that which we learned about the <i>halakhot</i> of misusing consecrated property (<i>Me’ila</i> 21a): If <b>one gave</b> his agent <b>a gold dinar,</b> which is equal in value to twenty-five dinars or six <i>sela</i>, <b>and said to him: Get me a robe. And he went and brought him a robe that</b> cost <b>three</b> <i>sela</i>, <b>and a cloak that</b> also cost <b>three</b> <i>sela</i>, after which it was discovered that the original dinar was consecrated property, the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>both are guilty of misusing consecrated property.</b>
<b>Granted, if you say</b> that the <b>agent in a case like this</b> is considered to be <b>performing his</b> assigned <b>agency, and he was</b> merely <b>adding to the words</b> of the employer, it is <b>due to that</b> reason that <b>the homeowner is guilty of misusing consecrated property. However, if you say</b> that the agent is <b>disregarding the words</b> of the employer, as the employer intended for him to buy a robe with all six <i>sela</i>, <b>why</b> is the employer <b>guilty of misusing consecrated property?</b> In this instance, the agent did not fulfill his assignment.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where he brought him</b> a robe <b>worth six</b> <i>sela</i> that he had succeeded in buying <b>for</b> only <b>three</b> <i>sela</i>, so that the employer received exactly what he wanted. And the agent did not deviate from his intentions, he merely added to them because he also bought him a cloak.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> if the employee did exactly what the employer had asked him to do, then <b>why</b> is the <b>agent guilty of misusing consecrated property?</b> The Gemara answers: He is guilty of misusing consecrated property because he spent three <i>sela</i> of consecrated property to buy <b>the cloak,</b> which the employer never requested from him.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> then <b>say the last clause</b> of the mishna quoted by Rabbi Ḥanina of Sura (<i>Me’ila</i> 21b): <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even in this</b> case <b>the homeowner is not guilty of misusing consecrated property because he is able to say: I would have requested a large robe and you brought me a robe</b> that is <b>small and bad.</b> If the agent had brought him a robe worth six <i>sela</i> as requested, then this should not be a bad robe.
The Gemara answers: <b>What</b> is meant by <b>bad? It is bad</b> in its <b>monetary</b> value because the agent spent on the robe less than what the employer instructed him. That is why the agent is considered to have violated the wishes of his employer, as the employer can <b>say to him:</b> Since you chanced upon a merchant who reduced his prices to such a degree, <b>if you had brought me</b> a robe <b>for six</b> <i>sela</i> as I asked you, it would <b>all the more so</b> have <b>been worth twelve</b> <i>sela</i>, and it would have been a much finer robe.
The Gemara notes: The language of the mishna <b>is also precise</b> when understood in this way, <b>as it teaches: Rabbi Yehuda concedes</b> that <b>both are guilty of misusing consecrated property</b> in the following case: The agent purchased only part of what the employer requested <b>in</b> the case of <b>legumes,</b> which are sold for a set price under all circumstances,

Daf 99b

<b>As,</b> whether he bought <b>legumes for a <i>sela</i> or</b> whether he bought <b>legumes for a <i>peruta</i>,</b> the price would have been the same even if he bought in bulk. The Gemara concludes: <b>Learn from here</b> that this is the proper interpretation of the mishna.
The Gemara asks about the sale of legumes: <b>What are the circumstances</b> where the price stays the same even if one bought in bulk? <b>If we say</b> that it occurs <b>in a locale where they sell</b> legumes <b>by appraisal</b> of an article’s value, <b>then when he gives the merchant a <i>sela</i></b> as payment, the seller <b>reduces the price for him more</b> than if he had bought less. In such a place the buyer profits, and it is clear that even legumes do not have a fixed price.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It is referring to <b>a locale where one measures with vessels</b> and to a case where the merchant <b>said to him:</b> Fill each <b>vessel for a <i>peruta</i>.</b> The buyer then receives the product in accordance to how much he pays, and does not pay less if he buys in bulk.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the mishna: If <b>her marriage contract was</b> worth <b>four hundred dinars,</b> and <b>she sold</b> property <b>to this</b> one <b>for one hundred dinars, and</b> she sold property <b>to that</b> one <b>for one hundred dinars,</b> and again to a third one, <b>and</b> she sold property <b>to the last</b> one <b>worth one hundred dinars and a dinar for</b> only <b>one hundred dinars, the</b> sale <b>of the last</b> property <b>is void, and all of the others, their sale is valid,</b> as they were sold for the correct price. Here, the widow was appointed as an agent to sell property worth four hundred dinars, and she initially sold property worth only one hundred dinars, and nevertheless the sale is valid. The mishna does not say that she disregarded the orphan’s instructions and the sale is void.
The Gemara answers: <b>It is as Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said</b> in another context: This is stated <b>with regard to small</b> tracts of land that are geographically separated and do not form one land mass that can be sold as a single unit. <b>Here too,</b> the ruling of the mishna is stated <b>with regard to small</b> tracts of land that are not part of one larger field, and so this case is not proof that an agent who sells less than he was instructed to is considered to be adding to and not disregarding his employer’s instructions.
§ In continuation of the previous discussion, the Gemara raises another problem: <b>It is obvious</b> that if the employer <b>said to</b> his agent: Sell my property <b>to one</b> person, <b>but not to two,</b> and the agent sold the property to two people, since <b>he said to him: To one, but not to two,</b> it is certain that the agent has disregarded his instructions and is no longer considered an agent. However, if the employer <b>said to</b> the agent: Sell <b>to one</b> person, <b>without specifying</b> that he should not sell to two people, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if the agent did sell the property to two people?
<b>Rav Huna said:</b> The employer meant to sell <b>to one</b> person and <b>not to two</b> people. It is <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rabba, son of Rav Huna, who both say:</b> He meant <b>to one</b> person <b>and even to two</b> people. When he said <b>to one</b> person, he meant <b>and even to one hundred</b> people, as he did not mean one person specifically.
<b>Rav Naḥman happened</b> to come <b>to Sura. Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna entered before him. They said to him: In a case like this</b> one, which was discussed above in the Gemara, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>He said to them:</b> When he said <b>to one</b> person, he meant <b>and even to two</b> people. When he said <b>to one</b> person, he meant <b>and even to one hundred</b> people.
Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna <b>said to him:</b> Is <b>the agent</b> considered to be performing his assigned agency <b>even though he erred,</b> e.g., by selling property for less than its value? Rav Naḥman <b>said to them: I do not say</b> so in a case <b>where the agent erred. They said to him: But didn’t the Master say</b> that <b>there is no</b> prohibition against <b>fraud</b> in the sale <b>of land,</b> and land does not have a set value?
He replied to them: <b>This applies only where the homeowner erred,</b> e.g., where he sold land for less than its market value. In that case, he cannot claim that the sale is invalid because of fraud. <b>However,</b> in a case where <b>the agent erred,</b> the homeowner can <b>say to</b> the agent: <b>I sent you to</b> act for <b>my benefit and not to my detriment,</b> and his appointment as an agent is nullified.
The Gemara explains: <b>And from where do you say that</b> there is <b>a</b> legal <b>difference between</b> an error made by <b>an agent and</b> an error made by <b>a homeowner?</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 4:4): In the case of <b>one who says to his agent: Go out and separate</b> the portion of the produce designated for the priest [<i>teruma</i>], the agent <b>separates</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>in accordance with the mind-set of the homeowner.</b> He must separate the amount that he assumes the owner would want to give, as there is no fixed fraction for the amount that one must set aside as <i>teruma</i>. A generous person would give as much as a fortieth of the produce as <i>teruma</i>, while a stingy person would give a sixtieth. <b>And if he does not know the mind-set of</b> the <b>homeowner, he separates an intermediate</b> measure, i.e., <b>one-fiftieth</b> of the produce. If <b>he subtracted ten</b> from the denominator and separated one-fortieth, <b>or added ten</b> to the denominator and separated one-sixtieth of the produce, <b>his <i>teruma</i></b> is considered <b><i>teruma</i>.</b>
<b>Whereas with regard to the homeowner</b> himself <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he separated</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>and even one-twentieth</b> of the produce <b>came up in his hand, his donation</b> is effective and is considered <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> The agent may deviate from the intention of the homeowner only within certain parameters. If he misunderstood the homeowner’s wishes and separated an unusually large percentage of the produce, his action accomplished nothing. The same action, however, when performed by the homeowner, is effective; if the homeowner himself mistakenly separated an unusually large percentage of his produce, it becomes <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara returns to discuss whether a person is particular about having too many documents with his name on them. The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the mishna: If <b>her marriage contract was</b> worth <b>four hundred dinars,</b> and <b>she sold</b> property <b>to this</b> one <b>for one hundred dinars, and</b> she sold property <b>to that</b> one <b>for one hundred dinars,</b> and again to a third one, <b>and</b> she sold property <b>to the last one worth one hundred dinars and a dinar for</b> only <b>one hundred dinars, the</b> sale <b>of the last</b> property <b>is void, and all of the others, their sale is valid,</b> as they were sold for the correct price. She should have sold the land to one individual and not increased the number of documents bearing guarantees for the orphans to worry about. Still, if she did sell to several people, the sales are all valid.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said:</b> This is stated <b>with regard to small</b> tracts of land that are geographically separated and do not form one land mass that can be sold as a single unit.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the assessment of the judges</b> of the value of a piece of property in order to sell it is as follows: <b>Where they decreased</b> the price by <b>one-sixth</b> of its market value <b>or added one-sixth</b> to its market value, <b>their sale is void.</b>
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Their sale is valid. If</b> it were <b>so</b> that the sale is void, then <b>what advantage</b> is there to <b>the power of the court</b> over an ordinary person? <b>However, if they made a document of inspection,</b> i.e., an announcement that people should come to inspect the field and bid on the property, then <b>even if they sold</b> property <b>worth one hundred dinars for two hundred</b> dinars, <b>or</b> sold property <b>worth two hundred</b> dinars <b>for one hundred dinars, their sale is valid,</b> as the transaction was agreed upon and done publicly.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>An agent</b> who mistakenly sold land for less than its value is <b>like whom?</b> Is he comparable to a judge, whose sale is effective if he did not err by more than one-sixth of the market price, or is he comparable to a widow, whose sale is void if she sold for anything less than the market price?

Daf 100a

<b>Rava said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman</b> said: The <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>agent</b> is <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to the <b>judges. Rav Shmuel bar Bisna</b> said that <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> with regard to the agent is <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a widow.</b>
<b>Rava said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman</b> said: The <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>agent</b> is <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>judges. Just as the judges</b> have an advantage because they <b>do not</b> assess the value of property <b>for their</b> own benefit, <b>so too, the agent also does not</b> act <b>for his</b> own benefit; this is <b>to the exclusion of a widow</b> who sells <b>for her own</b> benefit.
<b>Rav Shmuel, son of Bisna,</b> said that <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> with regard to the agent is <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a widow. Just as a widow</b> is <b>an individual, so too the agent</b> is <b>an individual.</b> This is <b>to the exclusion of the court, which is</b> composed of <b>many</b> people. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is</b> that with regard to this matter, <b>an agent is like a widow.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> that case <b>different from this</b> case? <b>As we learned in a mishna</b> (<i>Terumot</i> 4:4): In the case of <b>one who says to his agent: Go out and separate</b> <i>teruma</i>, the agent <b>separates</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>in accordance with the mind-set of the homeowner. And if he does not know the mind-set of homeowner, he separates an intermediate</b> measure, i.e., <b>one-fiftieth</b> of the produce. If <b>he subtracted ten</b> from the denominator and separated one-fortieth <b>or added ten</b> to the denominator and separated one-sixtieth of the produce, <b>his <i>teruma</i></b> is considered <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> If the agent is comparable to a widow, then why isn’t the <i>halakha</i> that the <i>teruma</i> that he has separated is nullified, since he did not act in accordance with the wishes of the homeowner?
The Gemara answers: <b>There, since there are</b> those <b>who separate in a miserly fashion</b> one-sixtieth, <b>and there are</b> those <b>who separate generously</b> one-fortieth, the agent can <b>say to</b> his employer: <b>I estimated you</b> to be generous or miserly. <b>However, here</b> there is no logical reason for the mistake made by the agent. <b>It is</b> simply <b>an error</b> on the part of the agent, and so the owner can <b>say to him: You ought not to have erred.</b>
§ <b>Rav Huna bar Ḥanina said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the statement of</b> the <b>Rabbis</b> in the mishna. The Gemara asks: <b>Does Rav Naḥman not</b> agree with the argument: <b>What</b> advantage is there to <b>the power of the court? Didn’t Rav Naḥman say</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> In a case of <b>orphans who came to divide their father’s property, the court appoints a steward [<i>apotropos</i>] for them and selects for</b> the orphans <b>appropriate portions</b> and divides the property accordingly. Afterward, once the orphans have <b>matured, they are able to protest</b> this division of the property. <b>And Rav Naḥman said his own</b> statement: Once the orphans have <b>matured, they are not able to protest, as if</b> they were able to do <b>so, what advantage</b> would there be to <b>the power of the court?</b> This proves that Rav Naḥman agrees with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult.</b> The case of the mishna was one <b>where</b> the judges <b>erred</b> in their assessment, and therefore Rav Naḥman said that the sale is void in accordance with the Rabbis. However, the case of the division of property among the orphans is one <b>where they did not err,</b> and so he ruled in accordance with the principle of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, that the court is given an advantage and the orphans are not able to protest the division.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the case is one <b>where</b> the judges <b>did not err,</b> with regard <b>to what could</b> the orphans <b>protest?</b> After all, the judges acted correctly. The Gemara answers: They can protest <b>with regard to</b> the <b>locations;</b> one of the orphans can contend that he prefers property in a different location than he was given.
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael, <b>he said:</b> A similar <b>incident</b> occurred <b>and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>acted in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis</b> of the mishna. <b>Perata, son of Rabbi Elazar ben Perata, grandson of Rabbi Perata the Great, said before him: If</b> that is the case, <b>what advantage</b> is there to <b>the power of the court</b> over an ordinary person? <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>reversed</b> his ruling about <b>the incident.</b>
<b>Rav Dimi</b> would <b>teach</b> the incident in <b>this</b> way, as described above. <b>Rav Safra</b> would <b>teach</b> it in <b>this</b> slightly altered way: There was <b>an incident, and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>wished to act in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis</b> of the mishna. <b>Perata, son of Rabbi Elazar ben Perata, grandson of Rabbi Perata the Great, said before him: If</b> that is the case, <b>what advantage</b> is there to the <b>power of the court</b> over an ordinary person? Consequently, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>did not take action</b> according to the statement of the Rabbis.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that they disagree about this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rav Dimi, <b>holds</b> that if one <b>erred in a matter</b> that appears in the <b>Mishna,</b> the decision is <b>revoked. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav Safra, <b>holds</b> that if one erred in this manner the decision <b>is not revoked.</b> This is why, in Rav Safra’s version, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi changed his mind before issuing his ruling.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No, everyone</b> agrees that if one <b>erred in a matter</b> that appears in the <b>Mishna,</b> the decision <b>is revoked.</b> There is no fundamental dispute between them, only a disagreement as to the details of the case. One <b>Sage holds</b> that the <b>incident</b> occurred <b>in this</b> way, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage holds</b> that the <b>incident</b> occurred <b>in this</b> way.
§ <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> In the case of <b>a widow who sold</b> property to support herself or as payment of her marriage contract, the property <b>guarantee</b> rests <b>upon the orphans.</b> Therefore, if she sold liened property that was then seized from the purchasers in payment of a previous debt, the buyers are entitled to be reimbursed from the property of the orphans. <b>And</b> so too, if the <b>court sold</b> property for the same purpose, the property <b>guarantee</b> rests <b>upon the orphans.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> this <b>obvious?</b> The widow does not sell her own property, but rather she sells property from her husband’s estate to pay off his debts to her, and so clearly the guarantee rests on his properties that now belong to the orphans.
The Gemara answers: In truth, <b>it was not necessary</b> for Rav Yosef to mention this with regard to the <b>widow,</b> as it is clear that the property guarantee rests upon the orphans. <b>Where</b> it <b>was necessary for</b> him to mention this <i>halakha</i> was with regard to the <b>court. Lest you say:</b>

Daf 100b

<b>Everyone who buys from the court buys with</b> the implicit <b>understanding that</b> the sale <b>generates publicity,</b> as a court sale is conducted in public with notices. The buyer could therefore think to himself that if no claimants came forward until the time of the actual purchase, then it is certain that there can be no problem with his purchase and he forgoes his property guarantee. Lest you say this, Rav Yosef <b>teaches us</b> that there is nevertheless a guarantee on the property, and it rests upon the orphans and not on the court.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says</b> that even if the judges err, the transaction is not void because of the prerogative of the court. The Gemara asks: <b>And to what</b> extent can they err without causing the deal to be reversed? <b>Rav Huna bar Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet said: Until half</b> of the value.
<b>That is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: A court that sold</b> property <b>worth one hundred dinars for two hundred</b> dinars, <b>or</b> property <b>worth two hundred</b> dinars <b>for one hundred dinars, their sale is valid.</b> Since he doesn’t give as an example a larger gap between the market value and the sale price, this must be the most extreme case in which the transaction is not reversed.
<b>Ameimar said in the name of Rav Yosef:</b> With regard to <b>a court that sold without an announcement,</b> it <b>is considered as</b> if <b>they erred in a matter</b> that appears in the <b>Mishna and</b> their decision is <b>reversed.</b>
The Gemara asks: Why does Rav Yosef say that it <b>is considered as</b> if the court erred in a matter that appears in the Mishna, when <b>it certainly erred</b> in this manner? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Arakhin</i> 21b): The <b>assessment</b> of <b>the orphans</b> is for <b>thirty days, and the assessment</b> for <b>consecrated property</b> is for <b>sixty days, and they make announcements</b> during the thirty and the sixty days respectively both <b>in the morning and in the evening.</b> The mishna states explicitly that announcements must be made. If the court did not make the announcements, it clearly erred in a matter that appears in the Mishna.
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> all the information that I had were <b>from that</b> mishna, <b>I would say</b> that <b>this applies</b> to <b>an agent but not to a court.</b> Therefore, Rav Yosef <b>teaches us</b> that even a court that sold property without making announcements has erred.
<b>Rav Ashi raised an objection to</b> the statement of <b>Ameimar:</b> The mishna teaches that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the assessment</b> of the value of a piece of property in order to sell it through <b>the judges</b> is as follows: In a case <b>where they decreased</b> the price by <b>one-sixth</b> of its market value <b>or added one-sixth</b> to its market value, <b>their sale is void.</b> One can see from here that if the judges sold the property <b>for its value, their sale is valid. What, is</b> the mishna <b>not</b> discussing a case where <b>no announcement was made?</b> Ameimar replied: <b>No,</b> the case under discussion is one <b>where they did make an announcement.</b>
The Gemara asks: Since <b>the last clause is</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> the court <b>made an announcement, the first clause</b> must be referring to a case <b>where they did not make announcements, as it teaches in the final clause: If they made a document of inspection</b> and announced the sale publicly, then <b>even if they sold</b> property <b>worth one hundred dinars for two hundred</b> dinars <b>or</b> property <b>worth two hundred</b> dinars <b>for one hundred dinars, their sale is valid.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> this should be understood differently. <b>Actually,</b> the first clause of the mishna is referring to a case <b>where they did not make an announcement, and</b> this is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> Ameimar is referring <b>to items for which one makes an announcement,</b> and if this was not done then the sale is void. <b>There,</b> the mishna is speaking of <b>items for which one does not make announcements.</b>
<b>And these are</b> the <b>items for which one does not make an announcement: Slaves, movable property, and contracts.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>slaves</b> are sold without an announcement? Slaves are sold without an announcement <b>lest they hear</b> that they are about to be sold <b>and escape.</b> Why is the sale of <b>movable property and contracts</b> also not announced? <b>Lest they be stolen.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>here</b> Ameimar is referring to <b>a time when one makes an announcement,</b> while <b>there</b> the mishna is referring to <b>a time when one does not make an announcement.</b>
When does one not make an announcement? <b>As</b> the Sages <b>of Neharde’a say: For</b> the purpose of paying <b>head tax,</b> and <b>for</b> payment to provide for children’s <b>sustenance, and for burial,</b> the court <b>sells</b> property inherited by orphans <b>without an announcement</b> because these are pressing needs. There is no time to wait for an announcement.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>here,</b> Ameimar is referring to <b>a locale where one makes an announcement,</b> while <b>there,</b> the mishna is referring to <b>a locale where one does not make an announcement, as Rav Naḥman said: They never made a document of inspection in Neharde’a.</b>
Some of the students <b>understood from</b> Rav Naḥman’s statement that no announcements were made in Neharde’a <b>because</b> the Sages there were all <b>expert in the appraisal</b> of an article’s value. <b>Rav Yosef bar Minyumi said to them:</b> This <b>was explained to me</b> personally <b>by Rav Naḥman himself:</b> It was <b>because</b> those who purchase the property <b>are called: People</b> who <b>consume property that was publicly announced.</b> This disparaging nickname was given because the purchasers were perceived as taking advantage of the distress of others by running to buy the property of someone in trouble. Since decent, honest people did not wish to buy property whose sale had been announced, they stopped making announcements.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Movable property that belongs to orphans is appraised and sold immediately</b> so that it not deteriorate over time. <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> said that <b>Avimi said:</b> The movable property <b>is sold on a market</b> day, when there are many potential buyers and the items will sell for a proper price.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> they do <b>not disagree</b> with each other. Rather, <b>this</b> opinion, that the items are sold on a market day, applies <b>when</b> the <b>market</b> day <b>is approaching,</b> so the property is not sold immediately. <b>That</b> opinion, that the items are sold immediately, applies <b>when</b> the <b>market</b> day <b>is far off.</b>
<b>Rav Kahana was in possession of beer</b> that belonged <b>to Rav Mesharshiyya bar Ḥilkai,</b> who was <b>an orphan. He delayed</b> selling <b>it until the Festival.</b> He explained the rationale for his actions and <b>said: Although</b> it is possible <b>that it may deteriorate [<i>itzatzta</i>]</b> and sour a little, <b>it</b> nevertheless <b>brings</b> in <b>money</b> at the time of the Festival, as it will sell for a higher price and for money, not credit. Consequently, it is in the best interests of Rav Mesharshiyya bar Ḥilkai to hold off and sell the beer at the next Festival.
It is also related that <b>Ravina was in possession of wine</b> belonging <b>to</b> the <b>orphan Ravina the younger,</b> who <b>was his sister’s son. He also had wine of his own,</b> which <b>he was taking to Sikhra</b> to sell.
<b>He came before Rav Ashi</b> and <b>said to him: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> here, am <b>I</b> able <b>to bring</b> his wine along <b>with</b> my wine, or must I wait for a more opportune time to sell it? <b>He said to him: Go</b> to Sikhra and take his wine along as well, as his <b>is no better than yours,</b> and if you sell your own wine in this manner, it is clear that you think this is the best way to sell, and it is permitted for you to sell his wine in this manner.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> An orphan girl who was married off by her mother or brother before reaching the age of majority may refuse to continue living with her husband upon reaching the age of majority, thereby retroactively annulling their marriage. In the case of <b>one who refuses</b> to continue living with her husband in this manner; and in the case of a woman who is <b>a secondary</b> forbidden <b>relative</b> by rabbinic law; <b>and</b> in the case of <b>a sexually underdeveloped woman [<i>ailonit</i>],</b> who is incapable of bearing children, each of these women <b>is not entitled to</b> payment of <b>a marriage contract; and</b> they are <b>not</b> entitled to remuneration for the <b>produce</b> that the husband consumed; <b>and</b> they are <b>not</b> entitled to <b>sustenance; and</b> they are <b>not</b> entitled to their <b>worn clothes</b> that were brought in to the marriage as part of their dowry and became worn out during the marriage.
<b>If, from the start, he married her with the understanding</b> that she is <b>an <i>ailonit</i>,</b> then <b>she is entitled to</b> payment of <b>a marriage contract.</b>
In the case of <b>a widow</b> who married <b>a High Priest;</b> or <b>a divorcée or a <i>yevama</i> who performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> and later married <b>a common priest;</b> or <b>a daughter born from an incestuous or adulterous relationship [<i>mamzeret</i>]</b> who married an Israelite; <b>or a Gibeonite woman</b> who married <b>an Israelite;</b> or <b>a Jewish woman</b> who married <b>a Gibeonite or a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> although each of these unions is prohibited by Torah law, the woman is still <b>entitled to</b> payment of <b>a marriage contract.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav taught</b> that <b>a minor girl</b> who was married off by her mother or by her brother and who <b>is divorced with a bill of divorce is not entitled to</b> her <b>marriage contract.</b> According to Torah law, this marriage never took effect, and it was never established that in this situation she would receive a marriage contract. <b>And all the more so, one who refuses</b> to continue living with her husband and annuls the marriage herself is not entitled to payment of a marriage contract.
<b>Shmuel taught</b> that <b>one who refuses</b> to continue living with her husband <b>is not entitled to</b> her <b>marriage contract, but one who is divorced with a bill of divorce is entitled to</b> her <b>marriage contract.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And Shmuel follows</b> his line of <b>reasoning, as Shmuel said: One who refuses</b> to continue living with her husband <b>is not entitled to</b> her <b>marriage contract,</b> but <b>one who is divorced with a bill of divorce is entitled to</b> her <b>marriage contract.</b>
Shmuel also said: <b>One who refuses</b> to continue living with her husband is <b>not disqualified from</b> marrying one of <b>the brothers</b> of her husband. Her refusal annuls the marriage, and it is as if it never happened. <b>And</b> for the same reason, unlike a divorcée, this girl <b>is not disqualified from</b> marrying a member of <b>the priesthood.</b> However, <b>one who is divorced with a bill of divorce</b> is <b>disqualified from</b> marrying one of <b>the brothers and</b> is also <b>disqualified from</b> marrying a member of <b>the priesthood.</b>
Another difference between a woman who refuses to continue living with her husband and a woman who was divorced normally is the following: <b>One who refuses</b> to continue living with her husband <b>does not need to wait three months</b> before remarrying, as other women who separate from their husbands must.

Daf 101a

<b>One who leaves</b> the marriage union <b>through a bill of divorce is required to wait three months</b> before remarrying.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Shmuel <b>teaching us</b> by telling us all of this? <b>We</b> already <b>learned it all</b> in <i>Yevamot</i> (108a): In the case of <b>one who refuses</b> to continue living <b>with</b> a certain <b>man, he is permitted to her relatives and she is permitted to his relatives, and she is not disqualified from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood.</b> If <b>he gave her a bill of divorce,</b> then <b>he is forbidden to her relatives and she is forbidden to his relatives, and she is disqualified from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary for him</b> to mention that if she receives a bill of divorce, <b>she is required to wait three months</b> before remarrying, <b>as we did not learn</b> that <i>halakha</i> in the mishna. Once Shmuel mentioned the difference between one who refuses to continue living with her husband and one who is divorced, he mentioned the other differences between the two cases.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this dispute between Rav and Shmuel is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <i>tanna’im</i>, as the <i>baraita</i> teaches: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The act of</b> marriage by <b>a minor girl is nothing,</b> i.e., has no legal impact, when she is married off not by her father, <b>and her husband is not entitled to</b> any lost <b>article that she finds, and not to her earnings; and</b> he is <b>not</b> able <b>to annul her vows; and he does not inherit</b> from <b>her; nor does he become impure for her</b> if he is a priest. The <b>principle is</b> that her legal status is <b>not that of his wife in every sense, only that she requires a refusal</b> in order to leave the marriage.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: The act of</b> marriage by <b>a minor girl is something,</b> i.e., has legal impact, <b>and her husband is entitled to</b> any lost <b>article that she finds and to her earnings; and</b> he is able <b>to annul her vows; and he inherits</b> from <b>her; and he becomes impure</b> for <b>her,</b> even if he is a priest. The <b>principle is that</b> her legal status is <b>that of his wife in every sense, except</b> for the fact <b>that she leaves</b> this union <b>through refusal</b> and does not need a bill of divorce.
<b>Shall we say that Rav said</b> that she does not receive payment of her marriage contract <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who holds that her marriage did not take effect, <b>and that Shmuel said</b> that she does receive payment of her marriage contract <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who holds that her marriage did take effect?
The Gemara rejects this: <b>According to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer, everyone agrees</b> that a minor girl’s marriage has no legal standing and, as Rav said, she is not entitled to payment of her marriage contract.
<b>When they disagree,</b> they disagree <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua. Shmuel</b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the literal opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua. And Rav</b> says that when <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said there</b> that a minor girl has a legal status of his wife in every sense, it was <b>only</b> with regard <b>to her</b> obligations <b>toward him. But</b> with regard <b>to his</b> obligations <b>toward her,</b> since according to Torah law they are not married, the Sages could <b>not</b> obligate the husband to pay her anything.
§ The mishna teaches that a girl who refuses to continue living with her husband, a woman who is forbidden by rabbinic law as a secondary relative, and an <i>ailonit</i> are not entitled to payment of a marriage contract <b>and</b> are <b>not</b> entitled to their <b>worn clothes. Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya said to Rav Kahana: You told us in the name of Shmuel: They taught</b> that she is not entitled to her worn clothes <b>only</b> with regard to the worn-out items of <b>usufruct property [<i>nikhsei melog</i>], but she does have</b> rights to the worn-out items of her <b>guaranteed property [<i>tzon barzel</i>].</b>
<b>Rav Pappa discussed it</b> and wondered: <b>To which</b> part of the mishna is this referring? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring <b>to one who refuses</b> to continue living with her husband, then <b>if</b> the worn-out articles <b>are still</b> in existence, <b>she takes both</b> the usufruct and the guaranteed properties. Since the marriage is annulled, she takes whatever belongs to her. <b>And if they are no longer</b> in existence and were completely worn out over the course of time, <b>then she does not take</b> compensation for <b>either</b> of them, as the husband was within his rights to make use of them.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that Shmuel’s statement is in reference <b>to an <i>ailonit</i>.</b> This too is difficult as, in that case, <b>if</b> the articles <b>are still</b> in existence <b>she takes both</b> the usufruct and the guaranteed properties. <b>If they are no longer</b> in existence, then Shmuel <b>should have</b> stated the <b>opposite</b> and said: With regard to the <b>usufruct property, which remains in her possession</b> during the marriage, <b>she does</b> receive compensation for it in the event that the marriage is annulled. However, <b>she does not</b> receive compensation for <b>the guaranteed property, which does not remain in her possession</b> during the marriage but in the possession of her husband.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that Shmuel’s statement is in reference <b>to a secondary</b> forbidden <b>relative, and</b> the rationale for this <i>halakha</i> is that the <b>Sages penalized</b> both the husband and the wife for violating a rabbinic prohibition. The Sages assigned a penalty <b>to her with regard to his</b> obligations to her, and she is not reimbursed for the worn-out usufruct property. <b>And</b> they assigned a penalty <b>to him with regard to her</b> obligations to him so that he is responsible for reimbursing her for the worn-out guaranteed property.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: Conclude from</b> the statement <b>of Rav Kahana</b> that <b>if</b> a wife <b>brought</b> home <b>to</b> her husband <b>a cloak</b> after they were already married, <b>it is</b> viewed as <b>capital, and he may not go and cover himself with it until it wears out.</b> With regard to land that the wife obtains during the marriage, the husband has the right to benefit from it by consuming its produce. From the fact that Rav Kahana stated that it is only in this particular case that the woman is not reimbursed for clothing that became worn out through her husband’s use, one can infer that generally, the husband does not have the right to use a garment she obtains, to the degree that it becomes worn out.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rav Naḥman say</b> that use of the cloak <b>is</b> considered <b>the produce</b> of her property, to which the husband is entitled? The Gemara answers: The statement <b>of Rav Naḥman</b> is in <b>disagreement</b> with that opinion.
§ The mishna teaches that these specific women <b>are not entitled to</b> payment of <b>a marriage contract. Shmuel said: They taught this only</b> with regard to the principal of the marriage contract, which the Sages instituted for all women, amounting to <b>one hundred dinars</b> for a widow and <b>two hundred</b> dinars for a virgin. <b>However,</b> the <b>additional</b> sum listed in the marriage contract, which their husband specified for them of his own accord, is considered a gift and <b>they are entitled to</b> it.
The Gemara notes: <b>That is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Women</b> with regard to <b>whom the Sages said: They are not entitled to</b> payment of <b>a marriage contract, for example, one who refused</b> to remain married to her husband, <b>and her companions, they are not entitled</b> to the principal of <b>one hundred dinars</b> or <b>two hundred</b> dinars. <b>But</b> as for the <b>additional</b> sum stipulated in the marriage contract that the husband added of his own accord, <b>they are entitled to</b> it.
However, <b>women</b> with regard to <b>whom the Sages said: They are divorced without</b> receiving payment for their <b>marriage contract, for example, a woman who violates</b> the <b>precepts</b> of <i>halakha</i> or Jewish custom, <b>and her companions, are not entitled to the additional</b> sum stipulated by their husbands in the marriage contract. <b>And</b> since they violated and transgressed the mitzvot, it is <b>all the more so</b> that they are not entitled to receive the principal <b>one hundred dinars</b> or <b>two hundred</b> dinars, as the Sages penalized them and negated all of their husband’s obligations that are recorded in the marriage contract. <b>And one who is divorced because</b> she received <b>a bad reputation</b> for licentiousness <b>takes what is left</b> of her usufruct property <b>and is divorced.</b>
The Gemara notes: This <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Huna, as Rav Huna said:</b> A woman who <b>was licentious has not lost</b>

Daf 101b

her right to <b>her worn clothes</b> that are in <b>existence.</b> She retains possession of her clothes and all of the other items that she brought with her to the marriage that have not been worn out.
<b>The <i>tanna</i> teaches</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Naḥman:</b> A woman who <b>was licentious lost</b> her right to <b>her extant, worn clothes,</b> i.e., when they divorce, she does not keep her clothing. <b>He said to him: If she</b> was unfaithful and <b>engaged in sexual intercourse</b> with another, <b>were her items</b> also <b>licentious?</b> Certainly she is not penalized by losing her right to her property, and therefore <b>teach</b> the opposite: A woman who was licentious <b>has not lost</b> her right to <b>her extant worn clothes.</b>
Similarly, <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: This</b> <i>baraita</i> taught by the <i>tanna</i> <b>is the statement of Rabbi Menaḥem, the unattributed,</b> as his opinion is cited in several places as the unattributed mishna. <b>However, the Rabbis say</b> that if <b>she was licentious, she has not lost</b> her right to <b>her extant worn clothes.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>if, from the start, he married</b> her with the understanding that she is an <i>ailonit</i>, she is entitled to payment of her marriage contract. <b>Rav Huna said: An <i>ailonit</i></b> is <b>a wife and she is not a wife,</b> while <b>a widow</b> who is married to a High Priest is <b>entirely a wife.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>An <i>ailonit</i></b> is sometimes treated as <b>a wife and she</b> is sometimes <b>not</b> treated as <b>a wife.</b> How so? If <b>he knew about her</b> that she was an <i>ailonit</i> before marrying her, <b>she is entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract</b> like any other wife. But if <b>he did not know about her</b> that she was an <i>ailonit</i> before marrying her, <b>she is not entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract. A widow</b> is <b>entirely</b> considered <b>a wife. Whether he knew about her</b> that she was a widow before marrying her <b>whether he did not know</b> this <b>about her, she is entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract.</b>
<b>And Rav Yehuda says: Both the</b> <i>ailonit</i> and <b>the</b> widow are sometimes treated as <b>a wife and</b> sometimes <b>not</b> treated as <b>a wife.</b> Even in the case of a widow who marries a High Priest, if <b>he knew about her</b> that she was a widow before marrying her, <b>she is entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract.</b> But if <b>he did not know about her</b> that she was a widow, <b>she is not entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract.</b>
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> to Rav Huna’s statement from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he married</b> the woman <b>with the presumption that she is so,</b> that she has some deficiency or that she is forbidden to him, <b>and it is found that she is so</b> as he thought from the start, then <b>she is entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract.</b> One can infer from here: If he married her <b>without specification,</b> and it turns out that she has a deficiency or that she is forbidden to him, <b>she is not entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Do not say</b> this implies <b>that</b> if he married her <b>without specification she is not entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract. Rather, say</b> the following inference: If <b>he married her with the presumption that she is not so and it is found that she is so, she is not entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if he married her <b>without specification, what</b> would the <i>halakha</i> be? The <i>halakha</i> would be that <b>she is entitled</b> to payment of her marriage contract. If that is the case, instead <b>of teaching</b> the case where he married her <b>with the presumption that she is so and she is found to be so</b> and <b>she is entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract, let him teach us</b> the case where he marries her <b>without specification.</b> If in a case where he marries her without specification she is entitled to payment of her marriage contract, then <b>all the more so</b> in <b>this</b> case, where he marries her knowingly, she must be entitled to it.
<b>And further,</b> it <b>is taught</b> explicitly in another <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he married her knowing</b> that she has a deficiency, <b>and it is found</b> that she does have the deficiency <b>as was known, she is entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract.</b> If he married her <b>without specification, she is not entitled to</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract.</b> This is <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>Rav Huna was misled by</b> the language of <b>the mishna</b> and made an inference that caused him to say something that is not in keeping with the <i>halakha</i>. <b>He thought that since</b> the mishna <b>differentiates</b> between a case where the husband was aware of her situation and a case where he was not aware <b>with</b> regard to <b>an <i>ailonit</i>, but</b> the mishna <b>does not differentiate with</b> regard to <b>a widow, by inference</b> one can say <b>that</b> with regard to <b>a widow, even where</b> one merely marries her without knowing that she is a widow, <b>she is entitled</b> to payment of her marriage contract. In truth, however, <b>that is not so. When</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>of the widow, it</b> is based <b>on the differentiation</b> stated <b>with</b> regard to <b>the <i>ailonit</i>.</b> The mishna intended for the distinction between whether the husband was aware of her situation before the marriage, which was stated in the case of an <i>ailonit</i>, to apply in the case of the widow as well.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who marries a woman, and she stipulated with him that he would sustain her daughter</b> from another man for <b>five years, is obligated to sustain her</b> daughter for <b>five years.</b>
If, in the course of those five years they were divorced and the woman <b>was married to another</b> man, <b>and she stipulated with him that he would sustain her daughter</b> for <b>five years, he</b> too <b>is obligated to sustain her</b> for <b>five years. The first</b> husband <b>may not say: When she comes to me, I will sustain her. Rather, he brings her sustenance to her, to the place where her mother</b> lives.
<b>And likewise, both of them may not</b> jointly <b>say: We will sustain</b> the girl <b>as one</b> in a partnership. <b>Rather, one sustains her,</b> providing her with food, while <b>the other gives her the monetary</b> value <b>of the sustenance.</b>
If the daughter <b>was married</b> during this period, her <b>husband provides her</b> with the <b>sustenance</b> customarily provided by a husband for his wife, <b>and</b> the two men obligated to sustain her due to agreements with her mother <b>provide her with the monetary value of the sustenance.</b> If the two husbands of the mother <b>died, their daughters are sustained from unsold property, and she,</b> their wife’s daughter, whom they agreed to sustain, <b>is sustained</b> even <b>from liened property</b> that was sold. This is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that her</b> legal status is <b>like</b> that of <b>a creditor,</b> given that he is contractually obligated to support her.
<b>The perspicacious</b> ones <b>would write</b> an explicit stipulation into the agreement: I agree <b>on the condition that I will sustain your daughter for five years</b> only <b>as long as you are with me.</b> Then they would not be obligated to sustain a girl who is not their daughter when they are no longer married to the girl’s mother.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was stated</b> with regard to <b>one who says to another: I am obligated to</b> pay <b>you one hundred dinars,</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> He is <b>obligated</b> to pay, <b>and Reish Lakish said:</b> He is <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara seeks to clarify: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If he said to</b> the people present: <b>You are my witnesses, what is the reasoning of Reish Lakish, who exempts</b> him from payment? He confessed before witnesses that he owes the money. <b>If he did not say to them: You are my witnesses, what is the reasoning of Rabbi Yoḥanan, who obligates</b> him to pay?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> it is a case <b>where he did not say to</b> those present: <b>You are my witnesses.</b> However, <b>here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where he said to</b> the other: <b>I am obligated to</b> give <b>you one hundred dinars,</b> and he did so <b>in a contract,</b> i.e., he gave him an unsigned contract in which he stated that he is obligated to give him one hundred dinars. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: He is obligated</b> to pay, since his <b>word</b> given through <b>a contract is</b> legally <b>as authoritative as one who said to</b> the bystanders: <b>You are my witnesses. Reish Lakish said: He is exempt</b> from payment, because his <b>word</b> given through <b>a contract is</b> legally <b>not</b> sufficiently <b>authoritative</b> to be considered a bona fide admission.
The Gemara presents a challenge to the opinion of Reish Lakish. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>One who marries a woman, and she stipulated with him</b> that he is obligated <b>to sustain her daughter</b> for <b>five years, is obligated to sustain her</b> for <b>five years. What, is it not</b> that the mishna is discussing <b>a case like this,</b> where he gave her a contract that lacks proper signatures and it is nevertheless legally binding, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan? If you say otherwise, where is the novelty in the teaching of the mishna?

Daf 102a

The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>of documents of stipulation</b> that record the amounts that parents agree to provide to their son or daughter, <b>and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Giddel.</b>
<b>As Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> When two families negotiate the terms of marriage for their respective children, one side says to the other: <b>How much do you give your son?</b> And the second side answers: <b>Such and such</b> amount. <b>How much do you give your daughter?</b> And the first side responds: <b>Such and such</b> amount. Then, if the son and daughter <b>arose and performed the betrothal,</b> all of these obligations are <b>acquired</b> and therefore binding. <b>These are</b> among <b>the things that are acquired through words</b> alone, without the need for an additional act of acquisition. The mishna is referring to a document that records such an agreement.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another challenge to the opinion of Reish Lakish, based upon the following mishna (<i>Bekhorot</i> 51a): If <b>he wrote to a priest</b> with whom he wants to perform the redemption of his firstborn son: <b>I am obligated to</b> pay <b>you five <i>sela</i>,</b> then <b>he is obligated to give him five <i>sela</i> and his son is not redeemed</b> even once he pays the money. This <i>baraita</i> apparently supports the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
The Gemara answers: <b>It is different there, because he is obligated</b> to give the five <i>sela</i> <b>to him by Torah</b> law in order to fulfill his obligation of redeeming his firstborn son, even without writing a contract. The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so, why did he write</b> the contract at all? The Gemara answers: <b>In order to select for himself a</b> specific <b>priest</b> with whom to perform the redemption of his son.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so, why is his son not redeemed</b> once he pays the money? The Gemara answers: This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ulla. As Ulla said, by Torah law</b> a son <b>is redeemed when</b> the father <b>gives</b> the money. <b>And for what reason did</b> the <b>Sages say: His son is not redeemed?</b> It is a rabbinic <b>decree</b> that was enacted <b>lest</b> people <b>say</b> that <b>one can redeem</b> a firstborn son <b>with documents,</b> i.e., by giving a document allowing the priest to collect a debt from a third party. This is not effective, since the Torah requires that one redeem his son with actual money.
<b>Rava said:</b> The dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish is <b>like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> over the same matter in the following mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 175b): In a case where <b>a guarantor appears after the signatures</b> in <b>contracts,</b> i.e., someone wrote that he is a guarantor for a loan after the contract was signed, the creditor <b>collects</b> only <b>from</b> the <b>unsold property</b> of the guarantor. Since the guarantee is not viewed as though it were written in the document, it is like a loan by oral agreement, which is collected only from unsold property.
<b>An incident came before Rabbi Yishmael, and he said:</b> The creditor <b>collects from unsold property. Ben Nannas said to him: He does not collect</b> from the guarantor at all; <b>not from unsold property, nor from liened property</b> that was sold, since what the guarantor wrote has no legal standing whatsoever.
Rabbi Yishmael <b>said to him: Why?</b> Ben Nannas <b>said to him:</b> If someone <b>was strangling another in the marketplace</b> and demanding money that is owed to him, <b>and a friend</b> of the victim <b>found</b> him <b>and said to</b> the strangler: <b>Leave him</b> alone <b>and I will give you</b> what you are demanding from him, the friend of the victim is <b>exempt</b> from having to make any payment. This is because the creditor <b>did not lend the money based on his trust</b> in the friend of the victim, as the friend promised to repay the loan only after the money had been loaned. The same should apply in the case of the guarantor who comes after the contracts were already signed.
Rava concludes: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan stated</b> his ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b> that the obligation that one accepts upon himself is binding, <b>and Reish Lakish stated</b> his ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>ben Nannas.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>According to</b> the opinion <b>of ben Nannas, everyone agrees</b> that if he wrote in a contract: I owe you one hundred dinars, he is not obligated to pay.

Daf 102b

<b>When they disagree, it is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> stated his ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the simple interpretation of the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael. And Reish Lakish</b> holds that <b>Rabbi Yishmael states</b> his opinion <b>only there,</b> in the case of the guarantor, <b>which relates to an obligation of Torah</b> law, since a guarantor is obligated by Torah law to pay. <b>But here,</b> where the case <b>does not relate</b> to <b>an obligation of Torah</b> law, as the man did not owe any money until he accepted this obligation upon himself, even Rabbi Yishmael would exempt him from paying.
§ The Gemara continues to analyze <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> mentioned earlier: <b>Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> When two families negotiate the terms of marriage for their respective children and one side says to the other: <b>How much do you give your son?</b> And the second side answers: <b>Such and such</b> amount. <b>How much do you give your daughter?</b> And the first side responds: <b>Such and such</b> amount. Then, if the son and daughter <b>arose and performed the betrothal,</b> all of these obligations are <b>acquired</b> and therefore binding. <b>These are</b> among <b>the things that are acquired through words</b> alone, without the need for an additional act of acquisition. The mishna is referring to a document that records such an agreement.
<b>Rava said: Rav’s statement is reasonable in</b> a case of a father <b>whose daughter</b> is <b>a young woman, since</b> the father <b>derives benefit</b> from this betrothal. The money given by the groom for the betrothal, as well as the rights to the bride’s marriage contract, belong to the father of the bride. Consequently, he accepts through verbal agreement alone the obligation to pay the money he specified. <b>However,</b> in the case of <b>a grown woman, where the</b> father <b>does not derive benefit</b> from the betrothal because the rights to the betrothal money and marriage contract belong to the woman herself, <b>no,</b> the father does not become obligated to pay the money he specified through verbal agreement alone.
Rava continues: <b>But by God! Rav said</b> his ruling <b>even</b> with regard to <b>a grown woman, as, if you do not say so,</b> in the case of <b>the father of the groom, what</b> monetary <b>benefit does he derive</b> from the betrothal? <b>Rather,</b> it must be explained that <b>in</b> exchange for <b>that benefit,</b> i.e., <b>that</b> the groom and bride <b>marry each other,</b> the fathers <b>fully transfer the rights</b> to the respective payments <b>to each other.</b>
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Are these matters,</b> i.e., verbal agreements concerning an upcoming marriage, <b>allowed to be written</b> down afterward in a proper contract, <b>or</b> are they <b>not allowed to be written</b> down afterward in a proper contract? Rav Ashi <b>said to him: They are not allowed to be written</b> down.
Ravina <b>raised an objection to</b> this from the mishna: <b>The perspicacious</b> ones <b>would write</b> an explicit stipulation into the agreement: I agree <b>on the condition that I will sustain your daughter for five years</b> only <b>as long as you are with me.</b> This indicates that one may document these verbal agreements. Rav Ashi responded: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term <b>write</b> in this case? It means <b>say.</b>
Ravina continued to ask: <b>Does</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>refer to saying</b> as <b>writing?</b> Rav Ashi replied: <b>Yes. And so we learned</b> in the mishna (83a): <b>One who writes to his wife: I have no legal</b> dealings <b>or involvement in your properties, and Rabbi Ḥiyya taught</b> in explanation, that it means: <b>One who says to his wife.</b> This proves that verbal agreements are sometimes referred to in the Mishna as writing.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the following mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 167b): <b>One writes documents of betrothal and marriage only with the consent of both of them.</b> It may be derived from here that <b>with the consent of both of them, one</b> may <b>write</b> the documents. <b>What, is it not</b> that this mishna is discussing <b>documents of stipulation</b> that specify the agreements accepted by each side before the marriage?
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> the discussion concerns <b>actual betrothal documents.</b> In other words, in a case where a man betroths a woman by giving her a document that states: You are hereby betrothed to me, the document must be written with the consent of both the man and the woman, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinions of <b>Rav Pappa and Rav Sherevya. As it was stated:</b> If the husband <b>wrote</b> a betrothal document <b>for the sake of</b> a specific woman and gave it to her, <b>but</b> he wrote it <b>without her consent, Rabba and Ravina say: She is betrothed</b> to this man. <b>Rav Pappa and Rav Sherevya say: She is not betrothed.</b>
The Gemara suggests further: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof that verbal agreements may be written down, based upon the mishna: If the two husbands <b>died, their daughters are sustained from unsold property, and she,</b> their wife’s daughter, whom they agreed to sustain for five years, <b>is sustained</b> even <b>from liened property</b> that was sold. This is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that her</b> legal status is <b>like</b> that of <b>a creditor,</b> given that they are contractually obligated to pay her. The fact that she is able to repossess liened property indicates that the agreement is recorded in a document.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Here, we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the woman <b>acquired from</b> each husband the right to her daughter’s sustenance, i.e., they performed an act of acquisition and did not suffice with a mere verbal agreement. Consequently, the agreement may be recorded in a document.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that a proper mode of acquisition was employed, then let the husbands’ own <b>daughters also</b> repossess liened properties that were sold. The Gemara answers: The case is such <b>where they acquired</b> the right to receive sustenance <b>for this</b> daughter of the wife, <b>and they did not acquire</b> this right <b>for that</b> daughter, i.e., they did not perform an act of acquisition confirming their obligations to provide sustenance for their own daughters.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> makes it <b>necessary</b> to say that the case is one in which an acquisition was made on behalf of the wife’s daughter and not on behalf of the husbands’ own daughters? The Gemara answers: <b>She,</b> the wife’s daughter from a previous marriage, <b>was present at the time of the transaction</b> when her mother was wed. Consequently, <b>for her the transaction is effective.</b> With regard to the <b>daughters</b> of the husbands, <b>who</b> were born after their parents’ marriage and <b>were not present at the time of the transaction, for them the transaction is not effective.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Are we not</b> also <b>dealing with</b> a situation where the husband’s daughters <b>were present at the time of the transaction? And what are the circumstances</b> that would allow for such a reality? This could occur in a situation <b>such as where</b> each one <b>divorced</b> his wife <b>and then took her back,</b> and they had a daughter from their first marriage.
<b>Rather,</b> the distinction is as follows: <b>She,</b> the wife’s daughter, <b>is not included in the stipulation of the court</b> requiring a husband to support his daughters. Consequently, <b>for her the transaction is effective.</b> However, with regard to the husband’s own <b>daughters, who are included in the stipulation of the court, for them the transaction is not effective.</b>
The Gemara wonders about this: Because they are included in the stipulation of the court <b>they are worse off?</b> On the contrary, since the stipulation of the court demands that they be supported, they should wield more power. <b>Rather, this is the reason</b> that <b>his</b> own <b>daughters</b> do not collect from liened property: <b>Since they are included in the stipulation of the court,</b> and it is therefore the norm for fathers to take care to provide their support, <b>say that</b> their father <b>gave them bundles of money</b> while he was still alive. Due to this concern, they cannot repossess liened property. However, in the case of the wife’s daughter, who is not included in the stipulation of the court, there is no concern that the husband gave her anything prior to his death.
§ We learned in the mishna that <b>the first</b> husband <b>may not say</b> that he will provide his wife’s daughter with support only when she is with him. Rather, he must bring the sustenance to her in the place where her mother lives. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: That is to say</b> that in a case of divorce, a <b>daughter</b> lives <b>with her mother.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> do we know that <b>we are dealing with</b> a case <b>of an adult woman</b> and there is a general guideline that in cases of divorce, a girl lives with her mother? <b>Perhaps we are dealing with</b> a case of <b>a minor girl, and</b> she lives with her mother because of concern for her safety, <b>due to an incident that occurred.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who died and left a minor son to</b> the care of <b>his mother,</b> and <b>the heirs of the father say:</b> The son <b>should grow up with us, and his mother says: My son should grow up with me,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>one leaves</b> the child <b>with his mother, and one does not leave</b> the child <b>with</b> one who is <b>fit to inherit</b> from <b>him,</b> i.e., the father’s heirs. <b>An incident occurred,</b> and the boy lived with his father’s heirs, <b>and they slaughtered him on the eve of Passover.</b> So too, a minor girl is not left in the care of those who are obligated to sustain her and who have a financial interest in her demise.
The Gemara answers: <b>If that is so, let</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> that the husband must bring the sustenance <b>to the place where she,</b> the daughter, is located.

Daf 103a

<b>What</b> is the purpose of emphasizing: <b>To the place where her mother</b> lives? <b>Conclude from here</b> that a <b>daughter</b> lives <b>with</b> her <b>mother;</b> it is <b>no different</b> if she is <b>an adult woman, and</b> it is <b>no different</b> if she is <b>a minor girl.</b>
§ It was taught in the mishna that if two men are obligated to support this girl, <b>both of them may not</b> jointly <b>say</b> that they will be partners in her support. Rather, each one fulfills his obligation independently.
The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain man who rented out a millstone to another for</b> the price of <b>grinding,</b> i.e., the one who rented the millstone was to pay the cost of the rental by grinding whatever the owner needed to be ground. <b>In the end,</b> the owner of the millstone <b>became rich,</b> and <b>he purchased</b> another <b>millstone and a donkey,</b> and he no longer required the services of the renter to grind things for him.
