If the Temple vessels could not be prepared with money consecrated for Temple maintenance, how were they able to use any of these funds for this purpose? <b>Rabbi Abbahu said: The court</b> initially <b>sets a mental stipulation about the</b> money collected: <b>If it is required</b> for Temple maintenance, <b>it is required</b> and is allocated accordingly, <b>and if not, it will be</b> used <b>for the service vessels.</b>
<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The funding for the <b>service vessels</b> of the Temple <b>comes from the collection of the</b> Temple treasury <b>chamber, as it is stated: “The rest of the money”</b> (II Chronicles 24:14). <b>Which money has a remainder? You must say</b> that <b>this</b> is referring to <b>the collection of the chamber.</b> After the money was brought into the chamber, a certain portion of it would be set aside for the requirements of the offerings, while the remainder was used for other purposes.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that <b>the remainder itself</b> was used for the Temple vessels, and the phrase “the rest of the money” does not refer to the funds of which there is a remainder, but to the remainder of the donations left in the chamber after the first collection was removed. The Gemara answers: This is <b>as Rava said</b> elsewhere, that the phrase <b>“the burnt-offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:5), with the definite article, is referring to <b>the first burnt-offering; so too,</b> the term <b>“the money”</b> (II Chronicles 24:14) is referring to <b>the first money,</b> i.e., the money removed from the collection of the chamber.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the following source: The funds for <b>the incense and all communal offerings come from the collection of the</b> Temple treasury <b>chamber.</b> The funds for <b>the golden altar,</b> located inside the Sanctuary and upon which the incense was offered, <b>the frankincense, and the service vessels</b> all <b>come from the leftover</b> money of the funds set aside for <b>the libations.</b>
The funds for the upkeep of <b>the altar of burnt-offerings,</b> which was located outside the Sanctuary and on which most offerings were burned, and for <b>the chambers, and</b> for <b>the</b> various <b>courtyards, come from</b> money <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance.</b> Funds for those matters that are <b>outside the walls of</b> the Temple <b>courtyard come from the remainder of the chambers. And</b> with regard to <b>this we learned: The wall of the city, its towers, and all of the requirements of the city</b> of Jerusalem likewise <b>come from the remainder of the chamber.</b> According to this source, the funds for the sacred vessels came from the leftover money of the funds set aside for the libations, not the collection of the Temple treasury chamber.
The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 6a): <b>What would they do with the leftover</b> funds <b>of the collection</b> of shekels that had not been spent on communal offerings? They would purchase <b>golden plates</b> as a <b>coating for</b> the walls and floor of <b>the Holy of Holies. Rabbi Yishmael says:</b> There were different types of remainders in the Temple, each of which had separate regulations. <b>The leftover produce</b> was used to purchase the <b>repletion [<i>keitz</i>] of the altar,</b> i.e., burnt-offerings sacrificed when the altar would otherwise be idle. <b>The leftover</b> funds <b>of the collection</b> were used <b>to</b> purchase <b>service vessels.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says: The leftover</b> funds <b>of the collection</b> of shekels were used to purchase the animals <b>for the repletion of the altar,</b> as they had originally been collected for offerings. <b>The leftover libations</b> were used <b>to</b> purchase <b>service vessels. Rabbi Ḥanina, the deputy High Priest, says: The leftover libations</b> were used to purchase animals for <b>the repletion of the altar,</b> while <b>the leftover</b> funds <b>of the collection</b> of shekels were used <b>to</b> purchase <b>service vessels.</b> Both <b>this</b> Sage, Rabbi Akiva, <b>and that</b> Sage, Rabbi Ḥanina, <b>did not agree</b> with Rabbi Yishmael’s opinion <b>with regard to</b> the leftover <b>produce.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is this produce? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What would they do with the leftover</b> funds <b>of the collection? They</b> would use it to <b>buy produce at a cheap</b> price <b>and</b> subsequently <b>sell</b> that produce <b>at an expensive</b> price, <b>and the profit</b> earned from this trade would be used <b>for the repletion of the altar. And</b> with regard to <b>this we learned: The leftover</b> funds <b>of produce</b> were used to purchase the animals <b>for the repletion of the altar.</b>
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>what</b> is the reason that both <b>this</b> Sage, Rabbi Akiva, <b>and that</b> Sage, Rabbi Ḥanina, <b>did not agree</b> with Rabbi Yishmael’s opinion <b>with regard to the</b> leftover <b>produce?</b> The Gemara answers: Rabbi Akiva is consistent with his opinion elsewhere, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 6a): <b>What would they do with the leftover remainder of the chamber? They</b> would <b>purchase wine, oil, and fine flour</b> and sell them to those who needed them for their private offerings. <b>And the profit</b> from these sales would go <b>to consecrated</b> property, i.e., to the Temple treasury. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says: One may not generate profit by</b> selling <b>consecrated</b> property, <b>nor</b> may one profit <b>from</b> funds set aside <b>for the poor.</b>
The Gemara explains the reason for Rabbi Akiva’s ruling: <b>What is the reason</b> that one may <b>not</b> use <b>consecrated</b> property to generate a profit? It is because <b>there is no poverty in a place of wealth,</b> i.e., the Temple must always be run in a lavish manner. Therefore, one may not use Temple funds to generate small profits in the manner of paupers. <b>What is the reason</b> that one may <b>not</b> use funds set aside <b>for the poor</b> to make a profit? It is because <b>perhaps one will encounter a poor person and there will be nothing to give him,</b> as all of the money is invested in some business transaction.
§ The Gemara returns to the mishna, which deals with the case of <b>one who went overseas</b> and his wife is demanding sustenance. <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> debated the following issue. <b>Rav said:</b>

Daf 107a

The court <b>apportions sustenance for a married woman,</b> i.e., if a husband went overseas and left behind nothing with which his wife could provide for her sustenance, the court withdraws money from his estate for this purpose. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> The court <b>does not apportion sustenance for a married woman. Shmuel</b> further <b>said: Abba,</b> i.e., Rav, <b>concedes to me</b> that the court does not touch the husband’s estate <b>for the first three months.</b> This is <b>because a person does not leave his house empty,</b> and therefore it is certain that he left something with which his wife can sustain herself at least in the short term.
The Gemara comments: In a case <b>where they heard that</b> the husband <b>died, everyone agrees</b> that the court sustains his wife from his estate. <b>When they disagree</b> it is in a case <b>where they did not hear that he had died</b> abroad. <b>Rav said</b> that the court <b>apportions</b> sustenance for the wife, <b>as</b> his estate is legally <b>mortgaged to her</b> and must provide her with sustenance, <b>and Shmuel said</b> that in this case the court <b>does not apportion</b> sustenance for her.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for Shmuel’s ruling? <b>Rav Zevid said:</b> One can <b>say that he gave her a bundle</b> of money before he departed. <b>Rav Pappa said: We are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps he said to her</b> before his departure: <b>Spend your earnings to sustain yourself,</b> i.e., he renounced his rights to her earnings and in exchange he is no longer required to provide her with support.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> these two explanations? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> in a case where the woman is <b>an adult,</b> and therefore it is possible that he left her money, <b>and</b> the amount she earns is <b>not enough</b> for her needs. According to the opinion of Rav Zevid, one can assume that he gave her money and therefore it is not necessary for the court to allocate her sustenance from his estate, whereas according to the opinion of Rav Pappa, as her earnings are not enough for her sustenance the court apportions more for her from his estate, despite the husband’s possible stipulation.
<b>Alternatively,</b> there is a difference between them in the case of <b>a minor</b> wife, with whom the husband would not have left money, <b>but</b> her earnings are <b>enough</b> for her sustenance. Rav Zevid would claim that the court must provide for her from his estate, as he would not have left her money, whereas Rav Pappa would argue that he might have told her to sustain herself from her own earnings.
§ <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: With regard to <b>one who went overseas and his wife is demanding sustenance, Ḥanan says: She takes an oath at the end, and she does not take an oath at the outset. The sons of High Priests disputed</b> Ḥanan’s opinion <b>and said: She takes an oath</b> both <b>at the outset and at the end.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>They disagree only with regard to an oath; however,</b> with regard to <b>sustenance</b> everyone agrees <b>that</b> the court <b>gives</b> it <b>to her.</b> This apparently contradicts the opinion of Shmuel. The Gemara explains that <b>Shmuel interpreted</b> the mishna in accordance with his opinion as referring to a case <b>when they heard concerning him that he died</b> overseas. In this scenario, everyone agrees that the court provides her with sustenance from the husband’s estate.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who went overseas and his wife is demanding sustenance, the sons of High Priests say: She takes an oath. Ḥanan says: She does not take an oath,</b> i.e., she receives sustenance without having to swear. <b>And if he came and said: I apportioned</b> money <b>for her sustenance</b> and left her with sufficient funds, <b>he is deemed credible</b> and she must return all that she received from his estate through the court. This poses a difficulty for the opinion of Shmuel, who maintains that the court does not supply her with sustenance <i>ab initio</i>.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here, too,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where they heard concerning him that he died</b> abroad. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>said: If he came and said,</b> which indicates that the husband is not dead. The Gemara explains that the <i>baraita</i> means: <b>If he came after the rumor.</b> There was a rumor that he had died, and for this reason the court provided her with sustenance, and later it was determined that the rumor was false.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who went overseas and his wife is demanding sustenance, if he came and said</b> that prior to his departure he told her: <b>Spend your earnings to sustain yourself, he is permitted</b> to act accordingly. <b>If the court went ahead and apportioned</b> sustenance for her, <b>what they apportioned is apportioned,</b> and she is not required to return it. Again, this poses a difficulty for the opinion of Shmuel. The Gemara answers: <b>Here, too,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where they heard concerning him that he died</b> abroad.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who went overseas and his wife is demanding sustenance,</b> the <b>court descends to his property and feeds and provides a livelihood for his wife, but not</b> for <b>his sons and daughters, and</b> they do <b>not</b> give her <b>something else.</b> Once again this presents a difficulty for the opinion of Shmuel.
<b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> This is referring <b>to one who feeds his wife by means of a third party.</b> In this case, even if the husband was available he would not be providing her with her sustenance directly, as he appointed someone else to give her money in accordance with her needs. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, his sons and daughters</b> should <b>also</b> receive this support. The Gemara answers: It is referring to a case <b>where he appointed</b> a third party <b>for this</b> purpose, his wife’s sustenance, <b>but he did not appoint</b> a third party <b>for this</b> purpose, the sustenance of his children. The Gemara asks: If that is correct, <b>why</b> was it stated <b>without qualification?</b> There is no hint in the <i>baraita</i> that the husband differentiated in this manner.
<b>Rather, Rav Pappa said</b> that Shmuel would explain this <i>baraita</i> as referring to a case <b>where she heard that he had died,</b> and she was told this <b>by one witness.</b> Therefore, as far as <b>she</b> is concerned, since this is a case <b>where if she wanted to remarry</b> based <b>on</b> the testimony of that <b>one witness she may marry,</b> as in this situation the Sages permitted her to rely on the account of a single witness so that she not end up a deserted woman, the court <b>also provides her with sustenance,</b> as she may claim her marriage contract based on this testimony.
However, with regard to <b>his sons and daughters,</b> since this is a case <b>where if they wanted to descend to his estate on</b> the basis of the testimony of <b>one witness, they may not descend</b> and take the property, as two witnesses are required for matters of inheritance, the court <b>also does not provide them with sustenance.</b> As far as the children are concerned, there is still insufficient evidence for the death of their father.
Incidentally, the Gemara asks: <b>What is: Something else,</b> mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>? <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> This is a wife’s <b>ornaments,</b> to which she is entitled in addition to her sustenance. <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> It is money for <b>charity.</b> The Gemara comments: According to <b>the one who said</b> that the court does not pay for her <b>ornaments</b> if the husband has gone overseas, <b>all the more so</b>

Daf 107b

he maintains that she does not receive money from his property for <b>charity,</b> as the court does not take donations of charity from one’s property without his knowledge. Conversely, <b>the one who said</b> that the court does not give money for <b>charity</b> would argue: <b>However, they do give her ornaments,</b> as it is assumed <b>that it is not satisfactory for him</b> for his wife <b>to be degraded</b> by a lack of jewelry.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> With regard to <b>a <i>yevama</i>,</b> a woman whose husband died childless and he has a brother [<i>yavam</i>], and who is waiting either to enter into levirate marriage with the <i>yavam</i> or perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, for the <b>first three months</b> after her husband’s death <b>she is sustained from</b> the property of <b>her husband.</b>
<b>From then on,</b> as long as she has not entered into levirate marriage, <b>she is not sustained, neither from</b> the property of <b>her husband nor from</b> that of the <b><i>yavam</i>.</b> If the <i>yavam</i> <b>stood in judgment</b> and the court ruled that he should enter into levirate marriage, <b>and he fled, she is sustained from</b> the property of the <b><i>yavam</i>.</b> This apparently contradicts Shmuel’s ruling, as here the woman is provided with sustenance from the estate of the <i>yavam</i> in his absence, despite the fact that his obligation toward her is less than that of a husband.
The Gemara answers that <b>Shmuel</b> could have <b>said to you: With regard to what</b> need <b>we be concerned</b> in <b>this</b> case? <b>If</b> the concern is <b>due to</b> the possibility that he gave her <b>a bundle</b> of money before his departure, <b>the mind of</b> the <i>yavam</i> <b>is not</b> that <b>close to</b> this woman that he would leave money with her; <b>if</b> the concern is <b>due to her earnings,</b> i.e., that he said to her: Spend your earnings to sustain yourself, <b>she is not</b> yet <b>obligated to</b> give <b>him</b> her earnings.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> With regard to <b>a wife who went with her husband overseas, and she came</b> back <b>and said: My husband died,</b> if <b>she wishes she is sustained</b> from his property, and if <b>she wishes she collects</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract.</b> If she said: <b>My husband divorced me,</b> but she does not present a bill of divorce, <b>she is continually sustained</b> from his property <b>up to the amount of her marriage contract.</b> The reason is that she may collect this money whether or not her claim is believed: If she is still married, she is entitled to her sustenance, and if she is divorced she receives the marriage contract. This once again presents a difficulty for the opinion of Shmuel, as she collects money from her husband’s estate in his absence.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here, too,</b> it is referring to a case where <b>they heard concerning</b> the husband <b>that he died.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And what is different</b> about the sum <b>up to the amount of her marriage contract;</b> why is she given no more than this? If he is dead, she should be allowed to sustain herself from all his property until she weds another. The Gemara answers: The reason is <b>that she is</b> the one who <b>caused</b> the <b>loss to herself.</b> By claiming that she was divorced, she forfeits her right to more sustenance.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: How,</b> i.e., in what case, <b>did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that a minor who <b>refuses</b> her husband <b>does not</b> receive <b>sustenance? You cannot say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>to</b> a young girl <b>who is living under</b> the authority of <b>her husband, as her husband is obligated in her sustenance. Rather,</b> it applies to a case <b>where her husband went overseas,</b> and <b>she borrowed</b> money <b>and sustained</b> herself for a while, and subsequently <b>she arose and refused</b> him. The Gemara infers: The <b>reason</b> is <b>that she refused</b> him, which indicates that if <b>she did not refuse</b> her husband, the court <b>gives</b> her sustenance. This apparently shows that a woman is sustained from her husband’s property when he goes overseas.
The Gemara answers that <b>Shmuel</b> could have <b>said to you: With regard to what</b> need <b>we be concerned here? If</b> the concern is <b>due to</b> the possibility that he left her <b>a bundle</b> of money before his departure, <b>one does not give a bundle</b> of money <b>to a minor. If</b> the concern is <b>due to</b> the possibility that he instructed her to subsist on <b>her earnings,</b> the earnings of <b>a minor</b> are <b>not enough</b> to cover the expenses of her sustenance. In summary, no resolution has been found for the dispute between Rav and Shmuel, notwithstanding the numerous sources cited by the Gemara.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the conclusion that was reached <b>about this</b> dispute? How should this case be treated in practice? <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael, <b>he said: An incident</b> of this kind <b>came before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>in Beit She’arim, and he apportioned sustenance for her.</b> However, a similar incident came <b>before Rabbi Yishmael in Tzippori, and he did not apportion sustenance for her. Rabbi Yoḥanan wondered about this</b> ruling: <b>And what did Rabbi Yishmael see</b> such <b>that he did not apportion sustenance for her?</b> After all, <b>the sons of High Priests and Ḥanan disagreed</b> in the mishna <b>only with regard to</b> whether she is obligated to swear <b>an oath, but</b> as far as <b>sustenance</b> is concerned, they concur that the court <b>gives it to her.</b>
<b>Rav Shemen bar Abba said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>Our Rabbi in Babylonia, Shmuel, already interpreted it</b> as referring to a case where <b>they heard concerning</b> the husband <b>that he died.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him</b> in astonishment: <b>Have you gone that far</b> in your analysis of this case that you were able to resolve this problem?
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael, <b>he said</b> a different version of this discussion: <b>An incident came before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>in Beit She’arim, and he did not apportion sustenance for her;</b> an incident came <b>before Rabbi Yishmael in Tzippori, and he apportioned sustenance for her. Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And what did Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>see</b> such <b>that he did not apportion sustenance for her? As, the sons of High Priests and Ḥanan disagreed only with regard to an oath, but</b> when it comes to <b>sustenance,</b> the court <b>gives it to her. Rav Shemen bar Abba said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>Shmuel in Babylonia already interpreted it</b> as referring to a case where <b>they heard concerning him that he died.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him</b> in astonishment: <b>Have you gone that far</b> in your analysis of this case?
The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, and</b> therefore <b>one apportions sustenance for a married woman</b> whose husband went overseas. In passing, the Gemara mentions other rulings of <i>halakha</i>. <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> that which <b>Rav Huna</b> said that <b>Rav said. As Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: A woman can say to her husband: I will not be sustained</b> by you <b>and</b> in turn <b>I will not work,</b> i.e., you will not keep my earnings. The reason is that this arrangement was enacted by the Sages for the wife’s benefit. Consequently, she can relinquish her rights to her sustenance in this manner.
<b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Zevid with regard to glazed [<i>kunya</i>]</b> vessels. <b>As Rav Zevid said:</b> With regard to <b>these glazed vessels [<i>manei dekunya</i>],</b> i.e., earthenware vessels that are glazed over, the <b>white and black ones are permitted</b> after they have been washed, as the glazing prevents the vessels from absorbing the foods placed inside them. Some earthenware vessels absorb the food and drink that is cooked in them and are therefore rendered forbidden if at any time they contained forbidden food, e.g., wine poured as a libation or leaven on Passover. The white and black vessels are not considered like regular earthenware vessels, which are rendered permanently forbidden.
Conversely, <b>green</b> ones <b>are forbidden,</b> as they absorb from the substances placed inside them. <b>And we said</b> that white and black ones are permitted <b>only if they do not have cracks; however, if they have cracks they are forbidden,</b> as the forbidden food is absorbed by the earthenware through the cracks.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a husband <b>who went overseas, and someone arose and sustained his wife</b> in his absence, and upon the husband’s return the provider demands from him the money he spent on his wife, <b>Ḥanan says:</b> He has <b>lost his money,</b> i.e., the husband is not obligated to repay him, as the provider acted of his own free will and was not instructed to do so by the husband.
<b>The sons of High Priests disagreed</b> with Ḥanan’s opinion <b>and said:</b> The man <b>swears how much he spent</b> on behalf of the woman, <b>and he takes</b> that sum from the husband. <b>Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas said</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with their statement. Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said: Ḥanan spoke well</b> in this case, as this man is like one who <b>placed his money on the horn of a deer</b> in midflight, i.e., he has no reasonable expectation of reimbursement.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Nedarim</i> 33a): With regard to <b>one</b> who is <b>prohibited by a vow</b> from <b>deriving benefit from another,</b>

Daf 108a

the other <b>may contribute his shekel for him,</b> i.e., it is permitted for the second individual to donate the half-shekel from his own money to the Temple on behalf of the first one, who is prohibited by the vow from deriving benefit; <b>and he may repay his debt</b> for him, i.e., if the one prohibited by the vow owes money to a third party, the one from whom he may not derive benefit may pay off that debt on his behalf. <b>And he may return to him his lost object, and in a place where one takes a wage</b> for returning a lost article, <b>the benefit</b> paid for the return of the item <b>goes to</b> the Temple treasury of <b>consecrated</b> property.
The Gemara discusses this mishna: <b>Granted, he may contribute his shekel for him,</b> as <b>he</b> thereby <b>performs a mitzva.</b> The one prohibited by the vow from deriving benefit does not derive any direct benefit from this action, as even if he did not pay the half-shekel, all Jews have a share in the communal offerings brought in the Temple, <b>as we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> performs the <b>collection</b> of money from the chamber with the intention that the ceremony apply to money <b>that is lost, and</b> money <b>that has</b> already <b>been gathered</b> but has not yet been brought to the Temple, <b>and</b> money <b>that will be gathered in the future.</b> This shows that even if one did not give a half-shekel, the communal offerings are nevertheless sacrificed in his name.
<b>And</b> concerning the <i>halakha</i> that <b>he may return to him his lost object, he also performs a mitzva</b> by means of this action. However, with regard to the statement that <b>he may repay his debt</b> for him, this is problematic because it <b>provides a gain for</b> the one prohibited by the vow from deriving benefit; if he did not repay the person’s debt, that person would have to pay it from his own pocket. Consequently, it should be considered as though the one prohibited from deriving benefit received money.
<b>Rav Oshaya said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Ḥanan, who said</b> in the mishna: He has <b>lost his money.</b> In other words, this is referring to a case in which he repays a debt that the other does not really have to repay at all, and therefore he is doing a favor to the creditor, not to the one who is prohibited from deriving benefit.
<b>And Rava said: You</b> can <b>even say</b> that this is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and here we are dealing with</b> a situation where the borrower <b>borrowed</b> money <b>on the condition that he</b> need <b>not pay it back</b> until he chooses to do so. In that case, if the one from whom this borrower may not derive benefit repaid the debt for him, he performed a favor only to the lender, not to the borrower.
The Gemara analyzes these opinions: <b>Granted, Rava did not say</b> his statement in accordance with the explanation <b>of Rav Oshaya, as he establishes</b> the mishna in <i>Nedarim</i> not only in accordance with the view of Ḥanan, but also <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. However, what is the reason</b> that <b>Rav Oshaya did not say</b> that the mishna is referring to a loan that did not have to be repaid, <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rava?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Oshaya</b> could have <b>said to you: Although</b> in this type of loan <b>there is no benefit to</b> the borrower, as he need not repay it within a certain period of time,

Daf 108b

<b>doesn’t he have shame</b> due to his failure to repay the debt? <b>There too,</b> in the case of one prohibited by a vow, <b>he has benefit;</b> namely, the <b>benefit that he is ashamed before him</b> until the loan is repaid.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Admon states</b> a dissenting opinion to that of the Rabbis in <b>seven</b> cases. The mishna elaborates: With regard to <b>one who died and left</b> behind both <b>sons and daughters, when the estate is large the sons inherit</b> the property <b>and the daughters are provided with sustenance</b> from it. <b>And with regard to a small estate,</b> which is insufficient to provide for both the sons and the daughters, <b>the daughters are provided with sustenance and the sons</b> have neither inheritance nor sustenance, and therefore, if they have no other means with which to support themselves, they must <b>go round</b> begging <b>at the doors. Admon says: Because I am a male,</b> will <b>I lose out? Rabban Gamliel said: I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Admon.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to Admon’s statement: Because I am a male will I lose out, the Gemara asks: <b>What is he saying?</b> What is the significance of the fact that one is male? <b>Abaye said</b> that <b>this is what he is saying: Because I am a male and,</b> unlike women, I <b>am fit to engage in Torah</b> study, should <b>I lose out?</b>
<b>Rava said to him:</b> Is that to say that it is <b>one who is engaged in Torah</b> study <b>who inherits,</b> whereas <b>one</b> who is <b>not engaged in Torah</b> study <b>does not inherit?</b> What does the study of Torah have to do with the matter at hand? <b>Rather, Rava said</b> that <b>this is what</b> Admon <b>is saying: Because I am a male,</b> who has a greater right to the property by Torah law, <b>and</b> therefore <b>it is fitting</b> for me <b>to inherit when the estate is large,</b> will <b>I</b> now <b>lose out</b> entirely <b>in</b> a case of <b>a small estate?</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna cites another case involving a dispute between Admon and the Rabbis. With regard to <b>one who claims</b> that <b>another</b> owes him <b>jugs of oil, and</b> the other <b>admits to</b> the claim of <b>pitchers</b> but not the oil, <b>Admon says: Since he made a partial admission to the claim, he takes an oath</b> swearing that he owes only what he has admitted to and no more. <b>And the Rabbis say: The partial admission</b> in this case <b>is not of the same type as the claim,</b> as the claim specified oil and the admission referred to pitchers. <b>Rabban Gamliel said: I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Admon.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> One can <b>conclude from here</b> that according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> if one <b>claimed</b> that another owed him <b>wheat and barley, and</b> the other party partially <b>admitted</b> that the claim was true only with regard <b>to the barley,</b> he is <b>exempt,</b> just as he is exempt in this case when the claim was for jugs of oil and the admission referred only to jugs.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that it is a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion that <b>Rav Naḥman</b> said that <b>Shmuel said. As Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> If one <b>claimed against</b> another that he owed him <b>wheat and barley, and</b> the other <b>admitted to</b> owing <b>one of</b> the types, <b>he is obligated</b> to take an oath, as he partially admitted to the claim.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The mishna is not referring <b>to</b> a case where one claimed that another owed him oil and pitchers. Rather, <b>he claimed</b> that another owed him a certain <b>measure</b> of oil, i.e., an amount of oil that would fill a certain number of jugs, while he did not claim the jugs at all. Consequently, the admission was not of the same type as the claim at all. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what is the rationale</b> for the ruling <b>of Admon</b> that he must take an oath? Clearly, the admission and the claim do not refer to the same objects.
<b>Rather, Rava said: Everyone agrees that</b> in a case <b>where he said to him: I have ten jugfuls of oil in your pit, he is claiming oil from him</b> and <b>he is not claiming pitchers from him</b> at all. In this case, it is clear that admitting to owing pitchers is not a partial admission whatsoever that would lead to an obligation to take an oath. Similarly, if he said to him: <b>I have ten full jugs of oil with you, he is claiming from him</b> both <b>oil and pitchers,</b> and therefore if the other party concedes to owing pitchers, this is a partial admission to the claim and everyone agrees that he must take an oath.
<b>When they disagree</b> in the mishna is in a case <b>where he said to him</b> simply: <b>I have ten jugs of oil with you. Admon says: This expression includes</b> a reference to the <b>pitchers,</b> while <b>the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>this expression does not include</b> a reference to the <b>pitchers.</b>
The Gemara infers: <b>Rather, the reason</b> for the ruling of the Rabbis <b>is</b> specifically <b>that the expression does not include</b> a reference to <b>pitchers,</b> which indicates that if <b>the expression includes</b> a reference to <b>pitchers,</b> one is <b>obligated</b> to take an oath. If so, <b>let us say</b> that <b>this is a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba. As Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said:</b> If one <b>claimed</b> against another that he owed him <b>wheat and barley, and</b> the other <b>admitted to one of</b> the types, <b>he is exempt</b> from an oath.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said:</b> The case of the mishna is not similar to that of wheat and barley, as those two types are not connected to one another. Rather, the case of jugs of oil <b>is</b> more <b>like</b> that of <b>one who claimed</b> that <b>the other</b> owed him <b>a pomegranate in its peel,</b> as the jugs are as necessary for the oil as the peel of a pomegranate protecting its fruit. <b>Ravina strongly objects to this:</b> The comparison between these cases does not bear close scrutiny. <b>A pomegranate without its peel cannot be preserved,</b> and therefore it is obvious that when one claims a pomegranate, he must be referring to the peel as well. By contrast, <b>oil can be preserved without</b> the <b>pitchers,</b> as it can be placed in another receptacle.
<b>Rather, here we are dealing with</b> a case where one <b>said to</b> another: <b>I have ten jugs of oil with you, and the other said to him:</b> With regard to the <b>oil, these matters never occurred;</b> I never borrowed oil from you. Concerning the <b>pitchers as well, you do have five</b> of them with me and these I admit I took from you, <b>but you do not have</b> the other <b>five</b> you claim.
<b>Admon says: This expression includes</b> a reference to <b>pitchers, and since he takes an oath about the pitchers,</b> as he partially admitted to owing them, <b>he takes an oath about the oil as well, by means of an extension</b> of the first oath. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>this expression does not include</b> a reference to the <b>pitchers,</b> and therefore <b>that which</b> the first person <b>claimed from him</b> the second person <b>did not admit to</b> at all, <b>and that which</b> the second person <b>admitted to,</b> the first person <b>had not claimed from him.</b> The second individual denied owing any oil, and as for his partial admission with regard to the pitchers, there was no claim about pitchers at all. Consequently, no oath is required whatsoever.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna states another case involving a ruling of Admon. With regard to one who promises and <b>apportions money for his son-in-law</b> as a dowry, <b>and he went bankrupt,</b> and he now claims that he does not have the money to fulfill his financial obligations,

Daf 109a

the betrothed woman can be left to <b>sit</b> unwed in her father’s house <b>until her head turns white.</b> If the groom does not wish to marry without a dowry he cannot be forced to do so, as the father failed to fulfill his promise. <b>Admon says</b> that <b>she can say: Had I apportioned</b> the money <b>myself</b> and broken my promise, I would agree to <b>sit until my head turns white.</b> However, <b>now that</b> my <b>father</b> was the one who <b>apportioned</b> the dowry, <b>what can I do? Either marry</b> me <b>or release</b> me by a bill of divorce. <b>Rabban Gamliel said: I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Admon.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (13:1) that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said: Admon and the Rabbis did not disagree with regard to one who</b> promises and <b>apportions money for his son-in-law</b> as a dowry <b>and</b> subsequently <b>went bankrupt, that</b> the betrothed woman <b>can say:</b> My <b>father apportioned</b> money <b>for me; what can I do?</b>
<b>With regard to what did they disagree?</b> It is <b>with regard to</b> a case <b>where she apportioned</b> money <b>for herself, as the Rabbis say: Let her sit until her head turns white,</b> as she did not fulfill her promise. However, <b>Admon says</b> that <b>she can say: I thought that</b> my <b>father would give</b> the money <b>for me, and now that</b> my <b>father is not giving</b> the money <b>for me, what can I do? Either marry</b> me <b>or release</b> me. And it is with regard to this case that <b>Rabban Gamliel said: I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Admon,</b> as the betrothed woman has no money of her own, and she was clearly relying on her father to provide the dowry.
§ It is <b>taught: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in the case <b>of an adult</b> woman. <b>However,</b> with regard <b>to a minor</b> girl, the court <b>compels</b> payment. The Gemara asks: <b>Whom do they compel? If we say</b> that they coerce the <b>father</b> to pay, the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have stated the opposite.</b> It is more reasonable to suggest that the father is compelled to pay when an adult woman promises the money, as the promises of an adult are legally valid, whereas a minor is not legally competent and therefore her promises are of no consequence. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> In the case of a minor, the court <b>compels the groom</b> either <b>to give</b> her <b>a bill of divorce</b> or to marry her.
§ <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak ben Elazar said in the name of Ḥizkiyya: Anywhere</b> it is recorded <b>that Rabban Gamliel said: I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Admon, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his</b> opinion. <b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman:</b> Does this halakhic principle apply <b>even</b> when the debate between Admon and the Rabbis is recorded <b>in a <i>baraita</i>?</b> Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: Did we say:</b> Anywhere it is recorded <b>in the Mishna? We said: Anywhere</b> it is recorded <b>that Rabban Gamliel said,</b> which means even in a <i>baraita</i>.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Yirmeya said:</b> With regard to the <b>two statements that Ḥanan said,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> he who ruled <b>similarly to him,</b> i.e., Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai (see 107b); however, with regard to the <b>seven statements that Admon said,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> he who ruled <b>similarly to him,</b> i.e., Rabban Gamliel. The Gemara asks: <b>What is he saying?</b> What does this ruling mean?
<b>If we say</b> that <b>this is what</b> he <b>is saying:</b> With regard to the <b>two statements that Ḥanan said,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>and in accordance with</b> he who ruled <b>similarly to him, and</b> with regard to the <b>seven statements that Admon said,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>and</b> also <b>not in accordance with</b> he who ruled <b>similarly to him, but didn’t Rabbi Yitzḥak ben Elazar say in the name of Ḥizkiyya: Anywhere</b> it is recorded <b>that Rabban Gamliel said: I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Admon,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his</b> opinion.
<b>Rather, this is what</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>is saying:</b> With regard to the <b>two statements that Ḥanan said,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>and is</b> also <b>in accordance with</b> he who ruled <b>similarly to him,</b> i.e., Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai. With regard to the <b>seven statements that Admon said, the <i>halakha</i> is not</b> only <b>in accordance with</b> the ruling of Rabban Gamliel, who ruled <b>similarly to</b> Admon in three of these cases. Rather, <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> Admon’s ruling <b>in all</b> seven cases.
The Gemara questions this interpretation: <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yitzḥak ben Elazar say in the name of Ḥizkiyya: Anywhere</b> it is recorded <b>that Rabban Gamliel said: I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Admon,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his</b> opinion? It may be inferred from here that in those cases concerning which Rabban Gamliel <b>said</b> his statement, <b>yes,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Admon’s ruling, but in those cases where Rabban Gamliel <b>did not say</b> his statement, <b>no,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Admon.
<b>Rather, this is what</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>is saying:</b> With regard to the <b>two statements that Ḥanan said,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>and</b> is also <b>in accordance with</b> he who ruled <b>similarly to him.</b> With regard to the <b>seven statements that Admon said, there are among</b> these rulings <b>those</b> in <b>which</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>and in accordance with</b> he who ruled <b>similarly to him, and there are among</b> these rulings <b>those</b> in <b>which</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>but in accordance with</b> he who ruled <b>similarly to him.</b>
The Gemara explains the above statement. In other words, <b>anywhere</b> it is recorded <b>that Rabban Gamliel said: I see</b> as correct <b>the statement of Admon,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his</b> opinion, whereas in those <b>other</b> cases, where Rabban Gamliel remained silent, indicating that he did not agree with him, the <i>halakha</i> is <b>not</b> in accordance with Admon.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who contests</b> ownership <b>of a field,</b> claiming that a field under the control of someone else actually belongs to him, <b>and</b> the claimant himself <b>is signed as a witness on</b> the bill of sale to that other person, <b>Admon says:</b> His signature does not disprove his claim of ownership of the property, as it is possible that the claimant said to himself: <b>The second</b> person <b>is easier for me,</b> as I can reason with him, <b>but the first</b> owner, who sold the field to the current holder, <b>is more difficult</b> to deal with <b>than him.</b> The claimant might have been afraid to protest against the first one, who is perhaps violent, and therefore he was even willing to sign as a witness to transfer the field to the control of someone more amenable to his ensuing protest.
<b>And the Rabbis say: He</b> has <b>lost his right</b> to contest ownership, as he signed a bill of sale that states that the field belongs to the present holder. If <b>he established</b> that field <b>as a marker for another</b> field, everyone agrees that <b>he</b> has <b>lost his right.</b> In other words, if the claimant wrote a document concerning another field and in that document he listed the first field as a boundary marker and described it as belonging to someone else, even Admon concedes that he has lost his right, as he had no reason to say it belonged to someone else other than his belief this was in fact the case.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Abaye said: They taught</b> this dispute <b>only</b> with regard to <b>a witness</b> who signed on a bill of sale. <b>However, a judge</b> who was contesting the ownership of a field and at the same time sat on a court that certified the bill of sale for that very tract of land <b>has not lost his right.</b> This is <b>as Rabbi Ḥiyya taught: Witnesses do not sign a document unless they have read it,</b> which means that a witness cannot reasonably claim that he is certifying only part of document; it is assumed that he read and is aware of everything it contains.

Daf 109b

<b>However, judges do sign a document even though they have not read it,</b> as they are merely certifying the signatures without relating to the content of the document at all.
§ The mishna taught that if someone <b>established</b> a field <b>as a marker for another</b> field, everyone agrees that he has lost his right to contest its ownership. <b>Abaye said: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> in a case where he stated this in a document unrelated to the field in question, which was written <b>for another</b> person. <b>However,</b> if he established it as a marker <b>for himself,</b> when he was buying a different field owned by the person who is in possession of the contested field, he has <b>not lost his right.</b>
The reason is <b>that</b> the claimant can <b>say: Had I not done this</b> act of writing that the field belongs <b>to him, he would not have sold me this other</b> field. <b>What have you to say</b> against this argument? Will you say that <b>I should have put out a notice</b> and declared in the presence of witnesses that I am forced to write this way in the contract? I was concerned about doing this, as <b>your friend has a friend and your friend’s friend has a friend.</b> In other words, it is hard to keep an announcement of this kind secret, and ultimately my notice would have become public knowledge and would have reached the owner of the field himself, and he would have refused to sell me the other tract of land.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain</b> individual <b>who established</b> a field <b>as a marker for another</b> field, with ownership of the first field ascribed to someone else. Later he <b>contested</b> the ownership of the first field, claiming it as his own, <b>and</b> he subsequently <b>died. And</b> prior to his death he had <b>appointed a steward</b> to manage the properties of his orphans. <b>The steward came before Abaye.</b> Abaye <b>said to him:</b> The deceased <b>established</b> the field <b>as a marker for another, and</b> therefore <b>he has lost his right</b> to contest ownership of the land.
The steward <b>said</b> to Abaye: <b>If the father of</b> these <b>orphans were alive he would have claimed and said: I established one furrow</b> for <b>you.</b> In other words, the marker I established by means of this field was not meant as a reference to the entire field but only to a furrow at the edge of the field. Abaye <b>said to him: You have spoken well, as Rabbi Yoḥanan said: If he claimed and said: I established one furrow</b> for <b>you, he is deemed credible. Go</b> and <b>give him one furrow in any event,</b> as you freely admit that at least one furrow belongs to the one currently in control of the property.
<b>On that</b> particular furrow <b>there was a row of palm trees,</b> which the steward did not want to lose. <b>He said to</b> Abaye: <b>If the father of</b> these <b>orphans were alive he would have claimed and said:</b> I did in fact sell the field to him, but <b>I went back and bought</b> it <b>from him</b> sometime later. Abaye <b>said to him: You have spoken well, as Rabbi Yoḥanan said: If he claimed and said: I went back and bought it from him, he is deemed credible.</b> After the steward won his suit in court, <b>Abaye said: One who</b> wants to <b>appoint a steward should appoint</b> someone <b>like this</b> person, <b>who knows how to look out for the rights of the orphans</b> and how to argue on their behalf.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who went overseas and</b> in the meantime <b>the path</b> leading <b>to his field was lost,</b> e.g., the path he used to reach his land was taken over by the owner of the field through which it passed, so that its exact position is now unknown, <b>Admon says: Let him go</b> to his field <b>by the shortest</b> possible route. <b>And the Rabbis say: Let him buy himself a path</b> from an owner of a neighboring field at whatever price he can, even if it is <b>one hundred dinars [<i>maneh</i>], or let him fly through the air.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis</b> that he is not automatically entitled to a path leading to his field? After all, <b>Admon speaks well,</b> as it was established that he owned a path beforehand. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The mishna is dealing with a case <b>where</b> the field <b>was surrounded on four sides by</b> the property of <b>four different people.</b> Each of the four properties adjoining his field belonged to a different person, each of whom denied that his path cut through his land. Since he is unable to prove his claim with regard to each one of them, he has no choice but to buy himself a new path. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Admon?</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> In a case <b>where</b> there are <b>four</b> owners of fields <b>who come by virtue of four</b> previous owners, <b>and</b> in a case where there are <b>four</b> owners <b>who come by virtue of one</b> previous owner of all four properties, <b>everyone agrees that they</b> may <b>put off</b> the claims of the owner of the field in the middle, as each can say: Your path did not cut through my property. <b>When they disagree</b> is in a case <b>where</b> there is <b>one</b> current owner of four fields <b>who comes by virtue of four</b> previous owners.
Rava elaborates: <b>Admon holds</b> that the claimant can say to the landowner: <b>In any case, I have a path through your</b> property. Although he cannot prove where the path ran, it was certainly within the perimeter of the landowner’s property that borders his own tract of land, and for this reason he selects the shortest route. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that the landowner can say to the man: <b>If you will stay silent,</b> then <b>stay silent</b> and we will compromise; <b>and if not, I will return the document</b> of each field <b>to its</b> previous <b>owner and you will not be able to negotiate with them,</b> as you do not know through which field your path passed.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain</b> man <b>who said to</b> his heirs, in his will: I am leaving <b>a palm tree for my daughter. The orphans went</b> and <b>divided up the property</b> and <b>they did not give</b> the daughter <b>a palm tree</b> at all. <b>Rav Yosef thought to say that this is</b> exactly like the case of <b>the mishna,</b> as each heir can say to her: The tree designated for you is not in my portion but in that of a different heir.
<b>Abaye said to him: Are</b> the cases <b>comparable? There, each and every one</b> of the fields’ owners <b>can put him off,</b> as in fact the path might not have passed through his property, whereas <b>here, the palm tree is in their</b> possession, i.e., they all share the obligation to give her a tree, and each is illegally holding on to a share of it. Abaye adds: <b>What is their remedy? Let them give her a palm tree and go back and divide</b> the inherited property once again <b>from the outset.</b> Since the palm tree will be taken from one of the shares, they must redistribute the estate afresh.
The Gemara relates a similar story: There was <b>a certain</b> man <b>who said to</b> his heirs, in his will: I am leaving <b>a palm tree for my daughter. He died and left behind two halves of palm trees,</b> as there had been two trees he had shared with different business partners. The heirs wished to give the girl these two halves, despite the fact that tending to them would involve considerably more trouble than taking care of a single tree.
<b>Rav Ashi sat and posed a difficulty to</b> the proposal of the heirs. <b>Do people refer to two halves of a palm tree</b> as a whole <b>palm tree or not?</b> If the statement of the dying father can reasonably be interpreted as referring to these two halves she is at a disadvantage, as the burden of proof rests upon the claimant. Alternatively, if this is an unreasonable explanation of his wishes, they must give her a whole tree. Which alternative is correct? <b>Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi: Avimi of Hagronya said as follows in the name of Rava: People do</b> in fact <b>refer to two halves of a palm tree as</b> a whole <b>palm tree.</b> Consequently, the heirs may fulfill their father’s dying wish by giving the girl the two halves they inherited.

Daf 110a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who produces a promissory note against another, and this</b> borrower <b>produced</b> a bill of sale dated after the promissory note that states <b>that</b> the lender <b>sold him a field</b> of his, <b>Admon says</b> that the borrower <b>can say: Were I</b> really <b>indebted to you, you should have collected your</b> loan <b>when you sold me the field,</b> and you would not have needed to sell it. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> This is no proof, as it is possible that <b>this</b> lender <b>was perspicacious, as he sold</b> the borrower <b>the land</b> for a good reason, <b>because now he can take</b> the field as <b>collateral from him</b> in lieu of the outstanding loan.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis?</b> After all, <b>Admon is saying well.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>In a place where</b> people first <b>give money and</b> only <b>afterward they write the bill</b> of sale, <b>everyone agrees that</b> the borrower <b>can say to</b> the lender: <b>You should have collected your</b> debt <b>when you sold me the field,</b> i.e., when you received money from me you should have said that it is not for the field but is repayment of the debt I owed you.
<b>When they disagree is</b> with regard <b>to a place where</b> people first <b>write out the bill</b> of sale <b>and</b> only <b>afterward they give money. Admon holds</b> that the lender <b>should have put out a</b> preemptive <b>declaration,</b> i.e., he should have earlier told witnesses that he is selling the field only so it can be used as collateral, and this transaction should not be taken as an indication that the buyer is not indebted to him. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that the lender may argue: <b>Your friend has a friend and your friend’s friend has a friend,</b> i.e., word of my intention to use the field as collateral would have come back to the borrower and he would not have agreed to the transaction, and that is why I did not issue any declaration.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>two</b> people <b>who</b> each <b>produced a promissory note</b> of a monetary debt <b>against the other, Admon says:</b> The one holding the note with the later date can say to the first: <b>If I owed you</b> money, <b>how</b> is it that <b>you are borrowing from me?</b> You should have sued to collect your debt. This is proof that your document is a forgery. <b>And the Rabbis say: This one collects his promissory note, and that one collects his promissory note.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disputed the case of <b>two</b> people <b>who</b> each <b>produced a promissory note against the other</b> for the same value. <b>Rav Naḥman said: This one collects</b> his debt <b>and that one collects</b> his debt. <b>Rav Sheshet said: Why do I</b> need <b>to shift</b> donkey <b>packs [<i>matrata</i>]</b> from one side to the other? <b>Rather,</b> as each will retain the same sum, let <b>this one stand with his</b> money <b>and</b> let <b>that one stand with his</b> money.
The Gemara analyses this dispute: <b>Everyone</b> agrees that if the field of one of the parties, which served as guarantee for the promissory note, was <b>superior-quality land and</b> the other person also had <b>superior-quality land,</b> or one had <b>intermediate-quality land and</b> the other had <b>intermediate-quality land,</b> or one had <b>inferior-quality land and</b> the other had <b>inferior-quality land,</b> this <b>is certainly</b> considered like <b>shifting</b> donkey <b>packs,</b> i.e., it is an exercise in futility, as there is no reason to exchange their money.
<b>When they disagree</b> is in a case <b>where one has intermediate-quality land and</b> the other <b>one</b> has <b>inferior-quality land. Rav Naḥman holds</b> that <b>this one collects</b> his debt <b>and that one collects</b> his debt, as <b>he holds</b> that <b>one assesses</b> the quality of land <b>on</b> the basis of <b>his own</b> fields, i.e., if the borrower has different types of land, then his best land is classified as superior-quality land, the next best is considered intermediate-quality land, and his worst fields are called inferior-quality land.
Consequently, <b>the owner of inferior-quality land,</b> Reuven, <b>will come and collect</b> his debt from the <b>intermediate-quality land</b> of his debtor, Shimon, in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> that a creditor collects payment from intermediate-quality land. Since Shimon does not have any land that is inferior, Reuven necessarily takes his debt from that land. However, at this stage the land Reuven took from Shimon <b>is</b> considered <b>for him superior-quality land,</b> as all of his other fields are of lower quality than the field he took. <b>And</b> therefore, <b>that</b> other creditor, Shimon, <b>comes</b> to collect his debt from Reuven, <b>and takes from inferior-quality land,</b> as the intermediate-quality land that Reuven took from Shimon is now, relative to Reuven’s other field, classified as superior-quality land. Consequently, each debtor will take different fields from the other, despite the fact that they owe the same sum.
<b>And Rav Sheshet,</b> who <b>said: Why do I</b> need <b>to shift</b> donkey <b>packs, holds</b> that the quality of the land is not assessed differently for each individual borrower. Rather, <b>one assesses</b> the quality of land <b>on</b> the basis of the lands of <b>all people,</b> i.e., there is a standard measure of land quality which applies to everyone. If so, then <b>ultimately, when that</b> second debtor, Shimon, comes to collect from Reuven he will take back his own <b>intermediate-quality land,</b> i.e., the field that Reuven took from him only a short while earlier. Consequently, no purpose is served by going through this process.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman, what did you see that</b> led you to establish that <b>the owner of inferior-quality land</b> will <b>come</b> and collect his debt <b>first,</b> as described above? <b>Let the owner of intermediate-quality land come first and collect inferior-quality land</b> from the other party, as that is all he possesses. In this scenario, the intermediate-quality land in the possession of the one who collected his debt will be classified as high quality, while his inferior-quality field will be considered of intermediate quality. <b>And</b> therefore <b>let</b> the other <b>return and collect</b> the same portion of land that he took from <b>him.</b> Once again, this is an apparently unnecessary exchange.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> only in a case <b>where</b> the owner of the low-quality land happened to <b>precede</b> the other <b>and claim</b> from him first. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Ultimately, when they come to collect</b> their respective debts, <b>they come together,</b> which means that they will pass the same portion of land back and forth.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara provides an alternative explanation: <b>No,</b> this dispute is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where one has superior-quality land and intermediate-quality land, and</b> the other <b>one has</b> only <b>inferior-quality land. One Sage,</b> Rav Naḥman, <b>holds</b> that <b>one assesses</b> the quality of land <b>on</b> the basis of <b>his own</b> fields. Consequently, the owner of the low-quality land stands to gain, as he collects intermediate-quality land from the other and pays low-quality land in return, regardless of the order of the claims. <b>And one Sage,</b> Rav Sheshet, <b>holds</b> that the court <b>appraises</b> the quality of land <b>on</b> the basis of the lands of <b>all people,</b> which means that they will be trading the same plot of land back and forth.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>And the Rabbis say: This one collects</b> his promissory note <b>and that one collects</b> his promissory note. This ruling apparently contradicts the opinion of Rav Sheshet. <b>Rav Naḥman</b> himself <b>interpreted</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Sheshet:</b> This is referring to a situation, <b>for example, where this one borrowed for</b> a period of <b>ten</b> years <b>and that one</b> borrowed <b>for five</b> years. In this case it makes sense to say that each collects as stated in the promissory note in his possession.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If we say</b> that the <b>first</b> one borrowed <b>for ten</b> years <b>and</b> the <b>second for five,</b> is <b>this</b> the case in which <b>Admon would say: If I owed you</b> money, <b>how</b> is it that <b>you are borrowing from me?</b> After all, the due <b>date has not yet arrived</b> for the second person to pay his debt. Perhaps the other creditor needs money to sustain himself for the next five years. <b>Rather, the first</b> one borrowed <b>for five</b> years <b>and the second for ten</b> years.
The Gemara continues to inquire: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> this is referring to a case <b>where</b> the due <b>date</b> of the first promissory note <b>had</b> already <b>arrived</b> when the second loan was issued, <b>what is the rationale for</b> the ruling of <b>the Rabbis?</b> The second person should not have borrowed money from the first, as he should have instead collected payment on the debt owed to him. <b>And if</b> the due <b>date had not</b> yet <b>arrived,</b> the second person clearly cannot demand his money, as the due <b>date had not yet arrived,</b> and perhaps he simply was in need of available money. <b>And</b> if so, <b>what is the rationale for</b> the opinion of <b>Admon?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where he came on</b> exactly <b>that day when the five years</b> of the first loan <b>were completed.</b> The dispute is as follows: <b>One Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>a person will take out a loan</b> even <b>for one day, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Admon, <b>holds</b> that <b>a person will not take out a loan for one day,</b> and therefore he would have waited one day to receive payment of the debt owed to him.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama stated</b> a different answer: <b>Here we are dealing with orphans,</b> i.e., one of the debtors died without leaving any landed properties, <b>as orphans collect</b> debts owed to their father but others <b>do not collect from them</b> the debts their father owed. Consequently, the statement of the Rabbis that each collects based on the document in his possession has practical ramifications. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> that <b>this one collects</b> his promissory note <b>and that one collects</b> his promissory note, whereas according to this interpretation only the orphans collect the debts they are owed. The Gemara answers: The mishna means that <b>this one collects, and that one</b> has the <b>potential to collect but he does not have</b> any land from which he may legally collect his debt.
<b>Rava said:</b> There are <b>two responses to this</b> explanation. <b>One</b> is <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> that <b>this one collects</b> his promissory note <b>and that one collects</b> his promissory note, which indicates that each actually collects what is owed to him, not that one is entitled to collect it but may not do so in practice. <b>And furthermore, let him give land to the orphans and return and collect it from them, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman. As Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> With regard to <b>orphans who collected land in payment of their father’s debt, a creditor may come back and collect it from them.</b> The Gemara comments: This does pose a <b>difficulty</b> for the explanation of Rami bar Ḥama.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And let us establish</b> the mishna as referring to a case where <b>the orphans have inferior-quality land, and he himself,</b> the other creditor, <b>has</b> both <b>superior-quality land and intermediate-quality land. In</b> this scenario <b>the orphans go</b> and <b>collect intermediate-quality land</b> from him, <b>while they give</b> him <b>inferior-quality land</b> in payment of the debt owed to him by their father. The reason is <b>that even if</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>one assesses</b> the quality of land <b>on</b> the basis of the lands of <b>all people,</b> and therefore the other creditor should be able to collect intermediate-quality land from the orphans, there is a principle that <b>one collects</b> a debt <b>from the property of orphans only from inferior-quality land.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>This applies only</b> to a case <b>where</b> the lender <b>has not as yet seized</b> any land from the orphans in payment of his debt. <b>However, where he has seized</b> intermediate-quality land, <b>he has seized</b> that land. Since he is already in possession of a field, it is not taken from him. In these circumstances there is no significance to each party collecting from the other.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Eretz Yisrael is divided into <b>three</b> separate <b>lands</b> with regard <b>to marriage: Judea, Transjordan, and the Galilee.</b> If a man marries a woman in one of these lands he may <b>not remove</b> her <b>from</b> one <b>town to</b> another <b>town</b> in another of these lands or <b>from</b> one <b>city to</b> another <b>city,</b> i.e., he cannot compel her to move to another land. <b>However, in the same land one may remove her from</b> one <b>town to</b> another <b>town</b> or <b>from</b> one <b>city to</b> another <b>city.</b>

Daf 110b

<b>However,</b> even within the same land one may <b>not</b> force his wife to move <b>from a town to a city, nor from a city to a town.</b>
The mishna adds: <b>One may remove</b> his wife <b>from a noxious residence to a pleasant residence,</b> even if it is in another land. <b>However,</b> one may <b>not</b> compel his wife to move <b>from a pleasant residence to a noxious residence. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> One may <b>also not</b> remove her <b>from a noxious residence to a pleasant residence, because a pleasant residence tests</b> the individual, i.e., one accustomed to certain environments can suffer even in more comfortable living quarters.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the statement in the mishna that one may not force one’s spouse to move from a city to a town or from a town to a city, the Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> one may not remove her <b>from a city to a town, as all items are</b> readily <b>available in a city,</b> whereas <b>in a town all items are not</b> as <b>available,</b> and therefore the wife can argue that living in a town is inconvenient for her. <b>However, what is the reason</b> that the husband cannot compel her to move <b>from a town to the city?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>This supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina, as Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that dwelling in cities is difficult? As it is stated: “And the people blessed all the men who willingly offered themselves to dwell in Jerusalem”</b> (Nehemiah 11:2). This shows that living in a city is difficult, due to the noise and the general hubbub of an urban area.
§ The mishna taught: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says</b> that a pleasant residence tests the individual. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term <b>tests</b> in this context? The Gemara explains: <b>This is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, as Shmuel said: A change in</b> one’s eating <b>habits [<i>veset</i>]</b> or in one’s place of residence is <b>the start of intestinal disease.</b> Similarly, <b>it is written in <i>Sefer Ben Sira</i>: All the days of the poor are terrible. And</b> yet <b>there are <i>Shabbatot</i> and Festivals,</b> when even the poor eat well. Once again, the Gemara answers: <b>This is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, as Shmuel said: A change in</b> one’s eating <b>habits</b> or in one’s place of residence is <b>the start of intestinal disease,</b> and as a result the poor suffer even from a change for the better.
Since the Gemara quoted from <i>Sefer Ben Sira</i>, it cites the rest of the passage concerning the terrible days of the poor. <b>Ben Sira says: Even the nights</b> of the poor are bad. <b>His roof is at the low point of the roofs,</b> i.e., his residence is at the lowest point in the city, <b>and his vineyard is at the mountain peaks,</b> at the highest point of the slope, which means that <b>the rain of roofs</b> washes down <b>to his roof, and the soil of his vineyard to</b> other <b>vineyards,</b> i.e., the rain washes away the soil in his vineyard and carries it away to the vineyards below.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All</b> may force their family <b>to ascend to Eretz Yisrael,</b> i.e., one may compel his family and household to immigrate to Eretz Yisrael, <b>but all may not remove</b> others from Eretz Yisrael, as one may not coerce one’s family to leave. Likewise, <b>all</b> may force their family <b>to ascend to Jerusalem, and all may not,</b> i.e., no one may, <b>remove</b> them from Jerusalem. <b>Both men and women</b> may force the other spouse to immigrate to Eretz Yisrael or to move to Jerusalem.
The mishna lists other halakhic distinctions between various geographic locations: If one <b>married a woman in Eretz Yisrael and divorced her in Eretz Yisrael,</b> and the currency of the sum in the marriage contract was not specified, <b>he gives her</b> the sum of her marriage contract <b>in the currency of Eretz Yisrael.</b> If one <b>married a woman in Eretz Yisrael and divorced her in Cappadocia,</b> where the currency holds greater value, <b>he gives her the currency of Eretz Yisrael.</b> If one <b>married a woman in Cappadocia and divorced her in Eretz Yisrael, he</b> likewise <b>gives her the currency of Eretz Yisrael. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: He gives her the currency of Cappadocia.</b> Everyone agrees that if one <b>married a woman in Cappadocia and divorced her in Cappadocia, he gives her the currency of Cappadocia.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna stated: <b>All</b> can force the members of their family <b>to ascend.</b> The Gemara asks: This inclusive phrase serves <b>to include what</b> case? The Gemara answers: It comes <b>to include slaves,</b> i.e., Hebrew slaves as well may be coerced to immigrate to Eretz Yisrael with their master’s family against their will.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to the one</b> whose text of the mishna <b>expressly teaches</b> the case of <b>slaves,</b> this phrase comes <b>to include what</b> case? As stated later in the Gemara, there are some editions of the mishna that state that this <i>halakha</i> applies equally to men, women, and slaves. The Gemara answers: It comes <b>to include</b> one who moves <b>from a pleasant residence to a noxious residence,</b> i.e., one may coerce his family to ascend to Eretz Yisrael even from a good residence abroad to an inferior one in Eretz Yisrael.
§ The mishna further taught: <b>But all may not remove</b> others. Once again the Gemara asks: This phrase comes <b>to include what</b> case? The Gemara answers: It comes <b>to include a</b> Canaanite <b>slave who ran away</b> from his master and came <b>from outside Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>to Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>as we say to</b> the master: <b>Sell</b> your slave <b>here,</b> in Eretz Yisrael, <b>and</b> then you may <b>go</b> and return abroad, but you may not take the slave abroad with you, <b>due to</b> the mitzva of <b>settling Eretz Yisrael.</b>
§ The mishna taught: <b>All</b> may force others <b>to ascend to Jerusalem.</b> The Gemara asks once again: This phrase comes <b>to include what</b> case? The Gemara answers: It comes <b>to include</b> a move <b>from a pleasant residence</b> elsewhere in Eretz Yisrael <b>to a noxious residence</b> in Jerusalem.
§ The mishna taught: <b>And all may not remove</b> them from Jerusalem. The Gemara asks: This phrase comes <b>to include what</b> case? The Gemara answers: It comes <b>to include even</b> a move <b>from a noxious residence to a pleasant residence.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>And since</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>taught: But one may not remove, in the first clause, he also taught: But one may not remove, in the latter clause,</b> despite the fact that this <i>halakha</i> could have been inferred from the first clause.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> If the husband <b>says</b> that he wishes <b>to ascend,</b> i.e., to immigrate to Eretz Yisrael, <b>and</b> his wife <b>says that</b> she does <b>not</b> wish <b>to ascend, one forces her to ascend. And if</b> she will <b>not</b> do so, as she resists all attempts to force her to make the move, <b>she is divorced without</b> receiving her <b>marriage contract,</b> i.e., she forfeits her rights to the benefits outlined in the marriage contract. If <b>she says</b> that she wishes <b>to ascend</b> to Eretz Yisrael <b>and he says that</b> he does <b>not</b> wish <b>to ascend, one forces him to ascend. And if</b> he does <b>not</b> wish to immigrate, <b>he must divorce</b> her <b>and give</b> her <b>the marriage contract.</b>
If <b>she says</b> that she wishes <b>to leave</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>and he says that</b> he does <b>not</b> wish <b>to leave, one forces her not to leave. And if</b> she does <b>not</b> wish to stay in Eretz Yisrael and resists all attempts to force her to stay, <b>she is divorced without</b> receiving her <b>marriage contract.</b> If <b>he says</b> that he wishes <b>to leave</b> Eretz Yisrael <b>and she says that</b> she does <b>not</b> wish <b>to leave, one forces him not to leave. And if</b> he does <b>not</b> wish to stay in Eretz Yisrael, <b>he must divorce</b> her <b>and give</b> her <b>the marriage contract.</b>
§ The mishna taught that if <b>one married a woman</b> in Eretz Yisrael and divorced her in Cappadocia, he must pay her the marriage contract in the currency of Eretz Yisrael. The same is true if he married her in Cappadocia and divorced her in Eretz Yisrael. The Gemara asks: <b>This matter itself is difficult,</b> i.e., there is an internal contradiction in the rulings provided by the mishna.
The Gemara elaborates: The mishna first <b>teaches</b> that if one <b>married a woman in Eretz Yisrael and divorced her in Cappadocia, he gives her the currency of Eretz Yisrael. Apparently, one follows</b> the customs of the place of the <b>lien,</b> i.e., he pays with the currency of the location of the wedding, where the obligation came into force. Now, <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: If one <b>married a woman in Cappadocia and divorced her in Eretz Yisrael, he</b> likewise <b>gives her currency of Eretz Yisrael. Apparently, one follows</b> the place of <b>the collection</b> of the money.
<b>Rabba said:</b> The Sages <b>taught here</b> one <b>of the leniencies</b> that apply to <b>a marriage contract.</b> The leniency is that the husband pays with the less valuable currency of Eretz Yisrael in both cases, whether the wedding or the divorce occurred there. This is because the <i>tanna</i> of this mishna <b>holds</b> that <b>a marriage contract</b> applies <b>by rabbinic</b> law.
§ The mishna taught that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says</b> that if one married a woman in Cappadocia and divorced her in Eretz Yisrael, <b>he</b> pays her the marriage contract <b>in the currency of Cappadocia.</b> The Gemara explains that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <b>holds</b> that <b>a marriage contract</b> applies <b>by Torah</b> law, which means that its debt must be paid according to its highest possible value. Consequently, one follows the place in which the obligation was formed, which is the <i>halakha</i> for all deeds and contracts, and there is no room for leniency in this matter.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to <b>one who produces a promissory note against another,</b> if <b>Babylonia is written in it, he pays it with the currency of Babylonia;</b> if <b>Eretz Yisrael is written in it, he pays it with currency of Eretz Yisrael.</b> In a case where it is <b>written without specification</b> as to where the document was written, if <b>he produced it in Babylonia he pays it with the currency of Babylonia</b> and if <b>he produced it in Eretz Yisrael he pays it with currency of Eretz Yisrael.</b> If the note <b>mentions money without specification</b> of what type of coins are to be used, <b>the borrower may pay it with any</b> type of coin <b>he likes,</b> even the smallest denomination available. However, <b>this is not</b> the case with regard <b>to a marriage contract.</b>
The Gemara asks: With regard to this last statement, that this is not the case with regard to a marriage contract: <b>To which</b> part of the <i>baraita</i> is this referring? <b>Rav Mesharshiyya said:</b> It is referring back to <b>the first clause,</b> that if the promissory note mentions Babylonia one pays with Babylonian currency. This indicates that one invariably pays based on the place where the document was written. The <i>tanna</i> adds that this principle does not apply to a marriage contract, as one pays based on the place where a marriage contract was written only if this would lead to a leniency, as explained above (Rid). This ruling comes <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who said</b> that that <b>a marriage contract</b> applies <b>by Torah</b> law and must always be paid in the currency of the place in which the obligation was first formed.
§ The Gemara continues to analyze the <i>baraita</i>, which teaches: If the note <b>mentions money [<i>kesef</i> ] without specification, the borrower may pay it with any</b> type of coin <b>he likes.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> can’t one <b>say</b> that perhaps the document was not speaking of coins but of silver [<i>kesef</i> ] <b>strips? Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case in <b>which it is written in</b> the document: <b>Coins,</b> although it does not specify which ones. The Gemara further asks: <b>And</b> can’t one <b>say</b> that one may pay off the debt with <b><i>perutot</i>,</b> a small denomination? <b>Rav Pappa said: People do not</b> ordinarily <b>mint <i>perutot</i> of silver,</b> as they reserve silver for larger denominations.
